{"listeriosis": [{"archive_id": "7647773", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand (02): (BP) fatal, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7647773", "date": "2020-08-05 15:34:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (02): (BAY OF PLENTY) FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Aug 2020 9:12 AM NZST\nSource: Sunlive [edited]\nhttps://sunlive.co.nz/news/249184-fourth-listeria-case-confirmed-tauranga.html\n\n\nA 4th case of [listeriosis] has been confirmed in Tauranga [Bay of Plenty]. Medical Officer of Health for Toi Te Ora Public Health, Dr Phil Shoemack says the 4th case was confirmed last week [week of 27 Aug 2020].\n\nThis follows on from 3 confirmed cases last month [June 2020]. Sadly, one of the people with the disease died, prompting a warning from medical professionals. All three of those who were affected last month [July 2020] were between 70 and 90 years old. The person who died already had a terminal condition, Medical Officer of Health Neil de Wet said at the time.\n\nHe said it was possible that the cases were linked, as it's unusual to see 3 cases in 2 weeks. Following confirmation of a 4th case last week, Dr Phil Shoemack says they are continuing to work with MPI [Ministry for Primary Industries] to locate a common source of each case. 'As yet, we have not managed to confirm whether there is a common source, such as a particular food.' He says the latest case did require hospitalisation, and the person has now been discharged.\n\nMPI compliance director Gary Orr says they are looking to see if there is a common food connection. 'Any case of [listeriosis] is a worry for us, particularly if there is a link to food ... If it is shown to have a link to food then we will move very quickly to take that risk food out of the system or alert the public.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tauranga is a western coastal city in the Bay of Plenty region and the 5th most populous city of New Zealand, with an urban population of 135 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tauranga). The Bay of Plenty is a region of New Zealand, situated around a bight of the same name in the northern coast of the North Island, stretching 260 km (about 161 mi) from the Coromandel Peninsula in the west to Cape Runaway in the east (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Plenty). A HealthMap/ProMED map of New Zealand can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5630 and a map showing the location of Tauranga at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Tauranga,+New+Zealand.\n\nThe news report above describes a 4th case of listeriosis in the city of Tauranga, in the Bay of Plenty region. About 2 weeks ago ProMED posted a report of 3 cases of listeriosis, aged in their late 70s to 90s, that were reported between 12 and 20 Jul 2020 (Listeriosis - New Zealand: (BP) fatal 20200727.7614443). All 3 were hospitalized and one with a previously diagnosed terminal condition had died.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a Gram-positive, facultative, intracellular, foodborne pathogen that causes listeriosis, which can be fatal, particularly in elderly populations, people with weakened immune systems, and newborns.\n\nConfirmation of a cluster of cases is based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue). A food history from patients in the cluster will then attempt to identify a possible common source. Isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, if found in the suspected food, can then undergo WGS to confirm if the suspected food is the common source.\n\nFood items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold-cut meats that do not require further cooking before eating, refrigerated pates or meat spreads, unpasteurized (raw) milk and dairy products, such as soft cheeses, and raw fruits and vegetables (such as sprouts). Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease.\n\nApparently the investigation of this outbreak is ongoing and no results are available as yet. ProMED would appreciate more information on this outbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "If it is shown to have a link to food then we will move very quickly to take that risk food out of the system or alert the public.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tauranga is a western coastal city in the Bay of Plenty region and the 5th most populous city of New Zealand, with an urban population of 135 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tauranga). ' Source: Sunlive [edited]\nhttps://sunlive.co.nz/news/249184-fourth-listeria-case-confirmed-tauranga.html\n\n\nA 4th case of [listeriosis] has been confirmed in Tauranga [Bay of Plenty]. \n\nMPI compliance director Gary Orr says they are looking to see if there is a common food connection. ' Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. \n\nThis follows on from 3 confirmed cases last month [June 2020].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-26 00:00:00", "2020-06-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2020-07-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tauranga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Runaway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7614443", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand: (BP) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7614443", "date": "2020-07-27 08:17:47", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: (BAY OF PLENTY) FATAL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2020\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2020/07/listeria-cases-prompt-warning-in-new-zealand/\n\n\nAuthorities in New Zealand are looking into 3 recent _Listeria_ cases to see if they are linked and to find a source of the infections.\n\nWhile investigations are underway to find the vehicle of infection for the reported cases in Tauranga, a city in the Bay of Plenty region, officials cautioned that often a source cannot be identified for individual cases.\n\nThe 3 cases, aged in their late 70s to 90s, were notified to Toi Te Ora Public Health between [12 and 20 Jul 2020]. All 3 were hospitalized and one person with a previously diagnosed terminal condition has died.\n\nToi Te Ora Public Health and the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) reminded the public of recommended food safety measures to reduce risk from _Listeria_.\n\n'Our investigations include determining what the cases may have eaten in order to identify any common risk factors or food that may be the source of infection,' said Dr Neil de Wet, medical officer of health for Toi Te Ora Public Health. MPI compliance director Gary Orr said that if there was a link identified between cases and the food supply chain, immediate action would be taken to ensure public safety.\n\nPeople at risk of more serious illness from _Listeria_ include pregnant women and their unborn babies, newborn babies, those with weakened immune systems, and elderly people, especially if they have poor health. The Bay of Plenty typically sees 1 to 5 cases each year.\n\nMPI advised people in an at-risk group to avoid uncooked, smoked or ready-to-eat fish or seafood, including oysters, prawns, sashimi, or sushi; pat\u00e9, hummus, and tahini-based dips and spreads; cold pre-cooked chicken; processed meats and chilled pre-cooked meats including chicken, salami, and other fermented or dried sausages; pre-prepared, pre-packed, or stored salads including fruit salads and coleslaws; raw milk and any food containing unpasteurized milk; soft-serve ice creams and soft, semi-soft, or surface-ripened soft cheese such as brie, camembert, feta, ricotta, or Roquefort.\n\nListeriosis is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. Symptoms include fever, muscle pain, septicemia (blood poisoning), and meningitis. The incubation period is usually one to 2 weeks but can vary between a few and 70 days.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Bay of Plenty is a region of New Zealand, situated around a bight of the same name in the northern coast of the North Island, stretching 260 km (about 161 mi) from the Coromandel Peninsula in the west to Cape Runaway in the east (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Plenty). Tauranga is a western coastal city in the Bay of Plenty region and the 5th most populous city of New Zealand, with an urban population of 135 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tauranga). A HealthMap/ProMED map of New Zealand can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5630 and a map showing the location of Tauranga at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Tauranga,+New+Zealand.\n\nThe news report above describes 3 people with listeriosis, aged in their late 70s to 90s, in the city of Tauranga, in the Bay of Plenty region, between 12 and 20 Jul 2020. All 3 were hospitalized and one with a previously diagnosed terminal condition died.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a Gram-positive, facultative, intracellular, foodborne pathogen that causes listeriosis, which can be fatal, particularly in elderly populations, people with weakened immune systems, and newborns.\n\nConfirmation of a cluster of cases is based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue). A food history from patients in the cluster will then attempt to identify a possible common source. Isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, if found in the suspected food, can then undergo WGS to confirm if the suspected food is the common source.\n\nFood items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold-cut meats that do not require further cooking before eating, refrigerated pates or meat spreads, unpasteurized (raw) milk and dairy products, such as soft cheeses, and raw fruits and vegetables (such as sprouts). Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nMPI advised people in an at-risk group to avoid uncooked, smoked or ready-to-eat fish or seafood, including oysters, prawns, sashimi, or sushi; pat\u00e9, hummus, and tahini-based dips and spreads; cold pre-cooked chicken; processed meats and chilled pre-cooked meats including chicken, salami, and other fermented or dried sausages; pre-prepared, pre-packed, or stored salads including fruit salads and coleslaws; raw milk and any food containing unpasteurized milk; soft-serve ice creams and soft, semi-soft, or surface-ripened soft cheese such as brie, camembert, feta, ricotta, or Roquefort. Food items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold-cut meats that do not require further cooking before eating, refrigerated pates or meat spreads, unpasteurized (raw) milk and dairy products, such as soft cheeses, and raw fruits and vegetables (such as sprouts). The news report above describes 3 people with listeriosis, aged in their late 70s to 90s, in the city of Tauranga, in the Bay of Plenty region, between 12 and 20 Jul 2020. Isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, if found in the suspected food, can then undergo WGS to confirm if the suspected food is the common source. The 3 cases, aged in their late 70s to 90s, were notified to Toi Te Ora Public Health between [12 and 20 Jul 2020]. MPI compliance director Gary Orr said that if there was a link identified between cases and the food supply chain, immediate action would be taken to ensure public safety. Date: Fri 24 Jul 2020\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tauranga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Runaway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8190625", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA : queso fresco cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8190625", "date": "2021-02-14 18:13:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: QUESO FRESCO CHEESE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2021\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/hispanic-soft-cheese-02-21/details.html\n\n\nCDC, public health, and regulatory officials in several states, and the FDA are collecting different types of data to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections.\n\nEpidemiologic data show that Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be making people sick. A specific type or brand of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheese has not yet been identified.\n\nAs of 11 Feb 2021, 7 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 4 states. Illnesses started on dates ranging from 20 Oct 2020, to 22 Jan 2021, with 6 recent illnesses in 2021.\n\nState / Number of Sick People\n------------------------------\nConnecticut / 1\nMaryland / 4\nNew York / 1\nVirginia / 1\n------------------------\nTotal / 7\n\nThe true number of sick people in an outbreak is likely higher than the number reported, and the outbreak may not be limited to the states with known illnesses. This is because some people recover without medical care and are not tested for _Listeria_. In addition, recent illnesses may not yet be reported as it usually takes 2 to 4 weeks to determine whether a sick person is part of an outbreak.\n\nSick people range in age from 45 to 75 years, with a median age of 61. Six people are Hispanic, and 43% are female. All 7 people have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nState and local public health officials are interviewing people about the foods they ate in the month before they got sick. Of the 4 people interviewed, 3 reported eating at least one type of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses, and all 3 reported eating queso fresco. Public health officials are continuing to interview sick people to try to identify a specific type or brand of cheese.\n\nPublic health investigators are using the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that may be part of this outbreak. CDC PulseNet manages a national database of DNA fingerprints of bacteria that cause foodborne illnesses. DNA fingerprinting is performed on bacteria using a method called whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS showed that bacteria from sick people's samples are closely related genetically. This means that people in this outbreak likely got sick from the same food.\n\nState officials are testing samples of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses that they collected from stores where sick people report purchasing cheeses from.\n\nCDC is advising people at higher risk for severe Listeria illness to not eat Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses (like queso fresco) until we learn more and to contact their healthcare provider right away if they have any symptoms of severe Listeria illness after eating Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hispanic style fresh, soft cheese often called queso fresco ('fresh cheese') is a classical vehicle for listeriosis. This bacterium, a Gram positive bacillus, is psychrotrophic, that is, it can grow at refrigerator temperatures and, therefore, can become an issue for refrigerated foods such as cheese, fresh cut fruit, and cold cuts. Infection with _L. monocytogenes_ can be asymptomatic but diarrhea can occur. However, in those with defects in cellular immunity, such as from chemotherapy or in organ transplant recipients, the gastrointestinal infection (which can be asymptomatic) can cause bacteremia and meningitis. Infection can also occur during pregnancy and may cause fetal loss. The elderly are also at higher risk of clinically overt listeriosis.\n\nThe following article highlights risk factors for _Listeria_ growth in queso fresco cheese:\n\nThomas M, Tiwari R, Mishra A: Predictive model of _Listeria monocytogenes_ growth in queso fresco. J Food Prot 2019;82:2071-2079.\n\nAbstract\n------\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a hardy, psychrotrophic pathogen that has been linked to several cheese-related outbreaks in the United States, including a recent outbreak in which a fresh cheese (queso fresco) was implicated. The purpose of this study was to develop primary, secondary, and tertiary predictive models for the growth of _L. monocytogenes_ in queso fresco and to validate these models using nonisothermal time and temperature profiles. A mixture of five strains of _L. monocytogenes_ was used to inoculate pasteurized whole milk to prepare queso fresco. 10 grams of each fresh cheese sample was vacuum packaged and stored at 4, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 C. From samples at each storage temperature, subsamples were removed at various times and diluted in 0.1% peptone water, and bacteria were enumerated on _Listeria_ selective agar. Growth data from each temperature were fitted using the Baranyi model as the primary model and the Ratkowsky model as the secondary model. Models were then validated using nonisothermal conditions. The Baranyi model was fitted to the isothermal growth data with acceptable goodness of fit statistics (R2 = 0.928; root mean square error = 0.317). The Ratkowsky square root model was fitted to the specific growth rates at different temperatures (R2 = 0.975). The tertiary model developed from these models was validated using the growth data with 2 nonisothermal time and temperature profiles (4 to 20 C for 19 days and 15 to 30 C for 11 days). Data for these 2 profiles were compared with the model prediction using an acceptable prediction zone analysis; over 70% of the growth observations were within the acceptable prediction zone (between -1.0 and 0.5 log CFU/g). The model developed in this study will be useful for estimating the growth of _L. monocytogenes_ in queso fresco. These predictions will help in estimation of the risk of listeriosis from queso fresco under extended storage and temperature abuse conditions. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "\n\nCDC is advising people at higher risk for severe Listeria illness to not eat Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses (like queso fresco) until we learn more and to contact their healthcare provider right away if they have any symptoms of severe Listeria illness after eating Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses.\n\n--\n \n\nThe following article highlights risk factors for _Listeria_ growth in queso fresco cheese:\n\nThomas M, Tiwari R, Mishra A: Predictive model of _Listeria monocytogenes_ growth in queso fresco. \nConnecticut / 1\nMaryland / 4\nNew York / 1\nVirginia / 1\n------------------------ A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nTotal / 7\n\nThe true number of sick people in an outbreak is likely higher than the number reported, and the outbreak may not be limited to the states with known illnesses. ------\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a hardy, psychrotrophic pathogen that has been linked to several cheese-related outbreaks in the United States, including a recent outbreak in which a fresh cheese (queso fresco) was implicated. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hispanic style fresh, soft cheese often called queso fresco ('fresh cheese') is a classical vehicle for listeriosis. Of the 4 people interviewed, 3 reported eating at least one type of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses, and all 3 reported eating queso fresco. \n\nEpidemiologic data show that Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be making people sick. State officials are testing samples of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses that they collected from stores where sick people report purchasing cheeses from. The tertiary model developed from these models was validated using the growth data with 2 nonisothermal time and temperature profiles (4 to 20 C for 19 days and 15 to 30 C for 11 days). The purpose of this study was to develop primary, secondary, and tertiary predictive models for the growth of _L. monocytogenes_ in queso fresco and to validate these models using nonisothermal time and temperature profiles. 10 grams of each fresh cheese sample was vacuum packaged and stored at 4, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 C. From samples at each storage temperature, subsamples were removed at various times and diluted in 0.1% peptone water, and bacteria were enumerated on _Listeria_ selective agar. Source: CDC [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/hispanic-soft-cheese-02-21/details.html\n\n\nCDC, public health, and regulatory officials in several states, and the FDA are collecting different types of data to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections. Growth data from each temperature were fitted using the Baranyi model as the primary model and the Ratkowsky model as the secondary model. \n\nState / Number of Sick People\n------------------------------ As of 11 Feb 2021, 7 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 4 states. \n\nState and local public health officials are interviewing people about the foods they ate in the month before they got sick. LISTERIOSIS - USA: QUESO FRESCO CHEESE\n The model developed in this study will be useful for estimating the growth of _L. monocytogenes_ in queso fresco. In addition, recent illnesses may not yet be reported as it usually takes 2 to 4 weeks to determine whether a sick person is part of an outbreak. Communicated by:\nProMED\n< LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106] The Baranyi model was fitted to the isothermal growth data with acceptable goodness of fit statistics (R2 = 0.928; root mean square error = 0.317).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2061-03-26 00:00:00", "2020-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7567091", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (03): (Netherlands) fatal, smoked trout, recall, WGS", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7567091", "date": "2020-07-12 15:34:29", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (03): (NETHERLANDS) FATAL, SMOKED TROUT, RECALL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Jul 2020\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2020/07/fatal-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-trout-in-the-netherlands/\n\n\nAt least 2 people have died in a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to chilled smoked trout fillets in the Netherlands.\n\nAll 6 sick people have been hospitalized, and 2 died from their infections. Another person has died, but no information about the cause of death was given.\n\nPatients became ill between the beginning of February and mid-June [2020]. Their age range is 42 to 85 years old with a median of 78 years old.\n\nThe outbreak was reported by the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) and the Wageningen Food Safety Research (WFSR) institute, who jointly monitor clustering of _Listeria_ isolates from patients and foods, when only 3 people were affected.\n\nAs part of listeriosis reporting, several fish consumption questions are usually asked. This information is currently available for 5 of the outbreak patients. They all ate fish, while 4 of them stated smoked fish, and one explicitly mentioned trout.\n\nIn the 3rd week of June [2020], 4 products were recalled: smoked trout fillets from Vis Marine, Albert Heijn and 2 fish items from Bond Seafood. Shelf life dates ranged from 20 Jun to 5 Jul 2020. An NVWA spokesman said it was not clear which of the products have caused illness, and all were made by the same production process.\n\nThe NVWA was notified that 3 food isolates and 3 patient isolates formed a cluster, based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) analyses. 'Following this notification, the outbreak investigation pointed toward a single production process as the source for this outbreak. It was concluded that the safety of products produced by this process could not be guaranteed, leading to the recall,' the NVWA spokesman told Food Safety News. Furthermore, steps have been taken by the producer to remove possible sources of contamination. As all involved food business operators have voluntarily taken all expected actions, no measures towards them were taken by the NVWA. As the recall was initiated on 19 Jun [2020], and given the potentially long incubation time for _Listeria_ [infection], we cannot exclude that more cases related to this outbreak will be identified.'\n\nThe Vis Marine 125-gram product was sold at Boon, Boni, Coop, Hoogvliet, Jan Linders, Nettorama, Plus, Poiesz, Spar and Vomar stores. Two products from Bond Seafood were sold at Jumbo Supermarkten, and the AH trout fillet was available for purchase at Albert Heijn stores.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes a cluster of 6 listeriosis cases in the Netherlands, at least 2 of which were fatal, linked to chilled smoked trout fillets. Whole genome sequencing on 3 of the patients' isolates matched that of 3 food isolates. All the smoked trout fillet products were recalled, since all were said to be made by 'the same production process.' Refrigerated, ready-to-eat, smoked fish is a classic food item responsible for listeriosis outbreaks. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNetherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe outbreak was reported by the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) and the Wageningen Food Safety Research (WFSR) institute, who jointly monitor clustering of _Listeria_ isolates from patients and foods, when only 3 people were affected. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes a cluster of 6 listeriosis cases in the Netherlands, at least 2 of which were fatal, linked to chilled smoked trout fillets. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (03): (NETHERLANDS) FATAL, SMOKED TROUT, RECALL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING\n*********************************************************************************************\n \n\nThe NVWA was notified that 3 food isolates and 3 patient isolates formed a cluster, based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) analyses. ' In the 3rd week of June [2020], 4 products were recalled: smoked trout fillets from Vis Marine, Albert Heijn and 2 fish items from Bond Seafood. At least 2 people have died in a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to chilled smoked trout fillets in the Netherlands. Whole genome sequencing on 3 of the patients' isolates matched that of 3 food isolates. All the smoked trout fillet products were recalled, since all were said to be made by 'the same production process.' They all ate fish, while 4 of them stated smoked fish, and one explicitly mentioned trout. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2020-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vomar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7893399", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): fatal, deli-sliced meats susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7893399", "date": "2020-10-27 14:32:40", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): FATAL, DELI-SLICED MEATS SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 25 Oct 2020 09:40 AM EDT\nSource: Bradenton Herald [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.bradenton.com/living/food-drink/article246703296.html\n\n\n_Listeria_ is a bacterium that can cause food-borne illness, known as listeriosis. It can grow in foods such as uncooked meats, vegetables, soft cheeses, and unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe current foodborne illness outbreak is listeriosis, according to the Centers for Disease Control, and has killed 1 person in Florida.\n\nIf more infections are coming falls outside the CDC's current knowledge. Here's what Friday's [23 Oct 2020] update from the CDC [https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/delimeat-10-20/index.html] says the agency does know:\n\nHow many cases are there and where are they? This is either a small outbreak or an outbreak tracked early, as there have been 10 cases so far -- 7 in Massachusetts, 2 in New York, and 2 in Florida. All required hospitalization.\n\nWhat's the food cause? The CDC says after interviewing 9 ill people; 'all reported eating Italian-style meats, such as salami, mortadella, and prosciutto. They reported purchasing prepackaged deli meats and meats sliced at deli counters at various locations.'\n\nBut a single store, brand, or manufacturer hasn't been identified.\n\n[Byline: David J Neal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An abridged CDC report referenced in the news report above follows:\n\n[Multistate] outbreak of _Listeria_ infections linked to deli meats: Investigation notice, posted 23 Oct 2020; https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/delimeat-10-20/index.html\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA-FSIS) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to deli meats.\n\nLatest outbreak information\n---------------------------\nAt a glance\nReported cases: 10\nStates: 3\nHospitalizations: 10\nDeaths: 1\n\n'10 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria_ have been reported from Florida, Massachusetts, and New York. All 10 ill people were hospitalized. One death has been reported from Florida. Epidemiologic evidence shows that deli meat is a likely source of this outbreak. In interviews with 9 ill people, all reported eating Italian-style meats, such as salami, mortadella, and prosciutto. They reported purchasing prepackaged deli meats and meats sliced at deli counters at various locations. A specific type of deli meat and common supplier have not yet been identified.'\n\nIn the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the _Listeria_ Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nFood items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products such as, smoked salmon, sushi, and cold cut meats, that do not require further cooking before eating. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease.\n\nPeople at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis, which include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems, should avoid eating food potentially contaminated with _Listeria_.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as the common source. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An abridged CDC report referenced in the news report above follows:\n\n[Multistate] outbreak of _Listeria_ infections linked to deli meats: Investigation notice, posted 23 Oct 2020; https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/delimeat-10-20/index.html\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- \n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as the common source. \nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA-FSIS) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to deli meats. 10\nDeaths: 1\n\n'10 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria_ have been reported from Florida, Massachusetts, and New York. The advisory was directed specifically to local and tribal health departments, hospitals, clinics, other facilities and any other healthcare providers. The advisory was not issued to the public as the outbreak is not believed to be linked to any products currently on the market.\n\nThe advisory notes that Minnesota experiences approximately 8 cases of listeriosis (invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ disease) per year. Recently, 2 seemingly separate cases of listeriosis, one a previously healthy teenager and the other, a person over the age of 60 years-old, have been confirmed in the state of Minnesota.\n\nAfter further investigation, the cases of listeriosis were found to have zero allele differences in an entire genome sequence, indicating that they share a common strain of _Listeria_. After extensive questioning, officials discovered that both ill persons had eaten at China Buffet restaurant in Alexandria on [15 Feb 2020], before falling ill.\n\nUpon investigating China Buffet, no fault has been found with their food safety procedures. Officials believe that the _Listeria_ contamination may be the fault of a preceding supplier instead. China Buffet's transactions are being tracked and each possible location investigated in order to pinpoint the source of the outbreak.\n\nHealth care providers and facilities were given the advisory in an effort to spread awareness for the detection of any future cases. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, and confusion. People at a higher risk for listeriosis infection include pregnant women and their infants, elderly, and any other immunocompromised persons.\n\nIf the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak of Minnesota is found to be linked to a public supplier of grocery stores or markets, the public will be immediately notified through the Food and Drug [Administration] (FDA).\n\n[Byline: Tony Coveny]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two individuals were found to be infected with _Listeria monocytogenes_, both of which had identical genotypes, suggesting a common source for their infections. Both individuals had eaten at an Asian restaurant in Alexandria, Minnesota on 15 Feb 2020, before falling ill, but we are not told what type of food both individuals ate in common.\n\nAlexandria is a city with a population of 11 070 as of the 2010 census (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandria,_Minnesota). Alexandria is near Interstate 94. A map showing the location of Alexandria can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Alexandria,+MN+56308.\n\nIn the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or produ cts of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing. In the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or produ cts of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing. LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (MINNESOTA) RESTAURANT, ADVISORY\n********************************************************\n Both individuals had eaten at an Asian restaurant in Alexandria, Minnesota on 15 Feb 2020, before falling ill, but we are not told what type of food both individuals ate in common.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2020-02-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alexandria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7562954", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (02): Finland, MLST 6, whole genome sequencing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7562954", "date": "2020-07-11 13:59:20", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): FINLAND, MULTILOCUS SEQUENCE TYPE 6, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING\n***************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2020\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2020/07/finland-searches-for-source-of-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nAuthorities in Finland are investigating a _Listeria_ outbreak that has affected 8 people. All patients have been hospitalized, but no deaths have been recorded. The age range of those sick is 60 to 93 years old, 5 are female, and they live in different parts of the country.\n\nRuska Rimhanen-Finne, a veterinary epidemiologist at the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL), said all illnesses occurred within a month in May and June [2020].\n\n'At the moment, we have several listeriosis clusters under investigation, but the others are long-term clusters with cases within several years,' she told Food Safety News. 'We encourage the local authorities to interview the patients as soon and thoroughly as possible by using an online questionnaire that is readable at THL in real-time. We compare the interviews in order to find common exposures. We also encourage the local authorities to go through foods in patients' homes and test risky foods for _Listeria_. The Finnish Food Authority (Ruokavirasto) types _Listeria_ strains from foods that have been tested in April and May [2020] in order to find similar strains as in patients. We also check if we can use patients' purchase information to find common exposures.'\n\nThe multilocus sequence typing (MLST) 6 cluster is being investigated with the help of whole genome sequencing. The THL is not aware of similar cases in other countries.\n\nFinland has between 40 and 90 listeriosis cases annually. Listeriosis is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. Symptoms include fever, muscle pain, septicemia (blood poisoning) and meningitis. The incubation period is usually 1 to 2 weeks but can vary between a few and 70 days. The elderly population, pregnant women, newborn infants and people with weak immune systems are more susceptible to infections.\n\nHigh-risk foods include pre-packed sandwiches, deli and ready-to-eat meat products such as cooked, cured and/or fermented meats and sausages, soft cheeses and cold smoked fishery products.\n\nBetween March and May [2020], 4 suspected foodborne outbreaks were reported in the country, compared with an average of 18 in previous years, according to the THL.\n\nThe agency believes this is because of the coronavirus pandemic and associated limitations and recommendations. When hands are washed and food prepared for smaller groups, there are fewer epidemics. Suspected pathogens in the 4 outbreaks were _Campylobacter_, _Yersinia_, and norovirus.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes a cluster of 8 listeriosis cases in Finland. The cluster was apparently identified on the basis of multilocus sequence typing of the isolated pathogens. The patients were hospitalized, but none died. The patients lived in different parts of the country.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a gram-positive, facultative, intracellular, foodborne pathogen that causes listeriosis, which can be fatal, particularly in elderly populations, pregnant women, and newborns.\n\nConfirmation of a clusters of cases is based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue). The isolates from the 8 patients are now undergoing WGS. A food history from patients in the cluster will then attempt to identify a possible common source. Isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, if found in the suspected food, can then undergo WGS to confirm if the suspected food is the common source.\n\nFood items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold-cut meats that do not require further cooking before eating, refrigerated pates or meat spreads, unpasteurized (raw) milk and dairy products, such as soft cheeses, and raw fruits and vegetables (such as sprouts). Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease.\n\nPeople at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis, which include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems, should avoid eating food potentially contaminated with _Listeria_.\n\nFinland is an EU country bordered by Sweden to the west, Russia to the east, and Norway to the north (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finland). A map showing the location of Finland can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Finland. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nFinland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/118]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Food items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_ include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold-cut meats that do not require further cooking before eating, refrigerated pates or meat spreads, unpasteurized (raw) milk and dairy products, such as soft cheeses, and raw fruits and vegetables (such as sprouts). \n\nPeople at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis, which include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems, should avoid eating food potentially contaminated with _Listeria_. \n\nHigh-risk foods include pre-packed sandwiches, deli and ready-to-eat meat products such as cooked, cured and/or fermented meats and sausages, soft cheeses and cold smoked fishery products. \n\nConfirmation of a clusters of cases is based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue). \n\n'At the moment, we have several listeriosis clusters under investigation, but the others are long-term clusters with cases within several years,' she told Food Safety News. ' \n\nBetween March and May [2020], 4 suspected foodborne outbreaks were reported in the country, compared with an average of 18 in previous years, according to the THL. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): FINLAND, MULTILOCUS SEQUENCE TYPE 6, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING\n***************************************************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news report describes a cluster of 8 listeriosis cases in Finland. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2020-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "https://www.google.com/maps/place/finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7085372", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, enoki mushrooms, 2016-2019, recall, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7085372", "date": "2020-03-13 11:53:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, ENOKI MUSHROOMS, 2017-2019, RECALL, ALERT\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Mar 2020\nSource: CDC, Listeria (Listeriosis), Outbreaks, Food Safety Alert [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/enoki-mushrooms-03-20/index.html\n\n\nRecall and advice for consumers, food service operators, and retailers\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAt a glance:\nReported cases: 36\nStates: 17\nHospitalizations: 30\nDeaths: 4\nRecall: Yes\n-----------------\n\nRecall information\n------------------\n- On 9 Mar 2020, Sun Hong Foods, Inc. recalled enoki mushrooms because they may be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria.\n- Enoki mushrooms are white, with long stems and small caps.\n- Enoki mushrooms from Sun Hong Foods were sold in 7.05 oz / 200 g clear plastic packaging with a green label.\n- 'Product of Korea' is labeled on the front of the packaging, and 'Sun Hong Foods, Inc.' is labeled on the back of the packaging underneath the bar code. These products can also be identified by the UPC code: 7 426852 625810.\n- This investigation is ongoing to determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness.\n\nAdvice to consumers, food service operators, and retailers\n----------------------------------------------------------\n- Do not eat, serve, or sell any recalled enoki mushrooms distributed by Sun Hong Foods, Inc.\n- Check your refrigerator for recalled enoki mushrooms. Return them to the purchase location or throw them away.\n- Do not eat any food made with recalled enoki mushrooms, even if some was consumed and no one became sick.\n- Wash and sanitize any surfaces and containers that may have come in contact with the recalled enoki mushrooms. Listeria can survive in refrigerated temperatures and can easily spread to other foods and surfaces.\n* Follow the 5 steps to clean your refrigerator at [https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html]:\n* Wash surfaces with hot, soapy water.\n* Wash containers with hot, soapy water or clean in the dishwasher.\n- Call your healthcare provider if you have consumed recalled enoki mushrooms and are experiencing symptoms of _Listeria_ infection.\n\nUntil we learn more about the source and distribution of the enoki mushrooms, CDC advises that people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infections -- pregnant women, adults ages 65 or older, and people with weakened immune systems, such as people with cancer or on dialysis -- avoid eating any enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea'.\n- At home, check your refrigerator for enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea'.\n- If you have them, don't eat them and throw them out.\n- If you have them, wash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators where they were stored. Follow these fiv5e steps to clean your refrigerator [https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html].\n- When you buy, order, or eat out, check with stores and restaurants that they do not use enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea'.\n- If they don't know where their enoki mushrooms are from, don't buy or order the product.\n- Call your healthcare provider if you have consumed enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' and are experiencing symptoms of Listeria infection.\n\nLatest outbreak information\n---------------------------\n- 36 people infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 17 states.\n- Illnesses started on dates ranging from [23 Nov 2016] to [13 Dec 2019].\n- 30 hospitalizations have been reported. 4 deaths have been reported from California, Hawaii, and New Jersey.\n- 6 pregnancy-associated cases have been reported, of which 2 resulted in fetal loss.\n- Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' are the likely source of this outbreak.\n- On [9 Mar 2020], Sun Hong Foods, Inc. recalled enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' because they may be contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ bacteria.\n- This investigation is ongoing to determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\nInvestigation details: [10 Mar 2020]\n------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _L. monocytogenes_ infections linked to enoki mushrooms.\n\nPublic health investigators are using the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that may be part of this outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA fingerprinting is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using a standardized laboratory and data analysis method called whole genome sequencing (WGS). CDC PulseNet manages a national database of these sequences that are used to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives investigators detailed information about the bacteria causing illness. In this investigation, WGS showed that bacteria isolated from ill people were closely related genetically. This means that people in this outbreak are more likely to share a common source of infection.\n\nAs of [9 Mar 2020], 36 people infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 17 states. A list of the states and the number of cases in each can be found on the Map of Reported Cases page [available at the source URL above].\n\n_Listeria_ samples from ill people were collected from [23 Nov 2016] to [13 Dec 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 to 97 years, with a median age of 67. Fifty-eight percent of ill people are female. Of 32 ill people with information available, 30 hospitalizations have been reported. 4 deaths have been reported from California, Hawaii, and New Jersey. 6 cases are pregnancy-associated and 2 resulted in fetal loss.\n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' are the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local public health officials interviewed ill people about the foods they ate in the month before they became ill. 12 out of 22 (55%) reported eating mushrooms, including enoki, portobello, white, button, cremini, wood ear, maitake, and oyster.\n\nMichigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development collected mushrooms for testing from a grocery store where an ill person purchased enoki mushrooms. 2 samples of enoki mushrooms yielded the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_. These mushrooms are labeled as 'Product of Korea' and were distributed by Sun Hong Foods, Inc. Additional product testing is ongoing in California.\n\nOn [9 Mar 2020], Sun Hong Foods, Inc. recalled enoki mushrooms (UPC 7 426852 625810) labeled as 'Product of Korea'. Consumers, food service operators, and retailers should not eat, serve, or sell recalled enoki mushrooms. Enoki mushrooms distributed by Sun Hong Foods, Inc. do not account for all illnesses in this outbreak. FDA is working to identify the source of the enoki mushrooms distributed by Sun Hong Foods, Inc. and determine if other distributors received the same enoki mushrooms.\n\nCDC is concerned that enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' may be contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ and are advising people at higher risk -- pregnant women, adults ages 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems -- to avoid eating any enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea', until investigators determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness.\n\nCDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "\n\nCDC is concerned that enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' may be contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ and are advising people at higher risk -- pregnant women, adults ages 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems -- to avoid eating any enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea', until investigators determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness. \n\nUntil we learn more about the source and distribution of the enoki mushrooms, CDC advises that people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infections -- pregnant women, adults ages 65 or older, and people with weakened immune systems, such as people with cancer or on dialysis -- avoid eating any enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea'. FDA is working to identify the source of the enoki mushrooms distributed by Sun Hong Foods, Inc. and determine if other distributors received the same enoki mushrooms. \n- Call your healthcare provider if you have consumed enoki mushrooms labeled as 'Product of Korea' and are experiencing symptoms of Listeria infection. On [9 Mar 2020], Sun Hong Foods, Inc. recalled enoki mushrooms (UPC 7 426852 625810) labeled as 'Product of Korea'. \n- 'Product of Korea' is labeled on the front of the packaging, and 'Sun Hong Foods, Inc.' is labeled on the back of the packaging underneath the bar code.
