As of [9 Mar 2020], 36 people infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 17 states. \n\nState and local public health officials interviewed ill people about the foods they ate in the month before they became ill. \n- Illnesses started on dates ranging from [23 Nov 2016] to [13 Dec 2019]. \n- 30 hospitalizations have been reported. Investigation details: [10 Mar 2020]\n------------------------------------ * Follow the 5 steps to clean your refrigerator at [https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html]:\n If they don't know where their enoki mushrooms are from, don't buy or order the product.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8199068", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): queso fresco cheese susp, awaiting WGS, recall, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8199068", "date": "2021-02-18 17:56:53", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): QUESO FRESCO CHEESE SUSPECTED, AWAITING WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCING, RECALL, ALERT\n******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Feb 2021\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2021/02/fda-warns-against-specific-brand-of-cheese-in-listeria-outbreak-investigation/\n\n\nFederal officials have identified at least one brand of cheese of interest in their investigation of an outbreak of _Listeria_ infections. The FDA is warning that consumers, restaurants, and retailers should not eat, sell, or serve El Abuelito brand queso fresco cheese.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration [FDA] has been working on the outbreak investigation with agencies in several states. This evening [Wed 17 Feb 2021], the FDA announced that the Connecticut Department of Public Health collected product samples of El Abuelito-brand Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses from a store where an outbreak patient bought cheeses.\n\n'Sample analysis showed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in samples of El Abuelito Queso Fresco sold in 10-ounce packages, marked as Lot A027 with an expiration date of 26 Feb 2021,' according to the FDA's outbreak update. 'Samples are currently undergoing whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis to determine if the _Listeria monocytogenes_ found in these samples is a match to the outbreak strain. At this time, there is not enough evidence to determine if this outbreak is linked to El Abuelito Queso Fresco.\n\n'FDA and state partners are working with the firm to recall the affected lot and to determine if additional products should be recalled. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available.'\n\nAlthough the FDA is stopping short of saying there is a concrete link to the El Abuelito cheese, it is warning consumers to not eat it. The agency also warns that other soft, Hispanic-style cheese may be implicated in the multi-state outbreak.\n\n'Consumers, restaurants, and retailers should not eat, sell, or serve El Abuelito Queso Fresco cheese until more information is known,' FDA warns. 'If you are at higher risk for severe _Listeria_ illness -- if you are pregnant, aged 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system due to certain medical conditions or treatments -- do not eat any Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses, including El Abuelito-brand queso fresco cheese, until we identify which cheeses are making people sick in this outbreak.'\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that 7 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported in Connecticut, Maryland, New York, and Virginia.\n\nAll 7 patients have required hospitalization. Six of the 7 ill people are Hispanic. Of the 4 people interviewed, 3 reported eating at least one type of Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses, and each of the 3 reported eating queso fresco.\n\n[Byline: Coral Beach]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A particular brand of queso fresco cheese is suspected as a source for the multistate outbreak of listeriosis involving 4 cases in Maryland, and one case each in New York, Connecticut, and Virginia (ProMED post Listeriosis - USA: queso fresco cheese, archive number 20210214.8190625). Linkage of this cheese to the outbreak awaits whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis to determine if the _Listeria monocytogenes_ found in the cheese samples matches the WGS of the outbreak strain isolated from the patients.\n\nQueso fresco ('fresh cheese'), Hispanic-style soft, unaged white cheese, is made by curdling milk; it can be made with either pasteurized or unpasteurized (raw) milk. It is considered safe when made with pasteurized milk, but multiple types of soft cheeses have been implicated in listeriosis outbreaks, with most outbreaks linked to Latin-style soft cheese (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6004860/).\n\nCheeses made from unpasteurized milk can be sold within US states that permit sale of raw dairy products. However, the US FDA prohibits interstate commerce of fresh, unaged (uncured) cheeses made from unpasteurized milk. FDA regulations do permit interstate distribution of raw milk cheeses, if aged (cured) for more than 60 days at a temperature of not less than 35 deg F [1.7 deg C], because aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA). However, aging raw milk cheese for 60 days may not totally ensure safety when _L. monocytogenes_ is introduced as a post-processing contaminant (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18724749).\n\nIn the US, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases of listeriosis based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole-genome sequencing. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html).\n\nWhen PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the _Listeria_ case report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nFood items likely to be contaminated with _Listeria_, in addition to soft cheeses, include ready-to-eat refrigerated meat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon, sushi, and cold cut meats. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease.\n\nPeople at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis, which include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems, should avoid eating food potentially contaminated with _Listeria_.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food-monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as the common source. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "If you are at higher risk for severe _Listeria_ illness -- if you are pregnant, aged 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system due to certain medical conditions or treatments -- do not eat any Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses, including El Abuelito-brand queso fresco cheese, until we identify which cheeses are making people sick in this outbreak.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A particular brand of queso fresco cheese is suspected as a source for the multistate outbreak of listeriosis involving 4 cases in Maryland, and one case each in New York, Connecticut, and Virginia (ProMED post Listeriosis - USA: queso fresco cheese, archive number 20210214.8190625). \n\nQueso fresco ('fresh cheese'), Hispanic-style soft, unaged white cheese, is made by curdling milk; it can be made with either pasteurized or unpasteurized (raw) milk. Linkage of this cheese to the outbreak awaits whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis to determine if the _Listeria monocytogenes_ found in the cheese samples matches the WGS of the outbreak strain isolated from the patients. \n\nWhen PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the _Listeria_ case report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. \n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food-monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as the common source. \n\nIn the US, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases of listeriosis based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole-genome sequencing. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Sample analysis showed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in samples of El Abuelito Queso Fresco sold in 10-ounce packages, marked as Lot A027 with an expiration date of 26 Feb 2021,' according to the FDA's outbreak update. ' This evening [Wed 17 Feb 2021], the FDA announced that the Connecticut Department of Public Health collected product samples of El Abuelito-brand Hispanic-style fresh and soft cheeses from a store where an outbreak patient bought cheeses. FDA regulations do permit interstate distribution of raw milk cheeses, if aged (cured) for more than 60 days at a temperature of not less than 35 deg F [1.7 deg C], because aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA). It is considered safe when made with pasteurized milk, but multiple types of soft cheeses have been implicated in listeriosis outbreaks, with most outbreaks linked to Latin-style soft cheese (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6004860/).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7333682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe: Switzerland, fatal, cheese, susp, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7333682", "date": "2020-05-14 12:31:23", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE: SWITZERLAND, FATAL, CHEESE, SUSPECTED, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 May 2020\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2020/05/hospital-listeria-cases-linked-to-cheese-in-switzerland/\n\n\nA total of 4 patients have been infected by _Listeria_ and one has died after eating potentially contaminated cheese at a hospital in Switzerland.\n\nDuring an internal check, Kaeserei Vogel AG, based in Steinerberg, found _Listeria_ in semi-hard cheese and at its production site. The company issued a recall and informed its buyers to remove the products from shelves. One of the buyers is a supplier to the Centre Hospitalier du Valais Romand (CHVR). This supplier told the CHVR purchasing manager on [30 Apr 2020] about the problem. He instructed the immediate withdrawal of implicated cheeses. The last delivery was [8 Apr 2020], but it has not been ruled out that previous lots were also contaminated.\n\nFrom [30 Mar to 2 Apr 2020], a diagnosis of invasive listeriosis infection was made in 4 CHVR patients who could have contracted illness from eating these cheeses during their hospital stays. According to information from meal cards, the infected patients did consume cheese during their hospitalization but it is not possible to be certain that it was the cheeses in question. 3 of the people have recovered but one person with underlying health conditions has died.\n\nKaeserei Vogel informed the Federal Food Safety and Veterinary Office (FSVO) in Switzerland about the contamination.\n\nFSVO, also known by its French acronym OSAV, Italian name USAV, and under the German name BLV, told people not to consume the products concerned by the recall as they may pose a health hazard.\n\nMore than 20 items including sheep and goat cheese, brie, and organic cheese sold across Switzerland have been recalled by the company. Cheeses can be identified as they have number CH-5707 on the packaging. Distribution also includes Belgium and Germany, according to the Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF) portal.\n\nDenner, a supermarket in Switzerland, has recalled all expiration dates of 'Denner Fromage de montagne de la Suisse centrale' because of detection of _Listeria_ at the site of the dairy producer.\n\nMigros, another retailer in the country, recalled all batches of 5 cheese products sold at different stores because of the problem.\n\nFood contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_ may not look or smell spoiled but can still cause serious and sometimes life-threatening infections. Anyone who has eaten any of the recalled products and developed symptoms of _Listeria_ infection should seek medical treatment and tell their doctors about the possible _Listeria_ exposure.\n\nAlso, anyone who has eaten any of the recalled product should monitor themselves for symptoms during the coming weeks because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop.\n\nSymptoms of _Listeria_ infection can include vomiting, nausea, persistent fever, muscle aches, severe headache, and neck stiffness. Specific laboratory tests are required to diagnose _Listeria_ infections, which can mimic other illnesses.\n\nPregnant women, the elderly, young children, and people such as cancer patients who have weakened immune systems are particularly at risk of serious illnesses, life-threatening infections and other complications. Although infected pregnant women may experience only mild, flu-like symptoms, their infections can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn or even stillbirth.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news article above reports that a cheese manufacturer, Kaserei Vogel AG, based in Steinerberg, a town in central Switzerland, found _Listeria_ in semi-hard cheese and at its production site. One of their buyers was the Sion Hospital (part of the Centre Hospitalier du Valais Romand). The city of Sion (population 35 000 residents) is the capital of the canton of Valais, in southwestern Switzerland (https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sion,+Switzerland). From 30 Mar to 2 May 2020, 4 patients were infected by _Listeria_ and 1 died after eating potentially contaminated cheese during their hospital stays. More than 20 items including sheep and goat cheese, brie, and organic cheese are sold in Switzerland and identified by number CH-5707 on the packaging. Distribution also included Belgium and Germany.\n\nWe are not told if any of the implicated cheeses were made from raw milk or the aging process for these cheeses. Typically, semi-hard cheeses are aged anywhere between one and six months depending on type. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) rule requires cheese made from unpasteurized milk to age for a minimum of 60 days before sale. Disease-causing pathogens are thought not to survive the acidifying process of aging for more than the 2-month aging process (https://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/is-the-60-day-rule-still-valid-for-raw-milk-cheese/). Of course, even if made from pasteurized milk, the cheese could have become contaminated with _Listeria_ as a result of environmental contamination at the production site.\n\nThe news report says that it is not known if the cheese eaten by the 4 patients was the _Listeria_-contaminated cheese produced by Kaeserei Vogel AG. However, if genotyping is done and genotypes of the 4 patient isolates match each other, then a common source outbreak can be established, and if the genotype of the outbreak strain matches that of the cheese isolate, then the source can be established. More information on this outbreak from knowledgeable sources would be appreciated. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Switzerland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8061]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news article above reports that a cheese manufacturer, Kaserei Vogel AG, based in Steinerberg, a town in central Switzerland, found _Listeria_ in semi-hard cheese and at its production site. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMore than 20 items including sheep and goat cheese, brie, and organic cheese sold across Switzerland have been recalled by the company. \n\nThe news report says that it is not known if the cheese eaten by the 4 patients was the _Listeria_-contaminated cheese produced by Kaeserei Vogel AG. A total of 4 patients have been infected by _Listeria_ and one has died after eating potentially contaminated cheese at a hospital in Switzerland.\n\n From 30 Mar to 2 May 2020, 4 patients were infected by _Listeria_ and 1 died after eating potentially contaminated cheese during their hospital stays. More than 20 items including sheep and goat cheese, brie, and organic cheese are sold in Switzerland and identified by number CH-5707 on the packaging. \n\nMigros, another retailer in the country, recalled all batches of 5 cheese products sold at different stores because of the problem. \n\nPregnant women, the elderly, young children, and people such as cancer patients who have weakened immune systems are particularly at risk of serious illnesses, life-threatening infections and other complications. From [30 Mar to 2 Apr 2020], a diagnosis of invasive listeriosis infection was made in 4 CHVR patients who could have contracted illness from eating these cheeses during their hospital stays. \n\nWe are not told if any of the implicated cheeses were made from raw milk or the aging process for these cheeses. However, if genotyping is done and genotypes of the 4 patient isolates match each other, then a common source outbreak can be established, and if the genotype of the outbreak strain matches that of the cheese isolate, then the source can be established. According to information from meal cards, the infected patients did consume cheese during their hospitalization but it is not possible to be certain that it was the cheeses in question. \n\nDenner, a supermarket in Switzerland, has recalled all expiration dates of 'Denner Fromage de montagne de la Suisse centrale' because of detection of _Listeria_ at the site of the dairy producer. \n\nFSVO, also known by its French acronym OSAV, Italian name USAV, and under the German name BLV, told people not to consume the products concerned by the recall as they may pose a health hazard.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Steinerberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SWITZERLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valais", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6852412", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): fatal, bulk hard-boiled eggs, 2017-2019, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6852412", "date": "2019-12-21 17:34:03", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): FATAL, BULK HARD-BOILED EGGS, 2017-2019, ALERT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Dec 2019\nSource: CDC Food Safety Alert [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/eggs-12-19/index.html\n\n\nThe CDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to hard-boiled eggs.\n\nAt a glance\n-----------\nReported cases: 7\nStates: 5\nHospitalizations: 4\nDeaths: 1\nRecall: No\n\nAdvice for retailers, food service operators, and consumers\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe CDC is concerned that bulk, fresh hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods of Gainesville, Georgia, are contaminated with _Listeria_ and have made people sick. These products were packaged in plastic pails for use nationwide by food service operators. These products have not been recalled. However, because _Listeria_ can cause severe infections, the CDC is warning against selling, serving, or using these eggs to make other food products.\n\nRetailers and food service operators should know who supplies their bulk hard-boiled eggs. Consumers will not be able to tell if products they've purchased from stores contain these eggs, so it is important that people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infections follow the advice listed below.\n\nAdvice for retailers and food service operators:\n- Retailers and food service operators should not use bulk hard-boiled eggs produced at the Almark Foods Gainesville, Georgia facility, regardless of use-by date.\n- These eggs were peeled, hard-boiled, and packaged in plastic pails of various sizes. Food processors and manufacturers should not use these eggs to make ready-to-eat foods, such as egg salad, deviled eggs, or salads.\n- These fresh hard-boiled eggs were packaged in plastic pails and have a 49-day shelf-life.\n- Wash and sanitize any surfaces that may have come in contact with the eggs or the pail packaging. _Listeria_ can easily spread to other foods and surfaces.\n- Retailers and food service operators should be aware of the following: This advice does not include Almark Foods hard-boiled eggs sold directly to consumers (https://www.almarkeggs.com/product-category/retail/hard-boiled-eggs/), or any other brands of hard-boiled eggs or products made with hard-boiled eggs. The data collected to date [have] not indicated that these products are linked to illness. This advice does not include eggs hard-boiled by retailers or restaurants.\n\nAdvice for people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection, such as pregnant women and their newborns, adults ages 65 or older, and people with weakened immune systems, such as people with cancer or on dialysis:\n- Until we learn more, CDC advises that people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection throw away any store-bought hard-boiled eggs or products containing hard-boiled eggs, such as egg salad. If you have these products at home, don't eat them. Throw them away, regardless of where you bought them or the use-by date.\n- Wash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where the products were stored. Follow these 5 steps to clean your refrigerator (see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html). This advice does not include eggs hard-boiled at home or homemade products made with those eggs, such as egg salad or deviled eggs.\n- If you buy products with hard-boiled eggs, or order or eat items with hard-boiled eggs at a restaurant: Before you buy, order, or eat, confirm with the store or restaurant that they do not use hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods. If they use hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods, don't buy or order the product. If they don't know where their hard-boiled eggs are from, don't buy or order the product.\n- People at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection are much more likely than the general public to get sick after eating a food contaminated with this bacteria. People on dialysis are 50 times more likely to get a _Listeria_ infection. People with cancer and pregnant women are 10 times more likely than other people to get a _Listeria_ infection. Adults 65 and older are 4 times more likely to get an infection.\n\nLatest outbreak information\n-------------------------\n- Seven people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 5 states. Four hospitalizations have been reported. One death has been reported from Texas.\n- Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that bulk hard-boiled eggs from Almark Foods are a likely source of this outbreak.\n- This investigation is ongoing to determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness.\n- The CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\nPublic health investigators are using the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that may be part of this outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by the CDC. DNA fingerprinting is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using a standardized laboratory and data analysis method called whole genome sequencing (WGS). CDC PulseNet manages a national database of these sequences that are used to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives investigators detailed information about the bacteria causing illness. In this investigation, WGS showed that bacteria isolated from ill people are closely related genetically. This means that people in this outbreak are more likely to share a common source of infection.\n\nAs of 17 Dec 2019, a total of 7 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 5 states. A list of the states and the number of cases in each can be found on the Map of Reported Cases page (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/eggs-12-19/map.html).\n\n_Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from 10 Apr 2017 to 12 Nov 2019. Ill people range in age from less than 1 to 82 years, with a median age of 75. Seventy-one percent of ill people are male. Of 6 ill people with information available, 4 hospitalizations have been reported. One death has been reported from Texas. One illness was reported in a newborn who was infected with _Listeria_ while the mother was pregnant, but the newborn survived.\n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that bulk hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods of Gainesville, Georgia, are a likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about the foods they ate and other exposures in the month before they became ill. Of the 5 people for whom information was available, 4 (80%) reported eating products containing eggs. Three of these people reported eating hard-boiled eggs in deli salads purchased from grocery stores and in salads eaten at restaurants.\n\nIn the PulseNet database, CDC noted 2 environmental samples from February 2019 that are closely related genetically to bacteria from ill people in this outbreak. The FDA reports that these samples were taken during a routine inspection of the Almark Foods facility (https://www.fda.gov/inspections-compliance-enforcement-and-criminal-investigations/warning-letters/almark-foods-inc-576633-07222019). These results provide additional evidence that people in this outbreak got sick from eating hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods.\n\nInvestigators are continuing to collect records from grocery stores and restaurants where ill people reported eating hard-boiled eggs. Investigations are ongoing to determine and document the distribution and production chain, as well as the source of hard-boiled eggs to the locations reported by ill people.\n\nThe CDC is concerned that bulk, fresh hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods of Gainesville, Georgia, are contaminated with _Listeria_ and have made people sick. These products were packaged in plastic pails for use nationwide by food service operators.\n\nThe investigation is ongoing to determine the source of contamination and if additional products are linked to illness. The CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source.\n\nThe above alert issued by the CDC concerns 7 people who have been infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 5 states from 10 Apr 2017 to 12 Nov 2019. One of the 7 people has died. Of cases for which information was available, 80% reported eating products containing eggs. Two 'environmental samples' taken at the Almark Foods facility of Gainesville, Georgia, a producer of bulk hard-boiled eggs, during a routine inspection in February 2019 are reported above to be closely related genetically to the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_, which provided additional evidence that 'that people in this outbreak got sick from eating [bulk] hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods.' The FDA report (https://www.fda.gov/inspections-compliance-enforcement-and-criminal-investigations/warning-letters/almark-foods-inc-576633-07222019) specifies that one swab was collected at the Almark Foods facility from the peeling room floor drain and the other from 'the egg counter entrance and stainless-steel area at the end of the conveyor belt', a location in contact with food. The FDA reports 'the 2 isolates are genetically identical to 2 cases of human illness dating back to 2017.' However, the CDC report above notes that these products have not been recalled. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "\n\nAdvice for people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection, such as pregnant women and their newborns, adults ages 65 or older, and people with weakened immune systems, such as people with cancer or on dialysis:\n- Until we learn more, CDC advises that people at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection throw away any store-bought hard-boiled eggs or products containing hard-boiled eggs, such as egg salad. \n- Retailers and food service operators should be aware of the following: This advice does not include Almark Foods hard-boiled eggs sold directly to consumers (https://www.almarkeggs.com/product-category/retail/hard-boiled-eggs/), or any other brands of hard-boiled eggs or products made with hard-boiled eggs. Two 'environmental samples' taken at the Almark Foods facility of Gainesville, Georgia, a producer of bulk hard-boiled eggs, during a routine inspection in February 2019 are reported above to be closely related genetically to the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_, which provided additional evidence that 'that people in this outbreak got sick from eating [bulk] hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods.' If you buy products with hard-boiled eggs, or order or eat items with hard-boiled eggs at a restaurant: Before you buy, order, or eat, confirm with the store or restaurant that they do not use hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods. \n\nAdvice for retailers and food service operators:\n- Retailers and food service operators should not use bulk hard-boiled eggs produced at the Almark Foods Gainesville, Georgia facility, regardless of use-by date. This advice does not include eggs hard-boiled at home or homemade products made with those eggs, such as egg salad or deviled eggs. The CDC is concerned that bulk, fresh hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods of Gainesville, Georgia, are contaminated with _Listeria_ and have made people sick. Of the 5 people for whom information was available, 4 (80%) reported eating products containing eggs. \n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. \n- People at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection are much more likely than the general public to get sick after eating a food contaminated with this bacteria. -------------------------\n- Seven people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 5 states. Of cases for which information was available, 80% reported eating products containing eggs. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based on whole genome sequencing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1975-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-02-26 00:00:00", "2019-12-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gainesville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6711608", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (15): (Netherlands) fatal, WGS, cold cuts", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6711608", "date": "2019-10-05 20:28:39", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (15): (NETHERLANDS) FATAL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, COLD CUTS\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Oct 2019\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\nhttps://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2019/10/three-dead-in-listeria-outbreak-source-traced-to-dutch-cold-meat-factory/\n\n\nA total of 3 people have died and one woman has had a miscarriage after eating cold meat contaminated with _Listeria_, the public health institute RIVM [Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment] said on Friday [4 Oct 2019]. All are thought to have become ill after eating meat products from the Offerman company over the past 2 years, the agency said.\n\nIn total, at least 20 people have become ill after eating Offerman cold cuts. The company issued a health warning on Friday [4 Oct 2019], and Jumbo, which stocks 135 different products from Offerman, ordered an immediate recall. Aldi too has recalled its Offerman products, which were also widely sold to company canteens.\n\nThe source of the infection was traced by the RIVM and product safety board NVWA [Netherlands Food and Consumer Product Safety] after an analysis of the different types of _Listeria_ infection this week. 'It has only been recently possible to use this technique and without it, we would not have been able to identify the source,' the RIVM said. [Probably they are referring to whole genome sequencing. - Mod.ML]\n\nThe factory where the bacteria originate[d] is located in Aalsmeer and has been closed pending a thorough clean-up, the AD reported on Friday afternoon [4 Oct 2019]. According to broadcaster NOS, the NVWA had ordered Offerman to take extra hygiene measures because there were suspicions that something was going wrong. 'But this would appear not to have done the job,' an NVWA spokesman told the broadcaster.\n\n_Listeria_ is found in meat that has not been properly cooked and in raw foods [that] have been kept [refrigerated?] for a long time, the RIVM said. Most people suffer mild flu-like symptoms, but the bacteria can cause serious symptoms in the elderly, newborns and people with weak immune systems. It is particularly dangerous to pregnant women and can cause miscarriages. Every year about 80 cases of [listeriosis] are reported to the RIVM.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genotyping, e.g., by whole genome sequencing, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ can identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at food processing facilities can confirm the source, if genotypes match, as likely happened in the outbreak described above.\n\nRefrigerated cold cut meats that are not cooked before eating (i.e., ready-to-eat) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. People at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNetherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genotyping, e.g., by whole genome sequencing, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ can identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at food processing facilities can confirm the source, if genotypes match, as likely happened in the outbreak described above. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n A total of 3 people have died and one woman has had a miscarriage after eating cold meat contaminated with _Listeria_, the public health institute RIVM [Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment] said on Friday [4 Oct 2019]. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (15): (NETHERLANDS) FATAL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, COLD CUTS\n**********************************************************************************\n People at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. Most people suffer mild flu-like symptoms, but the bacteria can cause serious symptoms in the elderly, newborns and people with weak immune systems. \n\nRefrigerated cold cut meats that are not cooked before eating (i.e., ready-to-eat) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. \n\nIn total, at least 20 people have become ill after eating Offerman cold cuts. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNetherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Aalsmeer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6789767", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (18): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6789767", "date": "2019-11-21 11:13:57", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (18): (GERMANY) FATAL, WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCING, MEAT, HEALTHCARE FACILITIES\n************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Nov 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/11/german-officials-admit-mistakes-in-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nAuthorities in Germany have admitted mistakes were made as part of investigations into a _Listeria_ outbreak that affected 37 people beginning in 2014.\n\nOne infection was recorded in 2014, 3 in 2016, and 4 in 2017 but the outbreak was only identified in 2018 by whole genome sequencing when there was an increase with 21 people sick. This year [2019], 8 more patients became ill with the last disease onset date in mid-July. 3 people are reported to have died with listeriosis as a contributing factor.\n\nThe Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) and the Federal Office of Consumer Protection and Food Safety (BVL) looked at supply chains and food samples. Investigations compared a _Listeria_ isolate from the Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren company near Hesse with patient isolates from the outbreak, finding a close relationship between them.\n\nThe United States was one of more than 20 countries that may have received meat from this German company but no illnesses were recorded in other nations.\n\nIssues were raised about the speed of communication between different authorities, scrutiny of Wilke and decision making around the timing of closing the business.\n\nReinhard Kubat, district administrator in Waldeck-Frankenberg, a county in Hessen, said the focus should not be on blame but on actions for the future.\n\n'We know that there have been mistakes... and we are ready to protect consumers to jointly improve food monitoring to regain consumer confidence. As we know, there have been failures at all levels of government. All authorities must work together to prevent a repeat of the Wilke case, if possible. There cannot be 100 percent certainty. All authorities, however, collectively share the duty of learning from what happened and to do everything possible to rule out such incidents.'\n\nA 40-page review of the Wilke case by authorities in Waldeck-Frankenberg was given to the Hessian Ministry for the Environment, Climate Protection, Agriculture and Consumer Protection.\n\nIt was agreed food monitoring would be improved with unannounced inspections in manufacturing companies to be stepped up and carried out at fixed intervals together with technical supervision. Businesses' self-control systems are also going to be looked at more intensively.\n\nWhat went wrong?\n----------------\nPriska Hinz, Hessen consumer protection minister, said the food business operator is primarily responsible at all stages of production, processing, and distribution in ensuring food meets requirements of the law.\n\n'These include in particular food safety, traceability, prevention, transparency and emergency measures, as well as cooperation with the authorities. Food inspection ensures that employers comply with their responsibilities and that only safe food comes onto the market,' she said.\n\n'In the case of Wilke, the food business operator obviously did not fulfill his obligations. Nevertheless, it is also important in the future to recognize such cases at an early stage and to act consistently.'\n\nBased on EU regulation, food firms are sorted into risk levels that equate to a certain frequency of checks. Wilke was classified as risk level 4 which should have meant the firm had to be inspected 12 times a year but a mistake saw the company reduced to quarterly inspections.\n\nFor a company the size as Wilke, a regular review of all operating rooms is necessary. However, control reports from 2018 show that inspections only took place in different areas of the site. Between 2015 and 2018 it could also not be shown that controls on self-checks at Wilke took place.\n\nListeria positives\n------------------\nBetween May 2018 and May 2019, _Listeria monocytogenes_ was found in 7 of 131 product samples examined by Wilke so the company told authorities it had strengthened hygiene controls.\n\nDespite _Listeria_ findings by authorities from Hamburg and Baden-Wuerttemberg, no further official sampling seems to have taken place for the next 4 months, based on investigations in April this year [2019].\n\nThe 31 tests from April are environmental samples of which 5 detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ and 2 samples contained other _Listeria_. However, despite this, there was no increase in the number of official samples.\n\nThe Hessian Ministry of Consumer Protection was informed by the BVL on [12 Aug 2019] that Wilke had supplied food to wholesalers in 6 of 9 health facilities where people suffering from the _Listeria_ outbreak strain were present. But authorities in Waldeck-Frankenberg, who are responsible for food monitoring at Wilke, were not informed until [20 Aug 2019].\n\nAfter an inspection in early September [2019], the company was told to sample all 5 slicers on a daily basis and thoroughly clean and disinfect all production rooms. Product samples were negative for _Listeria_. In mid-September [2019] a link between the company and the illness cluster was established after further analysis of the samples from April [2019]. _Listeria_ was found in environmental samples taken this month [November 2019].\n\nOfficials stopped production at the Wilke facility in early October [2019], with the company's inventory still at about 300 tons, and a criminal complaint was made to the public prosecutor in Kassel. The company has since filed for bankruptcy.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The news report above goes into greater detail concerning the listeriosis outbreak in Germany than the prior ProMED-mail post (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (16): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities 20191019.6736570), which described a listeriosis outbreak that affected 37 people, 3 of whom died, in 12 German states between 2014 and 2019, due to _Listeria_-contaminated meat products manufactured at a processing facility in the German state of Hesse and widely distributed to more than 20 European countries.\n\nWe were told in the prior ProMED-mail posting that most people infected in this outbreak ate the contaminated meat products at healthcare facilities. Such people are at increased risk of disseminated listeriosis if they eat _Listeria_-contaminated food that is not adequately cooked before eating. We are not told specifically if the contaminated food was ready-to-eat cold cuts. Refrigerated cold cut meats that are not cooked before eating are well-recognized sources for listeriosis and should not be served to at-risk people. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The news report above goes into greater detail concerning the listeriosis outbreak in Germany than the prior ProMED-mail post (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (16): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities 20191019.6736570), which described a listeriosis outbreak that affected 37 people, 3 of whom died, in 12 German states between 2014 and 2019, due to _Listeria_-contaminated meat products manufactured at a processing facility in the German state of Hesse and widely distributed to more than 20 European countries. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/11/german-officials-admit-mistakes-in-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nAuthorities in Germany have admitted mistakes were made as part of investigations into a _Listeria_ outbreak that affected 37 people beginning in 2014. ----------------\nPriska Hinz, Hessen consumer protection minister, said the food business operator is primarily responsible at all stages of production, processing, and distribution in ensuring food meets requirements of the law. \n\nWe were told in the prior ProMED-mail posting that most people infected in this outbreak ate the contaminated meat products at healthcare facilities. \n\nOne infection was recorded in 2014, 3 in 2016, and 4 in 2017 but the outbreak was only identified in 2018 by whole genome sequencing when there was an increase with 21 people sick. \n\nOfficials stopped production at the Wilke facility in early October [2019], with the company's inventory still at about 300 tons, and a criminal complaint was made to the public prosecutor in Kassel. The Hessian Ministry of Consumer Protection was informed by the BVL on [12 Aug 2019] that Wilke had supplied food to wholesalers in 6 of 9 health facilities where people suffering from the _Listeria_ outbreak strain were present. Between May 2018 and May 2019, _Listeria monocytogenes_ was found in 7 of 131 product samples examined by Wilke so the company told authorities it had strengthened hygiene controls. \n\nIt was agreed food monitoring would be improved with unannounced inspections in manufacturing companies to be stepped up and carried out at fixed intervals together with technical supervision. \n\n'These include in particular food safety, traceability, prevention, transparency and emergency measures, as well as cooperation with the authorities. \n\nBased on EU regulation, food firms are sorted into risk levels that equate to a certain frequency of checks. \n\n'In the case of Wilke, the food business operator obviously did not fulfill his obligations. \n\nThe United States was one of more than 20 countries that may have received meat from this German company but no illnesses were recorded in other nations. The Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) and the Federal Office of Consumer Protection and Food Safety (BVL) looked at supply chains and food samples. In mid-September [2019] a link between the company and the illness cluster was established after further analysis of the samples from April [2019]. \n\nIssues were raised about the speed of communication between different authorities, scrutiny of Wilke and decision making around the timing of closing the business. \n\nA 40-page review of the Wilke case by authorities in Waldeck-Frankenberg was given to the Hessian Ministry for the Environment, Climate Protection, Agriculture and Consumer Protection. But authorities in Waldeck-Frankenberg, who are responsible for food monitoring at Wilke, were not informed until [20 Aug 2019]. After an inspection in early September [2019], the company was told to sample all 5 slicers on a daily basis and thoroughly clean and disinfect all production rooms. Food inspection ensures that employers comply with their responsibilities and that only safe food comes onto the market,' she said. Despite _Listeria_ findings by authorities from Hamburg and Baden-Wuerttemberg, no further official sampling seems to have taken place for the next 4 months, based on investigations in April this year [2019]. [Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\n Such people are at increased risk of disseminated listeriosis if they eat _Listeria_-contaminated food that is not adequately cooked before eating. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. \n\nReinhard Kubat, district administrator in Waldeck-Frankenberg, a county in Hessen, said the focus should not be on blame but on actions for the future. Wilke was classified as risk level 4 which should have meant the firm had to be inspected 12 times a year but a mistake saw the company reduced to quarterly inspections. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101] LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (18): (GERMANY) FATAL, WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCING, MEAT, HEALTHCARE FACILITIES\n We know that there have been mistakes... and we are ready to protect consumers to jointly improve food monitoring to regain consumer confidence. Date: Wed 20 Nov 2019\n Refrigerated cold cut meats that are not cooked before eating are well-recognized sources for listeriosis and should not be served to at-risk people. The 31 tests from April are environmental samples of which 5 detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ and 2 samples contained other _Listeria_. We are not told specifically if the contaminated food was ready-to-eat cold cuts. Investigations compared a _Listeria_ isolate from the Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren company near Hesse with patient isolates from the outbreak, finding a close relationship between them. \n\nWhat went wrong? _Listeria_ was found in environmental samples taken this month [November 2019]. \n\n \n\n' \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n This year [2019], 8 more patients became ill with the last disease onset date in mid-July.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-11-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hessen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GERMANY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kassel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hesse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baden - Wuerttemberg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hamburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waldeck - Frankenberg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6745186", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (17): (Belgium) fatal, cold cuts, ex Netherlands, 2018", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6745186", "date": "2019-10-24 19:05:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (17): (BELGIUM) FATAL, COLD CUTS, ex NETHERLANDS, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Oct 2019\nSource: Brussels Times [edited]\nhttps://www.brusselstimes.com/belgium/75139/two-listeria-cases-detected-in-belgium-after-deadly-dutch-outbreak/\n\n\nTwo people in Belgium have been infected with _Listeria_ bacteria that lead to the death of 3 people and a miscarriage over a 2-year period in the Netherlands, a sampling by a federal health centre showed. [See ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (15): (Netherlands) fatal, WGS, cold cuts 20191005.6711608, which described a listeriosis outbreak that affected 20 people, 3 of whom died and one woman had a miscarriage, over the past 2 years after eating cold cuts produced by Offerman, a Netherland-based producer. - Mod.ML]\n\nThe cases in Belgium affected a 97-year-old woman and a Dutch national who recently gave birth in Antwerp [Belgium], a study by federal health research centre Sciensano confirmed. Both women were infected with the bacteria in 2018, according to the study, which compared samples of bacteria in the Netherlands with those of Belgian patients infected, HLN reports.\n\nThe centre's study comes after three people died and one woman had suffered a miscarriage in the Netherlands after eating meat contaminated with _Listeria_ over a 2-year period, which was reportedly linked to Dutch meat producer Offerman.\n\nIn Germany, 2 _Listeria_-related deaths were also reported in the central state of Hesse. [See ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (16): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities 20191019.6736570, which described a listeriosis outbreak that affected 40 people, 3 of whom have died, in 12 German states between 2014 and 2019, due to _Listeria_-contaminated meat products manufactured at a processing facility in the German state of Hesse and widely distributed to more than 20 European countries. This German outbreak associated with the Hesse-based meat processing facility is unrelated to the Netherlands/Belgium outbreak associated with the Netherlands-based meat processing facility. - Mod.ML]\n\nNews of the deaths led supermarkets in Belgium to issue recalls for prepackaged meat, a move they said at the time was precautionary. Offerman, a subsidiary of Belgian food group Ter Beke, has since been shut down in the Netherlands.\n\nThe Sciensano study could not identify the cause of the infections in Belgium, since isolated cases, unlike outbreaks, are not subject to follow-ups, Het Nieuwsblad reports.\n\n[Byline: Gabriela Galindo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[The incriminated meat is refrigerated cold cuts that are not cooked before eating (i.e., ready-to-eat). Cold cuts are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. People at increased risk for disseminated listeriosis, which include pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems, should avoid eating food potentially contaminated with _Listeria_. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nBelgium: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/99\nNetherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104]", "summary": "[See ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (15): (Netherlands) fatal, WGS, cold cuts 20191005.6711608, which described a listeriosis outbreak that affected 20 people, 3 of whom died and one woman had a miscarriage, over the past 2 years after eating cold cuts produced by Offerman, a Netherland-based producer.
