Date: Thu 24 Oct 2019\n Source: Brussels Times [edited]\nhttps://www.brusselstimes.com/belgium/75139/two-listeria-cases-detected-in-belgium-after-deadly-dutch-outbreak/ **\n Cold cuts are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. \n\n In Germany, 2 _Listeria_-related deaths were also reported in the central state of Hesse. \n\n \n\n Offerman, a subsidiary of Belgian food group Ter Beke, has since been shut down in the Netherlands.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hesse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Antwerp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6680145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (12): (France) fatal, raw milk cheeses, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6680145", "date": "2019-09-18 10:33:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (12): (FRANCE) FATAL, RAW MILK CHEESES, RECALL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 Sep 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/09/first-illness-in-french-listeria-outbreak-from-february-last-year/\n\n\nThe 7 people in France part of a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to organic dairy products fell ill over a period of 18 months, according to public health authorities. Those infected with the same strain of _Listeria_ were identified by the National Reference Center for Listeria, with an 8th case still under investigation.\n\nSante Publique France [Public Health France] reported 2 people have died, but the agency does not have any evidence to attribute the deaths to _Listeria_ infection.\n\nPeople fell ill between February 2018 and August 2019 and are aged between 36 and 93 years old; 5 are women. Four live in Alsace, while Burgundy, Ile-de-France, and Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur all have one case.\n\nInvestigations by Sante Publique France found these people had consumed organic dairy products in the weeks before contracting listeriosis. Analysis of food samples from a company, based in Bas-Rhin, Alsace confirmed contamination with _Listeria_. Raw milk cheeses are the suspected source of the contamination.\n\nTesting by the National Reference Center for _Listeria_ confirmed strains found in products had the same genetic characteristics as those isolated in the patients. Consumption of Ferme Durr products was also confirmed by several patients.\n\nFerme Durr recalled all dates of Durr brand organic dairy items, including natural yogurt and yogurt with fruit, cream, cottage cheese, and cheese. Products were sold directly at the firm, in markets and stores throughout France. Products were also distributed in Belgium, Germany, and Luxembourg.\n\nThe action was extended a few days later to include puddings and food such as cheese and cold meats resold but not produced at the site.\n\nAll production by the company has been stopped until further notice, according to French authorities after an investigation revealed 'serious shortcomings,' and results of official controls found 'widespread contamination' of the facility and food products.\n\nIt can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop. Symptoms of the infection can include vomiting, nausea, persistent fever, muscle aches, severe headache, and neck stiffness.\n\nPregnant women, the elderly, young children, and people who have weakened immune systems are more at risk of serious illnesses, life-threatening infections, and other complications.\n\nMeanwhile, the Joint Research Centre (JRC) of the European Commission has released a Certified Reference Material (CRM) to be used as quality assurance for analysis of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in food control laboratories. The aim is to support EU member states when monitoring listeriosis and ensure collection of comparable data on the disease.\n\nEvaluating the subtype of _Listeria monocytogenes_ is essential in epidemiological investigations or source tracking contamination from food factories. One of the methods used by labs for subtyping is pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE). The material was certified using an interlaboratory comparison study, in which all participants used PFGE.\n\nIn the EU, 2480 cases were reported in 2017, with a mortality rate of 14%. The disease is often severe with high hospitalization and mortality rates. Consumption of ready-to-eat foods such as smoked fish, deli meats and soft cheeses are the main routes of transmission.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The 7 patients infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria_ live in eastern France: 4 in Alsace, an historical region located in Grand Est (Grand Est is one of the 12 mainland regions of France) and 1 each in the regions of Burgundy, Ile-de-France, and Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur. A map showing these locations can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_France. Patients fell ill between February 2018 and August 2019.\n\nThe source of this listeriosis outbreak is believed to be raw milk cheeses produced by a facility in Bas-Rhin, Alsace. Products from this facility were consumed by several of the patients, and _Listeria_ isolated from some products had the same genetic characteristics as those isolated from the patients. Products were sold directly at the facility, as well as distributed throughout France and in Belgium, Germany, and Luxembourg.\n\nThe company ceased operation and recalled all its dairy items including cheeses, yogurt and yogurt with fruit, cream, cottage cheese, and cheese; the recall was extended a few days later to include food resold but not produced at the site.\n\nBas-Rhin is a department in northern Alsace (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bas-Rhin). The exact date of the recall is not given, but may be very recent. Because the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_, more cases can be expected. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100]", "summary": "\n\nThe company ceased operation and recalled all its dairy items including cheeses, yogurt and yogurt with fruit, cream, cottage cheese, and cheese; the recall was extended a few days later to include food resold but not produced at the site. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAll production by the company has been stopped until further notice, according to French authorities after an investigation revealed 'serious shortcomings,' and results of official controls found 'widespread contamination' of the facility and food products. \n\nFerme Durr recalled all dates of Durr brand organic dairy items, including natural yogurt and yogurt with fruit, cream, cottage cheese, and cheese. \n\nThe action was extended a few days later to include puddings and food such as cheese and cold meats resold but not produced at the site. \n\nInvestigations by Sante Publique France found these people had consumed organic dairy products in the weeks before contracting listeriosis. \n\nTesting by the National Reference Center for _Listeria_ confirmed strains found in products had the same genetic characteristics as those isolated in the patients. \n\nThe source of this listeriosis outbreak is believed to be raw milk cheeses produced by a facility in Bas-Rhin, Alsace. \n\nPeople fell ill between February 2018 and August 2019 and are aged between 36 and 93 years old; 5 are women. \n\nEvaluating the subtype of _Listeria monocytogenes_ is essential in epidemiological investigations or source tracking contamination from food factories. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (12): (FRANCE) FATAL, RAW MILK CHEESES, RECALL\n*******************************************************************\n The 7 people in France part of a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to organic dairy products fell ill over a period of 18 months, according to public health authorities. Products from this facility were consumed by several of the patients, and _Listeria_ isolated from some products had the same genetic characteristics as those isolated from the patients. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-08-26 00:00:00", "2019-09-17 00:00:00", "2480-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "EU", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FRANCE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand Est", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alsace", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6662490", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (10): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, UK tourist", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6662490", "date": "2019-09-07 14:59:47", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (10): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, UK TOURIST\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 6 Sep 2019\nSource: New Food Magazine [edited]\nhttps://www.newfoodmagazine.com/news/93192/death-reported-spain-literia-outbreak/\n\n\nA 3rd death has been reported in Spain's biggest _Listeria_ outbreak, which has seen 200 cases of infection reported so far. A man has reportedly died after eating tainted meat in Spain. This is the 3rd fatality in the outbreak, which comes on top of the deaths of 2 elderly women. The outbreak has also seen 5 women lose their babies due to the food-borne bacteria.\n\nThe 1st possible case of listeriosis outside of Spain as part of the current outbreak has also been reported. The potential victim is a Briton who may have become infected with the bacteria while in the focal point of the ongoing outbreak, Andalusia, before traveling to France, where he was diagnosed with listeriosis and spent several days in hospital, then returning to his home country.\n\nThe source of the outbreak has been traced to a pork product stuffed with garlic and other condiments sold under the commercial name 'la Mecha', which is made by the company Magrudis, based in Seville. Its factory has since been closed and its meat recalled from shops.\n\nAccording to EL PAIS [Spanish newspaper], the oven cart used at the company has tested positive for the bacteria _Listeria monocytogenes_. Last week [25-31 Aug 2019], the news outlet revealed that tests carried out on larding needles used by Magrudis also returned positive results for the presence of the bacteria.\n\nThe company said they are 'in a state of shock,' and 'couldn't explain what happened' in a press release reportedly released by Magrudis. The company also claims to have been in compliance with all sanitary regulations, with recent lab reports proving negative test results from just days before the product in question was packaged.\n\nShowing her solidarity with the people affected by the outbreak, the families of the deceased, and women who have suffered abortions or intrauterine fetal deaths, Maria Luisa Carcedo, the Minister of Health, Consumer Affairs and Social Welfare, has expressed her 'most sincere solidarity and deep regret in the name of the Government of Spain. I know that this is not enough and that the fundamental reparation that we are obliged to give [the victims and their families] is the determination of the causes and circumstances in which this outbreak has occurred and the adoption of decisions that prevent this from happening again.'\n\nThe 1st official report on the outbreak was on 16 Aug 2019 by Andalusian health authorities, said Carcedo: 'Since [16 Aug 2019], the protocols of the national alert network and the EU have worked,' said the minister. 'Spain is one of the most demanding countries in food security, and outbreaks such as [the one in] Andalusia should serve to further improve our action and response protocols.' Carcedo also thanked the health professionals of the National Health System and food safety 'who have worked both in patient care and in the containment of the outbreak'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 6 Sep 2019\nSource: El Pais [in Spanish, machine trans., abridged, edited]\nhttps://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=https://elpais.com/sociedad/2019/09/06/actualidad/1567770709_618948.html&prev=search\n\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak, the largest recorded in Spain to date, has so far caused 3 deaths, 7 abortions and affected more than 200 people. The authorities considered it controlled. Now this new front opens. Dr. Jose Miguel Cisneros has reported on Friday morning [6 Sep 2019] of a new confirmed case, which brings the number of people affected in Andalusia to 207, and another abortion, the 6th in the community and the 7th in the whole country. This is a pregnant woman from Seville, 23 weeks of gestation, and who had ingested the Mecha meatloaf a few weeks ago, without presenting symptoms. The number of hospitalized is 45 versus 40 on the previous day [5 Sep 2019], of which 19 are pregnant women. Two patients remain in the ICU.\n\n_Listeria_ is an almost harmless pathogen for most healthy people, but it can be lethal for those with weakened immune systems and for babies in gestation, as confirmed in the outbreak recorded so far by contaminated brand products La Mecha, from the Sevillian company Magrudis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak is now reported to extend throughout Spain, although most cases have occurred in Seville. The 2nd news report above says that the outbreak has now involved 7 miscarriages, and a case in a tourist from the UK who was hospitalized in France with listeriosis acquired in Seville.\n\n_Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked at a meat processing facility in Seville; after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices. Proper cooking of the meat at the processing facility should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have also occurred after cooking. The 1st news report above says that _Listeria_ was isolated from an oven cart used at the company; if the meat was placed on this cart after cooking, it could explain how the meat became contaminated despite having been previously cooked. The meat processing facility in Seville has been closed, and all its products have now been recalled.\n\nBecause it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.\n\nGenotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSpain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked at a meat processing facility in Seville; after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices. \n\n_Listeria_ is an almost harmless pathogen for most healthy people, but it can be lethal for those with weakened immune systems and for babies in gestation, as confirmed in the outbreak recorded so far by contaminated brand products La Mecha, from the Sevillian company Magrudis. The 1st news report above says that _Listeria_ was isolated from an oven cart used at the company; if the meat was placed on this cart after cooking, it could explain how the meat became contaminated despite having been previously cooked. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (10): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, UK TOURIST\n************************************************************************\n The 1st official report on the outbreak was on 16 Aug 2019 by Andalusian health authorities, said Carcedo: 'Since [16 Aug 2019], the protocols of the national alert network and the EU have worked,' said the minister. ' Genotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak is now reported to extend throughout Spain, although most cases have occurred in Seville. Proper cooking of the meat at the processing facility should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have also occurred after cooking. Showing her solidarity with the people affected by the outbreak, the families of the deceased, and women who have suffered abortions or intrauterine fetal deaths, Maria Luisa Carcedo, the Minister of Health, Consumer Affairs and Social Welfare, has expressed her 'most sincere solidarity and deep regret in the name of the Government of Spain. The listeriosis outbreak, the largest recorded in Spain to date, has so far caused 3 deaths, 7 abortions and affected more than 200 people. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The potential victim is a Briton who may have become infected with the bacteria while in the focal point of the ongoing outbreak, Andalusia, before traveling to France, where he was diagnosed with listeriosis and spent several days in hospital, then returning to his home country. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\n A 3rd death has been reported in Spain's biggest _Listeria_ outbreak, which has seen 200 cases of infection reported so far.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-09-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-08-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISCARRIAGES", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mecha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6670537", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (11): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, Mallorca", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6670537", "date": "2019-09-12 13:20:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (11): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, MALLORCA\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Sep 2019, 10:57 AM\nSource: The Olive Press [edited]\nhttps://www.theolivepress.es/spain-news/2019/09/12/outbreak-of-deadly-listeria-virus-confirmed-in-spain-killing-three-people-and-affecting-hundreds-more-in-mallorca/\n\n\nAn outbreak of the deadly [infection due to the bacterium] _Listeria_ has been confirmed in Mallorca.\n\nA patient is recovering in a private clinic in Palma as samples of the bacterium are being tested in Madrid to confirm if it is the same strain as the recent outbreak in Andalucia. It seems likely to have originated from the same lethal strain since the patient affected [in Mallorca] had come from Granada.\n\nSo far 3 people have died and 7 women have aborted babies out of the 200 people confirmed to have been affected.\n\nThe dangerous bacterium spreads through food and can cause severe illnesses including sepsis, meningitis and other life-long problems.\n\n[Byline: Jacque Talbot]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[_Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked at a meat processing facility in Seville implicated in this outbreak (after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices). Proper cooking of the meat at the processing facility should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat, may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have occurred after cooking. The prior news report said that _Listeria_ was isolated from an oven cart used at the processing facility in Seville; if the meat was placed on this cart after cooking, it could explain how the meat became contaminated despite having been previously cooked. The meat processing facility has been closed, and all its products have now been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.\n\nGenotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak.\n\nPalma, with a population of 409 661 residents, the capital and resort city of the autonomous community of the Balearic Islands in Spain, is located on the south coast of Mallorca (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palma_de_Mallorca). Mallorca is the largest island in the Balearic Islands, located approximately 300 km [186 mi] off the eastern coast of Spain in the western Mediterranean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mallorca). The autonomous community of Andalucia is located in southern Spain, with the Atlantic Ocean to the west and the Mediterranean Sea to the east (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seville). A map of Spain showing the locations of Andalucia and Mallorca can be found at https://www.mapshop.com/spain-wall-map-in-spanish/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIqu7U7K3L5AIVgv_jBx3CAQz_EAQYAyABEgIWb_D_BwE. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8735]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[_Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked at a meat processing facility in Seville implicated in this outbreak (after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The prior news report said that _Listeria_ was isolated from an oven cart used at the processing facility in Seville; if the meat was placed on this cart after cooking, it could explain how the meat became contaminated despite having been previously cooked. Genotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. Proper cooking of the meat at the processing facility should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat, may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have occurred after cooking. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (11): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, MALLORCA\n**********************************************************************\n The meat processing facility has been closed, and all its products have now been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Balearic Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISCARRIAGES", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Balearic Islands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6707785", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (14): (Austria) WGS, liver pate, fatal, 2018", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6707785", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(39): pii=1900274. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.39.1900274]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n'In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.'\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). A map showing the location of Styria can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria#/media/File:Steiermark_in_Austria.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n'In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. In late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. \n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. \n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else. \n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. \n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1]. A tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. At the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_. A total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. A total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died. Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market. In total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. \n\nOutbreak investigation\n Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. \n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. The 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. \n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-11-26 00:00:00", "2019-01-26 00:00:00", "2018-12-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Burgenland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huhulescu S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bundesland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Styria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lower Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6696978", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (13): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2014-19", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6696978", "date": "2019-09-27 10:38:17", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (13): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, FATAL, 2014-2019\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 25 Sep 2019 15:10 EEST\nSource: ERR News [edited]\nhttps://news.err.ee/984211/pealtnagija-deadly-listeria-traced-to-m-v-wool-fish-factory\n\n\n_Listeria_ bacteria that have been traced back to the M.V.Wool fish plant in Estonia have been contracted by 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom died as a result.\n\nSeveral countries' studies have suggested that a mutated and very aggressive form of the _Listeria_ bacteria is raging in an M.V.Wool fish plant located near Harku, just outside of Tallinn. According to the latest info, 26 people across Europe have already contracted the bacteria, 6 of whom have died -- among them 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom have died, according to a longer story to air on ETV investigative program Pealtn\u00e4gija on Wednesday night [25 Sep 2019].\n\nGenetic analysis ordered by the Veterinary and Food Board (VTA) revealed that the aggressive and contagious ST1247 strain of _Listeria_ can be traced back to the factory owned by M.V.Wool, Estonia's largest fish producer. Bacteria from this specific strain have been found both in the plant's production building as well as from people that have fallen ill.\n\nVTA deputy director general Olev Kalda said that the fish plant is under the watchful eye of inspectors, and each product batch to leave the plant is currently being thoroughly inspected. 'Clearly some fairly innocuous _Listeria monocytogenes_ ended up at that business, possibly 3 or 4 years ago, but it's possible that as a result of insufficient [cleaning] measures, this mutation occurred there and it developed into a persister strain, that is, a strain unique only to that specific place,' Kalda explained.\n\nM.V.Wool factory owner and board chairman Mati Vetevool has categorically denied that the dangerous bacteria came from their factory, pointing the finger instead at Norwegian and Finnish farms from which he claims the bacteria ended up in their plant. 'I absolutely do not agree that these bacteria are our bacteria,' Vetevool said. 'It comes in from the fish farm; it hasn't developed here. We can also end up stuck with a strain originating from a fish farm. Every night, our fish plant is thoroughly washed, and we destroy absolutely all bacteria in the cleaning process. It's not possible that we are poisoning anyone. Nothing of the sort is possible -- this is simply sheer libel.'\n\nAccording to Kalda, however, Vetevool's story doesn't add up. 'The studies show that this specific strain has been found only in products to be produced by this company, it has been found in this company's environment -- that is, in its production facilities, on its production equipment -- but it, as I mentioned, did not enter this company in this form, with this current strain of DNA,' the VTA official said.\n\nLast year [2018], Estonia was hit by an unexpected _Listeria_ outbreak as a result of which 28 people fell ill; it claimed 7 lives. Taavi Riit, head of the Department of Molecular Analysis at the Veterinary and Food Laboratory (VTL), said that based on the latest analyses, some of these cases could be tied to the M.V.Wool specifically.\n\n'Everyone certainly knows that DNA can be used to identify people, specifically in deaths, identify criminals, and identify genetic kinship between individuals,' Riit said. 'This exact principle applies to bacteria as well. We currently have no reason to doubt that this particular producer's products have caused this outbreak.'\n\nListeriosis is a serious transmissible disease caused by the bacteria _L. monocytogenes_, which is especially dangerous to pregnant people, newborns, the elderly, and others with a compromised or weak immune system.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above concerns a multinational European _Listeria_ outbreak associated with contaminated smoked salmon produced by a processing facility in Estonia. When last posted by ProMED-mail in June 2019, there were a total of 22 cases since 2014: Denmark has 9 cases, Estonia 6, Finland 2, France 1, and Sweden 4. Now there are a total of 26 affected people across Europe, 6 of whom have died -- among them 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom have died.\n\nThe outbreak _Listeria_ strain, ST1247 clonal complex 8, has been found both in the plant's production building as well as from affected people. The strain was also detected at wholesale and retail stores in France, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden from cold smoked or gravad salmon and from 6 batches of cold smoked trout products. Raw fish had been received from suppliers in Norway and Finland.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable the organism to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. In past listeriosis outbreaks, _Listeria_ contamination of food products occurred in parts of equipment 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/). Even if equipment used in food processing only adds a few organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated ready-to-eat food, because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient size to cause disease. - Mod.ML\n\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nFinland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/118\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "Date: Wed 25 Sep 2019 15:10 EEST\nSource: ERR News [edited]\nhttps://news.err.ee/984211/pealtnagija-deadly-listeria-traced-to-m-v-wool-fish-factory\n\n\n_Listeria_ bacteria that have been traced back to the M.V.Wool fish plant in Estonia have been contracted by 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom died as a result. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to the latest info, 26 people across Europe have already contracted the bacteria, 6 of whom have died -- among them 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom have died, according to a longer story to air on ETV investigative program Pealtn\u00e4gija on Wednesday night [25 Sep 2019]. The studies show that this specific strain has been found only in products to be produced by this company, it has been found in this company's environment -- that is, in its production facilities, on its production equipment -- but \n\nM.V.Wool factory owner and board chairman Mati Vetevool has categorically denied that the dangerous bacteria came from their factory, pointing the finger instead at Norwegian and Finnish farms from which he claims the bacteria ended up in their plant. \n\nThe outbreak _Listeria_ strain, ST1247 clonal complex 8, has been found both in the plant's production building as well as from affected people. ML\n\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nFinland: \n\nVTA deputy director general Olev Kalda said that the fish plant is under the watchful eye of inspectors, and each product batch to leave the plant is currently being thoroughly inspected. ' Clearly some fairly innocuous _Listeria monocytogenes_ ended up at that business, possibly 3 or 4 years ago, but it's possible that as a result of insufficient [cleaning] measures, this mutation occurred there and it developed into a persister strain, that is, a strain unique only to that specific place,' Kalda explained. Bacteria from this specific strain have been found both in the plant's production building as well as from people that have fallen ill. \n\nListeriosis is a serious transmissible disease caused by the bacteria _L. monocytogenes_, which is especially dangerous to pregnant people, newborns, the elderly, and others with a compromised or weak immune system. Now there are a total of 26 affected people across Europe, 6 of whom have died -- among them 9 people in Estonia, 2 of whom have died. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (13): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, FATAL, 2014-2019\n*********************************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-06-26 00:00:00", "2019-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Harku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vetevool", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tallinn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6652320", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (09): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, susp. tourist", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6652320", "date": "2019-09-01 19:09:58", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (09): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, SUSPECTED TOURIST\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 31 Aug 2019\nSource: Daily Star [edited]\nhttps://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/world-news/three-women-suffer-miscarriages-spains-19117027\n\n\nThree pregnant women have suffered miscarriages, and nearly 200 people have been hospitalised with [listeriosis] as an outbreak of the infection grips Spain's holiday spots.\n\nA nationwide alert has been sent out after _Listeria_, bacteria which can cause a type of food poisoning called listeriosis, were suspected in packaged pork. Listeriosis can cause severe illness, including severe sepsis, meningitis and sometimes results in lifelong harm or even death.\n\nTwo of the miscarriages happened in Seville and the other in Madrid. One devastated mother lost her baby at 32 weeks, while the others lost their little ones just 8 weeks into pregnancy. Most of the 197 cases have occurred in the southern Spanish region of Andalusia, but people have fallen ill across the country, from Madrid to the island of Tenerife.\n\nSpanish authorities have said that as many as 5 pregnant women may have lost their babies to the outbreak, and 3 people may have died, but stats are yet to be confirmed. At least 67 people have been hospitalised, the majority in Seville. Of these, 23 are pregnant women who are under antibiotic treatment, and 3 are patients admitted to intensive care units.\n\nAuthorities are investigating whether a pork product sold by Seville-based Magrudis could be the source of the outbreak after several of those struck down were found to have eaten it. The product under investigation is a pack of meat called 'Mecha,' of which a batch of 2000 are thought to be the source of the contamination.\n\nPregnant women are especially vulnerable to listeria, when bacteria may cross the placenta to infect the baby, who has no immunity. Spain's Health Minister Maria Luisa Carcedo said: 'We are monitoring this; alerts have been sent out, and we've ordered that all products (that have come) from this factory since May 2019 be pulled from shelves.' She said an investigation is looking into how the meat evaded what she called 'strict food safety controls.'\n\nA spokesman for the firm said recalls had been put in place and an investigation launched into the possible source.\n\nThe Spanish consumer organisation FACUA warned that the outbreak could get worse, as many people don't show symptoms straight away. It can take up to 4 weeks for people to fall ill.\n\nSpanish officials are also investigating whether a Brit tourist may be the 1st foreign national to become infected with _Listeria_, as an outbreak of the infection is gripping the country's holiday spots. According to local media, the man consumed meat while on holiday in Seville. The man, whose name and age have not been revealed, was later diagnosed with the bacterial infection listeriosis after he arrived in France where he was hospitalised.\n\nListeriosis can cause severe illness, including severe sepsis, meningitis, and sometimes results in lifelong harm or even death.\n\n[Byline: Lucy Domachowski]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak is now reported to extend throughout Spain, although most cases are occurring in Seville. The news report above says that the outbreak has involved 3 miscarriages, and a case in a tourist from the UK who is now hospitalized in France is suspected to have been acquired in Seville.\n\n_Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked; after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices. Proper cooking of the meat should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have also occurred after cooking. All products from this meat processing facility in Seville have now been recalled.\n\nBecause it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.\n\nGenotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSpain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak is now reported to extend throughout Spain, although most cases are occurring in Seville. https://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/world-news/three-women-suffer-miscarriages-spains-19117027\n\n\nThree pregnant women have suffered miscarriages, and nearly 200 people have been hospitalised with [listeriosis] as an outbreak of the infection grips Spain's holiday spots.\n\n \n\nSpanish authorities have said that as many as 5 pregnant women may have lost their babies to the outbreak, and 3 people may have died, but stats are yet to be confirmed. Listeria_ have been identified in 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked; after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices. Genotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. \n\nListeriosis can cause severe illness, including severe sepsis, meningitis, and sometimes results in lifelong harm or even death. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (09): (SPAIN) MEAT, FATAL, MISCARRIAGES, SUSPECTED TOURIST\n*******************************************************************************\n \n\nSpanish officials are also investigating whether a Brit tourist may be the 1st foreign national to become infected with _Listeria_, as an outbreak of the infection is gripping the country's holiday spots. \n\nAuthorities are investigating whether a pork product sold by Seville-based Magrudis could be the source of the outbreak after several of those struck down were found to have eaten it. \n\nA spokesman for the firm said recalls had been put in place and an investigation launched into the possible source. Proper cooking of the meat should have killed _Listeria_, which suggests either that the meat may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have also occurred after cooking.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISCARRIAGES", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tenerife", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6640291", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (08): (Spain) meat product, recall, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6640291", "date": "2019-08-25 17:03:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (08): (SPAIN) MEAT PRODUCT, RECALL, FATAL\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 24 Aug 2019\nSource: EuroWeekly News [edited]\nhttps://www.euroweeklynews.com/2019/08/24/second-death-thought-to-be-linked-to-spanish-listeriosis-outbreak/\n\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak in Spain is thought to have claimed a 2nd life. A 72 year old man with cancer died on Thu 22 Aug 2019. On Tue 20 Aug 2019, a 90 year old woman passed away. Both victims lived in Sevilla, the centre of the outbreak.\n\nAt the moment, there is no confirmation that the man had eaten the La Mecha branded 'carne mechada' that has been traced as the source of the outbreak that has so far affected 186 people. An investigation is under way to determine whether his death from listeriosis is linked. The outbreak has been traced to utensils used in the preparation of the food products.\n\nNow experts say that the bacteria may be present in other products from the Magrudis factory in Sevilla. All its production has been recalled, with experts saying that at least 2 other products are at high risk of having been infected.\n\nAccording to the latest data from the Junta de Andalucia regional government, 186 cases of listeriosis have been detected. Of these, 161 have occurred in Andalucia. The bulk (82 per cent) are in the province of Sevilla, with 153 cases. In the last 24 hours, there have been 25 more cases in total.\n\nOf the 99 people in hospital on Fri 23 Aug 2019, 18 have been confirmed as having listeriosis, with 4 in intensive care. The rest are suspected cases and are under observation.\n\nMedical authorities say this strain of the bacterium is particularly virulent, taking 3 days to incubate. Normally, the incubation period is up to 70 days. [The incubation period, that is, the duration it takes for symptoms to develop, varies from 3-70 days, with an estimated median incubation period of 3 weeks. - Mod.ML]\n\n[byline: Dilip Kuner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 23 Aug 2019\nSource: El Pais [edited]\nhttps://elpais.com/elpais/2019/08/23/inenglish/1566555905_085334.html\n\n\nTests carried out on larding needles used by the Seville-based company Magrudis to make a pork loin product called carne mechada have returned positive results for the presence of the bacteria _Listeria monocytogenes_, according to documents to which El Pais has had access. This confirms that its processing plant is one of the infected sites behind the current outbreak of listeriosis that has so far affected 200 people throughout Spain, most of them in Andalusia.\n\nA 90 year old woman died in the early hours of Monday [19 Aug 2019] in a Seville hospital after having contracted the bacterial infection, while it emerged on Friday [23 Aug 2019] that a terminal cancer patient had died with listeria in his bloodstream. It is not yet clear, however, whether that patient's death was related to the outbreak.\n\nCarne mechada, the product produced by Magrudis that is thought to be behind the outbreak, the biggest ever seen in Spain, is made by cooking pork loin in its own fat. The lard is introduced into the meat using larding needles before it is cooked. It is then usually served cold and in thin slices. The company sells the carne mechada, along with other similar products -- such as lomo, preserved pork loin, and chicharrones, pork belly -- under the brand name La Mecha. Seville City Hall confirmed on Fri 23 Aug 2019 that 2 other La Mecha products have been found to be contaminated: pork loin with sherry, and pork loin with paprika.\n\nSpain issued an international alert on Thu 22 Aug 2019 with European authorities and the World Health Organization (WHO) 'given the possibility that cases might be detected in other countries' should tourists visiting the country have consumed the affected products. So far, no cases have been detected outside Spanish territory.\n\nIt also emerged on Fri 23 Aug 2019 that the carne mechada produced by Magrudis had been sold on to a firm called Comercial Martinez Leon for resale with a different brand name. The authorities were not aware of this fact until Tue 20 Aug 2019, 5 days after the initial health alert was raised. These products were in circulation until they were ordered to be withdrawn on Wed 21 Aug 2019.\n\nSamples were taken from the company's production plant last Friday [16 Aug 2019?], and the results were returned on Monday [19 Aug 2019?]. The analysis of the larding needles was the 1st to become public knowledge.\n\n'If the larding needles were contaminated, there is no doubt that other areas of the production line were too,' said Juan Jose Rodriguez, a professor at the Autonomous University of Barcelona and a member of the Spanish Society of Food Safety. Rodriguez explained that the 'larding needle is an instrument used to fill raw meat, meaning that the bacteria should not survive the roasting process, and the final contamination may have taken place during another moment on the production line.' He added that the results were 'worrying, because they reveal widespread contamination that was unknown to the heads of the company.'\n\nThis new information points to a 2-fold failure in the Magrudis production line, according to experts consulted by El Pais. The 1st, which has now been confirmed, implies a lack of hygiene in the processing plant itself. The 2nd is the failure to detect the contamination of the final meat products, despite existing legislation obliging such producers to carry out tests on at least 5 samples of every batch produced.\n\nThese rules mean that food-production companies must design and execute a plan to guarantee that their products are put on the market with no risks to human health. Each firm has the freedom to carry out such plans however they see fit, but they are subject to regular inspections from the health authorities.\n\nAs well as carne mechada, Magrudis also produces 8 more products at its plant. The regional government in Andalusia, known as the Junta, requested that Seville City Hall carry out tests on these products on Mon 19 Aug 2019 and ordered them to be taken off the market on Wed 21 Aug 2019, a move that sources from the Junta said were precautionary. The central Health Ministry in Madrid advised on Thu 22 Aug 2019 that consumers should not eat any of the products made by the Seville-based firm.\n\nOn Fri 23 Aug 2019, it was reported that 82% of new cases in Andalusia were registered in Seville. In total, there were 99 people receiving hospital treatment, 17 more than on Thu 22 Aug 2019. Of these, 31 are pregnant women. Four people are currently being treated in intensive care, one more than the previous day. Of those in hospital, 18 have been confirmed to have listeriosis, while the remainder of patients are still being tested.\n\nSocial alarm over the listeriosis outbreak has seen emergency rooms in Seville overwhelmed by an increase in potential patients. On Wednesday [21 Aug 2019] night, medical staff from the Virgen del Rocio hospital, one of the biggest in the Andalusian capital, dealt with 100 more people than usual, 23% above the average. The majority had symptoms of the bacterial infection, according to a spokesperson from the Junta committee managing the crisis. The pressure on medical teams is such that doctors are resorting to WhatsApp groups to request help to cover shifts and draft in reinforcements.\n\nDespite extra staff being drafted in, the wait times in the emergency room at Virgen del Rocio on Thu 22 Aug 2019 evening were as high as 4 hours, and the personnel at the hospital were overwhelmed. Zahara Palos, a 28-year-old woman, arrived at 3pm with symptoms of diarrhea and fever. She was not seen by doctors until 7pm. 'I'm desperate,' she complained. 'I want to leave here with a solution.'\n\n[byline: Simon Hunter]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak, which was previously reported to have affected 114 people (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (07): (Spain) meat, recall, fatal 20190821.6634032), is now said to involve 200 people, in many of whom the diagnosis of listeriosis may be as yet unconfirmed. The cases are occurring mainly in the province of Seville, but the outbreak may extend throughout Spain and even beyond. Listeria have been identified in at least 3 meat products and in needles used to inject lard into the meat before it is cooked; after cooking, the meat is usually served cold and in thin slices. Proper cooking of the meat should have killed listeria, which suggests either that the meat may have been improperly cooked or that contamination may have also occurred after cooking. All products from this meat processing facility in Seville have apparently now been recalled.\n\nBecause it can take up to 70 days after exposure to listeria for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.\n\nGenotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSpain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43]", "summary": "ML]\n\n[byline: Dilip Kuner]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nA 90 year old woman died in the early hours of Monday [19 Aug 2019] in a Seville hospital after having contracted the bacterial infection, while it emerged on Friday [23 Aug 2019] that a terminal cancer patient had died with listeria in his bloodstream. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak, which was previously reported to have affected 114 people (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (07): (Spain) meat, recall, fatal 20190821.6634032), is now said to involve 200 people, in many of whom the diagnosis of listeriosis may be as yet unconfirmed. \n\n[byline: Simon Hunter]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nSpain issued an international alert on Thu 22 Aug 2019 with European authorities and the World Health Organization (WHO) 'given the possibility that cases might be detected in other countries' should tourists visiting the country have consumed the affected products. \n\nOf the 99 people in hospital on Fri 23 Aug 2019, 18 have been confirmed as having listeriosis, with 4 in intensive care. \n\nSamples were taken from the company's production plant last Friday [16 Aug 2019?], and the results were returned on Monday [19 Aug 2019?]. The regional government in Andalusia, known as the Junta, requested that Seville City Hall carry out tests on these products on Mon 19 Aug 2019 and ordered them to be taken off the market on Wed 21 Aug 2019, a move that sources from the Junta said were precautionary. \n\nDespite extra staff being drafted in, the wait times in the emergency room at Virgen del Rocio on Thu 22 Aug 2019 evening were as high as 4 hours, and the personnel at the hospital were overwhelmed.
