LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (08): (SPAIN) MEAT PRODUCT, RECALL, FATAL\n**************************************************************\n \n\nBecause it can take up to 70 days after exposure to listeria for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected. \n\nThese rules mean that food-production companies must design and execute a plan to guarantee that their products are put on the market with no risks to human health. The company sells the carne mechada, along with other similar products -- such as lomo, preserved pork loin, and chicharrones, pork belly -- under the brand name La Mecha. \n\nSocial alarm over the listeriosis outbreak has seen emergency rooms in Seville overwhelmed by an increase in potential patients. Genotyping clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes will help identify clusters of cases that have a common source, and genotyping the isolates from the food and environmental surfaces at the meat processing facility will help confirm the source, if genotypes match. On Wednesday [21 Aug 2019] night, medical staff from the Virgen del Rocio hospital, one of the biggest in the Andalusian capital, dealt with 100 more people than usual, 23% above the average. \n\n'If the larding needles were contaminated, there is no doubt that other areas of the production line were too,' said Juan Jose Rodriguez, a professor at the Autonomous University of Barcelona and a member of the Spanish Society of Food Safety. \n\nAs well as carne mechada, Magrudis also produces 8 more products at its plant. It also emerged on Fri 23 Aug 2019 that the carne mechada produced by Magrudis had been sold on to a firm called Comercial Martinez Leon for resale with a different brand name. \n\nThis new information points to a 2-fold failure in the Magrudis production line, according to experts consulted by El Pais.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2019-08-21 00:00:00", "2019-08-22 00:00:00", "2019-08-20 00:00:00", "2019-08-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2019-08-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Junta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6736570", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (16): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6736570", "date": "2019-10-19 23:07:11", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (16): (GERMANY) FATAL, WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCING, MEAT, HEALTHCARE FACILITIES\n************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 18 Oct 2019\nSource: just-food [edited]\nhttps://www.just-food.com/news/german-local-regulators-under-fire-in-meat-listeria-scandal_id142454.aspx\n\n\nGermany's Federal Ministry for Food and Agriculture has summoned its state-level counterparts for crisis talks following revelations _Listeria_-tainted meat products have killed 3 people and made another 37 sick.\n\nThe ministry confirmed to just-food the talks will be held next Friday (25 Oct [2019]), aiming to improve identification of weak health control points, boosting cooperation between state health regulators and federal officials, including more exchanges of information. 'The federal government must know where the weak points are on the local level,' said food and agricultural minister Julia Klockner. 'The states must be willing to discuss stronger pooling of competencies in order to optimize food inspections.'\n\nThe meat products in question were made by Twistetal, Hesse-based Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren.\n\nUnder Germany's federal system, food inspections are the responsibly of the state-level governments, with the state of Hesse being harshly criticized for acting sluggishly after receiving a warning from the Robert Koch Institute, which on 12 Aug [2019] flagged suspicions of _Listeria_ in Wilke products.\n\nProduction was not stopped by the authorities until 2 Oct [2019]. Last week, the administrative court of Kassel rejected Wilke's plea to restore production, citing a report by the hygiene inspector: 'The room was filled with completely rotten products, mould, rot, reek ... on the floor was a reeking fluid.'\n\nSeveral Romanian workers employed by Wilke have since echoed these remarks in interviews to local press. The EU's Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF) identified 25 countries to which Wilke products were exported, including most member states, as well as Switzerland, the US, Russia, and Japan.\n\nGerman media reports have also suggested Klockner will urge state-level governments next week to increase expenditure in food safety inspections, including through the addition of personnel.\n\njust-food contacted Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren for comment but had received no response at the time of writing.\n\n[Byline: Jens Kastner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 12 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/u-s-sent-meat-from-german-firm-linked-to-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nThe United States is one of more than 20 countries that may have received meat from a German company linked to a _Listeria_ outbreak.\n\nPotentially contaminated products from Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren were distributed to the US, according to the Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF).\n\nFood Safety News has contacted the Food Safety and Inspection Service at the US Department of Agriculture for information. A spokesman said the agency was not aware of any potential recalls related to sausages imported from Germany, and Wilke is not certified as eligible to export to the US.\n\nOther affected nations include Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Latvia, Lebanon, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom.\n\nProducts made by Wilke have been recalled. German authorities are updating a document with affected products that is now 13 pages long. They can be recognized by the oval identification mark 'DE EV 203 EG,' which identifies the manufacturer regardless of the brand. Items could have been sold loose and to hospital kitchens and canteens.\n\nOfficials in the Waldeck-Frankenberg district of Germany stopped production at the facility in Twistetal, Berndorf in early October [2019]. The company has since filed for bankruptcy.\n\nAccording to the German branch of consumer organization Foodwatch, there was suspicion of _Listeria_ in mid-August [2019] and hygiene deficiencies at the factory found at the end of August [2019], but a follow-up inspection in September [2019] revealed these issues were mostly corrected. The group accused authorities of being too slow in crisis management and not sharing sufficient information.\n\nAtria, a retailer in Sweden, recalled all the dates of 6 products from the Wilke range. None of the salami products have tested positive for _Listeria_. Deli Drengene ApS in Denmark recalled snack sausages, as _Listeria_ was found at the production company in Germany.\n\nIn Luxembourg, some of the products were marketed in catering establishments. Authorities contacted the institutions concerned to check compliance with withdrawal measures, and initial results show recalls have been made. Official samples are being taken to do lab tests on these items. Based on current information, the direct distribution of products to the consumer did not take place.\n\nThe outbreak involves a _Listeria monocytogenes_ sequence cluster type 2521 (serogroup IIa). It was identified last year [2018] by whole-genome sequencing, and 37 people are involved from 12 German states. So far, no related illnesses have been reported from other European countries.\n\nIn 2014, 2016, and 2017, a few sporadic cases were found, which have been retrospectively assigned as belonging to the outbreak. One infection was recorded in 2014, 3 in 2016, and 4 in 2017.\n\nGenome sequences of the _Listeria_ isolates are closely related, so it can be assumed that patients have become infected by a common source, according to the Robert Koch Institute (RKI).\n\nIn mid-2018, there was an increase with 21 cases detected by genome sequencing at RKI. This year, 8 more infections were found with the last known disease onset date being 13 Jul 2019. Most people were infected by eating food in healthcare facilities.\n\nThe age range of affected people is between 31 and 91 years. There are 18 women and 19 men but no pregnancy-related cases. Three people are reported to have died with listeriosis as a contributing factor. Ten other people infected with _Listeria_ died but not as a consequence of listeriosis, and for one patient the cause of death could not be determined.\n\nThe Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) and the Federal Office of Consumer Protection and Food Safety (BVL) looked at supply chains and food samples. Investigations compared a _Listeria_ isolate from a food of the company near Hesse with patient isolates of the outbreak, finding a close relationship between them.\n\nIn 2018, 701 reports of invasive listeriosis in Germany were submitted to the RKI.\n\nElderly and immunocompromised people, expectant mothers, and newborn babies have an increased risk of contracting listeriosis. Symptoms of the infection can include vomiting, nausea, persistent fever, muscle aches, severe headache, and neck stiffness. The time between becoming infected and developing symptoms varies from a few to 70 days with an average of 3 weeks.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above describe a listeriosis outbreak that has affected 40 people, 3 of whom have died, in 12 German states between 2014 and 2019, due to _Listeria_-contaminated meat products manufactured at a processing facility in the German state of Hesse and widely distributed to more than 20 European countries, Switzerland, Russia, Lebanon, Japan, and possibly the US. The meat products were said to have been recalled, and the last known case has a disease onset date of 13 Jul 2019, more than 70 days ago. Listeriosis has an incubation period of up to 70 days, so the outbreak is possibly over, if the recall of contaminated meat products was complete. However, the Hesse production facility was not closed until the beginning of October 2019.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ by whole-genome sequencing identified the cluster of cases as having a common source. _Listeria_ was reported to have been found at the Hesse production facility, and a 'close relationship' was found between the_Listeria_ isolated from a food of the Hesse company and the clinical outbreak strain.\n\nWe are told that most people infected in this outbreak ate the contaminated meat products at healthcare facilities. Such people are at increased risk of disseminated listeriosis if they eat _Listeria_-contaminated food that is not adequately cooked before eating. We are not told specifically if the contaminated food was ready-to-eat cold cuts. Refrigerated cold cut meats that are not cooked before eating are well-recognized sources for listeriosis and should not be served to at-risk people. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to a sufficient number to cause disease. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nGermany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above describe a listeriosis outbreak that has affected 40 people, 3 of whom have died, in 12 German states between 2014 and 2019, due to _Listeria_-contaminated meat products manufactured at a processing facility in the German state of Hesse and widely distributed to more than 20 European countries, Switzerland, Russia, Lebanon, Japan, and possibly the US. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Source: just-food [edited]\nhttps://www.just-food.com/news/german-local-regulators-under-fire-in-meat-listeria-scandal_id142454.aspx\n\n\nGermany's Federal Ministry for Food and Agriculture has summoned its state-level counterparts for crisis talks following revelations _Listeria_-tainted meat products have killed 3 people and made another 37 sick. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nWe are told that most people infected in this outbreak ate the contaminated meat products at healthcare facilities. Under Germany's federal system, food inspections are the responsibly of the state-level governments, with the state of Hesse being harshly criticized for acting sluggishly after receiving a warning from the Robert Koch Institute, which on 12 Aug [2019] flagged suspicions of _Listeria_ in Wilke products. \n\nGerman media reports have also suggested Klockner will urge state-level governments next week to increase expenditure in food safety inspections, including through the addition of personnel. \n\nThe Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) and the Federal Office of Consumer Protection and Food Safety (BVL) looked at supply chains and food samples. \n\nFood Safety News has contacted the Food Safety and Inspection Service at the US Department of Agriculture for information. The ministry confirmed to just-food the talks will be held next Friday (25 Oct [2019]), aiming to improve identification of weak health control points, boosting cooperation between state health regulators and federal officials, including more exchanges of information. ' The United States is one of more than 20 countries that may have received meat from a German company linked to a _Listeria_ outbreak.\n\n According to the German branch of consumer organization Foodwatch, there was suspicion of _Listeria_ in mid-August [2019] and hygiene deficiencies at the factory found at the end of August [2019], but a follow-up inspection in September [2019] revealed these issues were mostly corrected. \n\nElderly and immunocompromised people, expectant mothers, and newborn babies have an increased risk of contracting listeriosis. The meat products were said to have been recalled, and the last known case has a disease onset date of 13 Jul 2019, more than 70 days ago. \n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ by whole-genome sequencing identified the cluster of cases as having a common source. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nGermany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101] \n\njust-food contacted Wilke Waldecker Fleisch- und Wurstwaren for comment but had received no response at the time of writing. _Listeria_ was reported to have been found at the Hesse production facility, and a 'close relationship' was found between the_Listeria_ isolated from a food of the Hesse company and the clinical outbreak strain. \n\nProduction was not stopped by the authorities until 2 Oct [2019]. \n\nAtria, a retailer in Sweden, recalled all the dates of 6 products from the Wilke range. [Byline: Jens Kastner]\n\n--\n [Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\n \n\nThe age range of affected people is between 31 and 91 years. Listeriosis has an incubation period of up to 70 days, so the outbreak is possibly over, if the recall of contaminated meat products was complete. \n\nProducts made by Wilke have been recalled. \n\nThe outbreak involves a _Listeria monocytogenes_ sequence cluster type 2521 (serogroup IIa). The EU's Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF) identified 25 countries to which Wilke products were exported, including most member states, as well as Switzerland, the US, Russia, and Japan. 17:05:59", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (07): (SPAIN) MEAT, RECALL, FATAL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2019\nSource: WTOP [edited]\nhttps://wtop.com/recalls/2019/08/woman-dies-in-spain-as-listeria-in-pork-outbreak-sickens-114/\n\n\nHealth authorities in Spain are on high alert after a 90 year old woman died amid a listeria outbreak in the southern region of Andalusia that has affected more than 110 people.\n\nJose Miguel Cisneros, director of the infectious disease department at Seville's Virgen del Rocio Hospital, on Tuesday [20 Aug 2019] announced the 1st casualty since the outbreak was declared on 15 Aug [2019]. Authorities have closed the pork meat supplier's plant and recalled all of its products. Cisneros said roughly half of the 114 people affected by the bacteria remain hospitalized.\n\nHealth minister Maria Luisa Carcedo said an investigation is looking into how the meat evaded what she called 'strict food safety controls'.\n\nListeria is a bacteria that usually causes mild illness in healthy people but can be dangerous to pregnant women and those with weakened immune systems.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak, which was previously reported to have affected 44 people mainly in the cities of Huelva and Seville (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (06): (Spain) meat, recall, alert 20190817.6627473), is now said to involve 114 people.\n\nHuelva, with a population of 144 258 residents, is a city located along the Gulf of Cadiz coast in south western Spain in the autonomous community of Andalusia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huelva). Seville, with a metropolitan population of about 1.5 million, is the capital and largest city of the autonomous community of Andalusia, located about 80 km (50 mi) inland from the Gulf of Cadiz coast (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seville). A map showing the location of Huelva and Seville can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Seville,+Spain.\n\nWe still have not been told the characteristics of the meat product involved in this listeriosis outbreak. Adequate cooking of the meat before eating should have markedly reduced the risk for listeriosis. However, refrigerated ready-to-eat cold cut meats are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination added only a few listeria organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _Listeria monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient number to cause disease. Refrigerated ready-to-eat meat products should not be served to people who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women, adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems.\n\nThe meat ('La Mecha' made by the Magrudis company, based in Seville) suspected to be the source has been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to listeria for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected.\n\nIn the USA and Europe, clusters of related cases are identified based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ that have similar genotypes. Food is confirmed to be the source if listeria isolated from it has a genotype that matches the genotype of the clinical outbreak strain. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak, which was previously reported to have affected 44 people mainly in the cities of Huelva and Seville (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (06): (Spain) meat, recall, alert 20190817.6627473), is now said to involve 114 people. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Refrigerated ready-to-eat meat products should not be served to people who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women, adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe meat ('La Mecha' made by the Magrudis company, based in Seville) suspected to be the source has been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to listeria for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases can be expected. \n\nListeria is a bacteria that usually causes mild illness in healthy people but can be dangerous to pregnant women and those with weakened immune systems. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (07): (SPAIN) MEAT, RECALL, FATAL\n******************************************************\n https://wtop.com/recalls/2019/08/woman-dies-in-spain-as-listeria-in-pork-outbreak-sickens-114/\n\n\nHealth authorities in Spain are on high alert after a 90 year old woman died amid a listeria outbreak in the southern region of Andalusia that has affected more than 110 people.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Huelva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6638985", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - North America: fatal, Canada recall cooked diced chicken", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6638985", "date": "2019-08-24 17:26:55", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NORTH AMERICA: FATAL, CANADA RECALL COOKED DICED CHICKEN\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 23 Aug 2019\nSource: Public Health Agency of Canada, Public Health Notice [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/public-health-notices/2019/outbreak-listeria-infections-cooked-diced-chicken.html\n\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada is collaborating with provincial public health partners, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and Health Canada to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections involving 3 provinces: British Columbia, Manitoba and Ontario.\n\nBased on the investigation findings to date, Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken has been identified as a likely source of the outbreak. Rosemount cooked diced chicken was supplied to institutions (including cafeterias, hospitals and nursing homes) where many of the individuals who became sick resided or visited before becoming ill.\n\nOn [18 Aug 2019] the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) issued a food recall warning for Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken meat '13mm - \u00bd' (hash 16305), packdate - 01/21/2019'. During the food safety investigation, the CFIA identified additional affected products, and updated food recall warnings have been issued. For additional details on all recalled product names and lot codes, please consult CFIA's website.\n\nCanadians are advised not to eat any of the recalled products or any foods containing the recalled products. Food service establishments are advised not to sell or serve any recalled products, or any items that may have been prepared or produced using recalled products.\n\nThe investigation is ongoing, and it is possible that more products linked to the outbreak investigation will be identified. The CFIA is continuing its food safety investigation, which may lead to the recall of other products. If other products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated food recall warnings.\n\nThis public health notice will be updated as the investigation evolves.\n\nInvestigation summary\n---------------------\nAs of [23 Aug 2019], there have been 7 confirmed cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ illness in 3 provinces: British Columbia (1), Manitoba (1) and Ontario (5). Individuals became sick between November 2017 and June 2019. A total of 6 individuals have been hospitalized. Individuals who became ill are between 51 and 97 years of age. The majority of cases (86%) are female.\n\nThe collaborative outbreak investigation was initiated because of an increase of listeria illnesses that were reported in June 2019. Through the use of a laboratory method called whole genome sequencing, 2 listeria illnesses from November 2017 were identified to have the same genetic strain as the illnesses that occurred between April and June 2019. It is possible that more recent illnesses may be reported in the outbreak because of the period of time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported to public health officials. In national _Listeria monocytogenes_ outbreak investigations, the reporting time period is usually between 4 and 6 weeks.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is also investigating an outbreak of listeria illnesses occurring in several states. The type of listeria identified in the USA is closely related genetically (by whole genome sequencing) to the listeria making people sick in Canada. Canada and US public health and food safety partners are collaborating on these ongoing investigations.\n\nEpidemiological information\n---------------------------\nFigure 1 [at the source URL] is an epidemiological curve for this outbreak. This information is used by outbreak investigators to show when illnesses begin, when they peak, and when they trail off. It can take several weeks from the time a person becomes ill to when the illness is reported and testing confirms a link to the outbreak. Data are available for 7 cases.\n\n[The Public Health Agency of Canada, Public Health Notice above has been abridged. The complete report is available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 21 Aug 2019\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\nhttps://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2019-08-21/eng/1566441064966/1566441070819\n\n\nUpdated food recall warning -- Reuven International Ltd brand Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) and Sysco brand Natural Proportions Cooked Shredded Chicken recalled due to _Listeria monocytogenes_\n--------------\nRecall date: 21 Aug 2019\nReason for recall: Microbiological - listeria\nHazard classification: Class 2\nCompany/firm: Reuven International Ltd\nDistribution: Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, Newfoundland and Labrador, Ontario, possibly national, Quebec, Saskatchewan\nExtent of the distribution: Hotel/restaurant/institutional, retail\nReference number: 13169\nRecall details\nOttawa [21 Aug 2019]: The food recall warning issued on [18 Aug 2019] has been updated to include additional product information. This additional information was identified during the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) food safety investigation.\n\nReuven International Ltd is recalling Reuven International Ltd brand Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) and Sysco brand Natural Proportions Cooked Shredded Chicken from the marketplace due to possible _Listeria monocytogenes_ contamination. Consumers should not consume and distributors, retailers and food service establishments such as hotels, restaurants, cafeterias, hospitals and nursing homes should not sell or use the recalled products described below.\n\nRecalled products\n-----------------\nBrand name / Common name / Size / UPC / Code(s) on product\n- Reuven International Ltd / Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) (hash 15307) / 4.54 kg / 907 63572 15307 1 / Packdate: 21 Jan 2019\n- Reuven International Ltd / Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) (hash 15807) / 4.54 kg / 907 63572 15807 6 / Packdate: 21 Jan 2019\n- Sysco / Natural Proportions Cooked Shredded Chicken (hash 15885) / 4.54 kg / 007 34730 21450 4 / Packdate: 21 Jan 2019\n\nWhat you should do\n------------------\nIf you think you became sick from consuming a recalled product, call your doctor. Check to see if you have recalled products in your home or establishment. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the location where they were purchased.\n\nBackground\n----------\nThis recall was triggered by findings by the CFIA during its investigation into a foodborne illness outbreak. The CFIA is conducting a food safety investigation, which may lead to the recall of other products. If other high-risk products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated Food Recall Warnings.\n\nThe CFIA is verifying that industry is removing recalled product from the marketplace.\n\nRelated recalls\n---------------\n23 Aug 2019: Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken recalled due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ (https://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2019-08-23/eng/1566606520256/1566606526124)\n\n18 Aug 2019: Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken meat recalled due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ (https://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2019-08-18/eng/1566177360394/1566177366791)\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 23 Aug 2019\nSource: CDC Investigation Notice [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/monocytogenes-08-19/index.html\n\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), several states, and federal partners are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections. This investigation is ongoing and has not identified a specific food item, grocery store, or restaurant chain as the source of infections. CDC is not recommending that consumers avoid any particular food at this time. Restaurants and retailers are not advised to avoid serving or selling any particular food. We will update our advice if a source is identified.\n\nLatest outbreak information:\n- Reported cases: 24\n- States: 13\n- Hospitalizations: 22\n- Deaths: 2\n\nA total of 24 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 13 states. Of 23 ill people with information available, 22 hospitalizations have been reported. In addition, 2 deaths have been reported.\n\n_Listeria_ specimens were collected from ill people from 20 Jul 2017 to 1 Aug 2019. Ill people range in age from 35 to 92 years, with a median age of 72. Sixty-three per cent of ill people are female.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada is also investigating an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections in several Canadian provinces linked to cooked diced chicken. Whole genome sequencing showed that the type of listeria making people sick in Canada is closely related genetically to the listeria making people sick in the USA.\n\nState and local public health officials are interviewing ill people to determine what they ate and other exposures they had before their illness started. CDC will provide more information as it becomes available.\n\n[The CDC Investigation Notice above has been abridged. The complete report is available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Canada, clusters of possibly related cases are identified based on genotypes of their clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that match. In the USA, these isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the listeria case report from patients in the cluster to identify a common food source.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source.\n\nIn Canada, a cluster of 7 cases, aged 51 to 97 years, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, identified by whole genome sequencing, occurred in 3 provinces between November 2017 and June 2019. Cooked diced chicken from 2 producers has been recalled and is identified as a likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn the USA, a cluster of 24 cases, aged 35 to 92 years, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, identified based on whole genome sequencing, occurred in 13 states between July 2017 to August 2019. The outbreak strain of listeria identified in the USA is closely related genetically by whole genome sequencing to the Canadian outbreak strain. However, the specific food item has not been identified as yet in the USA as the source of the infections.\n\nWe await further developments as the investigations proceed. Because of delays in reporting and the long incubation period of listeriosis of up to 70 days after exposure to listeria for symptoms to develop, more cases can be expected. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]", "summary": "\n\nLatest outbreak information:\n- Reported cases: 24\n- States: 13\n- Hospitalizations: 22\n- Deaths: 2\n\nA total of 24 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 13 states. \nBrand name / Common name / Size / UPC / Code(s) on product\n- Reuven International Ltd / Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) (hash 15307) / 4.54 kg / 907 63572 15307 1 / Packdate: 21 Jan 2019\n- Reuven International Ltd / Natural Proportion Cooked Chicken Meat (Diced) (hash 15807) / 4.54 kg / 907 63572 15807 6 / Packdate: 21 Jan 2019\n- Sysco / Natural Proportions Cooked Shredded Chicken (hash 15885) / A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n ML]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Canada, clusters of possibly related cases are identified based on genotypes of their clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that match. Extent of the distribution: Hotel/restaurant/institutional, retail\nReference number: 13169\n When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the listeria case report from patients in the cluster to identify a common food source. On [18 Aug 2019] the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) issued a food recall warning for Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken meat '13mm - \u00bd' (hash 16305), packdate - 01/21/2019'. The Public Health Agency of Canada is collaborating with provincial public health partners, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and Health Canada to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections involving 3 provinces: British Columbia, Manitoba and Ontario. Reuven International Ltd\nDistribution: Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, Newfoundland and Labrador, Ontario, possibly national, Quebec, Saskatchewan\n In the USA, a cluster of 24 cases, aged 35 to 92 years, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, identified based on whole genome sequencing, occurred in 13 states between July 2017 to August 2019. In Canada, a cluster of 7 cases, aged 51 to 97 years, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, identified by whole genome sequencing, occurred in 3 provinces between November 2017 and June 2019. \n\nThe investigation is ongoing, and it is possible that more products linked to the outbreak investigation will be identified. During the food safety investigation, the CFIA identified additional affected products, and updated food recall warnings have been issued. \n\nInvestigation summary\n [21 Aug 2019]: The food recall warning issued on [18 Aug 2019] has been updated to include additional product information. Source: Public Health Agency of Canada, Public Health Notice [abridged, edited]\n \n\nCanadians are advised not to eat any of the recalled products or any foods containing the recalled products. \n\nEpidemiological information\n Through the use of a laboratory method called whole genome sequencing, 2 listeria illnesses from November 2017 were identified to have the same genetic strain as the illnesses that occurred between April and June 2019. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n The outbreak strain of listeria identified in the USA is closely related genetically by whole genome sequencing to the Canadian outbreak strain. Recall date: 21 Aug 2019\n Based on the investigation findings to date, Rosemount brand cooked diced chicken has been identified as a likely source of the outbreak. Food service establishments are advised not to sell or serve any recalled products, or any items that may have been prepared or produced using recalled products. Source: CDC Investigation Notice [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/monocytogenes-08-19/index.html\n\n\n Source: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\n Cooked diced chicken from 2 producers has been recalled and is identified as a likely source of this outbreak. As of [23 Aug 2019], there have been 7 confirmed cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ illness in 3 provinces: British Columbia (1), Manitoba (1) and Ontario (5). LISTERIOSIS - NORTH AMERICA: FATAL, CANADA RECALL COOKED DICED CHICKEN\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1972-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2019-08-18 00:00:00", "2019-01-21 00:00:00", "2019-06-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Labrador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Newfoundland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6586028", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, smoked salmon susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6586028", "date": "2019-07-24 19:13:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, SMOKED SALMON SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jul 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-49094165\n\n\nTwo people have died from _Listeria_ infections in Australia after probably eating contaminated smoked salmon, officials say. A 3rd person also contracted the illness -- known as listeriosis -- but survived. The 3 cases happened in different states.\n\nLocal media reports that the contamination is believed to originate in Tasmania, which produces most Australian salmon.\n\nHealth officials warned people most at risk to avoid certain foods.\n\nThe people who died were both aged above 70 [years] and had underlying health conditions, said Australia's chief medical officer Prof Brendan Murphy.\n\nThe Tasmanian government said the state's salmon producers had been cleared of food safety breaches following the _Listeria_ cases in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.\n\nOfficials said pregnant women, the elderly, infants, and those with weakened immune systems were most at risk of severe symptoms. 'This is a timely reminder for people to ensure that food is handled, prepared and stored safely, and that those most at-risk of listeriosis avoid certain foods,' Prof Murphy said in a statement on Wednesday [24 Jul 2019].\n\nWhat is listeriosis? It can be caught from food containing _Listeria_ bacteria, or close contact with farm animals. Cases usually involve unpasteurised milk or dairy products, such as Camembert and brie. Pre-packed foods, including sandwiches and pate, can also contain _Listeria_. Symptoms include high temperature, flu-like symptoms, vomiting and diarrhoea. Most people infected display no symptoms, but elderly and very young people are vulnerable.\n\nLast year [2018], a _Listeria_ outbreak traced to rockmelons killed 7 people across Australia. Other nations have also seen recent outbreaks. One in South Africa killed 180 people and was said to be the worst in history.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables it to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating.\n\nEven if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria _ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _Listeria_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient numbers to cause disease.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "summary": "\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6627473", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (06): (Spain) meat, recall, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6627473", "date": "2019-08-17 18:49:32", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (06): (SPAIN) MEAT, RECALL, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 17 Aug 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/08/listeria-outbreak-in-spain-linked-to-meat-product-salmonella-warning-issued-for-mardrid/\n\n\nSpanish authorities have linked an outbreak of _Listeria_ [infection] that has affected more than 40 people to a brand of meat. La Consejeria de Salud y Familias de la Junta de Andalucia [The Ministry of Health and Families of Andalucia] reported those ill lived in Seville and Huelva and became sick in the past 3 weeks.\n\nThe agency connected illnesses to the product by interviewing patients. It has a commercial name of 'La Mecha' and is made by the company Magrudis, based in Seville. The item has been withdrawn from sale.\n\nLocal media reported that 44 people were affected. Half of them needed hospital treatment.\n\nPreviously, 16 _Listeria_ infections were noted in 2 weeks in the 2 areas of Spain. Health authorities reported 12 listeriosis cases in Seville and 4 in Huelva with 4 people needing hospital treatment.\n\nIt can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop. Symptoms of infection can include vomiting, nausea, persistent fever, muscle aches, severe headache and neck stiffness.\n\nPregnant women, the elderly, young children, and people who have weakened immune systems are particularly at risk of serious illnesses, life-threatening infections and other complications. Although infected pregnant women may experience only mild, flulike symptoms, their infections can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn or even stillbirth.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 15 Aug 2019\nSource: Diario de Sevilla [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=https://www.diariodesevilla.es/sevilla/listeriosis-Empresa-retira-mechada-investiga-contaminacion_0_1382861952.html&prev=search\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Families has issued a health alert on Thursday [15 Aug 2018] and has withdrawn from the sale and consumption a meatloaf manufactured in Seville, with the commercial name La Mecha, which has caused an outbreak of listeriosis that has affected 40 people.\n\nIn the last 3 weeks, 40 cases of listeriosis have been recorded in the provinces of Seville and Malaga. Some of these people were hospitalized. As reported by the Ministry, the alert has been issued after verifying that this product, manufactured by the Magrudis firm, domiciled in Seville, is the causative agent of the listeriosis outbreak. The health alert, activated after the development of the protocols and the appropriate inspections, means the withdrawal of said product from the sale and consumption.\n\nThe company that manufactures this meat, which according to the Ministry has maintained a close collaboration with Public Health during the investigation, has already communicated these facts to its clients.\n\nThe meat company La Mecha reported on Thursday [15 Aug 2019] that it has found anomalies in some items: 'After having detected anomalies in the preparation of some batches of our product, Mecha meat, La Mecha brand, we communicate that said product should not be consumed by our customers or final consumers.'\n\nListeriosis is an infection caused by bacteria that may be present in uncooked meats. It causes fever and acute gastroenteritis, and is especially serious in cases of pregnant women, children and people with previous pathologies. The services of the Virgen del Rocio, Macarena and Juan Ramon Jimenez hospitals are attentive to the occurrence of possible cases of this disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Huelva, with a population of 144 258 residents, is a city located along the Gulf of Cadiz coast in southwestern Spain in the autonomous community of Andalusia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huelva). Seville, with a metropolitan population of about 1.5 million, is the capital and largest city of the autonomous community of Andalusia, located about 80 km (50 mi) inland from the Gulf of Cadiz coast (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seville). A map showing the location of Huelva and Seville can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Seville,+Spain.\n\nThe 1st news report above does not specify the type of meat involved in the listeriosis outbreak in Seville and Huelva, Spain, although the 2nd news report above says that it is a 'meatloaf'. Elsewhere it has been characterized as 'shredded meat' (https://www.diariodesevilla.es/sevilla/listeriosis-Empresa-retira-mechada-investiga-contaminacion_0_1382861952.html). Adequate cooking of the meat before eating should have markedly reduced the risk for listeriosis. However, refrigerated ready-to-eat cold cut meats are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination added only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _Listeria monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient number to cause disease. This type of meat product should not be served to people who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women, adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems.\n\nThe meat ('La Mecha' made by the company Magrudis, based in Seville) suspected to be the source has been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases may be expected.\n\nIn the USA and Europe, clusters of related cases are identified based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ that have similar genotypes. Food is confirmed to be the source if _Listeria_ isolated from it has a genotype that matches the genotype of the clinical outbreak strain. We await further developments in the investigation of this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSpain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n This type of meat product should not be served to people who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women, adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. \n\nThe meat ('La Mecha' made by the company Magrudis, based in Seville) suspected to be the source has been recalled, but because it can take up to 70 days after exposure to _Listeria_ for symptoms of listeriosis to develop, more cases may be expected. The meat company La Mecha reported on Thursday [15 Aug 2019] that it has found anomalies in some items: 'After having detected anomalies in the preparation of some batches of our product, Mecha meat, La Mecha brand, we communicate that said product should not be consumed by our customers or final consumers.'
