Europe (05): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6601489", "date": "2019-08-02 13:58:26", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (05): (UK) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, MEAT SANDWICHES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Aug 2019 11:24 AM BST\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttps://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2019/08/01/six-death-listeria-outbreak-nhs-sandwiches-public-health-england/\n\n\nA 6th person has died from a _Listeria_ infection after eating NHS sandwiches, Public Health England (PHE) has confirmed, as they continue to investigate whether more people have died at dozens of trusts.\n\nIn June [2019], public health officials said 5 seriously ill patients had died, and 9 more infected, after eating food, which contained the deadly bacteria _Listeria_.\n\nOn [Thu 1 Aug 2019] they confirmed that 1 of the 9 patients infected has now died.\n\nPHE said it was continuing to test all samples of _Listeria_ on an ongoing basis to check if they are linked to this outbreak.\n\n'Our investigations continue and the public should be reassured that the risk continues to be low,' PHE said in a statement released.\n\n[Byline: Sarah Knapton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In June 2019 ProMED-mail posted a report of the deaths of 3 hospitalized patients in Manchester and Liverpool among a total of 6 patients affected in England in a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to pre-packed meat sandwiches that were served at the hospitals. The meat had tested positive for the outbreak strain of _Listeria_, presumably on the basis of matching genotypes, and the meat sandwiches linked to the outbreak were said to have been 'withdrawn' at the time. See ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe (04): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches 20190608.6510327.\n\nThe nosocomial _Listeria_ outbreak reported in the news article above is likely the same as the June 2019 nosocomial _Listeria_ outbreak. The appearance of new cases more than one month after recall of the implicated food can be attributed to the long incubation period of listeriosis of up to 70 days. We are told that there are now 6 deaths from a _Listeria_ infection after eating National Health Service (NHS) sandwiches among a total of 14 affected patients.\n\nIn the USA and Europe, clusters of related cases are identified based on clinical isolates of _L. monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid and placental or fetal tissue) having similar genotypes. Food is confirmed to be the source if _Listeria_ isolated from it has a genotype that matches the genotype of the clinical outbreak strain.\n\nRefrigerated ready-to-eat smoked salmon and cold cut meats, that is, food that is not cooked before eating, are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient number to cause disease. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk are other sources of listeriosis. These types of food should not be served to hospitalized patients who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In June 2019 ProMED-mail posted a report of the deaths of 3 hospitalized patients in Manchester and Liverpool among a total of 6 patients affected in England in a _Listeria_ outbreak linked to pre-packed meat sandwiches that were served at the hospitals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The meat had tested positive for the outbreak strain of _Listeria_, presumably on the basis of matching genotypes, and the meat sandwiches linked to the outbreak were said to have been 'withdrawn' at the time. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (05): (UK) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, MEAT SANDWICHES\n******************************************************************\n In June [2019], public health officials said 5 seriously ill patients had died, and 9 more infected, after eating food, which contained the deadly bacteria _Listeria_. These types of food should not be served to hospitalized patients who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems. \n\nRefrigerated ready-to-eat smoked salmon and cold cut meats, that is, food that is not cooked before eating, are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. \n\n[Byline: Sarah Knapton]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-06-26 00:00:00", "2021-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Liverpool", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NOSOCOMIAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6510327", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (04): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6510327", "date": "2019-06-08 14:12:53", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (04): (UK) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, MEAT SANDWICHES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-48557421\n\n\nThree hospital patients have died in an outbreak of _Listeria_ linked to pre-packed sandwiches. Public Health England (PHE) said the victims were among 6 patients affected in England and the deaths occurred in Manchester and Liverpool.\n\nSandwiches and salads linked to the outbreak have been withdrawn, and supplier The Good Food Chain has voluntarily ceased production. The BBC has approached The Good Food Chain for comment.\n\nTwo of the patients who died were being treated at Manchester Royal Infirmary. The 3rd patient was in the care of Aintree University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust.\n\nPHE said the sandwiches and salads affected are no longer being produced while investigations continue. It added the products were withdrawn from hospitals when the links to the infections were first identified.\n\nDr. Nick Phin, deputy director at the National Infection Service at PHE said: 'To date, there have been no associated cases identified outside healthcare organisations, and any risk to the public is low.'\n\nPHE said The Good Food Chain had been supplied with meat produced by North Country Cooked Meats, which subsequently produced a positive test result for the outbreak strain of _Listeria_. This business and North Country Quality Foods, which it distributes through, have also voluntarily ceased production.\n\nThe BBC has contacted North Country Quality Foods for comment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Europe, clusters of related cases are identified based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid and placental or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes. The news report says that 'meat', which was supplied by North Country Cooked Meats and used by The Good Food Chain to make sandwiches for hospitalized patients, was 'positive' for this outbreak strain of _Listeria_, probably on the basis of matching genotypes.\n\nRefrigerated ready-to-eat smoked salmon and cold cut meats, food that is not cooked before eating, are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Even if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria_ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient number to cause disease. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk, as well as milk and milk products contaminated with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization, are other sources of listeriosis. These types of food should not be served to hospitalized patients who are likely to be at increased risk for listeriosis, such as pregnant women (and their newborns), adults aged 65 years or older, and people with weakened immune systems.\n\nManchester (population 545 500 in 2017) and Liverpool (population 491 500 in 2017) are 2 cities about 31 miles (50 km) apart in northwest England. A map showing the location of these cities can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Manchester,+UK. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40]", "summary": "\n\nDr. Nick Phin, deputy director at the National Infection Service at PHE said: 'To date, there have been no associated cases identified outside healthcare organisations, and any risk to the public is low.'\n\nPHE said The Good Food Chain had been supplied with meat produced by North Country Cooked Meats, which subsequently produced a positive test result for the outbreak strain of _Listeria_. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Europe, clusters of related cases are identified based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid and placental or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk, as well as milk and milk products contaminated with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization, are other sources of listeriosis. \n\nManchester (population 545 500 in 2017) and Liverpool (population 491 500 in 2017) are 2 cities about 31 miles (50 km) apart in northwest England. Source: BBC [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-48557421\n\n\nThree hospital patients have died in an outbreak of _Listeria_ linked to pre-packed sandwiches. The news report says that 'meat', which was supplied by North Country Cooked Meats and used by The Good Food Chain to make sandwiches for hospitalized patients, was 'positive' for this outbreak strain of _Listeria_, probably on the basis of matching genotypes. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (04): (UK) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, MEAT SANDWICHES\n******************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NOSOCOMIAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liverpool", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6430200", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): fatal, deli-sliced meats and cheeses", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6430200", "date": "2019-04-19 17:56:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, DELI-SLICED MEATS AND CHEESES\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Apr 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/04/one-dead-in-listeria-outbreak-caused-by-deli-sliced-meats-cheeses/\n\n\nDeli-sliced meats and cheeses are to blame for a multistate outbreak of _Listeria_ infections involving 8 people, one of whom has died. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention late [Wed 17 Apr 2019] announced a state and federal investigation into the _Listeria_ outbreak is underway.\n\nBoth the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have joined the effort.\n\n_Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [13 Nov 2016], through [4 Mar 2019]. People confirmed with _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections range in age from 40 to 88 years, with a median age of 57 [years]. 38 percent are female. All 8 confirmed patients were hospitalized. Michigan officials reported 1 patient in their state died.\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that deli-sliced meats and cheeses might be contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ and could make people sick, according to the CDC.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about the foods they ate and other exposures in the 4 weeks before they became ill. Of 6 patients who have been interviewed by public health officials, 5 reported eating products sliced at a deli counter, including meats and cheeses. Delis where ill people shopped served many different brands of products and there is limited information available about the brands' ill people bought.\n\nFSIS and FDA evaluated records state inspectors collected from delis where the ill people ate to determine whether a common meat or cheese product was served at the delis. The analysis of the available documentation could not identify a common product. The FSIS and FDA will continue to assist with the investigation should additional information become available.\n\nThe outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ has been identified in samples from meat sliced at a deli, and from deli counters in multiple retail locations in New York and Rhode Island. Whole genome sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strain from these samples is closely related genetically to the _Listeria_ strain from ill people. This result provides more evidence that people in this outbreak got sick from eating deli-sliced products. At this time, the investigation has not identified a common product that was sliced or prepared in the delis.\n\nCDC's advice to consumers and retailers\n---------------------------------------\n- People who are at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection should avoid eating lunch meats, cold cuts, or other deli meats unless they are heated to an internal temperature of 165 deg F [74 deg C] just before serving.\n- If you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection after eating deli-sliced products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate deli-sliced products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n- If you have eaten deli-sliced products and do not have any symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection, most experts believe that tests or treatment are not needed, even for people who have a higher chance of _Listeria_ infection.\n- _Listeria_ bacteria can survive at very low temperatures and can spread easily to other foods and surfaces. Consumers should clean refrigerators, kitchen countertops, utensils, and other surfaces that touch deli-sliced products.\n\nYou can take steps to prevent _Listeria_ infection\n--------------------------------------------------\n- Don't let juice from lunch meat and hot dog packages get on other foods, utensils, and food preparation surfaces.\n- Wash hands after handling deli meats, lunch meats, deli cheeses, and hot dogs.\n- Store opened packages of meat sliced at a local deli no longer than 3 to 5 days in the refrigerator.\n- Retailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers frequently and other areas where deli products are prepared, stored or served. Staff should follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure they [are] effective.\n- Regularly clean food contact surfaces, equipment, and utensils in direct contact with deli products, such as cutting boards, tables, cheese slicers, and knives.\n- Make sure food contact surfaces, such as cutting boards, are smooth, sealed, non-porous, and easily cleanable.\n- The FDA website has printable materials and more information about sanitizing commercial deli slicers [https://www.fda.gov/Food/GuidanceRegulation/RetailFoodProtection/IndustryandRegulatoryAssistanceandTrainingResources/ucm240554.htm].\n- CDC will update the advice to consumers and retailers if more information comes available, such as a supplier or type of deli product linked to illness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Europe, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based of whole genome sequencing. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n If you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection after eating deli-sliced products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate deli-sliced products. ---------------------------------------\n- People who are at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection should avoid eating lunch meats, cold cuts, or other deli meats unless they are heated to an internal temperature of 165 deg F [74 deg C] just before serving. LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, DELI-SLICED MEATS AND CHEESES\n************************************************************\n \n- Regularly clean food contact surfaces, equipment, and utensils in direct contact with deli products, such as cutting boards, tables, cheese slicers, and knives. \n- Retailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers frequently and other areas where deli products are prepared, stored or served. \n- Wash hands after handling deli meats, lunch meats, deli cheeses, and hot dogs. \n\nThe outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ has been identified in samples from meat sliced at a deli, and from deli counters in multiple retail locations in New York and Rhode Island. \n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that deli-sliced meats and cheeses might be contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ and could make people sick, according to the CDC. \n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies -- the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) -- to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. Of 6 patients who have been interviewed by public health officials, 5 reported eating products sliced at a deli counter, including meats and cheeses. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA and Europe, the CDC identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes based of whole genome sequencing. If you have eaten deli-sliced products and do not have any symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection, most experts believe that tests or treatment are not needed, even for people who have a higher chance of _Listeria_ infection. \n- Store opened packages of meat sliced at a local deli no longer than 3 to 5 days in the refrigerator. \n\nFSIS and FDA evaluated records state inspectors collected from delis where the ill people ate to determine whether a common meat or cheese product was served at the delis. \n- CDC will update the advice to consumers and retailers if more information comes available, such as a supplier or type of deli product linked to illness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rhode Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6506263", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (03): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2014-19", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6506263", "date": "2019-06-06 09:34:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (03): WGS, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, FATAL, 2014-2019\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Jun 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/06/five-dead-from-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-fish/\n\n\nMore than 20 people are part of a multi-country _Listeria_ outbreak traced to fish and 5 have died since 2014.\n\nAn outbreak assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) identified 22 listeriosis cases caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_ sequence type (ST) 1247, clonal complex 8 through whole genome sequencing (WGS).\n\nBoth agencies warned new cases cannot be ruled out until the point of contamination in an Estonian food processing plant has been identified. It builds on an assessment from March this year [2019] when 18 cases were identified. At that time, the Estonian fish processor, a firm called MV Wool, denied the link.\n\nOutbreak cases yearly since 2014: Denmark has 9 cases, Estonia 6, Finland 2, France 1, and Sweden 4. The 1st case had symptom onset in July 2014 in Estonia. The most recent occurred in Denmark in February this year [2019].\n\n'Outbreak cases have been reported every year since 2014, with a small clustering of cases between the end of 2015, 2016, and 2018, and the start of the following year. Estonia, Finland, and Sweden reported cases in the 1st 2 years of this outbreak; since January 2017, all cases with the exception of 1 case in France in 2018 have been reported in Estonia and Denmark,' according to ECDC.\n\nOut of 12 patients for whom a food consumption history was available, 8 confirmed eating cold-smoked fish products.\n\nInformation on age and gender is available for 20 patients, with the median age being 76 years; most are older than 50, except for 1 neonatal case reported in 2014. 11 patients are male and 9 are female.\n\nFood and environmental investigations: _L. monocytogenes_ food isolates, matching the human outbreak strain by WGS, were detected at wholesale and retail level in France, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden from 13 batches of cold smoked or gravad salmon and from 6 batches of cold smoked trout products.\n\nIn 16 batches, _Listeria_ was detected at less than 10 colony forming units per gram (cfu/g), in one batch at less than 40 cfu/g, and in 2 cold-smoked trout batches, it was enumerated at 400 cfu/g and 570 cfu/g.\n\nTraceability information pointed to the Estonian firm MV Wool as the common manufacturer of fish products. Raw fish was received from suppliers in Norway and Finland.\n\nAs of [20 Mar 2019], the processing company can only release cold-smoked and salted fish products after the verification of 'absence of _L. monocytogenes_ in 25 gram', following a request from the Estonian authority.\n\nEnvironmental investigations and food testing at the Estonian processing plant showed _L. monocytogenes_ that matched the outbreak strain in 2 samples on the processing line and in 4 batches of final product.\n\n'The presence of _L. monocytogenes_ matching the outbreak strain over several years in the fish products suggests the persistence of the microorganism at the Estonian company's premises. Further investigation is needed to identify points of (cross-) contamination in the food processing plant,' according to ECDC.\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated, ready-to-eat products (that is, products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked fish or cold-cut meats, like ham or pork) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk, as well as milk and milk products contaminated with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization, are other sources of listeriosis.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable the organism to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. In past listeriosis outbreaks, _Listeria_ contamination of food products occurred in parts of equipment 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/). Even if equipment used in food processing only adds a few organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated ready-to-eat food, because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient size to cause disease.\n\nThis epidemiologic investigation shows the power of genotyping clinical and environmental isolates to confirm the source of an outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nFinland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/118\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "\n\nFood and environmental investigations: _L. monocytogenes_ food isolates, matching the human outbreak strain by WGS, were detected at wholesale and retail level in France, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden from 13 batches of cold smoked or gravad salmon and from 6 batches of cold smoked trout products. In 16 batches, _Listeria_ was detected at less than 10 colony forming units per gram (cfu/g), in one batch at less than 40 cfu/g, and in 2 cold-smoked trout batches, it was enumerated at 400 cfu/g and 570 cfu/g.\n\nTraceability information pointed to the Estonian firm MV Wool as the common manufacturer of fish products. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nFinland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/118\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100\n Listeria_ outbreak traced to fish and 5 have died since 2014.\n\nAn outbreak assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) identified 22 listeriosis cases caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_ sequence type (ST) 1247, clonal complex 8 through whole genome sequencing (WGS). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nEnvironmental investigations and food testing at the Estonian processing plant showed _L. monocytogenes_ that matched the outbreak strain in 2 samples on the processing line and in 4 batches of final product. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated, ready-to-eat products (that is, products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked fish or cold-cut meats, like ham or pork) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis. \n\n'Outbreak cases have been reported every year since 2014, with a small clustering of cases between the end of 2015, 2016, and 2018, and the start of the following year. \n\nOut of 12 patients for whom a food consumption history was available, 8 confirmed eating cold-smoked fish products. Even if equipment used in food processing only adds a few organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated ready-to-eat food, because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient size to cause disease. \n\n'The presence of _L. monocytogenes_ matching the outbreak strain over several years in the fish products suggests the persistence of the microorganism at the Estonian company's premises.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-07-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00", "1247-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ST", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6383386", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe: Denmark, fatal, WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, 2016-19", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6383386", "date": "2019-03-23 22:04:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE: DENMARK, FATAL, WGS, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, 2016-2019\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 16 Mar 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/tag/denmark/\n\n\nDanish officials have solved a _Listeria_ outbreak that had been ongoing for 3 years. Cold-smoked fish products imported from Estonia are the source of the long-lasting outbreak, which had made 9 people sick and linked to 2 deaths since 2016.\n\nStatens Serum Institut (SSI), the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (Fodevarestyrelsen), and DTU Food - National Food Institute reported that 2 of the 9 cases that became ill with the same type of _Listeria_ were in 2019. Luise Muller from SSI told Food Safety News that the 1st case fell sick in December 2016; 5 cases were reported in 2017, one in 2018, and 2 in 2019.\n\n'_Listeria_ found in product from the Danish importer is produced in Estonia; we don't know what happened in the production facilities there. We know it is at the Estonian producer, as it is not handled or repackaged in Denmark; it is only relabelled and sent to the Danish consumer. We cannot exclude that more cases could come, due to the long incubation period of listeriosis [up to 70 days],' Muller said.\n\nCold-smoked fish products have now been recalled by 2 Danish retailers. The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration advised consumers that the items should be discarded or returned to the store where they were purchased.\n\nThe Danish importer, Food With You, issued a recall of smoked trout after _Listeria_ was found. All dates of 'Vores Koldroget Roget Orred,' 200 g [7 oz], sold at Bilka and Fotex across the country, are affected. Dagrofa also recalled smoked trout due to the presence of _Listeria_. All dates from 14-27 Mar 2019 of Blue Ocean roget orred, 200 g [7 oz], sold at Meny stores throughout Denmark are involved.\n\nPatients include 4 women and 5 men aged 52-90 years who are spread across the country. Two people died. All patients in the outbreak had serious illnesses that put them at high risk for serious infections.\n\n'We know they died within 30 days from the positive test for listeriosis, but since they are all immuno-suppressed people or people with underlying disease, we don't know if they died from listeriosis,' said Muller.\n\nBased on interviews with patients and after finding _Listeria_ in samples taken from the Danish importer, the source of infection was traced to cold-smoked trout and salmon produced in Estonia. These items were sold in Denmark through 2 retailers: Salling Group and Dagrofa.\n\nMuller said whole-genome sequencing was used in the investigation.\n\n'The outbreak was declared in January 2017 when we had 3 matching cases. It is a part of our regular surveillance that we sub-type all human isolates to see if any of them are within the same cluster, and we interview all patients with listeriosis in Denmark regardless of the subtyping. So all this information has been revised along the way, but it is not until now that we have the exact source,' she said.\n\n'We are in dialogue with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and other countries to find out if there are any human cases or findings from food isolates in other countries, but this is ongoing at the moment.'\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Mar 2019\nSource: SalmonBusiness [edited]\nhttps://salmonbusiness.com/danish-agency-traces-fatal-listeria-outbreak-to-estonian-fish-processor/\n\n\nIn a call to SalmonBusiness, a spokesperson for the authority confirmed it believes it has traced an outbreak of listeriosis from 3 years ago to its source. The agency alleges that fish from Estonian company M.V.Wool are behind [the outbreak].\n\nThe prolonged _Listeria_ outbreak has been confirmed by Statens Serum Institut (SSI), the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, and the DTU Food Institute in a press release. The outbreak included 9 people aged 52-90 who, since 2016, have become ill with the same type of _Listeria_, including 2 people who died in 2019.\n\nAn inspection from September of 2018 showed that the Estonian processor's smoked trout products showed a _Listeria_ contamination of 40-570 units, while the maximum is 100.\n\nBased on interviews with patients and after finding _Listeria_ in samples taken from the Danish importer, the source of infection has been designated to be cold-smoked trout and salmon products produced in Estonia. The product -- Blue Ocean roget orred 200 g [7 oz] -- were sold in Denmark through 2 Danish supermarket chains, Salling Group and Dagrofa. Denmark sent Estonia a message through the European food and feed safety alerts system, according to which it has ordered a recall of M.V.Wool's frozen smoked fish products through its Danish reseller.\n\nLuise Muller from SSI told Food Safety News that '_Listeria_ was found in product from the Danish importer, which is produced in Estonia; we don't know what happened in the production facilities there. We know it is at the Estonian producer, as it is not handled or repackaged in Denmark; it is only relabelled and sent to the Danish consumer. We cannot exclude that more cases could come due to the long incubation period of listeriosis [up to 70 days],' Muller said.\n\nSalmonBusiness spoke to a representative from M.V.Wool who strongly disagreed with the accusation. This publication has sent the company several follow-up questions about the Danish authorities' findings.\n\n[Byline: Owen Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak illustrates the power of whole-genome sequencing (WGS) performed on _Listeria_ isolated from ill persons to identify a cluster of cases that have a common source, as well as the power of WGS performed on suspected food and environmental isolates to confirm the source. There may be additional cases associated with the outbreak strain in other European countries, which is the subject of an ongoing investigation.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable the organism to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that may be difficult to access.\n\n_Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated, ready-to-eat products (that is, products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked fish or cold-cut meats, like ham or pork) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis due to the fact that _Listeria_ is able to multiply at refrigerator temperatures. Refrigeration allows small numbers of _Listeria_ that contaminate food at the source to grow to sufficient size to cause disease. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk, as well as milk and milk products contaminated with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization, are other sources of listeriosis. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak illustrates the power of whole-genome sequencing (WGS) performed on _Listeria_ isolated from ill persons to identify a cluster of cases that have a common source, as well as the power of WGS performed on suspected food and environmental isolates to confirm the source. \n\n_Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated, ready-to-eat products (that is, products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked fish or cold-cut meats, like ham or pork) are well-recognized sources for listeriosis due to the fact that _Listeria_ is able to multiply at refrigerator temperatures. \n\nAn inspection from September of 2018 showed that the Estonian processor's smoked trout products showed a _Listeria_ contamination of 40-570 units, while the maximum is 100.\n\n \n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\n Cold-smoked fish products imported from Estonia are the source of the long-lasting outbreak, which had made 9 people sick and linked to 2 deaths since 2016. We know they died within 30 days from the positive test for listeriosis, but since they are all immuno-suppressed people or people with underlying disease, we don't know if they died from listeriosis,' said Muller. \n\nCold-smoked fish products have now been recalled by 2 Danish retailers. The outbreak included 9 people aged 52-90 who, since 2016, have become ill with the same type of _Listeria_, including 2 people who died in 2019. Based on interviews with patients and after finding _Listeria_ in samples taken from the Danish importer, the source of infection has been designated to be cold-smoked trout and salmon products produced in Estonia. \n\nLuise Muller from SSI told Food Safety News that '_Listeria_ was found in product from the Danish importer, which is produced in Estonia; we don't know what happened in the production facilities there. \n\n'We are in dialogue with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and other countries to find out if there are any human cases or findings from food isolates in other countries, but this is ongoing at the moment.' Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk, as well as milk and milk products contaminated with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization, are other sources of listeriosis. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE: DENMARK, FATAL, WGS, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, 2016-2019\n**************************************************************************** \n\n'_Listeria_ found in product from the Danish importer is produced in Estonia; we don't know what happened in the production facilities there. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\n [Byline: Owen Evans]\n\n--\n Statens Serum Institut (SSI), the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (Fodevarestyrelsen), and DTU Food - National Food Institute reported that 2 of the 9 cases that became ill with the same type of _Listeria_ were in 2019. Luise Muller from SSI told Food Safety News that the 1st case fell sick in December 2016; 5 cases were reported in 2017, one in 2018, and 2 in 2019. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-09-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-12-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DENMARK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6390799", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (02): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2016-19", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6390799", "date": "2019-03-28 20:48:23", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): MULTI-COUNTRY, WGS, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, FATAL, 2016-2019\n****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Mar 2019\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/multi-country-cluster-listeria-monocytogenes-st1247-five-eu-countries\n\n\nMulti-country cluster of Listeria monocytogenes ST1247 in five EU countries news epidemiological update.\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nECDC has identified a microbiological link between an outbreak of 9 _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST1247 cases in Denmark and 9 additional cases reported between 2014 and 2018 in Estonia (2 cases) Finland (2), France (1) and Sweden (4).\n\nIn Denmark, the outbreak investigation is led by Statens Serum Institut (SSI), the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration and the DTU Food Institute.\n\nWhole Genome Sequencing (WGS) analysis performed at the national level and by ECDC found all isolates from the 18 cases within 2 allelic differences from each other (core genome MLST using Moura scheme, 1540 of 1748 loci detected in all 18 isolates). The latest case was reported in Denmark in February 2019 (Figure 1). [Figure 1: Distribution of Listeria monocytogenes isolates by country and time of reporting 2014-2019 (n=18) is available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\nA large-scale study led by ECDC on whole genome sequencing shows that most [listeriosis] outbreaks such as this one remain undetected. The study, published in 2018, suggests that more than half of the severe listeriosis cases in the European Union belong to clusters, many of which are not being picked up fast enough by the current surveillance system.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ causes listeriosis, which primarily affects pregnant women, newborns, and adults with a weakened immune system. Listeriosis is a relatively rare but potentially severe food-borne disease that has been reported in increasing numbers in the EU/EEA countries since 2008. In 2016, 2536 cases were reported, including 247 deaths. [See moderator comments below]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The ECDC reported the following (https://ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/zoonotic-diseases-progress-has-stalled):\n'Cases of listeriosis decreased slightly in 2017: 2480 infections were reported, against 2509 in 2016. However, the trend has been upward over the past 5 years. The group most affected by the disease in 2017 was the elderly, particularly those over 84. In this age group, the listeriosis fatality rate was 24%, while overall in the EU, the infection was fatal for one in every 10 patients. The highest levels of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were detected in fish and fishery products (6%), followed by ready-to-eat salads (4.2%).'\n\nProMED-mail recently posted a report of this listeriosis outbreak in Denmark (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe: Denmark, fatal, WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, 2016-19). Whole genome sequencing (WGS) of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolates by the ECDC and EU countries have identified clusters of patients with _Listeria_ infection who have isolates with similar genotypes in 4 additional countries, which implies they have the same source. In Denmark, based on interviews with patients and after finding _Listeria_ in samples taken from the Danish importer, the source of infection for the Danish cluster has been designated to be cold-smoked trout and salmon products produced in Estonia.\n\nIn the USA, a similar system identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes. These isolates had been forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which had been submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance (https://www.cdc.gov/pulsenet/outbreak-detection/index.html). When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies - the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) - to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nEstonia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/117]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[The ECDC reported the following (https://ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/zoonotic-diseases-progress-has-stalled):\n'Cases of listeriosis decreased slightly in 2017: 2480 infections were reported, against 2509 in 2016. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n --------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nECDC has identified a microbiological link between an outbreak of 9 _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST1247 cases in Denmark and 9 additional cases reported between 2014 and 2018 in Estonia (2 cases) Finland (2), France (1) and Sweden (4). In the USA, a similar system identifies clusters of possibly related cases based on clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue) that have similar genotypes. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolates by the ECDC and EU countries have identified clusters of patients with _Listeria_ infection who have isolates with similar genotypes in 4 additional countries, which implies they have the same source. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. \n\nOnce a cluster is identified, PulseNet also works with other federal food regulatory agencies - the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA/FSIS) - to find isolates found in food monitoring programs that have similar genotypes, which would implicate them as a common source. \n\nWhole Genome Sequencing (WGS) analysis performed at the national level and by ECDC found all isolates from the 18 cases within 2 allelic differences from each other (core genome MLST using Moura scheme, 1540 of 1748 loci detected in all 18 isolates). LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): MULTI-COUNTRY, WGS, SMOKED FISH, ex ESTONIA, FATAL, 2016-2019\n****************************************************************************************\n \n\nProMED-mail recently posted a report of this listeriosis outbreak in Denmark (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Europe:", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2536-03-26 00:00:00", "2480-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-02-26 00:00:00", "1540-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2509-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "1748-03-26 00:00:00", "1984-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6353086", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada: (ON) choc. milk, post-pasteurization pump, WGS, 2015-2016", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6353086", "date": "2019-03-06 17:24:08", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CANADA: (ONTARIO) CHOCOLATE MILK, POST-PASTEURIZATION PUMP, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, 2015-2016\n************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 Mar 2019\nSource: Food Poisoning Bulletin [edited]\nhttps://foodpoisoningbulletin.com/2019/listeria-outbreak-pasteurized-chocolate-milk/\n\n\nUsually, when we write about an outbreak associated with milk, the subject is raw milk. But in the CDC's Emerging Infectious Diseases issue for [March 2019], a _Listeria monocytogenes_ outbreak associated with pasteurized chocolate milk in Ontario, Canada is the subject (1). That outbreak took place from [November 2015] through [June 2016].\n\nThe article states that listeriosis outbreak[s] associated with pasteurized milk are rare in North America, but, like all foods, dairy products can be contaminated with pathogens after pasteurization.\n\nA study conducted in the U.S. reviewed 83 fluid milk-associated outbreaks from 1990 to 2006; only one was attributed to _Listeria monocytogenes_ (2).\n\n[In the referenced journal article (1)], 34 people were sickened during this outbreak, but only people who lived in Ontario were studied. Illness onset dates ranged from [14 Nov 2015] through [14 Feb 2019] [sic, 14 Feb 2016]. A 2nd wave of illnesses occurred during the time frame of [11 Apr to 20 Jun 2016].\n\nPublic health officials considered several other foods during the initial investigation. The 1st [thought] was leafy greens were the problem, since a _Listeria monocytogenes_ outbreak associated with that food was ongoing in the U.S. and Canada at that time. Cheddar cheese was suspected, but the investigation ruled out that food. Finally, investigators suspected coleslaw, but that was ruled out too.\n\nFinally, investigators isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from expired bagged chocolate milk collected from the home of one patient. The outer packaging was discarded, so officials weren't sure of the brand name. The investigation revealed that exposure to pasteurized milk was reported by 60% of case patients in the 1st wave, and 75% in the 2nd wave.\n\nOn [3 Jun 2016], a retail sample of brand B chocolate milk produced at facility C was confirmed positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_. The brand was recalled. Isolates from the original sample and 3 positive samples of chocolate milk matched the outbreak strain by PFGE and whole genome sequencing. Investigators found the outbreak strain within a post pasteurization pump dedicated to chocolate milk.\n\nThe conclusions of this study [were] that more attention should be given to the design of equipment and maintenance programs. _Listeria monocytogenes_ can be persistent in an environment, and 'harborage sites' that contain the pathogen can be undetected by routine monitoring. Officials stressed the importance of obtaining thoroughly food histories and collecting food that patients ate or drank during the incubation period. Finally, officials also stated that any food product sold in bags, especially food with an inner and outer bag, should be labeled on both bags to facilitate traceback.\n\n(1). Hanson H, Whitfield Y, Lee C, et al. Listeria monocytogenes Associated with Pasteurized Chocolate Milk, Ontario, Canada. Emerg Infect Dis. 2019;25(3):581-584. https://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2503.180742.\n(2). Newkirk R, Hedberg C and Bender J. Establishing a milkborne disease outbreak profile: potential food defense implications. Foodborne Pathog Dis. 2011;8:433-437.\n\n[Byline: Linda Larsen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable the organism to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. In past listeriosis outbreaks, _Listeria_ contamination of food products occurred in parts of the machinery 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/).\n\nThe machinery involved in the listeriosis outbreak described in the news report above was attributed to a post-pasteurization pump dedicated to chocolate milk. This outbreak illustrates that listeriosis can be caused by ready-to-eat food despite being previously cooked or pasteurized. Even if machinery used in food processing only adds a few organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated ready-to-eat food, like chocolate milk, because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures.\n\nThis study also shows the power of genotyping clinical and environmental isolates to confirm the source of an outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nOntario Province, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable the organism to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. Even if machinery used in food processing only adds a few organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated ready-to-eat food, like chocolate milk, because _L. monocytogenes_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe machinery involved in the listeriosis outbreak described in the news report above was attributed to a post-pasteurization pump dedicated to chocolate milk. The 1st [thought] was leafy greens were the problem, since a _Listeria monocytogenes_ outbreak associated with that food was ongoing in the U.S. and Canada at that time. On [3 Jun 2016], a retail sample of brand B chocolate milk produced at facility C was confirmed positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_. Investigators found the outbreak strain within a post pasteurization pump dedicated to chocolate milk. Finally, officials also stated that any food product sold in bags, especially food with an inner and outer bag, should be labeled on both bags to facilitate traceback. Usually, when we write about an outbreak associated with milk, the subject is raw milk. Isolates from the original sample and 3 positive samples of chocolate milk matched the outbreak strain by PFGE and whole genome sequencing. The article states that listeriosis outbreak[s] associated with pasteurized milk are rare in North America, but, like all foods, dairy products can be contaminated with pathogens after pasteurization. In past listeriosis outbreaks, _Listeria_ contamination of food products occurred in parts of the machinery 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-02-14 00:00:00", "2016-02-14 00:00:00", "2015-11-26 00:00:00", "2016-06-26 00:00:00", "1990-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "cheddar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6294098", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: ready-to-eat pork patties, end of outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6294098", "date": "2019-02-04 12:50:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: READY-TO-EAT PORK PATTIES, END OF OUTBREAK\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: Barfblog [edited]\nhttps://www.barfblog.com/2019/01/4-sickened-outbreak-of-listeria-linked-to-pork-products/\n\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control reports that an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to pork products produced by Long Phung Food Products appears to be over.\n\nOn [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C Corporation of Houston, Texas, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might have been contaminated with _Listeria_ bacteria.\n\nDo not eat, sell, or serve recalled products from Long Phung Food Products. The full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release]. Recalled products are labeled with establishment number 'EST. 13561' inside the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] mark of inspection.\n\nRecalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018, through 16 Nov 2018]. These items were shipped to distributors and retail locations nationwide. Recalled pork products should no longer be available in stores but may still be in home freezers.\n\nWash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. Follow these 5 steps to clean your refrigerator [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html for specifics.]\n\nRetailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers and other areas where recalled pork products were prepared, stored, or served. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nAs of [29 Jan 2019], this outbreak appears to be over.\n\nA total of 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 4 states. _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017, to 24 Oct 2018]. 4 people were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. On 20 Nov 2018, 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products. Listeriosis has a long incubation period, which ranges from 3 to 70 days. 70 days after the product recall on 29 Jan 2019, with no additional cases of listeriosis linked to the outbreak, the CDC declared the outbreak over. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C Corporation of Houston, Texas, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might have been contaminated with _Listeria_ bacteria.
