Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak. \n\nRetailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers and other areas where recalled pork products were prepared, stored, or served. \n\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control reports that an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to pork products produced by Long Phung Food Products appears to be over. \n\nWash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. \n\nDo not eat, sell, or serve recalled products from Long Phung Food Products. LISTERIOSIS - USA: READY-TO-EAT PORK PATTIES, END OF OUTBREAK\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-29 00:00:00", "2018-11-20 00:00:00", "2019-01-31 00:00:00", "2018-05-21 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6226705", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (07): Norway", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6226705", "date": "2018-12-28 22:02:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (07): NORWAY\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 22 Dec 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/norway-reports-increase-listeriosis-december-51216/\n\n\nOfficials with the Norwegian Institute of Public Health report seeing an increase in listeriosis cases in December [2018], prompting a warning for high-risk groups.\n\nAccording to an official notice Friday [21 Dec 2018] (computer translated), 6 cases were reported this month [December 2018] when the country typically sees 1-2 cases a month.\n\nFour of the 6 patients reported in December [2018] are from Hedmark and Oppland. Health officials are working to identify if there is a common food source linked to the increase in cases.\n\nListeriosis is usually transmitted through food, especially long-life foods that are refrigerated and eaten without further heat treatment. Many of these food products are popular as Christmas foods and can be found at many Christmas parties.\n\nPeople in the risk groups for listeriosis (i.e., pregnant women, persons with impaired immune systems, and the elderly with impaired general condition) should, as usual, avoid food products that may pose a risk to _Listeria_ infection, says consultant Hans Blystad at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health.\n\nExamples of such food products are\n- Rakfisk;\n- Products made from unpasteurized milk; and\n- Soft and semi-soft cheeses, such as brie, camembert, and other molds, whether or not they are made from pasteurized milk.\n\nConsumption of food contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. Less commonly, persons outside these risk groups are affected.\n\nListeriosis can cause fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions, sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. An invasive infection spreads beyond the gastrointestinal tract. In pregnant women, the infection can cause miscarriages, stillbirths, premature delivery, or life-threatening infection of the newborn.\n\nIn addition, serious and sometimes fatal infections occur in older adults and persons with weakened immune systems. Listeriosis is treated with antibiotics. Persons in the higher-risk categories who experience flu-like symptoms within 2 months after eating contaminated food should seek medical care and tell the healthcare provider about eating the contaminated food.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hedmark is a county in southeastern Norway, bordering Sweden to the east and Oppland to the west. Hedmark is one of the less urbanized areas in Norway; about half of the inhabitants live on rural land (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedmark). Hedmark and Oppland are the only Norwegian counties with no coastline. A map of Norwegian counties can be found at https://bluerose.karenlmyers.org/wp/scandinavia/norway/.\n\nBecause _Listeria monocytogenes_, a Gram-positive bacterium that causes listeriosis, can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, _Listeria_-contaminated refrigerated, ready-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold-cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized as potential sources for listeriosis. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk are other frequent sources of listeriosis. However, the source in some outbreaks has been contamination with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization.\n\nSerotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95% of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf). Genotyping the clinical isolates from the 6 ill people, if they match, will establish that we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from potential sources will establish transmission pathways, if they match the clinical isolates. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNorway: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/107]", "summary": "\n\nExamples of such food products are\n- Rakfisk;\n- Products made from unpasteurized milk; and\n- Soft and semi-soft cheeses, such as brie, camembert, and other molds, whether or not they are made from pasteurized milk. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPeople in the risk groups for listeriosis (i.e., pregnant women, persons with impaired immune systems, and the elderly with impaired general condition) should, as usual, avoid food products that may pose a risk to _Listeria_ infection, says consultant Hans Blystad at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health. Dec 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/norway-reports-increase-listeriosis-december-51216/\n\n\nOfficials with the Norwegian Institute of Public Health report seeing an increase in listeriosis cases in December [2018], prompting a warning for high-risk groups. A map of Norwegian counties can be found at https://bluerose.karenlmyers.org/wp/scandinavia/norway/.\n\nBecause _Listeria monocytogenes_, a Gram-positive bacterium that causes listeriosis, can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, _Listeria_-contaminated refrigerated, ready-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold-cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized as potential sources for listeriosis. \n\nConsumption of food contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hedmark is a county in southeastern Norway, bordering Sweden to the east and Oppland to the west. Persons in the higher-risk categories who experience flu-like symptoms within 2 months after eating contaminated food should seek medical care and tell the healthcare provider about eating the contaminated food. Serotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95% of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf). Genotyping the clinical isolates from the 6 ill people, if they match, will establish that we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from potential sources will establish transmission pathways, if they match the clinical isolates.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-12-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oppland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hedmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6332766", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, nosocomial", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6332766", "date": "2019-02-23 14:58:46", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: (VICTORIA) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Fri 2019\nSource: 3aw Mornings [edited]\nhttps://www.3aw.com.au/dhhs-confirms-listeria-case-at-melbourne-commercial-meals-delivery-service/\n\n\nAn elderly woman has died and there are fears thousands of others may be at risk following a _Listeria_ outbreak. A caller tipped off the Neil Mitchell program about the outbreak at the Dandenong South commercial food caterer, I Cook Foods, which was later confirmed by the Department of Health and Human Services.\n\nThe business has been shut down while health authorities investigate. 'They have tracked it to facility, which provides meals on wheels,' Heidi Murphy explained.' They have closed the facility until they are satisfied it is safe.'\n\nThe potentially deadly contamination made headlines last year [2018] after being linked to rockmelon nationwide.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2019\nSource: The Age [edited]\nhttps://www.theage.com.au/national/victoria/meals-on-wheels-service-hit-with-listeria-outbreak-20190222-p50zlp.html\n\n\nA woman has died and thousands of people are at risk of _Listeria_ infection after the bacteria was detected in food from a southeast Melbourne catering company that supplies food to hospitals, aged care homes and Meals on Wheels.\n\nThe catering service 'I Cook Foods' has been shut down after the woman, who was in her 80s and from the eastern suburbs, died in Knox Private Hospital on 4 Feb 2019. The woman contracted a listeria-related illness while in hospital after being admitted for an unrelated condition in late January [2019], a health department spokesman said.\n\nA total of 6 positive samples of _Listeria_ were found at the company's Dandenong South kitchen during an investigation into the cause of the woman's death over the past 2 weeks. The I Cook Foods kitchen provides meals to patients at private hospitals including St Vincent's, Frankston and Knox, as well as Mercy aged-care homes and many Meals on Wheels providers across the state [Victoria, Australia].\n\nVictoria's acting Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said the potentially contaminated food was in circulation until Thursday night [21 Feb 2019?], meaning people may have been eating the food on Friday [22 Feb 2019?] morning. 'People who might've eaten it [on Thursday] or in recent weeks might still develop illness,' Dr Sutton said. 'Potentially thousands of people have been exposed. I don't want to see any more [deaths].' People who may have eaten the food have been urged to be alert for early flulike signs of the bacteria, which can cause blood poisoning and meningitis.\n\nSt Vincent's confirmed the 'potential receipt of listeria-contaminated food from a catering provider,' saying an alternative food source had been organised. In a statement, St Vincent's said its hospitals at Kew and East Melbourne had discarded all potentially contaminated food, and had started compiling a list of patients who had eaten the food between 13 Jan and 21 Feb [2019]. The hospital said it would begin contacting all patients immediately, prioritising elderly persons, noting the 'potential delay in _Listeria_ symptom development.'\n\nMelbourne Private, Knox Private, Frankston Private, Holmesglen and North Park private hospitals have also been affected. All the hospitals are run by Healthscope, which confirmed on Friday [22 Feb 2019] afternoon that aged care facilities at Ivanhoe and Clayton South had also been hit.\n\nAll affected sites have been ordered to throw out remaining food from 'I Cook Foods.' Dr. Sutton said health authorities were taking no risks in ensuring the potential outbreak was contained. 'We're taking an abundance of precaution ... this was a production facility for so many vulnerable people,' he said. Healthscope said all food deliveries from 'I Cook Foods' had been thrown out and any patients who may have eaten a contaminated meal were being contacted. Acting chief health officer Brett Sutton says one-third of people who are infected can die of [listeriosis] and the elderly or pregnant women are at risk.\n\nDr. Sutton said the health department was taking all necessary steps to ensure 'I Cook Foods' passed all tests before reopening. He said this could take weeks. Dr. Sutton was reluctant to lay blame at the feet of 'I Cook Foods,' saying an investigation was underway to determine exactly which part of the food-handling process was at fault for spreading the bacteria. He said potential compensation for relatives of the woman would be a matter for the caterer, adding the family was being supported by authorities in the wake of the tragic incident.\n\n[Listeriosis's] gestation period is about 2 weeks [actually, listeriosis has a long incubation period of up to 70 days. - Mod.ML], according to health authorities, meaning those who have eaten the supplier's food in the past fortnight are particularly at risk. Dr. Sutton said the bacteria was usually found in foods such as soft cheeses, sliced meats and fruits.\n\nThe department has started alerting other catering companies that their food may be contaminated. Yarra Ranges Council told The Age it had contacted about 100 people who received Meals on Wheels supplied by 'I Cook Foods' and told them to throw out the meals. Knox City Council said it had begun assisting Meals on Wheels customers with disposing of any food received since 13 Jan [2019], providing _Listeria_ fact sheets detailing symptoms.\n\nThough Mercy Place Rosebud was supplied with contaminated meals, none of the residents have fallen ill. 'No one's sick and all we had to do was get rid of the food,' a spokesperson for the aged care provider said. 'We would have known in a few hours if they'd had _Listeria_ so luckily it's all under control here. They'll just have a new menu for a few days while we find an alternative.'\n\nI Cook Foods did not respond to requests for comment.\n\n_Listeria_ is rare, but it can be extremely dangerous -- particularly to pregnant women and the elderly. Symptoms include fever, tiredness, aches and pains and headaches, but the infection can become life-threatening if not treated appropriately. Last year [2018] 6 people died and one woman miscarried after a [listeriosis] outbreak linked with rockmelon grown in NSW. There have been 2 cases of listeriosis in Victoria this year [2019] compared with 2 in the same period last year [2018], with 27 in total during 2018.\n\n'I Cook Foods' provides meals to the following organizations:\nMEALS ON WHEELS -- City of Ballarat, City of Booroondara, City of Whitehorse, Glen Eira Council, Kingston Council, Knox City Council, Monash Council, Yarra Ranges Council.\nHOSPITALS -- Frankston Private, Holmesglen Private, Knox Private, Melbourne Private, Northbank Private, St Vincent's East Melbourne, St Vincent's Kew.\nAGED CARE HOMES -- Fairway Hostel Aged Care Sandringham, Healthscope Independent Living Moorabbin, Mercy Health Ballarat, Mercy Health Rosebud, Yallambee Aged Care Traralgon.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above report the death of an elderly woman with listeriosis after hospitalization in late January 2019 for an unrelated condition. Listeriosis in this patient has been linked to the commercial food caterer 'I Cook Foods' in the town of Dandenong South (Australia), which supplies prepared food to multiple hospitals and other institutions caring for the elderly and 'meals on wheels' in the Melbourne area.\n\nThe 'I Cook Foods' website says that it produces foods that have its texture modified to varying degrees (soft, minced, pureed), although its appearance is made to conform to its original form, e.g., 'broccoli looks like a floret of broccoli, carrots look like carrot batons and roast potatoes look like slices of roast potatoes,' to enhance visual appeal for people with dysphagia (https://www.icookfoods.com.au/texture-modified-foods).\n\nReady-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold-cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized as potential sources for listeriosis. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk are other frequent sources of listeriosis. However, the source in some outbreaks has been food contaminated with _Listeria_ only after cooking or pasteurization.\n\nIn all, 6 positive samples of _Listeria_ were found at the company's Dandenong South kitchen during an investigation, but no information is given on types of food that may have been implicated, although all food items produced by 'I Cook Foods' have been recalled. Genotyping the environmental isolates and the isolate from the patient will confirm the association, if the genotypes match.\n\nDandenong South, with a population of 160 residents, is an industrialized suburb of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, 31 km (19 miles) southeast of Melbourne's central business district. Its local government area is the City of Greater Dandenong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dandenong_South,_Victoria). A map showing the location of Dandenong South can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Dandenong+South+VIC+3175,+Australia. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nVictoria, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nVictoria's acting Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said the potentially contaminated food was in circulation until Thursday night [21 Feb 2019?], meaning people may have been eating the food on Friday [22 Feb 2019?] morning. ' \n\n\nA woman has died and thousands of people are at risk of _Listeria_ infection after the bacteria was detected in food from a southeast Melbourne catering company that supplies food to hospitals, aged care homes and Meals on Wheels. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n In a statement, St Vincent's said its hospitals at Kew and East Melbourne had discarded all potentially contaminated food, and had started compiling a list of patients who had eaten the food between 13 Jan and 21 Feb [2019]. Listeriosis in this patient has been linked to the commercial food caterer 'I Cook Foods' in the town of Dandenong South (Australia), which supplies prepared food to multiple hospitals and other institutions caring for the elderly and 'meals on wheels' in the Melbourne area. \n\n'I Cook Foods' provides meals to the following organizations:\nMEALS ON WHEELS -- City of Ballarat, City of Booroondara, City of Whitehorse, Glen Eira Council, Kingston Council, Knox City Council, Monash Council, Yarra Ranges Council. In all, 6 positive samples of _Listeria_ were found at the company's Dandenong South kitchen during an investigation, but no information is given on types of food that may have been implicated, although all food items produced by 'I Cook Foods' have been recalled. St Vincent's confirmed the 'potential receipt of listeria-contaminated food from a catering provider,' saying an alternative food source had been organised. \n\nA total of 6 positive samples of _Listeria_ were found at the company's Dandenong South kitchen during an investigation into the cause of the woman's death over the past 2 weeks. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news reports above report the death of an elderly woman with listeriosis after hospitalization in late January 2019 for an unrelated condition. The 'I Cook Foods' website says that it produces foods that have its texture modified to varying degrees (soft, minced, pureed), although its appearance is made to conform to its original form, e.g., 'broccoli looks like a floret of broccoli, carrots look like carrot batons and roast potatoes look like slices of roast potatoes,' to enhance visual appeal for people with dysphagia (https://www.icookfoods.com.au/texture-modified-foods). \n\nDr. Sutton said the health department was taking all necessary steps to ensure 'I Cook Foods' passed all tests before reopening. Healthscope said all food deliveries from 'I Cook Foods' had been thrown out and any patients who may have eaten a contaminated meal were being contacted. \n\nReady-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold-cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized as potential sources for listeriosis. AUSTRALIA: (VICTORIA) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL\n*****************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< There have been 2 cases of listeriosis in Victoria this year [2019] compared with 2 in the same period last year [2018], with 27 in total during 2018.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-13 00:00:00", "2019-02-04 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-02-21 00:00:00", "2019-02-22 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2019-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "hospital", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NSW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ballarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Greater Dandenong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Park", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6159661", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): ready-to-eat pork patties, WGS, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6159661", "date": "2018-11-22 14:21:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): READY-TO-EAT PORK PATTIES, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, RECALL\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Nov 2018\nSource: CDC, _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) Outbreaks, Food Safety Alert [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/porkproducts-11-18/index.html\n\n\nCDC and public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA-FSIS) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to pork products produced by 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products.\n\nAt a glance\n-----------\nReported cases: 4\nStates: 4\nHospitalizations: 4\nDeaths: 0\nRecall: Yes\nCha Chien Fried Pork Patty\n\nRecall\n------\n- On [Tue 20 Nov 2018], 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products in Houston, TX recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might be contaminated with _Listeria_.\n- Do not eat, sell, or serve recalled products from Long Phung Food Products.\nThe full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release].\n- Recalled products are labeled with establishment number 'EST. 13561' inside the USDA mark of inspection.\n- Recalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018], through [16 Nov 2018]. These items were shipped to distributors and retail locations nationwide.\n\nAdvice\n------\n- Return any recalled pork products to the store for a refund or throw them away. Even if some of the product was eaten and no one got sick, do not eat it. If you do not know if the pork product you purchased was recalled, ask the place where you purchased it or throw it away.\n- Wash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. Follow the 5 steps [at https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html] to clean your refrigerator.\n- Retailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers and other areas where recalled pork products were prepared, stored, or served. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n- If you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nLatest outbreak information\n---------------------------\n- 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 4 states.\n- _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017], to [24 Oct 2018].\n- 4 people have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n- Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products are a likely source of the outbreak.\n- On [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might be contaminated with _Listeria_.\n- This investigation is ongoing, and CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\nGeneral _Listeria_ information\n------------------------------\n- If you have eaten recalled pork products and do not have any symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection, most experts believe that tests or treatment are not needed, even for people who have a higher chance of _Listeria_.\n- In general, people who are at higher risk for _Listeria_ infection should not eat refrigerated pate or meat spreads from a deli or meat counter or from the refrigerated section of a store. Avoid eating hot dogs, lunch meats, cold cuts, other deli meats (such as bologna), or fermented or dry sausages unless they are heated to an internal temperature of 165 deg F [74 deg C] or until steaming hot just before serving.\n- Foods that do not need refrigeration, like canned or shelf-stable pate and meat spreads, are safe to eat. Refrigerate these foods after opening.\n- Learn more about how you can take steps to prevent _Listeria_ infection.\n\nSymptoms of _Listeria_ infection\n--------------------------------\n- Listeriosis can cause a variety of symptoms, depending on the person and the part of the body affected.\n- Pregnant women: pregnant women typically experience only fever and other flu-like symptoms, such as fatigue and muscle aches. However, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery, or life-threatening infection of the newborn.\n- People other than pregnant women: symptoms can include headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions in addition to fever and muscle aches.\n- People with invasive listeriosis usually report symptoms starting 1 to 4 weeks after eating food contaminated with _Listeria_; some people have reported symptoms starting as late as 70 days after exposure or as early as the same day of exposure. Listeriosis is treated with antibiotics.\n- Pregnant women and their newborns, adults age 65 and older, and people with weakened immune systems are more likely to get sick with listeriosis.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n21 Nov 2018\n-----------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA-FSIS) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections.\n\nPublic health investigators are using the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that may be part of this outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA fingerprinting is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using a technique called whole genome sequencing (WGS). CDC PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS performed on bacteria isolated from ill people showed that they were closely relatedly genetically. This means that people in this outbreak are more likely to share a common source of infection.\n\nAs of [20 Nov 2018], 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from four states. A list of the states and the number of cases in each can be found on the Map of Reported Cases page [at https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/porkproducts-11-18/map.html].\n\n_Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017 to 24 Oct 2018]. Ill people range in age from 35 to 84 years, with a median age of 60 years. All 4 ill people are female, and all 4 ill people were hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 10 weeks. Please see the Timeline for Reporting Cases of _Listeria_ Infection for more details.\n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n-------------------------------------\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products in Houston, TX is a likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about the foods they ate and other exposures in the 4 weeks before they became ill. 4 people were interviewed and all 4 reported eating Asian-style foods. 3 ill people reported shopping at stores where Long Phung Food Products are sold.\n\nWhole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ from ill people. These results provide more evidence that ill people became sick from eating contaminated pork products.\n\nOn [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products recalled ready-to-eat pork products (https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release) because they might be contaminated with _Listeria_ bacteria. Recalled pork products were produced from [21 May 2018], through [16 Nov 2018]. Consumers should return them to the store for a refund or throw them away. Restaurants and retailers should not serve or sell recalled Long Phung Food products.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing, and CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated ready-to eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold cut meats, like ham or pork, are well-recognized sources for listeriosis, due to the fact that _Listeria_ is able to multiply at refrigerator temperatures.\n\nAn epidemiologic investigation has identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis, in 4 states linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. On 20 Nov 2018, 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products recalled ready-to-eat pork products. New cases of listeriosis may continue to occur due either to delays in reporting, failure to discard _Listeria_-contaminated pork patties despite the recall, and the prolonged incubation period of up to 70 days. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "Recall: Yes\nCha Chien Fried Pork Patty\n\nRecall\n------\n- On [Tue 20 Nov 2018], 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products in Houston, TX recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might be contaminated with _Listeria_.\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n -----------\nReported cases: 4\nStates: 4\nHospitalizations: \n- People with invasive listeriosis usually report symptoms starting 1 to 4 weeks after eating food contaminated with _Listeria_; some people have reported symptoms starting as late as 70 days after exposure or as early as the same day of exposure. These results provide more evidence that ill people became sick from eating contaminated pork products. -----------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (USDA-FSIS) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. \n- 4 people have been hospitalized. \n- Recalled products are labeled with establishment number 'EST. Recalled pork products were produced from [21 May 2018], through [16 Nov 2018]. \n\nLatest outbreak information\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2018-11-20 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/porkproducts-11-18/map.html", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6090754", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (05): fatal, cantaloupe, heavy rainfall, dust storm", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6090754", "date": "2018-10-14 21:32:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (05): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, HEAVY RAINFALL, DUST STORM\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 13 Oct 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/10/weather-played-role-in-deadly-australian-listeria-melon-outbreak/\n\n\nAn investigation into a _Listeria_ outbreak in Australia linked to 7 deaths has found that the weather played a significant role in contamination.\n\nThe outbreak from rockmelons, known as cantaloupe in North America, affected 22 people with 6 cases in New South Wales (NSW), 8 cases in Victoria, 7 in Queensland and one in Tasmania between 16 Jan and 10 Apr this year [2018]. Seven people died, and one case resulted in a miscarriage.\n\nGovernment officials said the outbreak was linked to one grower named as Rombola Family Farms (RFF), based in Nericon in the state.\n\nThe strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that caused infections was related by whole genome sequencing to isolates from samples taken from 37 rockmelons from the farm. _Listeria_ also was found on the floor around the melon packing area and from a composite swab of washed melons. All _Listeria_-positives were identified as the outbreak strain.\n\nRockmelons are grown off the ground on plastic sheeting but are in the open farm environment and subject to rain, wind and other natural contamination.\n\nA NSW Department of Primary Industries (DPI) report found that hygiene and sanitation practices at Rombola Family Farms were on par with, or better than, most other rockmelon growers in Australia.\n\nAdverse weather events listed as heavy rainfall in December 2017 prior to harvest, followed by dust storms, were blamed for increasing the organic load and amount of _Listeria_ on rockmelons prior to harvest. Another issue is the netted skin of the fruit, making it harder to clean and sanitize.\n\n'Prior to the detection of the outbreak, RFF utilized a one minute and 30-40 second pre-wash and scrubbing step to reduce organic load, followed by a 35 second sanitizing step of 100 ppm chlorine sprays and scrubbing,' said the NSW DPI report.\n\n'It is likely that the 35 seconds at 100 ppm sanitizing step was effective in reducing _Listeria monocytogenes_ to a very low level, but these levels still resulted in illness when rockmelons were consumed by immunocompromised individuals.'\n\nWash water was not recirculated; sanitizer was constantly monitored and applied through an auto-dosing system, and all water coming into the facility was treated and considered potable, the report says.\n\nDirty fans used to reduce moisture levels on melons after washing and some spongy material on packing tables that was not easily cleaned may have been contributing factors to the outbreak but are not considered to be major underlying causes, investigators reported.\n\nNSW Food Authority inspections found that there was an opportunity for introduction of _Listeria_ after washing through contact with surfaces or equipment that may have had traces of the pathogen. This included dust blown from fans to dry the fruit after washing and from porous material on packing tables that was not able to be effectively cleaned.\n\n'During the investigation, there was an allegation of raw organic fertilizer use on the rockmelon crop, which was found to be incorrect,' the agency report said.\n\nThe business resumed harvesting and packing in early April 2018, and no _Listeria monocytogenes_ has been detected on any fruit since then.\n\nRombola Family Farms has made line modifications to improve cleaning, increased cleaning and sanitizing of the packing line environment and sanitizer concentration during washing of melons.\n\n'The rockmelon pre-wash was dosed with 200 ppm chlorine water during use. Similarly, the concentration of chlorine in the sanitizer wash step was increased to 200 ppm. This gives a total contact time for chlorine of over 2 minutes,' according to the NSW DPI report.\n\n'The fungicide tank and post wash drying fans have been made more accessible and easily cleaned. Black sponge material on the packing table has been removed and replaced with more suitable material.'\n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report says heavy rainfall and dust storms resulted in _Listeria moncytogenes_ contamination of rockmelons (also called cantaloupe) produced by a specific grower, Rombola Family Farms in southern New South Wales, Australia. As a result, 22 individuals in Australia were infected between Jan and April 2018 by eating the contaminated melons. Seven infected individuals died, and one miscarried.\n\n_Listeria_ is a fecal organism of farm animals and humans and is found in grazing land and farmland that has been fertilized with manure. _Listeria_ can survive for up to 84 days in some soils (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0075969). Raw organic fertilizer was reportedly not used at the Rombola farm. However, because cantaloupes grow on vines on the ground, even if separated from the soil by plastic sheeting as was the case at the Rombola farm, cantaloupe could possibly be susceptible to contamination with bacteria from animal feces in soil that was carried from surrounding grazing land or farmland by heavy rainwater runoff or dust storms.\n\nCantaloupe could also become contaminated in processing facilities if _Listeria_ are brought into the facility by a dust storm or on the soles of workers' shoes, or if the facility is flooded by heavy rain runoff. In fact, the outbreak stain of _Listeria_ was found on the floor around the Rombola melon packing area. Cantaloupe's rough surface could then impede effective cleaning. However, inspectors at the Rombola farm found there was an opportunity for introduction of _Listeria_ after washing cantaloupe through contact with surfaces or equipment that may have had traces of the pathogen. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "summary": "\n\n'Prior to the detection of the outbreak, RFF utilized a one minute and 30-40 second pre-wash and scrubbing step to reduce organic load, followed by a 35 second sanitizing step of 100 ppm chlorine sprays and scrubbing,' said the NSW DPI report. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDirty fans used to reduce moisture levels on melons after washing and some spongy material on packing tables that was not easily cleaned may have been contributing factors to the outbreak but are not considered to be major underlying causes, investigators reported. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report says heavy rainfall and dust storms resulted in _Listeria moncytogenes_ contamination of rockmelons (also called cantaloupe) produced by a specific grower, Rombola Family Farms in southern New South Wales, Australia. \n\nAdverse weather events listed as heavy rainfall in December 2017 prior to harvest, followed by dust storms, were blamed for increasing the organic load and amount of _Listeria_ on rockmelons prior to harvest. \n\n'It is likely that the 35 seconds at 100 ppm sanitizing step was effective in reducing _Listeria monocytogenes_ to a very low level, but these levels still resulted in illness when rockmelons were consumed by immunocompromised individuals.' \n\nThe outbreak from rockmelons, known as cantaloupe in North America, affected 22 people with 6 cases in New South Wales (NSW), 8 cases in Victoria, 7 in Queensland and one in Tasmania between 16 Jan and 10 Apr this year [2018]. \n\n[Byline: Joe Whitworth]\n\n--\n \n\nWash water was not recirculated; sanitizer was constantly monitored and applied through an auto-dosing system, and all water coming into the facility was treated and considered potable, the report says. However, because cantaloupes grow on vines on the ground, even if separated from the soil by plastic sheeting as was the case at the Rombola farm, cantaloupe could possibly be susceptible to contamination with bacteria from animal feces in soil that was carried from surrounding grazing land or farmland by heavy rainwater runoff or dust storms. \n\n'During the investigation, there was an allegation of raw organic fertilizer use on the rockmelon crop, which was found to be incorrect,' the agency report said. \n\nCantaloupe could also become contaminated in processing facilities if _Listeria_ are brought into the facility by a dust storm or on the soles of workers' shoes, or if the facility is flooded by heavy rain runoff. \n\nRockmelons are grown off the ground on plastic sheeting but are in the open farm environment and subject to rain, wind and other natural contamination. \n\nNSW Food Authority inspections found that there was an opportunity for introduction of _Listeria_ after washing through contact with surfaces or equipment that may have had traces of the pathogen.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nericon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6075737", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): fatal, ham, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6075737", "date": "2018-10-07 10:47:28", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, HAM, RECALL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 5 Oct 2018\nSource: Rye Daily Voice [edited]\nhttp://rye.dailyvoice.com/lifestyle/listeria-scare-leads-to-recall-of-89000-pounds-of-ham-products/742886/\n\n\nJohnston County Hams is recalling approximately 89 096 pounds of ready-to-eat ham products that may contain _Listeria monocytogenes_, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS). The recall was announced after several people fell ill and one died.\n\nThe recall includes products that were produced between 3 Apr last year [2017] and 2 Oct this year [2018]. 'The epidemiologic investigation identified a total of 4 listeriosis-confirmed illnesses, including one death, between 8 Jul 2017, and 11 Aug 2018,' the recall announcement said.\n\nAmong the products recalled include:\n- 'Johnston County Hams, Inc. Country Style Fully Cooked Boneless Deli Ham;'\n- 'Ole Fashioned Sugar Cured Old Dominion Brand Hams Premium Fully-Cooked Country Ham' with sell-by dates between 10 Apr and 19 Sep 2018;\n- 'Padow's Hams and Deli, Inc. Fully Cooked Country Ham Boneless Glazed with Brown Sugar;'\n- 'Premium Fully Cooked Country Ham Less Salt Distributed By Valley Country Hams LLC' with sell-by dates from 10 Apr 2018, through 27 Sep 2019, and;\n- 'Goodnight Brothers Country Ham Boneless Fully Cooked.'\n\nThe labels of the potentially tainted products can be found here [see source URL]. The recalled products have the establishment number 'EST. M2646' inside the USDA mark of inspection. The recall came after the FSIS was notified that a person was ill with listeriosis on 27 Sep [2018] after consuming a ham product produced at Johnston County Hams.\n\nOfficials said that 'working in conjunction with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and state public health and agriculture partners, FSIS determined that there is a link between the _Listeria monocytogenes_ illnesses and ham products produced at Johnston County Hams.'\n\nAccording to the FSIS, consumption of food contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. Less commonly, persons outside these risk groups are affected.\n\n'Listeriosis can cause fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance and convulsions sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. An invasive infection spreads beyond the gastrointestinal tract. In pregnant women, the infection can cause miscarriages, stillbirths, premature delivery or life-threatening infection of the newborn. In addition, there can be serious and sometimes fatal infections in older adults and persons with weakened immune systems.'\n\n[Byline: Zak Failla, Joe Lombardi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The epidemiologic investigation has identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis, including one death, between 8 Jul 2017 and 11 Aug 2018. Whole genome sequencing of isolates from 2 deli ham product samples collected at the Johnston County Hams, Inc. facility in 2016 and in early 2018 has been reported to show that _Listeria monocytogenes_ identified in deli ham both years was closely related genetically to _L. monocytogenes_ from outbreak patients (https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-084-2018-release).\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is able to multiply at refrigerator temperatures. _Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated ready-to eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold cut meats, such as ham, are recognized potential sources for listeriosis. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n , Inc. Fully Cooked Country Ham Boneless Glazed with Brown Sugar;'\n- 'Premium Fully Cooked Country Ham Less Salt Distributed By Valley Country Hams LLC' with sell-by dates from 10 Apr 2018, through 27 Sep 2019, and;\n- 'Goodnight Brothers Country Ham Boneless Fully Cooked.' LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, HAM, RECALL\n******************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The epidemiologic investigation has identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis, including one death, between 8 Jul 2017 and 11 Aug 2018. The epidemiologic investigation identified a total of 4 listeriosis-confirmed illnesses, including one death, between 8 Jul 2017, and 11 Aug 2018,' the recall announcement said. According to the FSIS, consumption of food contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. \n\n[Byline: Zak Failla, Joe Lombardi]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-09-27 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-08-11 00:00:00", "2018-09-19 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Johnston County Hams", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6122165", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (06): WGS, smoked/marinated salmon from Poland, 2015-18", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6122165", "date": "2018-10-31 13:30:30", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (06): FATAL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, SMOKED AND MARINATED SALMON FROM POLAND, 2015-2018\n*************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2018\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/multi-country-outbreak-listeria-monocytogenes-infections-linked-consumption-salmon\n\n\nReady-to-eat salmon products, such as cold-smoked and marinated salmon, are the likely source of an outbreak of listeriosis that has affected Denmark, Germany, and France since 2015. 12 cases, including 4 deaths, matched the outbreak strain identified by whole genome sequencing (WGS). A previous investigation and new WGS findings suggests a common source of contamination, states the latest report by ECDC and the European Food and Safety Authority (EFSA).\n\nWGS-based analysis identified 12 patients with onset of symptoms between October 2015 and May 2018: 6 in Denmark, 1 in France, and 5 in Germany. The 1st cluster of cases reported by Denmark in September 2017 was linked to the consumption of salmon products produced in Poland.\n\nInitial investigations suggested that contamination may have taken place at a Polish processing company but the lack of recent WGS data on the _Listeria monocytogenes_-isolates collected at the processing plant make it impossible to confirm this is the case.\n\nAlthough control measures were implemented following the Danish outbreak investigation in September 2017, the same strain was found in a salmon product in France in October 2017 and in a patient in Germany in May 2018. This suggests that the source of contamination may still be active and that contaminated products may have been distributed to more EU countries. Until the source of contamination is identified and controlled, new invasive _L. monocytogenes_ infections associated with this outbreak may still occur.\n\nIt is likely that the extent of the outbreak is underestimated, since the use of sequencing to characterise _L. monocytogenes_ isolates is only used by a few EU countries. A recent EU-wide study coordinated by ECDC revealed that more than half of the severe listeriosis cases in the European Union belong to clusters, many of which are not being picked up fast enough by the current surveillance system.\n\nListeriosis is a relatively rare but potentially severe food-borne disease that has been reported in increasing numbers in the EU/EEA countries since 2008. In 2016, 2536 cases were reported, including 247 deaths. Pregnant women, the elderly and immunocompromised people are at higher risk of contracting listeriosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Refrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product, that is, does not require further cooking before eating. The ECDC report said that more cases related to this outbreak are expected, despite a recall in 2017 by the Salling Group (formerly Dansk Supermarked Group/DSG) of cold-packed smoked salmon manufactured in Poland from 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland, after the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall 20170902.5290728). Salling Group consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland, and Sweden. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nDenmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111\nGermany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101\nFrance: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100]", "summary": "The ECDC report said that more cases related to this outbreak are expected, despite a recall in 2017 by the Salling Group (formerly Dansk Supermarked Group/DSG) of cold-packed smoked salmon manufactured in Poland from 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland, after the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall 20170902.5290728). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Refrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product, that is, does not require further cooking before eating. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (06): FATAL, WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, SMOKED AND MARINATED SALMON FROM POLAND, 2015-2018\n*************************************************************************************************************\n \n\n\nReady-to-eat salmon products, such as cold-smoked and marinated salmon, are the likely source of an outbreak of listeriosis that has affected Denmark, Germany, and France since 2015. \n\nAlthough control measures were implemented following the Danish outbreak investigation in September 2017, the same strain was found in a salmon product in France in October 2017 and in a patient in Germany in May 2018. \n\nInitial investigations suggested that contamination may have taken place at a Polish processing company but the lack of recent WGS data on the _Listeria monocytogenes_-isolates collected at the processing plant make it impossible to confirm this is the case.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2536-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-09-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-05-26 00:00:00", "2017-10-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "POLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6097249", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (05): Switzerland, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6097249", "date": "2018-10-18 13:27:06", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (05): SWITZERLAND, FATAL\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Oct 2018\nSource: RTS [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://www.rts.ch/info/suisse/9923103-un-nombre-inhabituel-de-cas-de-listeriose-a-ete-enregistre-en-suisse.html\n\n\nSince June [2018], an unexplained outbreak of listeriosis, a rare infectious disease, has been occurring across Switzerland [in 6 Swiss cantons]. The Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH) has identified 12 cases, 2 of which are fatal.\n\n'What is unusual is that it is all cases of the same subtype of bacteria. We counted 12 cases, which is not that much, but 12 of the same type in a short time, it's not normal,' said Daniel Koch, director of the Division of Communicable Diseases at the FOPH, told SRF [Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen, German-language broadcaster in Switzerland].\n\nResearch is being conducted to find the sources of the infection. Currently 6 cantons are affected by the listeriosis outbreak. In Neuchatel, 3 cases were reported, 4 in Valais and others in Ticino, Zurich, Aargau and Schwyz.\n\nListeriosis is a rare infectious disease caused by a bacterium that spreads especially through the ingestion of contaminated food. Charcuterie, soft cheeses and salads are all foods that are possible sources of infection.\n\n'We can talk about an epidemic and this disease can be deadly, but the population is not at risk. These germs benefit from flaws, a decrease in immunity, in the defenses of individuals. This therefore concerns especially pregnant women and the elderly,' Raffaele Malinverni, head of the Department of Medicine at the Neuchatel Hospital, told RTS on its Tuesday [16 Oct 2018] 12:45 broadcast.\n\nThe FOPH reminds that people at risk should avoid raw vegetables, raw or undercooked meat, raw fish and seafood, soft cheese and unpasteurized milk.\n\n'Our survey is all the more difficult because the cases are spread all over Switzerland; it's not easy, people have probably been infected with the same food, but it's a food that had to be distributed in many places,' said Daniel Koch.\n\nSeveral people infected by the same source of bacteria -- the case is not new. In 1987, more than 120 people became ill after eating Vacherin-Mont-d'or, and 30 of them died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable them to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. In past outbreaks, contamination occurred in parts of the machinery 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/). Because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, _Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated ready-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized potential sources for listeriosis. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk are other frequent sources of listeriosis. However, the source in some outbreaks has been contamination with _Listeria_ only after pasteurization.\n\nSerotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95 percent of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf). We are told in the news report above that all 12 cases have the same 'subtype,' but we are not told what that subtype is. Genotyping the clinical isolates from ill people, if they match, will establish that we are dealing with a common source.\n\nA map of Swiss cantons can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantons_of_Switzerland. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSwitzerland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/105]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enable them to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of food-processing equipment that are difficult to access. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Serotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95 percent of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf). \n\n'Our survey is all the more difficult because the cases are spread all over Switzerland; it's not easy, people have probably been infected with the same food, but it's a food that had to be distributed in many places,' said Daniel Koch. \n\nListeriosis is a rare infectious disease caused by a bacterium that spreads especially through the ingestion of contaminated food. The FOPH reminds that people at risk should avoid raw vegetables, raw or undercooked meat, raw fish and seafood, soft cheese and unpasteurized milk. Because _L. monocytogenes_ can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, _Listeria_-contaminated, refrigerated ready-to-eat products that do not require further cooking before eating, such as smoked salmon or cold cut meats (e.g., ham), are recognized potential sources for listeriosis. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (05): SWITZERLAND, FATAL\n*********************************************\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\n \n\nSeveral people infected by the same source of bacteria -- the case is not new. Unpasteurized milk and cheese and other milk products made from unpasteurized milk are other frequent sources of listeriosis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zurich", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SWITZERLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuchatel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valais", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ticino", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6007973", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (15): fatal, ST6, end of outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6007973", "date": "2018-09-05 09:40:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (15): FATAL, ST6, END OF OUTBREAK\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2018 17:17 SAST\nSource: Business Live [edited]\nhttps://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2018-09-03-listeriosis-outbreak-officially-over-says-aaron-motsoaledi/\n\n\nThe government has declared the end of the listeriosis outbreak, the world's deadliest on record, and has withdrawn advice against consuming ready-to-eat processed meat products.\n\nAnd the Enterprise factory in Limpopo, identified as the source of the outbreak, could reopen in October [2018], health minister Aaron Motsoaledi said in Johannesburg on [Mon 3 Sep 2018].\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak has been costly for Tiger Brands, with recall-related costs amounting to Rand 365 million [about 23.9 million] for the initial insurance claims, spokesperson Nevashnee Naicker said. The packaged goods company lost a further Rand 50 million [about USD 3.27 million] a month as operations ceased.\n\nThe National Institute for Communicable Diseases also identified _Listeria_ at RCL's Rainbow Foods, resulting in a recall of all ready-to-eat processed meat products from the facility.\n\nThe country has destroyed more than 5800 tons of recalled meat since the beginning of March [2018], when it linked the products to the outbreak and named a plant owned by Tiger Brands as the source of the crisis.\n\nMore than 200 people died from listeriosis between January 2017 and [26 Jul 2018] and 1060 cases of the illness were identified, according to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases. No new cases caused by the outbreak strain have been identified since the 1st week of June [2018] and incidences have dropped to pre-outbreak levels, Motsoaledi said, adding the outbreak has been declared over. It is still unclear how the bacteria strain entered the affected factory, Motsoaledi said.\n\n'Today's announcement means that ready-to-eat processed meat can now be safely consumed, as before the outbreak,' he said. South Africans are now free to eat 'kotas', a popular township meal made of a quarter loaf of bread stuffed with chips, cheese, and cold meat.\n\n[Byline: Penelope Mashego]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: August 2018\nSource: National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/An-update-on-the-outbreak-of-Listeria-monocytogenes-South-Africa.pdf\n\n\nAn update on the outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_, South Africa\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nAs of 14 Aug 2018, a total of 1064 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases has been reported to NICD since [1 Jan 2017 (Figure 3 [all figures are available at the source URL above]). Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (58 percent, 612/1064) followed by Western Cape (13 percent, 139/1064) and KwaZulu-Natal (8 percent, 84/1064) provinces. Cases have been diagnosed in both public (64 percent, 683/1064) and private (36 percent, 381/1064) healthcare sectors. Outcome is known for 828/1064 (78 percent) patients, of whom 218 (26 percent) have died (Figure 4).\n\nFemales account for 56 percent (576/1039) of cases where gender is reported. Where age was reported (n=1043), ages range from birth to 93 years (median 19 years) - Figure 5. Neonates aged 28 days and less account for 43 percent (444/1043) of cases. Of neonatal cases, 95 percent (424/444) had early-onset disease (birth to 6 days or less).\n\nAlthough outbreak-related cases have declined sharply, sporadic cases (that is, not epidemiologically linked) continue to be reported, as expected. Therefore, healthcare workers are encouraged to continue providing risk reduction guidance to persons at high risk for developing listeriosis (pregnant women, neonates 28 days of age and younger, persons older than 65 years of age, and persons with immunosuppression (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, chronic renal disease, chronic liver disease, transplantation and immunosuppressive therapy). Such guidance includes advice on food hygiene (the World Health Organization's 5 keys to safer food [http://www.who.int/foodsafety/publications/5keysmanual/en/] is a useful resource for generic food hygiene advice) and avoidance of at-risk food.\n\nThe end of the outbreak is approaching, and the activities of the listeriosis Incident Management Team are nearing completion. The following actions have been taken to strengthen health and environmental systems to ensure prevention and early detection of future outbreaks, particularly in ready-to-eat processed meat:\n1. Listeriosis has been declared a notifiable medical condition under an amendment to the National Health Act.\n2. The NICD has developed a system of surveillance and investigation of listeriosis cases including whole genome sequencing (WGS) of all isolates from laboratory-confirmed cases. This allows timeous identification of clusters which may represent outbreaks.\n3. The NHLS has strengthened capacity to conduct food and environmental testing for _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n4. Almost 900 environmental health practitioners in all health districts have been re-trained in inspection procedures, food safety systems, legislative aspects of food control and tools to support inspections including risk assessment tools and inspection checklists.\n5. All production facilities that manufacture ready-to-eat processed meat in South Africa have been identified (n=158) and all but 9 have been inspected by district environmental health practitioners, supported by a core incident management team.\n6. An amendment to the Regulations pertaining to the application of the hazard analysis and critical control system (HACCP), (R908 of 2003) was published on 14 Jun 2018 requiring all producers of ready-to-eat processed meat to be HACCP certified by externally accredited agencies within 9 months of publication of this act.\n7. Risk communication activities including the dissemination of information pertaining to food safety, avoidance of certain foodstuffs by persons who are at risk for listeriosis, and training of health promoters have been conducted.\n\nFurther resources on listeriosis can be found on the NICD website at http://www.nicd.ac.za, Diseases A-Z, under 'Listeriosis'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 2nd news report above, which is from the South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), says that a total of 1064 cases of the listeriosis were identified between January 2017 and 14 Aug 2018.\n\nOver 90 percent of isolates from listeriosis cases linked to the South African 'polony' outbreak were sequence type 6 (ST6) (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response 20180330.5718496). ST6 was also identified in 'polony', a widely consumed ready-to-eat processed meat product and in environmental samples collected from the facility that processed the implicated product.\n\nOf the 645 _Listeria_ clinical isolates that have been sequence typed, no ST6 isolates have been identified since the 1st week of June 2018 (see Figure 3 from the NICD report above at the source URL). Considering that the implicated 'polony' was recalled in early March 2018 and the incubation period of listeriosis is up to 70 days, the 1st news report above says that the South African government has 'declared the end of the listeriosis outbreak,' the world's largest on record (http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-march-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/), and has 'withdrawn advice against consuming ready-to-eat processed meat products.' - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Considering that the implicated 'polony' was recalled in early March 2018 and the incubation period of listeriosis is up to 70 days, the 1st news report above says that the South African government has 'declared the end of the listeriosis outbreak,' the world's largest on record (http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-march-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/), and has 'withdrawn advice against consuming ready-to-eat processed meat products.' - Mod. \n\nOver 90 percent of isolates from listeriosis cases linked to the South African 'polony' outbreak were sequence type 6 (ST6) (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response 20180330.5718496).
