Almost 900 environmental health practitioners in all health districts have been re-trained in inspection procedures, food safety systems, legislative aspects of food control and tools to support inspections including risk assessment tools and inspection checklists.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-14 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2018-08-14 00:00:00", "2018-08-26 00:00:00", "1060-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Limpopo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "st6", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5888338", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (14): fatal, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5888338", "date": "2018-07-04 20:19:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (14): FATAL, ST6\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/07/new-listeriosis-cases-down-newborns-remain-hardest-hit/#.Wz0klS2ZNao\n\n\nNew information out of South Africa shows that 1053 people have been confirmed with listeria infections in the past 18 months. One in 5 has died in what the World Health Organization has determined to be the largest listeriosis outbreak in recorded history.\n\nInfants in their 1st month of life have been harder hit than any other age group in the outbreak. Of the infants who are 28 days or younger, for whom complete information is available, 91 have died. Overall, at least 212 people have died in the outbreak. Officials do not yet have final reports on all of the sick people, so there could easily be additional deaths confirmed.\n\nPublic health investigators traced the outbreak to Tiger Brand's ready-to-eat polony, which is similar to baloney and hot dogs, that was produced at Enterprise Foods' Polokwane production facility.\n\nDuring the peak period of the outbreak, from late October 2017 through March this year [2018], health officials often confirmed more than 30 new cases per week. In some weeks, more than 40 new people were found to have infections from _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nPrior to 2017, health officials recorded less than 2 cases per week, for an average of 60 to 80 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases per year in the country.\n\nThe South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) began investigating the situation in July 2017 when increases in laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis were reported. On 5 Dec 2017, Minister of Health Dr. Aaron Motsoaledi declared the outbreak.\n\nA recall of Tiger Brand's polony was initiated on 4 Mar 2018. By mid-April 2018, the number of new cases per week had dropped to 5 or less.\n\nHighlights of the most recent report from South African public health officials include:\n\n- 1053 cases confirmed from 1 Jan 2017, through 20 Jun 2018;\n- Neonates younger than 28 days are the most affected age group;\n- People aged 15 to 49 years old are the 2nd most affected age group; and\n- Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province at 58 percent of all cases, followed by Western Cape with 13 percent, and KwaZulu-Natal with 8 percent.\n\n[Table 1 and Figures 1 and 2 are available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases continue to be reported for a total now of 1053 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, 20 more cases than last reported by ProMED-mail in May 2018, with a case fatality rate of 20 percent. The source, 'polony' contaminated with the outbreak strain of _Listeria moncytogenes_, was recalled in early March 2018. With an incubation period of up to 70 days, at this point, new cases of listeriosis are likely to be due to delays in reporting, or perhaps failure to discard listeria-contaminated polony despite the recall. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "include:\n\n- 1053 cases confirmed from 1 Jan 2017, through 20 Jun 2018;\n- Neonates younger than 28 days are the most affected age group;\n- People aged 15 to 49 years old are the 2nd most affected age group; and\n- promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases continue to be reported for a total now of 1053 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, 20 more cases than last reported by ProMED-mail in May 2018, with a case fatality rate of 20 percent. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Prior to 2017, health officials recorded less than 2 cases per week, for an average of 60 to 80 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases per year in the country. During the peak period of the outbreak, from late October 2017 through March this year [2018], health officials often confirmed more than 30 new cases per week. With an incubation period of up to 70 days, at this point, new cases of listeriosis are likely to be due to delays in reporting, or perhaps failure to discard listeria-contaminated polony despite the recall. Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province at 58 percent of all cases, followed by Western Cape with 13 percent, and KwaZulu-Natal with 8 percent. \n\nPublic health investigators traced the outbreak to Tiger Brand's ready-to-eat polony, which is similar to baloney and hot dogs, that was produced at Enterprise Foods' Polokwane production facility. The South African National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) began investigating the situation in July 2017 when increases in laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis were reported. LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (14): FATAL, ST6\n*******************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-20 00:00:00", "2017-07-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2018-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5890285", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (04): fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5890285", "date": "2018-07-06 22:08:46", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (04): FATAL, SEQUENCE TYPE 6, FROZEN CORN, 2015-2018, RECALL\n*********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2018\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/hungarian-frozen-vegetables-link-in-europe-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nFrozen corn and possibly other frozen vegetables are the likely source of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that has been affecting Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom since 2015.\n\nExperts used whole genome sequencing to identify the food source, which initially was thought to be limited to frozen corn. As of 8 Jun 2018, 47 cases including 9 deaths had been reported.\n\nThe same strains of _L. monocytogenes_ have been detected in frozen vegetables produced by the same Hungarian company in 2016, 2017, and 2018. This suggests that the strains have persisted in the processing plant despite the cleaning and disinfection procedures that were carried out.\n\nThe available information confirms the contamination at the Hungarian plant. However, further investigations, including thorough sampling and testing, are needed to identify the exact points of environmental contamination at the Hungarian plant. The same recommendation applies to other companies belonging to the same commercial group if environmental contamination is detected.\n\nOn 29 Jun 2018, the Hungarian Food Chain Safety Office banned the marketing of all frozen vegetable and frozen mixed vegetable products produced by the affected plant between August 2016 and June 2018, and ordered their immediate withdrawal and recall. This last measure is likely to significantly reduce the risk of human infections and contain the outbreak. All freezing activity at the plant has been stopped.\n\nNew cases could still emerge due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days); the long shelf-life of frozen corn products; and the consumption of frozen corn bought before the recalls and eaten without being cooked properly.\n\nTo reduce the risk of infection, consumers should thoroughly cook non ready-to-eat frozen vegetables, even though these products are commonly consumed without cooking (such as in salads and smoothies). This applies especially to consumers at highest risk of contracting listeriosis -- such as the elderly, pregnant women, newborns and adults with weakened immune systems.\n\n[Byline: Josh Fensterbush]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail in March 2018 (Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506), there was a total of 32 confirmed listeriosis cases, including 6 deaths, between December 2015 and 8 Mar 2018, in a multi-country outbreak in 5 EU member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom) linked by whole genome sequencing (genotyping) of clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ to frozen corn that was packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. As of 8 Jun 2018, there are now 47 reported cases, including 9 deaths.\n\nPossibly other frozen vegetables produced by the Hungarian facility are also being implicated and on 29 June 2018, the Hungarian Food Chain Safety Office ordered recall and banned further the marketing of all frozen vegetable and frozen mixed vegetable products produced by the affected facility between August 2016 and June 2018. All freezing activity at the plant has been stopped.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables them to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove, especially in parts of equipment that are difficult to access. In a prior ProMED-mail report of a listeriosis outbreak in Canada, the design of a commercial meat slicer responsible for contamination of deli meat made its regular cleaning difficult and costly for the food processor (Listeriosis - South Africa (04): comment 20180126.5586393). The contamination occurred in parts of the machinery 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/). Perhaps a similar situation is responsible for this prolonged multicountry EU outbreak.\n\nSerotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95 per cent of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf). The serotype of the strain of _L. monocytogenes_ responsible for this multi-country European outbreak is 4b, multi-locus sequence type 6 (ST6). Whole genome sequence (WGS) analysis of _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from 2 different samples of mixed frozen vegetables and an isolate from a surface where various vegetables could have been processed closely matched that of the clinical isolates (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506).\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Europe: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11767. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail in March 2018 (Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506), there was a total of 32 confirmed listeriosis cases, including 6 deaths, between December 2015 and 8 Mar 2018, in a multi-country outbreak in 5 EU member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom) linked by whole genome sequencing (genotyping) of clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ to frozen corn that was packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. \n\nPossibly other frozen vegetables produced by the Hungarian facility are also being implicated and on 29 June 2018, the Hungarian Food Chain Safety Office ordered recall and banned further the marketing of all frozen vegetable and frozen mixed vegetable products produced by the affected facility between August 2016 and June 2018. Whole genome sequence (WGS) analysis of _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from 2 different samples of mixed frozen vegetables and an isolate from a surface where various vegetables could have been processed closely matched that of the clinical isolates (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506). On 29 Jun 2018, the Hungarian Food Chain Safety Office banned the marketing of all frozen vegetable and frozen mixed vegetable products produced by the affected plant between August 2016 and June 2018, and ordered their immediate withdrawal and recall. \n\nNew cases could still emerge due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days); the long shelf-life of frozen corn products; and the consumption of frozen corn bought before the recalls and eaten without being cooked properly. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/hungarian-frozen-vegetables-link-in-europe-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nFrozen corn and possibly other frozen vegetables are the likely source of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that has been affecting Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom since 2015. \n\nThe same strains of _L. monocytogenes_ have been detected in frozen vegetables produced by the same Hungarian company in 2016, 2017, and 2018. Serotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95 per cent of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2047-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-06-29 00:00:00", "2018-06-08 {"location": "Hungary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5801104", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (13): fatal, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5801104", "date": "2018-05-17 16:59:22", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (13): FATAL, ST6\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 May 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/05/largest-listeria-outbreak-ever-coming-under-control-204-dead/#.Wv205saZPjB\n\n\nThe world's largest listeriosis epidemic is now under control because meat products from Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken have been recalled, Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi told the South African Parliament earlier this week [week 14 to 20 May 2018].\n\n'Since the recall, we have had fewer than 5 cases a week in the past 5 weeks compared to 40 a week before the recall,' Motsoaledi told Parliament.\n\nAccording to South Africa's National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) recent release, 1033 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 204 deaths, were reported from [1 Jan 2017 to 10 May 2018].\n\nNeonates 28 days of age and younger are the most affected age group, followed by adults ages 15 to 49.\n\nMost cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (59 percent, 605/1033), followed by Western Cape (13 percent, 130/1033) and KwaZulu-Natal (7 percent, 75/1033) provinces.\n\nThe findings of the NICD are in summary:\n- 92 percent of clinical isolates taken from case-patients belong to _Listeria_ sequence type 6 (ST6) and are genetically similar confirming that a single strain of _Listeria_ is responsible for the outbreak;\n- 86 percent of patients interviewed reported eating polony in the month before falling ill with listeriosis;\n- The isolates taken from patients and from the Enterprise Foods' Polokwane production facility (the post-cooking area and final production clips and casing) are 99.99 percent similar, linking the _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST6 strains; and\n- 7 samples of ready-to-eat processed meat products taken at the Enterprise Factory in Polokwane on [15 Feb 2018] tested positive for the ST6 outbreak strain. The samples were taken by the NICD accompanied by 2 food safety experts from the World Health Organization.\n\nAccording to the NICD, these findings are irrefutable evidence that:\n- Enterprise Foods, and by extension Tiger Brands Limited, are the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak; and\n- The ST6 strain of _Listeria_ responsible for the outbreak was not just found in the environment of the Enterprise Foods Polokwane operations as some commentators suggest, but also in the final product.\n\nTiger Brands has been transparent with its test results, which support the NICD findings.\n\nHere is the Tiger Brands' statement in full:\n\nResults of Independent Tests carried out in respect of the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST6 type ('LST6') Shareholders are referred to the SENS announcement issued by the Company on [5 Mar 2018], relating to an order issued by the National Consumer Commission for the Company to conduct a recall of certain identified Enterprise products. In that announcement, it was stated that in a batch of one of its products tested by the Company on [14 Feb 2018], the presence of the ST6 strain could not be confirmed and that the relevant samples had been sent to an external laboratory for the identification of the strain. The test results were received on [15 Mar 2018], but these had proved inconclusive and, as a result, the samples were sent for further re-testing.\n\nThe purpose of this announcement is to update shareholders on the results of the independent laboratory re-testing, which was carried out in respect of the presence of LST6 in the above samples, which were manufactured at the Enterprise Polokwane processing facility. On [24 Apr 2018], Tiger Brands received confirmation of the presence of LST6 in these samples. As reported previously, we have been actively engaging with the Department of Health and the National Institute of Communicable Diseases on our findings and will continue to collaborate with them on the actions taken to date to actively address our findings.\n\nThe Enterprise facilities in Polokwane, Pretoria, and Germiston still remain closed while remedial work continues. An arrangement has been concluded between Pork Packers (which is based in Clayville) and our pig suppliers to contract slaughter on their behalf with effect from [2 May 2018].\n\n'Now it is time to take care of the victims and to work with government, the industry, and the public to see that an outbreak like this never, ever occurs again,' said Seattle food safety attorney Bill Marler, who is acting as a consultant on the South Africa Listeria Class Action.\n\n[A graph that shows the timeline of cases and a table of cases and deaths for each South African province are available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases continue to be reported at a rate of less than 5 per week. As of 24 Apr 2018, a total of 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported, with a case fatality rate of 28.6 percent. As of 10 May 2018, 1033 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 204 deaths, were reported. Because of the long incubation period of up to 70 days for listeriosis, additional cases may occur, despite the recall of the contaminated 'polony' in early March 2018. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "\n\nThe findings of the NICD are in summary:\n- 92 percent of clinical isolates taken from case-patients belong to _Listeria_ sequence type 6 (ST6) and are genetically similar confirming that a single strain of _Listeria_ is responsible for the outbreak;\n- 86 percent of patients interviewed reported eating polony in the month before falling ill with listeriosis;\n- A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The isolates taken from patients and from the Enterprise Foods' Polokwane production facility (the post-cooking area and final production clips and casing) are 99.99 percent similar, linking the _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST6 strains; and\n- 7 samples of ready-to-eat processed meat products taken at the Enterprise Factory in Polokwane on [15 Feb 2018] \n\nMost cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (59 percent, 605/1033), followed by Western Cape (13 percent, 130/1033) and KwaZulu-Natal (7 percent, 75/1033) provinces. In that announcement, it was stated that in a batch of one of its products tested by the Company on [14 Feb 2018], the presence of the ST6 strain could not be confirmed and that the relevant samples had been sent to an external laboratory for the identification of the strain. \n\n'Since the recall, we have had fewer than 5 cases a week in the past 5 weeks compared to 40 a week before the recall,' Motsoaledi told Parliament. As of 24 Apr 2018, a total of 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported, with a case fatality rate of 28.6 percent. \n\nThe purpose of this announcement is to update shareholders on the results of the independent laboratory re-testing, which was carried out in respect of the presence of LST6 in the above samples, which were manufactured at the Enterprise Polokwane processing facility. According to the NICD, these findings are irrefutable evidence that:\n- Enterprise Foods, and by extension Tiger Brands Limited, are the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak; and\n- \n\nHere is the Tiger Brands' statement in full:\n\nResults of Independent Tests carried out in respect of the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ ST6 type ('LST6') According to South Africa's National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) recent release, 1033 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 204 deaths, were reported from [1 Jan 2017 to 10 May 2018]. As of 10 May 2018, 1033 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 204 deaths, were reported.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-05-02 00:00:00", "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "1024-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-05-10 00:00:00", "2018-05-17 00:00:00", "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "1033-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Polokwane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Motsoaledi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Clayville", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5807321", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (03): Sweden (VG) fatal, mashed potatoes, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5807321", "date": "2018-05-20 19:54:48", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (03): SWEDEN (VASTRA GOTALAND) FATAL, MASHED POTATOES, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2018\nSource: The Local [edited]\nhttps://www.thelocal.se/20180518/lethal-listeria-outbreak-prompts-food-recall-in-sweden\n\n\nProducts from a food producer in western Sweden have been recalled after they were linked to a deadly outbreak of [listeriosis].\n\nThere have been 4 deaths in V\u00e4stra G\u00f6taland in western Sweden that experts have linked to the _Listeria_ bacteria. Experts at the Centre for Communicable Disease Control (Smittskydd) stressed that all those who passed away were elderly people or affected by other illnesses. In other words, they said it was impossible to confirm that listeriosis, the disease caused by _Listeria_ bacteria, was responsible for the deaths.\n\nBut the group behind the meals and the local region are not taking any chances, issuing a recall for potentially contaminated products across the region. The group behind the products, Food Company, released a statement with information about the items that were affected and their expiration dates.\n\nSee the full list [in Swedish and machine translated below] at: http://www.foodcompany.se. The items have an expiration date between 16-25 May 2018.\n\nAll items -- single portion, pre-cooked and chilled packet meals -- contained mashed potatoes, with the company explaining that the machine that made the mash was responsible for the bacterial outbreak.\n\nIt added that the machine has since been removed from the production factory. 'This machine has been discarded and is no longer at our factory. We take the event seriously and will implement a number of measures to prevent this from happening again,' the company said in a statement.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is a machine-translated list of _Listeria_-contaminated products from the Food Company. The original, in Swedish, is available at http://www.foodcompany.se:\n\n'Fish Symphony with dill sauce and shrimp, served with mashed potatoes;\nCod with dill sauce and shrimp, served with mashed potatoes;\nAlmond baked fish with dill sauce, lemon, peas and mashed potatoes;\nCalffish [?] steak with onion peas, cream sauce, mashed potatoes and lingon;\n\n'The recall applies to products with the following best-served dates:\n2018-05-16\n2018-05-17\n2018-05-18\n2018-05-19\n2018-05-22\n2018-05-23\n2018-05-24\n2018-05-25\n\n'All of the above products should have been removed from store shelves already last week when we went out to our customers with the recall.\n\n'We encourage customers who bought any of these products with best served before dates mentioned above to bring the products in to the store in which they were bought and get their money back.\n\n'Food Company in Lidk\u00f6ping regrets it deeply.\n\n'For more information about _Listeria_, please visit the Swedish Food Administration website:\nhttps://www.livsmedelsverket.se/livsmedel-och-innehall/bakterier-virus-och-parasiter1/bakterier/listeria-monocytogenes/?.'\n\nThe above news report says that 4 deaths have been linked to _Listeria_- contaminated single portion, pre-cooked and chilled packet meals that contained mashed potatoes. The manufacturer says that a machine that made the mashed potatoes was responsible for the contamination, but we are not told how the linkage was established. Did genotypes of clinical _Listeria_ isolates match genotypes of _Listeria_ isolates from the contaminated products? Also, were there any cases of listeriosis linked to the contaminated products who survived their illnesses?\n\nWhat were the instructions for preparation of the _Listeria_-contaminated products before eating? Were the contaminated products ready-to-eat without further preparation or were they to be reheated or cooked before serving? Cooking or reheating in a microwave oven can leave areas that are inadequately cooked if contamination with an enteric pathogen such as _Listeria_ is present. The US CDC suggests microwaving to internal temperatures of about 165 F [74 C]; also, stirring food in the middle of heating and letting microwaved food sit for a few minutes after cooking to help distribute the heat from hotter areas of food, because microwaving is an uneven process (https://www.foodsafety.gov/keep/basics/cook/index.htm). More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nLidk\u00f6ping is a city with 25 644 residents in 2010 in V\u00e4stra G\u00f6taland [Western Gotland] County, Sweden (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidk\u00f6ping). V\u00e4stra G\u00f6taland County is on the western coast of Sweden (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V\u00e4stra_G\u00f6taland_County). A map showing the location of Lidk\u00f6ping can be found at: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lidk\u00f6ping,+Sweden. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "Calffish [?] steak with onion peas, cream sauce, mashed potatoes and lingon;\n\n'The recall applies to products with the following best-served dates:\n2018-05-16\n2018-05-17\n2018-05-18\n2018-05-19\n2018-05-22\n2018-05-23\n2018-05-24\n2018-05-25\n\n'All of the above products should have been removed from store shelves already last week when we went out to our customers with the recall. Source: The Local [edited]\nhttps://www.thelocal.se/20180518/lethal-listeria-outbreak-prompts-food-recall-in-sweden\n\n\nProducts from a food producer in western Sweden have been recalled after they were linked to a deadly outbreak of [listeriosis]. \n\n'For more information about _Listeria_, please visit the Swedish Food Administration website:\n ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-05-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lidk\u00f6ping", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "V\u00e4stra G\u00f6taland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "V\u00e4stra G\u00f6taland County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5709796", "headline": "PRO> Listeriosis - Europe (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5709796", "date": "2018-03-25 17:06:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 25 Mar 2018\nFrom: Steve Berger <steve@gideononline.com> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail. Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent series of outbreaks in Europe reflects an increasing incidence of listeriosis in the region. In the following graph, I've contrasted disease rates per 100 000 in the European Union with those of the United States [1,2] (graph link: https://www.gideononline.com/2018/03/25/listeriosis-in-the-european-union/).\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger S. Listeriosis: Global Status, 2018: 128 pages, 108 graphs, 1,203 references. Gideon e-books, https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/.\n2. Gideon e-Gideon multi-graph tool, https://www.gideononline.com/cases/multi-graphs/.\n\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nTel Aviv, Israel\n<steve@gideononline.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for his continuing contributions. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Gideon e-Gideon multi-graph tool, https://www.gideononline.com/cases/multi-graphs/.\n\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\n Tel Aviv, Israel\n<steve@gideononline.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for his continuing contributions. - Listeriosis - EU: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5782882", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (12): fatal, ST6, WHO update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5782882", "date": "2018-05-04 10:40:41", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (12): FATAL, ST6, WHO UPDATE\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 May 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/02-may-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/\n\n\nListeriosis - South Africa: Disease outbreak news [DON]\n-------------------------------------------------------\nIn South Africa, the current outbreak of listeriosis, a serious foodborne disease, that has affected the country since early 2017 is showing a downward trend after the food source was identified in early March 2018 (see previous DON), but additional cases are expected. Between 1 Jan 2017 through 24 Apr 2018, 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all provinces. The majority of cases have come from 3 provinces: 601 (59 percent) from Gauteng, 128 (13 percent) from Western Cape and 73 (7 percent) from KwaZulu-Natal provinces, with the remaining cases coming from the other provinces in South Africa. The outcome of illness is known for 700 patients, of whom 200 (28.6 percent) of them died; this case fatality rate is comparable to other recorded listeriosis outbreaks worldwide. Most of the cases are persons who have higher risks for a severe disease outcome, such as neonates, pregnant women, the elderly, and immunocompromised persons. In this outbreak, 42 percent of the cases are neonates who were infected during pregnancy or delivery.\n\nWhole genome sequencing was performed on 521 isolates from patients. 85 percent of the strains belonged to _Listeria monocytogenes_ sequence type 6 (ST6) and 15 percent (83/521) representing 19 other sequence types (ST1, ST54, ST876, ST2, ST5, ST204, ST219, ST224, ST71, ST101, ST121, ST155, ST3, ST403, ST515, ST7, ST8, and ST88). The same ST6 sequence type was identified in a widely consumed ready-to-eat processed meat product called 'Polony' [Bologna sausage]. The same strain was also found in the processing environment of the manufacturer of the implicated product. On 4 Mar 2018, the Ministry of Health, announced that this product was believed to be the source of the outbreak and initiated a countrywide recall of the implicated products. Since the recall, the number of cases has dropped significantly.\n\nThe food processing company and 3 of its retailers export to 15 countries (1) in the African region. All of these countries have been informed about the implicated lots imported through the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) and have issued recalls for the implicated products.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe country has activated a national multisectoral task force to coordinate investigation and response activities.\n\nEmergency response activities that have been conducted by various stakeholders are continuing and intensifying, including surveillance (detection and investigation of cases), risk communication activities, and food safety legislative review and reform. To inform and support these activities, additional activities will be implemented in a phased approach as follows:\n\n- Phase 1: identification of at-risk food processing plants, development of material and training of staff to support inspections of facilities (completed).\n- Phase 2: inspection of at-risk food processing plant and strengthening of district environmental health practitioners.\n- Phase 3: reporting and consolidation of health system strengthening activities, and after-action review.\n\nA multisectoral incident management team (IMT) has been strengthened under the leadership of the Department of Health with support from WHO. An updated Listeriosis Emergency Response Plan (ERP, April 2018) has been developed to intensify response activities to control and end the current listeriosis outbreak and strengthen health and food safety systems to prevent future outbreaks.\n\nA WHO Listeriosis Regional Technical Meeting took place in Johannesburg from 19-21 Apr 2018, attended by delegates from 16 countries from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region and beyond. The aim of the meeting was to share experiences from South Africa on the management of a listeriosis outbreak and increase awareness of listeriosis in the region. The meeting also guided countries in preparing contingency plans to respond and control listeriosis as part of an overall strengthening of their food safety systems.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nGlobally, this is the largest outbreak of listeriosis that has been detected. With the implicated food source identified and removed from the market, the number of cases is declining, but due to the potentially long incubation period of listeriosis (one to three weeks and up to 70 days) further cases are expected before the impact of the food recall will be fully observed.\n\nRecently, Namibia reported a confirmed case of listeriosis. The isolated _Listeria_ strains has been sequenced to determine potential links to the outbreak in South Africa. It belongs to a different sequence type and is therefore not linked to the outbreak in South Africa.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nCountries should strengthen national food safety and disease surveillance systems as a prerequisite to prevent similar events in the future and to ensure a safe food supply for their populations. Additionally, countries are urged to pay closer attention to common foodborne pathogens such as _Salmonella_ species, _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Listeria monocytogenes_, to make listeriosis a notifiable disease if not yet done, to make the best use of a new 'WHO manual to strengthen surveillance of and response to foodborne diseases', which was published on November 2017 and to refer to the 'WHO Factsheet on Listeriosis'. See below, in the 'Further Information' section for links to these documents.\n\nResponsible authorities are encouraged to proactively provide public health advice on the prevention and control of listeriosis, including, strengthened risk communication especially to at-risk population groups, to address public concerns and promote outbreak control measures.\n\nWHO does not currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions in relation to this outbreak, other than the continuous recall and safe disposal of the implicated processed meat products as indicated by the South African Government.\n\nWhile WHO understands the desire by sovereign governments to take measures to protect the health of their populations, States Parties to the IHR are required not to take actions that significantly interfere with international travel and trade, which are not based on scientific principles, and which may be viewed as excessive. Indeed such measures contravene the spirit and purpose of the IHR, and can impede public health objectives.\n\nCurrently, 13 out of the 15 countries to which South Africa exported food products have recalled the processed meat products implicated in the listeriosis outbreak, and banned imports of the same. Two of these countries have additionally banned imports of other food products, which are not directly linked to the current listeriosis outbreak. WHO continues to monitor the travel and trade measures taken by countries in relation to this outbreak and their compliance with requirements under the IHR.\n\nFor travelers, it is advisable to practice good food hygiene, such as avoiding uncooked food, avoiding food that has been kept at room temperature for several hours, and always washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before preparing or consuming food.\n\n1. The 15 countries include: Angola, Botswana, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Swaziland, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases continue to be reported. As of 14 Mar 2018, a total of 978 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases were reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all South Africa provinces (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response 20180330.5718496). As of 24 Apr 2018, a total of 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported, with a case fatality rate of 28.6 percent. Because of the long incubation period of up to 70 days for listeriosis, more cases may occur, despite the recall of the contaminated 'polony' in early March 2018. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "Source: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/02-may-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/\n\n\nListeriosis - South Africa: Disease outbreak news [DON]\n-------------------------------------------------------\n An updated Listeriosis Emergency Response Plan (ERP, April 2018) has been developed to intensify response activities to control and end the current listeriosis outbreak and strengthen health and food safety systems to prevent future outbreaks. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n With the implicated food source identified and removed from the market, the number of cases is declining, but due to the potentially long incubation period of listeriosis (one to three weeks and up to 70 days) further cases are expected before the impact of the food recall will be fully observed. \n\nCurrently, 13 out of the 15 countries to which South Africa exported food products have recalled the processed meat products implicated in the listeriosis outbreak, and banned imports of the same. \n\nResponsible authorities are encouraged to proactively provide public health advice on the prevention and control of listeriosis, including, strengthened risk communication especially to at-risk population groups, to address public concerns and promote outbreak control measures. In South Africa, the current outbreak of listeriosis, a serious foodborne disease, that has affected the country since early 2017 is showing a downward trend after the food source was identified in early March 2018 (see previous DON), but additional cases are expected. As of 14 Mar 2018, a total of 978 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases were reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all South Africa provinces (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response 20180330.5718496). \n\nEmergency response activities that have been conducted by various stakeholders are continuing and intensifying, including surveillance (detection and investigation of cases), risk communication activities, and food safety legislative review and reform. ----------\nCountries should strengthen national food safety and disease surveillance systems as a prerequisite to prevent similar events in the future and to ensure a safe food supply for their populations. For travelers, it is advisable to practice good food hygiene, such as avoiding uncooked food, avoiding food that has been kept at room temperature for several hours, and always washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before preparing or consuming food. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases continue to be reported. Additionally, countries are urged to pay closer attention to common foodborne pathogens such as _Salmonella_ species, _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Listeria monocytogenes_, to make listeriosis a notifiable disease if not yet done, to make the best use of a new 'WHO manual to strengthen surveillance of and response to foodborne diseases', which was published on November 2017 and to refer to the 'WHO Factsheet on Listeriosis'. To inform and support these activities, additional activities will be implemented in a phased approach as follows:\n\n- Phase 1: identification of at-risk food processing plants, development of material and training of staff to support inspections of facilities (completed). The majority of cases have come from 3 provinces: 601 (59 percent) from Gauteng, 128 (13 percent) from Western Cape and 73 (7 percent) from KwaZulu-Natal provinces, with the remaining cases coming from the other provinces in South Africa. Two of these countries have additionally banned imports of other food products, which are not directly linked to the current listeriosis outbreak. As of 24 Apr 2018, a total of 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported, with a case fatality rate of 28.6 percent. \n\nWHO does not currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions in relation to this outbreak, other than the continuous recall and safe disposal of the implicated processed meat products as indicated by the South African Government. Between 1 Jan 2017 through 24 Apr 2018, 1024 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all provinces.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "2019-04-21 20:18:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "1024-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-04-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mozambique", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lesotho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5727237", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, unpast soft cheese, aged 60 days", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5727237", "date": "2018-04-04 09:23:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, AGED 60 DAYS\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 2 Apr 2018 1:43 PM EDT\nSource: UPI (United Press International) [edited]\nhttps://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2018/04/02/NY-creamery-ordered-to-stop-production-over-deadly-listeria-outbreak/2801522686078/\n\n\nA New York creamery must stop producing and distributing products after _Listeria_-contaminated cheeses killed 2 people and sickened several others, the Department of Justice said [Mon 2 Apr 2018].\n\nVulto Creamery and owner Johannes Vulto violated the Federal Food, Drug and [FDCA] Act by manufacturing and selling the cheeses in Walton, New York, the department said in a statement.\n\nA complaint from the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the creamery prepared, packed, or held the contaminated products in unsanitary conditions. Additionally, company records indicated that Vulto officials detected _Listeria_ at the facility but failed to test cheese products, and used raw or unpasteurized milk to make the cheese.\n\n'The presence of these dangerous bacteria at a cheese manufacturing facility in Upstate New York is of grave concern,' US Attorney Grant Jaquith for the Northern District of New York said. 'We will continue to use all available tools to ensure that our food supply is safe and violations of laws protecting public heath are addressed.'\n\nIn order to begin making and selling products again, the creamery must comply with remedial measures under a consent decree with the Department of Justice. Vulto must hire a qualified independent expert to create a sanitation protocol for the creamery, and must received written approval from the FDA before resuming production.\n\n[Byline: Danielle Haynes]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 Apr 2018\nSource: US Department of Justice, Office of Public Affairs [edited]\nhttps://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/district-court-enters-permanent-injunction-against-new-york-food-manufacturer-linked\n\n\nDistrict Court enters permanent injunction against New York food manufacturer linked to listeriosis outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA federal court permanently enjoined a Walton, New York, creamery and its owner from manufacturing and distributing adulterated food, the Department of Justice announced today.\n\nIn a complaint filed March 19 [2018] at the request of the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the United States alleged that Vulto Creamery LLC and its owner, Johannes H Vulto, violated the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act by manufacturing and distributing ready-to-eat cheeses contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_ (L. mono). According to the complaint, a 2017 investigation by FDA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) determined Vulto Creamery cheese was the source of a multistate listeriosis outbreak that sickened at least 8 people, 2 of whom died. The defendants agreed to be bound by a consent decree filed with the complaint in US District Court for the Northern District of New York.\n\n'L. mono is a serious health threat that can prove fatal,' said Acting Assistant Attorney General Chad A Readler of the Justice Department's Civil Division. 'Consumers should be able to trust that the food they buy is safe, and we will continue working with FDA to take action against manufacturers that employ substandard practices.'\n\n'The presence of these dangerous bacteria at a cheese manufacturing facility in Upstate New York is of grave concern,' said US Attorney Grant C Jaquith for the Northern District of New York. 'We will continue to use all available tools to ensure that our food supply is safe and violations of laws protecting public heath are addressed.'\n\nThe complaint alleged that the defendants' cheeses were prepared, packed, or held under insanitary conditions. According to the complaint, company records revealed positive tests for a type of _Listeria_ in the Vulto facility, but the defendants never attempted to identify the species of _Listeria_ or its source. The complaint alleged the defendants also failed to conduct microbial testing of finished cheese products despite finding indications of _Listeria_ on food contact surfaces. Vulto Creamery used raw, or unpasteurized, milk to make its ready-to-eat cheese.\n\nThe consent decree entered by the court permanently enjoins the defendants from violating the FDCA. Under the order, the defendants may not manufacture or distribute food unless they comply with specific remedial measures set forth in the decree. Among other requirements, the defendants must hire a qualified independent expert to develop an effective sanitation control program to adequately control for the risk of L. mono. Before manufacturing or distributing any food, defendants must first receive FDA's written determination that their manufacturing practices comply with the law.\n\nThis matter was handled by Trial Attorney Natalie Sanders of the Civil Division's Consumer Protection Branch and Assistant US Attorney Michael Gadarian of the US Attorney's Office for the Northern District of New York, with the assistance of Associate Chief Counsel for Enforcement Leslie Cohen of the FDA's Office of General Counsel, Department of Health and Human Services.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2016-2017, a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) involved 8 people, including 2 deaths, infected with the outbreak strain in 4 states (New York, Florida, Connecticut, and Vermont) was linked to eating soft cheeses made from unpasteurized milk and aged for 60 days by Vulto Creamery in Walton, New York. The outbreak _Listeria_ strain was identified in samples taken from 3 intact wheels of cheese collected from Vulto Creamery.\n\nFDA regulations permit interstate distribution of raw milk cheeses, if aged for more than 60 days. However, ageing raw milk cheese for 60 days may not totally ensure safety if _L. monocytogenes_ is introduced as a post-processing contaminant (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18724749), which apparently occurred at the Vulto facility. The news report above says that Vulto officials detected _Listeria_ on food contact surfaces at the facility but Vulto failed to test their cheese products. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nWalton, New York, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/48087]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nIn a complaint filed March 19 [2018] at the request of the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the United States alleged that Vulto Creamery LLC and its owner, Johannes H Vulto, violated the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act by manufacturing and distributing ready-to-eat cheeses contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_ (L. mono). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2016-2017, a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) involved 8 people, including 2 deaths, infected with the outbreak strain in 4 states (New York, Florida, Connecticut, and Vermont) was linked to eating soft cheeses made from unpasteurized milk and aged for 60 days by Vulto Creamery in Walton, New York. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nA complaint from the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the creamery prepared, packed, or held the contaminated products in unsanitary conditions. \n\nVulto Creamery and owner Johannes Vulto violated the Federal Food, Drug and [FDCA] Act by manufacturing and selling the cheeses in Walton, New York, the department said in a statement. Additionally, company records indicated that Vulto officials detected _Listeria_ at the facility but failed to test cheese products, and used raw or unpasteurized milk to make the cheese. \n\n'The presence of these dangerous bacteria at a cheese manufacturing facility in Upstate New York is of grave concern,' US Attorney Grant Jaquith for the Northern District of New York said. \n\n'The presence of these dangerous bacteria at a cheese manufacturing facility in Upstate New York is of grave concern,' said US Attorney Grant C Jaquith for the Northern District of New York. The complaint alleged the defendants also failed to conduct microbial testing of finished cheese products despite finding indications of _Listeria_ on food contact surfaces. According to the complaint, a 2017 investigation by FDA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) determined Vulto Creamery cheese was the source of a multistate listeriosis outbreak that sickened at least 8 people, 2 of whom died. A New York creamery must stop producing and distributing products after _Listeria_-contaminated cheeses killed 2 people and sickened several others, the Department of Justice said [Mon 2 Apr 2018]. \n\nThe complaint alleged that the defendants' cheeses were prepared, packed, or held under insanitary conditions. https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/district-court-enters-permanent-injunction-against-new-york-food-manufacturer-linked\n\n\nDistrict Court enters permanent injunction against New York food manufacturer linked to listeriosis outbreak\n \n\nIn order to begin making and selling products again, the creamery must comply with remedial measures under a consent decree with the Department of Justice.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vulto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Walton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5736603", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (04): fatal, cantaloupe, international distribution, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5736603", "date": "2018-04-10 15:11:20", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (04): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, INTERNATIONAL DISTRIBUTION, WHO RESPONSE\n*****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Apr 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/09-april-2018-listeriosis-australia/en/\n\n\nOn 2 Mar 2018, the Australian National Focal Point (NFP) notified WHO of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection (listeriosis) associated with the consumption of rockmelons (cantaloupe) from a single grower.\n\nFrom 17 Jan 2018 through to 6 Apr 2018, 20 outbreak cases (19 confirmed and 1 probable) of listeriosis were reported. All of the cases were hospitalized and there have been 7 deaths and 1 miscarriage associated with the outbreak. All of the outbreak cases have had illness onset since 17 Jan 2018.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nEpidemiological investigations suggested that the source of the outbreak was rockmelon (cantaloupe melons) from a single grower in Australia. Epidemiological and environmental investigations were undertaken, which led to the recall of rockmelons produced by the single grower on 27 Feb 2018.\n\nOn 1 Mar 2018, the Australian NFP was notified that international distribution of the affected product had occurred. Australian authorities received information from trace forward investigations on 2 Mar 2018 that the rockmelons from this grower were exported to 8 countries; Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (China), Japan, Kuwait, Malaysia, Oman, Qatar, Singapore, and United Arab Emirates. The Australian NFP directly advised these countries on 3 Mar 2018 about the export of rockmelons from Australia to their country. In parallel, a notification via the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) was also sent on 3 Mar 2018.\n\nFurther trace forward investigations on 7 Mar 2018 identified that Bahrain also received an export of the rockmelons from this grower and on 8 Mar 2018, investigations further identified that the affected rockmelons may have been included in a consignment to the Seychelles. The Australian NFP advised the Bahrain NFP directly on 8 Mar 2018 and the Seychelles NFP directly on 9 Mar 2018. As of 8 Mar 2018, trace forward activities have been concluded.\n\nThe INFOSAN emergency contact points in the importing countries were provided with specific distribution details of the rockmelons to their respective countries by the INFOSAN emergency contact point in Australia, as they became available.\n\nOn 4 Apr 2018, it was reported that more than 30 samples of melons from the grower through the supply chain, including retail and on farm, tested positive to _L. monocytogenes_. Additional testing found _L. monocytogenes_ in the packing area. All _L. monocytogenes_ samples had the same genetic sequence as the human cases. It is believed that the cause of the outbreak was a combination of environmental conditions and weather contaminating the surface of the fruit, with low levels of the bacteria persisting after the washing process. The grower continues to work closely with the relevant authorities and has returned to supply rockmelons (during the week starting 2 Apr 2018) after testing cleared the property.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nThe prompt epidemiological and environmental investigation carried out led to the identification of the outbreak source and enabled the issuing of a recall. Due to the potentially long incubation period of _L. monocytogenes_, further outbreak cases may be reported.\n\nImport details have been provided though INFOSAN to the affected countries to enable them to take appropriate management measures including local recalls and risk communication. Cases in the affected countries may still be identified.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nPregnant women, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals should take precautions to avoid infection by _Listeria_ by avoiding the consumption of high-risk foods including dairy products made of unpasteurized milk, soft cheeses, deli meat products (ready-to eat meat cuts, p\u00e2t\u00e9, etc.); ice creams, raw seafood, crustaceans, and shellfish. These are the most common foods associated with _Listeria_ infection. In recent years, melon, and other fruits and vegetables have been implicated on rare occasions in outbreaks of listeriosis. To reduce the risk, it is important to thoroughly wash all fruits and vegetables.\n\nIt is recommended that risk communication messages regarding listeriosis be targeted to at-risk groups, primarily pregnant women, older persons and people with weakened immune systems, for example people with cancer, HIV, diabetes, kidney, or liver disease or those taking immunosuppressive medications. These messages should recommend avoiding the consumption of high-risk foods.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteurs Marianne Hopp and Mary Marshall\n\n[The listeriosis outbreak linked to rockmelons (cantaloupes) has been traced to a specific grower in the Australian state of New South Wales. The number of cases in Australia linked to the contaminated rockmelons has increased to 19 confirmed and 1 probable. All of the cases were hospitalized and there have been 7 deaths and 1 miscarriage associated with the outbreak. The contaminated rockmelons were also distributed to 8 countries; Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (China), Japan, Kuwait, Malaysia, Oman, Qatar, Singapore, and United Arab Emirates, as well Bahrain and perhaps the Seychelles.\n\nAustralia recalled the implicated rockmelons on 27 February 2018 and import details have been provided though the International Network of Food Safety Authorities (INFOSAN) to the affected countries to enable them to take appropriate management measures including local recalls and risk communication. All the affected countries had been notified by 9 Mar 2018. No cases of listeriosis are known to be linked to the imported rockmelons in the affected countries, but, due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days), further outbreak cases may yet be reported. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "summary": "\n\nFurther trace forward investigations on 7 Mar 2018 identified that Bahrain also received an export of the rockmelons from this grower and on 8 Mar 2018, investigations further identified that the affected rockmelons may have been included in a consignment to the Seychelles. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Australia recalled the implicated rockmelons on 27 February 2018 and import details have been provided though the International Network of Food Safety Authorities (INFOSAN) to the affected countries to enable them to take appropriate management measures including local recalls and risk communication. No cases of listeriosis are known to be linked to the imported rockmelons in the affected countries, but, due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days), further outbreak cases may yet be reported. On 2 Mar 2018, the Australian National Focal Point (NFP) notified WHO of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection (listeriosis) associated with the consumption of rockmelons (cantaloupe) from a single grower. From 17 Jan 2018 through to 6 Apr 2018, 20 outbreak cases (19 confirmed and 1 probable) of listeriosis were reported. ----------\nPregnant women, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals should take precautions to avoid infection by _Listeria_ by avoiding the consumption of high-risk foods including dairy products made of unpasteurized milk, soft cheeses, deli meat products (ready-to eat meat cuts, p\u00e2t\u00e9, etc.); ice creams, raw seafood, crustaceans, and shellfish.
