Singapore (02): Australian rockmelons (cantaloupes) ST240", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5751769", "date": "2018-04-17 12:55:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SINGAPORE (02): AUSTRALIAN ROCKMELONS (CANTALOUPES) ST240\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 16 Apr 2018 11:16 AM SGT\nSource: Channel NewsAsia [edited]\nhttps://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/listeria-singapore-australia-rockmelons-outbreak-moh-10141778\n\n\nAccording to a statement issued by the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Monday morning [Apr 16 2018], 2 patients in Singapore had been infected with a _Listeria_ strain similar to [one causing] an outbreak in Australia tied to rockmelons.\n\nOne patient has recovered while the other died for reasons not due to the _Listeria_ infection, the ministry said. MOH said its National Public Health Laboratory had completed genetic sequence analysis on _Listeria_ bacteria strains obtained from the 5 patients who had _Listeria_ disease this year [2018].\n\nAustralia's rockmelon _Listeria_ outbreak killed 7 people and caused one miscarriage between [17 Jan and 6 Apr 2018], the World Health Organization (WHO) said last week. The deaths were linked to the consumption of rockmelons contaminated with _Listeria_. The rockmelons were exported to at least 9 countries, including Singapore, the WHO said.\n\nSingapore's Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority on Mar 8 announced a recall of all rockmelons from Australia as a 'precautionary measure'. At least 2 consignments of rockmelons, which were traced to a specific Australian grower said to be implicated in the outbreak, were sold in Sheng Siong stores and wet markets.\n\nIn a statement on [12 Mar 2018], MOH said that one case of listeriosis at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) was not linked to the consumption of rockmelons. It added that up to [12 Mar 2018], there had been no reported cases of listeriosis linked to the consumption of rockmelons in Singapore. MOH had also informed doctors to refer suspected cases of listeriosis for testing and treatment and to notify MOH of suspected cases.\n\nOn [Mon 16 Apr 2018], MOH said that initial epidemiological investigations were conducted on 5 patients in Singapore who had _Listeria_ disease this year [2018]. 'There is no further public health risk from the Australia outbreak as the risks have been mitigated through the recall of the implicated consignments in March 2018,' MOH said. 'We will continue to monitor the situation closely.'\n\n_Listeria_ is a bacterium, which causes listeriosis, a form of food poisoning that is treatable with antibiotics if diagnosed early. Symptoms include fever and muscle aches, preceded by diarrhoea or other gastrointestinal symptoms that appear within 70 days after consumption of the contaminated food item.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 16 Apr 2018 00:29:26 SGT\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-04/17/c_137115668.htm\n\n\nSingapore identified a _Listeria_ bacteria strain similar to the one that a patient had contracted in the deadly outbreak in Australia this year [2018], Singapore's Ministry of Health said on [Mon 16 Apr 2018].\n\nThe ministry said in a statement that its National Public Health Laboratory has completed the genetic sequence analysis on bacteria strains taken from 5 patients who had listeriosis this year [2018].\n\nThe ministry found that 2 of them were infected by the _Listeria_ strain ST240, which had a similar gene sequence to the strain found in a patient in the Australian listeriosis outbreak.\n\nOne of the patients has recovered while the other died 'for reasons not due to the _Listeria_ infection,' it added.\n\nRockmelons contaminated with the listeriosis bacteria were exported from Australia to at least 9 countries including Singapore, where the affected rockmelons were recalled and destroyed by the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority in March [2018].\n\n'There is no further public health risk from the Australia outbreak as the risks have been mitigated through the recall of the implicated consignments in March 2018,' it said.\n\nThe ministry added that it will continue to monitor the situation closely.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genetic testing of isolates from 5 patients with listeriosis in Singapore confirmed that the genotype from 2 Singapore patients matched that of the strain causing the rockmelon (cantaloupe) outbreak in Australia.\n\nFrom 17 Jan 2018 through to 6 Apr 2018, 20 cases of listeriosis in Australia (19 confirmed and 1 probable) were associated with the consumption of rockmelons (cantaloupe) from a single grower in the Australian state of New South Wales. All of the cases were hospitalized and there have been 7 deaths and 1 miscarriage associated with the outbreak. The contaminated rockmelons were also distributed to 9 countries (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (China), Japan, Kuwait, Malaysia, Oman, Qatar, Singapore, United Arab Emirates, and Bahrain) and perhaps the Seychelles.\n\nAustralia recalled the implicated rockmelons on 27 Feb 2018. Export details were provided though the International Network of Food Safety Authorities (INFOSAN) to the affected countries to enable them to take appropriate management measures including local recalls and risk communication. All the affected countries had been notified by 9 Mar 2018. The news report above says that Singapore recalled and destroyed the imported rockmelons in March 2018.\n\nThe news report above says that the genotype of _Listeria_ isolates from 2 cases in Singapore match that of the outbreak strain in Australia. A prior ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - Singapore: Australian rockmelons, NOT 20180310.5678316) referred to one case in Singapore, which health authorities reported was not linked to the contaminated rockmelons from Australia. No other cases of listeriosis are known to be linked to the imported rockmelons in the affected countries, but, due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days), further outbreak cases may yet be reported. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSingapore: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nRockmelons contaminated with the listeriosis bacteria were exported from Australia to at least 9 countries including Singapore, where the affected rockmelons were recalled and destroyed by the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority in March [2018]. From 17 Jan 2018 through to 6 Apr 2018, 20 cases of listeriosis in Australia (19 confirmed and 1 probable) were associated with the consumption of rockmelons (cantaloupe) from a single grower in the Australian state of New South Wales. Singapore identified a _Listeria_ bacteria strain similar to the one that a patient had contracted in the deadly outbreak in Australia this year [2018], Singapore's Ministry of Health said on [Mon 16 Apr 2018]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Genetic testing of isolates from 5 patients with listeriosis in Singapore confirmed that the genotype from 2 Singapore patients matched that of the strain causing the rockmelon (cantaloupe) outbreak in Australia. No other cases of listeriosis are known to be linked to the imported rockmelons in the affected countries, but, due to the long incubation period of listeriosis (up to 70 days), further outbreak cases may yet be reported. According to a statement issued by the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Monday morning [Apr 16 2018], 2 patients in Singapore had been infected with a _Listeria_ strain similar to [one causing] an outbreak in Australia tied to rockmelons. The ministry said in a statement that its National Public Health Laboratory has completed the genetic sequence analysis on bacteria strains taken from 5 patients who had listeriosis this year [2018]. \n\n'There is no further public health risk from the Australia outbreak as the risks have been mitigated through the recall of the implicated consignments in March 2018,' it said. \n\nAustralia's rockmelon _Listeria_ outbreak killed 7 people and caused one miscarriage between [17 Jan and 6 Apr 2018], the World Health Organization (WHO) said last week. On [Mon 16 Apr 2018], MOH said that initial epidemiological investigations were conducted on 5 patients in Singapore who had _Listeria_ disease this year [2018]. ' In a statement on [12 Mar 2018], MOH said that one case of listeriosis at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) was not linked to the consumption of rockmelons. It added that up to [12 Mar 2018], there had been no reported cases of listeriosis linked to the consumption of rockmelons in Singapore. A prior ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - Singapore: Australian rockmelons, NOT 20180310.5678316) referred to one case in Singapore, which health authorities reported was not linked to the contaminated rockmelons from Australia. MOH said its National Public Health Laboratory had completed genetic sequence analysis on _Listeria_ bacteria strains obtained from the 5 patients who had _Listeria_ disease this year [2018]. Apr 2018 11:16 AM SGT\nSource: Channel NewsAsia [edited]\nhttps://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/listeria-singapore-australia-rockmelons-outbreak-moh-10141778\n\n\n There is no further public health risk from the Australia outbreak as the risks have been mitigated through the recall of the implicated consignments in March 2018,' MOH said. \n\nThe news report above says that the genotype of _Listeria_ isolates from 2 cases in Singapore match that of the outbreak strain in Australia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "2021-01-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2018-01-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LISTERIOSIS - SINGAPORE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qatar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sheng Siong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Arab Emirates", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Listeriosis - Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5718496", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5718496", "date": "2018-03-30 13:06:17", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (11): FATAL, ST6, WHO RESPONSE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Mar 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/28-march-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/\n\n\nIn South Africa, an outbreak of listeriosis, a serious foodborne disease, has been ongoing since the start of 2017. Between 1 Jan 2017 through 14 Mar 2018, 978 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all provinces. The majority of cases have come from 3 provinces: 581 (59 percent) from Gauteng, 118 (12 percent) from Western Cape and 70 (7 percent) from KwaZulu-Natal provinces, with the remaining cases coming from the other provinces in South Africa.\n\nThe outcome of illness is known for 674 patients, of whom 183 (27 percent) of them died; this case fatality rate is comparable to other recorded listeriosis outbreaks worldwide. Most of the cases are persons who have higher risks for a severe disease outcome, such as neonates, pregnant women, the elderly and immunocompromised persons. In this outbreak, 42 percent of the cases are neonates who were infected during pregnancy or delivery.\n\nWhole genome sequencing was performed on isolates from a large subset of patients. 91 percent of the strains belonged to _Listeria monocytogenes_ Sequence Type 6 (ST6). The same ST6 sequence type was identified in a widely consumed ready-to-eat processed meat product called 'Polony' [Bologna sausage]. The same strain was also found in the processing environment of the manufacturer of the implicated product.\n\nOn 4 Mar 2018, the Ministry of Health, announced that this product was believed to be the source of the outbreak.\n\nThe food processing company and 3 of its retailers export to 15 countries (1) in the African region. All of these countries have issued recalls for the implicated products.\n\nEnvironmental samples from other food production companies in South Africa have also tested positive for _Listeria_, but with strains different from the outbreak strain. These companies have also issued food recalls. Some of their products have been exported to some of the countries mentioned above.\n\n9 percent of the reported cases in the present outbreak in South Africa were infected with different strains of _Listeria_ than the predominant ST6 outbreak strain. This may indicate that more than one outbreak is ongoing. Comprehensive investigations to identify the source of infection of these cases should be conducted.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe country has activated a national multisectoral task force to coordinate investigation and response activities:\nThe Minister of Health, South Africa, held a press conference on 4 Mar 2018 to announce the source of the outbreak. Following the source identification, the national authorities have taken measures to limit further infections and associated mortality, including but not limited to the issuance of safety recall notices, compliance notices, and measures related to exportation of implicated products and risk communication with vulnerable groups.\n\nThe Southern African Development Community (SADC) Health Ministers held a meeting in Johannesburg on 15 Mar 2018, to share information and to enhance preparedness and response for listeriosis. Health Ministers were further reminded about their rights and obligations under the International Health Regulations (IHR) with regards to additional health measures for international travel and trade.\n\nListeriosis has been made a notifiable medical condition in South Africa since December 2017. National risk communication activities have been initiated since December 2017 around the 'WHO five keys to safer food messages.'\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nGlobally, this is the largest outbreak of listeriosis that has been detected. Due to the potentially long incubation period of listeriosis (1 to 3 weeks and up to 70 days) further cases are expected before the impact of the food recall is observed.\n\nFollowing the identification of the source of this outbreak, WHO is now concerned that the export of implicated products may have resulted in listeriosis cases in other countries. Detailed information on the implicated product batches exported to each of the identified 15 countries should be shared with WHO and the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) Secretariat. This will help to facilitate efficient recalls of these products.\n\nRecently, Namibia reported a confirmed case of listeriosis. It is important that this case and other possible cases be properly investigated and the implicated food sources identified. The isolated _Listeria_ strains should be sequenced to determine potential links to the outbreak in South Africa. Some of these countries may not have well-established surveillance systems and laboratory diagnostic services in place to detect cases of listeriosis. In such cases, WHO is ready to provide support and has reached out to 16 African nations (2 West African countries and 14 members of SADC) to provide support for preparedness and response.\n\nAn increase in public concern about the outbreak has been reflected in media reports and discussions in various social media platforms.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nCountries should strengthen national food safety and disease surveillance systems as a prerequisite to prevent similar events in the future and to ensure a safe food supply for their populations. Additionally, countries are urged to pay closer attention to common foodborne pathogens such as _Salmonella_ species, _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Escherichia coli_, and _Listeria monocytogenes_, to make listeriosis a notifiable disease if not yet done, to make the best use of a new 'WHO manual to strengthen surveillance of and response to foodborne diseases,' which was published in November 2017 and to refer to the 'WHO Factsheet on Listeriosis'. See below, in the 'Further Information' section for links to these documents.\n\nResponsible authorities are encouraged to proactively provide public health advice on the prevention and control of listeriosis, including, strengthened risk communication, to address public concerns and promote outbreak control measures.\n\nWHO does not currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions in relation to this outbreak, other than the recall of processed meat products indicated by the South African Government.\n\nWhile WHO understands the desire by sovereign governments to take measures to protect the health of their populations, States Parties to the IHR have obligations not to take actions that significantly interfere with international travel and trade which are not based on scientific principles and which may be viewed as excessive. Indeed such measures contravene the spirit and purpose of the IHR, and can impede public health objectives.\n\nCurrently, 12 out of 15 countries have recalled the implicated processed meat products, and banned imports of the same, while 3 out of these countries have additionally banned imports of other food products. WHO continues to monitor the travel and trade measures taken by countries in relation to this outbreak and their compliance with requirements under the IHR.\n\nFor travellers, it is advisable to practice good food hygiene, such as avoiding uncooked food, avoiding food that has been kept at room temperature for several hours, and always washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before preparing or consuming food.\n\n1. The 15 countries include: Angola, Botswana, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Swaziland, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nCurrently, 12 out of 15 countries have recalled the implicated processed meat products, and banned imports of the same, while 3 out of these countries have additionally banned imports of other food products. \n\nResponsible authorities are encouraged to proactively provide public health advice on the prevention and control of listeriosis, including, strengthened risk communication, to address public concerns and promote outbreak control measures. LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (11): FATAL, ST6, WHO RESPONSE\n On 4 Mar 2018, the Ministry of Health, announced that this product was believed to be the source of the outbreak. The outcome of illness is known for 674 patients, of whom 183 (27 percent) of them died; this case fatality rate is comparable to other recorded listeriosis outbreaks worldwide.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-11-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mozambique", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lesotho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5708506", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5708506", "date": "2018-03-25 05:30:32", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE: FATAL, SEQUENCE TYPE 6, FROZEN CORN, 2015-2018, RECALL\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/03/european-listeriosis-outbreak-blamed-on-frozen-corn-6-dead/#.WrUEW4jwbIU\n\n\nWeek-old speculation about frozen corn being responsible for a 3-year listeriosis outbreak in Europe, which has had an 18.75 per cent fatality rate, is probably correct. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) jointly published a rapid outbreak assessment today [Thu 22 Mar 2018] that says frozen corn is the 'likely source of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_' involving Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom since 2015.\n\nThe 5 European Union (EU) countries have reported 32 confirmed listeriosis cases with 6 deaths between December 2015 and 8 March 2018, according to the EFSA-ECDC assessment. Whole genome sequencing was used to define the multi-country outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ serogroup IVb multi-locus sequence type [ST] 6. Investigators also used it to identify the implicated food source.\n\nOther current listeriosis outbreaks in Australia, South Africa, and Europe are not related events.\n\nInvestigations point toward frozen corn packed in Poland and processed and produced in Hungary. The report recommends further investigation to identify the exact point of contamination in the food chain. Food business operators in Poland, Finland, Sweden and Estonia have withdrawn and recalled the implicated products. These measures are likely to reduce the risk of human infections in these countries.\n\nHowever, new cases may be identified due to the long incubation period of listeriosis, which is up to 70 days, the long shelf-life of frozen corn, and the possible future consumption of frozen corn bought before the recall was implemented. To reduce the risk of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection from frozen corn, consumers should adequately heat frozen vegetables to kill pathogens. This applies especially to consumers at the highest risk of contracting listeriosis -- such as the elderly, pregnant women, newborns, and adults with weakened immune systems.\n\nCoordination across the EU is crucial when there are multi-country foodborne outbreaks. One aspect of this coordination is the production of a rapid outbreak assessment (ROA) by EFSA and ECDC in close cooperation with affected countries. The ROA gives an overview of the situation in terms of public health and identifies the cause of the infections. It also includes trace-back and trace-forward investigations to identify the origin of the outbreak and where contaminated products have been distributed. These help to identify measures that will prevent further spread of the outbreak.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate Thu 22 Mar 2018\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control/European Food Safety Authority [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/sites/portal/files/documents/22-02-2018-RRA-Listeria-Finland.pdf\n\n\nMulti-country outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ serogroup IVb, multi-locus sequence type 6, infections probably linked to frozen corn -- joint ECDC-EFSA rapid outbreak assessment\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConclusion\n----------\nAn outbreak of invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ (_L. monocytogenes_) infections defined by whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and probably linked to frozen corn has been ongoing in five European Union member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom) since 2015. As of 8 March 2018, 32 cases have been reported and 6 patients have died due to or with the infection.\n\nWGS analysis of 6 non-human _L. monocytogenes_ isolates detected from 2016 to January 2018 in Austria, Finland, France and Sweden found these isolates closely related to the multi-country cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ serogroup IVb, multi-locus sequence type 6 (ST6). The non-human isolates were detected in 2 different samples from mixed frozen vegetables; 3 samples from frozen corn, and one sample from a surface where various vegetables could have been processed. The only common food item in all non-human samples was corn.\n\nThe WGS analysis provides a strong microbiological link between the human and the non-human isolates and is suggestive of a potential contaminated food source related to frozen corn persisting in the food chain at least since 2016. Traceability information for the 3 frozen corn samples pointed to frozen corn products packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. Two additional non-human strains isolated in Austria from frozen vegetable mixes with corn as an ingredient were traced back to the same common origin in Hungary. Further investigations are needed to verify the point of contamination in the food chain.\n\nConsumption of frozen corn has been confirmed by 2 patients, one in Finland and one in Sweden. In addition, a Danish patient reported consumption of mixed frozen vegetables, which could have included corn. The Finnish patient confirmed consumption of frozen corn of one suspected brand, supporting an epidemiological link between the outbreak cases and frozen corn. However, no traceability and microbiological information was available for the corn consumed by the Finnish and the Swedish patients.\n\nFood business operators in Estonia, Finland, Poland and Sweden have withdrawn and recalled the implicated frozen corn products from the market. These measures are likely to significantly reduce the risk of human infections in these countries. However, new invasive listeriosis cases may be identified due to the long incubation period (1-70 days), long shelf-lives of frozen corn products and potential consumption of frozen corn bought by the customers before the recalls and eaten without being properly cooked. Furthermore, until the root source of contamination is established and control measures implemented, new cases may occur.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A total of 32 confirmed listeriosis cases, including 6 deaths, between December 2015 and March 8 2018, in a multi-country outbreak in 5 EU member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom) have been linked by whole genome sequencing (genotyping) of clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, to isolates of the organism from frozen corn that was packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. Although the corn has been recalled in some EU states, more cases are expected due to the long incubation period (1-70 days), long shelf-lives of frozen corn products, and potential consumption of frozen corn bought by the customers before the recalls and eaten without being properly cooked.\n\nThe means by which the frozen corn in the EU outbreak was contaminated is yet to be determined. _L. monocytogenes_ widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables them to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nSerotyping of _L. monocytogenes_ strains, based on variations in the somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens, has determined that only 3 (1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b) of the 12 serotypes of _L. monocytogenes_ cause 95 per cent of human cases; serotype 4b is most commonly associated with outbreaks (https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/pdf/listeriainitiativeoverview_508.pdf).\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of European Union: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11767. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A total of 32 confirmed listeriosis cases, including 6 deaths, between December 2015 and March 8 2018, in a multi-country outbreak in 5 EU member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom) have been linked by whole genome sequencing (genotyping) of clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, to isolates of the organism from frozen corn that was packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. Source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control/European Food Safety Authority [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/sites/portal/files/documents/22-02-2018-RRA-Listeria-Finland.pdf\n\n\nMulti-country outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ serogroup IVb, multi-locus sequence type 6, infections probably linked to frozen corn -- joint ECDC-EFSA rapid outbreak assessment\n Although the corn has been recalled in some EU states, more cases are expected due to the long incubation period (1-70 days), long shelf-lives of frozen corn products, and potential consumption of frozen corn bought by the customers before the recalls and eaten without being properly cooked. However, new invasive listeriosis cases may be identified due to the long incubation period (1-70 days), long shelf-lives of frozen corn products and potential consumption of frozen corn bought by the customers before the recalls and eaten without being properly cooked. However, new cases may be identified due to the long incubation period of listeriosis, which is up to 70 days, the long shelf-life of frozen corn, and the possible future consumption of frozen corn bought before the recall was implemented. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The Finnish patient confirmed consumption of frozen corn of one suspected brand, supporting an epidemiological link between the outbreak cases and frozen corn. \n\nWGS analysis of 6 non-human _L. monocytogenes_ isolates detected from 2016 to January 2018 in Austria, Finland, France and Sweden found these isolates closely related to the multi-country cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ serogroup IVb, multi-locus sequence type 6 (ST6). The non-human isolates were detected in 2 different samples from mixed frozen vegetables; 3 samples from frozen corn, and one sample from a surface where various vegetables could have been processed. Traceability information for the 3 frozen corn samples pointed to frozen corn products packed in Poland and processed/produced in Hungary. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) jointly published a rapid outbreak assessment today [Thu 22 Mar 2018] that says frozen corn is the 'likely source of an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_' involving Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom since 2015. The WGS analysis provides a strong microbiological link between the human and the non-human isolates and is suggestive of a potential contaminated food source related to frozen corn persisting in the food chain at least since 2016. An outbreak of invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ (_L. monocytogenes_) infections defined by whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and probably linked to frozen corn has been ongoing in five European Union member states (Austria, Denmark, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom) since 2015. LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE: FATAL, SEQUENCE TYPE 6, FROZEN CORN, 2015-2018, RECALL\n*************************************************************************** To reduce the risk of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection from frozen corn, consumers should adequately heat frozen vegetables to kill pathogens. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nFood business operators in Estonia, Finland, Poland and Sweden have withdrawn and recalled the implicated frozen corn products from the market.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hungary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5691654", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (03): fatal, cantaloupe, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5691654", "date": "2018-03-16 16:58:21", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 16 Mar 2018, 8:33 PM\nSource: ABC news [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-16/fifth-rockmelon-listeria-death-victorian-man-dies/9554778\n\n\nA Victorian man in his 80s has become the 5th person to die in a listeriosis outbreak after eating contaminated rockmelons [also known as cantaloupes]. A total of 3 Victorians and 2 people from New South Wales have died after consuming fruit linked to a farm in southern NSW.\n\nVictoria's deputy chief health officer, Dr Brett Sutton, said the latest death had been linked to the outbreak only after test results came back. 'Sadly, the investigation has also confirmed that a miscarriage has also been linked to the outbreak,' Dr Sutton added. Victoria's health department would not provide further details about the victim, including the date of his death.\n\nAs many as 8 people in Victoria have been affected with listeriosis from the melons - 4 men and 4 women -, all from high-risk groups. Cases have also been reported in Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania.\n\nThe outbreak has been traced to Rombola Family Farms near Griffith. In a statement on [Thu 15 Mar 2018], the business said it was working with the NSW Food Authority to 'identify, quarantine and remedy' the source of the listeria. 'As a family business we are all too aware of the impact the outbreak is having on fellow growers and the wider industry,' the statement said. 'We remain ever vigilant to food safety and contamination risks and are focused on working to achieve a resolution for all stakeholders.' All affected melons, have been withdrawn from sale and distribution.\n\nThe NSW Food Authority said rockmelons currently on the shelf are safe to eat. The authority is also considering imposing additional regulation on the rockmelon industry to ensure compliance with food safety. Farmers have described the outbreak as a national disaster that will take the industry years to recover from.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 16 Mar 2018, 9:50 AM\nSource: The Sydney Morning Herald [edited]\nhttps://www.smh.com.au/national/fifth-death-and-miscarriage-linked-to-national-listeria-outbreak-20180316-p4z4my.html\n\n\nA 3rd Victorian has died and a woman has suffered a miscarriage after a national outbreak of listeriosis linked to contaminated rockmelons. The death of a man in his 80s brings the national death toll to 5. 'This latest case has only just been linked to the outbreak as a result of our microbiological testing,' Victoria's Deputy Chief Health Officer Dr Brett Sutton said. 'Sadly, the investigation has also confirmed that a miscarriage has also been linked to the outbreak.'\n\nThere have now been 19 recorded listeriosis cases across Australia. The outbreak has been linked to 2 other deaths in Victoria and 2 in New South Wales. There have now been 8 recorded cases in Victoria, 6 in NSW, 4 in Queensland and 1 in Tasmania. The affected Victorians, 4 men and 4 women, were all in high-risk groups.\n\nHealth authorities have connected the outbreak to rockmelon grower Rombola Family Farms in the Riverina region of New South Wales. The NSW Food Authority said it was working with the business in Nericon, near Griffith to determine the exact cause of the outbreak. 'The Food Authority is now working with Rombola Family Farms in an effort to support the business and the wider rockmelon industry as it works to recover from the impact of the outbreak,' it said in a statement on [Tue 13 Mar 2018]. The authority is confident all affected produce has been removed from the supply chain and the rockmelons currently for sale and export are not contaminated.\n\n[Byline: Anna Prytz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases and deaths in the current listeriosis outbreak traced to rockmelons (cantaloupes) in Australia has increased to 19 and 5, respectively. NSW [New South Wales] recorded 6 cases, Victoria recorded 8 cases; there have been 4 cases in Queensland and one in Tasmania. The outbreak has been linked to 2 deaths in NSW and 3 in Victoria. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Farmers have described the outbreak as a national disaster that will take the industry years to recover from.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [Byline: Anna Prytz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases and deaths in the current listeriosis outbreak traced to rockmelons (cantaloupes) in Australia has increased to 19 and 5, respectively. The Food Authority is now working with Rombola Family Farms in an effort to support the business and the wider rockmelon industry as it works to recover from the impact of the outbreak,' it said in a statement on [Tue 13 Mar 2018]. \n\nVictoria's deputy chief health officer, Dr Brett Sutton, said the latest death had been linked to the outbreak only after test results came back. ' Date: Fri 16 Mar 2018, 8:33 PM\nSource: ABC news [edited]\nhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-16/fifth-rockmelon-listeria-death-victorian-man-dies/9554778\n\n\n LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES\n***********************************************************\n \n\n\nA 3rd Victorian has died and a woman has suffered a miscarriage after a national outbreak of listeriosis linked to contaminated rockmelons. ' ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NSW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Griffith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nericon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5691653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (10): fatal, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5691653", "date": "2018-03-16 16:56:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (10): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Mar 2018\nSource: AllAfrica, a News24 report [edited]\nhttps://allafrica.com/stories/201803160070.html\n\n\nA total of 11 more cases of listeriosis have been reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), but no more deaths so far. 'No additional deaths have been reported since the last situation update [on 8 Mar 2018],' the NICD said on [Thu 15 Mar 2018]. So far, 183 people have died of the food-borne disease outbreak and 978 cases have been reported since January 2017.\n\nThe NICD has been able to analyse data relating to some of the patients, in an effort to form a picture of who it was affecting the most.\n\nOn March 4 [2018], Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi announced that an investigation into the outbreak had traced the ST6 strain of the _Listeria_ bacteria, believed to be behind the outbreak, to Tiger Brands's Enterprise factory in the Limpopo capital, Polokwane.\n\nA national recall of Enterprise polonies, viennas, cold meats and chilled meat products was ordered and, by [Mon 12 Mar 2018], Tiger Brands had amassed and quarantined around 3500 tons of the foods. They are destined for incineration and staff are deep-cleaning the factory as local and international experts privately conduct investigations for the company to confirm the NICD's findings.\n\nThis was after the NICD had analysed swabs taken at the factory in Polokwane, after tracing the source of a food believed to have been consumed by a group of sick creche children, who are being treated at the Chris Hani-Baragwanath Hospital in Soweto, Gauteng.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ were also found at Tiger Brands's Germiston plant, but it has not yet been confirmed that they were the ST6 strain. Tiger Brands is at present not supplying any of these chilled meat products and has embarked on an extensive campaign to alert the public to return the products to retailers for a full refund, even if the packet has already been opened. Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) has also recalled its polony as a precaution.\n\nThe NICD said in its latest bulletin that 748 of the known cases were reported in 2017, and 230 in 2018. Of the cases they managed to get more information on:\n\n- 532 of those affected were women (where gender was reported);\n- the ages of those affected ranged from birth to 92 years;\n- 398 of the people who became ill were babies younger than 28 days;\n- 96 percent of the affected babies became sick between birth and 6 days old;\n- most cases have been reported from Gauteng (581), followed by the Western\nCape (118) and then KwaZulu-Natal (70)\n- 639 cases were diagnosed in public health facilities; and\n- 342 were diagnosed in private health facilities.\n\nThe NICD added that cases were still expected to be reported up to 4 weeks or longer after the recall of the implicated foodstuffs, as the incubation period for listeriosis can be 21 days, with a reported maximum of 70 days.\n\n'Health care workers are urged to continue with vigilance for new cases as people who have consumed implicated processed meat products over the past few weeks may continue to present with listeriosis,' said the NICD.\n\nIn the meantime, Cabinet extended its 'heartfelt condolences' to the friends and families of those who lost their lives after contracting listeriosis, and wished those who were recuperating a speedy recovery. Motsoaledi was also expected to meet representatives of the SA Nursing Council on [Thu 15 Mar 2018].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are now a total of 978 cases of listeriosis, including 183 deaths, reported since January 2017 in this outbreak in South Africa linked to contaminated ready-to-eat meat produced by Tiger Brands's Enterprise factory in the Limpopo capital, Polokwane. More cases are expected, despite the recall, because of the long incubation period of listeriosis of up to 70 days. In addition, contaminated product may still be in the refrigerators of some people unaware of the situation. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "Of the cases they managed to get more information on:\n\n- 532 of those affected were women (where gender was reported);\n- the ages of those affected ranged from birth to 92 years;\n- 398 of the people who became ill were babies younger than 28 days;\n- 96 percent of the affected babies became sick between birth and 6 days old;\n- most cases have been reported from Gauteng (581), followed by the Western\nCape (118) and then KwaZulu-Natal (70)\n- 639 cases were diagnosed in public health facilities; and\n- 342 were diagnosed in private health facilities.\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are now a total of 978 cases of listeriosis, including 183 deaths, reported since January 2017 in this outbreak in South Africa linked to contaminated ready-to-eat meat produced by Tiger Brands's Enterprise factory in the Limpopo capital, Polokwane. 'This is the 1st case of listeriosis in Namibia since the beginning of the epidemic in neighboring South Africa,' he added. The patient is reported to have eaten Vienna sausages in Tsumeb town in [Oshikoto region] in northern Namibia, he said, adding that he was 'in a stable state'.\n\nThe minister again called on the population not to consume sausages produced in South Africa. This country is experiencing the worst epidemic in the world of listeriosis, which has killed at least 183 people since January 2017, according to the latest assessment of the South African authorities. After months of investigation, the source of the infection was finally identified on [4 Mar 2018], the Enterprise Food in South Africa.\n\nThe bacterium that causes listeriosis was also found in a sample from one of South Africa's Rainbow Chickens plants. The South African authorities have since temporarily suspended the export licenses of these 2 companies.\n\nListeriosis is caused by bacteria in soil, water, vegetation, and animal excrement, and can contaminate food, including meat, dairy products, and seafood.\n\nThe most vulnerable people include premature babies and pregnant women.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Multiple countries in Africa that have imposed restrictions on South African meat imports include Namibia, Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Swaziland, Zambia, and Zimbabwe (https://www.thesouthafrican.com/listeriosis-namibia-records-first-case-after-sa-outbreak/).\n\nThe 41-year-old Namibian man who was diagnosed with listeriosis was said in the news report above to have eaten Vienna sausages in Tsumeb, a city of 15 000 residents in northern Namibia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsumeb). However, we are not told if the Vienna sausages eaten by this man were imported from South Africa and manufactured by Enterprise Foods that produced the _Listeria_- contaminated ready-to-eat meat products involved in the South African listeriosis outbreak. Genotyping _Listeria_ isolated from the Namibian patient and the Vienna sausages he ate would help link this patient to the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. Ready-to-eat meat is a common source for listeriosis. If the genotype of the Namibian isolates does not match the genotype found in the South Africa outbreak strain, listeriosis in the Namibian man was likely due to a locally acquired strain.\n\nA map of Namibia showing the location of Tsumeb can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/9ZEowPTMxit. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nTsumeb, Oshikoto, Namibia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5791]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe 41-year-old Namibian man who was diagnosed with listeriosis was said in the news report above to have eaten Vienna sausages in Tsumeb, a city of 15 000 residents in northern Namibia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsumeb). Singapore: Australian rockmelons, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5678316", "date": "2018-03-10 15:34:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SINGAPORE: AUSTRALIAN ROCKMELONS, NOT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2018\nSource: Straits Times [edited]\nhttp://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/listeria-case-at-sgh-not-linked-to-contaminated-rockmelons-moh\n\n\nHealth authorities say there is no link between a patient who was seen at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) for listeriosis and the consumption of contaminated rockmelons from Australia, according to preliminary investigations.\n\nThe Ministry of Health (MOH) told The Straits Times on Friday [9 Mar 2018] that there is still no report of anyone here having contracted the bacterial disease as a result of eating the rockmelons, which have made 17 people ill in Australia and killed 4. All rockmelons from Australia are in the process of being recalled by authorities.\n\nThe ministry said it was notified by SGH of a case of listeriosis on Tue 6 Mar 2018. Further tests are ongoing to determine the source of infection.\n\nA WhatsApp message that circulated on Friday [9 Mar 2018] claimed that someone who ate rockmelons from Sheng Siong[*] ended up as the 'first case of listeria in SGH.'\n\nThe outbreak in Australia is linked to contaminated rockmelons from a farm in New South Wales. Consignments of melons from the farm were found to have been exported to Singapore.\n\nThere is an incubation period of between 3 and 70 days after consuming _Listeria_-contaminated food. Consumers should seek medical attention as early as possible if they develop fever and muscle aches that are preceded by diarrhoea or other gastrointestinal symptoms appearing within 70 days of eating Australian rockmelon, the ministry said.\n\nDoctors have been asked to refer suspected cases of listeriosis for testing and treatment and to notify MOH of suspected cases. 'We will continue to monitor the situation closely,' said the MOH spokesman.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 8 Mar 2018\nSource: Channel News Asia [edited]\nhttps://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-recall-all-rockmelons-australia-more-listeria-exported-10027154\n\n\nThe Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) on Thursday [8 Mar 2018] announced a recall of all rockmelons [cantaloupes] from Australia as a 'precautionary measure.' This is because it received new information from Australian authorities indicating that more _Listeria_-affected consignments had been exported to Singapore.\n\nThe _Listeria_ outbreak has so far been traced to a specific grower in the state of New South Wales. AVA had a few days ago recalled 2 consignments of rockmelon from this grower. Rockmelons from those 2 consignments were sold at Sheng Siong[*] stores and wet markets between 12 Feb and 2 Mar 2018. 'We expanded the recall to include all rockmelons from Australia immediately after receiving the latest updates from the Australian authorities,' said AVA in a media release.\n\n'The Australian authorities confirmed that the farm had stopped production on 23 Feb [2018] and that there are no other affected farms in Australia. AVA will continue to work with the Australian authorities on this matter.'\n\nIn Australia, 4 people have died, and 13 others fell ill after consuming melon contaminated with _Listeria_. Singapore authorities said that to date, there have been no such cases reported here.\n\n'We had earlier taken samples of locally sold rockmelons for food safety tests, including testing for _Listeria_. The results are pending,' added AVA.\n\nIt also advised food retail establishments to temporarily stop selling rockmelons from Australia as well as to stop using them in dishes immediately until further notice. 'If retailers are unsure of the source of their rockmelons, they should also stop the sale or use of such rockmelons as a precaution,' said the authority.\n\nConsumers who have bought rockmelons from Australia -- or who are unsure where the rockmelons they bought come from -- are advised not to eat them, AVA added. Those who do not feel well after consuming rockmelon should seek medical attention.\n\n_Listeria_ is a bacterium that causes listeriosis, a form of food poisoning that is treatable with antibiotics if diagnosed early. Symptoms include fever and muscle aches, preceded by diarrhoea or other gastrointestinal symptoms that appear within 70 days after consumption of the contaminated food item.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sheng Siong is the 3rd largest chain of supermarkets in Singapore (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheng_Siong).\n\nA report mistakenly said that listeriosis in a hospitalized patient at Singapore General Hospital was linked to eating a melon, but the melon was called a Hami melon, which is a type of muskmelon, originally from Hami, Xinjiang, China. This report was in Chinese and machine translated (https://www.channel8news.sg/news8/singapore/2080309-sg-sgh-listeria/3977428.html). Pictures of Hami melons are available at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hami_melon.\n\nSingapore recalled all rockmelons [cantaloupes] imported from Australia as a 'precautionary measure' several days ago in response to the outbreak in Australia that had been traced to a specific grower in the Australian state of New South Wales, No cases of listeriosis have been linked to consumption of Australian rockmelons in Singapore.\n\nSingapore is an island nation in Southeast Asia at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, with Indonesia to the south. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hami", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5672344", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, cantaloupe, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5672344", "date": "2018-03-07 19:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 6 Mar 2018\nSource: The Sydney Morning Herald [edited]\nhttps://www.smh.com.au/national/death-toll-rises-to-four-in-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-rockmelons-20180306-p4z34n.html\n\n\nFour people have died, and 2 fresh cases of [listeriosis] have been detected in a national outbreak linked to contaminated rockmelons [cantaloupes]. A Victorian man and a Queensland woman have taken the number of confirmed cases to 17. NSW [New South Wales] and Victoria have both recorded 6 cases; there have been 4 cases in Queensland and one in Tasmania. The outbreak has been linked to 2 deaths in NSW and 2 in Victoria.\n\nRockmelon from a farm [in Nericon, near Griffith in NSW] has been linked to the [listeriosis] outbreak that has affected 17 people across the country.\n\nVictoria's Deputy Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton said the most recent case had been linked to the outbreak strain through microbiological tests.\n\nThat state's 6 cases have affected 3 men and 3 women aged between 60 and 90.\n\nNSW Health's director of communicable diseases, Vicky Sheppeard, said the Victorian man and the Queensland woman got sick before the contaminated melons were recalled on 28 Feb 2018. Dr Sheppeard said listeriosis had a lengthy incubation period of up to 70 days. 'There are multiple foods consumed and retailers used by the cases, which need to be thoroughly investigated and the findings matched to specialist laboratory test results, to determine the source.'\n\nShe said NSW Health responded immediately with the NSW Food Authority and other state health departments to pinpoint the cause and advise vulnerable groups on how to minimise their risk. 'All state and national guidelines have been followed and public warnings issued here and interstate when the food source was identified.'\n\nAll affected melons have been withdrawn from sale and distribution; the rockmelons now available are not affected. If consumers are not sure of the origins of a rockmelon, they should put it in the waste bin to avoid further contamination.\n\nThe NSW Food Authority reminded people vulnerable to [listeriosis] to avoid all foods that posed a risk, including pre-packed cold salads, pre-cooked cold chicken, cold delicatessen meats, pate, raw or smoked seafood, unpasteurized milk, soft cheeses, sprouted seeds and raw mushrooms.\n\n[Byline: Megan Gorrey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<prome@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases and deaths in the current listeriosis outbreak traced to rockmelons (cantaloupes) in Australia have increased to 17 and 4, respectively.\n\nState health departments were able to pinpoint the source of the outbreak to a farm in Nericon, near the city of Griffith, in the New South Wales (NSW), Riverina district (http://theconversation.com/what-is-listeria-and-how-does-it-spread-in-rockmelons-92651). However, we have not been told so far how the rockmelons became contaminated.\n\nRiverina is an agricultural region of south western NSW, Australia. A map of Australia showing the location of Nericon can be found at https://www.whereis.com/nsw/nericon-2680. A HealthMap of New South Wales, Australia can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.\n\nMy colleague, ProMED-mail moderator LXL reports that Qatar has now banned the importation of melons from Australia and New Zealand (source article in Chinese, machine translated, http://spzx.foods1.com/show_2726017.htm). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<prome@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases and deaths in the current listeriosis outbreak traced to rockmelons (cantaloupes) in Australia have increased to 17 and 4, respectively. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe NSW Food Authority reminded people vulnerable to [listeriosis] to avoid all foods that posed a risk, including pre-packed cold salads, pre-cooked cold chicken, cold delicatessen meats, pate, raw or smoked seafood, unpasteurized milk, soft cheeses, sprouted seeds and raw mushrooms. \n\nRockmelon from a farm [in Nericon, near Griffith in NSW] has been linked to the [listeriosis] outbreak that has affected 17 people across the country. https://www.smh.com.au/national/death-toll-rises-to-four-in-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-rockmelons-20180306-p4z34n.html\n\n\nFour people have died, and 2 fresh cases of [listeriosis] have been detected in a national outbreak linked to contaminated rockmelons [cantaloupes]. \n\nState health departments were able to pinpoint the source of the outbreak to a farm in Nericon, near the city of Griffith, in the New South Wales (NSW), Riverina district (http://theconversation.com/what-is-listeria-and-how-does-it-spread-in-rockmelons-92651). \n\nThat state's 6 cases have affected 3 men and 3 women aged between 60 and 90. \n\nNSW Health's director of communicable diseases, Vicky Sheppeard, said the Victorian man and the Queensland woman got sick before the contaminated melons were recalled on 28 Feb 2018. LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES\n***********************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-02-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nericon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Griffith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qatar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5666617", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (09): fatal, health dept. press release", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5666617", "date": "2018-03-05 12:14:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nFrom: Charlene Jacobs <charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za> [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n'The situation now is as follows:\n\n'As of [2 mar 2018], the total of laboratory-confirmed cases has risen to 948, still counting from January 2017. Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n'On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. The paediatrician suspected foodborne disease, including listeriosis, as a possible cause. The environmental health practitioners (EHPs) were informed and on the same day visited the cr\u00e8che, and obtained samples from 2 unrelated polony brands (manufactured by Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) respectively) and submitted these to the laboratory for testing.\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n'I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n'Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. The outbreak strain, ST6, was confirmed in at least 16 environmental samples collected from this Enterprise facility.\n\n'The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane.\n\n'Additionally, preliminary results show that several ready-to-eat processed meat products from the Enterprise facility located in Germiston contain _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence type is not known as yet.\n\n'Investigation of the RCL Wolwehoek production facility is also underway. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n'With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n'1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n'Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n'The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n'2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n'3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n'4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n'Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n'The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n'It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.'\n\n'For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>'\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap: South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "\n\n'Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease). should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n'3. \n\n'The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.
