LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\n Director: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180 \n\n'With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n'1. [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n \n\n'Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\n \n\n'For media enquiries, please contact:\n \n\n'The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'. \n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane. \n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2018-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soweto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polokwane", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5659577", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: fatal, cantaloupe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5659577", "date": "2018-03-01 17:25:16", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: FATAL, CANTALOUPE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Feb 2018, 4:11 PM\nSource: Mirage News [edited]\nhttps://www.miragenews.com/listeriosis-outbreak-linked-to-rockmelon/\n\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales, Australia] Food Authority is advising consumers who are most vulnerable to listeria infection -- such as older persons, and people who have weakened immune systems due to illness or pregnancy -- to avoid eating rockmelon [also called cantaloupe] after a recent spike in listeriosis cases in elderly people has been linked to the fruit. As a precaution, consumers [particularly those who are elderly, pregnant or immune compromised] who may have rockmelon already in their home are advised to discard it.\n\nListeria is found widely in the environment and rarely causes serious illness in the general population but for vulnerable people, such as those who are over 70, pregnant, or have diabetes, cancer or suppressed immune systems, it can be extremely serious or even life threatening.\n\nAll states and territories are working together to investigate the outbreak and to date they have identified 10 cases in elderly patients in NSW (6), Victoria (1) and Queensland (3) with onset of illness notification dates between [17 Jan and 9 Feb 2018]. All 10 cases consumed rockmelon prior to their illness.\n\nThe outbreak has been linked to a grower in Nericon NSW. The company voluntarily ceased production on [Fri 23 Feb 2018], shortly after being notified of a potential link to illness and is working proactively with the authority to further investigate how any contamination could have occurred in order to get back into production as soon as possible. Any affected product is being removed from the supply chain, so consumers can be assured rockmelons currently available on shelves are not implicated in this outbreak.\n\nListeriosis starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, and sometimes diarrhoea. The symptoms can take a few days or even up to 6 weeks to appear after eating contaminated produce. People at risk should consult their local doctor as early as possible should symptoms appear.\n\nThe NSW Food Authority and NSW Health will continue to work with other jurisdictions to monitor the situation.\n\nThe 6 NSW cases linked to consumption of rockmelon form only a portion of the increased listeriosis cases in NSW so far this year, with 15 people affected, mainly elderly with underlying health conditions. Vulnerable people are reminded to avoid all foods that pose a risk of listeriosis, including: pre-cut melons such as rockmelon or watermelon; pre-packed cold salads including coleslaw and fresh fruit salad; pre-cooked cold chicken, cold delicatessen meats, p\u00e2t\u00e9; raw seafood, uncooked smoked seafood (such as smoked salmon); unpasteurised milk or milk products, soft cheeses (for example brie, camembert, ricotta or blue-vein); [and] sprouted seeds or raw mushrooms.\n\nThe NSW Food Authority and NSW Health are continuing investigations into other possible sources of the remaining recent listeriosis cases.\n\nFurther food safety advice relating to the safe preparation and storage of rockmelon can be found at <www.foodauthority.nsw.gov.au/foodsafetyandyou/special-care-foods/rockmelons/media release>.\n\n[Two of the 6 who became ill in NSW reportedly died (https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/mar/01/australians-told-to-throw-out-rockmelon-after-two-deaths-in-listeria-outbreak). - Mod.ML]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The melon with sweet orange flesh and a rough skin, known as a cantaloupe in the USA, is called a rockmelon in much of Australia. The melons can become contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, anywhere along the chain of food production: planting, harvesting, packing, distribution, preparation and serving. All ten people in the current listeriosis outbreak in Australia ate rockmelon before they fell sick and state and territory health departments were able to pinpoint the source to a farm in Nericon, near the city of Griffith, in the New South Wales (NSW) Riverina district (http://theconversation.com/what-is-listeria-and-how-does-it-spread-in-rockmelons-92651).\n\nA large multistate outbreak of listeriosis in the USA in 2011 that involved a total of 147 patients -- with 33 deaths attributed to listeriosis -- in 28 states was linked to whole cantaloupes grown at a farm in the US state of Colorado. _L. monocytogenes_ outbreak subtypes were isolated from difficult-to-clean equipment at a packing facility. It was suspected that a dump truck used to take deformed melons to a cattle farm could have brought listeria to this packing facility (http://blog.consumerbell.com/2011/10/19/consumer-recall-safety-fda-announces-investigation-results-from-listeria-contaminated-cantaloupe/). Farm animals can carry listeria in their intestinal tract and shed _L. monocytogenes_ in the feces. Their manure can then contaminate soil and run-off from a cattle farm. We are not told in the news report above how rockmelons in the current outbreak in Australia became contaminated.\n\nRiverina is an agricultural region of south western NSW, Australia. A map of Australia showing the location of Nericon can be found at https://www.whereis.com/nsw/nericon-2680.\n\nHealthMap: New South Wales, Australia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Vulnerable people are reminded to avoid all foods that pose a risk of listeriosis, including: pre-cut melons such as rockmelon or watermelon; pre-packed cold salads including coleslaw and fresh fruit salad; pre-cooked cold chicken, cold delicatessen meats, p\u00e2t\u00e9; raw seafood, uncooked smoked seafood (such as smoked salmon); unpasteurised milk or milk products, soft cheeses (for example brie, camembert, ricotta or blue-vein); Food Authority is advising consumers who are most vulnerable to listeria infection -- such as older persons, and people who have weakened immune systems due to illness or pregnancy -- to avoid eating rockmelon [also called cantaloupe] after a recent spike in listeriosis cases in elderly people has been linked to the fruit. ML]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The melon with sweet orange flesh and a rough skin, known as a cantaloupe in the USA, is called a rockmelon in much of Australia. \n\nA large multistate outbreak of listeriosis in the USA in 2011 that involved a total of 147 patients -- with 33 deaths attributed to listeriosis -- in 28 states was linked to whole cantaloupes grown at a farm in the US state of Colorado. \n\nThe 6 NSW cases linked to consumption of rockmelon form only a portion of the increased listeriosis cases in NSW so far this year, with 15 people affected, mainly elderly with underlying health conditions. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAll states and territories are working together to investigate the outbreak and to date they have identified 10 cases in elderly patients in NSW (6), Victoria (1) and Queensland (3) with onset of illness notification dates between [17 Jan and 9 Feb 2018]. All ten people in the current listeriosis outbreak in Australia ate rockmelon before they fell sick and state and territory health departments were able to pinpoint the source to a farm in Nericon, near the city of Griffith, in the New South Wales (NSW) Riverina district (http://theconversation.com/what-is-listeria-and-how-does-it-spread-in-rockmelons-92651). Listeria is found widely in the environment and rarely causes serious illness in the general population but for vulnerable people, such as those who are over 70, pregnant, or have diabetes, cancer or suppressed immune systems, it can be extremely serious or even life threatening. \n\nFurther food safety advice relating to the safe preparation and storage of rockmelon can be found at <www.foodauthority.nsw.gov.au/foodsafetyandyou/special-care-foods/rockmelons/media release>. The melons can become contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, anywhere along the chain of food production: planting, harvesting, packing, distribution, preparation and serving. The company voluntarily ceased production on [Fri 23 Feb 2018], shortly after being notified of a potential link to illness and is working proactively with the authority to further investigate how any contamination could have occurred in order to get back into production as soon as possible.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2070-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-17 00:00:00", "2018-02-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NSW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nericon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5665592", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (08): fatal, more cases, source found, polony", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5665592", "date": "2018-03-05 10:30:28", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (08): FATAL, MORE CASES, SOURCE FOUND, POLONY\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43279627\n\n\nSouth Africa says it has finally traced the source of an outbreak [of listeriosis] that has killed 180 people in the past year -- said to make it the worst in history.\n\nThe source is a factory operated by Enterprise Foods in Polokwane in Limpopo. More facilities are being tested to see if they contributed to the outbreak, which infected almost 1000 people.\n\nThe health minister warned cross-contamination of other processed meats could have occurred in shops. 'Avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat\u201a' Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi told journalists at the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) on Sunday afternoon [4 Mar 2018]. He told pregnant women to avoid any processed meat 'like the plague', reported Times Live.\n\nMore than 16 environmental samples from the Enterprise Polokwane factory tested positive for the _Listeria monocytogenes_ strain ST 6 -- a particularly virulent strain. Mr Motsoaledi said a ready-to-eat sausage known as polony, made by Enterprise Food and RCL Foods, would be recalled from stores.\n\nA shortage of the solution used for testing for the _Listeria_ bacteria meant the results of the tests at the Polokwane factory were delayed by 2 weeks, NICD's Dr Juno Thomas told Times Live.\n\nIt is believed that the factory will be closed down.\n\nThe _Listeria_ bacterium is hard to test for, as it is not homogenously distributed in food. It can also 'hide away' in cracks or niches in factories. Consumers who stored recalled products in their fridges should disinfect them with diluted bleach.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018 13:20 SAST\nSource: News24 [edited]\nhttps://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/breaking-listeriosis-outbreak-traced-to-enterprise-facility-in-polokwane-20180304\n\n\nThe outbreak of listeriosis has been traced to an Enterprise Foods facility in Polokwane, Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi announced on [Sun 4 Mar 2018]. 'We can now conclude scientifically that the source of the present outbreak is the Enterprise Food production facility located in Polokwane,' he said at the offices of the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) in Johannesburg.\n\n_Listeria_ has [also] been traced to another Enterprise facility in Germiston on the East Rand, and a Rainbow chicken facility in the Free State, but further tests were needed as the sequence type was not yet known.\n\nThe National Consumer Commission has issued safety recall notices to those manufacturers and facilities, and the companies are now responsible for coming up with the recall plan. The plan must be sufficient to cover their entire distribution chain, and the facilities will also have to resource and pay for the implementation.\n\nMotsoaledi said several children presented with gastroenteritis in Soweto [Johannesburg metropolitan municipality, Gauteng] earlier in the week. Tests were done, and it was found that they had listeriosis. The strain they were affected with, which was the same for the larger outbreak, was traced to Enterprise's Polokwane facility.\n\nMotsoaledi said statistics on [2 Mar 2018] show that the outbreak has claimed about 180 lives and 948 laboratory-confirmed cases had been reported to the NICD.\n\nHe said while polony was a definite source, other products such as Viennas, Russians, Frankfurters, other sausages and cold meats not typically cooked could also be affected due to the risk of cross-contamination.\n\nPregnant women, neonates, elderly people and anyone with weakened systems should 'not go near' these products.\n\nMotsoaledi said retailers must clean their fridges, meat slicers, and either remove the ready-to-eat meat products or place them in plastic bags in separate fridges -- ahead of the recall. 'I've already emptied [out] my fridge this morning... I woke up my wife -- [and told let's] just take these things out,' he said. 'Any human being in the country who has these products in their fridge must take them out immediately.'\n\n_Listeria_ is a bacterium that is naturally found in the environment -- it commonly occurs in soil, water, vegetation, and in the faeces of some animals. It can contaminate a wide variety of food types, including meat and meat products, dairy products (unpasteurised and pasteurised), fresh and frozen produce (fruits, vegetables, and sprouts) and ready-to-eat products.\n\n[Byline: Tammy Petersen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-safrica-disease-listeria/south-africa-traces-deadly-listeria-to-processed-meat-issues-recall-idUSKBN1GG0OF\n\n\nSouth Africans were told on [Sun 4 Mar 2018] not to consume ready-to-eat processed meat as the government identified the source of a [listeriosis] outbreak that has killed 180 people as a cold meat product made by the country's biggest consumer foods group.\n\nThe meat, known as 'polony', made by Tiger Brands unit Enterprise Food and by RCL Foods, would be recalled from stores, Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said.\n\n'We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat,' Motsoaledi said, adding that, due to the risk of cross-contamination, all such foods were a potential health hazard.\n\n'We can now conclude scientifically that the source of the present outbreak is the Enterprise Food production facility located in Polokwane,' Motsoaledi told a briefing at the offices of the National Institute of Communicable Diseases.\n\nTiger Brands said it was cooperating with authorities and RCL Foods said it would suspend all production of its Rainbow Polony brand.\n\nMotsoaledi said although RCL Foods had not been identified as a source of the outbreak, a facility owned by the firm was under investigation. Inquiries were ongoing at a second facility run by Enterprise Foods to establish if it too had contributed.\n\nThe outbreak has caused 180 fatalities and 948 reported cases since January 2017.\n\nTiger Brands spokeswoman Nevashnee Naicker said: 'We are all extremely concerned by listeriosis -- we all want to find the source or sources of listeriosis, together with the government.'\n\nRCL Foods chief legal officer Stephen Heath said the company was recalling its polony products even though test results were still pending. 'RCL Foods is sharing all results from its testing, both internally and externally, with the relevant authorities,' Heath said. 'We will continue to take every precaution to safeguard our products as well as our consumers.\n\nSouth African supermarket operator Pick n Pay said it had withdrawn the products from its shelves. 'All fridges and food preparation areas in our stores will now be re-cleaned to prevent any cross-contamination. Recalled meat is being isolated and will be safely destroyed,' spokeswoman Tamra Capstick-Dale said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: James Macharia]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (07): fatal, more cases 20180224.5648305), there were 915 confirmed cases nationally, including 172 deaths, with a case fatality rate of 18.8 percent. Now the outbreak involves 948 laboratory-confirmed cases, including 180 deaths, which is said to be the world's biggest documented listeriosis outbreak.\n\nThe news reports above say that the outbreak strain, _Listeria monocytogenes_ strain ST 6, has been recovered from the Enterprise factory in Polokwane (Tiger Brands unit), definitely involving a ready-to-eat sausage known as polony, but possibly could also involve other ready-to-eat meat products such as Viennas, Russians, Frankfurters, other sausages and cold meats due to cross-contamination. According to another news report, preliminary, results show that other ready-to-eat products at Enterprise's Germiston plant\u201a as well as Rainbow Chickens' (RCL) Wolwehoek plant, also contain _Listeria_\u201a but the sequence type has yet to be confirmed (https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/consumer-live/2018-03-04-listeriosis-what-to-do-with-your-enterprise-or-rainbow-polony/).\n\nWe are told that polony, made by Enterprise Food, would be recalled from stores, but are not given identification markings. Another news report says that Enterprise is also being urged to recall smoked Russians and frankfurters and Rainbow (RCL) is being instructed to do the same with its chicken Viennas, although RCL Foods has not been identified as a source of the outbreak (https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/consumer-live/2018-03-04-listeriosis-what-to-do-with-your-enterprise-or-rainbow-polony/).\n\nBologna sausage, known in South Africa as polony, is a finely ground pork sausage, originally from the Italian city of Bologna; bologna can alternatively be made out of chicken (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bologna_sausage).\n\nPolokwane is the capital of the Limpopo province and South Africa's largest urban center north of the province of Gauteng; Gauteng is divided into 5 municipalities, 2 of which are Johannesburg and Pretoria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polokwane). A map of Polokwane can be found at https://goo.gl/maps/XkFihj5gve12. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Tiger Brands spokeswoman Nevashnee Naicker said: 'We are all extremely concerned by listeriosis -- we all want to find the source or sources of listeriosis, together with the government.'\n\nRCL Foods chief legal officer Stephen Heath said the company was recalling its polony products even though test results were still pending. ' \n\nMotsoaledi said retailers must clean their fridges, meat slicers, and either remove the ready-to-eat meat products or place them in plastic bags in separate fridges -- ahead of the recall. Source: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43279627\n\n\nSouth Africa says it has finally traced the source of an outbreak [of listeriosis] that has killed 180 people in the past year -- said to make it the worst in history. \n\nMotsoaledi said statistics on [2 Mar 2018] show that the outbreak has claimed about 180 lives and 948 laboratory-confirmed cases had been reported to the NICD. According to media reports, 57 people lost their lives last week [week of Sun 11 Feb 2018] alone.\n\n'Unfortunately, the source of the outbreak still remains unknown,' the department said. Specialized tests are being conducted by experts at the NICD laboratories to assist in detecting the source as soon as possible, the department said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (06): fatal, more cases 20180218.5635764), there was a total of 872 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 164 deaths. Now, there are 915 confirmed cases nationally, including 172 deaths, a case fatality rate of 18.8 percent.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single, widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility and distributed nationally. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown.\n\nA map of (South Africa): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single, widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility and distributed nationally. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (06): fatal, more cases 20180218.5635764), there was a total of 872 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 164 deaths. \n\nAs of [Tue 20 Feb 2018], the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) has reported 915 laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis, the department said in its latest update on the pandemic that has gripped the country since January 2017. LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (07): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\n http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/22/c_136992188.htm\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak, believed to be the world's largest, has claimed 172 lives in South Africa, the Department of Health said on [Thu 22 Feb 2018].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-02-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5635764", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (06): fatal, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5635764", "date": "2018-02-18 14:32:56", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (06): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 17 Feb 2018\nSource: Brinkwire [edited]\nhttp://en.brinkwire.com/154653/listeriosis-getting-worse/\n\n\nThe country's listeriosis outbreak shows no sign of slowing down. In the last week alone, 57 people died from the food-borne disease, bringing the death toll to over 160. The source of the outbreak remains unknown.\n\nThe manner in which food is prepared in businesses and in homes has been under the spotlight since the outbreak of the disease in December 2017. Fruit and vegetables must be washed well and meat cooked thoroughly.\n\nBut awareness of the outbreak remains low. 'Somebody preparing food in Pretoria to a small group of people will not have that food available in the Northern Cape, for example, so I doubt very much that it's a preparation process in a home kitchen. I believe this is a processed product of some sort that is distributed across the entire country,' said food safety expert Dr Lucia Anelich. Anelich believes processed foods and cold meats and ready-made salads found at local delis could be the culprit for the outbreak. 'Environmental hygiene from an industry perspective is really important ... to find it and to kill it so it doesn't continuously contaminate different products.'\n\nAnother expert believes taking charge of how your food is being prepared is the safest bet. 'If it's been made outside of your control, keep yourself away from that. Get into the habit of cooking thoroughly and make sure you have handled your own food, because that is the only way you can be under control until we hear more about sources of infection,' said Unisa researcher, Dr Prudence Kayoka-Kabongo.\n\nWhile the National Institute for Communicable Diseases tries to locate the source of the outbreak, over 800 cases in all 9 provinces have been confirmed. The majority of deaths, 98, have occurred in Gauteng.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 16 Feb 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/02/listeria-south-africa/#.Womo98aZPjA\n\n\nIn the midst of the largest listeriosis outbreak to date in the world, the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) is asking victims in South Africa to list everything they can remember eating in the past month with the hopes of identifying a source.\n\nOf the 872 confirmed cases, 164 people have died, 43 percent of whom were babies less than a month old.\n\n'Given the scale of our mystery outbreak, it has led to what one delegate termed 'listeria hysteria', at a listeriosis workshop hosted by the South African Association of Food Science and Technology (SAAFoST) in Johannesburg on Wednesday [14 Feb 2018],' according to a story from The Times in Johannesburg.\n\nLucia Anelich, SAAFoST president, said given that a single, unique 'homegrown' strain of listeriosis was identified in more than 90 percent of the confirmed cases, it was likely that the source was a single food product or range of food products consumed often and by both rich and poor across South Africa; 'Cold meats, for example, range from Viennas and polony to more expensive slices of ham.'\n\nSince proper cooking temperatures kill _Listeria_, the food source is thought to be a fruit, vegetables, or a ready-to-eat food item. Additionally, the possibility of ill-treated irrigation water is a likely culprit.\n\nA food safety expert and an epidemiologist with listeriosis experience have been sent to South Africa by the World Health Organization (WHO) to help identify the source of the outbreak. According to a WHO spokesman, a 'strong lead' is pending with laboratory results.\n\nSouth Africa is in desperate need for an update to their entire food system, a call for 'a dramatic overhaul of our legislation and the entire food safety system.'\n\nFor example, there were fewer than 2000 environmental health practitioners responsible for monitoring all food outlets from restaurants to informal vendors; the WHO said that South Africa needs 5000 of them.\n\n[Byline: Kelsey M. Mackin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (05): fatal, more cases 20180131.5596282), there was a total of 820 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 82 deaths. Now, there are 872 confirmed cases nationally, including 164 deaths, a case fatality rate of 18.8%.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single, widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility and distributed nationally. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single, widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility and distributed nationally. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nSince proper cooking temperatures kill _Listeria_, the food source is thought to be a fruit, vegetables, or a ready-to-eat food item. , it was likely that the source was a single food product or range of food products consumed often and by both rich and poor across South Africa; 'Cold meats, for example, range from Viennas and polony to more expensive slices of ham.' \n\nSouth Africa is in desperate need for an update to their entire food system, a call for 'a dramatic overhaul of our legislation and the entire food safety system.' \n\nA food safety expert and an epidemiologist with listeriosis experience have been sent to South Africa by the World Health Organization (WHO) to help identify the source of the outbreak. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (05): fatal, more cases 20180131.5596282), there was a total of 820 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 82 deaths. \n\n'Given the scale of our mystery outbreak, it has led to what one delegate termed 'listeria hysteria', at a listeriosis workshop hosted by the South African Association of Food Science and Technology (SAAFoST) in Johannesburg on Wednesday [14 Feb 2018],' according to a story from The Times in Johannesburg. \n\nFor example, there were fewer than 2000 environmental health practitioners responsible for monitoring all food outlets from restaurants to informal vendors; the WHO said that South Africa needs 5000 of them. \n\nLucia Anelich, SAAFoST president, said given that a single, unique 'homegrown' strain of listeriosis was identified in more than 90 percent of the confirmed cases LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (06): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\n \n\nWhile the National Institute for Communicable Diseases tries to locate the source of the outbreak, over 800 cases in all 9 provinces have been confirmed. Somebody preparing food in Pretoria to a small group of people will not have that food available in the Northern Cape, for example, so I doubt very much that it's a preparation process in a home kitchen. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. Source: Food Safety News [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5586393", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - South Africa (04): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5586393", "date": "2018-01-26 14:45:05", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (04): COMMENT\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jan 2018\nFrom: Monir Taha <monir.taha@ottawa.ca> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Listeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180122.5577247\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSouth African officials may be interested in reviewing a Canadian investigation into a major listeriosis outbreak in Canada in 2008. See 'Report of the independent investigator into the 2008 listeriosis outbreak, July 2009,' Government of Canada at http://publications.gc.ca/collections/collection_2009/agr/A22-508-2009E.pdf.\n\n--\nMonir Taha, MD, FRCPC\nAssociate Medical Officer of Health\nOttawa Public Health\nOttawa, Canada\n<monir.taha@ottawa.ca>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Monir Taha for drawing our attention to the very relevant 'Report of the Independent Investigator into the 2008 Listeriosis Outbreak, July 2009.'\n\nThe report evaluates the response to a multi-province outbreak of listeriosis that involved a total of 57 laboratory-confirmed cases, of which 30 were fatal. _Listeria_-contaminated deli meat from a single producer at a Toronto processing plant was eventually found to be the source. A commercial meat slicer, the design of which made its regular cleaning difficult and costly for the food processor, contaminated the deli meat products. The contamination occurred in parts of the machinery 'well beyond the [manufacturer's] recommended sanitation process' and was 'found only after the devices were completely disassembled' (https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maple-leaf-eyes-meat-slicers-in-outbreak/article1060898/). The contaminated ready-to eat meat products were distributed to institutions that included hospitals and long-term care homes, where ready-to eat meat products were served to vulnerable populations. Of the 57 cases, 54 were elderly people in hospitals and long-term care homes. Cultures at the processing plant were positive for _Listeria_ for months before the outbreak started, and authorities weren't alerted to suspect the plant's deli meats for more than 2 months after the outbreak began. ProMED-mail reported on this outbreak in several posts in 2008 and one in 2009 (see also's below).\n\nThe following is extracted from the Executive Summary of the 'Report of the independent investigator into the 2008 listeriosis outbreak, July 2009.' Interested readers are encouraged to access the full report at http://publications.gc.ca/collections/collection_2009/agr/A22-508-2009E.pdf.\n\n'1. The focus on food safety among senior management in both the public and private domains.\nOur key findings are:\nMaple Leaf Foods\n----------------\n- Maple Leaf Foods' Bartor Road plant was aware that it had occurrences of _Listeria_ in the plant in 2007 and 2008, and tried to correct the problem with sanitation procedures standard in the industry. The plant's management thought _Listeria_ was under control. (Chap 5, Rec 5, 15 a to d)\n\n- Maple Leaf Foods did not conduct the trend analysis required under its _Listeria_ control policy. The recurring positive results were not known nor were the positive results verified to determine the presence/absence of _L. monocytogenes_. At the same time, the company was producing larger packages of deli-meat products for sale to institutions, including hospitals and long-term care homes. They had created a recipe that used less sodium, which was attractive to the institutional market as many of its clients benefited from reduced-sodium diets. This combination of circumstances exposed vulnerable populations to risk. (Chap 5, Rec 15 e, 21)\n\n- Maple Leaf Foods staff notified their superiors of the repeated presence of _Listeria_ beyond the Bartor Road plant into the Head Office. However, this information did not reach the office of the Chief Executive Officer because it was thought that the plant's interventions had controlled the problem. (Chap 5, Rec 1)\n\n- Employees in the Maple Leaf Foods Bartor Road plant were not required to, nor did they volunteer, information concerning the repeated occurrences of _Listeria_ in the plant to the CFIA Inspectors. (Chap 5, Rec 6)\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA)\n--------------------------------------\n- A new federal inspection approach, the Compliance Verification System (CVS), was put into effect in the spring of 2008, at the same time Maple Leaf Foods' environmental testing was identifying _Listeria_ at the Bartor Road plant (Chap 5, Rec 10)\n\n- Although the CVS is regarded as a sound system and has broad support, it needs critical improvements related to its design, planning, and implementation. (Chap 5, Rec 10)\n\n- The CFIA inspectors had no obligation to request or examine the company's _Listeria_ testing results under their CVS tasks. (Chap 5, Rec 20)\n\n- In the lead-up to the outbreak the number, capacity, and training of inspectors assigned to Maple Leaf Foods Bartor Road plant appear to have been stressed due to their responsibilities at other plants, the complexity of the Bartor Road plant, including its size and hours of operation, and necessary adjustments required by the implementation of the CVS. (Chap 5, Rec 7)\n\n- Due to the lack of detailed information and differing views heard, the investigation was not able to determine the current level of resources as well as the resources needed to conduct the CVS activities effectively. For the same reason, we were also unable to come to a conclusion concerning the adequacy of the program design, implementation plan, training and supervision of inspectors, as well as oversight and performance monitoring. (Chap 5, Rec 7)\n\n- The latest CFIA _Listeria_ controls do not distinguish between foods at much lower risk of harbouring _Listeria_ (such as dried sausages) and those that are much higher risk (such as hot-dogs). Furthermore, they do not establish 'test and hold' product controls. (Chap 5, Rec 15 d)\n\n- There is a need for increased coordination and improved communication about food processing equipment among the manufacturer, the food processor, and the CFIA regarding design specifications and the validation of sanitation procedures. (Chap 5, Rec 14)\n\nHealth Canada\n-------------\n- The Health Canada _L. monocytogenes_ policy (currently under review) does not provide adequate direction on expected outcomes leaving room for interpretation by industry. The lack of integration with the CFIA policies creates gaps and overlaps. (Chap 5, Rec 11)\n\n- In approving food additives and technologies, Health Canada has not been taking into account food safety considerations when assigning priorities or fast-tracking for approval these substances and processes. (Chap 5, Rec 12)\n\nMulti-jurisdictional emergency response\n---------------------------------------\nNational foodborne outbreaks are rare in Canada. Nevertheless, the Foodborne Illness Outbreak Response Protocol (FIORP) and complementary agreements are in place to manage such events but they were not widely known or understood by senior leadership at the time of the 2008 outbreak. (Chap 5, Rec 24)\n\n'2. The state of readiness of the various governments.\nOur key findings are:\nMulti-jurisdictional emergency response\n---------------------------------------\n- The 2008 outbreak first emerged in Ontario and was therefore under provincial leadership.\n\n- At the outset, the outbreak was not considered a severe foodborne emergency. This led to a void in leadership in managing the crisis. It took close to 3 weeks before senior executives in all key organizations became fully engaged in the event. (Chap 7, Rec 24 b-i)\n\n- The protocol (FIORP), which is in need of updating, was not recognized as the protocol to be used. The lack of a clear understanding about which organization or level of government was responsible for doing what -- including which organization should lead the response to the crisis -- contributed to the inconsistent management of the outbreak. Few of those involved in the 2008 outbreak, especially senior executives, were familiar with the FIORP. (Chap 7, Rec 24)\n\n- Since national foodborne illness outbreaks of this magnitude are rare in Canada, opportunities to practice this emergency management approach are very limited. (Chap 7, Rec 24 c)\n\n- Public health labs are not formally networked and could be more effectively used during a foodborne illness emergency. (Chap 7, Rec 33)\n\n- The Public Health Agency of Canada is making headway in epidemiological data collection and analysis in cases of human illness (such as H1N1), but improvements are still required in integrating the data collection, and analysis, of food samples (such as listeriosis). (Chap 7, Rec 35 c)\n\n- Enhanced coordination of various testing (such as cross-coding of human and food samples linked to the same patient) could further accelerate the analysis and decision-making necessary in the management of foodborne emergencies. (Chap 7, Rec 35 a)\n\n- Based on our investigation, to maintain confidence in the food safety system, there is a need for independent review after all national foodborne emergencies, in addition to each organization's lessons learned review. (Chap 7, rec 27)\n\n- Most organizations involved in the response to the 2008 outbreak had very limited pre-planned surge capacity. (Chap 7, Rec 24 b-iii and 34 b)\n\n'3. The sense of urgency at the outset of the outbreak.\nOur key findings are:\nMaple Leaf Foods\n----------------\n- Maple Leaf Foods did not initially report the presence of _Listeria_ at the Bartor Road plant or provide product distribution records. (Chap 5, Rec 6)\nPublic Health Agency of Canada\n\nPublic Health Agency of Canada\n-------------------------------\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada did not consider it had the federal leadership role, therefore there was a delay in identifying the outbreak as a public health emergency. (Chap 7, Rec 24 b-i)\n\nHealth Canada\n-------------\n- Health Canada's Health Risk Assessment team was not operating on a 24/7 basis during the summer of 2008, leaving gaps in coverage during the response to the emergency. (Chap 9, Appendix C)\n\nPublic health and food safety sectors\n-------------------------------------\n- There are differing views on the quality of evidence needed to advise the public about potential food contamination and/or to recall the food product. Some advocate specific laboratory confirmation to ensure the correct product is removed from the market. Others advocate for a precautionary approach, based on epidemiological evidence, to protect the public from potential harm. (Chap 7, Rec 24 b-iv, 29)\n\n'4. National communications with the public.\nOur key findings are:\n- Canadians were seeking reassurance from governments that public health was being protected.\n\n- Information about the outbreak did not provide the public with what they needed; it was sometimes inconsistent given the many jurisdictions involved, sometimes hard to find and sometimes difficult to understand. (Chap 8, Rec 26, 40)\n\n- The majority of Canadians were unaware which segments of the population were at greater risk of becoming ill if exposed to _Listeria monocytogenes_, and what foods these vulnerable groups should avoid (such as pointing to the need for precautionary labelling). (Chap 8, Rec 42)\n\n- There was an absence of an 'advance' communications strategy and related implementation plan, that should have included ready-made information products and the use of traditional and new media vehicles. (Chap 8, Rec 41)\n\n- Federal communications to the public were slow off the mark, and were not sustained for a sufficient period of time. In addition, there was no designated communications coordinator, which resulted in a fragmented approach and seemingly inconsistent messaging.\n\n- Having the Minister responsible for Agriculture and Agri-food and the CFIA serve as the lead ministerial spokesperson, was considered by some to be a 'conflict of interest' even though the minister has a legitimate role in relation to the food industry. It appeared to limit government's capacity to communicate health information sought by the public. The perceived lack of federal public health leadership during the outbreak attracted many comments. (Chap 8)\n\n- The greatest challenges for physicians in educating patients about minimizing risks of foodborne illness are lack of patient-friendly materials (77 percent), lack of knowledge about the outbreak (69 percent), and lack of time (69 percent). (Chap 8)'\n- Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Ottawa Public Health\nOttawa, Canada\n<monir.taha@ottawa.ca>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Monir Taha for drawing our attention to the very relevant 'Report of the Independent Investigator into the 2008 Listeriosis Outbreak, July 2009.' --------------------------------------\n- A new federal inspection approach, the Compliance Verification System (CVS), was put into effect in the spring of 2008, at the same time Maple Leaf Foods' environmental testing was identifying _Listeria_ at the Bartor Road plant (Chap 5, Rec 10)\n\n- \n\n--\nMonir Taha, MD, FRCPC\n (Chap 8)\n\n- The greatest challenges for physicians in educating patients about minimizing risks of foodborne illness are lack of patient-friendly materials (77 percent), lack of knowledge about the outbreak (69 percent), and lack of time (69 percent). (Chap 5, Rec 15 d)\n\n- There is a need for increased coordination and improved communication about food processing equipment among the manufacturer, the food processor, and the CFIA regarding design specifications and the validation of sanitation procedures. \n\nPublic health and food safety sectors\n (Chap 5, Rec 6)\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA)\n Public Health Agency of Canada\n\nPublic Health Agency of Canada\n (Chap 7, Rec 24 b-i)\n\nHealth Canada\n (Chap 7, Rec 35 a)\n\n- Based on our investigation, to maintain confidence in the food safety system, there is a need for independent review after all national foodborne emergencies, in addition to each organization's lessons learned review. Our key findings are:\nMulti-jurisdictional emergency response\n (Chap 7, Rec 35 c)\n\n- Enhanced coordination of various testing (such as cross-coding of human and food samples linked to the same patient) could further accelerate the analysis and decision-making necessary in the management of foodborne emergencies. (Chap 5, Rec 7)\n\n- Due to the lack of detailed information and differing views heard, the investigation was not able to determine the current level of resources as well as the resources needed to conduct the CVS activities effectively. (Chap 5, Rec 1)\n\n- Employees in the Maple Leaf Foods Bartor Road plant were not required to, nor did they volunteer, information concerning the repeated occurrences of _Listeria_ in the plant to the CFIA Inspectors. (Chap 5, Rec 14)\n\nHealth Canada\n ----------------\n- Maple Leaf Foods' Bartor Road plant was aware that it had occurrences of _Listeria_ in the plant in 2007 and 2008, and tried to correct the problem with sanitation procedures standard in the industry. (Chap 7, rec 27)\n\n- Most organizations involved in the response to the 2008 outbreak had very limited pre-planned surge capacity. -------------------------------------\n- There are differing views on the quality of evidence needed to advise the public about potential food contamination and/or to recall the food product. (Chap 7, Rec 24 c)\n\n- Public health labs are not formally networked and could be more effectively used during a foodborne illness emergency. Our key findings are:\nMaple Leaf Foods\n Our key findings are:\nMaple Leaf Foods\n -------------\n- Health Canada's Health Risk Assessment team was not operating on a 24/7 basis during the summer of 2008, leaving gaps in coverage during the response to the emergency. (Chap 5, Rec 5, 15 a to d)\n\n- Maple Leaf Foods did not conduct the trend analysis required under its _Listeria_ control policy. LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (04): COMMENT\n****************************************\n \n\n- Information about the outbreak did not provide the public with what they needed; it was sometimes inconsistent given the many jurisdictions involved, sometimes hard to find and sometimes difficult to understand. \n\nThe report evaluates the response to a multi-province outbreak of listeriosis that involved a total of 57 laboratory-confirmed cases, of which 30 were fatal. Nevertheless, the Foodborne Illness Outbreak Response Protocol (FIORP) and complementary agreements are in place to manage such events but they were not widely known or understood by senior leadership at the time of the 2008 outbreak. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179] (Chap 5, Rec 7)\n\n- The latest CFIA _Listeria_ controls do not distinguish between foods at much lower risk of harbouring _Listeria_ (such as dried sausages) and those that are much higher risk (such as hot-dogs). \n\nThe following is extracted from the Executive Summary of the 'Report of the independent investigator into the 2008 listeriosis outbreak, July 2009.' Cultures at the processing plant were positive for _Listeria_ for months before the outbreak started, and authorities weren't alerted to suspect the plant's deli meats for more than 2 months after the outbreak began. ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSouth African officials may be interested in reviewing a Canadian investigation into a major listeriosis outbreak in Canada in 2008.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-07-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2040-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5577247", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5577247", "date": "2018-01-22 20:54:48", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (03): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, ST6\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 22 Jan 2018\nSource: Poultry World [edited]\nhttp://www.poultryworld.net/Meat/Articles/2018/1/Poultry-under-suspicion-in-worst-listeriosis-outbreak-238226E/\n\n\nCooked chicken and other deli meats such as ham and Bologna sausage are high on the list of suspects for causing the world's worst ever recorded listeriosis outbreak.\n\nAt least 81 people have died in the ongoing outbreak in South Africa, according to the country's National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), with the number of recorded cases now 767 spread across all 9 provinces. It is massively larger than the 2nd biggest outbreak, which took place in the United States in 2011, when 147 cases were reported.\n\nThe disease -- contracted from eating food contaminated with the foodborne pathogen _Listeria_ -- normally has a mortality rate of between 20-25%. However, the NICD has said 'outcome data' from the 235 cases that it has studied has put the death rate at 34%.\n\nIt said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. Earlier this month [January 2018], there had been speculation that one of South Africa's major poultry producers, Sovereign Foods, based at Hartbeespoort in the Eastern Cape, could be involved in the outbreak. Environmental health officers visited Sovereign Foods' abattoirs to collect food samples, but these samples did not pick up the ST6 strain, although the tests found other strains with the potential to cause disease.\n\nSouth Africa's Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said that as the abattoir had _Listeria_, the abattoir was prohibited from further preparing food pending a deep clean. The abattoir was closed on 22 Dec 2017 but reopened on 9 Jan [2018]. Blaine van Rensberg, Sovereign Foods' head of production, said the company was further strengthening steps to render products safer than 'they already are.'\n\nFood safety experts Dr Lucia Anelich said the 'culprit' was most likely a product consumed 'extremely often' across the country. 'Deli meats are obviously consumed by a wide variety of people in the population, whether it's a cheaper cut or a more expensive one,' she said.\n\n[Byline: Tony McDougal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300), there were a total of 748 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 67 deaths. Now there are 767 nationally, including 81 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility.
