It said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. \n\nThe disease -- contracted from eating food contaminated with the foodborne pathogen _Listeria_ -- normally has a mortality rate of between 20-25%.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hartbeespoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5508986", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5508986", "date": "2017-12-17 11:15:17", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (04): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Dec 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-africa-listeriosis-outbreak-cases-top-600-year-71626/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa, the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) puts the number of laboratory-confirmed cases at 602 nationally as of 13 Dec 2017, including 40 deaths.\n\nSix out of 10 cases have been reported from Gauteng Province, while Western Cape and KwaZulu-Natal accounted for an additional 20 percent of cases.\n\nThe Minister of Health convened a multisectoral meeting on 14 Dec 2017 with representatives from the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fishery (DAFF), NDoH and NICD at which NICD presented data contained in this Situation Report. A multisectoral outbreak response plan is being compiled.\n\nOver 15 in-depth food histories have been taken from case-patients in Gauteng Province. A number of foodstuffs have been identified that are common to all affected persons.\n\nEnvironmental health practitioners have been requested to visit homes of persons newly diagnosed with listeriosis and sample available food where possible.\n\nConsumption of food contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. Less commonly, persons outside these risk groups are affected.\n\nListeriosis can cause fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance and convulsions sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. An invasive infection spreads beyond the gastrointestinal tract. In pregnant women, the infection can cause miscarriages, stillbirths, premature delivery or life-threatening infection of the newborn. In addition, there are serious and sometimes fatal infections in older adults and persons with weakened immune systems. Listeriosis is treated with antibiotics. Persons in the higher-risk categories who experience flu-like symptoms within 2 months after eating contaminated food should seek medical care and tell the health care provider about eating the contaminated food.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail, there were, as of 29 Nov 2017, a total of 557 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, with most cases being reported from Gauteng Province (62%). Now there are 602 nationally as of 13 Dec 2017, including 40 deaths.\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post said that whole genome sequencing, performed on 189 _Listeria monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6, which suggested that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a common source. Some food items are said to have been identified that are common to affected persons from a small number of 'in-depth' food histories, but investigations are ongoing. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail, there were, as of 29 Nov 2017, a total of 557 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, with most cases being reported from Gauteng Province (62%). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-africa-listeriosis-outbreak-cases-top-600-year-71626/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa, the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) puts the number of laboratory-confirmed cases at 602 nationally as of 13 Dec 2017, including 40 deaths. \n\nConsumption of food contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_ can cause listeriosis, a serious infection that primarily affects older adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women and their newborns. The prior ProMED-mail post said that whole genome sequencing, performed on 189 _Listeria monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6, which suggested that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a common source. Persons in the higher-risk categories who experience flu-like symptoms within 2 months after eating contaminated food should seek medical care and tell the health care provider about eating the contaminated food. Some food items are said to have been identified that are common to affected persons from a small number of 'in-depth' food histories, but investigations are ongoing. \n\nEnvironmental health practitioners have been requested to visit homes of persons newly diagnosed with listeriosis and sample available food where possible. \n\nListeriosis can cause fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance and convulsions sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NDoH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ST", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5566300", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5566300", "date": "2018-01-17 19:45:47", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (02): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, ST6\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 14 Jan 2018\nSource: News24 [edited]\nhttps://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/listeriosis-outbreaks-getting-worse-20180114-2\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak is causing widespread panic and leaving death in its wake, but the National Institute for Communicable Diseases [NICD] is yet to determine the source of the food-borne listeriosis outbreak that has reached 748 laboratory-confirmed cases.\n\nOn Friday [12 Jan 2018], the institute said 67 people had been confirmed dead from the outbreak gripping the country, which surfaced early last month [December 2017] and affects all 9 provinces.\n\nThis week, Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi gave a situational update on the outbreak, revealing that since the last briefing held in December [2017], cases rose from 527 in December [2017] to 748 by Friday [12 Jan 2018].\n\nDr Juno Thomas, head of the Centre for Enteric Diseases at the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), said this figure was 'of great concern.'\n\n'It means that the source of the outbreak is not controlled, in other words, that the contaminated food items are still being distributed and consumed by people countrywide,' she told City Press on Friday [12 Jan 2018].\n\nAt this stage, Thomas explained, it wasn't possible to predict the course of the outbreak.\n\nHowever, based on global experience with listeriosis outbreaks, she said that such an outbreak may suddenly stop when the contaminated food items are no longer available. This would eliminate the bacteria from the food production environment, otherwise, the contamination would continue until investigations provided clues as to the likely source.\n\nThomas and her team at the NICD have identified the ST6 strain of the disease as the main [one] for the current outbreak, out of 8 other sequence types. According to Motsoaledi, this confirmed the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak.\n\nExplaining the strain's particular impact on humans, Thomas said: 'In persons who develop meningitis (infection of the brain) due to _Listeria monocytogenes_, the ST6 in particular causes more severe disease than the other sequence types.'\n\nBut the disease's main victims have been babies. Infants less than 28 days old account for close to 40 percent of cases so far in the country. Infants are especially vulnerable from birth to 6 days after birth.\n\nDue to the rapid spread and the unusual behaviour of the disease, it has now been classified as a priority, which requires medical professionals to immediately report it to the department. Prior to this outbreak, medical staff treated about 80 cases annually that were not severe.\n\nLast month [December 2017], environmental health practitioners from the City of Tshwane investigated a Tshwane patient hospitalised with listeriosis and collected a chicken sample from the fridge at the patient's home. It tested positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_. The sample was traced back to the store and back to the Sovereign Foods' abattoir from which it was sourced. As a precaution, the abattoir was served with a prohibition notice pending further investigations.\n\nHowever, following whole-genome sequencing on the abattoir-related samples (a DNA-fingerprinting analysis to see whether particular organisms are related and were of the same sequence type), experts didn't pick up the outbreak strain (ST6). 'At this juncture, we cannot conclude that the abattoir called Sovereign Foods is the source of the present outbreak,' Mostoaledi explained.\n\nThe department said it was also an arduous process tracking the patients with confirmed cases of the disease. Currently, of the 748 lab-confirmed cases, the outbreak team has only traced the outcomes of 160 patients. According to the department, tracking the patients from the health facility that had the specimen was not easy because some did not have traceable physical addresses.\n\nMostoaledi said food premises within Gauteng -- with the highest number of cases at 442 -- would be inspected, targeting the food processing areas such as abattoirs and food retail shops.\n\nThe Director-General of the National Department of Health has formally requested food industry stakeholders to submit details of _Listeria_-positive food items, environmental swabs, and _Listeria_ isolates to the NICD.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 Archive Number: 20180108.5545556), there were a total of 720 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 61 deaths. Now there are 748 nationally, including 67 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility.\n\nHowever, the genotype of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolated at a suspected abattoir in Tshwane did not match to the genotype of the outbreak strain. No ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown.\n\nThe City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality is the metropolitan municipality that forms the local government of northern Gauteng Province, South Africa; the Metropolitan area is centered on the city of Pretoria with surrounding towns and localities included into the local government area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Tshwane_Metropolitan_Municipality). Gauteng Province, with a population of about 14 million residents in 2017, contains the country's largest city, Johannesburg, as well as Pretoria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng). A map of the city of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Pretoria,+South+Africa. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179.]", "summary": "\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 Archive Number: 20180108.5545556), there were a total of 720 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 61 deaths. \n\nMostoaledi said food premises within Gauteng -- with the highest number of cases at 442 -- would be inspected, targeting the food processing areas such as abattoirs and food retail shops. A listeriosis outbreak is causing widespread panic and leaving death in its wake, but the National Institute for Communicable Diseases [NICD] is yet to determine the source of the food-borne listeriosis outbreak that has reached 748 laboratory-confirmed cases. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'It means that the source of the outbreak is not controlled, in other words, that the contaminated food items are still being distributed and consumed by people countrywide,' she told City Press on Friday [12 Jan 2018]. \n\nThis week, Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi gave a situational update on the outbreak, revealing that since the last briefing held in December [2017], cases rose from 527 in December [2017] to 748 by Friday [12 Jan 2018]. \n\nAt this stage, Thomas explained, it wasn't possible to predict the course of the outbreak.\n\n \n\nThomas and her team at the NICD have identified the ST6 strain of the disease as the main [one] for the current outbreak, out of 8 other sequence types. According to Motsoaledi, this confirmed the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak. \n\nThe department said it was also an arduous process tracking the patients with confirmed cases of the disease. However, based on global experience with listeriosis outbreaks, she said that such an outbreak may suddenly stop when the contaminated food items are no longer available. \n\nThe City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality is the metropolitan municipality that forms the local government of northern Gauteng Province, South Africa; the Metropolitan area is centered on the city of Pretoria with surrounding towns and localities included into the local government area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Tshwane_Metropolitan_Municipality). On Friday [12 Jan 2018], the institute said 67 people had been confirmed dead from the outbreak gripping the country, which surfaced early last month No ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tshwane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Motsoaledi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Tshwane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5487695", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5487695", "date": "2017-12-06 20:35:43", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (03): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, GENOTYPING\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Nov 2017\nSource: Communicable Diseases Communiqu\u00e9 Vol. 16(11):9 [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/NICD_Communicable_Diseases_Communique_November_2017.pdf\n\n\nAs of 22 Nov 2017, a total of 536 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases has been reported from all provinces across the country since 1 Jan 2017 (Figure 9). Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (65%, 348/536) followed by Western Cape (12%, 67/536) and KwaZulu-Natal (6%, 35/536) provinces.\n\nIn the majority of cases, diagnosis was based on the isolation of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in blood culture (69%, 371/536), or CSF (26%, 141/536). Where age was reported (n=517), ages ranged from birth to 93 years (median 26 years) and 37% (193/517) were neonates aged 28 days or less. Females accounted for 53% (273/517) of cases where gender was reported.\n\nAs of 22 Nov 2017, 180 case investigation forms (CIFs) of variable completeness have been received. Apart from neonates (28 days or under) and the elderly (over 65 years), other risk factors reported in adults with listeriosis were pregnancy (10/35 females aged 15-49 years) and HIV infection (38/93 (41%) cases where HIV status was known). Final outcome data is available for 12% (65/536) of cases, of which 52% (34/65) died.\n\nTo date, whole genome sequencing has been performed on 189 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates. 15 sequence types (STs) have been identified; however, 71% (134/189) belong to a single ST (ST6). Isolates in this ST6 cluster are very closely related, showing less than 20 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) differences. This suggests that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a widely available, common food type/source.\n\nActions to date to assist with identification of the source include in-depth interviews of persons who have been diagnosed with listeriosis, engagement with food control industry to identify potential sources, and ongoing data collection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 4 Dec 2017\nSource: Centre for Enteric Diseases (CED) and Division of Public Health Surveillance and Response, Outbreak Response Unit (ORU), National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD)/ National Health Laboratory Service (NHLS) [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/NICD_Situation_report_on_listeriosis_outbreak_South_Africa_04_December_2017.pdf\n\n\nAs of 29 Nov 2017, a total of 557 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported from all provinces since 1 Jan 2017 (Figure 1). Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (62%, 345/557) followed by Western Cape (13%, 71/557) and KwaZulu-Natal (7%, 37/557) provinces. In the majority of cases, diagnosis was based on the isolation of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in blood culture (69%, 386/557), followed by CSF (26%, 146/557). Where age was reported (n=540), ages range from birth to 93 years (median 26 years) and 37% (203/540) are neonates aged 28 days and under (Figure 2). Of neonatal cases, 96% (195/203) had early-onset disease (birth to 6 days or less). Females account for 53% (286/538) of cases where gender is reported. Provincial distribution of cases by district is shown in Figure 3.\n\nClinical findings\n---------------------\nAs of 29 Nov 2017, case investigation forms (CIFs) of variable completeness have been received for 192 cases. Apart from neonates (28 days and under) and the elderly (over 65 years), additional risk factors for listeriosis reported include pregnancy (10/39 females aged 15-49 years) and HIV infection status. In non-neonatal cases where HIV status was known (n=63), 62% (39/63) were HIV positive. Maternal HIV status is known for 57 neonatal cases, of which 22/57 (38%) were HIV positive. Final outcome data is available for 12% (70/557) of cases, of which 51% (36/70) died. Limited food consumption history data are available, and indicate that a wide variety of food items documented to have caused previous outbreaks/clusters of listeriosis (including dairy products, meat products, vegetables, fruit, and ready-to-eat products) were commonly consumed, and no specific food item/s or food consumption patterns that could guide targeted environmental investigations have been identified as yet.\n\nReference laboratory findings\n-----------------------------\nTo date, whole genome sequencing has been performed on 189 clinical _L. monocytogenes_ isolates. 15 sequence types (STs) have been identified; however, 71% (134/189) belong to a single ST (ST6). Isolates in this ST6 cluster are very closely related, showing under 20 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) differences. This suggests that most cases in this outbreak have had exposure to a widely available, common food type/source.\n\nNarrative summary of actions to date\n------------------------------------\nEpidemiology and surveillance\n- The line list database of listeriosis cases is updated daily with data from NHLS Central Data Warehouse (CDW) downloads as well as direct reports of listeriosis cases detected at private sector laboratories.\n- Case investigations forms (CIFs) are currently being completed by numerous healthcare workers in public and private sectors, including GERMS-SA surveillance officers at enhanced surveillance site hospitals (public sector), clinical microbiologists (public sector), IPC practitioners at private sector hospitals, and Department of Health officials. Data from CIFs are entered into the database. All healthcare practitioners (clinicians, nurses, IPC practitioners, pathologists, Department of Health officials etc.) are encouraged to complete CIFs where possible, since identification of possible contaminated food types/sources will be guided by analysis of this data. The CIF with accompanying instruction sheet can be found on the NICD website at http://www.nicd.ac.za, and completed CIFs emailed to <outbreak@nicd.ac.za>.\n- A team of NICD epidemiologists has compiled a comprehensive food item checklist and is conducting in-depth interviews of case-patients in Gauteng Province when feasible in order to ascertain detailed food consumption histories. To date, 5 such interviews have been conducted. This information will hopefully assist us in drafting a concise food consumption questionnaire, which can easily be administered by an interviewer or completed by case-patients themselves.\n\nClinical management\n- Clinical listeriosis management guidelines have been drafted and are currently under review. If you would like to view the draft and provide comment, please email <outbreak@nicd.ac.za>.\n\nLaboratory diagnostics and investigations\n- Private and public sector laboratories are submitting clinical isolates to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases (CED). Please email <arvindas@nicd.ac.za>, <junot@nicd.ac.za> or <karenk@nicd.ac.za> should you have queries or require assistance.\n- For cases where there is a high clinical index of suspicion for listeriosis but specimens (blood culture or CSF) are culture negative, a polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based test can be performed at the NICD. Please contact <anthonys@nicd.ac.za>, <arvindas@nicd.ac.za>, <junot@nicd.ac.za> or <karenk@nicd.ac.za> for further details.\n- All _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from food samples tested at the NHLS Infection Control Services Laboratory are routinely submitted to the CED.\n- Selected private sector food testing laboratories have voluntarily submitted _L. monocytogenes_ isolates (from anonymised food samples and food processing facilities) to the CED.\n- All isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ received at the CED are subjected to confirmatory identification tests, and are stored.\n- Whole genome sequencing is being performed on all clinical isolates and selected food/environmental isolates.\n\nFood control and environmental health\n- The Director General of the National Department of Health has formally requested food industry stakeholders to submit _Listeria_ isolates to the NICD, along with details of _Listeria_-positive food/food processing environmental samples.\n- Environmental health practitioners have been requested to visit homes of persons diagnosed with listeriosis and sample food from their refrigerators. These specimens must be submitted to the NHLS Infection Control Services Laboratory in Johannesburg. Please email Rob Stewart (<rob.stewart@nhls.ac.za>) or Teena Thomas (<teena.thomas@nhls.ac.za>) for details regarding specimen submission.\n\nCommunications\n- The NICD has made information available on the website regarding listeriosis, including Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs), clinical management guidance, and laboratory testing methodology. These can be accessed at http://www.nicd.ac.za/index.php/listeriosis/.\n- The Food Control Division within the National Department of Health has distributed information about the outbreak to food industry stakeholders.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Irene Lai, from SOS International, and an EpiCore member for their submissions of the above reports in response to the RFI.\n\nIn summary, most laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis in South Africa have been reported from Gauteng Province (62%, 345/557), where cases started to increase around epidemiological week 23 (4-10 Jun 2017) when 5 cases occurred in that week to epidemiological week 46 (12-18 Nov 2017) when over 20 cases occurred (item 1, figure 9 at the source URL.) 37% (203/540) are neonates aged 28 days or less. Of neonatal cases, 96% (195/203) had early-onset disease.\n\nNo specific food item/s or food consumption patterns have been identified as yet from a limited number of food histories. However, whole genome sequencing, performed on 189 _L. monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6, which suggested that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a common source. Investigations to identify this source are ongoing.\n\nGauteng, one of the 9 provinces of South Africa, is the smallest and most populous, with a population of over 13 million residents, containing the country's largest city, Johannesburg, its administrative capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng). A map of South Africa provinces can be found at https://www.southafrica.to/provinces/provinces.htm. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179\nGauteng Province, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3070]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n In summary, most laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis in South Africa have been reported from Gauteng Province (62%, 345/557), where cases started to increase around epidemiological week 23 (4-10 Jun 2017) when 5 cases occurred in that week to epidemiological week 46 (12-18 Nov 2017) when over 20 cases occurred (item 1, figure 9 at the source URL.) Communicated by:\nDr. Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n Limited food consumption history data are available, and indicate that a wide variety of food items documented to have caused previous outbreaks/clusters of listeriosis (including dairy products, meat products, vegetables, fruit, and ready-to-eat products) were commonly consumed, and no specific food item/s or food consumption patterns that could guide targeted environmental investigations have been identified as yet. \n- Selected private sector food testing laboratories have voluntarily submitted _L. monocytogenes_ isolates (from anonymised food samples and food processing facilities) to the CED. \n- Case investigations forms (CIFs) are currently being completed by numerous healthcare workers in public and private sectors, including GERMS-SA surveillance officers at enhanced surveillance site hospitals (public sector), clinical microbiologists (public sector), IPC practitioners at private sector hospitals, and Department of Health officials. However, whole genome sequencing, performed on 189 _L. monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6, which suggested that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a common source. \n- A team of NICD epidemiologists has compiled a comprehensive food item checklist and is conducting in-depth interviews of case-patients in Gauteng Province when feasible in order to ascertain detailed food consumption histories. Communicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project member\n< \nEpidemiology and surveillance\n- This suggests that most cases in this outbreak have been exposed to a widely available, common food type/source. This suggests that most cases in this outbreak have had exposure to a widely available, common food type/source.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2004-06-10 20:17:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-18 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "71/557", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ST", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5402225", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5402225", "date": "2017-10-25 11:25:23", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA: INCREASING INCIDENCE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 22 Oct 2017 8:02:38 AM\nSource: MENAFN (Middle East North Africa Financial Network) [edited]\nhttp://menafn.com/1095972932/Spike-in-Listeria-infections-in-South-Africa-why-it-matters\n\n\n_Listeria_ is an organism that contaminates food and can result in pregnant women going into premature labour or even losing their babies. The Conversation Africa's Health and Medicine Editor Candice Bailey spoke to Kerrigan McCarthy from the National Institute of Communicable Diseases about listeriosis and why it needs attention.\n\nIn South Africa, the 1st documented outbreaks of listeriosis were in 1977. Between August 1977 and April 1978, 14 cases were reported in the Johannesburg area. Since then, sporadic cases have occurred throughout the country. For example, between January 2015 and September 2015 7 cases were reported at a tertiary hospital in the Western Cape province.\n\nOver the last few months the National Institute for Communicable Diseases has received reports of a marked increase in the number of cases across the country, but particularly in the Gauteng Province, South Africa's smallest but most densely populated province.\n\nThere have been 190 confirmed cases across the country. In Gauteng, the population incidence rates have increased from 2 per million to 8 per million. The highest incidence has been recorded in the City of Johannesburg at 12 cases per million. This is not as high as the number of people who get meningococcal meningitis or pulmonary tuberculosis, but the consequences are just as serious.\n\nOf the 122 cases in Gauteng, over 60 percent are newborn babies that have been infected.\n\nThe institute is trying to establish what the source of the infection is so that measures can be put in place to prevent further cases. Mothers who have been infected with the bacteria are being interviewed and the institute is also engaging with the food service quality industry.\n\nOutbreaks of _Listeria_ in food are common across the world. Outbreaks of listeriosis across the world present the same problem: that the source of contaminated food is difficult to identify. There are 2 reasons for this:\n- firstly, the incubation period of 70 days makes it difficult to track what the patient ate and therefore to identify the contaminated food;\nand\n- secondly, once the food source is narrowed down, tests need to be conducted on the range of possible foods to establish which is the implicated one. Only once authorities are able to identify the source are they able implement measures to prevent further cases.\n\nThere is no vaccine or pre-exposure prophylaxis that can prevent infection. The main preventive measure is good basic hygiene, and proper, safe food preparation and storage.\n\nUnlike most other foodborne pathogens, _Listeria monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigerated foods that are contaminated. To prevent this, fridge temperatures should be set below 4 deg C [about 39 deg F]; and freezer temperatures below -18 deg C [about 0 deg F].\n\nThose at high risk of listeriosis should avoid: raw or unpasteurised milk, or dairy products that contain unpasteurized milk; soft cheeses like feta, goat cheese, and brie; foods from delicatessen counters like prepared salads and cold meats that have not been heated and reheated adequately; [and] refrigerated p\u00e2t\u00e9s.\n\nAdditional measures include thoroughly cooking raw foods from animal sources, such as beef, pork, or poultry. Raw fruit and vegetables should be thoroughly washed before eating. And surfaces where food is prepared should be decontaminated regularly, particularly after preparing raw meat, poultry, and eggs, including industrial kitchens.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gauteng, one of the 9 provinces of South Africa, is the smallest and most populous, with a population of over 13 million residents, containing the country's largest city, Johannesburg, its administrative capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng).\n\nGenotyping _Listeria_ isolates is important to identify transmission pathways. In the USA, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases.\n\nWhen PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis of food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. The genotype of clinical isolates is then compared to genotypes of food isolates to identify the source. More information in this regard from the South African outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179.]", "summary": "There are 2 reasons for this:\n- firstly, the incubation period of 70 days makes it difficult to track what the patient ate and therefore to identify the contaminated food;\nand\n- secondly, once the food source is narrowed down, tests need to be conducted on the range of possible foods to establish which is the implicated one. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Gauteng, one of the 9 provinces of South Africa, is the smallest and most populous, with a population of over 13 million residents, containing the country's largest city, Johannesburg, its administrative capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng). \n\nWhen PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis of food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. \n\nThose at high risk of listeriosis should avoid: raw or unpasteurised milk, or dairy products that contain unpasteurized milk; soft cheeses like feta, goat cheese, and brie; foods from delicatessen counters like prepared salads and cold meats that have not been heated and reheated adequately; [and] refrigerated p\u00e2t\u00e9s. \n\nThe institute is trying to establish what the source of the infection is so that measures can be put in place to prevent further cases. In the USA, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. The genotype of clinical isolates is then compared to genotypes of food isolates to identify the source. Outbreaks of listeriosis across the world present the same problem: that the source of contaminated food is difficult to identify. \n\nAdditional measures include thoroughly cooking raw foods from animal sources, such as beef, pork, or poultry. Only once authorities are able to identify the source are they able implement measures to prevent further cases. \n\nOf the 122 cases in Gauteng, over 60 percent are newborn babies that have been infected. Over the last few months the National Institute for Communicable Diseases has received reports of a marked increase in the number of cases across the country, but particularly in the Gauteng Province, South Africa's smallest but most densely populated province.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-09-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5545556", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5545556", "date": "2018-01-08 20:46:19", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA: FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, ST6\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 8 Jan 2018\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttps://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFKBN1EX13M-OZATP?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews\n\n\nThe death toll from an outbreak of [listeriosis] in South Africa has jumped beyond 60 in the past month [December 2017], health authorities said on Monday [8 Jan 2018], adding they had closed a poultry abattoir where the bug that causes the disease had been detected.\n\nSince monitoring of the outbreak began last January [2017], 720 laboratory-confirmed cases of food poisoning due to the disease, also known as listeriosis, have been reported, the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) said.\n\nThat was up from 557 in December [2017], since when recorded deaths had risen to 61 from 36 [case fatality rate of 8.5%].\n\nA food microbiologist said the 'alarming' outbreak appeared to be the biggest ever recorded and could spread further if it was not tackled urgently. 'Of the documented outbreaks globally that we know of ... our numbers are way above any of those other cases,' said Dr Lucia Anelich, who runs her own food safety consultancy.\n\nThe Department of Health said it had closed a poultry abattoir operated by Sovereign Foods in the capital Pretoria after detecting _Listeria_ there, and had banned it from preparing food. The department said it did not yet know whether this abattoir was the source of the outbreak, which the NICD said was still unknown.\n\nNo one at Sovereign Foods, which delisted from the Johannesburg stock exchange in November [2017], was immediately available for comment.\n\n_Listeria_ food poisoning is a bacterial infection that can be treated with antibiotics if diagnosed in time. The bacteria can be found in animal products including cold cut meats, poultry and unpasteurised milk, as well as fresh fruits and vegetables. The disease can cause flu-like symptoms and diarrhoea, and in more severe cases spread from the intestine to the blood, causing bloodstream infections, or to the central nervous system, causing meningitis.\n\nAnelich said a listeriosis strain known as ST6 had been identified in 9 out of 10 of the South African cases. That should make tracing the source easier, 'because now we know that it probably originates from one processing facility'.\n\nA health department official said the strain was not drug-resistant and that the deaths were due to delays in diagnosis, meaning cases were not treated in time.\n\n[Byline: Mfuneko Toyana, Kate Kelland, John Stonestreet]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 7 Jan 2018\nSource: Times LIVE [edited]\nhttps://www.timeslive.co.za/news/2018-01-07-listeriosis-flare-up-now-seen-as-worst-documented-outbreak-in-global-history/\n\n\nIn the past month\u201a another 167 people have contracted deadly listeriosis\u201a bringing the total number of confirmed cases in South Africa to 717.\n\nFood scientists are now calling it the worst documented listeriosis outbreak in global history. In its latest listeriosis update\u201a dated 3 Jan 2018\u201a the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) -- which has been tracking the listeriosis outbreak for an entire year -- said 61 deaths had been reported.\n\nListeriosis has a relatively high mortality rate [actually the case fatality rate, not mortality rate], 20-25% compared to illnesses caused by most other food-borne pathogens. Less than 1% of people who get _Salmonella_ or _E. coli_ O157 die as a result. Neonates -- babies less than 28 days old -- remain the most affected by listeriosis.\n\nA prohibition notice has been issued to an abattoir in the Tshwane area halting it from distributing meat after samples taken from it tested positive. The outbreak is across all 9 provinces, and clinical tests have revealed that the _Listeria_ originates from a single source, 'most likely a food product on the market or a series of food products produced in the same manufacturing environment\u201a' says Dr Lucia Anelich\u201a a prominent South African food microbiologist and food safety expert.\n\nThe City of Tshwane's environmental health practitioners recently traced the source of a hospitalised Tshwane man's listeriosis to chicken supplied to a store by a certain abattoir. Samples they took from the abattoir tested positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_, and the abattoir was closed pending further investigations.\n\n'Although _Listeria monocytogenes_ has been found in a specific abattoir\u201a precise confirmation of the strain is still required\u201a' Anelich says. 'Much work needs to be done to match the outbreak strain with food products originating from the same manufacturing environment\u201a including clear evidence that the apparently contaminated food was ingested by the majority of people across 9 provinces. As things stand\u201a the source of this outbreak is still not known.' The significance of isolating _L. monocytogenes_ from raw poultry\u201a which is cooked before consumption\u201a thus killing the bacterium\u201a is questionable\u201a Anelich says.\n\n[Byline: Wendy Knowler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 3 Jan 2018\nSource: Centre for Enteric Diseases (CED) and Division of Public Health Surveillance and Response, Outbreak Response Unit (ORU), National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD)/ National Health Laboratory Service (NHLS) [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/NICD-Situation-report-on-listeriosis-outbreak-South-Africa_03-January-2018.pdf\n\n\nSituation Report on Listeriosis Outbreak South Africa, 2017-2018\n-----------------------\nCase data and outbreak response activity summary is the best available at time of publication and are updated on an ongoing basis.\n\nDue to recent challenges with NHLS laboratory information system data (since epidemiological week 47) and a possible lag in reporting as a result of the public holidays, case numbers for weeks 47-52 of 2017 are likely to change on a daily basis, and trends must be interpreted with caution until it has been confirmed that all cases have been captured.\n\nDescriptive epidemiology\n----------------\nAs of 3 Jan 2018, a total of 717 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to NICD since 1 Jan 2017 (Figure 1). Most cases have been reported from Gauteng Province (61%, 436/717) followed by Western Cape (13%, 92/717) and KwaZulu-Natal (7%, 50/717) provinces. Cases have been diagnosed in both public (66%, 470/717) and private (34%, 247/717) healthcare sectors. Diagnosis was based most commonly on the isolation of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in blood culture (70%, 502/717), followed by CSF (24%, 175/717). Where age was reported (n=683), ages range from birth to 93 years (median 26 years) and 39% (268/683) are neonates aged 28 days and under (Figure 2). Of neonatal cases, 96% (258/268) had early-onset disease (birth to 6 days and under). Females account for 55% (382/692) of cases where gender is reported.\n\nAs of 2 Jan 2018, case investigation forms (CIFs) of variable completeness have been received for 264/712 (37%) cases. Apart from neonates (28 days and under) and the elderly (over 65 years), additional risk factors for listeriosis reported include pregnancy (15/61 females aged 15-49 years where pregnancy status known) and HIV infection status (44/120 cases with known HIV infection status are HIV-positive). Final outcome data is available for only 19% (134/712) of cases, of which 45% (61/134) died.\n\nRecent developments\n--------------------\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners from the City of Tshwane recently investigated a Tshwane patient hospitalised with listeriosis. A chicken sample collected from the fridge at the patient's home tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. This chicken was traced back to the store, and from there traced back to the abattoir it was sourced from. The Environmental Health Practitioners visited the abattoir and collected food and environmental samples, several of which tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. As a precaution, the abattoir was closed pending further investigations. The abattoir-related _L. monocytogenes_ are undergoing WGS to assess whether they are related to the ST6 outbreak strain or not; these results will be available during the week.\n\nAt present, the source of the outbreak is not known, so it is uncertain which food/s may be implicated. Cases of listeriosis will continue to be investigated, with trace back and further investigation of any positive food/environmental samples.\n\nUpdate on whole genome sequencing analysis\n---------------------------------------\nWhole genome sequencing of currently available clinical and food-related (food and food production facility environmental sample) isolates received since 1 Jan 2017 is ongoing. As of 3 Jan 2018, of the 337 isolates sequenced to date, 73% (247/337) are clinical isolates, 22% (74/337) are food isolates, and 5% (16/337) are food production environment isolates.\n\nThe clinical isolates are represented by 9 sequence types (ST1, ST101, ST2, ST219, ST5, ST54, ST6, ST8 and ST876); however, 91% (225/247) are sequence type 6 (ST6) and are very closely related, representing a single strain of _L. monocytogenes_ - i.e. the outbreak strain. This ST6 strain has been identified in isolates from all 9 provinces, and this finding supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility.\n\nThe food and environmental samples are represented by 18 sequence types, 4 of which (ST1, ST101, ST2 and ST5) are STs also represented in the clinical isolates. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date.\n\n[The figure and 'Narrative summary of actions to date' are available at the source URL. - Mod.ML]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence 20171217.5508986), there were a total of 602 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 40 deaths. Now there are 720 nationally, including 61 deaths.\n\nA previous ProMED-mail post said that molecular typing, performed on 189 _Listeria monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6. The 1st and 3rd items above say that now ST6 has been identified for over 90% of clinical isolates. This ST6 strain has been identified in isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility.\n\nThe 2nd and 3rd items above say that, although samples taken from a chicken sample in one patient's home and an abattoir from which the chicken had been obtained were positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_, molecular testing of these isolates has not been done as yet to see whether their genotypes match the genotype of the clinical isolate. No ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak is still not known.\n\nThe City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality is the metropolitan municipality that forms the local government of northern Gauteng Province, South Africa; the Metropolitan area is centered on the city of Pretoria with surrounding towns and localities included into the local government area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Tshwane_Metropolitan_Municipality). Gauteng Province, with a population of about 14 million residents in 2017, contains the country's largest city, Johannesburg, as well as Pretoria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng). A map of the city of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Pretoria,+South+Africa. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The outbreak is across all 9 provinces, and clinical tests have revealed that the _Listeria_ originates from a single source, 'most likely a food product on the market or a series of food products produced in the same manufacturing environment\u201a' says Dr Lucia Anelich\u201a a prominent South African food microbiologist and food safety expert. This ST6 strain has been identified in isolates from all 9 provinces, and this finding supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. This ST6 strain has been identified in isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. \nWhole genome sequencing of currently available clinical and food-related (food and food production facility environmental sample) isolates received since 1 Jan 2017 is ongoing. Source: Centre for Enteric Diseases (CED) and Division of Public Health Surveillance and Response, Outbreak Response Unit (ORU), National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD)/ National Health Laboratory Service (NHLS) [edited]\nhttp://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/NICD-Situation-report-on-listeriosis-outbreak-South-Africa_03-January-2018.pdf\n\n\nSituation Report on Listeriosis Outbreak South Africa, 2017-2018\n \n\nSince monitoring of the outbreak began last January [2017], 720 laboratory-confirmed cases of food poisoning due to the disease, also known as listeriosis, have been reported, the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) said. As of 3 Jan 2018, of the 337 isolates sequenced to date, 73% (247/337) are clinical isolates, 22% (74/337) are food isolates, and 5% (16/337) are food production environment isolates. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThe clinical isolates are represented by 9 sequence types (ST1, ST101, ST2, ST219, ST5, ST54, ST6, ST8 and ST876); however, 91% (225/247) are sequence type 6 (ST6) and are very closely related, representing a single strain of _L. monocytogenes_ - i.e. the outbreak strain. \n\nA previous ProMED-mail post said that molecular typing, performed on 189 _Listeria monocytogenes_ clinical isolates, found that 71% (134/189) belong to a single sequence type (ST6) and identified a clonal cluster within sequence type (ST) 6. Much work needs to be done to match the outbreak strain with food products originating from the same manufacturing environment\u201a including clear evidence that the apparently contaminated food was ingested by the majority of people across 9 provinces. In its latest listeriosis update\u201a dated 3 Jan 2018\u201a the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) -- which has been tracking the listeriosis outbreak for an entire year -- said 61 deaths had been reported. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence 20171217.5508986), there were a total of 602 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 40 deaths. \n\nThe food and environmental samples are represented by 18 sequence types, 4 of which (ST1, ST101, ST2 and ST5) are STs also represented in the clinical isolates. \n\n[Byline: Wendy Knowler]\n\n--\n \n\nListeriosis has a relatively high mortality rate [actually the case fatality rate, not mortality rate], 20-25% compared to illnesses caused by most other food-borne pathogens. Apart from neonates (28 days and under) and the elderly (over 65 years), additional risk factors for listeriosis reported include pregnancy (15/61 females aged 15-49 years where pregnancy status known) and HIV infection status (44/120 cases with known HIV infection status are HIV-positive). \n\n'Although _Listeria monocytogenes_ has been found in a specific abattoir\u201a precise confirmation of the strain is still required\u201a' Anelich says. ' \n\nThe City of Tshwane's environmental health practitioners recently traced the source of a hospitalised Tshwane man's listeriosis to chicken supplied to a store by a certain abattoir. The death toll from an outbreak of [listeriosis] in South Africa has jumped beyond 60 in the past month [December 2017], health authorities said on Monday [8 Jan 2018], adding they had closed a poultry abattoir where the bug that causes the disease had been detected. \n\nA food microbiologist said the 'alarming' outbreak appeared to be the biggest ever recorded and could spread further if it was not tackled urgently. ' \n\nFood scientists are now calling it the worst documented listeriosis outbreak in global history. \n\nAt present, the source of the outbreak is not known, so it is uncertain which food/s may be implicated. No ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak is still not known. The 2nd and 3rd items above say that, although samples taken from a chicken sample in one patient's home and an abattoir from which the chicken had been obtained were positive for _Listeria monocytogenes_, molecular testing of these isolates has not been done as yet to see whether their genotypes match the genotype of the clinical isolate. \n\nA health department official said the strain was not drug-resistant and that the deaths were due to delays in diagnosis, meaning cases were not treated in time. The Environmental Health Practitioners visited the abattoir and collected food and environmental samples, several of which tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. As of 3 Jan 2018, a total of 717 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to NICD since 1 Jan 2017 (Figure 1).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-11-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2017-12-26 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Tshwane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ST101", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Tshwane 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ST", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5484927", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5484927", "date": "2017-12-05 17:14:06", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (02): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 5 Dec 2017, 9:49 AM\nSource: News24 [edited]\nhttps://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/36-people-dead-in-listeriosis-outbreak-20171205\n\n\nMore than 30 people have died following an outbreak of listeriosis.\n\nHealth Minister Dr Aaron Motsoaledi announced on [Tue 5 Dec 2017] morning that while listeriosis is a serious disease, it is a disease which can be treated with antibiotics.\n\nThe bacteria are found in soil, water and vegetation. Motsoaledi said people who are most vulnerable include the elderly, children, newborns or those who are ill.\n\nApproximately 557 cases have been reported, with the majority coming from Gauteng province. He said they had traced 70 patients, of whom 36 died.\n\n[Byline: Alex Mitchley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 5 Dec 2017, 1:45 PM\nSource: News24 [edited]\nhttps://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/those-displaying-symptoms-of-listeriosis-should-seek-medical-help-immediately-motsoaledi-20171205\n\n\nThe minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi has urged anyone who is displaying symptoms of listeriosis to seek medical attention immediately following the outbreak of the disease across South Africa. At a media briefing in Pretoria today [Tue 5 Dec 2017], Motsoaledi announced that there is an outbreak of listeriosis - a disease caused by a bacterium found in soil, water and vegetation, which contaminates food sources such as animal products and fresh produce.\n\nThe minister said those who contract the disease will have flu-like symptoms including diarrhoea, fever, general body pains and weakness. He said the disease can cause meningitis, which is an infection of the brain and septicemia which is an infection of the blood stream, both can be fatal. However, Motsoaledi stressed that while the disease is serious and dangerous, it is treatable with antibiotics and urged that anyone who is showing symptoms should get medical help immediately. 'If you encounter the symptoms I've mentioned please rush to look for medical help, in other words don't just assume and sit at home especially if you get flu like symptoms now in summer.'\n\nMotsoaledi said that tracing as far back as [1 Jan 2017] up until [29 Nov 2017], 557 laboratory confirmed cases have been reported. Of the 557 cases, the department of health has found the final outcome of 70 confirmed cases of listeriosis. 'Of these 70 cases, 36 persons have perished,' said Motsoaledi.\n\nThe Head of the Centre for Enteric Diseases at the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), Dr Juno Thomas, said the number of deaths will increase as they receive final outcome data on the reported cases.\n\nMotsoaledi added that whilst anyone can get the diseases, which has a mortality rate of between 20 and 30 percent, those at a high risk of developing the disease are newborns, the elderly, pregnant women and people with weak immunity systems such as HIV or cancer sufferers.\n\nThe World Health Organisation has advised on food safety measures which includes; that people should keep clean especially when handling food, food should be cooked thoroughly; raw food should not be eaten; use safe water, keep food at safe temperatures and use pasteurized milk products.\n\nThe source of the outbreak is currently being investigated, but Motsoaledi said it's believed that this particular outbreak is from a food source that is being consumed by both the rich and the poor, and the contamination points may well be farms and food processing plants. 'All the stakeholders are cooperating with the investigation led by the NICD. Environmental health officers are following up diagnosed cases and are visiting their homes to sample food where available,' said Motsoaledi.\n\n_Listeria_ typically occurs every year, with between 60 - 80 cases detected and treated annually, however, in July this year [2017], the Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital in Johannesburg and Steve Biko Academic Hospital in Pretoria alerted the NICD to unusually high numbers of babies with listeriosis.\n\nOut of the 557 cases reported, 345 cases were reported in Gauteng, followed by the Western Cape which reported 71 cases, and 37 cases of listeriosis reported in KwaZulu-Natal.\n\nMembers of the public can contact the NICD emergency operations centre during working hours (011 386 2000) or the NICD hotline for clinical emergencies after hours (082 883 9920).\n\n[Byline: Alex Mitchley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted on this outbreak, there were 122 cases of listeriosis in the province of Gauteng (mostly in the city of Johannesburg), over 60 percent of which are newborn babies, with 190 cases in South Africa as a whole (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225). There are now a total of 557 reported cases, with 345 (61.9 percent) coming from Gauteng province in 2017. There were 71 cases reported in the Western Cape and 37 cases of listeriosis reported in KwaZulu-Natal. Only 60 - 80 cases are detected and treated in South Africa annually. 70 of the 557 cases have been traced, of which 36 were fatal. The overall case fatality rate of listeriosis is 20-30 percent and the case fatality rate in infected newborns has been reported to be approximately 50 percent (http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/listeriosis.pdf).\n\nGauteng, one of the 9 provinces of South Africa, is the smallest and most populous, with a population of over 13 million residents, containing the country's largest city, Johannesburg, its administrative capital (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauteng). A map of South Africa provinces can be found at https://www.southafrica.to/provinces/provinces.htm.\n\nGenotyping _Listeria_ isolates is important to identify transmission pathways. In the USA, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases.\n\nWhen PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis of food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. The genotype of clinical isolates is then compared to genotypes of food isolates to identify the source.\n\nMore information on food exposures and genotyping of clinical and environmental isolates from the South African outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When ProMED-mail last posted on this outbreak, there were 122 cases of listeriosis in the province of Gauteng (mostly in the city of Johannesburg), over 60 percent of which are newborn babies, with 190 cases in South Africa as a whole (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225). \n\nOut of the 557 cases reported, 345 cases were reported in Gauteng, followed by the Western Cape which reported 71 cases, and 37 cases of listeriosis reported in KwaZulu-Natal. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nThe World Health Organisation has advised on food safety measures which includes; that people should keep clean especially when handling food, food should be cooked thoroughly; raw food should not be eaten; use safe water, keep food at safe temperatures and use pasteurized milk products. \n\nMotsoaledi said that tracing as far back as [1 Jan 2017] up until [29 Nov 2017], 557 laboratory confirmed cases have been reported.
