In the USA, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gauteng province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pretoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Motsoaledi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5596282", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (05): fatal, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5596282", "date": "2018-01-31 07:00:43", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (05): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jan 2018 14:17 GMT\nSource: Food Quality News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodqualitynews.com/Article/2018/01/29/False-reports-circulate-in-South-African-Listeria-outbreak\n\n\nThe case count in the South African [listeriosis] outbreak has risen again as the search continues to find the source.\n\nAn additional 53 cases and 1 death have been recorded by the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD). 13 cases occurred during 2017 and were retrospectively reported.\n\nOutcome data is available for 29 percent (238/820) of cases, of which 82 died. A total of 820 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have now been reported to NICD since January 2017.\n\nMost are from Gauteng Province (59 percent), Western Cape (13 percent) and KwaZulu-Natal (7 percent) provinces.\n\nIt is already by far the largest ever [listeriosis] outbreak, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\nGenetic testing on _Listeria_ from patients suggests a single strain, sequence type 6 (ST6), is responsible for the majority of infections. However, it has not been found in samples from processing facilities, abattoirs, or food from patients' homes.\n\nTensions are mounting as rumours circulate about the source of the outbreak. The Nelson Mandela Bay municipality hit out at 'unfounded allegations' that its tap water was one of the causes. 'The institution would like to condemn individuals who have been spreading inaccurate and irresponsible information about this serious issue through social media. This misinformation has not only caused panic across the city, it has also led to undue pressure on our Service Delivery Call Centre, which we use to deal with water leaks among others.'\n\nAnother rumour is apples are the source of the pathogen. Hortgro, the deciduous fruit industry body, said according to its knowledge no _Listeria_ had ever been found on fresh South African apples. 'A report is currently being circulated on certain WhatsApp groups, which refer to an incident dating back to 2015 in California in the USA when _Listeria_ was found on caramelised apples,' Anton Rabe, Hortgro's executive director. 'To link this to the current situation and in any manner or form with the fruit industry as such is misleading and sensation-seeking.'\n\nSouth Africa has made listeriosis a notifiable disease meaning every diagnosed patient must be reported.\n\n[This] infection is primarily affecting pregnant women, neonates, elderly, and immuno-compromised people. The 1st documented outbreaks occurred in 1977 (14 cases) and 2015 (7 cases) and since, only sporadic infections have been detected in the country.\n\nThe European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) said since October 2017 an increase in the number of neonatal cases was observed.\n\n'This increase and the associated deaths are of concern, as South Africa also has high prevalence of HIV infection. In addition, poorly regulated street food vendors are common across South Africa. Many people lack access to electricity and thus refrigeration.\n\n'Based on WGS [whole genome sequencing] analysis, no associated cases were reported in EU/EEA countries. The risk of spread to Europe is very low. 'European travellers should consume only bottled drinks and factory-produced ice cubes; avoid unpasteurised milk and milk products; ensure meat and fish are thoroughly cooked; properly wash fruits and vegetables; and consider general hygiene conditions when consuming local products, such as freshly made fruit juices, coconut water, drinks, and cocktails to reduce risk of infection.\n\n[Byline: Joseph James Whitworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180122.5577247), there was a total of 767 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 81 deaths. Now there are 820 nationally, including 82 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]", "summary": "\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, that is, a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180122.5577247), there was a total of 767 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 81 deaths. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n European travellers should consume only bottled drinks and factory-produced ice cubes; avoid unpasteurised milk and milk products; ensure meat and fish are thoroughly cooked; properly wash fruits and vegetables; and consider general hygiene conditions when consuming local products, such as freshly made fruit juices, coconut water, drinks, and cocktails to reduce risk of infection. LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (05): FATAL, MORE CASES\n**************************************************\n \n\nMost are from Gauteng Province (59 percent), Western Cape (13 percent) and KwaZulu-Natal (7 percent) provinces. \n\nOutcome data is available for 29 percent (238/820) of cases, of which 82 died. \n\n'Based on WGS [whole genome sequencing] analysis, no associated cases were reported in EU/EEA countries. ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179] \n\nGenetic testing on _Listeria_ from patients suggests a single strain, sequence type 6 (ST6), is responsible for the majority of infections. The 1st documented outbreaks occurred in 1977 (14 cases) and 2015 (7 cases) and since, only sporadic infections have been detected in the country. \n\nSouth Africa has made listeriosis a notifiable disease meaning every diagnosed patient must be reported. \n\nAn additional 53 cases and 1 death have been recorded by the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-01-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-10-26 00:00:00", "2017-01-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Gauteng Province", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5321964", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): (RI) unpasteurized soft cheese, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5321964", "date": "2017-09-17 13:26:20", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (RHODE ISLAND) UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, ALERT\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Sep 2017\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2017/09/raw-milk-cheese-tied-to-listeria-cases-moms-to-be-at-high-risk/#.Wb1OpciGNPY\n\n\nAt least 2 people in Rhode Island have developed infections from _Listeria monocytogenes_, causing public health officials to warn against eating soft cheese referred to as queso fresco.\n\nAn alert posted Wednesday [13 Sep 2017] by the Rhode Island Department of Health did not include any details about the 2 victims but specifically urged pregnant women to not eat cheese made with unpasteurized milk. Pasteurizing milk kills _Listeria_ and other bacteria that often are present in so-called raw milk.\n\n'Queso fresco is a type of soft cheese. Queso fresco, queso blanco, panela, and asadero-style cheeses are only considered safe when they are marked with a professional label stating that they are 'pasteurized' or 'made from pasteurized milk,'' according to the state warning. 'Homemade queso fresco is sometimes made with unpasteurized, or raw, milk. Unpasteurized milk can cause serious illness.'\n\nPregnant women are significantly more likely than other people to develop serious listeriosis infections when they consume foods or beverages contaminated with even trace amounts of the bacteria. Among pregnant women, the highest rates of [listeriosis] are seen among Hispanic women, according to the Rhode Island health warning. A pregnant woman with listeriosis can pass the infection to her unborn baby. It can cause miscarriages, stillbirths, and impairments in newborns.\n\nAnyone who has eaten any soft cheese recently and developed symptoms of _Listeria_ infection should seek medical attention and tell their doctors about the possible exposure. It can take up to 70 days after exposure to the bacteria for symptoms to develop.\n\nSymptoms can include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions, sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. In some cases, an invasive infection spreads beyond the gastrointestinal tract.\n\nIn addition to pregnant women, high-risk groups include young children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems, including cancer patients and transplant recipients.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Queso fresco is a soft unaged white cheese that is made by curdling milk and then straining the curds in cheesecloth and pressing. It can be made from either pasteurized or unpasteurized (raw) milk. The US FDA prohibits interstate commerce of fresh, unaged (uncured) cheeses made from unpasteurized milk. These cheeses, however, can be sold within states that permit sales of raw dairy products. Rhode Island is one of the states that do not permit the sale of raw milk (http://www.realrawmilkfacts.com/raw-milk-regulations/state/rhode-island). If the queso fresco involved in the Rhode Island outbreak was homemade, the news report above does not say how the households obtained the raw milk in Rhode Island.\n\nBecause aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination, the FDA permits interstate commerce of cheese made from raw milk if the cheese is aged (cured) at a temperature of not less than 35 F [1.6 C] for at least 60 days (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA). However, ageing raw milk cheese for 60 days may not totally ensure safety when _Listeria monocytogenes_ is introduced as a post-processing contaminant (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18724749). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/241.]", "summary": "\n\nBecause aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination, the FDA permits interstate commerce of cheese made from raw milk if the cheese is aged (cured) at a temperature of not less than 35 F [1.6 C] for at least 60 days (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Queso fresco is a soft unaged white cheese that is made by curdling milk and then straining the curds in cheesecloth and pressing. An alert posted Wednesday [13 Sep 2017] by the Rhode Island Department of Health did not include any details about the 2 victims but specifically urged pregnant women to not eat cheese made with unpasteurized milk. Queso fresco, queso blanco, panela, and asadero-style cheeses are only considered safe when they are marked with a professional label stating that they are 'pasteurized' or 'made from pasteurized milk,'' according to the state warning. ' However, ageing raw milk cheese for 60 days may not totally ensure safety when _Listeria monocytogenes_ is introduced as a post-processing contaminant (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18724749). At least 2 people in Rhode Island have developed infections from _Listeria monocytogenes_, causing public health officials to warn against eating soft cheese referred to as queso fresco. \n\nPregnant women are significantly more likely than other people to develop serious listeriosis infections when they consume foods or beverages contaminated with even trace amounts of the bacteria. Pasteurizing milk kills _Listeria_ and other bacteria that often are present in so-called raw milk. If the queso fresco involved in the Rhode Island outbreak was homemade, the news report above does not say how the households obtained the raw milk in Rhode Island. Homemade queso fresco is sometimes made with unpasteurized, or raw, milk. \n\n'Queso fresco is a type of soft cheese. \n\nSymptoms can include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions, sometimes preceded by diarrhea or other gastrointestinal symptoms. In addition to pregnant women, high-risk groups include young children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems, including cancer patients and transplant recipients. Anyone who has eaten any soft cheese recently and developed symptoms of _Listeria_ infection should seek medical attention and tell their doctors about the possible exposure. UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, ALERT\n The US FDA prohibits interstate commerce of fresh, unaged (uncured) cheeses made from unpasteurized milk. It can be made from either pasteurized or unpasteurized (raw) milk. Rhode Island is one of the states that do not permit the sale of raw milk (http://www.realrawmilkfacts.com/raw-milk-regulations/state/rhode-island). These cheeses, however, can be sold within states that permit sales of raw dairy products. Date: Thu 14 Sep 2017\n Source: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2017/09/raw-milk-cheese-tied-to-listeria-cases-moms-to-be-at-high-risk/#.Wb1OpciGNPY A pregnant woman with listeriosis can pass the infection to her unborn baby. **\n \n\n \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "http://www.realrawmilkfacts.com/raw-milk-regulations/state/rhode-island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rhode Island", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5290728", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5290728", "date": "2017-09-02 10:42:15", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK, POLAND: SMOKED SALMON, RECALL\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017\nSource: HealthMap [edited]\nhttp://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901\n\n\nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after F\u00f8devarestyrelsen (Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon.\n\n[Byline: Joe Withworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The original article, available at the source URL (http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark), is copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. However, it is summarized below:\n\nThe Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon, manufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113.]", "summary": "[Byline: Joe Withworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The original article, available at the source URL (http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark), is copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source. Source: HealthMap [edited]\nhttp://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901\n\n\nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after F\u00f8devarestyrelsen (Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-05-26 00:00:00", "2017-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "POLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5621382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Spain (03): listeriosis, raw soft ewe cheese, Portugal, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5621382", "date": "2018-02-11 12:22:57", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - SPAIN (03): LISTERIOSIS, RAW SOFT EWE CHEESE, PORTUGAL, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate Thu 8 Feb 2018\nSource: Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition (AECONSAN) [in Spanish, trans., edited]\nhttp://www.aecosan.msssi.gob.es/AECOSAN/web/seguridad_alimentaria/ampliacion/quesos.htm\n\n\nOn [5 Feb 2018] the Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition, through the Coordinated System of Rapid Information Exchange (SCIRI), learned of the existence of [a 39-year-old man; see 20180209.5618781] in the Community of Madrid affected by meningitis as a result of food intoxication by _Listeria monocytogenes_, presumably associated with the consumption of soft milk sheep cheese made by the company Ohian Txiki Koop located in the Basque Country. The affected [person is recovering] favorably.\n\nThe allegedly involved cheeses are the following: Gutizia, a raw sheep milk cheese; Txuria, a soft cheese from raw sheep milk; and Beltza, a lactic cheese-curl of raw sheep's milk.\n\nThe manufacturer has distributed these products to the autonomous communities of Madrid, Catalonia, and the Basque Country. As of [7 Feb 2018] there is evidence that there has been a small redistribution of a few units from Madrid to Andalusia, Castile-La Mancha, Castile and Leon, Extremadura, Galicia, Valencia, and Portugal.\n\nThe removal of all batches of raw soft-ewe sheep milk cheese is being carried out.\n\nThis information has been communicated through the national alert network to the competent authorities in the autonomous communities who are carrying out the appropriate actions, as well as to the competent Portuguese authorities through the European Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, people who have any of these products at home are advised to refrain from consuming them. If they have consumed them and present any unusual symptoms, it is recommended that they go to a health center.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 10 Feb 2018\nFrom: Allen Lenoir <alenoir165@aol.com> [edited]\n\n\nHas the cause of the meningitis in the 39-year-old in Spain been determined, and is more known about the patient? _Listeria_ would seem to be less likely in a patient this age unless they were immunocompromised. A more likely cause of meningitis related to the consumption of unpasteurized cheese in an immunocompetent 39 year old would be _Brucella_.\n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Irene Lai and Allen Lenoir for providing their contributions.\n\nDr Lenoir is correct. As I stated in my moderator comments (see 20180209.5618781), listeriosis affects mainly pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and adults with impaired immune systems. Invasive disease, like meningitis, due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ would be uncommon in an immune competent 39-year-old man, but certainly invasive disease in apparently immunocompetent non-elderly adults has been reported (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6428282, https://ojs.library.dal.ca/DMJ/article/download/3793/3465, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5771898/, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149, https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0b1e/3e311e79f55e4e80c82eee5a4c9512cea0a1.pdf).\n\nMore information on the 39-year old man in Madrid who developed _Listeria_ meningitis would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nA map of Spain can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43 and of Portugal at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Irene Lai and Allen Lenoir for providing their contributions. Dr Irene Lai\nInternational SOS\n<irene.lai@internationalsos.com>\n\n******\n The allegedly involved cheeses are the following: Gutizia, a raw sheep milk cheese; Txuria, a soft cheese from raw sheep milk; and Beltza, a lactic cheese-curl of raw sheep's milk. On [5 Feb 2018] the Spanish Agency for Consumer Affairs, Food Safety and Nutrition, through the Coordinated System of Rapid Information Exchange (SCIRI), learned of the existence of [a 39-year-old man; see 20180209.5618781] in the Community of Madrid affected by meningitis as a result of food intoxication by _Listeria monocytogenes_, presumably associated with the consumption of soft milk sheep cheese made by the company Ohian Txiki Koop located in the Basque Country. Invasive disease, like meningitis, due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ would be uncommon in an immune competent 39-year-old man, but certainly invasive disease in apparently immunocompetent non-elderly adults has been reported (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6428282, https://ojs.library.dal.ca/DMJ/article/download/3793/3465, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5771898/, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149, https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/0b1e/3e311e79f55e4e80c82eee5a4c9512cea0a1.pdf). MENINGITIS - SPAIN (03): LISTERIOSIS, RAW SOFT EWE CHEESE, PORTUGAL, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n \n\nMore information on the 39-year old man in Madrid who developed _Listeria_ meningitis would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. \n\nThis information has been communicated through the national alert network to the competent authorities in the autonomous communities who are carrying out the appropriate actions, as well as to the competent Portuguese authorities through the European Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed. A more likely cause of meningitis related to the consumption of unpasteurized cheese in an immunocompetent 39 year old would be _Brucella_. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2018-02-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galicia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22760149", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Txuria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4717347", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, no common source identified", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4717347", "date": "2016-12-22 19:56:06", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: (VICTORIA) FATAL, NO COMMON SOURCE IDENTIFIED\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Dec 2016, 7:40 AM\nSource: Herald Sun [edited]\nhttp://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/one-victorian-dead-in-listeria-food-poisoning-surge/news-story/16ca34ccf916371d3b05695df8b296ec\n\n\nThe Department of Health confirmed 1 person had died from listeria poisoning [actually an infection called listeriosis] but were unable to provide further details to protect their privacy. The tragedy is 1 of 7 cases of listeriosis reported in the last 3 weeks. Victoria typically only deals with a single case of listeria every 2 to 3 weeks. All of the other patients have either already left hospital or their conditions are regarded as improving.\n\nA Health Department investigation found no links between any of the 7 cases and a different strain of the listeriosis bacteria was responsible for each, raising concerns of wider problems over the coming weeks.\n\n'Although it's hard to piece together exactly the pattern over summer for listeriosis, all the kind of things that create risk are present -- higher temperatures, food is left out longer, soft foods, rich foods, foods left where it's not safe -- so it seems like this is a time to be mindful of the food safety messages,' Victoria's acting Chief Health Officer Dr Finn Romanes said.\n\n'Pregnant women and their foetuses, newborn babies, the elderly and those who are immune compromised ... those groups are particularly at risk, they have a 30 percent fatality rate and these bacteria can end up in their blood, in joints and in meningitis and a serious brain infection.'\n\nHealth Minister Jill Hennessy reiterated the warning for all Victorians follow simple safety measures. 'Preventing food poisoning can be as simple as washing your hands thoroughly with soap and water and making sure food is prepared and stored safely -- if you're sick, avoid parties and preparing food for at least 24 hours afterwards,' she said.\n\nThose in high-risk groups are warned to avoid soft cheeses, ready-to-eat seafood such as cooked chilled prawns, smoked fish, oysters or raw seafood, pre-prepared salads and sandwiches, drinks made from fresh fruit and vegetables and unpasteurised dairy products or soft-serve ice cream.\n\nA Chief Health Officer Advisory sent to doctors today called for all health professionals to take extra precautions when dealing with pregnant women presenting with fever, fatigue and muscle aches, and consider the possibility of [listeriosis] being the cause.\n\nDoctors have been requested to take a clinical sample [blood sample for culture?] of patients fitting the profile to test for listeriosis.\n\nDepartment of Health's top 10 food safety tips\n----------------------------------------------\n1. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food\n2. Keep your utensils, cutting boards, dishes and containers clean and dry\n3. Store food at the correct temperatures. Cold food should be stored at less than 5 deg.C [41 deg.F]\n4. Cook food thoroughly\n5. If in doubt throw it out\n6. Separate raw and cooked foods\n7. Use different utensils, cutting boards and containers for raw and ready-to- eat food\n8. Check your fridge and freezer temperatures\n9. Keep salads, spreads, dips and other perishable products in the fridge or a cooler until needed\n\n[Byline: Grant McArthur]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating food contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. _Listeria_ can be found in a variety of raw foods as well as in processed foods and food made from unpasteurized milk. Cooking will usually kill the organism; but food can be contaminated after cooking and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 deg.F (2-3 deg.C). If previously refrigerated contaminated food is reheated sufficiently before serving, _Listeria_ again should be killed, but can cause listeriosis if served without further cooking, for example, in 'ready-to-eat' food.\n\nIn the U.S., _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nThe news report above says that 'a different strain of the listeriosis bacteria was responsible for each' [case] and there were 'no links between any of the 7 cases', suggesting that each isolate had a different genotype and a food history failed to find a common food exposure.\n\nMaps of Australia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288. Victoria, in southeastern Australia, is the country's 2nd-most populous state. Most of its population of over 5.7 million is concentrated in the area surrounding Port Phillip Bay, which includes the metropolitan area of its capital and largest city, Melbourne, Australia's 2nd-largest city http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_(Australia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]", "summary": "Although it's hard to piece together exactly the pattern over summer for listeriosis, all the kind of things that create risk are present -- higher temperatures, food is left out longer, soft foods, rich foods, foods left where it's not safe -- so it seems like this is a time to be mindful of the food safety messages,' Victoria's acting Chief Health Officer Dr Finn Romanes said. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating food contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. Preventing food poisoning can be as simple as washing your hands thoroughly with soap and water and making sure food is prepared and stored safely -- if you're sick, avoid parties and preparing food for at least 24 hours afterwards,' she said. The news report above says that 'a different strain of the listeriosis bacteria was responsible for each' [case] and there were 'no links between any of the 7 cases', suggesting that each isolate had a different genotype and a food history failed to find a common food exposure. \n\nThose in high-risk groups are warned to avoid soft cheeses, ready-to-eat seafood such as cooked chilled prawns, smoked fish, oysters or raw seafood, pre-prepared salads and sandwiches, drinks made from fresh fruit and vegetables and unpasteurised dairy products or soft-serve ice cream. If previously refrigerated contaminated food is reheated sufficiently before serving, _Listeria_ again should be killed, but can cause listeriosis if served without further cooking, for example, in 'ready-to-eat' food. Use different utensils, cutting boards and containers for raw and ready-to- eat food\n8. \n\nDepartment of Health's top 10 food safety tips\n When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source. \n\nA Health Department investigation found no links between any of the 7 cases and a different strain of the listeriosis bacteria was responsible for each, raising concerns of wider problems over the coming weeks. LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: (VICTORIA) FATAL, NO COMMON SOURCE IDENTIFIED\n**********************************************************************\n In the U.S., _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food\n2. Cooking will usually kill the organism; but food can be contaminated after cooking and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 deg.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4365160", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - France: (LR) unpasteurized cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4365160", "date": "2016-07-23 17:15:23", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - FRANCE: (LOIRE) UNPASTEURIZED CHEESE, RECALL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Jul 2016\nSource: Le Progres [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://www.leprogres.fr/loire/2016/07/14/incomprehension-chez-le-fromager\n\n\nThe Puillet cheese factory, located in Roanne [Loire Department, France], withdrew its products from sale after detection of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a bacterium causing listeriosis. 2 people from the retirement home of Belmont-de-la-Loire have been infected.\n\n_Listeria_ bacterium has been detected in Camembert cheese made from cow's milk from a local dairy.\n\nThe presence of bacteria was detected after 2 people from the retirement home of Belmont-de-la-Loire, returned after a festive meal on 23 Jun [2106]. The investigation by the DDPP Loire (Department for Protection of Populations) revealed that the infection had come from cheese consumed during the meal. The 2 seniors are on antibiotic treatment and were supported by the ARS (Regional Health Agency).\n\nCheese had been made from raw cow's milk and mixed cow and goat milk under the name of 'Camembel' from the cheese maker Puillet. The cheese has been recalled and production had been stopped. Cleaning and disinfection of the entire manufacturing process is underway. Different surface sampling and monitoring products have yet to be analyzed. The establishment will resume production when the safety will be assured and validated by the DDPP. 'The controls are very strict, since consumer safety is at stake,' said Patrick Rubi, deputy director of the DDPP.\n\nThe manager of the dairy remains dubious: 'We do not know where it comes from or how it could be contaminated. It's been over 20 years since we started (the business) and it never happened before. It is really hurting our business.'\n\nPatrick Rubi says that the management of the cheese business is fully cooperating: 'The management has implemented all necessary measures to find the best possible level of hygiene. He has been very cooperative. This causes big problems for him and it's quite sad. But it was an industrial accident that may happen.' The village mayor, Jean-Luc Matray, himself a farmer, said he was 'reassured that there was no epidemic.'\n\nNote: The last case of listeriosis was detected in a dairy in Sainte-Agathe-la-Bouteresse, in July 2015, almost a year to the day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Roanne, on the Loire River with a population of 45 105 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanne), and Belmont-de-la-Loire, with a population of about 1500 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belmont-de-la-Loire), are towns in the Loire Department in central France. They are located about 37 km (about 23 miles) apart (http://www.viamichelin.fr/web/Itineraires/Itineraire-Roanne-42300-Loire-France-vers-Belmont_de_la_Loire-42670-Loire-France).\n\nCamembert is a soft, creamy, surface-ripened cow's milk cheese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camembert). The cheese involved in the recall was made from 'raw cow's milk and mixed cow and goat milk' under the name of 'Camembel.'\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts below (e.g., Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17812.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Roanne, on the Loire River with a population of 45 105 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanne), and Belmont-de-la-Loire, with a population of about 1500 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belmont-de-la-Loire), are towns in the Loire Department in central France. \n\nCheese had been made from raw cow's milk and mixed cow and goat milk under the name of 'Camembel' from the cheese maker Puillet. \n\nThe presence of bacteria was detected after 2 people from the retirement home of Belmont-de-la-Loire, returned after a festive meal on 23 Jun [2106]. The cheese involved in the recall was made from 'raw cow's milk and mixed cow and goat milk' under the name of 'Camembel.' \n\nPatrick Rubi says that the management of the cheese business is fully cooperating: 'The management has implemented all necessary measures to find the best possible level of hygiene. \n\nCamembert is a soft, creamy, surface-ripened cow's milk cheese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camembert). \n\nNote: The last case of listeriosis was detected in a dairy in Sainte-Agathe-la-Bouteresse, in July 2015, almost a year to the day. Listeria_ bacterium has been detected in Camembert cheese made from cow's milk from a local dairy. \n\n--\n LISTERIOSIS - FRANCE: (LOIRE) UNPASTEURIZED CHEESE, RECALL\n*********************************************************", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-07-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FRANCE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4893360", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, unpast soft cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4893360", "date": "2017-03-11 05:11:35", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, RECALL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Mar 2017\nSource: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/two-dead-raw-milk-cheese-contaminated-listeria-n731416\n\n\nA total of 2 people have died and 4 more have been hospitalized in an outbreak of [listeriosis] linked to cheese made using raw milk, federal investigators said [on Thu 9 Mar 2017]. They've traced to cases to Ouleout cheese, a soft cheese made by Vulto Creamery in New York. The cheese is distributed nationally and it's all being recalled.\n\n'As many as 6 people infected with the outbreak strain of listeria have been reported from 4 states since [1 Sep 2016],' the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said in a statement. 'All 6 people were hospitalized and 2 people from Connecticut and Vermont died. One illness was reported in a newborn. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicate that soft raw milk cheese made by Vulto Creamery of Walton, New York, is the likely source of this outbreak.' Raw milk that has not been pasteurized can carry bacteria such as listeria.\n\n'CDC recommends that consumers do not eat, restaurants do not serve, and retailers do not sell recalled soft raw milk cheeses made by Vulto Creamery,' the agency said. Vulto Creamery has recalled all lots of Ouleout, Miranda, Heinennellie, and Willowemoc soft wash-rind raw milk cheeses.\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a bacterium which can cause serious and sometimes fatal infections in young children, frail or elderly people, pregnant women and others with weakened immune systems,' the Food and Drug Administration said. 'Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhea, listeria infection can cause miscarriages, stillbirths and fetal infection among pregnant women.'\n\n[Listeriosis] outbreaks are common. CDC estimates that [listeriosis] puts 1600 people into the hospital each year and kills 260 of them.\n\nThere's a 2nd big recall of cheese going on over listeria fears. This one involves cheese distributed by Deutsch Kase Haus of Middlebury, Indiana and it includes products sold under various brand names, including Sargento, Biery Cheese, Yoke's Fresh Market, Amish Classics, Gussisberg Cheese and others. No one has been reported sick in this outbreak.\n\n[byline: Maggie Fox]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the USA, clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to identify a common source.\n\nThe news report in this multistate cluster says that the common source was soft cheese made from unpasteurized milk by a producer in New York State and distributed nationally. Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_.\n\nIn 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers; however, sale of nonpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article). To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm). We are not told the arrangements made for the interstate distribution of the unpasteurized cheese involved in this outbreak. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm). '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-09-01 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Walton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Middlebury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ouleout", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4563526", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada (02): (BC) Asian food susp, alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4563526", "date": "2016-10-16 14:53:24", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CANADA (02): (BRITISH COLUMBIA) ASIAN FOOD SUSPECTED, ALERT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Oct 2016\nSource: Vancouver Coastal Health [edited]\nhttp://www.vch.ca/about-us/news/news-releases/public-safety-advisory-for-customers-of-foody-world\n\n\nVancouver Coastal Health [VCH] is warning customers not to consume any produce or ready-to-eat foods made in-house at Foody World, at 3000 Sexsmith Road in Richmond, due to possible listeria contamination. So far at least 6 people have been hospitalized due to the illness.\n\nPotentially contaminated items include all ready-to-eat meat products such as BBQ pork and marinated meats, sushi, produce, and baked goods purchased since July 2016. If you have any produce, ready-to-eat or raw food items from Foody World, please dispose of them immediately.\n\nSymptoms of listeriosis include fever, headache, diarrhea, vomiting, and muscle aches. Listeriosis can also cause serious illness such as meningitis or blood infections in pregnant women and newborns, those with weakened immune systems and older adults or seniors. Symptoms typically start within 4 weeks after consuming, but can appear up to 10 weeks later.\n\nIf you think you have an infection caused by listeria, see a doctor for testing, advice and treatment. VCH Public Health will follow-up with any patients whose lab results are positive for listeria. Most healthy people require no treatment, however, those at higher risk of serious illness can be treated with antibiotics.\n\nVCH public health inspectors have closed the store and kitchen. The store will be reopened once it meets all health and safety standards.\n\nFor more information about the food recall, members of the public can call Vancouver Coastal Health - Health Protection at 604-233-3147 and ask to speak to a senior environmental health officer. Further information is available at the following websites:\nBC Centre for Disease Control - listeria/listeriosis\nhttp://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/listeria-listeriosis\nHealthLinkBC - listeriosis\nhttps://www.healthlinkbc.ca/healthlinkbc-files/listeriosis\nHealthLinkBC - Chinese version\nhttps://www.healthlinkbc.ca/hlbc/files/documents/healthfiles/hfile75-c.pdf\nGovernment of Canada - food poisoning\nhttp://healthycanadians.gc.ca/eating-nutrition/risks-recalls-rappels-risques/poisoning-intoxication/poisoning-intoxication/ecoli-eng.php\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to identify any specific food product, bought at Foody World, that is suspected to be contaminated by _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis. More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nFoody World is an Asian supermarket (http://www.chowhound.com/post/foodyworld-richmond-omg-1034656) located in Richmond, a coastal city that is part of the Metro Vancouver area in the Canadian province of British Columbia; Richmond has an immigrant population of 60 per cent, the highest in Canada, with over 50 per cent of residents identifying as Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond,_British_Columbia#Demographics).\n\nFor discussions about listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail posts: Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719 and Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/276.]", "summary": "Further information is available at the following websites:\nBC Centre for Disease Control - listeria/listeriosis\nhttp://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/listeria-listeriosis\nHealthLinkBC - listeriosis\nhttps://www.healthlinkbc.ca/healthlinkbc-files/listeriosis\nHealthLinkBC - Chinese version\nhttps://www.healthlinkbc.ca/hlbc/files/documents/healthfiles/hfile75-c.pdf\nGovernment of Canada - food poisoning\n http://healthycanadians.gc.ca/eating-nutrition/risks-recalls-rappels-risques/poisoning-intoxication/poisoning-intoxication/ecoli-eng.php\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to identify any specific food product, bought at Foody World, that is suspected to be contaminated by _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis. For more information about the food recall, members of the public can call Vancouver Coastal Health - Health Protection at 604-233-3147 and ask to speak to a senior environmental health officer.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-26 00:00:00", "2016-07-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4204205", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (05): fatal, frozen org & trad fruit/veg, exp recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4204205", "date": "2016-05-05 15:24:48", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA, CANADA (05): FATAL, FROZEN ORGANIC AND TRADITIONAL FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, EXPANDED RECALL\n************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 3 May 2016\nSource: refinery29 [edited]\nhttp://www.refinery29.com/2016/05/109924/trader-joes-recall\n\n\nTrader Joe's and CRF Frozen Foods issued a recall [Tue 3 May 2016] after the frozen vegetable supplier alerted the grocery chain that some products could be contaminated by _Listeria monocytogenes_. The chain was the most prominent member of the suppliers or brands affected by the contamination at the CRF Frozen Foods plant. The FDA released a statement saying that CRF Frozen Foods fully cooperated after discovering the contamination.\n\nThe manufacturing process could have been contaminated since as early as May 1 2014. Products with sell-by dates between 26 Apr 2016 and 26 Apr 2018 are included in the recall. CRF Frozen Foods recall encompasses 358 consumer products sold under 42 separate brands, a more detailed list of which can be seen [in the following list]. Trader Joe's said that any of the following whose lot designation contains the code 'BF' could be subject to contamination:\n\n- Trader Joe's Organic Peas (SKU/Barcode 00496636)\n- Trader Joe's Petite Peas (SKU/Barcode 00122689)\n- Trader Joe's Organic Whole Green Beans (SKU/Barcode 00169219)\n- Trader Joe's Broccoli Florettes (SKU/Barcode 00542784)\n- Trader Joe's Organic Foursome (SKU/Barcode 00908672)\n\n'Out of an abundance of caution, all products from this supplier have been removed from store shelves,' the grocery store said in a release. 'If you purchased any of the affected vegetable products with the 'BF' code, please do not eat them. We urge you to discard the product or return it to any Trader Joe's for a full refund.'\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ are potentially very serious. 'The organism can cause serious and sometimes fatal infections in young children, frail or elderly people, and others with weakened immune systems,' the FDA said in the release. 'Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, _Listeria_ infection can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant women.'\n\nThe CDC says that it has identified 7 people in 3 states whose _Listeria_ infection forced hospitalization. Though 2 of those people died, their causes of death were not _Listeria_.\n\nTrader Joe's posted its Customer Relations number, (626) 599-3817, or asked that concerned customers email them. CRF Frozen Foods may be called at 844-483-3866, Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 8:00pm Eastern Standard Time.\n\nThe full Trader Joe's release is available here (http://www.traderjoes.com/announcement/recall-potential-listeria-in-certain-frozen-vegetables?e=ja.bogen@gmail.com). The full FDA release, including a list of contaminated CRF products, is available here (http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm498841.htm).\n\n[Byline: Michael Hafford]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 2 may 2016\nSource: FDA [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm498841.htm\n\n\nCRF Frozen Foods Expands Voluntary Recall to Include All Frozen Vegetable and Fruit Products Due To Possible Health Risk\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAs a precaution, CRF Frozen Foods of Pasco, Washington is expanding its voluntary recall of frozen organic and traditional fruits and vegetables. We are performing this voluntary recall in cooperation with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) because these products have the potential to be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_. The organism can cause serious and sometimes fatal infections in young children, frail or elderly people, and others with weakened immune systems. Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, _Listeria_ infection can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant women.\n\nThis expanded recall of frozen vegetables includes all of the frozen organic and traditional fruit and vegetable products manufactured or processed in CRF Frozen Foods' Pasco facility since 1 May 1 2014. All affected products have the best by dates or sell by dates between 26 Apr 2016 and 26 Apr 2018. These include approximately 358 consumer products sold under 42 separate brands, the details of which are listed below. Products include organic and non-organic broccoli, butternut squash, carrots, cauliflower, corn, edamame, green beans, Italian beans, kale, leeks, lima beans, onions, peas, pepper strips, potatoes, potato medley, root medley, spinach, sweet potatoes, various vegetable medleys, blends, and stir fry packages, blueberries, cherries, cranberries, peaches, raspberries, and strawberries. For a complete list of affected products, see below.\n\nWe apologize for any concern or inconvenience this expanded recall has caused our customers and consumers who enjoy our products. We are issuing this release to alert consumers not to eat these products. Consumers who purchased these products may return them to the store where they were purchased for a refund, or simply discard them. Consumers with questions may call the company's consumer hotline at 844-483-3866, Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 8:00pm Eastern Standard Time.\n\nCRF had already suspended operations at its Pasco, Washington facility as of Monday morning, 25 Apr 2016 following the initial voluntary recall, so a thorough review could be conducted.\n\nCDC has informed CRF Frozen Foods that the government has identified 7 people from 3 states who became ill and were hospitalized due to _Listeria_. Some of these illnesses have been linked to consuming CRF-manufactured or processed products. CDC also informed us that, sadly, 2 of these individuals later died, but that _Listeria_ was not the cause of death in either person.\n\nAll retailers who received the products have been contacted. Products being recalled may have been purchased in all 50 U.S. states and the following Canadian Provinces: British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, Saskatchewan.\n\n[A table listing all the recalled products by brand or private labels, container size and UPC can be found at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail post below (Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n [A table listing all the recalled products by brand or private labels, container size and UPC can be found at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n- Trader Joe's Petite Peas (SKU/Barcode 00122689)\n- Trader Joe's Organic Whole Green Beans (SKU/Barcode 00169219)\n- Trader Joe's Broccoli Florettes (SKU/Barcode 00542784)\n Source: FDA [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm498841.htm\n\n\nCRF Frozen Foods Expands Voluntary Recall to Include All Frozen Vegetable and Fruit Products Due To Possible Health Risk\n \n\nThis expanded recall of frozen vegetables includes all of the frozen organic and traditional fruit and vegetable products manufactured or processed in CRF Frozen Foods' Pasco facility since 1 May 1 2014. Products include organic and non-organic broccoli, butternut squash, carrots, cauliflower, corn, edamame, green beans, Italian beans, kale, leeks, lima beans, onions, peas, pepper strips, potatoes, potato medley, root medley, spinach, sweet potatoes, various vegetable medleys, blends, and stir fry packages, blueberries, cherries, cranberries, peaches, raspberries, and strawberries. - Trader Joe's Organic Foursome (SKU/Barcode 00908672)\n\n'Out of an abundance of caution, all products from this supplier have been removed from store shelves,' the grocery store said in a release. ' CRF Frozen Foods recall encompasses 358 consumer products sold under 42 separate brands, a more detailed list of which can be seen [in the following list]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< LISTERIOSIS - USA, CANADA (05): FATAL, FROZEN ORGANIC AND TRADITIONAL FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, EXPANDED RECALL\n*********************************************************************************************************** \n\nCRF had already suspended operations at its Pasco, Washington facility as of Monday morning, 25 Apr 2016 following the initial voluntary recall, so a thorough review could be conducted. [Tue 3 May 2016] after the frozen vegetable supplier alerted the grocery chain that some products could be contaminated by _Listeria monocytogenes_. Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, _Listeria_ infection can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant women.' Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, _Listeria_ infection can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant women. [Byline: Michael Hafford]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Products with sell-by dates between 26 Apr 2016 and 26 Apr 2018 are included in the recall. \n\nCDC has informed CRF Frozen Foods that the government has identified 7 people from 3 states who became ill and were hospitalized due to _Listeria_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2001-05-01 20:14:00", "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "2014-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pasco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4896013", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): fatal, unpast soft cheese, aged 60 days, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4896013", "date": "2017-03-12 18:42:17", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, AGED 60 DAYS, RECALL\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 9 Mar 2017\nSource: CDC Listeria (Listeriosis) [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheese-03-17/index.html\n\n\nHighlights\n----------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). Listeria can cause a serious, life-threatening illness. Six people infected with the outbreak strain of listeria have been reported from 4 states since 1 Sep 2016. All 6 people were hospitalized, and 2 people from Connecticut and Vermont died. One illness was reported in a newborn.\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory evidence indicates that soft raw milk cheese made by Vulto Creamery of Walton, New York is the likely source of this outbreak. Six of 6 people interviewed reported eating various types of soft cheeses in the month before their illness started.\n\nThe outbreak strain of listeria was identified in samples taken from 3 intact wheels of Ouleout cheese collected from Vulto Creamery. On 7 Mar 2017, Vulto Creamery recalled all lots of Ouleout, Miranda, Heinennellie, and Willowemoc soft wash-rind raw milk cheeses. The soft raw milk cheeses were distributed nationwide, with most being sold at retail locations in the northeastern and Mid-Atlantic states, California, Chicago, Portland, Oregon, and Washington DC.\n\nCDC recommends that consumers do not eat, restaurants do not serve, and retailers do not sell recalled soft raw milk cheeses made by Vulto Creamery. This investigation is ongoing. Updates will be provided when more information is available.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 10 Mar 2017\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttps://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/10/nyregion/two-people-die-after-eating-raw-milk-cheese-made-in-new-york.html?_r=0\n\n\nTwo people have died following an outbreak of listeriosis linked to a popular artisanal raw milk cheese made in upstate New York the authorities said this week.\n\nThe deaths occurred in Vermont and Connecticut, local officials said. Four other people in New York and Florida reported feeling sick after eating Ouleout, the artisanal cheese, which is produced by Vulto Creamery in Walton, NY. Illnesses started on dates between 1 Sep of last year [2016] to 22 Jan 2017, the FDA said. All 6 people were hospitalized, and 2 people died.\n\nVulto Creamery, which produces Ouleout, said it was recalling the product, and, as a precautionary measure, 3 other soft wash-rind raw milk cheeses: Miranda, Heinennellie, and Willowemoc. 'We are very busy working on this recall with FDA and our customers,' the creamery said in an email, without offering details on the cause of the outbreak.\n\nVulto Creamery began contacting clients on 3 Mar [2017], asking them to return purchases of Ouleout after being informed of a listeria strain in a sample, the health department said. It issued a recall on 7 Mar 2017 and extended it to the 3 other brands.\n\nThe deaths highlighted concerns over safety regulations around artisanal cheese production in the United States, particularly around the raw milk cheese segment, which emerged only about a decade ago, experts say. The outbreak has also revived a continuing debate between the virtues of raw milk cheese, which aficionados say tastes better, and safety. Some customers swear only by pasteurized-milk cheese.\n\nEuropeans have eaten raw milk cheese for hundreds of years. In France, for example, 15 per cent of its cheese is made of unpasteurized milk, according to French agricultural statistics. The thinking is that when milk is cooked, or pasteurized, many of the flavor-rich enzymes are destroyed.\n\nOuleout, a soft washed-rind cheese that is aged for 60 days, 'requires real craftsmanship' because it needs to retain a good amount of moisture even as it matures, said Carlos Yescas, program director at Oldways Cheese Coalition, a nonprofit organization that promotes artisanal cheese making. 'Otherwise, the cheese will dry out really quickly.' Washed-rind cheese is made by washing and curing the cheese in beer and other solutions, helping create its pungent flavor.\n\nMore than half of artisanal cheese produced in the US is made of unpasteurized milk, Mr Yescas said, adding that there are a number of ways in which the cheese could be contaminated. Listeria, he said, could originate from the wood boards used to age the cheese, the water supply or improper sanitation, like walking in dirty boots. 'It's hard to pinpoint,' Mr Yescas said.\n\nIn the US, regulations on raw milk cheese are less stringent than in Europe, where more steps are required to ensure that there is no contamination, he said. Here, there is only a single national standard for raw milk cheese production, Mr Yescas said, which requires that the cheese be aged for at least 60 days to block _Escherichia coli_ from developing. 'We need to take a look again at the 60-day rule and have a consensus with the scientific community, regulators and cheese producers,' Mr Yescas said.\n\n[byline: Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 12 Mar 2017\nFrom: Christopher Henry <chrishen@umich.edu> [edited]\n\n\nFDA regulations prohibit the sale across state lines of raw milk itself or of cheeses made from raw milk that have been aged for less than 60 days. Raw milk cheeses aged for more than 60 days may be sold, provided that they are clearly labeled as such. All of the cheeses sold by Vulto Creamery appear to fall into the latter category.\n\n--\nChristopher Henry\nPhD student in Epidemiology\nUniversity of Michigan\n<chrishen@umich.edu>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Christopher Henry for his submission.\n\nThe US FDA prohibits interstate commerce of fresh, un-aged (uncured) cheeses made from unpasteurized (raw) milk. These cheeses, however, can be sold within states that permit sales of unpasteurized dairy products. Because aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination, the FDA permits interstate commerce of cheese made from raw milk if the cheese is aged (cured) at a temperature of not less than 35 F [1.6 C] for at least 60 days (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA).\n\nAs suggested by Christopher Henry, the 2nd news report above says that the soft cheese made from raw milk manufactured by Vulto Creamery in New York State that is responsible for the multistate listeriosis outbreak is aged for 60 days, which likely explains why it was able to be distributed nationally.\n\nHowever, ageing raw milk cheese for 60 days may not totally ensure safety when _Listeria monocytogenes_ is introduced as a post-processing contaminant (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18724749). In 2014, the FDA tested cheese made from unpasteurized milk that had been aged 60 days for the presence of the pathogens salmonella, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_ (https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Food/ComplianceEnforcement/Sampling/UCM512217.pdf). Of the 1606 raw milk cheese samples tested, 29 per cent were of domestic and 71 per cent were of international origin; most were semi-soft (63 per cent) and hard (35.5 per cent), but only 3 per cent were soft-ripened, like the Vulto cheese, and 1.5 per cent were fresh. Although the overall contamination rate for each of the pathogens was less than one per cent, the FDA detected _L. monocytogenes_ in 10 of the 1606 cheese samples tested, 5 in domestic (3 of the 5 collected at a single firm) and 5 imported cheeses; 9 of the 10 samples that tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_ were of the semi-soft type. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Of the 1606 raw milk cheese samples tested, 29 per cent were of domestic and 71 per cent were of international origin; most were semi-soft (63 per cent) and hard (35.5 per cent), but only 3 per cent were soft-ripened, like the Vulto cheese, and 1.5 per cent were fresh. Because aging/ripening of cheese for at least 60 days is thought to reduce bacterial contamination, the FDA permits interstate commerce of cheese made from raw milk if the cheese is aged (cured) at a temperature of not less than 35 F [1.6 C] for at least 60 days (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/02/publishers-platform-60-day-rule-the-facts/#.WMWFxLGZPjA). \n\nOuleout, a soft washed-rind cheese that is aged for 60 days, 'requires real craftsmanship' because it needs to retain a good amount of moisture even as it matures, said Carlos Yescas, program director at Oldways Cheese Coalition, a nonprofit organization that promotes artisanal cheese making. Here, there is only a single national standard for raw milk cheese production, Mr Yescas said, which requires that the cheese be aged for at least 60 days to block _Escherichia coli_ from developing. LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED SOFT CHEESE, AGED 60 DAYS, RECALL\n***************************************************************************** In 2014, the FDA tested cheese made from unpasteurized milk that had been aged 60 days for the presence of the pathogens salmonella, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_ (https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Food/ComplianceEnforcement/Sampling/UCM512217.pdf). \n\nEuropeans have eaten raw milk cheese for hundreds of years. \n\nThe US FDA prohibits interstate commerce of fresh, un-aged (uncured) cheeses made from unpasteurized (raw) milk.
