At least 19 states don't have laws requiring laboratories to submit confirmed _Listeria_ samples, or 'isolates,' to state health officials. Texas Department of State Health Services spokeswoman Carrie Williams said the agency instead prefers to work with labs and health providers to educate them and bring them into compliance. LISTERIOSIS - USA (09): PULSENET, DATA COLLECTION, PROBLEMS\n***********************************************************\n \n\n--\n [Byline: Mark Collette]\n\n--\n In PulseNet, the CDC keeps a database of bacterial DNA from public health laboratories that extract it from people who got sick. Of those that do, Texas hovers around the middle of the pack in states missing samples in confirmed cases, according to the Council to Improve Foodborne Outbreak Response. \n\n\nBlue Bell Creameries announced on Tue 14 Jul 2015, that an investment by prominent Texas businessman Sid Bass will 'ensure' the return of its ice cream products to the market. But [the patient] is one of thousands of Americans whose severe foodborne illnesses have never been properly counted or studied -- and not because the technology doesn't exist.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2032-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2013-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "1996-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-05-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3741423", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (11): fatal, soft cheeses, update, investigation closed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3741423", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA 'fingerprinting' is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1). In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. \n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. \n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. \n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. DNA 'fingerprinting' is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2015-08-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "1973-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-09-26 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3437487", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (08): fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, risk remains", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3437487", "date": "2015-06-15 14:38:39", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (08): FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ICE CREAM, RISK REMAINS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2015\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/ice-cream-03-15/index.html\n\n\nMultistate Outbreak of Listeriosis Linked to Blue Bell Creameries Products (Final Update)\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled products may still be in people's freezers and consumers unaware of the recalls could eat them. Institutions should not serve and retailers should not sell recalled products. Read the Advice to Consumers, Institutions, and Retailers.\n\nHighlights\n----------\nAt a Glance: Case Count: 10; States: 4; Deaths: 3; Hospitalizations: 10; Recall: Yes.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. Information gathered as part of the investigation indicated that various Blue Bell brand products were the source of this outbreak of listeriosis.\n\n- Listeriosis is a life-threatening infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium (germ) _Listeria monocytogenes_ (_Listeria_). People at high risk for listeriosis include pregnant women and their newborns, adults 65 and older, and people with weakened immune systems.\n\n- A total of 10 people with listeriosis related to this outbreak were reported from 4 states: Arizona (1), Kansas (5), Oklahoma (1), and Texas (3). All ill people were hospitalized; 3 deaths were reported from Kansas (3).\n\n- On [20 Apr 2015], Blue Bell Creameries voluntarily recalled all of its products currently on the market made at all of its facilities, including ice cream, frozen yogurt, sherbet, and frozen snacks.\n\n- Consumers should not eat any recalled Blue Bell brand products, and institutions and retailers should not serve or sell them. This is especially important for people at higher risk for listeriosis. These products are frozen, so consumers, institutions, and retailers should check their freezers.\n\n- On [7 May 2015], the U.S. Food and Drug Administration released the findings from recent inspections at the Blue Bell production facilities in Brenham, Texas [see source document]; Broken Arrow, Oklahoma [see source document]; and Sylacauga, Alabama [see source document].\n\nOutbreak Summary\nIntroduction\n------------\nThis was a complex multistate outbreak investigation of listeriosis cases occurring over several years. Public health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of this outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA 'fingerprinting' is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks of enteric illness. Several PFGE patterns (strains) of _Listeria_ were involved in this outbreak.\n\nA total of 10 people infected with several strains of _Listeria_ were reported from 4 states: Arizona (1), Kansas (5), Oklahoma (1), and Texas (3). Illness onset dates ranged from January 2010 through January 2015. The people with illness onsets during 2010-2014 were identified through a retrospective review of the PulseNet database for DNA fingerprints matching isolates collected from Blue Bell ice cream samples. All 10 (100 percent) people were hospitalized; 3 deaths were reported from Kansas.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nFebruary 2015\nIn February 2015, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control isolated _Listeria_ as part of routine sampling from Blue Bell brand single-serving ice cream products collected from a distribution center: Chocolate Chip Country Cookie Sandwiches and Great Divide Bars. In response to the findings in South Carolina, the Texas Department of State Health Services collected product samples from the Blue Bell Creameries production facility in Brenham, Texas, that made these products. Testing by Texas health officials yielded _Listeria_ isolates from some samples of the same 2 products tested by South Carolina and from another Blue Bell ice cream product called 'Scoops.' This product was made on the same production line as the Chocolate Chip Country Cookie Sandwiches and Great Divide Bars. PFGE was performed on the _Listeria_ isolated from the ice cream samples; 7 different PFGE patterns were identified and uploaded to PulseNet.\n\nMarch 2015\nIn March 2015, Kansas health officials identified 2 people from the same hospital who were infected with _Listeria_ bacteria that had the same PFGE pattern; 3 additional listeriosis cases with 3 other PFGE patterns had previously been identified from the same hospital. All 5 people were hospitalized for unrelated problems before developing invasive listeriosis -- a finding that strongly suggested their infections were acquired in the hospital. _Listeria_ isolates from 4 of the 5 people had PFGE patterns that were also identified in ice cream tested by South Carolina and Texas. Although some of the illnesses occurred more than a year before this investigation began, all 4 people with available information consumed milkshakes made with the 'Scoops' Blue Bell ice cream product while they were in the hospital. Isolates from 4 of these people were highly related to each other by whole genome sequencing. _Listeria_ isolated from the 5th person was not related to isolates from the other 4 ill people. In addition, the PFGE pattern was not identified in any ice cream samples. However, this person was part of a recognized illness cluster at the hospital and consumed milkshakes made with 'Scoops' while hospitalized. As a result, this person was included as a case in the outbreak. Illness onset dates for the 5 people ranged from January 2014 through January 2015. Three of these people died as a result of their _Listeria_ infection.\n\nOn [13 Mar 2015], Blue Bell Creameries reported removing the 'Scoops' ice cream product and other products made on the same production line from the market. The company also reported that it had shut down that production line at its Brenham, Texas, facility.\n\nOn [22 Mar 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) reported that _Listeria_ was isolated from a previously unopened, single-serving Blue Bell brand 3 oz. institutional/food service chocolate ice cream cup collected from the Kansas hospital involved in the outbreak. Samples of Blue Bell brand 3 oz. institutional/food service chocolate ice cream cups collected from the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility also yielded _Listeria_. _Listeria_ isolated from ice cream cup samples were indistinguishable from each other by PFGE, but were different from those isolated from people in Kansas and from other Blue Bell brand ice cream products previously sampled in Texas and South Carolina. On [23 Mar 2015], Blue Bell announced a recall of 3 oz. institutional/food service ice cream cups (with tab lids) of several flavors produced at the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility.\n\nApril 2015\nOn [3 Apr 2015], CDC reported that illnesses might be linked to ice cream made in Blue Bell Creameries' Oklahoma facility, but lacked sufficient information to include them as cases in the outbreak at the time. These illnesses were identified when investigators searched the PulseNet database and identified 6 people from Arizona (1), Oklahoma (1), and Texas (4) with listeriosis between 2010 and 2014 who had _Listeria_ isolates with PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from the chocolate ice cream cups made in the Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility. The 4 people reported from Texas were hospitalized for unrelated problems before developing listeriosis. Information available for one person indicated that they consumed ice cream in a Texas hospital before developing listeriosis; the Texas Department of State Health Services reported that the hospital had received Blue Bell brand ice cream cups. None of the 4 people in Texas died from _Listeria_ infection. At this point in the investigation, CDC recommended that consumers not eat and institutions and retailers not serve any products made at the company's Oklahoma facility, in addition to any previously recalled or withdrawn products. That day, Blue Bell Creameries reported that they had voluntarily suspended operations at their facility in Oklahoma.\n\nOn [8 Apr 2015], CDC reported that whole genome sequencing confirmed that 3 of the 4 isolates from people in Texas were nearly identical to _Listeria_ strains isolated from ice cream produced at Blue Bell Creameries' Oklahoma facility. These 3 people were added to the case count for the outbreak, bringing the total to 8. The 4th isolate was later determined not to be part of the outbreak by whole genome sequencing and this illness was not added to the case count.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2015], Blue Bell Creameries voluntarily recalled all products currently on the market made at all of its facilities, including ice cream, frozen yogurt, sherbet, and frozen snacks. Blue Bell announced this recall after sampling by the company revealed that Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough Ice Cream half gallons produced on [17 Mar 2015] and [27 Mar 2015] contained _Listeria_.\n\nOn [21 Apr 2015], CDC reported that whole genome sequencing confirmed that the people from Arizona (1) and Oklahoma (1) were part of the outbreak, bringing the total case count to 10.\n\nMay 2015\nOn [7 May 2015], FDA released the findings from recent inspections at the Blue Bell production facilities in Brenham, Texas [see source document]; Broken Arrow, Oklahoma [see source document]; and Sylacauga, Alabama [see source document].\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled products may still be in people's freezers and consumers unaware of the recalls could eat them. Institutions should not serve and retailers should not sell recalled products. These products are frozen, so consumers, institutions, and retailers should check their freezers. Read the Advice to Consumers, Institutions, and Retailers [http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/ice-cream-03-15/advice-consumers.html].\n\n[Figures of epidemic curve and a map of the U.S. showing the states where cases are located are available at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously reported this multistate outbreak of listeriosis traced to eating _Listeria_-contaminated ice cream manufactured by Blue Bell Creameries -- see refs. below. The above news report from the CDC is a summary of the events at the conclusion of the investigation.\n\nFor discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]", "summary": "On [23 Mar 2015], Blue Bell announced a recall of 3 oz. institutional/food service ice cream cups (with tab lids) of several flavors produced at the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility.\n\nApril 2015\n These illnesses were identified when investigators searched the PulseNet database and identified 6 people from Arizona (1), Oklahoma (1), and Texas (4) with listeriosis between 2010 and 2014 who had _Listeria_ isolates with PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from the chocolate ice cream cups made in the Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility. On [8 Apr 2015], CDC reported that whole genome sequencing confirmed that 3 of the 4 isolates from people in Texas were nearly identical to _Listeria_ strains isolated from ice cream produced at Blue Bell Creameries' Oklahoma facility. Listeria_ isolated from ice cream cup samples were indistinguishable from each other by PFGE, but were different from those isolated from people in Kansas and from other Blue Bell brand ice cream products previously sampled in Texas and South Carolina. Information available for one person indicated that they consumed ice cream in a Texas hospital before developing listeriosis; the Texas Department of State Health Services reported that the hospital had received Blue Bell brand ice cream cups. \n\n- A total of 10 people with listeriosis related to this outbreak were reported from 4 states: Arizona (1), Kansas (5), Oklahoma (1), and Texas (3). In March 2015, Kansas health officials identified 2 people from the same hospital who were infected with _Listeria_ bacteria that had the same PFGE pattern; 3 additional listeriosis cases with 3 other PFGE patterns had previously been identified from the same hospital. Although some of the illnesses occurred more than a year before this investigation began, all 4 people with available information consumed milkshakes made with the 'Scoops' Blue Bell ice cream product while they were in the hospital. In February 2015, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control isolated _Listeria_ as part of routine sampling from Blue Bell brand single-serving ice cream products collected from a distribution center: Chocolate Chip Country Cookie Sandwiches and Great Divide Bars. \n\n- On [7 May 2015], the U.S. Food and Drug Administration released the findings from recent inspections at the Blue Bell production facilities in Brenham, Texas [see source document]; Broken Arrow, Oklahoma [see source document]; and Sylacauga, Alabama [see source document]. LISTERIOSIS - USA (08): FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ICE CREAM, RISK REMAINS\n***************************************************************** On [22 Mar 2015], the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) reported that _Listeria_ was isolated from a previously unopened, single-serving Blue Bell brand 3 oz. institutional/food service chocolate ice cream cups collected from the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, facility also yielded _Listeria_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2065-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-05-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brenham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3336094", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada: apple products, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3336094", "date": "2015-05-03 11:26:42", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CANADA: APPLE PRODUCTS, ALERT, RECALL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Apr 2015\nSource: The Canadian Press [edited]\nhttp://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2015/04/30/listeria-scare-prompts-apple-recall-for-starbucks-subway.html\n\n\nSliced apples and products containing them produced by Sun Rich Fresh Foods Ltd., of Brampton, Ontario are being recalled because of the possible presence of _Listeria_. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) says the recall is based on its test results, and there has been one illness linked to the slices.\n\nThe recall covers Sun Rich Apple Slices in 57-gram, 595-gram and 3-pound packages with a best-before date of 17 May 2015. Other Sun Rich products -- Fruit Medley, Waldorf Salad Kit and Apple Slices with Grapes -- are also being recalled. Shoppers Drug Mart Apples and Grapes and Subway Apples are also part of the recall. The CFIA initially listed Starbucks Seasonal Fruit Salad as one of the affected products. It later updated the notice to say: 'This product does not contain apples affected by this recall and as such is excluded from the recall.'\n\nThe CFIA says food service establishments such as hotels, restaurants, cafeterias, hospitals and nursing homes should also avoid selling or using these products.\n\nA list of the recalled products, package sizes and best-before dates are available at the CFIA website http://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/20150429b/eng/1430375161334/1430375167258.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The recent American outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples involved 37 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. In addition, 2 Canadians have also developed listeriosis caused by _Listeria_ with the same genotype as one of the US outbreak strains. No illnesses were said to be associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that were not prepackaged, according to the CDC. All the companies involved obtained some of their apples from the same apple supplier headquartered in Bakersfield, California (Bidart Bros.). This recall does not appear to be related to the USA one. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The recent American outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples involved 37 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. Two of them died within 30 days of the bacterium's discovery.\n\nThe institute said that 2 of the new cases resemble the same type that was present in batches of the popular deli meat rullepolse produced by the company Jorn A. Rullepolser in 2014. That outbreak began in August 2014 and infected a total of 41 individuals, 17 of whom died. Two of the other new cases resemble previous minor outbreaks, while the 5th is infected with a type of _Listeria_ that has not yet been seen.\n\n'It's unusual to have 5 cases in one week. Normally we see one case of listeriosis per week. But it is also unusual that we were able to so quickly determine the type of _Listeria_. That is a sign that our monitoring for the organism has gotten better,' SSI spokesman Kare Molbak said.\n\nThe Jorn A. Rullepolser listeriosis outbreak led to a total of 30 products -- including variations of rullepolse, salami and hot dogs -- being recalled from stores nationwide. The company was shut down as a result.\n\nThe source of the new cases was not immediately known, Molbak said. 'It's the same bacteria as in the rullepolse outbreak. So it's possible that the old outbreak has been rekindled,' he told public broadcaster DR.\n\nSSI said that the majority of those who have been infected with _Listeria_ had weakened immune systems. Fatality rates among infected individuals is 25 percent, the institute said.\n\nDenmark normally sees around 50 listeriosis cases per year, but in the years 2009-2014, that number was closer to 100.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The locations of the 5 cases in Denmark are not stated in the posting, but it seems to be the case that the strains are not all genotypically related.\n\nThe following is part of a moderation written by my colleague ML regarding listeriosis:\n'Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating foods contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. _Listeria_ can be in a variety of raw foods as well as in processed foods and foods made from unpasteurized milk. The process of making asparagus soup, if cooked at temperatures higher than 150 F (65 C), should have killed _Listeria monocytogenes_, the gram-positive bacillus that is the cause of listeriosis, in any of the soup's ingredients. However, _Listeria_ can contaminate foods after the food is cooked, and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 F (2-3 C). If previously refrigerated soup had been reheated sufficiently before serving, _Listeria_ again should have been killed. The FDA recommends that soups, sauces, and gravy should be brought to a boil when reheating, and leftovers should be reheated to 165 F (74 C) (http://www.fda.gov/food/resourcesforyou/consumers/ucm079667.htm). Presumably, the asparagus soup was served cold or insufficiently reheated to hospitalized patients, many of whom were likely at high risk of developing listeriosis.'\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe following is part of a moderation written by my colleague ML regarding listeriosis:\n'Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating foods contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. \n\nThe institute said that 2 of the new cases resemble the same type that was present in batches of the popular deli meat rullepolse produced by the company Jorn A. Rullepolser in 2014. \n\nThe Jorn A. Rullepolser listeriosis outbreak led to a total of 30 products -- including variations of rullepolse, salami and hot dogs -- being recalled from stores nationwide. The process of making asparagus soup, if cooked at temperatures higher than 150 F (65 C), should have killed _Listeria monocytogenes_, the gram-positive bacillus that is the cause of listeriosis, in any of the soup's ingredients. \n\nDenmark normally sees around 50 listeriosis cases per year, but in the years 2009-2014, that number was closer to 100. \n\n\nFive people were infected with listeriosis within a one-week span earlier in April 2015, the Danish State Serum Institute (SSI) said on Tue 28 Apr 2015. LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK: MULTIPLE GENOTYPES\n*****************************************\n \n\nThe source of the new cases was not immediately known, Molbak said. ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The locations of the 5 cases in Denmark are not stated in the posting, but it seems to be the case that the strains are not all genotypically related.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-04-26 00:00:00", "2015-04-28 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3344944", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (07): ice cream, whole gene sequencing detection", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3344944", "date": "2015-05-06 13:01:03", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (07): ICE CREAM, WHOLE GENE SEQUENCING DETECTION\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 May 2015\nSource: Science Insider [edited]\nhttp://news.sciencemag.org/biology/2015/05/sequencing-finds-listeria-unlikely-places\n\n\nThe listeria outbreak that killed 3 and prompted Texas ice cream company Blue Bell Creameries to recall every one of its products late in April 2015 is the latest example of how genetic epidemiology is changing the detection of foodborne illnesses. 2 years ago, the CDC in Atlanta launched a pilot program to sequence the DNA of every listeria sample tied to an illness in the USA -- all told, about 800 per year.\n\n'Now that we're turning whole-genome sequencing on, we're identifying outbreak after outbreak,' says Brendan Jackson, a medical epidemiologist with CDC. 'We're also finding smaller outbreaks that we weren't able to find before.' They're also finding them originating in previously unsuspected foods, from caramel apples to ice cream.\n\nThe new detection method can identify gaps in the food safety system, especially when used alongside similar efforts by the FDA to sequence samples from food and from the places where food is prepared, from factories to distribution centers, Jackson says.\n\nIn the Blue Bell case, a quick-thinking nurse was the first to link 5 cases in Kansas with the tainted ice cream. For more than a year, Infection Prevention and Control Coordinator Karen Bally at Via Christi Health in Wichita and the rest of the team had been searching for anything to tie together the infections, which started with a single illness in January 2014. Traditional epidemiological tools showed nothing. Diet records were inconclusive, and samples from the 1st 4 patients seemed unrelated using the standard technique for DNA analysis.\n\nWhen the 5th patient fell ill in early 2015, standard DNA analysis finally showed a link to a previous case -- patient number 3. The state of Kansas sent a sample to CDC for confirmation. Whole-genome sequencing revealed that the 2 samples of _Listeria_ were a near-perfect match. 'That was like the 'aha' moment,' Bally says.\n\nBut they still didn't have a source. Bally and her team scoured FDA recalls and public health listservs for reports of tainted foods. Nothing. Then, she heard about a quality problem with one of their vendors --Blue Bell ice cream. Unknown to Bally, FDA sampling had turned up listeria in a Blue Bell distribution center in South Carolina, and inspectors had traced it to a production facility in Texas. Without explanation, Blue Bell stopped delivering its most popular products to Bally's hospital.\n\nBally called the state health department. They contacted FDA, which had just sequenced the tainted ice cream samples. When they compared those results to the CDC samples, they found another match. CDC then looked into other unsolved listeria cases. By sequencing samples still in storage, they confirmed 5 additional cases, dating back to 2010.\n\n'It's not something that we've seen before -- being able to look at cases so far back,' Jackson says. And although it took many tools to track the current outbreak, whole-genome sequencing 'made all the difference,' he says.\n\nBefore now, investigators had 2 main tools for tracking cases: diet interviews and DNA analysis known as genetic fingerprinting. Fingerprinting shows the degree to which two different samples of DNA are related. But it isn't 100 percent accurate -- in some cases, different bacterial strains can appear related and similar strains can appear to be unrelated.\n\nWhole-genome sequencing, in contrast, allows scientists to accurately compare every single DNA base pair in samples, giving them 'a much sharper look at the differences and similarities in the strains,' Jackson says. The process takes longer -- 72 hours for testing compared with 48 hours -- and it costs more. CDC's goal is to create a national DNA database for foodborne pathogens from clinical samples that could be integrated with an already-existing FDA database of foodborne pathogens from food and environmental samples. The agency plans to add other foodborne illnesses, including salmonellosis and the most common disease-causing strain of _Escherichia coli_, to the project within 3 years.\n\nBut progress toward setting up a comprehensive national network has been incremental, because only 2 states can currently perform their own sequencing. The rest must send their samples to central CDC laboratories. And because the onus is on the state to send in samples, some go unsequenced. But the technology can do more than simply identify outbreaks, according to Robert Tauxe, deputy director of CDC's Division of Foodborne, Waterborne, and Environmental Diseases.\n\n'Whole-genome sequencing shines a new light in this area that helps us find unsuspected gaps in the food safety system,' he says. Ice cream, for example, was rarely tested for _Listeria_ prior to the Blue Bell outbreak. But in the weeks since, several states have said that _Listeria_ testing in ice cream will now be part of their regimen. 'Finding these outbreaks related to foods we never suspected before is a very surprising thing,' Tauxe says. 'This is a wake-up call to the ice cream industry in general and to the regulators.'\n\n[Byline: Catherine Matacic]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This technology appears to be more useful in linking isolates of potential foodborne outbreaks, such as listeriosis, and is to be expanded in the future to other infections such as salmonellosis and enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "\n\nThe new detection method can identify gaps in the food safety system, especially when used alongside similar efforts by the FDA to sequence samples from food and from the places where food is prepared, from factories to distribution centers, Jackson says. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Science Insider [edited]\nhttp://news.sciencemag.org/biology/2015/05/sequencing-finds-listeria-unlikely-places\n\n\nThe listeria outbreak that killed 3 and prompted Texas ice cream company Blue Bell Creameries to recall every one of its products late in April 2015 is the latest example of how genetic epidemiology is changing the detection of foodborne illnesses. \n\nWhole-genome sequencing, in contrast, allows scientists to accurately compare every single DNA base pair in samples, giving them 'a much sharper look at the differences and similarities in the strains,' Jackson says. \n\n'Whole-genome sequencing shines a new light in this area that helps us find unsuspected gaps in the food safety system,' he says. CDC's goal is to create a national DNA database for foodborne pathogens from clinical samples that could be integrated with an already-existing FDA database of foodborne pathogens from food and environmental samples. \n\nWhen the 5th patient fell ill in early 2015, standard DNA analysis finally showed a link to a previous case -- patient number 3. \n\n'Now that we're turning whole-genome sequencing on, we're identifying outbreak after outbreak,' says Brendan Jackson, a medical epidemiologist with CDC. \n\nIn the Blue Bell case, a quick-thinking nurse was the first to link 5 cases in Kansas with the tainted ice cream. \n\n[Byline: Catherine Matacic]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This technology appears to be more useful in linking isolates of potential foodborne outbreaks, such as listeriosis, and is to be expanded in the future to other infections such as salmonellosis and enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_. \n\nBefore now, investigators had 2 main tools for tracking cases: diet interviews and DNA analysis known as genetic fingerprinting. LISTERIOSIS - USA (07): ICE CREAM, WHOLE GENE SEQUENCING DETECTION\n Whole-genome sequencing revealed that the 2 samples of _Listeria_ were a near-perfect match. ' But it isn't 100 percent accurate -- in some cases, different bacterial strains can appear related and similar strains can appear to be unrelated. 2 years ago, the CDC in Atlanta launched a pilot program to sequence the DNA of every listeria sample tied to an illness in the USA -- all told, about 800 per year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-04-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wichita", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3980669", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (02): fatal, recall, pre-packed salads, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3980669", "date": "2016-01-31 10:08:44", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA, CANADA (02): FATAL, RECALL, PRE-PACKED SALADS, SAME GENOTYPE\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jan 2016\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2016/01/123015/#.VquuFvnhDIU\n\n\nAs federal officials reported new illnesses in a 7-month listeriosis outbreak linked to packaged salads from Dole, the company clarified its recall of all products from its production plant in Springfield, Ohio.\n\nAs of [Wed 27 Jan 2016], 15 people across 8 US states had been confirmed in the outbreak. The most recent case was diagnosed [3 Jan 2016], according to a [Thu 28 Jan 2016] update from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. All have required hospitalization and 1 died.\n\nIn Canada, public health officials report 7 people across 5 provinces have been infected. 1 person died, but it has not yet been confirmed that listeriosis was the cause.\n\n'Laboratory tests performed on clinical isolates from ill people in Canada showed that the isolates are highly related genetically to _Listeria_ isolates from ill people in the United States,' the CDC reports.\n\nOn [Tue 26 Jan 2016], Dole Food Co. of Westlake Village, California, posted a statement indicating its 'voluntary withdrawal' a week earlier of all products from its Springfield facility amounted to a recall. 'Voluntary recall is a specific term used by the Food and Drug Administration. While our actions under a voluntary recall as compared to the previously reported voluntary withdrawal remain the same, we have updated our communication terminology to reference a 'recall,' ' according to the Dole company statement. 'We have done this with the aim of using terminology that may be more familiar to consumers.'\n\nThe federal definition of 'recall' indicates a company knows consuming a product could cause 'serious adverse health consequences or death.' The term 'withdrawal' indicates 'a minor violation that would not be subject to legal action by the FDA or which involves no violation.'\n\nDole reports all retailers across 23 states and 3 Canadian provinces that received products from the Springfield, Ohio, facility had been contacted as of [27 Jan 2016].\n\nHealth officials did not link the Springfield facility to the outbreak -- which dates back to at least July 2015 and is ongoing -- until earlier this month [January 2016], when a lab test of a packaged salad collected in Ohio returned a positive test result for _Listeria monocytogenes_. That _Listeria_ strain matched samples uploaded from outbreak victims to federal disease databases.\n\nThe recalled salads include a variety of mixes of leafy greens and other fresh cut vegetables. They are packaged under the brands: Dole; Fresh Selections; Simple Truth; Marketside; The Little Salad Bar; and President's Choice Organics.\n\nDole distributed the salads to retailers in these US states and Canadian provinces: Alabama; Connecticut; Florida; Georgia; Illinois; Indiana; Kentucky; Louisiana; Michigan; Massachusetts; Maryland; Minnesota; Missouri; Mississippi; North Carolina; New Jersey; New York; Ohio; Pennsylvania; South Carolina; Tennessee; Virginia; Wisconsin; Ontario; New Brunswick; and Quebec.\n\n[Byline: Coral Beach]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently reported on the multi-province Canadian listeriosis outbreak suspected to be due to listeria-contaminated pre-packaged leafy vegetables or mixed salads, in which 7 people fell ill between September 2015 and the beginning of January 2016 (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Canada: fatal, pre-packed vegetables susp, RFI 20160122.3956200). This time period overlaps that of the US listeriosis outbreak reported by CDC, due to packaged salads (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA, Canada: fatal, recall, pre-packed salads, RFI 20160123.3960428).\n\nThe news report above says that genotypes of clinical isolates from ill people in the Canadian listeriosis outbreak match those from the US outbreak. Both outbreaks were linked to packaged salads produced at the Dole processing facility in Springfield, Ohio.\n\nFor discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail recently reported on the multi-province Canadian listeriosis outbreak suspected to be due to listeria-contaminated pre-packaged leafy vegetables or mixed salads, in which 7 people fell ill between September 2015 and the beginning of January 2016 (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Canada: fatal, pre-packed vegetables susp, RFI 20160122.3956200). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This time period overlaps that of the US listeriosis outbreak reported by CDC, due to packaged salads (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA, Canada: fatal, recall, pre-packed salads, RFI 20160123.3960428). As federal officials reported new illnesses in a 7-month listeriosis outbreak linked to packaged salads from Dole, the company clarified its recall of all products from its production plant in Springfield, Ohio. \n\n'Laboratory tests performed on clinical isolates from ill people in Canada showed that the isolates are highly related genetically to _Listeria_ isolates from ill people in the United States,' the CDC reports. \n\nThe news report above says that genotypes of clinical isolates from ill people in the Canadian listeriosis outbreak match those from the US outbreak. \n\nAs of [Wed 27 Jan 2016], 15 people across 8 US states had been confirmed in the outbreak. \n\nDole reports all retailers across 23 states and 3 Canadian provinces that received products from the Springfield, Ohio, facility had been contacted as of [27 Jan 2016]. \n\nHealth officials did not link the Springfield facility to the outbreak -- which dates back to at least July 2015 and is ongoing -- until earlier this month While our actions under a voluntary recall as compared to the previously reported voluntary withdrawal remain the same, we have updated our communication terminology to reference a 'recall,' ' according to the Dole company statement. ' \n\nThe federal definition of 'recall' indicates a company knows consuming a product could cause 'serious adverse health consequences or death.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-27 00:00:00", "2016-01-26 00:00:00", "2016-01-03 00:00:00", "2016-01-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kentucky", "country": "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3291517", "date": "2015-04-11 14:02:06", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (06): (KANSAS, TEXAS) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ICE CREAM, RECALL, UPDATE\n************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 10 Apr 2015\nSource: Fairfield Citizen, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.fairfieldcitizenonline.com/news/texas/article/Number-of-people-sickened-by-listeria-outbreak-6188629.php\n\n\nDays after a foodborne illness was linked to Blue Bell ice cream products, a state inspection of an Oklahoma plant later tied to the infection praised the facility for having no violations and doing a 'great job,' according to a copy of the inspection report.\n\nInspectors had no reason to check for _Listeria_ during the routine 18 Mar [2015] review as no problems were detected and the facility didn't have a history of issues linked to the illness, said Stan Stromberg, director of the food safety division for the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry. 'With an organism like _Listeria_, you cannot do a visual inspection,' Stromberg said on Thursday [9 Apr 2015].\n\nTainted Blue Bell ice cream products have sickened 8 people -- 5 in Kansas and 3 in Texas. 3 of the 5 in Kansas have died and health officials there say listeriosis [the illness caused by _Listeria_] might have been a contributing factor in the deaths.\n\nBlue Bell has temporarily closed its facility in Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, and shut down a production line at its facility in Brenham, Texas, where the company is headquartered. Blue Bell has also recalled more than 25 of its products since last month [March 2015].\n\nIn the one-page report about the Oklahoma plant, provided to The Associated Press in response to an open records request, an inspector wrote 'No Violations Observed!' and 'Keep it up!' At the time of the inspection, _Listeria_ had only been traced to Blue Bell's Brenham facility. Blue Bell issued its 1st recall on 13 Mar [2015]. Stromberg said Oklahoma officials didn't learn until 22 Mar [2015] that _Listeria_ was connected to a product produced by the Oklahoma plant.\n\nStromberg said his agency has been at the plant ever since, working with the Food and Drug Administration and other agencies to determine a cause of the _Listeria_. 'Once you identify where it is, _Listeria_ is relatively easy to control. But it's going to be like looking for a needle in a haystack,' he said.\n\nOfficials in Washington [State] can attest to the difficulty of tracking down _Listeria_ at a plant. At least 2 people became ill after the _Listeria_ was detected in products manufactured by Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream. The company responded by issuing a recall in December [2014]. It addressed health safety concerns and was given approval to resume operations a month later.\n\n'You may just be working to keep your plant really, really clean, but you also need to work to keep it in good repair because that organism can slide into a crack on the door, or get into the crack where the wall and floor meet,' said Lucy Severs, food safety manager for the Department of Agriculture in Washington.\n\nStromberg said he didn't believe there was any sort of breakdown in the inspection process in Oklahoma, as officials don't normally submit samples for laboratory testing as a part of routine reviews, unless there were problems such as with cleanliness. No such problems were detected in the 18 Mar [2015] inspection, which is one of 8 to 10 done each year at the plant.\n\nBefore the recall, the facility in Brenham had last been fully inspected in February [2015] and the Texas Department of State Health Services had found a couple of minor issues. The Brenham facility is inspected monthly.\n\n'Over the years, Blue Bell has had a good inspection record and very few issues, none leading to any enforcement issue (i.e. penalty),' agency spokeswoman Carrie Williams wrote in an email.\n\nIn a statement Thursday [9 Apr 2015], Blue Bell said, 'the fact that our products may be linked to these events is very distressing to us. We are sorry for this news and we are doing everything possible to determine the cause of the outbreak.'\n\nListeriosis is a life-threatening infection caused by eating food contaminated with bacteria called _Listeria monocytogenes_, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]. The disease primarily affects pregnant women and their newborns, older adults, and people with immune systems weakened by cancer, cancer treatments, or other serious conditions.\n\nThe CDC said Thursday preliminary tests indicate another 3 people hospitalized at some point from 2010 to 2012 appear to have a similar strain of _Listeria_ as the others, but further testing is necessary before confirming a connection.\n\n[Byline: David Warren, Juan A. Lozano]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2015\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2015/04/cdc-update-8-sickened-in-blue-bell-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nAccording to an update Wednesday night [8 Apr 2015] from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there have been 8 people sickened by strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ linked to Blue Bell Creameries products in Kansas and Texas.\n\nThe outbreak now consists of 2 clusters of illnesses that are likely linked to Blue Bell brand ice cream.\n\nBlue Bell Creameries Cluster 1 consists of 5 patients reported from Kansas during January 2014 through January 2015 who were all hospitalized at a single hospital for unrelated problems before developing listeriosis. Of the 4 ill people for whom information is available on the foods eaten in the month before _Listeria_ infection, all consumed milkshakes made at the hospital with a Blue Bell brand ice cream product called 'Scoops.'\n\nWhole genome sequences of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from 4 of the patients were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 'Scoops' and 2 other products made on the same line at the company's Texas facility. These products were recalled by Blue Bell Creameries on 13 Mar 2015.\n\nCluster 2 consists of 3 patients reported from Texas between 2011 and 2014 who were all hospitalized for unrelated problems before developing listeriosis. Whole genome sequences of their _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains were highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from another Blue Bell ice cream product -- 3-oz. institutional/food service chocolate ice cream cups made at the company's Oklahoma production facility. The cup products were recalled by Blue Bell Creameries on 23 Mar 2015.\n\n3 additional patients with listeriosis during 2010 through 2012 whose isolates have PFGE patterns similar to those of others in the cluster have been identified in the PulseNet database. Further testing is underway to determine whether these illnesses may be related to this outbreak. Results of this testing will be reported once they are available.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains from a 1-pint container of Blue Bell brand banana pudding ice cream collected from the company's Oklahoma production facility. This contaminated product was produced in the same facility but on a different line from the 3-oz. institutional/food service ice cream cups previously recalled.\n\nOn 3 Apr 2015, Blue Bell Creameries reported that they had voluntarily suspended operations at their Oklahoma production facility.\n\nOn 7 Apr 2015, Blue Bell Creameries announced a 3rd product recall that included banana pudding ice cream pints and other products made on the same line that were produced between 12 Feb 2015, and 27 Mar 2015, at their Oklahoma facility.\n\nFurther testing of environmental and product samples from Blue Bell Creamery facilities is ongoing.\n\nCDC recommends that consumers do not eat any recalled products or Blue Bell brand products made at the Oklahoma production facility and that retailers and institutions not sell or serve them. This advice is particularly important for consumers at higher risk for listeriosis, including pregnant women, adults 65 and older, and people with weakened immune systems.\n\nState and local health officials, CDC and FDA continue to work closely on the investigation.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously reported that listeriosis in 5 Kansans (3 of whom died), who had developed this infection while hospitalized, was traced to eating _Listeria_-contaminated ice cream manufactured by a Blue Bell Creameries facility in Brentham, Texas (Listeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917). All consumed milkshakes made at the hospital with a Blue Bell brand ice cream product called 'Scoops' (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/ice-cream-03-15/).\n\nThe above news reports add 3 additional people from Texas who developed listeriosis linked by genotyping to _Listeria_-contaminated Blue Bell ice cream products between 2011 and 2014, made at the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma production facility. This brings the total number of listeriosis cases linked by genotyping to Blue Bell to 8. The 2nd news report above says that these 3 additional cases from Texas also developed their infection while hospitalized, like the 5 from Kansas. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease caused by _Listeria_.\n\nFor discussions of listeriosis, please see moderator comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED map of Kansas, United States can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219 and\na HealthMap/ProMED map of Texas, United States can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously reported that listeriosis in 5 Kansans (3 of whom died), who had developed this infection while hospitalized, was traced to eating _Listeria_-contaminated ice cream manufactured by a Blue Bell Creameries facility in Brentham, Texas (Listeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917). \n\nThe above news reports add 3 additional people from Texas who developed listeriosis linked by genotyping to _Listeria_-contaminated Blue Bell ice cream products between 2011 and 2014, made at the company's Broken Arrow, Oklahoma production facility. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n On 7 Apr 2015, Blue Bell Creameries announced a 3rd product recall that included banana pudding ice cream pints and other products made on the same line that were produced between 12 Feb 2015, and 27 Mar 2015, at their Oklahoma facility. \n\nWhole genome sequences of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from 4 of the patients were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 'Scoops' and 2 other products made on the same line at the company's Texas facility. \n\nThe Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains from a 1-pint container of Blue Bell brand banana pudding ice cream collected from the company's Oklahoma production facility. \n\n\nDays after a foodborne illness was linked to Blue Bell ice cream products, a state inspection of an Oklahoma plant later tied to the infection praised the facility for having no violations and doing a 'great job,' according to a copy of the inspection report. \n\nTainted Blue Bell ice cream products have sickened 8 people -- 5 in Kansas and 3 in Texas. \n\nBlue Bell Creameries Cluster 1 consists of 5 patients reported from Kansas during January 2014 through January 2015 who were all hospitalized at a single hospital for unrelated problems before developing listeriosis. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nCDC recommends that consumers do not eat any recalled products or Blue Bell brand products made at the Oklahoma production facility and that retailers and institutions not sell or serve them. \n\nCluster 2 consists of 3 patients reported from Texas between 2011 and 2014 who were all hospitalized for unrelated problems before developing listeriosis.
