LISTERIOSIS - USA (06): (KANSAS, TEXAS) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ICE CREAM, RECALL, UPDATE\n************************************************************************************\n [2015] review as no problems were detected and the facility didn't have a history of issues linked to the illness, said Stan Stromberg, director of the food safety division for the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry. ' \n\n'You may just be working to keep your plant really, really clean, but you also need to work to keep it in good repair because that organism can slide into a crack on the door, or get into the crack where the wall and floor meet,' said Lucy Severs, food safety manager for the Department of Agriculture in Washington. According to an update Wednesday night [8 Apr 2015] from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there have been 8 people sickened by strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ linked to Blue Bell Creameries products in Kansas and Texas. \n\nListeriosis is a life-threatening infection caused by eating food contaminated with bacteria called _Listeria monocytogenes_, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]. Of the 4 ill people for whom information is available on the foods eaten in the month before _Listeria_ infection, all consumed milkshakes made at the hospital with a Blue Bell brand ice cream product called 'Scoops.' \n\n3 additional patients with listeriosis during 2010 through 2012 whose isolates have PFGE patterns similar to those of others in the cluster have been identified in the PulseNet database. ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED map of Kansas, United States can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219 and\na HealthMap/ProMED map of Texas, United States can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-04-03 00:00:00", "2021-02-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2015-04-07 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00", "2065-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brenham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brentham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3244417", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3244417", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. takes precautionary step of voluntarily recalling fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm405943.htm.\n2. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. expands its voluntary recall of fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm407600.htm\n3. CDC. _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) surveillance. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html\n4. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Ob-Gyns address management of Listeria during pregnancy. Available at http://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/News-Room/News-Releases/2014/Ob-Gyns-Address-Management-of-Listeria-During-Pregnancy\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As stated in the post, this is the 1st link between stone fruit and human listeriosis.\n\nThe name pluot was not known to me. The strangely named 'pluot(R)' (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as 'dinosaur eggs(R)' due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the 'flavor grenade,' 'dapple dandy,' and 'flavorglo' are fairly common, as are the 'hand grenade' and the 'last chance.' The 'flavor heart' is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the 'candy stripe' has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. [Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). \n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption. In early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\n Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not. \n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3231917", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3231917", "date": "2015-03-15 20:02:55", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): (KANSAS) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ICE CREAM\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 13 mar 2015\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/blue-bell-creameries-listeria-outbreak-sickens-5-in-kansas-killing-3/#.VQUggsZNql1\n\n\nThe Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) has been working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) to investigate an outbreak of listeriosis cases in 5 adult Kansas residents linked to ice cream consumed from Blue Bell Creameries. Listeriosis is a serious infection usually caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nIn this outbreak 5 people in Kansas have become ill and 3 deaths have been reported. Patients became ill with listeriosis after hospitalizations for unrelated causes at the same hospital. They became ill between January 2014 and January 2015 after a majority were known to have consumed Blue Bell Creameries ice cream at the hospital. The hospital was not aware of the listeriosis contamination. The outbreak was recently discovered after 2 patients were identified with the same strain of listeriosis. Further investigation identified 3 other patients with listeriosis who had been hospitalized for unrelated causes before the onset of listeriosis.\n\nToday, the FDA warned consumers about the potential contamination in Blue Bell Creameries' products. Kansas health officials are warning consumers who have purchased the following Blue Bell Creameries novelty items and have not consumed the items to discard them: Chocolate Chip Country Cookie; Great Divide Bar; Sour Pop Green Apple Bar; Cotton Candy Bar; Scoops; Vanilla Stick Slices; Almond Bar; and No Sugar Added Mooo Bar (regular Mooo Bars are not included).\n\nPotentially contaminated items have been pulled from retail locations by Blue Bell Creameries and are no longer available for purchase. At this time, no other products from Blue Bell Creameries have been linked to this outbreak. The FDA issued a consumer advisory about certain Blue Bell ice cream products made in Texas. The March 13 [2015] notice was issued after several confirmed cases of listeriosis in Kansas were linked to products made on a single production line at the Blue Bell Creameries plant in Brenham [Brenham is a city in east-central Texas; see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brenham,_Texas].\n\nThe disease primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and adults with weakened immune systems. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance and convulsions. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria. In 2014, 5 cases of listeriosis were reported in Kansas.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 14 Mar 2015\nSource: Time [edited]\nhttp://time.com/3744962/ice-cream-contaminated-kansas-blue-bell-creameries/\n\n\nIn Kansas 3 people have died after eating contaminated Blue Bell Creameries brand ice cream products. A total of 5 people were infected, and the ice cream has been recalled. But how does ice cream get tainted in the first place?\n\nThe bacteria that contaminated the ice cream is called _Listeria monocytogenes_, and according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), about 1600 Americans get sick from listeriosis every year. It's the 3rd leading cause of death from food poisoning. It's the same bacteria that contaminated caramel apples from California in January 2015, causing 35 people in 12 states to get sick, and killing 7.\n\nThe bacterium grows very well at refrigerator temperatures, even as low as 40 degrees Fahrenheit. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) says that the longer ready-to-eat refrigerated foods are stored in the fridge, the more opportunity the bacterium has to grow.\n\n'It's why it's a problem for cooler foods like ice cream and cheese,' says Bill Marler, a food safety lawyer in Washington state.\n\nThe FDA was able to confirm that 3 strains of the bacteria came from a single Blue Bell production line at 1 facility in Brenham, Texas, though the agency has not disclosed a precise point of contact. Blue Bell says one of its machines produced the problem.\n\n'Likely what happened is the piece of machinery was contaminated. The liquid form of the ice cream goes through the machine when it's not yet frozen, but around 40 degrees, and it's a great place for [_Listeria_] to grow,' says Marler.\n\nIt's not the 1st time contaminated ice cream has sickened Americans. In December 2014, Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream, Inc. issued a voluntary recall of several of its ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet products when they tested positive for _Listeria_ and sickened 2 people. In 1994, 200 000 people became ill from eating Schwan's ice cream that had been transported by a distribution truck that had previously transported non-pasteurized liquid eggs contaminated with _Salmonella_.\n\nOther recent dairy outbreaks include a 2014 outbreak of listeriosis in cheese and dairy products produced by Oasis Brands, Inc., when 5 people became ill and 1 died. A year earlier, 6 people were infected with _Listeria_ in Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company cheese products -- one person died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus that is transmitted to humans, other than newborn infants, by ingestion of contaminated food. (Neonatal listeriosis is acquired transplacentally or during or after delivery.) _Listeria_ can be found in a variety of raw foods as well as in processed foods and foods made from unpasteurized milk. Pasteurization or cooking at temperatures higher than 150 F (65 C) should kill _L. monocytogenes_. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization or cooking, and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 F (2-3 C) and is reported to survive freezer temperatures (http://etd.lsu.edu/docs/available/etd-11102004-072203/unrestricted/Beverly_dis.pdf).\n\nInfection with this organism results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nListeriosis was added to the list of nationally notifiable diseases in 2001. Almost all reported cases of listeriosis have invasive infection in which the bacteria spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\n\n******\n \n\nOther recent dairy outbreaks include a 2014 outbreak of listeriosis in cheese and dairy products produced by Oasis Brands, Inc., when 5 people became ill and 1 died. In December 2014, Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream, Inc. issued a voluntary recall of several of its ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet products when they tested positive for _Listeria_ and sickened 2 people. The bacteria that contaminated the ice cream is called _Listeria monocytogenes_, and according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), about 1600 Americans get sick from listeriosis every year. In 1994, 200 000 people became ill from eating Schwan's ice cream that had been transported by a distribution truck that had previously transported non-pasteurized liquid eggs contaminated with _Salmonella_. In Kansas 3 people have died after eating contaminated Blue Bell Creameries brand ice cream products. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for genotyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. \n\nIt's not the 1st time contaminated ice cream has sickened Americans. \n\nInfection with this organism results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). \n\nThe FDA was able to confirm that 3 strains of the bacteria came from a single Blue Bell production line at 1 facility in Brenham, Texas, though the agency has not disclosed a precise point of contact. The March 13 [2015] notice was issued after several confirmed cases of listeriosis in Kansas were linked to products made on a single production line at the Blue Bell Creameries plant in Brenham Further investigation identified 3 other patients with listeriosis who had been hospitalized for unrelated causes before the onset of listeriosis. They became ill between January 2014 and January 2015 after a majority were known to have consumed Blue Bell Creameries ice cream at the hospital. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization or cooking, and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 F (2-3 C) and is reported to survive freezer temperatures (http://etd.lsu.edu/docs/available/etd-11102004-072203/unrestricted/Beverly_dis.pdf).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "1994-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brenham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Almond Bar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3129444", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3129444", "date": "2015-01-29 19:46:41", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (ILLINOIS, MICHIGAN), FATAL, SPROUTS, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: Food Poisoning Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://foodpoisoningbulletin.com/2015/wholesome-soy-listeria-outbreak-ends-with-5-sick-2-dead/\n\n\nThe Wholesome Soy listeriosis outbreak has ended after sickening 5 people in Michigan and Illinois, killing 2 of them. [See prior ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351.]\n\nThe Chicago [Illinois]-based company is longer producing sprouts, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]'s final report on the outbreak, issued today [27 Jan 2015]. Calls to the company were not answered.\n\nHealth officials used whole genome sequencing (WGS) and pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) to link sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy to 4 cases of listeriosis in Illinois and 1 case in Michigan. All 5 case patients in this outbreak were hospitalized. During interviews, 2 of the surviving patients reported eating bean sprouts before they became ill.\n\nThe US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) inspected the Wholesome Soy Products Chicago facility in August and October [2014] and found unsanitary conditions, many of which were present during both inspections.\n\nListeriosis poses a special risk for children, seniors, pregnant women and others with compromised immune systems. The CDC recommends that these groups never eat raw sprouts. Among pregnant women, listeriosis can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery and newborns with listeriosis.\n\nSymptoms of listeriosis can take up to 70 days after exposure to develop and include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, headache, stiff neck and muscle aches. Treatment almost always requires hospitalization.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gillespie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2015\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/bean-sprouts-11-14/index.html\n\n\nThis investigation is closed. _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection (listeriosis) is an important cause of illness in the United States. More information about listeriosis, and steps people can take to reduce their risk of infection, can be found on the CDC Listeria Web Page [http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/].\n\nHighlights\n----------\nOn 7 Nov 2014, Wholesome Soy Products Inc. of Chicago, Illinois, agreed to close their facility and to cease production and distribution of sprouts. The facility is no longer in production.\n\nSprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products Inc. are likely no longer available for purchase or consumption given the 5-day shelf life reported by the facility.\n\nOn 28 Aug 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. conducted a voluntary recall of mung bean sprouts due to possible _Listeria monocytogenes_ contamination after FDA isolated the pathogen from samples as a result of a routine assignment.\n\nDuring FDA inspections of the Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. facility in August and October 2014, investigators observed unsanitary conditions, many of which were present during both inspections. Whole genome sequences of the _Listeria_ strains isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. and environmental isolates collected at the production facility were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 people who became ill from June through August 2014. These 5 ill people were reported from 2 states: Illinois (4) and Michigan (1). All ill people were hospitalized. 2 deaths were reported.\nThe 2 people interviewed reported eating bean sprouts.\n\nAlthough limited information is available about the specific sprout products that ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc.\n\nCDC recommends that consumers, restaurants, and other retailers always follow food safety practices to avoid illness from contaminated sprouts. Make sure that children, older adults, pregnant women, and persons with weakened immune systems avoid eating raw sprouts of any kind (including alfalfa, clover, radish, and mung bean sprouts). Cook sprouts thoroughly to reduce the risk of illness. Cooking sprouts thoroughly kills any harmful bacteria.\n\n_Listeria_ is still an important cause of human illness in the United States. More information about _Listeria_ and steps people can take to reduce their risk of infection can be found on the CDC Listeria Web Page.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously reported on an outbreak of listeriosis in 2014 related to consumption of contaminated sprouts (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351).\n\nThe CDC now reports that whole-genome sequences of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from 5 ill people were found to be highly related to sequences of the _Listeria_ strain isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. of Chicago, Illinois. These ill people have been reported from 2 states: Illinois (4) and Michigan. They became ill from June through August 2014. On 7 Nov 2014, Wholesome Soy Products agreed to close their facility and to cease production and distribution of sprouts. No new cases of listeriosis caused by similar strains apparently have occurred since August 2014, and the CDC has closed its investigation. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/216.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail previously reported on an outbreak of listeriosis in 2014 related to consumption of contaminated sprouts (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Although limited information is available about the specific sprout products that ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc.\n\nCDC recommends that consumers, restaurants, and other retailers always follow food safety practices to avoid illness from contaminated sprouts. Whole genome sequences of the _Listeria_ strains isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. and environmental isolates collected at the production facility were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 people who became ill from June through August 2014. \n\nThe CDC now reports that whole-genome sequences of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from 5 ill people were found to be highly related to sequences of the _Listeria_ strain isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. of Chicago, Illinois. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (ILLINOIS, MICHIGAN), FATAL, SPROUTS, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n**********************************************************************************\n \n\nSprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products Inc. are likely no longer available for purchase or consumption given the 5-day shelf life reported by the facility. On 7 Nov 2014, Wholesome Soy Products agreed to close their facility and to cease production and distribution of sprouts.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2014-10-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-08-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MICHIGAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3107945", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed deaths, ovine, caprine - FYR Macedonia (02): listeriosis conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3107945", "date": "2015-01-21 16:13:57", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS, OVINE, CAPRINE - FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA (02): LISTERIOSIS CONFIRMED\n******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 20 Jan 2015\nFrom: Elena Arsevska <elena.arsevska@cirad.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Undiagnosed deaths, ovine, caprine - FYR Macedonia: RFI 20150116.3094497\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nI am forwarding you a link with the official information published in the website of the veterinary services of Macedonia, regarding the undiagnosed death in small ruminants.\n\nBriefly, it says that the cause of death is _Listeria_ and the animals were infected via contaminated feed.\n\n--\nElena Arsevska, MSc, DMV\nPhD [epidemiology student]\nCIRAD (Agricultural Research for Development) UMR, CMAEE (Control of exotic and emerging animal diseases)\nTA A-15/B Bureau 219 Campus international de Baillarguet\n34398 Montpellier cedex 05\nFrance\nhttp://umr-cmaee.cirad.fr/\n<elena.arsevska@cirad.fr>\n\n[We are most grateful to Dr Arsevska for the information above in response to our request for information and for assisting us by kindly checking the accuracy of the translation of the official Macedonian news release, included in item 2 below. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 16 Jan 2015\nSource: News, Macedonia's Food and Veterinary Agency website [in Macedonian, machine trans.; summ. & edited]\nhttp://www.fva.gov.mk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=524:listeriozata-pricina-za-uginuvanjeto-na-ovcite-vo-kumanovskoto-selo-sopot&catid=34&Itemid=78&lang=mk\n\n\nLaboratory analysis of samples from the animals and feed in the sheep/goat farm in the village of [Sopot in Kumanovo district], where 175 animals died in December [2014], have confirmed listeriosis to be the cause of the reported mortality. The bacterium was detected in tissues of the dead animals and in feed samples. This confirms the initial suspicions by the competent veterinary association of Kumanovo and representatives from the Food and Veterinary Agency.\n\nThe infection was caused by contaminated silage, a common source of infection for such cases in winter and early spring. The incubation period for the disease is 2-3 weeks; unfortunately, the breeder, without being aware of the problem, continued to feed the animals with the contaminated silage up to the appearance of the clinical signs.\n\nRepresentatives of the Food and Veterinary Agency visited the farm on 15 Jan 2015, and noted the disease subsiding and no new cases appearing. Restrictions on the movements of the animals and disinfection requirements have been imposed on the affected farm. Guidelines to protect humans from infection have been issued. The measures will remain in force until expiration of the incubation period of the disease following detection of the last case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nElena Arsevska\n<elena.arsevska@cirad.fr>\n\n[A wide variety of animal species can be infected with _Listeria monocytogenes_, but clinical listeriosis is mainly a ruminant disease, with occasional sporadic cases in other species. Outbreaks in ruminants are most prevalent during spring and winter seasons. Soil contamination and ingestion of contaminated silage are the primary modes of transmission. Poor quality silage, a pH greater than 5.5 is commonly implicated, and accounts for listeriosis often being referred to as 'silage disease'. Both host management and the pathogen itself make different contributions to the occurrence of the disease.\n\nThe clinical manifestations of listeriosis in animals include rhombencephalitis (affecting the brainstem and cerebellum; or in some cases more disseminated encephalitic changes), septicaemia, and abortion, especially in sheep, goats, and cattle. During an outbreak within a flock or herd, usually only one clinical form of listeriosis is encountered. The rhombencephalitic form is referred to as 'circling disease' because of a tendency of the animal to circle in one direction, and it is the most common manifestation of the disease in ruminants. Also, it is amongst the most common causes of neurological disease in ruminants. The clinical signs include depression, anorexia, head pressing or turning of the head to one side, and unilateral cranial nerve paralysis. The latter is due to involvement of cranial nerves and their nuclei within the brainstem. Abortion is usually late term (after 7 months in cattle and 12 weeks in sheep). The septicaemic form is relatively uncommon and generally, but not invariably, occurs in the neonate. It is marked by depression, inappetence, fever, and death. In sheep, endophthalmitis (inflammation of the ocular cavities and their adjacent structures) is a typical disease sign, and may be unilateral. Rarely, mastitis (inflammation of breast tissue) of ruminants has been associated with _L. monocytogenes_ infection. Gastrointestinal infections can occasionally occur in sheep.\n\nThe post-mortem findings and histopathology in animal listeriosis depend on the clinical presentation. In the encephalitic form, the cerebrospinal fluid may be cloudy and the meningeal vessels congested. Gross lesions are generally subtle and characterised by vascular congestion and mild tan discoloration of the brainstem. On occasion, the medulla shows areas of softening (malacia) and abscessation. Characteristic histopathological changes consist of foci of intraparenchymal neutrophils and macrophages (microabscesses) in the brainstem with adjacent perivascular mononuclear cuffing. The microabscesses often affect one side more severely. More extensive malacic pathology may occur. The medulla and pons are most severely involved. In the septicaemic form, multiple foci of necrosis in the liver and, less frequently the spleen, may be noted. Aborted fetuses of ruminants show very few gross lesions, but autolysis may be present if the fetus was retained before being expelled.\n\nThose diseases affecting the nervous system such as rabies, gid (coenurosis or sturdy; invasion of the brain and spinal cord by the intermediate stage of _Taenia multiceps_), scrapie, pregnancy toxemia, and deficiency diseases in lambs such as enzootic ataxia (swayback) and polioencephalomalacia (PEM, or cerebrocortical necrosis, CCN) should be differentiated from listeriosis. Silage feeding should be discontinued if an outbreak of listeriosis is confirmed. In the case of abortion, isolation of aborting ewes and does from their offspring reduces further infection of the dam. The recommended drugs used for treatment of listeriosis include oxytetracycline, penicillin-G, and dexamethasone.\n\nListeriosis is zoonotic; affected animals may not be slaughtered for meat. They must be either treated immediately or euthanized.\n\nThe food industry and public health agencies play a pivotal role in the prevention of foodborne listeriosis by developing and implementing effective HACCP (hazard analysis and critical control points) programmes to reduce the presence of _L. monocytogenes_ at all critical points in the food production and distribution chain (from the farm to the market). Likewise, the lack of well designed and tested vaccines for animal use, means that control of listeriosis in animals is most feasible by preventing the environmental conditions that favour its presentation. There is a well established link between silage feeding and listeriosis and, as _L. monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in nature, with animals and birds acting as carriers, contamination of silage is not uncommon. Emphasis should therefore be placed on reducing the likelihood of the multiplication of the organism, which occurs more frequently at pH values greater than 5, particularly where ineffective fermentation has occurred and where there is concomitant growth of moulds. Every effort should be made to produce silage of good quality, with early cutting of grass, minimal contamination with soil or faeces, and ensuring optimal anaerobic fermentation, which will insure that the pH falls below 5.0; at that level, growth of _Listeria_ spp is inhibited. The best silage for feeding should be selected, especially in the case of sheep, discarding material that has obvious signs of contamination with mould. Material a few centimetres from the top, front and sides of an opened bale or bag, should also be discarded. Leftover silage should be removed.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. OIE terrestrial Manual 2014. chapter 2.9.7. '_Listeria monocytogenes_'. Version adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2014\nhttp://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.09.07_LISTERIA_MONO.pdf\n2. Fentahun T, Fresebehat A: Listeriosis in Small Ruminants: A Review. Advances in Biological Research. 2012; 6(6): 202-9\nhttp://idosi.org/abr/6(6)12/1.pdf\n- Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43646.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nElena Arsevska\n<elena.arsevska@cirad.fr>\n\n[A wide variety of animal species can be infected with _Listeria monocytogenes_, but clinical listeriosis is mainly a ruminant disease, with occasional sporadic cases in other species. \n\n--\nElena Arsevska, MSc, DMV\nPhD [epidemiology student]\nCIRAD France\nhttp://umr-cmaee.cirad.fr/\n<elena.arsevska@cirad.fr>\n\n[We are most grateful to Dr Arsevska for the information above in response to our request for information and for assisting us by kindly checking the accuracy of the translation of the official Macedonian news release, included in item 2 below. - Mod. \n\nThe food industry and public health agencies play a pivotal role in the prevention of foodborne listeriosis by developing and implementing effective HACCP (hazard analysis and critical control points) programmes to reduce the presence of _L. monocytogenes_ at all critical points in the food production and distribution chain (from the farm to the market). Version adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2014\nhttp://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.09.07_LISTERIA_MONO.pdf\n2. 2012; 6(6): 202-9\nhttp://idosi.org/abr/6(6)12/1.pdf\n- Mod. \n\n\nLaboratory analysis of samples from the animals and feed in the sheep/goat farm in the village of [Sopot in Kumanovo district], where 175 animals died in December [2014], have confirmed listeriosis to be the cause of the reported mortality. TA A-15/B Bureau 219 Campus international de Baillarguet\n34398 Montpellier cedex 05\n There is a well established link between silage feeding and listeriosis and, as _L. monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in nature, with animals and birds acting as carriers, contamination of silage is not uncommon. The incubation period for the disease is 2-3 weeks; unfortunately, the breeder, without being aware of the problem, continued to feed the animals with the contaminated silage up to the appearance of the clinical signs. The clinical manifestations of listeriosis in animals include rhombencephalitis (affecting the brainstem and cerebellum; or in some cases more disseminated encephalitic changes), septicaemia, and abortion, especially in sheep, goats, and cattle. \n\nThose diseases affecting the nervous system such as rabies, gid (coenurosis or sturdy; invasion of the brain and spinal cord by the intermediate stage of _Taenia multiceps_), scrapie, pregnancy toxemia, and deficiency diseases in lambs such as enzootic ataxia (swayback) and polioencephalomalacia (PEM, or cerebrocortical necrosis, CCN) should be differentiated from listeriosis. \n\nFurther reading:\n1. OIE terrestrial Manual 2014. Poor quality silage, a pH greater than 5.5 is commonly implicated, and accounts for listeriosis often being referred to as 'silage disease'. UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS, OVINE, CAPRINE - FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA (02): LISTERIOSIS CONFIRMED\n \n\nRepresentatives of the Food and Veterinary Agency visited the farm on 15 Jan 2015, and noted the disease subsiding and no new cases appearing. \n\n--\n \n\nThe post-mortem findings and histopathology in animal listeriosis depend on the clinical presentation. The rhombencephalitic form is referred to as 'circling disease' because of a tendency of the animal to circle in one direction, and it is the most common manifestation of the disease in ruminants.
