[edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Undiagnosed deaths, ovine, caprine - FYR Macedonia: RFI 20150116.3094497\n Source: News, Macedonia's Food and Veterinary Agency website [in Macedonian, machine trans.; summ. & edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-16 00:00:00", "2014-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-20 00:00:00", "2015-01-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kumanovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ph", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fentahun", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taenia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3085796", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3085796", "date": "2015-01-12 10:35:28", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, UPDATE, ALERT\n************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Jan 2015\nSource: Bakersfield Now, Eyewitness News [edited]\nhttp://www.bakersfieldnow.com/news/health/Deadly-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-local-apple-packing-plant-288119501.html\n\n\nA Kern County [California] apple-packing plant has been linked to a deadly _Listeria_ outbreak. Bidart Bros., based in Bakersfield, has recalled all of its Granny Smith and Gala apple shipments from its Shafter facility this past year [2014]. The apples can be sold under the brand names 'Big B' and 'Granny's Best,' and they can also be sold under other brand names or no brand at all. Consumers are urged to ask retailers if the apples were supplied by Bidart Bros. Friday [9 Jan 2015], the company confirmed they are closed for the season, but noted the last shipment of apples this past year was sent out on [2 Dec 2014].\n\nThe fruit has been linked to a _Listeria_ infection found in prepackaged caramel apples. The apples were coated by another company off site, but the _Listeria_ was found on the apple's production line, connecting the illness to the Bidart's Shafter plant.\n\nThe bacteria may have caused up to 6 deaths and 31 additional illnesses reported across 11 states.\n\nKern County Environmental Health director Donna Fenton warns that [listeriosis] is a very serious disease and that the apples may still be in stores. 'It can cause pregnant women to miscarry, so it's a very serious food-borne illness,' said Fenton. '_Listeria_ is a colder-loving bacteria, so it tends to be on things that you wouldn't suspect, like apples or caramel apples.'\n\nThe disease can contaminate other food in your refrigerator, so consumers who may have purchased the fruit are urged to sanitize the walls and shelves of their refrigerators, cutting boards and counter tops.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration is still gathering the list of the specific store locations the apples might have been shipped to, but Fenton confirmed the fruit was sold at various Albertsons, Stater Bros. and Sprouts grocery stores across the nation.\n\n[Byline: Kyndell Nunley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples has now involved 37 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. In addition, 2 Canadians have also developed listeriosis caused by _Listeria_ with the same genotype as one of the US outbreak strains. No illnesses were said to be associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that were not prepackaged, according to the CDC. All the companies involved obtained some of their apples from the same apple supplier headquartered in Bakersfield, California (Bidart Bros.). The news report above says that _Listeria_ has been isolated from the apple's production line at Bidart's Shafter plant. The news report does not say if the genotype of the Shafter plant's isolate matches that of the clinical isolates.\n\nShafter, with a population of 16 988 in 2010, is a city in Kern County, California, United States, and is located 18 miles (29 km) west-northwest of the city of Bakersfield (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shafter,_California). A map of California showing the location of Shafter can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Shafter,+CA/@35.4698815,-119.2021354,8z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x80ea456137d02c27:0x7dfb5ad9f7a37c73.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples has now involved 37 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. Consumers are urged to ask retailers if the apples were supplied by Bidart Bros. Friday [9 Jan 2015], the company confirmed they are closed for the season, but noted the last shipment of apples this past year was sent out on [2 Dec 2014]. LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, UPDATE, ALERT\n************************************************************************************\n No illnesses were said to be associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that were not prepackaged, according to the CDC. \n\nThe Food and Drug Administration is still gathering the list of the specific store locations the apples might have been shipped to, but Fenton confirmed the fruit was sold at various Albertsons, Stater Bros. and Sprouts grocery stores across the nation. \n\nThe fruit has been linked to a _Listeria_ infection found in prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ is a colder-loving bacteria, so it tends to be on things that you wouldn't suspect, like apples or caramel apples.' The apples were coated by another company off site, but the _Listeria_ was found on the apple's production line, connecting the illness to the Bidart's Shafter plant.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UPDATE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2941351", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2941351", "date": "2014-11-09 18:42:43", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (ILLINOIS, MICHIGAN), FATAL, SPROUTS, RECALL\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Nov 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)/Listeriosis/Outbreaks [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/bean-sprouts-11-14/index.html\n\n\nCDC recommends that consumers do not eat any products produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. Restaurants, and retailers should not sell or serve them.\n\nOn 28 Aug 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. conducted a voluntary recall of mung bean sprouts due to possible _Listeria monocytogenes_ contamination after FDA isolated the pathogen from samples as a result of a routine assignment.\n\nDuring FDA inspections of the Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. facility in August and October 2014, investigators observed unsanitary conditions, many of which were present during both inspections.\n\nWhole genome sequences of the _Listeria_ strains isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. and environmental isolates collected at the production facility were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 people who became ill from June through August 2014. These 5 ill people were reported from 2 states: Illinois (4) and Michigan (1). All ill people were hospitalized. Two deaths were reported. The 2 people interviewed reported eating bean sprouts.\n\nAlthough limited information is available about the specific sprout products that the ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. This investigation is ongoing, and new information will be provided when available.\n\nInvestigation\n-----------\nThe U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from mung bean sprouts and sprout irrigation water samples obtained during a routine assignment on 13 Aug 2014 at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. Based on this finding, FDA conducted an inspection of the facility from 12 Aug 2014, through 3 Sep 2014, and isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 25 environmental swabs obtained during the inspection. FDA also issued a report with 12 inspectional observations, citing the firm for numerous unsanitary conditions and poor equipment maintenance.\n\nOn 28 Aug 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. agreed to conduct a voluntary recall of mung bean sprouts and notified customers by telephone. Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of sprouts on 28 Aug 2014, and resumed production on 15 Sep 2014 after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was not identified in finished product. From 7-31 Oct 2014, FDA re-inspected the facility and identified _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 9 environmental swabs. FDA investigators issued another report to the firm, noting 12 inspectional observations involving unsanitary conditions and poor equipment maintenance. Nine of these observations had persisted from the previous inspection.\n\nOn 14 Oct 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of all products except mung bean and soy bean sprouts. FDA is working with the company to ensure that they do not produce sprouts until FDA has adequate assurances that this persistent and dangerous strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ is sufficiently controlled. Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) is working to embargo all product[s] at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. and the other wholesalers that presently have product. In addition, IDPH has asked local health departments to contact facilities in their jurisdictions that have received the product to have the facilities either hold the product or destroy per the CDC recommendations.\n\nFDA performed pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS) on the isolates from mung bean sprouts and environmental samples from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. to further characterize the _Listeria_ isolates. Compared with PFGE, WGS provides a clearer distinction of genetic differences among _Listeria_ isolates (strains that are highly related by WGS are more likely to have a common source).\n\nPublic health investigators used PFGE and WGS to identify cases of illness that were caused by highly related strains and therefore possibly related to products made at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. This included data from PulseNet, the national subtyping network of state and local public health laboratories, CDC, and federal food regulatory laboratories that perform molecular surveillance of foodborne infections.\n\nWhole-genome sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 ill people were found to be highly related to sequences of the _Listeria_ strain isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. These ill people have been reported from 2 states: Illinois (4) and Michigan (1). They became ill from June through August 2014. All 5 people were hospitalized, and 2 deaths were reported. Two of the 5 people were interviewed, and both reported consuming bean sprouts in the month before becoming ill.\n\nThe high degree of genetic similarity between isolates from ill people and from mung bean sprouts and environmental samples collected at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. shows that the food was contaminated with a strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that can cause serious illness. Although limited information is available about the specific sprout products that the ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc.\n\nCDC, the states involved, and FDA continue to work closely on this ongoing investigation, and new information will be provided when available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that _Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from mung bean sprouts and sprout irrigation water on 13 Aug 2014 at Wholesome Soy Products; and the company ceased production and recalled mung bean sprouts on 28 Aug 2014. The company resumed production on 15 Sep 2014 after _L. monocytogenes_ was not identified in finished product. However, from 7-31 Oct 2014, on re-inspection of the facility by the FDA, _L. monocytogenes_ was again identified in 9 environmental swabs, but the news report above then says, 'On 14 Oct 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of all products except mung bean and soy bean sprouts.' So, potentially contaminated sprouts may again be available in stores. Clarification on this matter would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _L. monocytogenes_ transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nListeriosis was added to the list of nationally notifiable diseases in 2001. Almost all reported cases of listeriosis have invasive infection in which the bacteria spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nThe average annual incidence of invasive listeriosis in the United States was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population for 2009-2011, with a case-fatality rate (CFR) (deaths and fetal losses) of 21 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w).\n\nFor a further discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail posts Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that _Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from mung bean sprouts and sprout irrigation water on 13 Aug 2014 at Wholesome Soy Products; and the company ceased production and recalled mung bean sprouts on 28 Aug 2014. \n\nWhole genome sequences of the _Listeria_ strains isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. and environmental isolates collected at the production facility were found to be highly related to sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 people who became ill from June through August 2014. However, from 7-31 Oct 2014, on re-inspection of the facility by the FDA, _L. monocytogenes_ was again identified in 9 environmental swabs, but the news report above then says, 'On 14 Oct 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of all products except mung bean and soy bean sprouts.' Although limited information is available about the specific sprout products that the ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc.\n\nCDC, the states involved, and FDA continue to work closely on this ongoing investigation, and new information will be provided when available. \n\nWhole-genome sequences of _Listeria_ strains isolated from 5 ill people were found to be highly related to sequences of the _Listeria_ strain isolated from mung bean sprouts produced by Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. Although limited information is available about the specific sprout products that the ill people consumed, the whole genome sequencing findings, together with the sprout consumption history of 2 patients and inspection findings at the firm, suggest that these illnesses could be related to products from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. The high degree of genetic similarity between isolates from ill people and from mung bean sprouts and environmental samples collected at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. shows that the food was contaminated with a strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that can cause serious illness. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from mung bean sprouts and sprout irrigation water samples obtained during a routine assignment on 13 Aug 2014 at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. \n\nFDA performed pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS) on the isolates from mung bean sprouts and environmental samples from Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. to further characterize the _Listeria_ isolates. On 28 Aug 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. conducted a voluntary recall of mung bean sprouts due to possible _Listeria monocytogenes_ contamination after FDA isolated the pathogen from samples as a result of a routine assignment. Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of sprouts on 28 Aug 2014, and resumed production on 15 Sep 2014 after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was not identified in finished product. On 14 Oct 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. ceased production of all products except mung bean and soy bean sprouts. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. Based on this finding, FDA conducted an inspection of the facility from 12 Aug 2014, through 3 Sep 2014, and isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 25 environmental swabs obtained during the inspection. Two of the 5 people were interviewed, and both reported consuming bean sprouts in the month before becoming ill.\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPublic health investigators used PFGE and WGS to identify cases of illness that were caused by highly related strains and therefore possibly related to products made at Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. On 28 Aug 2014, Wholesome Soy Products, Inc. agreed to conduct a voluntary recall of mung bean sprouts and notified customers by telephone. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). The 2 people interviewed reported eating bean sprouts.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-07-31 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-09-15 00:00:00", "2014-08-28 00:00:00", "2014-09-03 00:00:00", "2014-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MICHIGAN", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2922167", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Macedonia (02): (UM) fatal, pork meat product, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2922167", "date": "2014-11-01 21:01:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - MACEDONIA (02): (KUMANOVO), FATAL, PORK MEAT PRODUCT, UPDATE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 31 Oct 2014\nSource: Global Post [edited]\nhttp://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/xinhua-news-agency/141031/french-labs-confirm-source-listeria-outbreak-macedonia\n\n\nTwo prominent French reference laboratories have confirmed that the source of the listeriosis outbreak here was the smoked pork product 'Extra Mein,' made by a Kumanovo-based company, the Macedonian health minister said on Friday [31 Oct 2014].\n\nThe test results from the Paris-based Louis Pasteur Institute and Anses confirmed the primary findings of the source investigated by Macedonian institutions. The results will be submitted to the Macedonian Public Prosecutor's Office, where the case has already been filed.\n\n10 patients were infected with _Listeria_ bacteria in July and August [2014] in Macedonia, 5 of whom died.\n\nListeriosis is a bacterial infection commonly caused by consuming _Listeria [monocytogenes_] bacteria-contaminated food such as processed meat, unpasteurized milk and diary products, and insufficiently washed fruits and vegetables. The immunocompromised, such as the elderly, pregnant women and newborns are vulnerable to listeriosis, which can cause infections of the central nervous system (meningitis, meningoencephalitis, brain abscess, cerebritis) and bacteremia.\n\nPrevention includes washing raw food thoroughly as well as reheating leftovers or ready-to-eat foods until steaming hot.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive 20071230.4186.\n\nThere are now 10 patients involved in the Macedonian listeriosis outbreak, including 5 deaths, associated with consumption of the smoked pork product 'Extra Mein' made by a Kumanovo-based company. The above news report says that Louis Pasteur Institute and Anses confirmed this association, presumably by pulsed field gel electrophoresis of isolates of _L. monocytogenes_. However, in the prior post on this outbreak, the manufacturer of the pork meat product contended that contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occurred after the product left their facility (Listeriosis - Macedonia: (UM) fatal, pork meat product alert, recall 20140808.2670279).\n\nIn the US, _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for PFGE subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nMaps of Macedonia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/europe/Macedonian-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40862.\n\nKumanovo is a city with a population of 70 842 (in 2002) and a municipality in the Northeastern Statistical Region, one of 8 statistical regions in the Republic of Macedonia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumanovo). For a map of Macedonia showing the location of Kumanovo Municipality, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeastern_statistical_region#mediaviewer/File:Map_of_the_municipalities_of_the_Northeastern_Statistical_Region_en.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/76.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIn the US, _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for PFGE subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive 20071230.4186. However, in the prior post on this outbreak, the manufacturer of the pork meat product contended that contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occurred after the product left their facility (Listeriosis - Macedonia: (UM) fatal, pork meat product alert, recall 20140808.2670279). \n\nPrevention includes washing raw food thoroughly as well as reheating leftovers or ready-to-eat foods until steaming hot.\n\n--\n \n\nThere are now 10 patients involved in the Macedonian listeriosis outbreak, including 5 deaths, associated with consumption of the smoked pork product 'Extra Mein' made by a Kumanovo-based company.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-07-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2812994", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark (04): (SD) fatal, nosocomial, asparagus soup", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2812994", "date": "2014-09-28 19:59:57", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (04): (SYDDANMARK), FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ASPARAGUS SOUP\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 27 Sep 2014\nSource: The Local [edited]\nhttp://www.thelocal.dk/20140927/new-listeria-outbreak-traced-to-three-deaths\n\n\nThree people have died from _Listeria_-infested asparagus soup at Odense University Hospital. The deaths are a result of a new listeriosis outbreak and are not related to the one that has been traced to the deli meat rullepoelse, which has claimed 16 lives [See prior ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Denmark (03): (Copenhagen) fatal, deli meat susp, more cases 20140910.2764685].\n\n'There are 2 different outbreaks, and they are not connected. In the asparagus soup [outbreak], it is a completely different strain of _Listeria_ than in the rullepoelse outbreak. The deaths we have listed on our website are only from the rullepoelse outbreak,' Tyra Grove Krause of the Danish State Serum Institute (SSI) told Ritzau news agency.\n\nThe asparagus soup outbreak has sickened 5 patients over the past 6 months. Three of the infections proved fatal, with the most recent death in April 2014.\n\nA recent check by the Danish Food and Veterinary Service (Foedevarestyrelsen) found traces of _Listeria_ in 3 soups at Odense University Hospital and Svendborg Hospital. _Listeria_ was also found in meatballs served with the soups. The infected asparagus soup was served to patients through 21 Sep 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating foods contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. _Listeria_ can be in a variety of raw foods as well as in processed foods and foods made from unpasteurized milk. The process of making asparagus soup, if cooked at temperatures higher than 150 F (65 C), should have killed _Listeria monocytogenes_, the gram-positive bacillus that is the cause of listeriosis, in any of the soup's ingredients. However, _Listeria_ can contaminate foods after the food is cooked, and unlike many other foodborne bacteria, _Listeria_ multiply at refrigerator temperatures (between 35-38 F (2-3 C). If previously refrigerated soup had been reheated sufficiently before serving, _Listeria_ again should have been killed. The FDA recommends that soups, sauces, and gravy should be brought to a boil when reheating, and leftovers should be reheated to 165 F (74 C) (http://www.fda.gov/food/resourcesforyou/consumers/ucm079667.htm). Presumably, the asparagus soup was served cold or insufficiently reheated to hospitalized patients, many of whom were likely at high risk of developing listeriosis.\n\nOdense and Svendborg are cities on the island of Funen in the Region of Southern Denmark (Region Syddanmark) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Region_of_Southern_Denmark). Odense, with a population of 172 512 in 2014, located 45 km (28 miles) north of Svendborg, is the 3rd largest city in Denmark (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odense). Svenborg, with a population of 26 672 in 2014, is Funen's 2nd largest city (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svendborg). Odense University Hospital is said to be the largest hospital in Denmark (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odense_University_Hospital).\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no. 20071230.4186. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is an illness caused by eating foods contaminated by the bacterium, _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive bacillus. The deaths are a result of a new listeriosis outbreak and are not related to the one that has been traced to the deli meat rullepoelse, which has claimed 16 lives [See prior ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - Denmark (03): (Copenhagen) fatal, deli meat susp, more cases 20140910.2764685]. The process of making asparagus soup, if cooked at temperatures higher than 150 F (65 C), should have killed _Listeria monocytogenes_, the gram-positive bacillus that is the cause of listeriosis, in any of the soup's ingredients. LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (04): (SYDDANMARK), FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, ASPARAGUS SOUP\n***************************************************************************\n \n\nThe asparagus soup outbreak has sickened 5 patients over the past 6 months. Presumably, the asparagus soup was served cold or insufficiently reheated to hospitalized patients, many of whom were likely at high risk of developing listeriosis. In the asparagus soup [outbreak], it is a completely different strain of _Listeria_ than in the rullepoelse outbreak. The infected asparagus soup was served to patients through 21 Sep 2014. \n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-09-21 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-04-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NOSOCOMIAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3044758", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (04): fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3044758", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA 'fingerprinting' is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). [An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n< \n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available. \n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. Out of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. \n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Source: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014]. \n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. \n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes. CDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. No illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples. LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\n In Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination. The information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged. The Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples. [A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.] \n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported. \n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each. \n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2764685", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark (03): (Copenhagen) fatal, deli meat susp, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2764685", "date": "2014-09-10 20:43:19", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (03): (COPENHAGEN), FATAL, DELI MEAT SUSPECTED, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 9 Sep 2014\nSource: The Local [edited]\nhttp://www.thelocal.dk/20140909/listeria-outbreak-claims-15th-victim\n\n\nA new death [the 15th] was confirmed on Monday [8 Sep 2014], and the number of [_Listeria_] infections has now risen to 38.\n\nThe outbreak has been traced to the deli meat rullepoelse produced by the company Joern A. Rullepoelser, which has been shut down.\n\nA total of 30 products -- including variations of rullepoelse, salami and hot dogs -- were recalled.\n\nThe Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (Foedevarestrylsen) also warned on Monday [8 Sep 2014] of a listeriosis risk in halibut sold by the company Hjerting Laks that was sold in Netto, Irma and Foetex stores.\n\nThe food authorities advised that any consumers who might have halibut (hellefisk in Danish) purchased from Hjerting Laks before 1 Jun [2014] in their freezers to throw it out or return it to where it was purchased.\n\nFoedevarestrylsen was criticised for not acting quickly enough in responding to the listeriosis outbreak, with the food and agriculture minister, Dan Joergensen, saying that 'serious mistakes' took place.\n\nDespite the continuing listeria problems, and recent _Salmonella_ and MRSA scares, the government has proposed cutting food safety funding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases of listeriosis linked to Danish rullepoelse has risen from 24 to 38 and deaths from 13 to 15.\n\nThe implicated food source (rullepoelse) was only recalled on Mon 11 Aug 2014. Because some product may still be in consumers' refrigerators and because of the long incubation period of up to 2 months, additional cases can be expected. A warning about the Danish _Listeria_-contaminated rullepoelse has also appeared directed at Norwegian consumers since Danish rullepoelse is eaten in other Scandinavian countries.\n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). A similar 'rolled sausage' is also eaten in Norway and Sweden.\n\nThe news report says that a meat product made by Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S has been proven to be the main source of infection but does not say how this was proven. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the Danish cases with each other and with isolates from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nThe news report above also mentions a listeriosis risk from halibut sold by the company Hjerting Laks that was sold in Netto, Irma and Foetex stores, but mentions no cases of listeriosis associated with this contaminated food.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no. 20071230.4186. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12054.]", "summary": "\n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases of listeriosis linked to Danish rullepoelse has risen from 24 to 38 and deaths from 13 to 15. \n\nThe Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (Foedevarestrylsen) also warned on Monday [8 Sep 2014] of a listeriosis risk in halibut sold by the company Hjerting Laks that was sold in Netto, Irma and Foetex stores. The news report above also mentions a listeriosis risk from halibut sold by the company Hjerting Laks that was sold in Netto, Irma and Foetex stores, but mentions no cases of listeriosis associated with this contaminated food. \n\nThe food authorities advised that any consumers who might have halibut (hellefisk in Danish) purchased from Hjerting Laks before 1 Jun [2014] in their freezers to throw it out or return it to where it was purchased. \n\nFoedevarestrylsen was criticised for not acting quickly enough in responding to the listeriosis outbreak, with the food and agriculture minister, Dan Joergensen, saying that 'serious mistakes' took place. LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (03): (COPENHAGEN), FATAL, DELI MEAT SUSPECTED, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\n \n\nThe news report says that a meat product made by Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S has been proven to be the main source of infection but does not say how this was proven.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-09-08 00:00:00", "2014-08-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Irma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2708272", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark (02): (KO) fatal, deli meat susp. more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2708272", "date": "2014-08-20 21:13:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (02): (COPENHAGEN), FATAL, DELI MEAT SUSPECTED, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Aug 2014\nSource: Shanghai Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=236203\n\n\nAnother person has died after being infected with _Listeria_ bacteria from a Danish sausage company, bringing the death toll of the disease outbreak to 13, the State Serum Institute (SSI) said Tuesday [19 Aug 2014]. A total of 24 people have so far been confirmed with the infection, as 3 new cases were reported on Monday [18 Aug 2014], according to the SSI.\n\nA Hedehusene-based sausage company, Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S, has proved to be the main source of infection. The company has been shut down, and all its products were withdrawn from shelves.\n\nOn Sunday [17 Aug 2014], the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration submitted a report on its handling of the listeriosis outbreak, saying it did not respond quickly enough in tracing the problem. 'When it is proved there is a direct connection between the food products and deaths, the authorities should immediately launch a thorough investigation of the specific company,' Minister for food, agriculture and fishery Dan Joergensen said in a press release. 'That hasn't happened quickly enough, which is lamentable,' said the minister.\n\nThe head of the emergency management unit of the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration was removed from his post.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases of listeriosis linked to Danish rullepoelse has risen from 20 to 24 and deaths from 12 to 13.\n\nThe implicated food source (rullepoelse) was only recalled on Mon 11 Aug 2014. Because some product may still be in consumers' refrigerators and the long incubation period of up to 2 months, additional cases can be expected. A warning about the Danish _Listeria_-contaminated rullepoelse has also appeared directed at Norwegian consumers since Danish rullepoelse is eaten in other Scandinavian countries.\n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon (Danish, sky) and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). A similar 'rolled sausage' is also eaten in Norway and Sweden.\n\nThe news report says that a meat product made by Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S has been proven to be the main source of infection but does not say how this was proven. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the Danish cases with each other and with isolates from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no 20071230.4186. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12054.]", "summary": "\n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon (Danish, sky) and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases of listeriosis linked to Danish rullepoelse has risen from 20 to 24 and deaths from 12 to 13. \n\nThe head of the emergency management unit of the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration was removed from his post.\n\n--\n LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK (02): (COPENHAGEN), FATAL, DELI MEAT SUSPECTED, MORE CASES\n********************************************************************************\n When it is proved there is a direct connection between the food products and deaths, the authorities should immediately launch a thorough investigation of the specific company,' Minister for food, agriculture and fishery Dan Joergensen said in a press release. ' \n\nA Hedehusene-based sausage company, Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S, has proved to be the main source of infection. \n\nThe news report says that a meat product made by Joern A. Rullepoelser A/S has been proven to be the main source of infection but does not say how this was proven.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2014-08-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3068902", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3068902", "date": "2015-01-03 12:39:28", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, UPDATE, ALERT\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 31 Dec 2014\nSource: The Columbian, Seattle Times report [edited]\nhttp://www.columbian.com/news/2014/dec/31/listeria-tainted-apples-sicken-at-least-32-6-die/\n\n\nAt least 32 people in the US have been sickened by _Listeria_-tainted caramel apples -- including 6 who have died -- even as firms nationwide continue to recall the treats sold this fall, health officials said Wednesday [31 Dec 2014].\n\nOfficials with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] updated their figures in the growing outbreak, reporting that 31 of 32 victims have been hospitalized in 11 states. In addition, 2 cases related to the outbreak have been reported by the Public Health Agency of Canada.\n\nOf the 6 deaths tied to the outbreak, all of the victims were confirmed to be infected with the outbreak strain of bacteria, but [listeriosis] contributed directly to only 3 of the deaths. It's unclear whether [listeriosis] contributed to 2 others, and 1 death wasn't related to the infection, health officials said.\n\nThe CDC continues to warn consumers not to eat any prepackaged caramel apples while the investigation into the [listeriosis] outbreak continues. That includes plain caramel apples and those decorated with nuts, sprinkles or chocolate.\n\n3 firms have issued voluntary recalls for commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples in connection with the outbreak that led to illnesses reported from [17 Oct to 11 Dec 2014]. Happy Apples of Washington, Missouri, issued a recall on [24 Dec 2014] for packaged apples sold at grocery stores, discount stores and club stores in more than 30 states. California Snack Foods of South El Monte, California, issued a recall [27 Dec 2014], for all styles of its Karm'l Dapples products sold in Arizona, California, Nevada, Texas and Utah. And Merb's Candies of St. Louis, Missouri, issued a recall of its Bionic Apples and Double Dipped Apples sold in St. Louis stores and by mail order nationwide.\n\nAll of the retailers said they were issuing recalls after learning that Bidart Bros., a Bakersfield, California, apple producer, had voluntarily recalled fresh apples because they may be contaminated with _Listeria_. In a letter to suppliers dated [22 Dec 2014], company president Leonard Bidart said the firm had consulted with the federal Food and Drug Administration [FDA] and California public health officials.\n\n'Out of an abundance of caution tempered by our deep concern for public safety, we are instituting a recall of the processor apples we shipped to you during the 2014 season,' the letter said. However, no formal notification of the Bidart recall has been issued by the FDA or the California Department of Public Health.\n\nIn the Northwest, the Bidart move forced the recall of about 220 cases of prepackaged caramel apples distributed by Pacific Coast Fruit Company, said Ted Hendryx, executive vice president.\n\nCaramel apples are typically a fall treat and the products should not remain on retail store shelves, health officials said.\n\n_Listeria_ bacteria can cause life-threatening infections in young children, pregnant women, the elderly and those with compromised immune systems. Symptoms can show up weeks or even months after exposure.\n\n[Byline: Jonel Aleccia]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 31 Dec 2014\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Food/RecallsOutbreaksEmergencies/Outbreaks/ucm427573.htm\n\n\nThe FDA, CDC and state and local officials are investigating an outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially-produced, prepackaged whole caramel apples. [Listeriosis is caused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_.]\n\nAccording to the CDC, as of [30 Dec 2014], 32 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 11 states. The CDC reports that 31 ill people have been hospitalized. 6 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to 3 of these deaths and it is unclear whether it contributed to 2 others. The 6th death was unrelated to listeriosis. 10 illnesses were pregnancy-related, with 1 illness resulting in a fetal loss.\n\nThe CDC reports that 23 of the 26 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially-produced, prepackaged whole caramel apples. To date, caramel apple brands named in interviews include Happy Apple, Carnival and Merb's Candies. However, the investigation is ongoing and other brands may be identified. No illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, and no illnesses have been linked to caramel candy.\n\nOn [18 Dec 2014], the Minnesota Department of Health reported 4 illnesses. The Minnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations.\n\n3 companies have issued voluntary recalls of caramel apples because they have the potential to be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_. These companies are: Happy Apple Company of Washington, Missouri; California Snack Foods, of El Monte, California; [and] Merb's Candies of St. Louis, Missouri. Each company reported receiving notice from Bidart Bros., an apple supplier headquartered in Bakersfield, California, that there may be a connection between the listeriosis outbreak and the apples supplied to them by Bidart Bros.\n\nThe FDA has traced the distribution of the caramel apples eaten by 8 ill people involved in the outbreak. Although the Happy Apple Company and Merb's Candies receive apples from other growers, the FDA's ongoing traceback investigation has confirmed that Bidart Bros. is the only apple grower that supplied apples to both companies.\n\nOn [22 Dec 2014], the FDA briefed Bidart Bros. on the status of the investigation. On [22 Dec 2014], Bidart Bros. issued a recall of Granny Smith apples it sold in 2014 to those customers known to produce caramel apples. Then, on [24 Dec 2014], Bidart Bros. notified all customers receiving Granny Smith apples in 2014 to recall those apples if they had been used to make caramel apples.\n\nThe FDA is continuing its investigation into whether there are common sources of caramel, caramel ingredients, sticks, or packaging to these caramel apple makers. Additionally, FDA and state investigators are working to identify the source of the contamination and determine what products may be contaminated. New information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples has now involved 32 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. In addition, 2 Canadians have also developed listeriosis caused by _Listeria_ with the same genotype as one of the US outbreak strains. No illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, according to the CDC. All the companies involved obtained some of their apples from the same apple supplier headquartered in Bakersfield, California (Bidart Bros.). (However, the news reports above do not say if _Listeria_ has been isolated from any Bidart apples.) The FDA is continuing its investigation into whether there are additional common sources of caramel, caramel ingredients, sticks, or packaging material that may be contaminated with _Listeria_.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nIn July 2014, peaches & plums were recalled from stores nationwide in the USA because of _Listeria_ contamination http://edition.cnn.com/2014/07/22/health/costco-fruit-recall/index.html. The likelihood is that the apples used (from California) were contaminated by soil containing _Listeria_ and not properly washed before caramel was added. _Listeria_ can grow at refrigerator temperatures.\n\nPhoto of caramel apples (toffee-apples): http://grahamsfinec979.corecommerce.com/images/products/218.jpg. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Then, on [24 Dec 2014], Bidart Bros. notified all customers receiving Granny Smith apples in 2014 to recall those apples if they had been used to make caramel apples. \n\n3 firms have issued voluntary recalls for commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples in connection with the outbreak that led to illnesses reported from [17 Oct to 11 Dec 2014]. No illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, and no illnesses have been linked to caramel candy.\n\n On [22 Dec 2014], Bidart Bros. issued a recall of Granny Smith apples it sold in 2014 to those customers known to produce caramel apples. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak caused by 2 genotypically distinct strains of _Listeria_ linked to eating caramel apples has now involved 32 cases, including 6 deaths, in 11 US states. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n At least 32 people in the US have been sickened by _Listeria_-tainted caramel apples -- including 6 who have died -- even as firms nationwide continue to recall the treats sold this fall, health officials said Wednesday [31 Dec 2014]. No illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, according to the CDC. \n\nThe FDA is continuing its investigation into whether there are common sources of caramel, caramel ingredients, sticks, or packaging to these caramel apple makers. Happy Apples of Washington, Missouri, issued a recall on [24 Dec 2014] for packaged apples sold at grocery stores, discount stores and club stores in more than 30 states. The Minnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. \n\nThe CDC continues to warn consumers not to eat any prepackaged caramel apples while the investigation into the [listeriosis] outbreak continues. \n\n3 companies have issued voluntary recalls of caramel apples because they have the potential to be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_. The FDA, CDC and state and local officials are investigating an outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially-produced, prepackaged whole caramel apples. Each company reported receiving notice from Bidart Bros., an apple supplier headquartered in Bakersfield, California, that there may be a connection between the listeriosis outbreak and the apples supplied to them by Bidart Bros.\n\n \n\n'Out of an abundance of caution tempered by our deep concern for public safety, we are instituting a recall of the processor apples we shipped to you during the 2014 season,' the letter said. And Merb's Candies of St. Louis, Missouri, issued a recall of its Bionic Apples and Double Dipped Apples sold in St. Louis stores and by mail order nationwide. Although the Happy Apple Company and Merb's Candies receive apples from other growers, the FDA's ongoing traceback investigation has confirmed that Bidart Bros. is the only apple grower that supplied apples to both companies. In the Northwest, the Bidart move forced the recall of about 220 cases of prepackaged caramel apples distributed by Pacific Coast Fruit Company, said Ted Hendryx, executive vice president. The CDC reports that 23 of the 26 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially-produced, prepackaged whole caramel apples. \n\nOf the 6 deaths tied to the outbreak, all of the victims were confirmed to be infected with the outbreak strain of bacteria, but [listeriosis] contributed directly to only 3 of the deaths. Photo of caramel apples (toffee-apples): http://grahamsfinec979.corecommerce.com/images/products/218.jpg. - Mod. LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, UPDATE, ALERT\n Caramel apples are typically a fall treat and the products should not remain on retail store shelves, health officials said. The FDA has traced the distribution of the caramel apples eaten by 8 ill people involved in the outbreak. The FDA is continuing its investigation into whether there are additional common sources of caramel, caramel ingredients, sticks, or packaging material that may be contaminated with _Listeria_. \n\nOfficials with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] updated their figures in the growing outbreak, reporting that 31 of 32 victims have been hospitalized in 11 states. The likelihood is that the apples used (from California) were contaminated by soil containing _Listeria_ and not properly washed before caramel was added. That includes plain caramel apples and those decorated with nuts, sprinkles or chocolate. According to the CDC, as of [30 Dec 2014], 32 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 11 states. All of the retailers said they were issuing recalls after learning that Bidart Bros., a Bakersfield, California, apple producer, had voluntarily recalled fresh apples because they may be contaminated with _Listeria_. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Date: Wed 31 Dec 2014\n In addition, 2 cases related to the outbreak have been reported by the Public Health Agency of Canada.
