JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-07-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Monte", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Louis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UPDATE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3060474", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (05): (WA) ice cream, gelato, custard, sorbet, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3060474", "date": "2014-12-29 20:04:53", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): (WASHINGTON), ICE CREAM, GELATO, CUSTARD AND SORBET, ALERT\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 24 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2014/12/ice-cream-recalled-for-possible-listeria-contamination/#.VKFR_rACA\n\n\n2 Washington State men in their 50s were recently hospitalized in connection with recalled Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream, according to the Washington State Department of Health. The men, who both live in King County, are now out of the hospital and recovering, said department spokesman Donn Moyer, who added that both have underlying health conditions.\n\nOne became ill at the end of November [2014], and the other the 1st week of December 2014, he said. 'They were ill; the disease investigation started; they started noticing some similarities, and traced it back to this product,' Moyer said.\n\nResults from lab tests done using pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) confirmed one man's case as listeriosis, while the other is a probable case, but Moyer noted they are 'epidemiologically linked.'\n\nThere was also a positive result for the same strain of _Listeria_ in the now-recalled product, he said. Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream Inc. of Snohomish, WA has issued a voluntary recall of all ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet for all flavors and container sizes produced on or after 1 Jan 2014 until 15 Dec 2014 because these products have the potential to be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nThe products are labeled Snoqualmie Ice Cream, Snoqualmie Gelato, Snoqualmie Custard, Snoqualmie Sorbet or Emerald & Spruce Ice Cream or Top Pot Hand Forged Ice Cream and have a production date code located on the bottom of the container. The date codes included either end in '4', e.g., XXX4 (pints and cups) or are listed by date: 'Jan. 1, 2014, through Dec. 15, 2014,' (trays & tubs).\n\nThe ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet were distributed in Arizona, Idaho, California, Oregon and Washington, and may have been further distributed and sold in various retail outlets in Alaska, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Texas, Utah and Wyoming.\n\nThe recall was initiated based on the confirmation of a positive result of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in the samples collected within the production facility and analyzed by the Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA). The company is working with FDA and WSDA to investigate the root cause.\n\nCustomers who have purchased the affected product should dispose of it or return it to the place of purchase, where they will receive a refund.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is an organism that can cause serious and sometimes fatal infections in young children, frail or elderly people, and others with weakened immune systems. Although healthy individuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhea, _Listeria_ infection can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant women.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 29 Dec 2014\nSource: Science Times [edited]\nhttp://www.sciencetimes.com/articles/2213/20141226/first-caramel-apples-now-the-ice-cream-may-be-infected-listeria-epidemic.htm\n\n\nIn a recent international outbreak of a bacterial infection [listeriosis], health officials from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have investigated recent deaths and sourced the outbreak back to potentially bad batches of pre-made caramel apples sold in retail stores such as Safeway over the past few months. But now, as the holiday season is in full bloom and more cases are popping up day after day, CDC officials are finding other sources, as well, and are now putting a warning on ice cream potentially infected in some areas of the nation.\n\nCaused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_, listeriosis is a disease that can cause gastrointestinal distress and flu-like symptoms in individuals, with a particular ability for harming people whose immune systems are stressed or compromised, including the elderly and pregnant women. In a press release issued this morning [29 Dec 2014], the CDC warns all consumers to avoid prepackaged caramel apples while they investigate the outbreak and source the cause of the infection in a joint collaboration alongside the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and state health organizations.\n\nThe newest warnings have arisen out of 2 new cases from Washington state, where 2 gentlemen in their 50s, who also happen to be residents of King County, were recently hospitalized after consuming ice cream from the local Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream shop. Washington State Department of Health officials confirmed that the 2 men had in fact been infected with _Listeria_, but they are also facing complications of previously underlying medical issues as well.\n\n'They were ill,' Washington Department of Health spokesperson Donn Moyer says. '[As] the disease investigation started, they started noticing some similarities and traced it back to this product.'\n\nWhile the current epidemic could very possibly be attributed to other sources, including a significant contribution from caramel apples recently recalled, the CDC is convinced that Snoqualmie's gourmet ice cream may be a source of _Listeria_ to more than 5 states currently infected, including: Arizona, Oregon, Washington, Idaho and California.\n\nCompany officials with Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream have declined to comment, though they did issue a voluntary recall on Tue 23 Dec 2014 for all flavors and sizes of their ice creams, custards, gelatos and sorbet manufactured and distributed from 15 Dec 2014 to 1 Jan 2015 to be sure that consumers need not fear eating their products in the near future.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak that has affected 2 people in Washington State are linked by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis genotyping with contaminated ice cream products manufactured by Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream, but the Snoqualmie ice creams, custards, gelatos and sorbet have been distributed and sold in various retail outlets in multiple other states in addition to Washington State (Arizona, Idaho, California, Oregon, as well as Alaska, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Texas, Utah and Wyoming). Cases of listeriosis caused by this _Listeria_ strain may be anticipated.\n\nThe 2nd news report intimates that the Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream outbreak may be connected with the listeriosis/caramel apple outbreak occurring in multiple US states and Canada, but the caramel apple outbreak is associated with 2 genotypically distinct _Listeria_ strains. The news reports above give no indication that the _Listeria_ strain causing the Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream outbreak and those causing the caramel apple outbreak are genetically closely related.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak that has affected 2 people in Washington State are linked by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis genotyping with contaminated ice cream products manufactured by Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream, but the Snoqualmie ice creams, custards, gelatos and sorbet have been distributed and sold in various retail outlets in multiple other states in addition to Washington State (Arizona, Idaho, California, Oregon, as well as Alaska, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Texas, Utah and Wyoming). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nCompany officials with Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream have declined to comment, though they did issue a voluntary recall on Tue 23 Dec 2014 for all flavors and sizes of their ice creams, custards, gelatos and sorbet manufactured and distributed from 15 Dec 2014 to 1 Jan 2015 to be sure that consumers need not fear eating their products in the near future. Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream Inc. of Snohomish, WA has issued a voluntary recall of all ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet for all flavors and container sizes produced on or after 1 Jan 2014 until 15 Dec 2014 because these products have the potential to be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_. The 2nd news report intimates that the Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream outbreak may be connected with the listeriosis/caramel apple outbreak occurring in multiple US states and Canada, but the caramel apple outbreak is associated with 2 genotypically distinct _Listeria_ strains. \n\nThe newest warnings have arisen out of 2 new cases from Washington state, where 2 gentlemen in their 50s, who also happen to be residents of King County, were recently hospitalized after consuming ice cream from the local Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream shop. \n\nWhile the current epidemic could very possibly be attributed to other sources, including a significant contribution from caramel apples recently recalled, the CDC is convinced that Snoqualmie's gourmet ice cream may be a source of _Listeria_ to more than 5 states currently infected, including: Arizona, Oregon, Washington, Idaho and California. In a recent international outbreak of a bacterial infection [listeriosis], health officials from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have investigated recent deaths and sourced the outbreak back to potentially bad batches of pre-made caramel apples sold in retail stores such as Safeway over the past few months. LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): (WASHINGTON), ICE CREAM, GELATO, CUSTARD AND SORBET, ALERT\n**********************************************************************************\n The products are labeled Snoqualmie Ice Cream, Snoqualmie Gelato, Snoqualmie Custard, Snoqualmie Sorbet or Emerald & Spruce Ice Cream or Top Pot Hand Forged Ice Cream and have a production date code located on the bottom of the container. In a press release issued this morning [29 Dec 2014], the CDC warns all consumers to avoid prepackaged caramel apples while they investigate the outbreak and source the cause of the infection in a joint collaboration alongside the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and state health organizations. \n\nThe ice cream, gelato, custard and sorbet were distributed in Arizona, Idaho, California, Oregon and Washington, and may have been further distributed and sold in various retail outlets in Alaska, Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Texas, Utah and Wyoming. The news reports above give no indication that the _Listeria_ strain causing the Snoqualmie Gourmet Ice Cream outbreak and those causing the caramel apple outbreak are genetically closely related. \n\nOne became ill at the end of November [2014], and the other the 1st week of December 2014, he said. ' Caused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_, listeriosis is a disease that can cause gastrointestinal distress and flu-like symptoms in individuals, with a particular ability for harming people whose immune systems are stressed or compromised, including the elderly and pregnant women.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-01-01 00:00:00", "2014-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:50", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2015-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "King County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Snohomish", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2686589", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark: (Copenhagen) fatal, deli meat susp, recall, Norway Alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2686589", "date": "2014-08-13 16:24:51", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK: (COPENHAGEN) FATAL, DELI MEAT SUSPECTED, RECALL, NORWAY ALERT\n************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] [2] Denmark\n[3] Norway alert\n\n******\n[1] Denmark\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28761463\n\n\nDanish officials say they suspect that sausage contaminated with _Listeria [monocytogenes]_ bacteria has killed at least 12 people.\n\nThe infection is thought to have come from pork sausages called rullepoelse [rolled sausage], made by a firm in Hedehusene, near the capital Copenhagen. The product has now been withdrawn from sale.\n\nSo far 8 other people have tested positive for _Listeria_. Deaths occur mostly among people who are already in a weak condition. The outbreak began last September [2013]. Denmark's state health agency SSI says the outbreak is believed to be under control.\n\nHealth officials are trying to determine if any of the contaminated meat was sent to schools or restaurants, or was exported.\n\nListeriosis symptoms often include fever, headache, diarrhoea, and vomiting. The incubation period can last 2 months, making it often difficult to trace the source of contamination.\n\n_Listeria_ can spread from delicatessen food even when kept cool in a refrigerator.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Denmark\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: The Copenhagen Post [edited]\nhttp://cphpost.dk/news/listeria-outbreak-in-denmark-has-now-claimed-12-lives-in-12-months.10469.html\n\n\nSince September last year [2013], 12 people have died of listeriosis and a further 8 have been infected after consuming some bad 'rullepoelse' sandwich meat.\n\nThe food product authorities Foedevarestyrelsen [Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fisheries] suspect that the bad meat originated from Joern A Rullepoelser in Hedehusene near Copenhagen and have closed down the producer. [The meat producer was ordered shut late Mon 11 Aug 2014, and all products recalled (http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/10-feared-dead-denmark-listeria-outbreak-24943819)].\n\nThe 20 infected patients consist of 11 women and 9 men aged 43-89 from various parts of Denmark, according to the national serum institute, Statens Seruminstitut.\n\n'From September 2013 until today [12 Aug 2014], 20 patients have been registered suffering from listeriosis, which is an aspect of the outbreak,' Statens Seruminstitut wrote in a press release.\n\n'Most cases have however occurred recently. In June, July, and August [2014], 15 cases have been registered alone.'\n\n[Byline: Christian Wenande]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Norway alert\nDate: Wed 13 Aug 2014\nSource: NTB/The Local [edited]\nhttp://www.thelocal.no/20140813/norwegians-at-risk-from-the-danish-listeria-bug\n\n\nNorwegian citizens who have bought or have meat from Denmark are being asked to search their fridges, looking for the _Listeria [monocytogenes]_ bacterium that has taken 12 lives in Denmark this week.\n\nThe Norwegian Food Safety Authority recommended on Tuesday [12 Aug 2014] consumers who have recently bought or received food from Denmark be vigilant and check their food stocks. The warning follows 20 people in Denmark falling ill from contaminated food and 12 of those victims dying.\n\nTurid Berglund, senior advisor for the Norwegian Food Safety Authority, said: 'We ask everyone who shopped for food in Denmark recently to listen out for any information from the Danish authorities. Please take a look in your fridge to see if you have any meat products bought from Denmark.\n\nThe source of contamination is thought to be a type of cold cut meat. The Danish authorities have so far not confirmed which product it is, but suspicion is directed towards head cheese or rolled sausage ('Rullepoelse'), from the company 'Joern A Rullepoelser A/S' in Hedehusene, Denmark.\n\nThe products are sold in the supermarket chains 'SuperBest', 'Eurospar', and select 'Spar' stores. Berglund said: 'If you have such a package, then we ask you to throw it in the bin. We have no reason to suspect other Danish food groceries sold in Norway.'\n\nBerglund advised it is usually people already unwell -- high-risk groups -- who are most exposed to becoming ill from _Listeria_. She still encouraged Norwegians having had their vacation in Denmark, and bought Danish meat products there, to check who produced it. The Norwegian Food Safety Authority now awaits confirmation from Denmark on where the possibly contaminated products are sold and if they could have been distributed to Norway. Danish authorities have attacked the caution coming from Norway. The Danes said they cannot connect the deaths in their country directly to _Listeria_ contamination, since the dead people already had a weakened health from other diseases.\n\nThe Danish Veterinary and Food Administration told Danish newspaper 'Politiken' that patients at hospitals and nursing homes had been served head cheese or other infected meat cuts. The officials fear also kindergartens, canteens and restaurants had bacteria-infected meat on their menus.\n\nProduction at 'Joern A Rullepoelser A/S' has been stopped and the brand has withdrawn 30 different types of cold cuts from the supermarket shelves. Palle Andersen, director of 'Joern A Rullepoelser A/S', said to NTB his firm has done everything to keep the production under control. Andersen said: 'For us it is incomprehensible that our products still contain _Listeria_ bacteria. It is even more difficult to relate to the fact that people became sick or died as a consequence of it.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak is said to be ongoing for the past year, although most cases (15 of the 20 cases) occurred only recently in June, July, and August 2014. Apparently the implicated food source (rullepoelse) was being sold for this entire time, only being recalled on Mon 11 Aug 2014. Some product may still be in consumers' refrigerators. A warning about the Danish _Listeria_-contaminated rullepoelse has also appeared directed at Norwegian consumers; see item [3] above.\n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon (Danish, sky) and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). A similar 'rolled sausage' is also eaten in Norway and Sweden.\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the Danish cases with each other and with isolates from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no 20071230.4186. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12054.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRullepoelse, meaning 'rolled sausage' in Danish, is a piece of pork belly (also can be made with beef flank or lamb) that is flattened out and spread with herbs and seasoning (salt, pepper, allspice), chopped onions and in some variants also parsley, then rolled up, placed in a brine for a number of days and then placed in a special press, cooled and sliced thinly as a cold cut for the Danish open-faced sandwich, smoerrebroed; usually garnished with a thick slice of gelatinized bouillon (Danish, sky) and rings of raw onion (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiced_meat_roll). \n\n[Byline: Christian Wenande]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This listeriosis outbreak is said to be ongoing for the past year, although most cases (15 of the 20 cases) occurred only recently in June, July, and August 2014. [1] [2] Denmark\n [3] Norway alert\n The Danish authorities have so far not confirmed which product it is, but suspicion is directed towards head cheese or rolled sausage ('Rullepoelse'), from the company 'Joern A Rullepoelser A/S' in Hedehusene, Denmark. \n\n'From September 2013 [1] Denmark\n In this posting:\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2014-08-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hedehusene", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berglund", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2670279", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Macedonia: (UM) fatal, pork meat product alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2670279", "date": "2014-08-08 23:21:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - MACEDONIA: (KUMANOVO) FATAL, PORK MEAT PRODUCT ALERT, RECALL\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2014\nSource: Focus News Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.focus-fen.net/news/2014/08/07/344928/utrinski-vesnik-macedonia-source-of-listeria-bacteria-found.html\n\n\n[The] source of _Listeria_ bacteria [has been] found. Smoked blade shoulder pork produced by a firm called 'Ekstra Mein' in Kumanovo [Macedonia] is most probably the source of _Listeria_ bacteria in Macedonia, which infected 8 people, 4 of whom died, the Macedonian online news edition Utrinski Vesnik reported.\n\nThe contagious diseases commission with the ministry of health said the _Listeria_ found were of the same prototype the 8 people were infected with. Yesterday [6 Aug 2014] it was announced that a 5th person had died of listeriosis in Macedonia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2014\nSource: Republika [summ., edited]\nhttp://english.republika.mk/?p=126479\n\n\nA sample of smoked pork neck slices, product of Kumanovo company 'Extra Mein', has tested positive for the presence of _Listeria_ bacteria, which is a 98 percent match with the bacteria genotype found in 8 patients in Macedonia, 4 of whom have died.\n\nThis is a serious direction for locating the source of the disease. Relevant institutions should now make epidemiological tests and take further measures for following the chain of the disease outbreak, Zvonko Milenkovic, chair of the Commission for Infectious Disease at the Ministry of Health, told reporters on Wednesday [6 Aug 2014].\n\nDirector of the Food and Veterinary Dejan Runtevski said all of the smoked pork neck slices products would be withdrawn from retail sale by the end of the day. An order has been also issued for putting the production on hold, which will enable testing of samples taken from the working places, machines, and anywhere that this bacterium may be present, Runtevski said. All products that are to be distributed to markets will be also tested, he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2014\nSource: Republika [edited]\nhttp://english.republika.mk/?p=126524\n\n\nPotentially _Listeria_ contaminated products of 'Ekstra Mein' meat industry have been recalled Wednesday [6 Aug 2014], after Health Ministry and Food and Veterinary Agency detected _Listeria_ presence in smoked pork neck slices.\n\nMeanwhile, Food and Veterinary Agency recommends for citizens to stop consuming Ekstra Mein's product 'smoked pork neck slices', lots 07632 and 07633, produced at 21.07.2014 and best before 04.09.2014.\n\nThe Food and Veterinary Agency is working toward detection of the _Listeria_ source, conducting further tests and analyses.\n\nAs of 30 Jul 2014, the Agency implements extremely strict control of all lots of animal source food to prevent, decrease, and eliminate the risk of _Listeria_ [contamination].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2014\nSource: Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.mk/articles/8098/Ekstra+Mein+No+Listeria+at+Our+Premises,+We+Will+Ask+For+Supernalysis%22\n\n\n[Telegraf.mk reports that in response to findings that their product vacuum pork neck, is the cause of the listeriosis that infected 9 people and killed 4 of them, the company 'Ekstra Mein' from Kumanovo, said all their products, including the sliced pork neck, are thermally treated at a temperature of 73-79 deg C [163.4-174.2 deg F], which guarantees destruction of the bacteria _Listeria_.]\n\nThe company claims that since the beginning of the year [2014], according to a regular plan for sampling, 158 samples were taken from 112 products and swabs (69 of desktops and machines and 43 of workers). All obtained results were negative to the presence of any bacteria.\n\n'It is impossible for thermally unprocessed product to exit our company. All products, including the sliced pork neck are thermally treated at a temperature of 73-79 deg C [163.4-174.2 deg F], which guarantees destruction of the bacteria _Listeria_. Additionally, the company is subject to constant quality controls of the products. We have a regular plan of test sampling of the finished product in accordance with legal regulations, a regular plan for taking swabs, as well as our own control system using a device that detects the presence of organic matter. The 3 extraordinary controls in our factory in the past 10 days by the Food and Veterinary Agency and the Ministry of Health of the overall HACCP [Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points]-documentation and hygiene-technical norms at the facility showed no irregularities. All samples and swabs taken from 'Ekstra Mein' were negative,' the statement said.\n\nThe company will require superanalysis of this product (for the isolate as well as the typization) from the Food and Veterinary Agency, which should be made in world-renowned institution.\n\n'Ekstra Mein' management also [points out] the fact that the sample with bacteria was found in products in retail shops, so the company cannot guarantee how the products were kept, if loss of vacuum was possible and, if that was the case, whether they came in contact with other products that contain bacteria.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no 20071230.4186.\n\nIn the US, _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (such as amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nPresumably, what the 1st news report refers to as the 'prototype' may be the molecular pattern found on PFGE of _L. monocytogenes_ strains. If so, the news report is saying that all 8 patients had the same 'prototype' (that is, PFGE subtype), suggesting a common source, and the 'prototype' of the strains isolated from the 8 patients is the same as the 'prototype' of the strain isolated from the suspected food source (smoked pork). However, the manufacturer of the pork meat product contends that contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occurred after the product left their facility.\n\nMaps of Macedonia can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/europe/Macedonian-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40862.\n\nKumanovo is a city, with a population of 70 842 in 2002, and municipality in the Northeastern Statistical Region, 1 of 8 statistical regions in the Republic of Macedonia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumanovo). For a map of Macedonia showing the location of Kumanovo Municipality, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeastern_statistical_region#mediaviewer/File:Map_of_the_municipalities_of_the_Northeastern_Statistical_Region_en.svg. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [Telegraf.mk reports that in response to findings that their product vacuum pork neck, is the cause of the listeriosis that infected 9 people and killed 4 of them, the company 'Ekstra Mein' from Kumanovo, said all their products, including the sliced pork neck, are thermally treated at a temperature of 73-79 deg C [163.4-174.2 deg F], which guarantees destruction of the bacteria _Listeria_.] \n\n'Ekstra Mein' management also [points out] the fact that the sample with bacteria was found in products in retail shops, so the company cannot guarantee how the products were kept, if loss of vacuum was possible and, if that was the case, whether they came in contact with other products that contain bacteria. A sample of smoked pork neck slices, product of Kumanovo company 'Extra Mein', has tested positive for the presence of _Listeria_ bacteria, which is a 98 percent match with the bacteria genotype found in 8 patients in Macedonia, 4 of whom have died. LISTERIOSIS - MACEDONIA: (KUMANOVO) FATAL, PORK MEAT PRODUCT ALERT, RECALL\n**************************************************************************\n If so, the news report is saying that all 8 patients had the same 'prototype' (that is, PFGE subtype), suggesting a common source, and the 'prototype' of the strains isolated from the 8 patients is the same as the 'prototype' of the strain isolated from the suspected food source (smoked pork). \n\nThe company claims that since the beginning of the year [2014], according to a regular plan for sampling, 158 samples were taken from 112 products and swabs (69 of desktops and machines and 43 of workers). \n\nDirector of the Food and Veterinary Dejan Runtevski said all of the smoked pork neck slices products would be withdrawn from retail sale by the end of the day. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< All products, including the sliced pork neck are thermally treated at a temperature of 73-79 deg C [163.4-174.2 deg F], which guarantees destruction of the bacteria _Listeria_. Potentially _Listeria_ contaminated products of 'Ekstra Mein' meat industry have been recalled Wednesday [6 Aug 2014], after Health Ministry and Food and Veterinary Agency detected _Listeria_ presence in smoked pork neck slices. Smoked blade shoulder pork produced by a firm called 'Ekstra Mein' in Kumanovo [Macedonia] is most probably the source of _Listeria_ bacteria in Macedonia, which infected 8 people, 4 of whom died, the Macedonian online news edition Utrinski Vesnik reported. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["7633-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-07-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kumanovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Macedonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2304710", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2304710", "date": "2014-02-27 22:12:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SWEDEN: DELI MEAT SUSPECTED\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: Barfblog [edited]\nhttp://barfblog.com/2014/02/listeria-cases-climb-in-sweden-outbreak-declared/\n\n\nSweden's Public Health Agency has declared a specific outbreak of listeriosis during the final 3 months of 2013, with 41 sickened compared to 25 for the same period the year before. 'There was a clear increase, which led us to suspect that this was an outbreak, and therefore we decided to investigate the matter immediately,' says Viktor Dahl with the Public Health Agency.\n\nWhile previous _Listeria_ outbreaks have largely been linked to smoked or pickled salmon, investigators suspect cold cuts in the latest increase.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although this outbreak is said to have occurred during the last 3 months of 2013, the investigation is continuing (via machine translation of the original report in Swedish that is available from the source URL). The cases in Sweden are said to have been linked to consumption of contaminated cold cuts, but we are not told about patient characteristics.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in nature and is transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection may result in diarrhea, but almost all reported cases of listeriosis have invasive infection in which the bacteria spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. People at risk of developing invasive listeriosis are newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature; e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows, or contamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other processing. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures and eaten without further cooking. A detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail archive no. 20071230.4186.\n\nIn the US, _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the Swedish cases with each other and with those of strains isolated from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/20NO.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although this outbreak is said to have occurred during the last 3 months of 2013, the investigation is continuing (via machine translation of the original report in Swedish that is available from the source URL). In the US, _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. \n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the Swedish cases with each other and with those of strains isolated from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature; e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows, or contamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other processing. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures and eaten without further cooking.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2306847", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Sweden (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2306847", "date": "2014-02-28 22:23:31", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SWEDEN (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Feb 2014\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/2014/02/27/listeriosis-in-scandinavia/\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Listeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp. 20140227.2304710\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nRates of listeriosis have been increasing in Scandinavia for over 20 years, and are currently 2- to 5-fold higher than those reported in the United States -- see graph (black arrow = USA) (1-3), http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/ListeriaSweden.png).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of Sweden, 2014. 484 pages, 137 graphs, 2,231 references Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-sweden/.\n2. Berger SA: Listeriosis: Global Status, 2014. 101 pages, 105 graphs, 746 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/.\n3. Gideon graph tool: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions.\n\nThe CDC estimates that the average annual incidence of listeriosis in the United States was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population for 2009-2011 and has remained relatively stable since 2001 (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). Almost all listeriosis occurs in persons in higher-risk groups (the elderly, pregnant women, newborns, and immunocompromised persons) and in the USA most cases of listeriosis occur in the age group over 65 years (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w).\n\nA possible reason for the higher and increasing incidence of listeriosis in Scandinavian countries includes increasingly more people at risk of invasive listeriosis in these countries, for example, an increasingly aged population. However, in Denmark at least, the incidence of listeriosis has risen substantially within the age group of over 70-year-olds, so demographic changes alone do not explain the increase (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19522).\n\nAnother possible explanation is increasing exposure to _Listeria monocytogenes_ because of increasing levels of food contamination or increased consumption of contaminated food. _L. monocytogenes_ is frequently present in raw foods of both plant and animal origin and may be also present in cooked foods if contaminated after cooking. Even if _L. monocytogenes_ is initially present at a low level in a contaminated food, because of its ability to grow during refrigerated storage, levels of contamination are likely to increase during refrigerated storage of those foods that can support the growth of the microorganism.\n\nListeriosis outbreaks have been frequently attributed to refrigerated ready-to-eat food (RTE) (such as, such as pate, cold cut meats, and fish) that is eaten without further cooking. In fact, consumer surveys from Statistics Denmark, comparing the period from 2005 to 2007 with the period from 2003 to 2005, indicate that expenditures for RTE products have increased by 87 percent for RTE meat products and by 34 percent for RTE fish products among individuals older than 60 years and living alone (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19522). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/20NO.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions. ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nRates of listeriosis have been increasing in Scandinavia for over 20 years, and are currently 2- to 5-fold higher than those reported in the United States -- see graph (black arrow = USA) (1-3), http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/ListeriaSweden.png). \n\nA possible reason for the higher and increasing incidence of listeriosis in Scandinavian countries includes increasingly more people at risk of invasive listeriosis in these countries, for example, an increasingly aged population. LISTERIOSIS - SWEDEN (02): BACKGROUND\n*************************************\n In fact, consumer surveys from Statistics Denmark, comparing the period from 2005 to 2007 with the period from 2003 to 2005, indicate that expenditures for RTE products have increased by 87 percent for RTE meat products and by 34 percent for RTE fish products among individuals older than 60 years and living alone (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19522). Almost all listeriosis occurs in persons in higher-risk groups (the elderly, pregnant women, newborns, and immunocompromised persons) and in the USA most cases of listeriosis occur in the age group over 65 years (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). \n\nAnother possible explanation is increasing exposure to _Listeria monocytogenes_ because of increasing levels of food contamination or increased consumption of contaminated food. Even if _L. monocytogenes_ is initially present at a low level in a contaminated food, because of its ability to grow during refrigerated storage, levels of contamination are likely to increase during refrigerated storage of those foods that can support the growth of the microorganism.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3055407", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3055407", "date": "2014-12-26 08:51:44", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CANADA: (ONTARIO, MANITOBA) ex USA, SUSPECTED, SAME GENOTYPE\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 23 Dec 2014\nSource: Virtual Press Office (VPO), Public Health Agency of Canada report [edited]\nhttp://www.virtualpressoffice.com/publicsiteContentFileAccess?fileContentId=1849722\n\n\nThe United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_) infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. Listeria can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThere are currently 2 cases of listeriosis in Canada with the same genetic fingerprint as seen in the US investigation (one case in Ontario, one case in Manitoba). The investigation continues to determine if these individuals consumed prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada and its federal partners, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency and Health Canada are investigating whether the products potentially linked to illnesses in the US may have been imported into Canada. As a precaution, the Public Health Agency of Canada is advising that Canadians do not eat commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US until further notice. This includes plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings. These products could have a shelf life of one month.\n\nBased on current information related to this investigation, the risk to Canadians is low. The Public Health Agency of Canada and its partners will notify Canadians of any increased risk to public health as new information becomes available.\n\nThe status of these [2 Canadian] individuals is not known at this time.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada is working with its provincial and territorial partners to determine the source of these illnesses. At this time, it is not known whether these illnesses are linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency is working closely with US officials to determine if any potentially affected product may have been distributed in Canada. If products are identified, the Agency will inform the public and ensure that they are promptly removed from the marketplace.\n\nIf you have any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US in your home, do not eat them. If you have a candy apple product and are unsure if it would qualify as a caramel apple, do not consume it. Secure the caramel apple in a plastic bag and throw it out. Then wash your hands thoroughly in warm soapy water. Securing it in a plastic bag will ensure that no animals consume the product from your garbage. Food contaminated with listeria may not look or smell spoiled but can still make you sick. If you suspect you have been ill from eating a commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apple, talk to your healthcare provider.\n\nIn the milder form of the disease [listeriosis], symptoms can start the following day after consuming a product with listeria. For the more serious form of the disease, the incubation period is generally much longer; on average about 21 days, but can be up to 70 days after exposure. Listeriosis can be treated with antibiotics, but early diagnosis is key, especially for people at high risk, such as pregnant women, older adults and people with weakened immune systems.\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada, in collaboration with federal, provincial and territorial partners, will continue to monitor for and investigate any new cases of [listeriosis] that may be related to this outbreak as part of its routine surveillance activities.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 25 Dec 2014\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2014/12/25/missouri-company-recalls-caramel-apples-that-may-be-linked-to-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA Missouri company is recalling packaged caramel apples that may be linked to a [listeriosis] outbreak that has hospitalized 29 people and killed at least 3 in 10 states. Happy Apples of Washington, Missouri, recalled caramel apples carrying a best-use date between [25 Aug 2014] and [23 Nov 2014] that were sold in grocery, discount, and club stores in packs of one, 3, 4, and 8. In a statement issued on Wednesday [24 Dec 1024], the company said an apple supplier, Bidart Brothers, had notified it that 'there may be a connection between this outbreak and the apples that they supplied' to a Happy Apples facility in California.\n\nOn Friday [19 Dec 2014], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned consumers to stop eating prepackaged caramel apples while it investigated the outbreak [due to] _Listeria monocytogenes_, a bacterium that causes the rare but sometimes fatal infection [listeriosis]. Older people, pregnant women, newborns, and people with weakened immune systems are particularly vulnerable to the pathogen. CDC said 9 of the illnesses occurred in pregnant women or newborns. 3 people have come down with meningitis.\n\nIn 2011, listeria in cantaloupes killed 33 people and sickened 147 in 28 states, according to CDC. In the current outbreak, no illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, the agency said.\n\nCDC originally linked the bacteria to 5 deaths, but the Food and Drug Administration, in an update posted on Thursday [25 Dec 2014], said only 3 deaths can be attributed to listeria. It is unclear whether a 4th death is connected to listeria, the FDA said, and the 5th was not caused by the organism.\n\nOn Monday [22 Dec 2014], Seattle food safety attorney Bill Marler filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the Safeway grocery store chain over the death of 81 year old, who, Marler stated, bought a caramel apple shortly before Halloween and died [2 Dec 2014]. Listeriosis was the cause of death, according to the statement, which cited [the patient's] family. Safeway later pulled the caramel apples from its shelves.\n\nHealth officials still have not determined the location of the listeria contamination.\n\nHappy Apples said the caramel apples were available in Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, and Wisconsin. The company ceased production of them at the end of October [2014]. They are no longer available in stores.\n\n[byline: Lenny Bernstein]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A listeriosis outbreak has involved so far at least 3 deaths and 29 illnesses in 10 US states and has now been linked to eating Happy Valley Brand Caramel Apples made by the Happy Apple Company, which has manufacturing facilities are located in Orosi, California and Union, Missouri. Happy Apple Brand Caramel Apples have been sold at multiple retail, discount, and club store locations in 31 US states.\n\nAccording to the 1st news report above, 2 Canadians have also developed listeriosis caused by listeria with the same genotype as a US outbreak strain. We are not told if the Canadian patients ate caramel apples while in the US or if contaminated caramel apples had been exported from the US and obtained locally in Canada. The recalled Happy Valley Caramel Apples were pre-packaged in clear, plastic containers, as a single, 3-, 4- or 8-pack. No illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, according to the CDC.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A listeriosis outbreak has involved so far at least 3 deaths and 29 illnesses in 10 US states and has now been linked to eating Happy Valley Brand Caramel Apples made by the Happy Apple Company, which has manufacturing facilities are located in Orosi, California and Union, Missouri. \n\nOn Friday [19 Dec 2014], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned consumers to stop eating prepackaged caramel apples while it investigated the outbreak [due to] _Listeria monocytogenes_, a bacterium that causes the rare but sometimes fatal infection [listeriosis]. In the current outbreak, no illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, the agency said. \n\n[byline: Lenny Bernstein]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Happy Apples of Washington, Missouri, recalled caramel apples carrying a best-use date between [25 Aug 2014] and [23 Nov 2014] that were sold in grocery, discount, and club stores in packs of one, 3, 4, and 8. No illnesses have been associated with uncoated apples or caramel candy, or with caramel apples that are not prepackaged, according to the CDC. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_) infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. A Missouri company is recalling packaged caramel apples that may be linked to a [listeriosis] outbreak that has hospitalized 29 people and killed at least 3 in 10 states. \n\nHappy Apples said the caramel apples were available in Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, and Wisconsin. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nIf you have any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US in your home, do not eat them. We are not told if the Canadian patients ate caramel apples while in the US or if contaminated caramel apples had been exported from the US and obtained locally in Canada. At this time, it is not known whether these illnesses are linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US. On Monday [22 Dec 2014], Seattle food safety attorney Bill Marler filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the Safeway grocery store chain over the death of 81 year old, who, Marler stated, bought a caramel apple shortly before Halloween and died [2 Dec 2014]. As a precaution, the Public Health Agency of Canada is advising that Canadians do not eat commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples imported from the US until further notice. \n\nCDC originally linked the bacteria to 5 deaths, but the Food and Drug Administration, in an update posted on Thursday [25 Dec 2014], said only 3 deaths can be attributed to listeria. Happy Apple Brand Caramel Apples have been sold at multiple retail, discount, and club store locations in 31 US states.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": "2014-12-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country":
