"unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2394195", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2394195", "date": "2014-04-10 14:36:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): 2013, FATAL, CHEESE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: fdlreporter.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.fdlreporter.com/viewart/20140408/FON03/140408008/Dodge-County-cheese-plant-cited-illness-outbreak\n\n\nAn illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says.\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. The death was in Minnesota, while illnesses from _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported in Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. All 3 had previously captured national and international awards for Crave, one of Wisconsin's most well-known cheesemakers.\n\n'Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,' CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted.\n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. But contamination can occur after pasteurization, according to government regulators. 'Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,' the CDC report said. Details of the contamination were not in the report, and Crave Brothers declined to comment.\n\nThe 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nListeria infections are among the 3 most deadly foodborne bacteria after toxoplasmosis and salmonellosis.\n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted.\n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. They ranged in age from 31 to 67 years old, according to the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nThe company has not been fined, and checks of court records haven't revealed lawsuits. Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. 'But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,' he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. \n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. \n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak. \n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). \n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. \n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. \n\n'Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,' CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_. \n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. As of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). An illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011. The 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers. Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,' the CDC report said. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. On [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. \n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. \n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted. \n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jackson KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1832515", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): (CT) ex Bosnia & Herzegovina, cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1832515", "date": "2013-07-19 10:46:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (CONNECTICUT) ex BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA, CHEESE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jul 2013\nSource: Jana Preis <jana.preis@va.gov> [edited]\n\n\nA a man in his 30s originally from Ravno, Bosnia and Herzegovina traveled with his wife and children to his home town for a family event. The man had no significant past medical history. While there, the family visited a local zoo, hiked, and visited ta cheese factory (which employs 4 people) outside Ravno. The factory uses cow and goat milk for producing cheese, and all cheese preparation is manual.\n\nTwo days after this visit, the patient started having a low grade [fever]. Five days later, upon returning to the USA to Connecticut, he presented to an emergency room with a fever of 101 F [38.3 C], significant headache, and some watery diarrhea. Because of sensitivity to light and some neck rigidity, a spinal tap was performed. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture grew _Listeria monocytogenes_. The following day, his wife was admitted with a similar clinical picture but with a less severe headache, and her CSF culture also grew _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nThe factory also reported 3 more cases of a similar disease locally over 2 weeks. Both milk sources, goat and cow, were cultured, and the goat culture was positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nCheese production was temporarily halted for 'terminal cleaning.'\n\n--\nJana Preis MD\nInfectious Diseases\nVA New York Harbor Health Care System\nBrooklyn Campus\n<jana.preis@va.gov>\n\n[The following is excerpted from ProMED report: Listeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert, archive Number: 20071230.4186 by my colleague Mod.ML:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Most human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. Contamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or following subsequent cooking or other processing.\n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures. Listeria can also survive in frozen food. Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (e.g., brie, camembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli meats, and hotdogs have been sources of human listeriosis. The sources of human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques matching _Listeria_ spp. isolated from a possible source with a species recovered from a patient.\n\nListeriosis is a world-wide zoonosis caused by _Listeria moncytogenes_, which is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and in some patients invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the US), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (e.g., HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nThe organism can be killed by pasteurization, but heavy contamination can reduce pasteurization's effectiveness. Although cooking can kill the organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can contaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking prior to eating. The organism can then continue to grow in the refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat product, since _L. monocytogenes_ grows at refrigerator temperatures. Its presence in food does not alter the taste or smell of the food.'\n\nIt is not clear whether the implicated goat cheese was made from pasteurized milk or not. The most important take-away point here is that _Listeria_ meningitis can occur in seemingly immunocompetent individuals. This is important because some antimicrobials used for treatment of presumptive bacterial meningitis (such as ceftriaxone, because of lack of activity, and vancomycin, because of poor CSF penetration) are not ideal for _Listeria_ meningitis. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/7FYJ.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Contamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or following subsequent cooking or other processing. Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (e.g., brie, camembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli meats, and hotdogs have been sources of human listeriosis. VA New York Harbor Health Care System\nBrooklyn Campus\n<jana.preis@va.gov>\n\n[The following is excerpted from ProMED report: Listeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert, archive Number: 20071230.4186 by my colleague Mod. \n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures. \n\nListeriosis is a world-wide zoonosis caused by _Listeria moncytogenes_, which is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Most human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. Although cooking can kill the organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can contaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking prior to eating. Infection results in diarrhea and in some patients invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. \n\nIt is not clear whether the implicated goat cheese was made from pasteurized milk or not. Both milk sources, goat and cow, were cultured, and the goat culture was positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The factory uses cow and goat milk for producing cheese, and all cheese preparation is manual. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (e.g., HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease. Its presence in food does not alter the taste or smell of the food.' Source: Jana Preis <jana.preis@va.gov> [edited]\n\n\nA a man in his 30s originally from Ravno, Bosnia and Herzegovina traveled with his wife and children to his home town for a family event.
