Date: Thu 18 Jul 2013\n The sources of human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques matching _Listeria_ spp.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bosnia and Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ravno", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1909350", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1909350", "date": "2013-08-28 19:27:58", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): MULTISTATE, FATAL, CHEESE, RECALL\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Aug 2013\nSource: The Courier [edited]\nhttp://www.hngnews.com/waterloo_marshall/news/local/article_78012fcc-0f5f-11e3-940d-0019bb30f31a.html\n\n\nA 6th person, this time from Texas, has been sickened with the strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ linked to Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese, LLC.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced Thursday [22 Aug 2013] that a 6th person has been infected in the outbreak. The number of ill persons identified includes 2 from Minnesota, and one each from Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and now one from Texas. One of the 2 Minnesota victims died, and another person sickened was a pregnant woman, whose illness resulted in a miscarriage. All 6 ill persons were hospitalized.\n\nOn 3 Jul 2013, the Waterloo-based company recalled 3 varieties of soft cheese, including its Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles, made on 1 Jul 2013 or earlier due to possible _L. monocytogenes_ contamination. The products were distributed nationwide.\n\nAccording to the CDC, a collaborative investigation is being conducted by local and state public health and regulatory agencies. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration indicates that Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses are the likely source of the outbreak.\n\nInformation about specific cheeses consumed is available for 5 of the 6 ill persons. Of those, all 5 either definitely or probably ate Les Freres cheese made by Crave Brothers before getting sick, according to the CDC.\n\nAmong persons for whom information is available, dates that illnesses were diagnosed range from 20 May to 7 Jul 2013. Ill persons range in age from 30 to 67 years, with a median age of 55 years, and 83 percent are female, according to the CDC. Clinical specimens that were collected after 10 Aug 2013 might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. It takes an average of 2-3 weeks.\n\nPublic health investigators used DNA 'fingerprints' of _Listeria_ bacteria obtained through diagnostic testing with pulse-field gel electrophoresis to identify cases of illness that may be part of the outbreak. The DNA fingerprint of the outbreak strain is typically associated with about 14 cases per year, even in the absence of a recognized outbreak, according to the CDC website.\n\nBetween 2-10 Jul 2013, the FDA conducted an inspection at the firm's processing facility in cooperation with the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture. During that inspection, the FDA collected a sample of Petit Frere with Truffles that was found to contain _Listeria monocytogenes_ with the same DNA fingerprint as the outbreak strain, the CDC reported.\n\nCrave Brothers cheese stopped production, and the FDA and the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture are monitoring corrective action being made by the firm.\n\nAbout 800 laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis are reported each year in the United States, and typically 3 or 4 outbreaks are identified and reported to the CDC annually. The organism can cause serious and sometimes fatal infections in young children, frail or elderly people, and others with weakened immune systems.\n\nCrave Brothers Farmstead Cheese did not provide a comment on the one new outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Diane Graff]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above adds one more case to the 5 cases of listeriosis previously posted (Listeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187) in now 5 states with still one death (in Minnesota) and one miscarriage. The prior post indicated that the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified on the basis of genotyping in cheeses made by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin. Les Frere and the smaller version Petit Frere sold in wooden boxes are washed rind, semi-soft, soft ripened cheeses; for a picture of them, see http://www.cravecheese.com/cheese-detail.php?Petit-Fr-re-5.\n\nThe cheeses are described as being 'hand-ladeled' [sic, probably ladled by hand], washed regularly with brine, and matured for a minimum of 3 weeks on site,' (http://culturecheesemag.com/node/1227).\n\nOn 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers recalled the 3 implicated cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier. The recalled cheeses were distributed nationwide through retail and foodservice outlets and mail order. More cases can be anticipated because of the long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes not showing up until 2 months after people have consumed the tainted food, and delays in reporting.\n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _L. monocytogenes_ transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nListeriosis was added to the list of nationally notifiable diseases in 2001. Almost all reported cases of listeriosis have invasive infection in which the bacteria spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nThe average annual incidence of invasive listeriosis in the United States was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population for 2009-2011, with a case-fatality rate (CFR) (deaths and fetal losses) of 21 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w).\n\nFor a further discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail posts Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719 and Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above adds one more case to the 5 cases of listeriosis previously posted (Listeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187) in now 5 states with still one death (in Minnesota) and one miscarriage. \n\nAbout 800 laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis are reported each year in the United States, and typically 3 or 4 outbreaks are identified and reported to the CDC annually. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. \n\nThe average annual incidence of invasive listeriosis in the United States was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population for 2009-2011, with a case-fatality rate (CFR) (deaths and fetal losses) of 21 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). \n\nPublic health investigators used DNA 'fingerprints' of _Listeria_ bacteria obtained through diagnostic testing with pulse-field gel electrophoresis to identify cases of illness that may be part of the outbreak. On 3 Jul 2013, the Waterloo-based company recalled 3 varieties of soft cheese, including its Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles, made on 1 Jul 2013 or earlier due to possible _L. monocytogenes_ contamination. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). \n\nThe cheeses are described as being 'hand-ladeled' [sic, probably ladled by hand], washed regularly with brine, and matured for a minimum of 3 weeks on site,' (http://culturecheesemag.com/node/1227). \n\nInformation about specific cheeses consumed is available for 5 of the 6 ill persons. On 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers recalled the 3 implicated cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier. \n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _L. monocytogenes_ transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. \n\nBetween 2-10 Jul 2013, the FDA conducted an inspection at the firm's processing facility in cooperation with the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture. For a further discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail posts Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719 and Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643. Clinical specimens that were collected after 10 Aug 2013 might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. The DNA fingerprint of the outbreak strain is typically associated with about 14 cases per year, even in the absence of a recognized outbreak, according to the CDC website.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-05-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1689741", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Chile: (SG, BI) fatal, meat, camembert susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1689741", "date": "2013-05-03 14:49:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CHILE: (SANTIAGO, BIO BIO) FATAL, MEAT, CAMEMBERT SUSPECTED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n\n[1] Santiago, Bio Bio: camembert cheese, recall\n[2] Santiago Metropolitan Region: turkey ham\n\n******\n[1] Santiago, Bio Bio: camembert cheese, recall\nDate: Mon 29 Apr 2013\nSource: La Segunda online [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.lasegunda.com/Noticias/Nacional/2013/04/842845/Listeria-en-quesos-Hoy-se-dan-a-conocer-las-marcas-afectadas\n\n\nRosa Oyarce, the metropolitan health SEREMI [las Secretarias Regionales Ministeriales de Salud; regional governmental ministerial unit], confirmed that the listeriosis outbreak affecting the country in recent months comes from a batch of camembert soft cheese of the Santa Rosa brand, which is already being recalled nationwide.\n\nThe batch number is 073 210, with an expiration date of 23 May 2013, and consists of 2000 units that were distributed mostly in Santiago and in the Bio Bio Region, where listeriosis patients were also registered.\n\nAccording to the SEREMI, once the alert was raised due to the increased number of cases, [health authorities] began an investigation of the products that might be contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_, including raw food and unpasteurized milk, as well as dairy products such as soft cheeses. Through these tests, the contaminated food was detected.\n\nOyarce clarified that only 'certain items (those with the bacteria) and not the whole production (of cheese) were affected. A single batch was contaminated.' The products are already being recalled to prevent further infections.\n\nJorge Diaz, assistant health secretary, reported that until last week [week of 22 Apr 2013], 34 cases had been registered in the country including 5 deaths. Santiago is the most affected, with 18 cases and 4 deaths.\n\nThe SEREMI reiterated the call for people to pay attention to hygiene measures when handling food, especially vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women and the elderly and chronically ill, who are more susceptible to [infection] with the bacteria.\n\n'People who are not at risk will most likely not have many problems apart from general malaise, but for people at higher risk, we maintain the preventive message to avoid eating raw foods or foods such as these (soft cheeses), because the risk is higher for them,' she said.\n\nAmong the products that as a general rule could be contaminated are unpasteurized milk and its byproducts, raw meat, fish, and seafood, as well as cold cuts and sausages, and fruit and vegetables that have contacted the soil, as the bacterium is typically found in soil and water.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Santiago Metropolitan Region: turkey ham\nDate: Tue 30 Apr 2013\nSource: Cooperativa.cl [in Spanish, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/pais/salud/listeriosis/seremi-sumario-almacen-de-san-ramon-por-contagio-de-listeriosis/2013-04-30/163230.html\n\n\nOn Tue 30 Apr 2013, [Rosa Oyarce], the metropolitan health SEREMI [regional governmental ministerial unit], imposed legal measures on a neighborhood store in the commune of San Ramon [Santiago Metropolitan Region], where one of the 18 people affected with listeriosis in the region would have been infected.\n\nThe bacteria were found in a [sample of] turkey ham, but according Oyarce, contamination occurred in the cutting machine, since other samples of the same product showed no listeria.\n\n'There is talk of a sick person in the commune of San Ramon who would have consumed foods in some stores in the area. Samples taken from this store tested positive in our environmental health laboratory,' said Oyarce. From the 14 shops that were investigated in the commune as a result of the infection of one person, only the store in question gave a positive result, but Oyarce said they would to continue to investigate to find other possible sources of contamination.\n\nThe health authority also confirmed that of the 45 samples of different foods from different brands tested during the past week, the Santa Rosa cheeses are the only ones contaminated with listeria.\n\nThe authority outlined the following measures to prevent infection with the disease:\n- wash hands before and after handling food;\n- wash vegetables and fruits;\n- wash surfaces and utensils that have been in contact with foods at risk;\n- separate raw from cooked foods to avoid cross contamination;\n- consume only pasteurized dairy products (milk, fresh cheese, cottage cheese, buttery cheese, chanco cheese, gouda, etc.);\n- reheat food at high temperature, to ensure removal of any contamination. Reheating in microwave ovens may be inadequate.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nRaw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie and camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold cuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, pate, deli meats, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken have been sources of human listeriosis. Listeria can also survive in frozen food. Even minimal contamination of refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products is a problem, since _L. monocytogenes_ grows at refrigerator temperatures, and its presence in food does not alter the taste or smell of the food.\n\nThe sources of human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques that match _Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source with the strains recovered from patients.\n\nThere seems to be 2 concurrent listeriosis outbreaks in Chile at the present time: One involves as of the week of 22 Apr 2013, 34 cases, including 5 deaths nationwide. Santiago Metropolitan Region is the most affected, with 18 cases and 4 deaths. This outbreak apparently has been attributed to a batch (#073 210, with an expiration date of 23 May 2013) of Camembert soft cheese of the Santa Rosa brand, which is already being recalled nationwide. This batch was distributed mostly in Santiago and in the Bio Bio Region. The 2nd outbreak involves at least one of the 18 Santiago cases that has been attributed to turkey ham, which is thought to have been contaminated by the cutting machine at a neighborhood store. The linkages of cases to possible sources are not stated. However, DNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from patients could confirm a linkage. Reports of additional cases can be expected even after all the sources have been removed, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 2 months.\n\nThe Bio Bio Region and Santiago Metropolitan Region (or Metropolitan Region), are 2 of Chile's 15 administrative divisions. The Metropolitan Region, which contains the nation's capital, Santiago, is Chile's smallest by area and most densely populated region (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Metropolitan_Region). A map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "The authority outlined the following measures to prevent infection with the disease:\n- wash hands before and after handling food;\n- wash vegetables and fruits;\n- wash surfaces and utensils that have been in contact with foods at risk;\n- separate raw from cooked foods to avoid cross contamination;\n- consume only pasteurized dairy products (milk, fresh cheese, cottage cheese, buttery cheese, chanco cheese, gouda, etc.);\n- reheat food at high temperature, to ensure removal of any contamination. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely distributed in nature. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRaw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie and camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold cuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, pate, deli meats, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken have been sources of human listeriosis. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< MJ, edited]\nhttp://www.lasegunda.com/Noticias/Nacional/2013/04/842845/Listeria-en-quesos-Hoy-se-dan-a-conocer-las-marcas-afectadas\n\n\nRosa Oyarce, the metropolitan health SEREMI [las Secretarias Regionales Ministeriales de Salud; regional governmental ministerial unit], confirmed that the listeriosis outbreak affecting the country in recent months comes from a batch of camembert soft cheese of the Santa Rosa brand, which is already being recalled nationwide. \n\n'People who are not at risk will most likely not have many problems apart from general malaise, but for people at higher risk, we maintain the preventive message to avoid eating raw foods or foods such as these (soft cheeses), because the risk is higher for them,' she said. According to the SEREMI, once the alert was raised due to the increased number of cases, [health authorities] began an investigation of the products that might be contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_, including raw food and unpasteurized milk, as well as dairy products such as soft cheeses. The organism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. \n\nThere seems to be 2 concurrent listeriosis outbreaks in Chile at the present time: One involves as of the week of 22 Apr 2013, 34 cases, including 5 deaths nationwide. \n\nJorge Diaz, assistant health secretary, reported that until last week [week of 22 Apr 2013], 34 cases had been registered in the country including 5 deaths. \n\nThe health authority also confirmed that of the 45 samples of different foods from different brands tested during the past week, the Santa Rosa cheeses are the only ones contaminated with listeria. In this update:\n\n[1] Santiago, Bio Bio: camembert cheese, recall\n LISTERIOSIS - CHILE: (SANTIAGO, BIO BIO) FATAL, MEAT, CAMEMBERT SUSPECTED\n*************************************************************************\n \n\nThe batch number is 073 210, with an expiration date of 23 May 2013, and consists of 2000 units that were distributed mostly in Santiago and in the Bio Bio Region, where listeriosis patients were also registered. On Tue 30 Apr 2013, [Rosa Oyarce], the metropolitan health SEREMI [regional governmental ministerial unit], imposed legal measures on a neighborhood store in the commune of San Ramon [Santiago Metropolitan Region], where one of the 18 people affected with listeriosis in the region would have been infected. Among the products that as a general rule could be contaminated are unpasteurized milk and its byproducts, raw meat, fish, and seafood, as well as cold cuts and sausages, and fruit and vegetables that have contacted the soil, as the bacterium is typically found in soil and water. \n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. \n\nThe SEREMI reiterated the call for people to pay attention to hygiene measures when handling food, especially vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women and the elderly and chronically ill, who are more susceptible to [infection] with the bacteria. \n\nThe bacteria were found in a [sample of] turkey ham, but according Oyarce, contamination occurred in the cutting machine, since other samples of the same product showed no listeria.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-04-30 00:00:00", "2013-05-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Rosa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Ramon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1816187", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1816187", "date": "2013-07-10 18:25:59", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: FATAL, CHEESE, RECALL\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 5 Jul 2013\nSource: CDC _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) Outbreaks [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-07-13/index.html\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheeses\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC is collaborating with public health and regulatory officials in several states and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). The joint investigation indicates that Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses made by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin are the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nPublic health investigators are using DNA 'fingerprints' of _Listeria_ obtained through testing with pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, or PFGE, to identify cases of illness that may be part of this outbreak. They are using data from PulseNet, the national subtyping network of state and local public health laboratories and federal food regulatory laboratories that performs molecular surveillance of foodborne infections.\n\nA total of 5 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 4 states. The number of ill people identified in each state is as follows: Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Minnesota (2), and Ohio (1).\n\nAmong persons for whom information is available, dates that illness was diagnosed range from 20 May 2013 to 17 Jun 2013. All 5 ill persons were hospitalized. Ill persons range in age from 31 years to 67 years, with a median age of 58 years, and 80 percent are female. One illness in a pregnant woman resulted in a miscarriage. One death was reported in Minnesota.\n\nThe outbreak can be visually described with a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each day [http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-07-13/epi.html]. This chart is called an epidemic curve or epi curve. Clinical specimens that were collected after 22 Jun 2013 might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 3 weeks.\n\nAbout 800 laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis are reported each year in the United States, and typically 3 or 4 outbreaks are identified and reported to CDC annually. Some foods that have been linked to outbreaks in recent years are Mexican-style soft cheeses, imported ricotta salata cheese, whole cantaloupe, raw sprouts, and pre-cut celery.\n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and trace-back investigations conducted by officials in local, state, and federal public health, agriculture, and regulatory agencies indicate that Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses manufactured by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company are the likely source of this outbreak of listeriosis.\n\nIn interviews, ill persons answered questions about foods consumed and other exposures in the month before becoming ill. All 5 ill persons reported consuming a soft cheese. Information about specific cheeses consumed is available for 4 of the ill persons. Of those, 3 either definitely or probably ate Les Freres cheese made by Crave Brothers before getting sick. Investigation of specific types of cheeses consumed by other ill persons is ongoing.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of Les Freres and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses made by Crave Brothers from 2 retail stores indicate the presence of the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_. Further testing and confirmation of the results are pending.\n\nOn 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin voluntarily recalled its Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier due to possible _L. monocytogenes_ contamination. The recalled cheeses were distributed nationwide through retail and foodservice outlets as well as by mail orders.\n\nThe FDA is conducting an inspection at Crave Brothers' processing facility in coordination with the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture. FDA is working closely with CDC, Crave Brothers, and public health authorities in states where illnesses occurred to determine the exact cause of contamination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC report above concerns 5 cases of listeriosis in 4 states, with 1 death (in Minnesota) and 1 miscarriage. The report indicates that the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified, presumably on the basis of genotyping, in cheeses made by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin. Les Frere and the smaller version Petit Frere sold in wooden boxes are washed rind, semi-soft, soft ripened cheeses; for a picture of them, see http://www.cravecheese.com/cheese-detail.php?Petit-Fr-re-5.\n\nThe cheeses are described as being 'hand-ladeled [sic, probably ladled by hand], washed regularly with brine, and matured for a minimum of 3 weeks on site' (http://culturecheesemag.com/node/1227).\n\nOn 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers recalled the 3 implicated cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier. The recalled cheeses were distributed nationwide through retail and foodservice outlets and mail order. More cases can be anticipated because of the long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes not showing up until 2 months after people have consumed the tainted food.\n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, transmitted to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but [that type of] the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFor a further discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail posts Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719 and Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS. - Mod.ML]\n\n[The primary reservoir for _L. monocytogenes_ is soil, forage, mud, and silage. Additional reservoirs include infected domestic and wild animals, fowl, and humans.\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and trace-back investigations conducted by officials in local, state, and federal public health, agriculture, and regulatory agencies indicate that Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses manufactured by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company are the likely source of this outbreak of listeriosis. \n\nAbout 800 laboratory-confirmed cases of listeriosis are reported each year in the United States, and typically 3 or 4 outbreaks are identified and reported to CDC annually. \n\nA total of 5 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 4 states. \n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of Les Freres and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses made by Crave Brothers from 2 retail stores indicate the presence of the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_. \nCDC is collaborating with public health and regulatory officials in several states and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC report above concerns 5 cases of listeriosis in 4 states, with 1 death (in Minnesota) and 1 miscarriage. On 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin voluntarily recalled its Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with Truffles cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier due to possible _L. monocytogenes_ contamination. \n\nThe cheeses are described as being 'hand-ladeled [sic, probably ladled by hand], washed regularly with brine, and matured for a minimum of 3 weeks on site' (http://culturecheesemag.com/node/1227). On 3 Jul 2013, Crave Brothers recalled the 3 implicated cheeses with make dates of 1 Jul 2013 or earlier. \n\nPublic health investigators are using DNA 'fingerprints' of _Listeria_ obtained through testing with pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, or PFGE, to identify cases of illness that may be part of this outbreak. \n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheeses\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------- \n\nThe outbreak can be visually described with a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each day [http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-07-13/epi.html]. Ill persons range in age from 31 years to 67 years, with a median age of 58 years, and 80 percent are female. \n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n The report indicates that the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified, presumably on the basis of genotyping, in cheeses made by Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Company of Waterloo, Wisconsin. \n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, transmitted to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. For a further discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail posts Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719 and Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643. The number of ill people identified in each state is as follows: Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Minnesota (2), and Ohio (1).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-06-17 00:00:00", "2013-05-20 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2294169", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2294169", "date": "2014-02-22 16:10:55", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA, MARYLAND) FATAL, HISPANIC-STYLE SOFT CHEESE, RECALL\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 21 Feb 2014\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-listeria-20140221,0,5723535.story#axzz2u3mCLneF\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak linked to cheese has killed 1 person in California and sickened 7 in Maryland, including 3 newborns.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said Friday [21 Feb 2014] that the outbreak is linked to semi-soft, Latino-style cheese called Cuajada en Terron that is sold from a chain of grocery stores in Maryland.\n\nThe cheese was made by Roos Foods of Kenton, Delaware. The Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene issued a warning Wednesday [19 Feb 2014] to avoid products made by Roos Foods, which also sells cheese under the brand names Santa Rosa de Lima, Amigo, Mexicana, Suyapa, La Chapina, and La Purisima Crema Nica.\n\nThe CDC did not name the grocery chain linked to the outbreak. The illnesses were diagnosed between [1 Aug 2013] and [27 Nov 2013]. Of the 8 cases, 7 were hospitalized; 5 of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy.\n\nListeriosis is an infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. Symptoms include fever and muscle aches and diarrhea. Seniors, pregnant women and newborns are particularly vulnerable to the illness.\n\nIn 2011, 33 people died after consuming cantaloupe contaminated with _Listeria_.\n\n[Byline: David Pierson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 21 Feb 2014\nSource: CDC [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-02-14/index.html\n\n\nA total of 8 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 2 states. The number of ill persons identified in each state was as follows: California (1) and Maryland (7); 7 of 8 ill persons were hospitalized. One death was reported in California. And 5 of the illnesses (2 mother-newborn pairs and a newborn) were related to pregnancy. All patients are of Hispanic ethnicity. Investigation into the source of these illnesses is ongoing.\n\nInitial Announcement\n--------------------\nCDC is collaborating with public health and regulatory officials in several states and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). Public health investigators are using data from PulseNet, the national subtyping network of state and local public health laboratories, CDC, and federal food regulatory laboratories that performs molecular surveillance of foodborne infections, to identify cases of illness that may be part of this outbreak. The PulseNet data consists of DNA 'fingerprints' of _Listeria_ obtained through testing with pulsed-field gel electrophoresis, or PFGE. We are supplementing PFGE data with whole-genome sequencing. The 5 isolates already sequenced are closely related.\n\nA total of 8 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 2 states. The number of ill people identified in each state is as follows: California (1), Maryland (7).\n\nAmong persons for whom information is available, dates that illness was diagnosed range from [1 Aug 2013] to [27 Nov 2013. Seven of the 8 ill persons were hospitalized. Five of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy; 2 of these were diagnosed in 2 mother-newborn pairs, and 1 in only the newborn. The 3 other illnesses occurred among adults. One death was reported in California. All ill persons were reported to be of Hispanic ethnicity.\n\nThe outbreak can be visually described with a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each day. This chart is called an epidemic curve or epi curve. Clinical specimens that were collected after [1 Feb 2014] might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 3 weeks.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nIn interviews, ill persons answered questions about foods consumed and other exposures in the month before becoming ill. All patients in Maryland reported consuming soft or semi-soft Hispanic-style cheese and all shopped at different locations of same food store chain (Chain A). Testing of cheese products collected from Chain A stores was performed in Maryland and Virginia.\n\nVirginia's Division of Consolidated Laboratory Services (DCLS) identified the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ in a sample of Cuajada en Terron (fresh cheese curd) collected by the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS) from a Chain A store. This cheese was likely produced by Roos Foods of Kenton, Delaware, and was later repackaged in the Chain A store. VDACS issued a press release on [15 Feb 2014] instructing persons who purchased this product not to consume the cheese and to discard any remaining product.\n\nVDACS subsequently collected pre-packaged Cuajada en Terron produced by Roos Foods from Chain A that was not repackaged in the store. The Virginia DCLS identified _L. monocytogenes_ from these samples; a consumer advisory was issued on [21 Feb 2014]. DNA fingerprinting and whole-genome sequencing will be performed on these isolates. In addition, the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has tested samples of pre-packaged cheese products purchased at Chain A stores; those products produced by Roos Foods are preliminarily positive for _L. monocytogenes_. On [19 Feb 2014], the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene issued a warning to consumers to not eat any cheese products made by Roos Foods. Their warning stated that Roos Foods cheese products are sold under brand names Santa Rosa de Lima, Amigo, Mexicana, Suyapa, La Chapina, and La Purisima Crema Nica.\n\n[The epidemic curve and consumer advisories are available at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The reports above say that an outbreak in the US of listeriosis linked to semi-soft, Latino-style cheese called Cuajada en Terron has involved 8 people so far including 5 (2 mother-newborn pairs and a newborn) that were related to pregnancy. There has been one fatality. The 5 isolates are closely related on DNA typing. There may be additional cases because of the long incubation period for listeriosis of up to 60 days.\n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _L. monocytogenes_ transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection.\n\nListeriosis was added to the list of nationally notifiable diseases in the US in 2001. Almost all reported cases of listeriosis have invasive infection in which the bacteria spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html).\n\nIn the US, the CDC reported 1651 people were sickened by listeriosis during 2009-2011; the average annual incidence was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population, with a case-fatality rate (CFR) (deaths and fetal losses) of 21 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). At least 90 percent of people who get listeriosis are in a high risk group; pregnant women, the fetus and newborns, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease. Infection during pregnancy can cause fetal loss (miscarriage or stillbirth), preterm delivery, and illness or death in newborn infants. Pregnant women are about 10 times more likely than the general population to get listeriosis and pregnant Hispanic women are about 24 times more likely than the general population to get listeriosis (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/risk.html). Although the news report tells us newborns were infected in 3 of 5 pregnancy-related illnesses, we are not told the outcome of the pregnancies in the 2 other mothers.\n\nMany outbreaks have been linked to soft cheese made with unpasteurized milk. However, in the period 2009-2011, 5 outbreak investigations by the CDC implicated soft cheeses made from pasteurized milk that the CDC says were likely contaminated during cheese-making (4 implicated Mexican-style cheese, and 1 implicated 2 other types of cheese); 2 outbreaks were linked to raw produce (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). _Listeria_ grows at refrigeration temperatures, so it can thrive when soft cheeses that support its growth have been contaminated.\n\nCuajada, which means 'curdled' in Spanish, is a cheese that is popular in Latin America, especially in El Salvador and Nicaragua. The following is extracted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuajada and http://www.nicaliving.com/node/1092: Raw milk that is warmed or heated to about 80 degrees C is mixed with rennet, vinegar, or citrus juice and left to curdle. The precipitate is placed in cheesecloth to drain. Cuajada is usually served as dessert with honey and walnuts or sometimes sugar, and, less often, for breakfast with fruit or honey. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3DHP.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The reports above say that an outbreak in the US of listeriosis linked to semi-soft, Latino-style cheese called Cuajada en Terron has involved 8 people so far including 5 (2 mother-newborn pairs and a newborn) that were related to pregnancy. However, in the period 2009-2011, 5 outbreak investigations by the CDC implicated soft cheeses made from pasteurized milk that the CDC says were likely contaminated during cheese-making (4 implicated Mexican-style cheese, and 1 implicated 2 other types of cheese); 2 outbreaks were linked to raw produce (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). [The epidemic curve and consumer advisories are available at the source URL.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said Friday [21 Feb 2014] that the outbreak is linked to semi-soft, Latino-style cheese called Cuajada en Terron that is sold from a chain of grocery stores in Maryland. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, usually from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, tissue from a normally sterile site, or products of conception (e.g., amniotic fluid, placental, or fetal tissue), are forwarded to state public health laboratories for pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) subtyping, the results of which are submitted to PulseNet, the National Molecular Subtyping Network for Foodborne Disease Surveillance, to identify clusters of possibly related cases. \n\nIn the US, the CDC reported 1651 people were sickened by listeriosis during 2009-2011; the average annual incidence was 0.29 cases per 100 000 population, with a case-fatality rate (CFR) (deaths and fetal losses) of 21 percent (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6222a4.htm?s_cid=mm6222a4_w). \n\nVirginia's Division of Consolidated Laboratory Services (DCLS) identified the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ in a sample of Cuajada en Terron (fresh cheese curd) collected by the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS) from a Chain A store. Five of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy; 2 of these were diagnosed in 2 mother-newborn pairs, and 1 in only the newborn. The number of ill persons identified in each state was as follows: California (1) and Maryland (7); 7 of 8 ill persons were hospitalized. All patients in Maryland reported consuming soft or semi-soft Hispanic-style cheese and all shopped at different locations of same food store chain (Chain A). \nCDC is collaborating with public health and regulatory officials in several states and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). http://www.latimes.com/business/money/la-fi-mo-listeria-20140221,0,5723535.story#axzz2u3mCLneF\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak linked to cheese has killed 1 person in California and sickened 7 in Maryland, including 3 newborns. When PulseNet identifies a cluster of _L. monocytogenes_ patient isolates with the same molecular pattern, epidemiologists conduct a preliminary case-control analysis by comparing responses to food exposures reported on the Listeria Case Report from patients in the cluster to those from patients outside the cluster (http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html). Public health investigators are using data from PulseNet, the national subtyping network of state and local public health laboratories, CDC, and federal food regulatory laboratories that performs molecular surveillance of foodborne infections, to identify cases of illness that may be part of this outbreak. \n\nListeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _L. monocytogenes_ transmitted to humans who are not newborn infants by ingestion of contaminated food. A total of 8 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 2 states. A total of 8 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _L. monocytogenes_ have been reported from 2 states. In addition, the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has tested samples of pre-packaged cheese products purchased at Chain A stores; those products produced by Roos Foods are preliminarily positive for _L. monocytogenes_. At least 90 percent of people who get listeriosis are in a high risk group; pregnant women, the fetus and newborns, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease. Clinical specimens that were collected after [1 Feb 2014] might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. \n\nMany outbreaks have been linked to soft cheese made with unpasteurized milk. And 5 of the illnesses (2 mother-newborn pairs and a newborn) were related to pregnancy. LISTERIOSIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA, MARYLAND) FATAL, HISPANIC-STYLE SOFT CHEESE, RECALL\n********************************************************************************** \n\nListeriosis is an infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. \n\nThe outbreak can be visually described with a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each day.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2014-02-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-15 00:00:00", "2014-02-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-02-21 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "1651-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "El Salvador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nicaragua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexicana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amigo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Chapina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuajada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Rosa de Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MARYLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Suyapa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1661868", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (03): (Sydney) nosocomial, profiterole", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1661868", "date": "2013-04-21 11:13:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (SYDNEY) NOSOCOMIAL, PROFITEROLE\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Apr 2013\nSource: Yahoo 7 News, ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/16818325/profiteroles-blamed-for-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA batch of dodgy profiteroles is being blamed on a listeriosis outbreak that could have spread across 13 public hospitals in Sydney.\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales] Department of Health says that so far 3 patients, including a terminally ill man at Campbelltown Hospital who has since died, have tested positive for listeriosis. The 2 other patients, one from Concord hospital and another from the Royal Prince Alfred are responding well to treatment.\n\nThe profiteroles, which were made by Rich Products Australia, have since been withdrawn from all patient meals.\n\nAn investigation into the outbreak, which is believed to have occurred between mid-March and 16 Apr 2013, is ongoing.\n\nNSW Director of Health Protection Jeremy McAnulty says the risk of further cases is low but if people are concerned they should seek medical advice.\n\n'If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,' he said. 'We've withdrawn them from serving to patients.'\n\n[Symptoms] include fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and diarrhoea. In the more severe form, symptoms also include collapse and shock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections.\n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak.\n\nThe incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. With such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1*7F. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Food implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. \n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings. \n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole). \n\n'If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,' he said. ' \n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections. \n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concord", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SYDNEY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1538072", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, soft cheese, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1538072", "date": "2013-02-11 13:08:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, SOFT CHEESE, MORE CASES\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 10 Feb 2013\nSource: Sydney Morning Herald [edited]\nhttp://m.smh.com.au/national/health/third-death-in-listeria-outbreak-20130209-2e51f.html\n\n\nA NSW [New South Wales] man has been confirmed as the 3rd fatality in Australia's largest outbreak of listeriosis. The death of the 68 year old man late last month [January 2013] was confirmed by Victoria's acting chief health officer as being linked to the outbreak at Jindi, one of the nation's biggest cheese companies. The outbreak, which has been traced to the company's factory in Gippsland, Victoria, has been linked to the deaths of an 84 year old Victorian man and a 44 year old Tasmanian man. 26 cases have been identified so far, including a New South Wales woman who had a miscarriage.\n\nVictoria's Department of Health maintains it acted promptly to contain the outbreak, which came to the attention of authorities in mid-December [2012] and led to the recall of more than 100 cheese products, but it has warned there could be more cases and further fatalities.\n\n'I'm confident the intervention that has been put in place with terrific cooperation from Jindi is absolutely appropriate and is the best possible,' said the acting chief health officer, Michael Ackland. 'Unfortunately because of the 70 day incubation period for listeriosis, there will almost certainly be people who have consumed cheese prior to the recall who may still get sick -- that could go on for another couple of months.'\n\n[byline: Rachel Wells]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts last year (2012):\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143;\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643;\nListeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822; and\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439.\n\nThe total number of cases has risen from 21 when last posted on ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall 20130125.1514992) to 26, now with 3 deaths and one miscarriage. This outbreak has occurred nationwide and the last recall of cheeses apparently has been relatively recent, but the exact date of this recall has not been specified in the news reports posted by ProMED-mail. With an incubation period of up to 70 days, more cases of listeriosis associated with this outbreak can be expected.\n\nThe news report says that the outbreak has been traced to the Jindi Cheese company's factory in Gippsland, Victoria but does not say on what basis the linkage was made, that is, did the genotypes of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolated from patients match that of any isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ from the recalled cheeses?\n\nThe Australian mainland is made up of 5 states (Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland, Victoria, and New South Wales), and 3 territories (Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory, and Jarvis Bay Territory), with the 6th island state of Tasmania to the south of the mainland. In addition, there are 6 island territories, known as external territories, and the Australian Antarctic Territory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia). The outbreak, which has been traced to the company's factory in Gippsland, Victoria, has been linked to the deaths of an 84 year old Victorian man and a 44 year old Tasmanian man.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gippsland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Territory", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1514992", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1514992", "date": "2013-01-25 19:10:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: FATAL, SOFT CHEESE, RECALL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Jan 2013\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/soft-cheese-listeria-outbreak-spreads/story-e6freuy9-1226561642576\n\n\n\nA total of 3 more people have been struck down by listeriosis after eating soft cheese. The cases in New South Wales (NSW) follow 7 cases last week. They bring the total number of people affected nationwide to 21. 2 Australians have died and a pregnant woman has miscarried following the outbreak.\n\nThe people ate cheese produced by the Jindi Cheese Company that has since been recalled. Tests are still under way to confirm a direct link with the current outbreak, according to NSW Health. Jindi has voluntarily recalled all batches of cheese manufactured up to and including 6 Jan 2013. It follows an earlier recall of Brie and Camembert cheeses on 19 Dec 2012 after the 1st cases were identified.\n\nListeria has a 70-day incubation period so new cases could still emerge.\n\nNSW Health acting director of health protection Professor Wayne Smith said all of the recent cases involved people aged over 65 with one person in a serious condition. 'These cases highlight the need for people to check their fridges to see if they have any of the recalled cheeses and discard or return to the place of purchase any cheese that is on the list of recalled products,' he said in a statement. 'If the brand or best before date is unknown, do not consume the cheese, rather it should be discarded,' he said.\n\nListeria is a bacteria that can affect a number of food products but particularly soft cheeses including Brie and Camembert. The infection may cause minor or no symptoms in healthy individuals but can be particularly dangerous for the elderly, pregnant women and people with compromised immune systems, such as cancer patients. Early symptoms include fever, headache, tiredness, aches and pains.\n\nList of recalled soft cheese products:\n-------------------------------------\n- Wattle Valley 110g Brie and Camembert and Jindi 125g Brie and Camembert with `best before' dates up to 27 Feb 2013\n- Jindi 120g blue Brie and 120g triple cream blue with `best before' dates up to 28 Feb 2013\n- Top Paddock and Blue Cow 1kg Brie with `best before' dates up to 27 Mar 2013\n- Jindi, Wattle Valley and Harris Farm 200g Camembert with `best before' dates up to 20 Mar 2013\n- Coles Finest triple cream blue 140g with `best before' dates up to 21 Feb 2013.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts last year (2012):\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143;\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643;\nListeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822; and\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439.\n\nThe total number of cases has risen from 8 when last posted on ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159) to 21, now with 2 deaths and one miscarriage. This outbreak has occurred nationwide and the last recall of cheeses apparently has been relatively recent, but the exact date of this recall was not specified in the news report. With an incubation period of up to 70 days, more cases of listeriosis associated with this outbreak can be expected.\n\nThe news report says that 'people [with listeriosis] ate cheese produced by the Jindi Cheese Company that has since been recalled' and 'tests are still under way to confirm a direct link [of the recalled cheeses] with the current outbreak,' probably by matching the genotype of the isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ from patients with that of any isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ from the recalled cheeses.\n\nThe Australian mainland is made up of 5 states (Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland, Victoria, and New South Wales), and 3 territories (Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory, and Jarvis Bay Territory), with the 6th island state of Tasmania to the south of the mainland. A map of Australia showing its states and territories can be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1z_*. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts last year (2012):\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143;\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643;\nListeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822; and\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439. \n\nList of recalled soft cheese products:\n-------------------------------------\n- Wattle Valley 110g Brie and Camembert and Jindi 125g Brie and Camembert with `best before' dates up to 27 Feb 2013\n \n\nThe news report says that 'people [with listeriosis] ate cheese produced by the Jindi Cheese Company that has since been recalled' and 'tests are still under way to confirm a direct link [of the recalled cheeses] with the current outbreak,' probably by matching the genotype of the isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ from patients with that of any isolates of _L. monocytogenes_ from the recalled cheeses. - Jindi 120g blue Brie and 120g triple cream blue with `best before' dates up to 28 Feb 2013\n- Top Paddock and Blue Cow 1kg Brie with `best before' dates up to 27 Mar 2013\n- Jindi, Wattle Valley and Harris Farm A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n g Camembert with `best before' dates up to 20 Mar 2013\n- Coles Finest triple cream blue 140g with `best before' dates up to 21 Feb 2013. LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: FATAL, SOFT CHEESE, RECALL\n***************************************************\n These cases highlight the need for people to check their fridges to see if they have any of the recalled cheeses and discard or return to the place of purchase any cheese that is on the list of recalled products,' he said in a statement. ' \n\nThe total number of cases has risen from 8 when last posted on ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159) to 21, now with 2 deaths and one miscarriage. The people ate cheese produced by the Jindi Cheese Company that has since been recalled. \n\nListeria is a bacteria that can affect a number of food products but particularly soft cheeses including Brie and Camembert.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00", "2013-01-06 00:00:00", "2013-02-21 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northern Territory", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1459159", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1459159", "date": "2012-12-19 15:22:28", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: CHEESE, RECALL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Dec 2012\nSource: The Western Australian, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/newshome/15669766/listeria-outbreak-prompts-cheese-recall/\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak has prompted a nationwide recall of certain brands of soft cheeses.\n\nA total of 8 cases of listeriosis infection across Australia, including one in WA [Western Australia], have been found to be linked and a further 3 cases are under investigation, Victoria's Department of Health said.\n\nThe State's chief health officer Rosemary Lester said consumers should discard 1 kg brie and camembert cheese branded Jindi, the 1 kg Wattle Valley double brie, and the 1 kg Wattle Valley camembert with a best before date of 21 Dec [? 2012].\n\nDr Lester warned consumers to check the best before date of any Jindi or Wattle Valley soft cheeses. 'Consumers who have purchased a cut portion of camembert or brie from a supermarket or delicatessen who are unsure of the brand should discard it,' she said.\n\nSo far, 2 Victorians, 3 NSW [New South Wales] residents, and one person each in Queensland, Tasmania, and Western Australia have been diagnosed with the infection.\n\nThe cheeses have been voluntarily recalled as a precaution.\n\nListeriosis infections usually only produce mild symptoms in healthy people, but can be dangerous to pregnant women, their unborn babies, and elderly people, Dr Lester said. 'It can cause miscarriages in pregnant women and even death in people with compromised immune systems,' she said. 'Investigations into listeriosis are complex as it can be difficult to identify the source. Symptoms of illness can take up to 70 days to appear.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822; and Listeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439.\n\nThe news report above says that the 8 cases of listeriosis, occurring in 5 of Australia's 6 states and various territories, are 'linked', but fails to says if the linkage is based on a common history of having eaten one of the recalled cheeses, or if genotyping has actually revealed a common strain among the clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ and if the genotype of clinical isolates matches that of any isolates from the cheeses.\n\nThe Australian mainland is made up of 5 states (Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland, Victoria, and New South Wales), and 3 territories (Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory, and Jarvis Bay Territory), with the 6th island state of Tasmania to the south of the mainland. In addition, there are 6 island territories, known as external territories, and the Australian Antarctic Territory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia).\nA map of Australia showing its states and territories can be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1z_*. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Symptoms of illness can take up to 70 days to appear.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N.
