A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The news report above says that the 8 cases of listeriosis, occurring in 5 of Australia's 6 states and various territories, are 'linked', but fails to says if the linkage is based on a common history of having eaten one of the recalled cheeses, or if genotyping has actually revealed a common strain among the clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ and if the genotype of clinical isolates matches that of any isolates from the cheeses. \n\nThe State's chief health officer Rosemary Lester said consumers should discard 1 kg brie and camembert cheese branded Listeriosis infections usually only produce mild symptoms in healthy people, but can be dangerous to pregnant women, their unborn babies, and elderly people, Dr Lester said. ' Jindi, the 1 kg Wattle Valley double brie, and the 1 kg Wattle Valley camembert with a best before date of 21 Dec [? 2012]. \n\nDr Lester warned consumers to check the best before date of any Jindi or Wattle Valley soft cheeses. ' CHEESE, RECALL\n***************************************\n \n\nA total of 8 cases of listeriosis infection across Australia, including one in WA", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Territory", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1341613", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (04): fatal, cheese, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1341613", "date": "2012-10-14 05:18:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CHEESE, UPDATE\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 12 Oct 2012\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2012/10/two-more-victims-counted-in-listeria-ricotta-outbreak/\n\n\nThe total case count in the ongoing _Listeria_ outbreak linked to imported Italian ricotta cheese has expanded from 18 to 20 and one more victim has died, announced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in an update on Friday [12 Oct 2012]. [See below.]\n\nThe 2 new illnesses were reported in California. One of these 2 victims died, bringing the total number of victim deaths from 3 to 4.\n\nLast week, Food Safety News reported on 2 cases in California that had not yet been counted in CDC's investigation update -- a pregnant mother who contracted a listeria infection and her son who was born prematurely on 19 Sep 2012 and died on 4 Oct 2012. CDC and the California Department of Public Health have yet to confirm whether the mother and her son were the newly counted 2 cases and death linked to the outbreak, but it's likely that they are, since the outbreak strain of listeria was isolated from both the baby and the placenta.\n\n19 of the 20 people in 12 states and Washington DC, who've now been infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been hospitalized, reports CDC. One stillbirth has also been tied to the outbreak. The 11 victims who were not fetal or newborn range in age from 30 to 87 years old, with a median age of 77, according to CDC's update.\n\nThe contaminated cheese causing this outbreak is imported from Italy by Forever Cheese of Long Island City, New York, and sold under the Marte brand as Ricotta Salata Frescolina.\n\n[byline: Gretchen Goetz]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Oct 2012\nSource: CDC.gov [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/index.html\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to imported Frescolina Marte brand ricotta salata cheese\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nAs of 11 Oct 2012, a total of 20 persons infected with the outbreak-associated strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 12 states and the District of Columbia. [The 2 new cases are from California.]\n\n19 ill persons reported being hospitalized. 4 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 2 of these deaths. One fetal loss has also been reported.\n\nAmong persons for whom information is available, dates when clinical specimens were collected range from 28 Mar 2012 to 19 Sep 2012. 19 ill persons reported being hospitalized. 9 of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy; 3 of these illnesses were diagnosed in newborns. The other 11 ill persons range in age from 30 years to 87 years, with a median age of 77 years, and 55 per cent of them are female.\n\nCollaborative investigation efforts of local, state, and federal public health and regulatory agencies indicate that imported ricotta salata cheese is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nOn 14 Sep 2012, Forever Cheese, Inc, issued an expanded recall of all lots and production codes of Frescolina Marte brand ricotta salata cheese and issued a market withdrawal of all cheeses they received that were produced by the Italian cheese exporter.\n\nFrescolina Marte brand ricotta salata cheese may also have been referred to as Ricotta Frescolina Marte Tipo Toscanella or Ricotta Salata Soft (lot number T9425) during distribution.\n\nLabeling of the recalled ricotta salata cheese after it was cut and repackaged has been inconsistent. Be aware that labels of repackaged cheese may not include the words 'Marte' or 'Frescolina'.\n\nConsumers who purchased recalled Marte brand Frescolina ricotta salata cheese are advised not to eat it and to discard any remaining cheese.\n\nThis is especially important for pregnant women, persons with weakened immune systems, and older adults.\n\nCheese retailers should not sell or serve recalled Marte brand Frescolina ricotta cheese distributed by Forever Cheese, Inc, regardless of any expiration coding.\n\nResults of testing of clinical specimens that were collected after 24 Sep 2012 might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. The recalled cheese should be off store shelves now because the recall began on 10 Sep 2012, and was expanded on 14 Sep 2012. However, more ill persons may be reported because up to 2 months can elapse between eating contaminated food and developing listeriosis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases in this multistate outbreak of listeriosis related to ricotta salata cheese has risen from 15 to 20 and the number of deaths from 3 to 4 since the last ProMED-mail post [Listeriosis - USA (03): fatal, cheese, recall, update 20120923.1305794] on this outbreak. 9 of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy; 3 of these illnesses were diagnosed in newborns. One fetal loss has also been reported. DNA 'fingerprints', -- that is, genotyping, of listeria have been used to identify cases of illness that are linked to this outbreak.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357; Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. The total case count in the ongoing _Listeria_ outbreak linked to imported Italian ricotta cheese has expanded from 18 to 20 and one more victim has died, announced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in an update on Friday [12 Oct 2012]. \n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to imported Frescolina Marte brand ricotta salata cheese\n \n\nConsumers who purchased recalled Marte brand Frescolina ricotta salata cheese are advised not to eat it and to discard any remaining cheese. \n\nCollaborative investigation efforts of local, state, and federal public health and regulatory agencies indicate that imported ricotta salata cheese is the likely source of this outbreak. LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CHEESE, UPDATE\n*********************************************\n \n\nResults of testing of clinical specimens that were collected after 24 Sep 2012 might not be reported yet due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. The contaminated cheese causing this outbreak is imported from Italy by Forever Cheese of Long Island City, New York, and sold under the Marte brand as Ricotta Salata Frescolina. As of 11 Oct 2012, a total of 20 persons infected with the outbreak-associated strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 12 states and the District of Columbia. Frescolina Marte brand ricotta salata cheese may also have been referred to as Ricotta Frescolina Marte Tipo Toscanella or Ricotta Salata Soft (lot number T9425) during distribution.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-09-10 00:00:00", "2012-09-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-09-24 00:00:00", "2012-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frescolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1212514", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand (03): (HB) nosocomial, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1212514", "date": "2012-07-24 11:13:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (03): (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 23 Jul 2012\nSource: All About Hawke's Bay [edited]\nhttp://www.hawkesbay.co.nz/medical-and-hospital-news-page:/51265-hawkes-bay-district-health-board-is-warning-about-an-outbreak-of-listeria-in-hawkes-bay.html\n\n\nHawke's Bay District Health Board [HBDHB] is warning about an outbreak of listeriosis in Hawke's Bay. 4 people have been diagnosed with listeriosis; 2 of those, who were elderly and immuno-compromised, have subsequently died, and 2 have recovered.\n\nSamples of ready-to-eat meats supplied to the hospital have tested positive to _Listeria_. All of the hospital's supplied ready-to-eat meat has since been quarantined, and the results are now part of an investigation into the source of the outbreak, he said.\n\nDirector of Public Health Caroline McElnay said listeriosis has a long incubation period of up to several weeks. Dr McElnay said listeriosis is very rare, and there are only about 25 cases a year in New Zealand. The disease is only dangerous to pregnant women, their babies, the elderly, and people with a lowered immune system. Almost all other people are not harmed by it.\n\nThe outbreak served as a warning for anyone who was immuno-compromised, elderly, or pregnant to be very aware of food safety. People at high risk should not eat ready-to-eat foods like soft cheeses made with pasteurised and unpasteurised milk, processed meat and poultry [The relatively high moisture content of soft cheeses favors proliferation of _Listeria_ even at refrigeration temperatures. The ubiquitous nature of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in the environment means that contamination of soft cheeses may occur at any point post-pasteurization.]. If high-risk people develop flu like symptoms such as a mild fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, aches and pains, or a mild cough or cold, they should seek medical advice.\n\nHow did _Listeria_ get into food at the hospital? The food samples were all pre-packaged ready-to-eat meat, which is supplied to the hospital by an external provider. The Ministry for Primary Industries is making further enquiries.\n\nHow does HBDHB ensure food is safe? As part of the hospital's food safety programme, Nutrition and Food Services only purchases from approved suppliers. For a medium to high-risk product like cooked meat, this means that suppliers must have an NZ Food Safety Authority approved food safety or risk management programme in place. HBDHB's kitchen has a Certificate of Registration from Hastings District Council, which was achieved with 'excellence' from 31 Mar 2012 until 31 Mar 2013. High-risk foods are restricted to [sic] certain at risk groups, e.g. ante-natal patients.\n\nDid listeriosis cause the deaths of these 2 people? It appears that listeriosis was the cause of death in at least one of these patients, and in the other patient, it probably was a contributing factor. Both patients were immuno-compromised.\n\nWhat action has HBDHB taken? 'As part of our investigation, the hospital kitchens were inspected and food samples taken. We withdrew all pre-packaged ready-to-eat meats from the kitchen on Tue 10 Jul 2012 and reviewed our internal processes. These samples of ready-to-eat meats from the kitchen have now tested positive to _Listeria_. The Ministry for Primary Industries is making further inquiries regarding the source of _Listeria_ infection. We are informing the public now in order to raise awareness about the ever-present risk of listeriosis to vulnerable patients.'\n\nHas anyone else gotten sick from listeriosis and been hospitalised? There have been no other hospitalised cases or further notifications in Hawke's Bay.\n\nWhat has happened to the food that has tested positive? 'We have withdrawn it.'\n\nIn New Zealand, around 25 cases occur annually. Of those, about 20 percent are associated with pregnancy or newborn babies.\n\nThere is more information available from\nhttp://www.surv.esr.cri.nz/PDF_surveillance/AnnualRpt/AnnualSurv/2011/2011AnnualSurvRpt.pdf.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in the 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012) on a nosocomial outbreak in Northern Ireland: Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357;\nListeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643;\nand Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822.\n\nThe news report above confirms that _Listeria_ has been cultured from samples of ready-to-eat meats supplied to the hospital from an outside vendor. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with those of strains isolated from the ready-to-eat meats would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nThe pre-packaged ready-to-eat meats were withdrawn from the hospital's kitchen on 10 Jul 2012. However, the incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. Although there have been no new cases since 29 Jun 2012, with such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis for at least the next several weeks.\n\nHawke's Bay is a region on the east coast of the North Island of New Zealand. For a map of Hawke's Bay Region, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Position_of_Hawkes_Bay.png.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1VY-. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357;\nListeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643;\nand Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in the 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012) on a nosocomial outbreak in Northern Ireland: A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n People at high risk should not eat ready-to-eat foods like soft cheeses made with pasteurised and unpasteurised milk, processed meat and poultry [The relatively high moisture content of soft cheeses favors proliferation of _Listeria_ even at refrigeration temperatures. \n\nThe pre-packaged ready-to-eat meats were withdrawn from the hospital's kitchen on 10 Jul 2012. For a medium to high-risk product like cooked meat, this means that suppliers must have an NZ Food Safety Authority approved food safety or risk management programme in place. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _Listeria monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with those of strains isolated from the ready-to-eat meats would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source. LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (03): (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL\n****************************************************************\n The food samples were all pre-packaged ready-to-eat meat, which is supplied to the hospital by an external provider. All of the hospital's supplied ready-to-eat meat has since been quarantined, and the results are now part of an investigation into the source of the outbreak, he said. \n\nThe outbreak served as a warning for anyone who was immuno-compromised, elderly, or pregnant to be very aware of food safety. Samples of ready-to-eat meats supplied to the hospital have tested positive to _Listeria_. We withdrew all pre-packaged ready-to-eat meats from the kitchen on Tue 10 Jul 2012 and reviewed our internal processes. The news report above confirms that _Listeria_ has been cultured from samples of ready-to-eat meats supplied to the hospital from an outside vendor. Although there have been no new cases since 29 Jun 2012, with such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis for at least the next several weeks. \n\nDid listeriosis cause the deaths of these 2 people? These samples of ready-to-eat meats from the kitchen have now tested positive to _Listeria_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-06-29 00:00:00", "2013-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1210276", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) nosocomial, fatal, background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1210276", "date": "2012-07-21 20:42:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (02): (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, BACKGROUND\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 21 Jul 2012\nSource: Dr. Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\n-----------------------------------\nAmong the major English-speaking countries, New Zealand reports the highest incidence of listeriosis per 100,000 population - approximately twice the rate reported in Australia - see graph at http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Listeriosis-NZ.png (1-3).\n\nGideon http://www.GideonOnline.com records 5 outbreaks of listeriosis in New Zealand during 1969 to 2000, including:\n1980 - An outbreak (22 cases, 5 fetal deaths) of perinatal listeriosis among 3 obstetrics hospitals in Auckland.\n1981 to 1982 - An outbreak (18 cases, 3 abortions and one neonatal death) in Christchurch.\n1992 - An outbreak (2 cases) of perinatal listeriosis related to contaminated smoked mussels.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of New Zealand, 2012. 413 pages, 136 graphs, 1534 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-new-zealand/\n2. Berger SA. Listeriosis: Global Status, 2012. 95 pages, 105 graphs, 557 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/\n3. Gideon Graph Tool at http://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Steve Berger for this background information.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1VY-. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n1992 - An outbreak (2 cases) of perinatal listeriosis related to contaminated smoked mussels.\n\nReferences:\n1. \n\nGideon http://www.GideonOnline.com records 5 outbreaks of listeriosis in New Zealand during 1969 to 2000, including:\n1980 - An outbreak (22 cases, 5 fetal deaths) of perinatal listeriosis among 3 obstetrics hospitals in Auckland. LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (02): (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, BACKGROUND\n****************************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine Source: Dr. Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\n----------------------------------- Tel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Steve Berger for this background information.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "1992-03-26 00:00:00", "1980-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1136357", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1136357", "date": "2012-05-17 17:10:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - UK (04): (NORTHERN IRELAND) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 May 2012\nSource: Antrim Times [edited]\nhttp://www.antrimtimes.co.uk/news/local/public-health-agency-to-investigate-listeria-outbreak-1-3841394\n\n\nThe Public Health Agency [PHA] is leading a detailed investigation into the potential source of an outbreak of listeriosis among hospital patients. 4 cases including one death have been reported previously and 2 further cases have been confirmed. There have been no new cases identified since 18 Apr 2012.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, and while this investigation is ongoing, PHA has recommended that some pre-prepared foods should not be served to hospital in-patients. This is a precautionary measure while the PHA, along with the Food Standards Agency, Environmental Health officials and HSC Trusts, continue to investigate the potential source of this outbreak.\n\nPHA has taken steps to reassure patients, their relatives and the public by producing a patient and visitor information leaflet 'Preventing food poisoning at home and in health care settings' and also a short fact sheet on listeriosis. These have been distributed to all HSC Trusts and give details of foods that may be associated with _Listeria_ infection, practical food safety tips and advice on how to prevent food poisoning. PHA is also working with all Trusts to ensure that robust arrangements for food safety are maintained in the hospital setting.\n\nListeriosis is an uncommon infection in the hospital setting. It is usually food-borne, most often found in ready-to-eat refrigerated and processed foods such as chilled meats, soft cheeses, cold cuts of meat, pates and smoked fish. It may also be found in food items containing one or more of these products, e.g., sandwiches.\n\nThere would normally be between 3 to 5 cases of listeriosis each year in Northern Ireland. Listeriosis is a rare but potentially life-threatening disease. Most adults experience only mild infections of the eye and skin or gastroenteritis. It can, however, lead to severe illness including blood poisoning or meningitis.\n\nOlder people and individuals with weakened immune systems, including those who have cancer, AIDS or issues with alcohol misuse, are all susceptible. Listeriosis may be particularly dangerous in pregnancy as it can present as a mild and 'flu-like' illness that is not serious to the mother but can cause miscarriage, premature delivery, stillbirth or severe illness in a newborn child.\n\nThe PHA is reminding patients in hospitals and those attending hospital day services that they should only eat foods provided on the wards by hospital staff and not eat foods from other sources such as hospital canteens, shops or restaurants. Visitors are urged not to bring food into hospitals for patients unless this has been discussed and agreed with ward managers. Patients should wash their hands before and after eating, eat food as soon as it is served, dispose of any leftovers immediately and not hold over food for later consumption.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alert\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In an April 2012 ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822), a news report indicated that there were 3 cases of nosocomial listeriosis, one of which was fatal, at 2 hospitals in Northern Ireland (Antrim Area Hospital in Antrim and Causeway Hospital in Coleraine), possibly due to contaminated food prepared outside the hospital. The above news report indicates that the number of cases of nosocomial listeriosis is now 6, although no new cases have occurred since 18 Apr 2012. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the 6 cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods would help to establish if a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nAntrim is a town in County Antrim with a population of 20 001 people in 2001 22 miles (35 km) northwest of Belfast, and Coleraine is a town in County Londonderry with a population of 24 042 people in 2001 55 miles (88.5 km) northwest of Belfast (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coleraine). A map of Northern Ireland can be found at http://www.nidex.com/map1.htm.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1KlI. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In an April 2012 ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822), a news report indicated that there were 3 cases of nosocomial listeriosis, one of which was fatal, at 2 hospitals in Northern Ireland (Antrim Area Hospital in Antrim and Causeway Hospital in Coleraine), possibly due to contaminated food prepared outside the hospital. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The PHA is reminding patients in hospitals and those attending hospital day services that they should only eat foods provided on the wards by hospital staff and not eat foods from other sources such as hospital canteens, shops or restaurants. \n\nPHA has taken steps to reassure patients, their relatives and the public by producing a patient and visitor information leaflet 'Preventing food poisoning at home and in health care settings' and also a short fact sheet on listeriosis. \n\nAntrim is a town in County Antrim with a population of 20 001 people in 2001 22 miles (35 km) northwest of Belfast, and Coleraine is a town in County Londonderry with a population of 24 042 people in 2001 55 miles (88.5 km) northwest of Belfast (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coleraine). The above news report indicates that the number of cases of nosocomial listeriosis is now 6, although no new cases have occurred since 18 Apr 2012. Comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the 6 cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods would help to establish if a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source. Patients should wash their hands before and after eating, eat food as soon as it is served, dispose of any leftovers immediately and not hold over food for later consumption. These have been distributed to all HSC Trusts and give details of foods that may be associated with _Listeria_ infection, practical food safety tips and advice on how to prevent food poisoning. It is usually food-borne, most often found in ready-to-eat refrigerated and processed foods such as chilled meats, soft cheeses, cold cuts of meat, pates and smoked fish. The Public Health Agency [PHA] is leading a detailed investigation into the potential source of an outbreak of listeriosis among hospital patients.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-04-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2012-04-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NORTHERN IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belfast", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1209143", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1209143", "date": "2012-07-20 13:43:37", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 19 Jul 2012\nSource: Radio New Zealand News [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/111064/dhb-failed-to-test-its-food,-despite-fatal-listeria-cases\n\n\nHawke's Bay District Health Board [DHB] has admitted it failed to test hospital food for _Listeria_, despite 4 patients becoming ill with the bug and 2 of them dying. The DHB says [the] 2 patients at Hawke's Bay Hospital [who] died after getting listeriosis were both older women who had compromised immune systems. Two others, also older people with compromised immune systems, who had used hospital services also got listeriosis but have since recovered.\n\nThe cases were confirmed in May and June 2012, but processed meat such as salami, ham and pepperoni -- which are known as sources of _Listeria_ -- were not removed from the hospital menu until 10 Jul 2012. The DHB has confirmed the meat had signs of contamination, but won't say whether it was the source of the outbreak. Director of population health, Caroline McElnay, told Checkpoint the food wasn't tested because staff did not suspect the bug was in it. Dr McElnay says in hindsight the hospital could have withdrawn the meats as a precaution after the 1st patient caught the bug. She says the hospital is considering leaving processed meat off its menu permanently.\n\nFood safety officials say they hope the outbreak is over. The DHB says the 1st of the 4 cases was notified in early May 2012 and the last on 29 Jun 2012. The Ministry of Primary Industries is seeking to identify the source and the extent of the outbreak. Its deputy director general of compliance and response, Andrew Coleman, says he hopes it won't go further than the hospital. 'At this stage, it doesn't seem that it will be much broader. There's certainly been no unfortunate deaths and illnesses through the Hawke's Bay District Health Board's hospital since the June [2012] date.' The DHB says investigations are still underway and it's too soon to say how the patients got the bacterium, but food is a likely source.\n\nPregnant women, the elderly and those with weakened immune systems are warned to be careful what foods they eat. They are advised to avoid soft cheeses, processed meats and poultry. Family doctors say people who are generally well have nothing to fear from the outbreak.\n\nThe ministry says it has overseen a voluntary recall of a number of ready-to-eat meat products. At this stage, the ministry says there is only one firm involved in its inquiry into the outbreak. Bay Cuisine of Napier supplied ready-to-eat meat products to the hospital, but the ministry says it's not clear yet whether any of these products are linked to the cases. The ministry says it's talking only to Bay Cuisine, the board's sole supplier of packed meats, at this stage but may talk to other companies.\n\nBay Cuisine hasn't been available for interview, but in a statement, it says it's concerned about the outbreak and 2 deaths. It says it understands the source of the contamination is yet to be determined and it's working with authorities to find the source. It says it recalled products sold in Mad Butcher stores throughout the country and in Preston's stores in Wellington, Porirua and Palmerston North, although none has shown any evidence of contamination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in the 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year on a nosocomial outbreak in Northern Ireland: Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357; Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; and Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822.\n\nFrom ProMED-mail moderator LL's comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049:\n\n'Because of the risk of listeriosis from sandwich cold meats, one might think that their distribution as part of a menu in locations where [there are] particularly at-risk individuals such as health care settings is not a good idea.'\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods would help to establish whether a common source was involved and what would be the most likely source.\n\nHawke's Bay is a region on the east coast of the North Island of New Zealand. For a map of Hawke's Bay Region, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Position_of_Hawkes_Bay.png.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1VY-. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in the 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year on a nosocomial outbreak in Northern Ireland: A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n From ProMED-mail moderator LL's comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049:\n\n'Because of the risk of listeriosis from sandwich cold meats, one might think that their distribution as part of a menu in locations where [there are] particularly at-risk individuals such as health care settings is not a good idea.' The ministry says it has overseen a voluntary recall of a number of ready-to-eat meat products.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-06-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2012-06-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Preston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Porirua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wellington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1305794", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): fatal, cheese, recall, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1305794", "date": "2012-09-23 14:15:42", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (MULTISTATE), FATAL, CHEESE, RECALL, UPDATE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Sep 2012\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2012/09/wa-counts-victim-in-nationwide-listeria-cheese-outbreak/#.UF8Fyhjx_oB\n\n\nThe total number of people sickened with listeriosis linked to ricotta [salata] cheese from a New York cheese importer has risen from 14 to 15, with a new illness reported in Washington State, according to the outbreak update issued by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday [21 Sep 2012]. [A picture of the package label for the incriminated cheese is available at http://www.foodsafetynews.com/RicottaRecallMain.jpg.]\n\nThe total number of cases by state is as follows: California (1), Colorado (1), District of Columbia (1), Maryland (3), Minnesota (1), Nebraska (1), New Jersey (1), New Mexico (1), New York (1), Ohio (1), Pennsylvania (1), Virginia (1) and Washington (1). [A map of cases by state is available at http://www.foodsafetynews.com/RicottaMap.jpg.]\n\nAll 15 victims have been hospitalized as a result of their infections, according to CDC. Three deaths have occurred, one each in Minnesota, Nebraska and New York. These deaths were reported by CDC in its initial outbreak report on 11 Sep 2012. The 1st illness connected to this outbreak began on 25 Mar 2012, and illness onsets have been recorded as recently as 26 Aug 2012.\n\nForever Cheese of Long Island City, NY, which imports the recalled cheese, has also announced that it will no longer be importing cheese made by Fattorie Chiarappa Srl, the company whose ricotta is now linked to the multistate listeriosis outbreak. 'Forever Cheese has decided to stop importing and selling all products produced by Fattorie Chiarappa Srl,' the firm said last week. Brands including Ricotta Salata Frescolina, the brand linked to this outbreak; Marte brand Roasted Ricotta and Hard Ricotta Salata will be discontinued immediately, said the company.\n\nHealth officials note that the affected cheese may also have been labeled as Ricotta Frescolina Marte Tipo Toscanella and/or Ricotta Salata Soft Lot (T9425) as it was being distributed.\n\nConsumers who may have purchased the affected cheeses should not eat them and should discard them. This warning is especially important for pregnant women, people with weakened immune systems, and older adults, warns FDA, as people in these categories risk more serious infections from _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nSymptoms of _Listeria_ infection, or listeriosis, usually include fever, chills, severe headache, vomiting, and other influenza-type symptoms. The CDC notes that infected individuals may develop fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. If you think you may have contracted listeriosis, contact your healthcare provider.\n\n[Byline: Gretchen Goetz]\n\n-\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases in a multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to consumption of tainted ricotta salata cheese has risen from 14 to 15, and the number of states and District of Columbia with cases has risen from 12 to 13 since the last ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - USA (02): (multistate) fatal, cheese, recall 20120912.1292100). The number of deaths has remained at 3.\n\nThe U.S. CDC has reported on the results of the outbreak investigation, which is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/index.html:\n\n- DNA 'fingerprints,' i.e., genotyping, of _Listeria_ have been used to identify cases of illness that are linked to this outbreak;\n- A time line for the occurrence of cases ('epi curve') is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/epi.html;\n- 4 of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy;\n- 2 of these illnesses were diagnosed in newborns;\n- the other 11 ill persons range in age from 30 years to 87 years, with a median age of 77 years;\n- 64 percent of them are female;\n- no fetal losses have been reported;\n- listeriosis contributed 2 of the 3 deaths;\n- 12 (86 percent) of 14 ill persons interviewed reported consuming a soft cheese. All 6 ill persons who could provide information about packaging of cheeses reported consuming cheese that had been cut and repackaged at a retail location;\n- no one cheese was reported by the majority of ill persons, suggesting that cross-contamination of other cheeses through cutting boards and utensils may have played a role (The investigation has focused on identifying intact cheeses shipped to multiple retail locations where ill persons purchased cut and repackaged cheese.);\n- FDA identified the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria in a sample of uncut imported Marte brand Frescolina ricotta salata cheese distributed by Forever Cheese, Inc., lot number (T9425) and/or a production code (441202) that has been recalled;\n- Forever Cheese has expanded the original recall to include all lots and all production codes of Marte Brand Frescolina Ricotta Salata cheese;\n- FDA is working closely with CDC, the firm involved, and public health authorities in states where illnesses occurred to determine the exact cause of contamination.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357; Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; and Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "\n\nThe U.S. CDC has reported on the results of the outbreak investigation, which is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/index.html:\n\n- DNA 'fingerprints,' i.e., genotyping, of _Listeria_ have been used to identify cases of illness that are linked to this outbreak;\n- A time line for the occurrence of cases ('epi curve') is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/epi.html;\n- 4 of the illnesses were related to a pregnancy;\n- 2 of these illnesses were diagnosed in newborns;\n- the other 11 ill persons range in age from 30 years to 87 years, with a median age of 77 years;\n- 64 percent of them are female;\n- no fetal losses have been reported;\n- listeriosis contributed 2 of the 3 deaths;\n- 12 (86 percent) of 14 ill persons interviewed reported consuming a soft cheese. All 6 ill persons who could provide information about packaging of cheeses reported consuming cheese that had been cut and repackaged at a retail location;\n- no one cheese was reported by the majority of ill persons, suggesting that cross-contamination of other cheeses through cutting boards and utensils may have played a role (The investigation has focused on identifying intact cheeses shipped to multiple retail locations where ill persons purchased cut and repackaged cheese.);\n- FDA identified the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria in a sample of uncut imported Marte brand Frescolina ricotta salata cheese distributed by Forever Cheese, Inc., lot number (T9425) and/or a production code (441202) that has been recalled;\n- Forever Cheese has expanded the original recall to include all lots and all production codes of Marte Brand Frescolina Ricotta Salata cheese;\n- FDA is working closely with CDC, the firm involved, and public health authorities in states where illnesses occurred to determine the exact cause of contamination. [Byline: Gretchen Goetz]\n\n-\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of cases in a multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to consumption of tainted ricotta salata cheese has risen from 14 to 15, and the number of states and District of Columbia with cases has risen from 12 to 13 since the last ProMED-mail post (Listeriosis - USA (02): (multistate) fatal, cheese, recall 20120912.1292100). California (1), Colorado (1), District of Columbia (1), Maryland (3), Minnesota (1), Nebraska (1), New Jersey (1), New Mexico (1), New York (1), Ohio (1), Pennsylvania (1), Virginia (1) and Washington (1). For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357; Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; and Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The total number of people sickened with listeriosis linked to ricotta [salata] cheese from a New York cheese importer has risen from 14 to 15, with a new illness reported in Washington State, according to the outbreak update issued by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday [21 Sep 2012]. LISTERIOSIS - USA (03): (MULTISTATE), FATAL, CHEESE, RECALL, UPDATE\n*******************************************************************\n Forever Cheese of Long Island City, NY, which imports the recalled cheese, has also announced that it will no longer be importing cheese made by Fattorie Chiarappa Srl, the company whose ricotta is now linked to the multistate listeriosis outbreak. ' \n\nHealth officials note that the affected cheese may also have been labeled as Ricotta Frescolina Marte Tipo Toscanella and/or Ricotta Salata Soft Lot (T9425) as it was being distributed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-09-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2044-12-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frescolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Long Island City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cheese-09-12/epi.html", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1107753", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1107753", "date": "2012-04-20 10:04:20", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - UK (03): (NORTHERN IRELAND) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, BACKGROUND\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 19 Apr 2012\nFrom: Graham Clive <Clive.Graham@ncuh.nhs.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThere have been a number of reported outbreaks of listeriosis in the UK that relate to food ingested on healthcare premises. The sources implicated include hospital sandwiches and salads; it should be noted that these may be brought into the hospital after preparation elsewhere (1).\n\nI also note a report of an outbreak at a Norwegian Hospital that implicated Camembert cheese; this outbreak was associated with a short incubation period (2).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Coetzee N, Laza-Stanca V, Orendi JM, et al: A cluster of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections in hospitalised adults, Midlands, England, February 2011. Euro Surveill. 2011; 16(20): pii=19869. Available at http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19869.\n2. Johnsen BO, Lingaas E, Torfoss D, et al: A large outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection with short incubation period in a tertiary care hospital. J Infect. 2010; 61(6): 465-70. Epub 2010 Sep 24. [Abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20813130].\n\n--\nGraham Clive\nNorth Cumbria University Hospitals\nUK\n<Clive.Graham@ncuh.nhs.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Graham Clive for this background information.
