LISTERIOSIS - UK (03): (NORTHERN IRELAND) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, BACKGROUND\n********************************************************************** \nThere have been a number of reported outbreaks of listeriosis in the UK that relate to food ingested on healthcare premises. The Norwegian nosocomial outbreak was previously reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452). Johnsen BO, Lingaas E, Torfoss D, et al: A large outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection with short incubation period in a tertiary care hospital.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-02-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-24 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NORTHERN IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NOSOCOMIAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1105643", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1105643", "date": "2012-04-18 20:34:11", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - UK (02): (NORTHERN IRELAND) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, COMMENT\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Apr 2012\nFrom: Marilyn Simunich <Marilyn.Simunich@agri.idaho.gov> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to my Merck manual, 8th ed, p. 479, _Listeria_ is a ubiquitous saprophyte that lives in the plant-soil environment and has been isolated from more than 42 species of mammals and more than 22 species of birds, fish, and crustaceans. Just because ruminants seem to be more clinically susceptible doesn't mean that they are the primary source for people. Many monogastric animals can carry _Listeria_ in their GI tracts, too... dogs, cats, rabbits, and other small mammals.\n\n--\nMarilyn M. Simunich, DVM, Dipl. ACVPM\nDirector, Animal Health Laboratory\nDivision of Animal Industries\nIdaho State Dept. of Agriculture\nUSA\n<Marilyn.Simunich@agri.idaho.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Simunich for her comments. _Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the natural environment and a large variety of animal species (including cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, dogs, cats, horses, deer, rodents, domestic and wild birds, fish, and crustaceans) excrete _L. monocytogenes_ from their intestinal tracts into the environment. _L. monocytogenes_ has been recovered from raw vegetables and the soil they grow in. Most human _L. monocytogenes_ infections follow consumption of food contaminated with the bacterium. Many different types of food have been involved in outbreaks of listeriosis; these foods include deli meats, raw (unpasteurized) milk or milk products made from unpasteurized milk, such as soft cheeses or Mexican-style cheeses, pate or meat spreads, refrigerated smoked seafood and crustaceans, and raw fruit and vegetables.\n\nHowever, the routes of transmission of _L. monocytogenes_ for listeriosis in human and other animals are complex and not completely understood (see Sauders BD, Wiedmann M: Ecology of _Listeria_ species and _L. monocytogenes_ in the natural environment. Chapter 2. (2007) In: Listeria, Listeriosis, and Food Safety. ET Ryser, EH Marth (eds). Marcel Dekker, Inc., New York, NY). Human infections with _L. monocytogenes_ can result from consumption of contaminated unprocessed raw food, such as uncooked meats, unpasteurized milk or milk products, fruits, and vegetables, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food such as deli meat (Gravani R: _Listeria_ in food-processing facilities, p 657-709. (1999) In: Listeria, Listeriosis, and Food Safety. ET Ryser, EH Marth (eds). Marcel Dekker, Inc., New York, NY)\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ survives extremely well in the food-processing facility environment. However, information on how these strains entered that environment is limited. They may be introduced into these facilities through a variety of routes, including raw materials, employees' shoes or clothes, and equipment. When _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing factory (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe food-borne infections.\n\nThe role of the dairy farm as a potential source for _L. monocytogenes_ has been investigated by comparison of the pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) restriction enzyme digestion profiles of _L. monocytogenes_ dairy farm-associated strains (milk, environmental, and bovine) with that of human sporadic and epidemic disease strains (Borucki MK, et al: Dairy farm reservoir of _Listeria monocytogenes_ sporadic and epidemic strains. J Food Prot. 2004; 67(11): 2496-9; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15553633). 23 percent of human sporadic strains had PFGE patterns identical to that of dairy farm isolates and the PFGE of farm isolates were identical to that of a strain of _L. monocytogenes_ responsible for a 1985 California epidemic.\n\nIt is hoped that comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains involved in human disease with that of strains isolated from other animals, from food for human and other animal consumption, from food-processing facilities, and from the natural environment, will allow a better understanding of the routes of transmission. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1KlI.]", "summary": "\n\nThe role of the dairy farm as a potential source for _L. monocytogenes_ has been investigated by comparison of the pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) restriction enzyme digestion profiles of _L. monocytogenes_ dairy farm-associated strains (milk, environmental, and bovine) with that of human sporadic and epidemic disease strains (Borucki MK, et al: Dairy farm reservoir of _Listeria monocytogenes_ sporadic and epidemic strains. Human infections with _L. monocytogenes_ can result from consumption of contaminated unprocessed raw food, such as uncooked meats, unpasteurized milk or milk products, fruits, and vegetables, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food such as deli meat (Gravani R: It is hoped that comparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains involved in human disease with that of strains isolated from other animals, from food for human and other animal consumption, from food-processing facilities, and from the natural environment, will allow a better understanding of the routes of transmission. Many different types of food have been involved in outbreaks of listeriosis; these foods include deli meats, raw (unpasteurized) milk or milk products made from unpasteurized milk, such as soft cheeses or Mexican-style cheeses, pate or meat spreads, refrigerated smoked seafood and crustaceans, and raw fruit and vegetables.\n\n _Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the natural environment and a large variety of animal species (including cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, dogs, cats, horses, deer, rodents, domestic and wild birds, fish, and crustaceans) excrete _L. monocytogenes_ from their intestinal tracts into the environment. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n When _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing factory (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Director, Animal Health Laboratory\nDivision of Animal Industries\nIdaho State Dept. of Agriculture\nUSA\n<Marilyn.Simunich@agri.idaho.gov>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Simunich for her comments. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe food-borne infections. However, the routes of transmission of _L. monocytogenes_ for listeriosis in human and other animals are complex and not completely understood (see Sauders BD, Wiedmann M: Ecology of _Listeria_ species and _L. monocytogenes_ in the natural environment. 23 percent of human sporadic strains had PFGE patterns identical to that of dairy farm isolates and the PFGE of farm isolates were identical to that of a strain of _L. monocytogenes_ responsible for a 1985 California epidemic. Marcel Dekker, Inc., New York, NY)\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ survives extremely well in the food-processing facility environment.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-03-26 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NORTHERN IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NOSOCOMIAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1072439", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1072439", "date": "2012-03-16 20:34:23", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: (NEW JERSEY), PERINATAL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Mar 2012\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/infectious-disease-in-national/nj-health-issue-listeria-warning-on-the-heels-of-pregnant-woman-s-infection\n\n\nNearly 2 weeks after a 38-week pregnant woman was diagnosed with a _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services (NJDHSS) issued a warning Thursday, 15 Mar 2012, advising the public not to eat any cheese products produced by El Ranchero del Sur of South River, NJ.\n\nThe woman was diagnosed with the potentially fatal infection on 2 Mar 2012 at a New Brunswick hospital.\n\nThe Middlesex County Health Department performed an investigation on her infection and samples of cheese products were analyzed by the NJDHSS Public Health Environmental and Agricultural labs, who confirmed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in a sample of Los Corrales Queso Fresco Fresh Cheese and Banana Leaf code dated 03/16/12. El Ranchero del Sur agreed to a voluntary recall its products and to close its production plant while the investigation is in progress.\n\nAccording to the NJDHSS health alert, El Ranchero del Sur cheese products can be found primarily in Mexican and Latin American grocery stores, restaurants, and other Hispanic food establishments under the name brands El Ranchero, Los Corrales, and Carnes Don Beto with the plant number 34-0013669 marked on the label. All products are 14 ounces in weight except for the Queso Hebra Oaxaca String Cheese ball in 10 pound packages.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is a bacterium that is normally found in the environment and has been found in animals, birds and vegetation. It can be found in raw foods and in processed foods that get contaminated after processing. Some of the most common foods that are associated with listeriosis are raw milk, soft cheeses, vegetables, and many ready to eat meats like hot dogs, deli meats and pates. Those at greatest risk of serious listeriosis include pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and adults with weakened immune systems.\n\nMost healthy persons show no symptoms of this disease. Initial symptoms of food-borne listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, fatigue and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. Primarily in high risk groups but occasionally in healthy adults, the infection can spread to the blood and central nervous system where it can cause sepsis and meningitis.\n\nDue to a naturally depressed immune system, pregnant women are about 20 times more likely than other healthy adults to contract this disease. Though many women may only experience mild flu-like symptoms, infections during pregnancy can have devastating consequences to the fetus which include stillbirth or miscarriage, premature delivery and serious infections in the newborn.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alert\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is an excellent primer from the USA FDA that overviews the relationship of pregnancy and infection with _Listeria monocytogenes_\nhttp://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~pregnant/whillist.html:\n\n'What is _Listeria monocytogenes_?\nIt's a harmful bacterium that can be found in refrigerated, ready-to-eat foods (meat, poultry, seafood, and dairy (unpasteurized milk and milk products or foods made with unpasteurized milk)) and in soil. Animals can carry this bacterium without appearing ill, and thus, it can be found in foods made from animals. _L. monocytogenes_ is unusual because it can grow at refrigerator temperatures where most other foodborne bacteria do not. When eaten, it may cause listeriosis, an illness to which pregnant women and their unborn children are very susceptible.\n\n'How could I get listeriosis?'\nBy eating ready-to-eat meats, poultry, seafood, and dairy products that are contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_. You can also get listeriosis by eating contaminated foods processed or packaged in unsanitary conditions or by eating vegetables that are contaminated from the soil or from manure used as fertilizer.\n\n'How could listeriosis affect me?'\nThe symptoms can take a few days or even weeks to appear and may include fever, chills, muscle aches, diarrhea or upset stomach, headache, stiff neck, confusion, and loss of balance. In more serious cases, listeriosis could also lead to the mother's death. Most of the time, pregnant women who are infected with listeriosis don't feel sick. However, they can pass the infection to their unborn babies without even knowing it. That's why prevention of listeriosis is very important. In any case, if you experience any of the above symptoms, see your doctor or health-care provider immediately. Pregnant women are about 20 times more likely to get listeriosis than other healthy adults, and an estimated 1/3rd of all Listeria cases occur in pregnant women.\n\n'How could listeriosis affect my baby?'\nDuring the 1st trimester of pregnancy, listeriosis may cause miscarriage. As the pregnancy progresses to the 3rd trimester, the mother is more at risk. Listeriosis can also lead to premature labor, the delivery of a low-birth-weight infant, or infant death. Fetuses who suffer a late infection may develop a wide range of health problems, including mental retardation, paralysis, seizures, blindness, or impairments of the brain, heart or kidney. In newborns, _L. monocytogenes_ can cause blood infections and meningitis.\n\n'Listeriosis and Pregnant Hispanic Women'\nStudies show that pregnant Hispanic women may have a higher incidence of listeriosis than pregnant non-Hispanic women. This is most likely because they might make and eat homemade soft cheese and other traditional foods made from unpasteurized milk. 'Queso fresco' -- a traditional homemade cheese, prepared from unpasteurized milk and widely consumed by Hispanics -- has led to miscarriages, death of newborns, and premature delivery caused by _L. monocytogenes_. To prevent the risk of listeriosis, Hispanic pregnant women should not eat homemade soft cheeses and other traditional foods made from unpasteurized milk. Like all other pregnant women, they should follow the food safety precautions outlined below.\n\n'How can I prevent listeriosis?'\nThe good news is that listeriosis can be prevented! Here's how:\n- Your refrigerator should register at 40 F (4 C) or below and the freezer at 0 F (-18 C). Place a refrigerator thermometer in the refrigerator, and check the temperature periodically. During the automatic defrost cycle, the temperature may register slightly higher than 40 F. This is okay.\n- Refrigerate or freeze perishables, prepared food, and leftovers within 2 hours of eating or preparation. Follow the 2-Hour Rule: Discard food that has been left out at room temperature for longer than 2 hours. When temperatures are above 90 F (32 C), discard food after one hour.\n- Use ready-to-eat, perishable foods, such as dairy, meat, poultry, seafood, and produce, as soon as possible.\n\n***Don't eat:\n- Hot dogs and luncheon meats unless they're reheated until steaming hot.\n- Soft cheeses like Feta, Brie, and Camembert, 'blue-veined cheeses,' or 'queso blanco,' 'queso fresco,' or Panela unless they're made with pasteurized milk; Make sure the label says, 'made with pasteurized milk'\n- refrigerated pates or meat spreads\n- refrigerated smoked seafood -- unless it's in a cooked dish, such as a casserole (Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod, tuna, or mackerel is most often labeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' These types of fish are found in the refrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and delicatessens.)\n- Raw (unpasteurized) milk or foods that contain unpasteurized milk\n\nIt's okay to eat:\n- Canned or shelf-stable (able to be stored unrefrigerated on the shelf) pates and meat spreads.\n- Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood.\n- Pasteurized milk or foods that contain pasteurized milk.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n- Soft cheeses like Feta, Brie, and Camembert, 'blue-veined cheeses,' or 'queso blanco,' 'queso fresco,' or Panela unless they're made with pasteurized milk; Make sure the label says, 'made with pasteurized milk'\n- refrigerated pates or meat spreads\n- refrigerated smoked seafood -- unless it's in a cooked dish, such as a casserole (Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod, tuna, or mackerel is most often labeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It's a harmful bacterium that can be found in refrigerated, ready-to-eat foods (meat, poultry, seafood, and dairy (unpasteurized milk and milk products or foods made with unpasteurized milk)) and in soil. \n- Raw (unpasteurized) milk or foods that contain unpasteurized milk\n\n To prevent the risk of listeriosis, Hispanic pregnant women should not eat homemade soft cheeses and other traditional foods made from unpasteurized milk. Some of the most common foods that are associated with listeriosis are raw milk, soft cheeses, vegetables, and many ready to eat meats like hot dogs, deli meats and pates. \n\n'Listeriosis and Pregnant Hispanic Women'\n Pregnant women are about 20 times more likely to get listeriosis than other healthy adults, and an estimated 1/3rd of all Listeria cases occur in pregnant women. \n\n\nNearly 2 weeks after a 38-week pregnant woman was diagnosed with a _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection, the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services (NJDHSS) issued a warning Thursday, 15 Mar 2012, advising the public not to eat any cheese products produced by El Ranchero del Sur of South River, NJ. \n- Pasteurized milk or foods that contain pasteurized milk.' - Mod. \n\nThe Middlesex County Health Department performed an investigation on her infection and samples of cheese products were analyzed by the NJDHSS Public Health Environmental and Agricultural labs, who confirmed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in a sample of Los Corrales Queso Fresco Fresh Cheese and Banana Leaf code dated 03/16/12. \n- Use ready-to-eat, perishable foods, such as dairy, meat, poultry, seafood, and produce, as soon as possible. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is an excellent primer from the USA FDA that overviews the relationship of pregnancy and infection with _Listeria monocytogenes_\n Queso fresco' -- a traditional homemade cheese, prepared from unpasteurized milk and widely consumed by Hispanics -- has led to miscarriages, death of newborns, and premature delivery caused by _L. monocytogenes_. \n\n***Don't eat:\n- Hot dogs and luncheon meats unless they're reheated until steaming hot. Studies show that pregnant Hispanic women may have a higher incidence of listeriosis than pregnant non-Hispanic women. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alert\n< It's okay to eat:\n- Canned or shelf-stable (able to be stored unrefrigerated on the shelf) pates and meat spreads. Those at greatest risk of serious listeriosis include pregnant women, newborns, the elderly, and adults with weakened immune systems. This is most likely because they might make and eat homemade soft cheese and other traditional foods made from unpasteurized milk. ' You can also get listeriosis by eating contaminated foods processed or packaged in unsanitary conditions or by eating vegetables that are contaminated from the soil or from manure used as fertilizer. By eating ready-to-eat meats, poultry, seafood, and dairy products that are contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_. \n- Refrigerate or freeze perishables, prepared food, and leftovers within 2 hours of eating or preparation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Corrales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Ranchero", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1101822", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1101822", "date": "2012-04-15 13:17:44", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - UK: (NORTHERN IRELAND) NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: irishtimes.com [edited]\nhttp://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/0413/breaking50.html\n\n\nAn elderly patient has died following an outbreak of listeriosis in two Northern Ireland hospitals. The pensioner was one of two patients in the Antrim Area Hospital who contracted the food-borne bacteria. Another acquired the bug in the Causeway Hospital on the region's north coast. The patient who died was already ill but listeriosis has been confirmed as a contributory cause of death.\n\nBoth hospitals are managed by the Northern Trust, which has declared an outbreak. The Trust's director of nursing Olive MacLeod said: 'The person who died was a frail, elderly patient who had other illnesses but this _Listeria_ infection did contribute to their death.'\n\nListeriosis is usually associated with refrigerated food stuffs. Chilled meats, soft cheeses, cold cuts of meat, pates and smoked fish are all potential sources. Ms MacLeod said a full investigation was under way but said the hospitals were satisfied with how cold food was managed. She said listeriosis was 'uncommon' in a hospital setting. 'Normally there would be between three to five cases of listeriosis per annum in Northern Ireland,' she added. 'Because these three cases have occurred within a short period of time, we are declaring an outbreak.'\n\nA series of measures have been introduced in response to the outbreak with visitors to the hospitals being told not to bring food in from the outside.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alert\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, that is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nThe organism can be killed by pasteurization, but contamination may occur after pasteurization. Although cooking can kill the organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can recontaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking prior to eating. The organism can then continue to grow in the refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat product, since _L. monocytogenes_ grows at refrigerator temperatures. Its presence in food does not alter the taste or smell of the food.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold cuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post 20071230.4186. Nosocomial listeriosis has been described before related to food service in health care facilities, but is quite uncommon. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, e.g., cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Northern Ireland is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/01wb. - Mod.ML\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, e.g., cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings. Food implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold cuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken. Source: irishtimes.com [edited]\nhttp://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/0413/breaking50.html\n\n\nAn elderly patient has died following an outbreak of listeriosis in two Northern Ireland hospitals. Although cooking can kill the organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can recontaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking prior to eating. \n\nA series of measures have been introduced in response to the outbreak with visitors to the hospitals being told not to bring food in from the outside. \n\nListeriosis is usually associated with refrigerated food stuffs. [Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, that is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Ms MacLeod said a full investigation was under way but said the hospitals were satisfied with how cold food was managed. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease. Nosocomial listeriosis has been described before related to food service in health care facilities, but is quite uncommon.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1292100", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): (multistate) fatal, cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1292100", "date": "2012-09-12 23:54:55", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (MULTISTATE), FATAL, CHEESE, RECALL\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 11 Sep 2012\nSource: foodpoisonjournal.com [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/cheese-kills-3-sickening-14-in-11-state-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nAs of 11 Sep 2012, a total of 14 persons infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 11 states and the District of Columbia.\n\nThe number of ill persons identified in each state is as follows: California (1), Colorado (1), District of Columbia (1), Maryland (3), Minnesota (1), Nebraska (1), New Jersey (1), New Mexico (1), New York (1), Ohio (1), Pennsylvania (1), and Virginia (1). All 14 ill persons have been hospitalized; 3 deaths have been reported.\n\nCollaborative investigation efforts of local, state, and federal public health and regulatory agencies indicate that imported ricotta salata cheese is the likely source of this outbreak. On 10 Sep 2012, Forever Cheese, Inc. recalled one lot of Frescolina brand ricotta salata cheese due to _L. monocytogenes_ contamination.\n\nThe cheese was sold to distributors for retailers and restaurants in California, Colorado, District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Washington between 20 Jun and 9 Aug 2012.\n\n[Byline: Bill Marler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 12 Sep 2012\nSource: wtvr.com [edited]\nhttp://wtvr.com/2012/09/12/imported-cheese-sold-in-va-linked-to-3-deaths-14-hospitalizations/\n\n\nAn outbreak of illness linked to consumption of tainted ricotta salata cheese has been linked to 3 deaths and 14 hospitalizations in 11 states, according to a release on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website.\n\nThe outbreak -- blamed on the bacteria _Listeria monocytogenes_ -- is possibly linked to consumption of Frescolina brand ricotta salata from Forever Cheese lot T9425 and/or production code 441202. The cheese was sold to distributors for retailers and restaurants in California, Colorado, Washington D.C., Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Massachusetts, Maryland, Maine, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Washington between 20 Jun and 9 Aug 2012. The company has issued a voluntary recall.\n\nAccording to the CDC report, all 14 ill persons were hospitalized: 4 of the illnesses were related to pregnancy; 2 of these were diagnosed in newborns. Deaths were reported in Minnesota, Nebraska, and New York.\n\nRepresentatives for Forever Cheese claim that all distributors and retailers are being contacted in an effort to recall any and all remaining product in the marketplace. The company encourages consumers with questions to contact Jeff DiMeo at Forever Cheese from 9 a.m. - 5 p.m. ET, (888) 930-8693, and mention Recall. The CDC advises consumers to discard any remaining cheese.\n\nAccording to the Food and Drug Administration, _Listeria_ is an organism that can cause foodborne illness. Symptoms of infection may include fever, muscle aches, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. Pregnant women and adults with weakened immune systems are at the greatest risk, and most healthy adults and children rarely become seriously ill.\n\n[Byline: Nick Dutton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357; Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753; Listeriosis - UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; and Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822.\n\nRicotta is not properly a cheese because it is produced from the whey that separates from the milk during the production of cheese (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricotta). Ricotta Salata is a dried, salty, aged ricotta made from sheep's milk. Ricotta means re-cooked and salata means salted. It is firm, ideal for grating and often used in salads or pasta dishes (http://www.gourmet-food.com/italian-cheese/ricotta-salata-cheese-1000464.aspx).\n\nThe news reports above indicate that _Listeria monocytogenes_ has actually been isolated from the particular lot of ricotta salata cheese that has been recalled, but they do not say whether genotyping has been done on isolates from the ricotta salata and patient specimens to see if there is a match, which would confirm the linkage of this lot of cheese to the clinical cases.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n California (1), Colorado (1), District of Columbia (1), Maryland (3), Minnesota (1), Nebraska (1), New Jersey (1), New Mexico (1), New York (1), Ohio (1), Pennsylvania (1), and Virginia (1). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of listeriosis, please see moderator ML's comments in 4 prior ProMED-mail posts this year (2012): Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643; and Listeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822. \n\nThe news reports above indicate that _Listeria monocytogenes_ has actually been isolated from the particular lot of ricotta salata cheese that has been recalled, but they do not say whether genotyping has been done on isolates from the ricotta salata and patient specimens to see if there is a match, which would confirm the linkage of this lot of cheese to the clinical cases. To the more\nthan 95 percent of subscribers who have not, please donate now:\nhttp://www.isid.org/donate/netathon2011F.shtml - Mod.LM]\n\nDear Colleagues:\n\nThe end of the summer holiday weekend saw 3 people in Colorado in\nhospital complaining of headaches, stiff necks and sore muscles,\nfever, and diarrhea. By Wednesday, their illness was diagnosed. By\nFriday, ProMED was reporting a listeriosis outbreak, by the following\nweek ProMED was following up with confirmation of the culprit -- the\n'smoking' cantaloupes.\n\nMy 1st letter to you when we began this year's ProMED fundraising\nrecounted how this outbreak swept the United States in September and\nOctober 2011. ProMED had alerted the infectious disease community\nwithin days of the outbreak and provided detailed information about\nthe threat of Listeria. But, although these fruits were being\ndistributed throughout North America, a full week passed before the\nstory appeared in a national newspaper, and 2 full weeks before the\nstory was picked up and broadcast by major radio, television, and\nnewspapers. How many unknowing consumers bought and consumed melons\nthat put themselves and their families at risk because of this delay?\n\nProMED's ability to get you news when you want it -- now -- is what\nmakes ProMED so important to your life and work. And that is why it is\nso important that you contribute to keeping ProMED healthy, now!\n\nhttp://www.isid.org/donate/netathon2011F.shtml\n\nNo other source provides the accurate, relevant, and timely emerging\ninfectious disease reporting that ProMED provides multiple times each\nday. Covering the entire One Health spectrum of human, animal, and\ncrop plant diseases, ProMED brings you news and unique expert\ninterpretation and context that informs you about the disease and\nhelps you understand how it might affect you, your family, your\npatients, your business, and your plans. No other source keeps you so\nwell informed on topics you need and want to know about. No other\nsource covers the topic of infectious diseases so broadly, deeply, and\ninternationally. No other source keeps you so\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "P.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "938581", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (14): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=938581", "date": "2011-11-05 16:33:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Nov 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011].\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms has been traced as the cause of what has become one of\nthe deadliest U.S. food-borne outbreaks in U.S. history. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n'indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.'\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n'What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,' food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. 'As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,' said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: 'Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,' or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads 'Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords'\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report. Source: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011]. As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,' said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\n In a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n'indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.' On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination. Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name. The long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "918653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=918653", "date": "2011-10-22 04:03:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (12): CANTALOUPE\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Oct 2011\nFrom: Adrienne LeBailly <alebailly@larimer.org> [edited]\n\n\nJensen Farms is not near Rocky Ford, Colorado. While it's often\nhelpful to have a map link to the area of an outbreak, the map on\nProMED-mail post from issue 492 links to the town of Rocky Ford [CO].\nHowever, the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak, Jensen Farms, is near\nHolly, Colorado, which is nearly 100 miles [161 km] and 2 counties\naway. The Rocky Ford region of Colorado can be found on a map at\nhttp://g.co/maps/prqf4.\n\nThe cantaloupe growers around Rocky Ford have been devastated\neconomically by the outbreak associated with Jensen farms, even though\nthey were not involved in this outbreak. See\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_19084937. It would be helpful in\nfuture posts not to target the Rocky Ford town or immediate region,\nwhich was not the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak.\n\n--\nAdrienne LeBailly\n<alebailly@larimer.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Adrienne LeBailly for bringing to our attention\nthat Holly, Colorado, where Jensen Farm is located, is nearly 90 miles\n(145 km) to the east of Rocky Ford, Colorado. The 2 towns along Route\n50 can be seen on the map accessed at http://g.co/maps/mpq3d. The\ntown of Holly is in Prowers County in south eastern Colorado, 4 miles\n(6.5 km) from the Kansas border\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holly,_Colorado) and Rocky Ford is in\nOtero County, Colorado\n(http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml). Bent\nCounty separates Otero from Prowers County.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of south eastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: 'Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe' or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads 'Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\u201a'\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of south eastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (12): CANTALOUPE\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The\ntown of Holly is in Prowers County in south eastern Colorado, 4 miles\n(6.5 km) from the Kansas border\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holly,_Colorado) and Rocky Ford is in\nOtero County, Colorado\n(http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml). While it's often\nhelpful to have a map link to the area of an outbreak, the map on\nProMED-mail post from issue 492 links to the town of Rocky Ford [CO]. Subsequently cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name. However, the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak, Jensen Farms, is near\nHolly, Colorado, which is nearly 100 miles [161 km] and 2 counties\naway. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of south eastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - It would be helpful in\nfuture posts not to target the Rocky Ford town or immediate region,\nwhich was not the source of the _Listeria_ outbreak. The cantaloupe growers around Rocky Ford have been devastated\neconomically by the outbreak associated with Jensen farms, even though\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Otero County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prowers County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "916599", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=916599", "date": "2011-10-20 15:06:11", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (11): CANTALOUPE, FARM FACTORS\n*******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Oct 2011\nSource: The New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/20/business/listeria-outbreak-traced-to-colorado-cantaloupe-packing-shed.html\n\n\nA nationwide listeria outbreak that has killed 25 people who ate\ntainted cantaloupe was probably caused by unsanitary conditions in the\npacking shed of the Colorado farm where the melons were grown, federal\nofficials said on Wednesday [19 Oct 2011].\n\nGovernment investigators said that workers had tramped through pools\nof water where listeria was likely to grow, tracking the deadly\nbacteria around the shed, which was operated by Jensen Farms, in\nGranada, Colorado. The pathogen was found on a conveyor belt for\ncarrying cantaloupes, a melon drying area and a floor drain, among\nother places.\n\n'You're rolling around cantaloupe on uncleanable equipment and you're\ngetting it wet and you're not cooling it -- it provides the perfect\nenvironment for listeria growth and spread,' said James Gorny, a\nsenior food safety adviser at the Food and Drug Administration [FDA].\n\nThe outbreak, which began in late July 2011, is the deadliest caused\nby foodborne disease since 1985. A total of 123 people in 26 states\nhave fallen ill, including those who died, according to the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNicholas J Parolisi Jr, a lawyer for Jensen Farms, said he could not\ncomment on the FDA's accusations. The farm had passed a food safety\naudit by an outside contractor just days before the outbreak began.\nEric Jensen, a member of the family that runs the farm, said in an\nemail that the auditor had given the packing plant a score of 96\npoints out of 100. FDA officials did not criticize the auditor\ndirectly. But Michael R Taylor, deputy commissioner for foods, said\nthe agency intended to establish standards for how auditors should be\ntrained and how audits should be conducted. The food industry\nincreasingly has come to rely on what it calls 3rd-party audits of\nfarms or processing plants to ensure the safety of food. But the\nauditors are hired by the companies being inspected, and their\nprocedures are largely unregulated. In several recent food safety\nlapses, the facilities involved had passed 3rd-party audits.\n\nIt was not clear how listeria initially got into the packing shed,\nwhich officials described as an open-air structure having a concrete\nfloor, a roof, and no walls. Listeria is frequently found in soil or\nmanure, but tests of the soil on the farm did not turn up the\nbacteria. Officials said that a dump truck used to take culled melons\n[removal of any product that showed signs of physical damage, such as\nskin breaks or decay] to a cattle farm was parked near the processing\nshed and could have brought bacteria to the facility.\n\nJensen Farms, run by Mr Jensen and his brother Ryan, had recently\nacquired a set of used machinery to upgrade the way it washed and\ndried its cantaloupes. The equipment had been used to clean potatoes\nand was not intended for use with cantaloupes, officials said. They\nsaid the equipment was corroded in places and built in a way that made\nit difficult to clean and sanitize. An area used to dry the melons\nincluded a cloth cover that could easily have harbored the bacteria,\naccording to a person who discussed the operation with the Jensens.\n\nOfficials also said that the cantaloupes had not been adequately\ncooled before they were placed in refrigerated storage, which could\nhave caused condensation to form on the fruit, creating hospitable\nconditions for listeria. The bacteria grow well in wet or damp\nconditions and can also thrive in cold.\n\nDr Gorny said that some of the conditions he described, including\npools of water on the floor, had been noted during a visit in\nmid-September 2011 after the plant ceased operation and the equipment\nwas dismantled. It was not clear if investigators who had visited the\nplant while it was still in operation saw the same unsanitary\nconditions. Officials said that conditions at Jensen Farms were not\ntypical of the produce industry. 'We have no reason to believe these\nfactors are indicative of practices throughout the industry,' said\nSherri McGarry, a senior FDA adviser.\n\nThe outbreak is likely to focus new attention on the use of auditors\nin the food industry. Typically farms or processors are required by\ntheir customers, like supermarket or restaurant chains, to have an\nauditor evaluate their food safety procedures. Jensen Farms hired an\nauditor called PrimusLabs, based in California, to inspect its\nfacility. Primus gave the job to a subcontractor, Bio Food Safety,\nwhich is based in Texas. Jensen and Primus declined to provide a copy\nof the audit report.\n\nRobert Stovicek, the president of PrimusLabs, said his company had\nreviewed the audit and found no problems in how it was conducted or in\nthe auditor's conclusions. 'We thought he did a pretty good job,' Mr\nStovicek said. He said the auditor, James M DiIorio, has been doing\naudits for the company since March 2011. He said that Mr DiIorio had\nreceived 2 one-week training courses as part of his preparation and\nhad also gone on audits with other auditors. Asked how Mr DiIorio\ncould have given high marks to a facility that the FDA described as a\nbreeding ground for _Listeria_, Mr Stovicek said, 'There's lots of\nvariations as to how people interpret unsanitary conditions.' Mr\nDiIorio did not return phone calls seeking comment.\n\nTrevor V Suslow, a professor of food safety at the University of\nCalifornia, Davis, said auditors may give farmers, processors, and\nretailers a false sense of security. 'There needs to be training,\ncertification, and auditing of the auditors,' he said.\n\n[byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An FDA draft guidance to minimize microbial hazards of melons (July\n2009) spelled out ways cantaloupes can become contaminated\n(http://www.fda.gov/Food/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/GuidanceDocuments/ProduceandPlanProducts/ucm174171.htm).\nIn this document, more foodborne illness outbreaks were noted to be\nassociated with melons that have netted rinds perhaps because human\npathogens may adhere to, survive on, and be more difficult to\neliminate from netted melon rind surfaces. Specifically, cantaloupe\nwas noted to be involved in 10 of the 13 outbreaks associated with\nmelon consumption and all of the melon-associated outbreaks were due\nto bacterial agents, such as _Salmonella_ species.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is frequently found in soil or manure.\nCantaloupe grow on a vine on the ground and the rind can become\ncontaminated with these enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated\nsoil or fertilizer, but tests of the soil on the farm involved in the\ncurrent outbreak did not turn up the bacteria. Instead this pathogen\nwas found on a conveyor belt for carrying cantaloupes, a melon drying\narea, and a floor drain, among other places. The news release above\ndid not comment on the possibility of contaminated water used to wash\nthe cantaloupe or equipment. _L. monocytogenes_ can be commonly found\nin a wide range of surface waters, including lakes, ponds, and\nstreams, contaminated possibly by discharge of sewage or runoff from\nfarms\n(http://books.google.com/books?id=NZsS6tbSAFYC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq).\nInstead, a dump truck parked near the processing shed used to take\nculled melons to a cattle farm was implicated.\n\nThe Rocky Ford region of Colorado can be found on a map at\nhttp://maps.google.com/maps?client=safari&q=rocky+ford+colorado&oe=UTF-8&ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Rocky+Ford,+Otero,+Colorado&gl=us&t=h&z=14&vpsrc=0.\nThe states of the USA involved in this outbreak can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1e1B. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (11): CANTALOUPE, FARM FACTORS\n*******************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n _L. monocytogenes_ can be commonly found\nin a wide range of surface waters, including lakes, ponds, and\nstreams, contaminated possibly by discharge of sewage or runoff from\nfarms\n \n\n\nA nationwide listeria outbreak that has killed 25 people who ate\ntainted cantaloupe was probably caused by unsanitary conditions in the\npacking shed of the Colorado farm where the melons were grown, federal\nofficials said on Wednesday [19 Oct 2011]. \n\n'You're rolling around cantaloupe on uncleanable equipment and you're\ngetting it wet and you're not cooling it -- it provides the perfect\nenvironment for listeria growth and spread,' said James Gorny, a\nsenior food safety adviser at the Food and Drug Administration [FDA]. \n\nGovernment investigators said that workers had tramped through pools\nof water where listeria was likely to grow, tracking the deadly\nbacteria around the shed, which was operated by Jensen Farms, in\nGranada, Colorado. \n\nOfficials also said that the cantaloupes had not been adequately\ncooled before they were placed in refrigerated storage, which could\nhave caused condensation to form on the fruit, creating hospitable\nconditions for listeria. Dr Gorny said that some of the conditions he described, including\npools of water on the floor, had been noted during a visit in\nmid-September 2011 after the plant ceased operation and the equipment\nwas dismantled. Cantaloupe grow on a vine on the ground and the rind can become\ncontaminated with these enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated\nsoil or fertilizer, but tests of the soil on the farm involved in the\ncurrent outbreak did not turn up the bacteria. Asked how Mr DiIorio\ncould have given high marks to a facility that the FDA described as a\nbreeding ground for _Listeria_, Mr Stovicek said, 'There's lots of\nvariations as to how people interpret unsanitary conditions.' \nEric Jensen, a member of the family that runs the farm, said in an\nemail that the auditor had given the packing plant a score of 96\npoints out of 100. \n\n[byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In this document, more foodborne illness outbreaks were noted to be\nassociated with melons that have netted rinds perhaps because human\npathogens may adhere to, survive on, and be more difficult to\neliminate from netted melon rind surfaces. ' \n\nIt was not clear how listeria initially got into the packing shed,\nwhich officials described as an open-air structure having a concrete\nfloor, a roof, and no walls.
