The latest deaths included one each in Indiana, New York, and\nWyoming.\n\nThe cases have been linked to Rocky Ford brand cantaloupe from Jensen\nFarms in Colorado. Most of those sickened in the outbreak are over the\nage of 60, and the median age is 77. Nearly all patients for whom\ninformation was available -- 105 of 107 -- were hospitalized. CDC\nofficials have called the outbreak the most deadly foodborne disease\nepisode in a decade. Last week officials said they expected reports of\ncases to continue for several weeks, as the incubation time for\nlisteriosis is up to 2 months.\n\nIn a related development, a company in western New York has recalled\n4800 packages containing cantaloupe because of possible _Listeria_\ncontamination related to the Jensen Farms recall, the Associated Press\nreported today. The firm, Fruit Fresh Up Inc. of Depew, said the\nproducts included cantaloupe pieces and various fruit salads sold in\nthe Buffalo area through stores and caterers between 31 Aug and 11 Sep\n[2011], the story said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupe grow on a vine on the ground and the rind can become\ncontaminated with enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated soil,\nfertilizer, or water used for irrigation or washing. Contamination\ncould also occur later during the distribution process. Cutting\nthrough the outer skin can then contaminate the pulp of cantaloupe, if\nwashing of the outside is inadequate. It is therefore important to\nwash the melon thoroughly before cutting into it, since bacteria can\ngrow on the rind. However, because _Listeria_ multiple at refrigerator\ntemperatures, inoculation of the pulp by even low numbers of the\norganism can result in high-grade contamination of refrigerated\nproduct.\n\nThe Rocky Ford region of Colorado can be found on a map at\nhttp://maps.google.com/maps?client=safari&rls=en&q=rocky+ford+colorado&oe=UTF-8&um=1&ie=UTF-8&hq=&hnear=0x87120fd3a2bb35c5:0xeda6a4565b9b796c,Rocky+Ford,+CO&gl=us&ei=8iBwTsiQLKT10gHDntj9CQ&sa=X&oi=geocode_result&ct=image&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ8gEwAA.\nThe states of the USA involved in this outbreak can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1e1B. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (10): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/fs/food-disease/news/oct0711foodnewsscan.html\n\n\nA total of 9 more cases and 3 more deaths have been reported since 3\nOct 2011 in the _Listeria_ outbreak tied to cantaloupe, bringing the\ntotals to 109 cases with 21 deaths, the Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention (CDC) said today (7 Oct 2011) \n4 states -- Iowa, New York, Oregon, and South Dakota -- had their 1st\ncases, raising the number of affected states to 24, the CDC update\nshows. In a related development, a company in western New York has recalled\n4800 packages containing cantaloupe because of possible _Listeria_\ncontamination related to the Jensen Farms recall, the Associated Press\nreported today. The firm, Fruit Fresh Up Inc. of Depew, said the\nproducts included cantaloupe pieces and various fruit salads sold in\nthe Buffalo area through stores and caterers between 31 Aug and 11 Sep\n However, because _Listeria_ multiple at refrigerator\ntemperatures, inoculation of the pulp by even low numbers of the\norganism can result in high-grade contamination of refrigerated\nproduct. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupe grow on a vine on the ground and the rind can become\ncontaminated with enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated soil,\nfertilizer, or water used for irrigation or washing. Last week officials said they expected reports of\ncases to continue for several weeks, as the incubation time for\nlisteriosis is up to 2 months. The states of the USA involved in this outbreak can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1e1B. - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-26 00:00:00", "1977-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-10-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "924461", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=924461", "date": "2011-10-26 20:07:05", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (13): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue Oct 25 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/25/us-listeria-idUSTRE79O8PE20111025\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupes in the\nUnited States has climbed to 28, the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention said on Tue Oct 25 2011.\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms have been traced as the cause of what has become the\ndeadliest U.S. food-borne listeriosis outbreak in a quarter century.\n\nA total of 133 people in 26 states have fallen ill so far in the\noutbreak, and the CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the\ntime she fell ill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak in the United\nStates was in 1985 when a Jalisco Products' Mexican-style soft cheese\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ killed 18 adults and 10 newborns and\ncaused 20 miscarriages.\n\nThe illness has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume _Listeria_-tainted\nfoods. In a warning letter to Jensen Farms on 18 Oct 2011, the U.S.\nFood and Drug Administration said testing turned up widespread\n_Listeria_ contamination at its Granada, Colorado packing plant, which\n'indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.'\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from listeriosis. Symptoms include\nfever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and other\ngastric problems.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Greg McCune, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jensen Farms, where the _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe were\ngrown, has been variously located either in Holly, Colorado\n(ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more\ncases & deaths 20110930.2950) or, according to the above news release,\nin Granada, Colorado. Like Holly, Granada is also located in Prowers\nCounty, Colorado. Granada is nearly 80 miles (145 km) to the east of\nRocky Ford, Colorado and is the site of a Japanese American internment\ncamp during World War II, south of US 50\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granada,_Colorado).\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: 'Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,' or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads 'Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords'\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jensen Farms, where the _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe were\ngrown, has been variously located either in Holly, Colorado\n(ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more\ncases & deaths 20110930.2950) or, according to the above news release,\nin Granada, Colorado. LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (13): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak in the United\nStates was in 1985 when a Jalisco Products' Mexican-style soft cheese\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ killed 18 adults and 10 newborns and\ncaused 20 miscarriages. In a warning letter to Jensen Farms on 18 Oct 2011, the U.S.\nFood and Drug Administration said testing turned up widespread\n_Listeria_ contamination at its Granada, Colorado packing plant, which\n'indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.' Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name. A total of 133 people in 26 states have fallen ill so far in the\noutbreak, and the CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the\ntime she fell ill, had a miscarriage. \n\nThe illness has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume _Listeria_-tainted\nfoods. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Produce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,' or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads 'Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords'\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "893555", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=893555", "date": "2011-10-01 07:15:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (08): BACKGROUND\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2011\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network)\n[edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more\ncases & deaths 20110930.2950\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough _Listeria monocytogenes_ is a relatively uncommon cause of\nfoodborne infection, this species is associated with a\ndisproportionately high mortality rate. In fact, the number of\nAmerican deaths due to listeriosis (graph 1) is strikingly similar to\nthat caused by salmonellosis, despite the fact that salmonellosis is\nover 60-fold more common than listeriosis (graph 2). [1,2]\n\nGraph 1: Foodborne bacteria: deaths, United States\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/FoodDeaths-US.png.\nGraph 2: Foodborne bacteria: cases, United States\nhttp://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/FoodCase-US.png.\n\n(See the Graph tool tutorial at\nhttp://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps)\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA: Infectious Diseases of the United States, 2011. 1030 pp,\n464 graphs, 8237 references. GIDEON ebooks,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-the-united-states/.\n2. Berger SA: Listeriosis: Global Status, 2011. 93 pp, 103 graphs, 487\nreferences. GIDEON ebooks,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail once again thanks Dr Berger for his background reports. -\nMod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (08): BACKGROUND\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In fact, the number of\nAmerican deaths due to listeriosis (graph 1) is strikingly similar to\nthat caused by salmonellosis, despite the fact that salmonellosis is\nover 60-fold more common than listeriosis (graph 2). \n\n(See the Graph tool tutorial at\nhttp://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps)\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail once again thanks Dr Berger for his background reports. -\nMod. Re: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more\ncases & deaths 20110930.2950\n Although _Listeria monocytogenes_ is a relatively uncommon cause of\nfoodborne infection, this species is associated with a\ndisproportionately high mortality rate. GIDEON ebooks,\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/.\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "1030-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "893557", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=893557", "date": "2011-10-01 07:20:42", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: ROMAINE LETTUCE, RECALL\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2011\nSource: CBS News, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/09/30/health/main20113757.shtml\n\n\nAlaska officials say bags of chopped romaine lettuce are being\nrecalled over concerns of potential _Listeria_ contamination.\nMeanwhile, a California farm said Thursday [29 Sep 2011] it was\nvoluntarily recalling bags of chopped romaine lettuce because of\npossible contamination, though no illnesses have been reported.\n\nThe Alaska Department of Conservation has confirmed that the 2-pound\nbags of chopped romaine lettuce from True Leaf Farms of Salinas,\nCalifornia, which have a use-by date of 29 Sep 2011, were distributed\nin Alaska by Church Brothers, LLC.\n\nThere have been no reported illnesses, but listeriosis can be fatal\nand is particularly dangerous to people with weakened immune systems,\nincluding infants, the elderly and people with HIV or those who are\nundergoing chemotherapy.\n\n_Listeria_ rarely shows up in produce, but an outbreak linked to\ncantaloupe from a Colorado farm has caused at least 72 illnesses,\nincluding up to 16 deaths, in 18 states.\n\nOfficials urge those who purchased the potentially tainted product,\nwhich carries a bag and box code of B256-46438-8, to throw it out.\nPreviously, True Leaf Farms announced the recall of 90 cartons that\nwere shipped to an Oregon food service distributor. From the\ndistributor, it might have gone to at least 2 other states, Washington\nand Idaho.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration notified the company that a sample\nfrom one bag taken as part of a random check tested positive for\n_Listeria_. Federal health officials say they've gotten better at\ndetecting the germs that cause food poisoning, so they are seeing them\nin produce more often.\n\nCalifornia health officials are looking into the contamination, said\nKen August, spokesman for the California Department of Public Health,\nbut have not yet determined how the lettuce became contaminated.\n'Anytime there is a contaminated food product, we are concerned and\ntake steps so that it's removed from shelves as quickly as possible\nand to notify consumers,' he said. August said the state is working\nwith the company to verify the distribution of the produce being\nrecalled. Most of the lettuce was sold to California institutions such\nas restaurants and cafeterias, he said, and only a small amount went\nto retail in other states, August said.\n\nThe Salinas Valley is known as the 'Salad Bowl of the World' for its\nproduction of lettuce and numerous other crops. Lettuce currently\npicked at the farm is safe to eat, said Steve Church, CEO of Church\nBrothers, which sells and markets the farm's produce. The company is\nworking with the FDA, Church said, to determine if there are any\nproblems at the farm and is taking more time to sanitize its produce.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail posts this recall of _Listeria_-contaminated romaine\nlettuce, even though no human cases of listeriosis have been\nassociated with this food product at this time, because of the\npotential morbidity and disproportionately high mortality caused by\nthis food-borne infection (Farber JM, Peterkin PI: _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, a food-borne pathogen. Microbiol Rev. 1991; 55(3):\n476-511; available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC372831. Ramaswamy V,\nCresence VM, Rejitha JS, et al: _Listeria_ -- review of epidemiology\nand pathogenesis. J Microbiol Immunol Infect. 2007; 40(1): 4-13;\navailable at\nhttp://www.sochinf.cl/documentos/infectologia/listeria.pdf).\n\nListeriosis is especially severe among infants, the elderly, and those\nwith immune deficiency. _Listeria_ can be passed to a fetus through\nthe placenta and lead to premature delivery, miscarriage, and\nstillbirth. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail posts this recall of _Listeria_-contaminated romaine\nlettuce, even though no human cases of listeriosis have been\nassociated with this food product at this time, because of the\npotential morbidity and disproportionately high mortality caused by\nthis food-borne infection (Farber JM, Peterkin PI: _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, a food-borne pathogen. The company is\nworking with the FDA, Church said, to determine if there are any\nproblems at the farm and is taking more time to sanitize its produce.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThere have been no reported illnesses, but listeriosis can be fatal\nand is particularly dangerous to people with weakened immune systems,\nincluding infants, the elderly and people with HIV or those who are\nundergoing chemotherapy. The Alaska Department of Conservation has confirmed that the 2-pound\nbags of chopped romaine lettuce from True Leaf Farms of Salinas,\nCalifornia, which have a use-by date of 29 Sep 2011, were distributed\nin Alaska by Church Brothers, LLC. \nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Meanwhile, a California farm said Thursday [29 Sep 2011] it was\nvoluntarily recalling bags of chopped romaine lettuce because of\npossible contamination, though no illnesses have been reported. \n\nCalifornia health officials are looking into the contamination, said\nKen August, spokesman for the California Department of Public Health,\nbut have not yet determined how the lettuce became contaminated. \n\n_Listeria_ rarely shows up in produce, but an outbreak linked to\ncantaloupe from a Colorado farm has caused at least 72 illnesses,\nincluding up to 16 deaths, in 18 states. LISTERIOSIS - USA: ROMAINE LETTUCE, RECALL\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org Most of the lettuce was sold to California institutions such\nas restaurants and cafeterias, he said, and only a small amount went\nto retail in other states, August said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-09-29 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "1991-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "897817", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=897817", "date": "2011-10-05 08:44:37", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (09): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2011\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2011; 60 (early release); 1-2\n[edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm60e0930a1.htm?s_cid=mm60e0930a1_w\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis associated with Jensen Farms\ncantaloupe - United States, August-September 2011\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nListeriosis is caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive\nbacillus common in the environment and acquired by humans primarily\nthrough consumption of contaminated food. Infection causes a spectrum\nof illness, ranging from febrile gastroenteritis to invasive disease,\nincluding sepsis and meningoencephalitis. Invasive listeriosis occurs\npredominantly in older adults and persons with impaired immune\nsystems. Listeriosis in pregnant women is typically a mild 'flu-like'\nillness, but can result in fetal loss, premature labor, or neonatal\ninfection. Listeriosis is treated with antibiotics. On 2 Sep 2011, the\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) notified\nCDC of 7 cases of listeriosis reported since 28 Aug 2011. On average,\nColorado reports 2 cases of listeriosis annually in August. By 6 Sep\n2011, all 7 Colorado patients interviewed with the Listeria Initiative\nquestionnaire reported eating cantaloupe in the month before illness\nbegan, and 3 reported eating cantaloupe marketed as 'Rocky Ford.'\n\nA case was defined as illness with one of the outbreak strains\nisolated on or after 1 Aug 2011. Outbreak strains initially were\ndefined as: 1) clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ with\nspecimen collection dates in August 2011; 2) with a 2-enzyme,\npulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern combination that\noccurred in 2 or more persons; and 3) that matched any of the 2\npattern combinations found among Colorado residents in August 2011.\nAnalysis of Listeria Initiative data comparing the 1st 19\noutbreak-associated cases in 2011 with 85 cases among persons aged 65\nyears or greater with sporadic listeriosis identified during August of\nthe years 2004-2010 indicated that cantaloupe consumption was strongly\nassociated with illness caused by the outbreak strains: 19 of 19 (100\npercent) versus 54 of 85 (64 percent); (odds ratio = 14.9; 95 percent\nCI = 2.4-infinity). Initial tracebacks of cantaloupe purchased by\npatients converged on Jensen Farms in Colorado.\n\nAfter cantaloupe was implicated, PulseNet, the national molecular\nsubtyping network for foodborne bacterial disease surveillance,\ndetected a multistate cluster with a 4th PFGE pattern combination; a\nsample of cantaloupe collected from the implicated farm yielded _L.\nmonocytogenes_ with this pattern, and interviews with patients\nrevealed that most had consumed cantaloupe. Isolates with this pattern\nwere then also considered to be among the outbreak strains. By 29 Sep\n2011, 84 cases with one of the 4 outbreak PFGE pattern combinations\nhad been reported from 19 states, including 83 with information on the\ndate of illness onset. Among the patients, 88 percent were aged 60\nyears or greater (range: 35-96 years); 55 percent were female, and 2\nwere pregnant. 15 deaths were reported. 92 percent (57 of 62 with\ninformation on food consumption) reported eating cantaloupe in the\nmonth before illness began. All 4 outbreak strains of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ were isolated from whole and cut cantaloupe samples\nfrom patients' homes or from samples of Jensen Farms cantaloupe\ncollected from grocery stores and the farm. On 14 Sep 2011, the farm\nissued a voluntary recall of its cantaloupe.\n\nThis outbreak has several unusual features. First, this is the 1st\nlisteriosis outbreak associated with melon. Second, 4 widely differing\nPFGE pattern combinations and 2 serotypes (1/2a and 1/2b) have been\nassociated with the outbreak. Third, this outbreak is unusually large;\nonly 2 US listeriosis outbreaks, one associated with frankfurters (108\ncases) and one with Mexican-style cheese (142), have had more cases\n[1,2]. Additional cases likely will be reported because of the long\nincubation period (usually 1-3 weeks, range: 3-70 days) and the time\nneeded for diagnosis and confirmation. Fourth, this outbreak has the\nhighest number of deaths of any US foodborne outbreak since a\nlisteriosis outbreak in 1998 [1].\n\nCDC recommends that persons do not eat cantaloupes from Jensen Farms.\nThis recommendation is especially important for persons at greater\nrisk for listeriosis, including older adults, persons with weakened\nimmune systems, and pregnant women. Not all of the recalled\ncantaloupes are individually labeled with stickers to indicate\nproduction by Jensen Farms. Consumers should consult the retailer or\ndiscard any cantaloupe of uncertain origin. Recommendations for\npreventing listeriosis from other foods are available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria.\n\n[Reported by\nShaun Cosgrove, Alicia Cronquist, Colorado Dept of Public Health and\nEnvironment. Gail Wright, Boulder County Public Health. Tista Ghosh,\nRichard Vogt, Tri-County Health Department. Paul Teitell,\nInvestigations Br, Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Denver District.\nAllen Gelfius, Charlotte Spires, Tracy Duvernoy, Sheila Merriweather,\nFDA Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation (CORE) Network. Molly\nFreeman, Patricia M. Griffin, Kelly A. Jackson, Lavin A. Joseph,\nBarbara E. Mahon, Karen Neil, Benjamin J. Silk, Cheryl Tarr, Robert\nTauxe, Eija Trees, Div of Foodborne, Waterborne, and Environmental\nDiseases, National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious\nDiseases; Mam Ibraheem, Maho Imanishi, Neena Jain, Jeffrey McCollum,\nKatherine A. O'Connor, EIS officers, CDC. Corresponding contributor:\nKelly A. Jackson, <gqv8@cdc.gov>]\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Mead, PS, Dunne EF, Graves L, et al: Nationwide outbreak of\nlisteriosis due to contaminated meat. Epidemiol Infect 2006; 134(4):\n744-51 [available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2870438].\n2. Linnan, MJ, Mascola L, Lou XD, et al: Epidemic listeriosis\nassociated with Mexican-style cheese. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(13):\n823-8 [abstract available at\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198809293191303].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 4 Oct 2011\nSource: US CDC, Listeriosis (_Listeria_ infection) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to whole cantaloupes from\nJensen Farms, Colorado. Today's highlights, 4 Oct 2011\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAs of 11 am EDT on 3 Oct 2011, a total of 100 persons infected with\nany of the 4 outbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_\nhave been reported to CDC from 20 states. All illnesses started on or\nafter 31 Jul 2011. The number of infected persons identified in each\nstate is as follows: Alabama (1), Arkansas (1) California (1),\nColorado (30), Idaho (1), Illinois (1), Indiana (2), Kansas (7),\nMaryland (1), Missouri (3), Montana (1), Nebraska (6), New Mexico\n(13), North Dakota (1), Oklahoma (11), Texas (14), Virginia (1), West\nVirginia (1), Wisconsin (2), and Wyoming (2).\n\n18 deaths have been reported: 5 in Colorado, 2 in Kansas, 1 in\nMaryland, 1 in Missouri, 1 in Nebraska, 5 in New Mexico, 1 in\nOklahoma, and 2 in Texas.\n\nOn 14 Sep 2011, FDA issued a press release to announce that Jensen\nFarms issued a voluntary recall of its Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupes\nafter being linked to a multistate outbreak of listeriosis. Although\nJensen Farms issued a voluntary recall of Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupes\non 14 Sep 2011 and the recalled cantaloupe should be off store\nshelves, more ill persons may be reported because of the time lag\nbetween diagnosis and laboratory confirmation and also because up to 2\nmonths can elapse between eating contaminated food and developing\nlisteriosis. CDC recommends that consumers not eat Rocky Ford-brand\ncantaloupe from Jensen Farms. This is especially important for older\nadults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant women. Even\nif some of the cantaloupe has been eaten without becoming ill, dispose\nof the rest of the cantaloupe immediately.\n\n_Listeria_ bacteria can grow in the cantaloupe at room and\nrefrigerator temperatures.\n\nCantaloupes that are known to NOT have come from Jensen Farms are safe\nto eat. If consumers are uncertain about the source of a cantaloupe\nfor purchase, they should ask the grocery store. A cantaloupe\npurchased from an unknown source should be discarded: 'when in doubt,\nthrow it out.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2011\nSource: Bloomberg Businessweek [edited]\nhttp://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9Q4VLJG1.htm\n\n\nAn elderly woman from East Baton Rouge Parish died over the weekend\n[1-2 Oct 2011] after being diagnosed with listeriosis, Louisiana's\nstate epidemiologist, Dr Raoult Ratard, said Monday [3 Oct 2011]. The\nwoman had eaten cantaloupe 2 or 3 weeks earlier, but her family didn't\nknow which store or state it came from, he said.\n\nInvestigators will try to learn whether the _Listeria_ is the same\nstrain found in Colorado cantaloupe recalled because of the bacterium,\nbut it will take at least a week to grow and test the bacteria and the\ntests may be inconclusive, Ratard said.\n\nCantaloupe from Jensen Farms in Colorado has been linked to 84\nillnesses and as many as 17 deaths in 19 states.\n\nState officials said Friday [30 Sep 2011] that Jensen Farms had added\nLouisiana to its recall list for cantaloupes shipped between 29 Jul\nand 10 Sep 2011.\n\nThe fatal infection is the only listeriosis case reported since July\n2011 in Louisiana, Ratard said. 'By now any (recalled) cantaloupe left\nwould be rotten. So it looks like the danger from cantaloupe is very\nlow now,' Ratard said. 'But you never know. Something else may come\nup.'\n\n_Listeria_ is common in soil and water, according to the Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention. The CDC's website says it can be found\nin uncooked meats and vegetables, unpasteurized milk and cheese made\nfrom unpasteurized milk, and processed meats, smoked seafood, and soft\ncheeses that become contaminated after cooking and processing. And\nsince it can take a month or more for symptoms to show up, people who\nate contaminated cantaloupe before the recall could still get sick.\n\nSymptoms can vary widely. The CDC says older adults and people with\nimmune system disorders are most likely to develop blood poisoning and\nmeningitis, which can cause headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of\nbalance, and convulsions. Pregnant women may have a mild, flu-like\nillness followed by a miscarriage or a life-threatening illness in the\nnewborn. People whose immune systems are in good shape may not feel\nsick or might get high fever and muscle aches, with diarrhea, nausea,\nor vomiting sometimes coming first.\n\n[Byline: Janet McConnaughey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 3 Oct 2011, a total of 100 persons infected with any of the 4\noutbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been\nreported to CDC from 20 states. 18 deaths were reported from 8 states.\nListeriosis is known to be more severe in the elderly and almost 90\npercent were 60 years of age or greater in the current outbreak. 2\nwere pregnant. Although, most pregnant women may experience mild\nillness, maternal bacteremia can result in intrauterine infection that\nmay be followed by fetal loss or neonatal infection. No mention is\nmade of associated miscarriages, stillbirths, or neonatal infection in\nthis current outbreak. More cases likely will be reported because of\nthe long incubation period (up to one month or more) and the time\nneeded for diagnosis of this disease.\n\nFor comparison, in a prior large, national listeriosis outbreak that\nwas associated with contaminated frankfurters, 108 cases were reported\nwith 14 associated deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths (Mead, PS,\nDunne EF, Graves L, et al: Nationwide outbreak of listeriosis due to\ncontaminated meat. Epidemiol Infect 2006; 134(4): 744-51; available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2870438) and in a prior\nlarge outbreak that was associated with Mexican-style cheese, 142\ncases were reported with 48 deaths: 20 fetuses, 10 neonates, and 18\nnon pregnant adults (Linnan, MJ, Mascola L, Lou XD, et al: Epidemic\nlisteriosis associated with Mexican-style cheese. N Engl J Med 1988;\n319(13): 823-8; abstract available at\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198809293191303). - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Analysis of Listeria Initiative data comparing the 1st 19\noutbreak-associated cases in 2011 with 85 cases among persons aged 65\nyears or greater with sporadic listeriosis identified during August of\nthe years 2004-2010 indicated that cantaloupe consumption was strongly\nassociated with illness caused by the outbreak strains: 19 of 19 (100\npercent) versus 54 of 85 (64 percent); (odds ratio = 14.9; 95 percent\nCI = 2.4-infinity). Although\nJensen Farms issued a voluntary recall of Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupes\non 14 Sep 2011 and the recalled cantaloupe should be off store\nshelves, more ill persons may be reported because of the time lag\nbetween diagnosis and laboratory confirmation and also because up to 2\nmonths can elapse between eating contaminated food and developing\nlisteriosis. LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (09): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The number of infected persons identified in each\nstate is as follows: Alabama (1), Arkansas (1) California (1),\nColorado (30), Idaho (1), Illinois (1), Indiana (2), Kansas (7),\nMaryland (1), Missouri (3), Montana (1), Nebraska (6), New Mexico\n(13), North Dakota (1), Oklahoma (11), Texas (14), Virginia (1), West\nVirginia (1), Wisconsin (2), and Wyoming (2). Outbreak strains initially were\ndefined as: 1) clinical isolates of _Listeria monocytogenes_ with\nspecimen collection dates in August 2011; 2) with a 2-enzyme,\npulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern combination that\noccurred in 2 or more persons; and 3) that matched any of the 2\npattern combinations found among Colorado residents in August 2011. Epidemiol Infect 2006; 134(4): 744-51; available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2870438) and in a prior\nlarge outbreak that was associated with Mexican-style cheese, 142\ncases were reported with 48 deaths: 20 fetuses, 10 neonates, and 18\nnon pregnant adults (Linnan, MJ, Mascola L, Lou XD, et al: Epidemic\nlisteriosis associated with Mexican-style cheese. \n\nAfter cantaloupe was implicated, PulseNet, the national molecular\nsubtyping network for foodborne bacterial disease surveillance,\ndetected a multistate cluster with a 4th PFGE pattern combination; a\nsample of cantaloupe collected from the implicated farm yielded _L.\nmonocytogenes_ with this pattern, and interviews with patients\nrevealed that most had consumed cantaloupe. A cantaloupe\npurchased from an unknown source should be discarded: 'when in doubt,\nthrow it out.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< For comparison, in a prior large, national listeriosis outbreak that\nwas associated with contaminated frankfurters, 108 cases were reported\nwith 14 associated deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths (Mead, PS,\nDunne EF, Graves L, et al: Nationwide outbreak of listeriosis due to\ncontaminated meat. Freeman, Patricia M. Griffin, Kelly A. Jackson, Lavin A. Joseph,\nBarbara E. Mahon, Karen Neil, Benjamin J. Silk, Cheryl Tarr, Robert\nTauxe, Eija Trees, Div of Foodborne, Waterborne, and Environmental\nDiseases, National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious\nDiseases; Mam Ibraheem, Maho Imanishi, Neena Jain, Jeffrey McCollum,\nKatherine A. O'Connor, EIS officers, CDC. By 6 Sep\n2011, all 7 Colorado patients interviewed with the Listeria Initiative\nquestionnaire reported eating cantaloupe in the month before illness\nbegan, and 3 reported eating cantaloupe marketed as 'Rocky Ford.' By 29 Sep\n2011, 84 cases with one of the 4 outbreak PFGE pattern combinations\nhad been reported from 19 states, including 83 with information on the\ndate of illness onset. Third, this outbreak is unusually large;\nonly 2 US listeriosis outbreaks, one associated with frankfurters (108\ncases) and one with Mexican-style cheese (142), have had more cases\n All 4 outbreak strains of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ were isolated from whole and cut cantaloupe samples\nfrom patients' homes or from samples of Jensen Farms cantaloupe\ncollected from grocery stores and the farm. Corresponding contributor:\nKelly A. Jackson, <gqv8@cdc.gov>]\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. \nListeriosis is caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, a gram-positive\nbacillus common in the environment and acquired by humans primarily\nthrough consumption of contaminated food. The CDC's website says it can be found\nin uncooked meats and vegetables, unpasteurized milk and cheese made\nfrom unpasteurized milk, and processed meats, smoked seafood, and soft\ncheeses that become contaminated after cooking and processing. The CDC says older adults and people with\nimmune system disorders are most likely to develop blood poisoning and\nmeningitis, which can cause headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of\nbalance, and convulsions. \n\n18 deaths have been reported: 5 in Colorado, 2 in Kansas, 1 in\nMaryland, 1 in Missouri, 1 in Nebraska, 5 in New Mexico, 1 in\nOklahoma, and 2 in Texas. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 3 Oct 2011, a total of 100 persons infected with any of the 4\noutbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been\nreported to CDC from 20 states. As of 11 am EDT on 3 Oct 2011, a total of 100 persons infected with\nany of the 4 outbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_\nhave been reported to CDC from 20 states. Fourth, this outbreak has the\nhighest number of deaths of any US foodborne outbreak since a\nlisteriosis outbreak in 1998 [1]. On 2 Sep 2011, the\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) notified\nCDC of 7 cases of listeriosis reported since 28 Aug 2011. http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm60e0930a1.htm?s_cid=mm60e0930a1_w\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis associated with Jensen Farms\ncantaloupe - United States, August-September 2011\n On 14 Sep 2011, FDA issued a press release to announce that Jensen\nFarms issued a voluntary recall of its Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupes\nafter being linked to a multistate outbreak of listeriosis. Additional cases likely will be reported because of the long\nincubation period (usually 1-3 weeks, range: 3-70 days) and the time\nneeded for diagnosis and confirmation. Second, 4 widely differing\nPFGE pattern combinations and 2 serotypes (1/2a and 1/2b) have been\nassociated with the outbreak. The\nwoman had eaten cantaloupe 2 or 3 weeks earlier, but her family didn't\nknow which store or state it came from, he said. 92 percent (57 of 62 with\ninformation on food consumption) reported eating cantaloupe in the\nmonth before illness began. Listeriosis in pregnant women is typically a mild 'flu-like'\nillness, but can result in fetal loss, premature labor, or neonatal\ninfection. Date: Tue 4 Oct 2011\nSource: US CDC, Listeriosis (_Listeria_ infection) [edited]\n \n\nInvestigators will try to learn whether the _Listeria_ is the same\nstrain found in Colorado cantaloupe recalled because of the bacterium,\n Even\nif some of the cantaloupe has been eaten without becoming ill, dispose\nof the rest of the cantaloupe immediately. No mention is\nmade of associated miscarriages, stillbirths, or neonatal infection in\nthis current outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2011-07-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2011-09-06 00:00:00", "2011-08-28 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "1988-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-02 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "- United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Louisiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "881617", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=881617", "date": "2011-09-22 09:03:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (05): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 21 Sep 2011\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/nczved/divisions/dfbmd/diseases/listeriosis/092111.htm\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states,\nincluding Colorado, and the FDA to investigate a multistate outbreak\nof listeriosis. Listeriosis is a serious infection usually caused by\neating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nInvestigators are using DNA analysis of Listeria isolated from\npatients to identify cases of illness that may be part of this\noutbreak. The _Listeria_ bacteria are obtained from diagnostic\ntesting; pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) is used to determine\nDNA fingerprint patterns. Investigators are using data from PulseNet,\nthe national subtyping network made up of state and local public\nhealth laboratories and federal food regulatory laboratories that\nperform molecular surveillance of foodborne infections.\n\nAs of 5pm EDT on 20 Sep 2011, a total of 55 persons infected with the\n4 outbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been\nreported from 14 states. All illnesses started on or after 4 Aug 2011.\nThe number of infected persons identified in each state is as follows:\nCalifornia (1), Colorado (14), Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Maryland\n(1), Montana (1), Nebraska (4), New Mexico (10), Oklahoma (8), Texas\n(9), Virginia (1), West Virginia (1), Wisconsin (2), and Wyoming (1).\nListeriosis illnesses in several other states are currently being\ninvestigated by state and local health departments to determine\nwhether they are part of this outbreak.\n\nPatient ages range from 35 to 96 years, with a median age of 78 years\nold. Most ill persons are over 60 years old or have health conditions\nthat weaken the immune system. 59 percent of ill persons are female.\nAmong the 43 ill persons with available information on whether they\nwere hospitalized, all were hospitalized. Eight deaths have been\nreported, 2 in Colorado, one in Maryland, 4 in New Mexico, and one in\nOklahoma.\n\nAbout 800 cases of Listeria infection are diagnosed each year in the\nUSA, along with 3 or 4 outbreaks of Listeria-associated foodborne\nillness. The foods that typically cause these outbreaks have been deli\nmeats, hot dogs, and Mexican-style soft cheeses made with\nunpasteurized milk. Produce is not often identified as a source, but\nsprouts caused an outbreak in 2009, and celery caused an outbreak in\n2010.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 21 Sep 2011\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/business/cdc-says-8-people-are-dead-in-listeria-outbreak-traced-to-colorado-cantaloupe/2011/09/21/gIQAPMyrlK_story.html\n\n\nThe death toll has risen to 8 in an outbreak of listeria traced to\nColorado-grown cantaloupes, officials said Wednesday [21 Sep 2011].\n\nThe CDC said that a person in Maryland died from eating the tainted\nproduce. Four deaths have been reported in New Mexico and 2 in\nColorado, and one person has died in Oklahoma.\n\nThe CDC said 55 people in 14 states have now been confirmed as\nsickened from eating the cantaloupes. On Mon 19 Sep 2011, the CDC\nreported 4 deaths and 35 illnesses in 10 states.\n\nThe death count, the highest in a known food outbreak since tainted\npeanuts were linked to 9 deaths almost 3 years ago, could go even\nhigher. The CDC said illnesses in several other states potentially\nconnected to the outbreak were under investigation.\n\nHealth officials have said they think the number of illnesses and\ndeaths could continue to grow because the incubation period for\nlisteria can be up to a month. Unlike many pathogens, listeria\nbacteria can grow at room and refrigerator temperatures. The FDA and\nCDC recommend anyone who may have one of the contaminated cantaloupes\nthrow it out immediately.\n\nAbout 800 cases of listeria are found in the United States each year,\naccording to CDC, and there usually are 3 or 4 outbreaks. Most of\nthese are traced to deli meat and soft cheeses, where listeria is most\ncommon. Produce has rarely been the culprit, but federal investigators\nsay they have seen more produce-related listeria illnesses in the past\n2 years. It was found in sprouts in 2009 and celery in 2010.\n\nWhile most healthy adults can consume listeria with no ill effects, it\ncan kill the elderly and those with compromised immune systems. It is\nalso dangerous to pregnant women because it easily passes through to\nthe fetus. In the current outbreak, the median age of those sickened\nis 78, according to the CDC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the 2 days since the last update, the number of cases has\nincreased from 35 to 55, the deaths from 4 to 8, and the states\ninvolved from 10 to 14. As noted in the AP report, this _Listeria_\noutbreak is quickly approaching the number of deaths associated with a\n_Salmonella enterica_ serotype Typhimurium outbreak linked to peanut\nbutter in 2009, although more than 600 cases were reported.\n\nMore cases are likely to be included in this growing outbreak in the\ndays to come. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (05): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The number of infected persons identified in each state is as follows:\nCalifornia (1), Colorado (14), Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Maryland\n(1), Montana (1), Nebraska (4), New Mexico (10), Oklahoma (8), Texas\n As noted in the AP report, this _Listeria_\noutbreak is quickly approaching the number of deaths associated with a\n_Salmonella enterica_ serotype Typhimurium outbreak linked to peanut\nbutter in 2009, although more than 600 cases were reported. Investigators are using data from PulseNet,\nthe national subtyping network made up of state and local public\nhealth laboratories and federal food regulatory laboratories that\nperform molecular surveillance of foodborne infections. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the 2 days since the last update, the number of cases has\nincreased from 35 to 55, the deaths from 4 to 8, and the states\ninvolved from 10 to 14. As of 5pm EDT on 20 Sep 2011, a total of 55 persons infected with the\n4 outbreak-associated strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been\nreported from 14 states. \n\nAbout 800 cases of Listeria infection are diagnosed each year in the\nUSA, along with 3 or 4 outbreaks of Listeria-associated foodborne\nillness. \n\nThe death count, the highest in a known food outbreak since tainted\npeanuts were linked to 9 deaths almost 3 years ago, could go even\nhigher. \n\nHealth officials have said they think the number of illnesses and\ndeaths could continue to grow because the incubation period for\nlisteria can be up to a month. Produce is not often identified as a source, but\nsprouts caused an outbreak in 2009, and celery caused an outbreak in\n2010. Listeriosis illnesses in several other states are currently being\ninvestigated by state and local health departments to determine\nwhether they are part of this outbreak. http://www.cdc.gov/nczved/divisions/dfbmd/diseases/listeriosis/092111.htm\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states,\nincluding Colorado, and the FDA to investigate a multistate outbreak\nof listeriosis. Produce has rarely been the culprit, but federal investigators\nsay they have seen more produce-related listeria illnesses in the past\n2 years. Investigators are using DNA analysis of Listeria isolated from\npatients to identify cases of illness that may be part of this\noutbreak. Eight deaths have been\nreported, 2 in Colorado, one in Maryland, 4 in New Mexico, and one in\nOklahoma. The _Listeria_ bacteria are obtained from diagnostic\ntesting; pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) is used to determine\nDNA fingerprint patterns. The foods that typically cause these outbreaks have been deli\nmeats, hot dogs, and Mexican-style soft cheeses made with\nunpasteurized milk.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "1978-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2011-09-21 00:00:00", "2011-09-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Listeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "880073", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=880073", "date": "2011-09-21 10:49:19", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (04): CANTALOUPE, ALERT\n************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] CDC update\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: CDC [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/nczved/divisions/dfbmd/diseases/listeriosis/091911.html\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states,\nincluding Colorado, and the FDA to investigate a multistate outbreak\nof listeriosis. Listeriosis is a serious infection usually caused by\neating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nInvestigators are using DNA analysis of Listeria isolated from\npatients to identify cases of illness that may be part of this\noutbreak. The Listeria bacteria are obtained from diagnostic testing;\npulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) is used to determine DNA\nfingerprint patterns. Investigators are using data from PulseNet, the\nnational subtyping network made up of state and local public health\nlaboratories and federal food regulatory laboratories that performs\nmolecular surveillance of foodborne infections.\n\nA total of 35 persons infected with the outbreak-associated strains of\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. All\nillnesses started on or after 4 Aug 2011. The number of infected\npersons identified in each state is as follows: California (1),\nColorado (12), Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Montana (1), Nebraska (4),\nNew Mexico (5), Oklahoma (6), Texas (3), and West Virginia (1).\nListeriosis illnesses in several other states are currently being\ninvestigated by state and local health departments to determine\nwhether they are part of this outbreak.\n\nThe ages of those infected range from 35 to 96 years, with a median\nage of 81 years old. Most ill persons are over 60 years old or have\nhealth conditions that weaken the immune system. 65 percent of ill\npersons are female. Among the 28 ill persons with available\ninformation on whether they were hospitalized, all were hospitalized.\nFour deaths have been reported: one in Colorado, one in Oklahoma, and\n2 in New Mexico.\n\nAbout 800 cases of Listeria infection are diagnosed each year in the\nUSA, along with 3 or 4 outbreaks of Listeria-associated foodborne\nillness. The foods that typically cause these outbreaks have been deli\nmeats, hot dogs, and Mexican-style soft cheeses made with\nunpasteurized milk. Produce is not often identified as a source, but\nsprouts caused an outbreak in 2009, and celery caused an outbreak in\n2010.\n\nInvestigation of the outbreak\n-----------------------\nOngoing collaborative investigations by local, state, and federal\npublic health and regulatory agencies indicate the source of the\noutbreak is cantaloupe. Among the 27 ill persons with available\ninformation on what they ate, 26 (96 percent) reported consuming\ncantaloupes. Ill persons were interviewed about exposures during the\nmonth before they became ill; investigators compared their responses\nto persons with listeriosis reported through the CDC Listeria\nInitiative, whose illnesses were not part of this outbreak. Several\nill persons remembered the type of cantaloupe they had eaten and said\nthey were Rocky Ford cantaloupes, which are grown in the Rocky Ford\nregion of southeastern Colorado. Source tracing of the cantaloupes\nthat ill persons ate indicated that they came from Jensen Farms, of\nGranada, Colorado and were marketed as being from the Rocky Ford\nregion. These cantaloupes were harvested in August and September 2011,\nwere distributed widely in the USA, and may still be available in\ngrocery stores.\n\nLaboratory testing by the Colorado Department of Public Health and\nEnvironment identified _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria on\ncantaloupes collected from grocery stores and from an ill person's\nhome. Product traceback information from Colorado state officials\nindicated these cantaloupes also came from Jensen Farms. FDA is\nworking closely with CDC, the firms involved, and public health\nauthorities in states where illnesses occurred to determine the exact\ncause of contamination.\n\nCDC advises persons throughout the mainland United States who are at\nhigh risk for listeriosis, including older adults, persons with\nweakened immune systems, and pregnant women, to not eat Rocky Ford\ncantaloupes from Jensen Farms. Other consumers who want to reduce\ntheir risk of Listeria infection should not eat Rocky Ford cantaloupes\nfrom Jensen Farms.\n\nRecall\n----\nOn 14 Sep 2011, FDA issued a press release to announce that Jensen\nFarms issued a voluntary recall of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because the\ncantaloupes have the potential to be contaminated with Listeria and\nmay be linked to a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n----------------\nContaminated cantaloupes may still be in grocery stores and in\nconsumers' homes.\n\nCDC recommends that persons at high risk for listeriosis, including\nolder adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant\nwomen, do not eat Rocky Ford cantaloupes from Jensen Farms. Even if\nsome of the cantaloupe has been eaten without anyone becoming ill, the\nrest of the cantaloupe should be disposed of immediately. Listeria\nbacteria can grow in the cantaloupe at room and refrigerator\ntemperatures. Other consumers who want to reduce their risk of\nListeria infection should not eat Rocky Ford cantaloupes from Jensen\nFarms.\n\nThe recalled cantaloupes may have a sticker [See:\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. - Mod.LL]. Not all\nof the recalled cantaloupes are labeled with a sticker. Consumers\nshould consult the retailer if they have questions about the origin of\na cantaloupe.\n\nConsumers and food preparers should wash their hands before and after\nhandling any whole melon, such as cantaloupe, watermelon, or honeydew.\n\n- Wash the melons and dry them with a clean cloth or paper towel\nbefore cutting.\n- Cut melon should be promptly consumed or refrigerated at or less\nthan 40 F (32-34 F is best) for no more than 7 days.\n- Cut melons left at room temperature for more than 4 hours should be\ndiscarded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of affected individuals has grown from 22 to 35 in the 5\ndays between CDC postings on the outbreak, and 3 more states have\nreported outbreak cases. As noted in this post and below, a 'smoking'\nmelon has been found which microbiologically confirms the\nepidemiological data - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] 'Smoking melon'\nDate: Fri 16 Sep 2011\nSource: Colorado Dept of Public Health and Environment [edited]\nhttp://www.cdphe.state.co.us/release/2011/091611.pdf\n\n\nLaboratory results of samples obtained by the Colorado Department of\nPublic Health and Environment's state lab have confirmed a direct link\nbetween human cases in the Listeria outbreak and cantaloupe labeled as\n'Rocky Fords' from Jensen Farms in Holly.\n\nCantaloupe samples from the refrigerator of a Listeria patient's home,\nas well as samples obtained from various retail outlets last week,\nhave the same DNA fingerprints as the Listeria that has infected 12\nColorado residents. All of the Listeria-positive cantaloupe samples at\nthis time appear to have been grown at Jensen Farms.\n\nDr. Chris Urbina, chief medical officer and executive director of the\ndepartment, reiterated to consumers that: 'Individuals who are high\nrisk for listeriosis should not eat cantaloupe if they know it is from\nJensen Farms or if they don't know where the cantaloupe they purchased\nis from.' Urbina said high-risk individuals for listeriosis are people\naged 60 and older; those with weakened immune systems from transplants\nor certain chronic diseases, immunosuppressive therapies or\nmedications; and pregnant women. Healthy adults under age 60 rarely\ndevelop this illness.\n\nOn Wed 14 Sep 2011, Jensen Farms voluntarily recalled its cantaloupe,\nshipped between 29 Jul 2011 and 10 Sep 2011, which was distributed to\nat least 17 states with possible further distribution. An FDA news\nrelease issued Wednesday [14 Sep 2011] night said that although the\ninvestigation is ongoing, no other cantaloupe producer has been\nimplicated.\n\nAlthough these cantaloupes have been, and are being, removed from\ncommerce, additional infections likely will be reported, because it\ntakes an average of 3 weeks to become ill with listeriosis after\neating a contaminated product. Ten samples collected from cantaloupes\nidentified as being from Jensen Farms all came back positive for\n_Listeria monocytogenes_. Several samples matched the lab results of\nColorado's 12 confirmed human cases. The state health department\ncontinues to work with FDA and CDC to determine the source of the\ncantaloupe contamination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The vehicle for _L. monocytogenes_ in this substantial outbreak is\nunusual, so ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the\ncontamination. Since the melon grows on a vine on the ground, its rind\ncan become contaminated with pathogens by contact with contaminated\nsoil, fertilizer, or water used for irrigation or washing.\nContamination could also occur later during the process of bringing\nthe food from field to table. Cutting through the outer skin can then\ncontaminate the pulp of cantaloupe, if washing of the outside is\ninadequate. It is, therefore, important to wash the melon thoroughly\nbefore cutting into it, since bacteria can grow on the rind. However,\nbecause Listeria reproduce at refrigerator temperatures, inoculation\nof the pulp by even low numbers of the organism can result in higher\ngrade contamination of refrigerated product. There is also increasing\ndata to suggest that some enteric pathogens (such as _E. coli_ O157:H7\nor _Salmonella enterica_ serotypes) could persist internally in the\ngrowing plant if introduced to the seed or early growing phases.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in nature. The\norganism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat\nand poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the\nintestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans,\nand in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Most human\ninfections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur\nfrom mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an\ninfected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in\nveterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (04): CANTALOUPE, ALERT\n************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] CDC update\n Sep 2011\nSource: Colorado Dept of Public Health and Environment [edited]\nhttp://www.cdphe.state.co.us/release/2011/091611.pdf\n\n\nLaboratory results of samples obtained by the Colorado Department of\nPublic Health and Environment's state lab have confirmed a direct link\nbetween human cases in the Listeria outbreak and cantaloupe labeled as\n'Rocky Fords' from Jensen Farms in Holly. \n\nDr. Chris Urbina, chief medical officer and executive director of the\ndepartment, reiterated to consumers that: 'Individuals who are high\nrisk for listeriosis should not eat cantaloupe if they know it is from\nJensen Farms or if they don't know where the cantaloupe they purchased\nis from.' Most human\ninfections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur\nfrom mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an\ninfected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in\nveterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. The\norganism can be found in soil, water, silage, raw vegetables, raw meat\nand poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the\nintestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans,\nand in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. \n\nCDC advises persons throughout the mainland United States who are at\nhigh risk for listeriosis, including older adults, persons with\nweakened immune systems, and pregnant women, to not eat Rocky Ford\ncantaloupes from Jensen Farms. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA issued a press release to announce that Jensen\nFarms issued a voluntary recall of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because the\ncantaloupes have the potential to be contaminated with Listeria and\nmay be linked to a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis. \n\nLaboratory testing by the Colorado Department of Public Health and\nEnvironment identified _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria on\ncantaloupes collected from grocery stores and from an ill person's\nhome. Ill persons were interviewed about exposures during the\nmonth before they became ill; investigators compared their responses\nto persons with listeriosis reported through the CDC Listeria\nInitiative, whose illnesses were not part of this outbreak. The number of infected\npersons identified in each state is as follows: California (1),\nColorado (12), Illinois (1), Indiana (1), Montana (1), Nebraska (4),\nNew Mexico (5), Oklahoma (6), Texas (3), and West Virginia (1). Although these cantaloupes have been, and are being, removed from\ncommerce, additional infections likely will be reported, because it\ntakes an average of 3 weeks to become ill with listeriosis after\neating a contaminated product. Source tracing of the cantaloupes\nthat ill persons ate indicated that they came from Jensen Farms, of\nGranada, Colorado and were marketed as being from the Rocky Ford\nregion. Urbina said high-risk individuals for listeriosis are people\naged 60 and older; those with weakened immune systems from transplants\nor certain chronic diseases, immunosuppressive therapies or\nmedications; and pregnant women. Investigators are using data from PulseNet, the\nnational subtyping network made up of state and local public health\nlaboratories and federal food regulatory laboratories that performs\nmolecular surveillance of foodborne infections. Cantaloupe samples from the refrigerator of a Listeria patient's home,\nas well as samples obtained from various retail outlets last week,\nhave the same DNA fingerprints as the Listeria that has infected 12\n An FDA news\nrelease issued Wednesday [14 Sep 2011] night said that although the\ninvestigation is ongoing, no other cantaloupe producer has been\nimplicated. FDA is\nworking closely with CDC, the firms involved, and public health\nauthorities in states where illnesses occurred to determine the exact\ncause of contamination. However,\nbecause Listeria reproduce at refrigerator temperatures, inoculation\nof the pulp by even low numbers of the organism can result in higher\ngrade contamination of refrigerated product. There is also increasing\ndata to suggest that some enteric pathogens (such as _E. coli_ O157:H7\nor _Salmonella enterica_ serotypes) could persist internally in the\ngrowing plant if introduced to the seed or early growing phases. \n\nCDC recommends that persons at high risk for listeriosis, including\nolder adults, persons with weakened immune systems, and pregnant\nwomen, do not eat Rocky Ford cantaloupes from Jensen Farms. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of affected individuals has grown from 22 to 35 in the 5\ndays between CDC postings on the outbreak, and 3 more states have\nreported outbreak cases. On Wed 14 Sep 2011, Jensen Farms voluntarily recalled its cantaloupe,\nshipped between 29 Jul 2011 and 10 Sep 2011, which was distributed to\nat least 17 states with possible further distribution. Ongoing collaborative investigations by local, state, and federal\npublic health and regulatory agencies indicate the source of the\noutbreak is cantaloupe. Among the 27 ill persons with available\ninformation on what they ate, 26 (96 percent) reported consuming\ncantaloupes. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The vehicle for _L. monocytogenes_ in this substantial outbreak is\nunusual, so ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the\ncontamination. Listeriosis illnesses in several other states are currently being\ninvestigated by state and local health departments to determine\nwhether they are part of this outbreak. \n\nAbout 800 cases of Listeria infection are diagnosed each year in the\nUSA, along with 3 or 4 outbreaks of Listeria-associated foodborne\nillness. \n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states,\nincluding Colorado, and the FDA to investigate a multistate outbreak\nof listeriosis. Produce is not often identified as a source, but\nsprouts caused an outbreak in 2009, and celery caused an outbreak in\n2010.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2011-09-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-08-26 00:00:00", "2060-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Urbina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Listeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "883593", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=883593", "date": "2011-09-23 16:37:08", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (06): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Kansas cases\n[2] Texas: possible new cases\n[3] FDA: broader distribution of cantaloupes\n\n******\n[1] Kansas cases\nDate: Thu 22 Sep 2011\nSource: KSN News [edited]\nhttp://www.ksn.com/news/local/story/1-dead-in-Sedgwick-County-from-listeria-outbreak/TCTm7F4hFkaZErYzXGb_mw.cspx\n\n\nKansas health officials say 5 cases of listeriosis in Kansas are\nrelated to contaminated cantaloupe from Colorado. 3 of the cases were\nin Sedgwick County, with 1 of them ending in the patient's death.\nState officials said Thu 22 Sep 2011 that at least 8 people in Kansas\nhave become ill from the bacteria since 26 Aug 2011, but only 5 of the\npeople have been tied to the cantaloupe. In typical years, Kansas\nreports fewer than 6 cases a year.\n\nThe CDC says it has confirmed 55 cases in 14 states of people sickened\nby the cantaloupes. Jensen Farms is voluntarily recalling the Rocky\nFord cantaloupe linked to the outbreak. The recalled cantaloupes were\nshipped to at least 17 states, including Kansas, from the Rocky Ford\ngrowing region of Colorado from 29 Jul 2011 through 10 Sep 2011.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These 5 cases with a death were not included in the 21 Sep 2011 CDC\nupdate on the outbreak. Adding these cases results in at least 60\ncases and 9 deaths. The number of deaths is now equal to that of the\n2009 _Salmonella_ Typhimurium peanut butter outbreak but that outbreak\ninvolved more than 600 people. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Texas: possible new cases\nDate: Thu 22 Sep 2011\nSource: NBC Dallas-Fort Worth News [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.nbcdfw.com/news/health/Two-Listeria-Cases-Surface-in-Dallas-County-130355433.html\n\n\nOf the people who got sick from cantaloupes contaminated with\n_Listeria_, 2 live in Dallas County. The health department said the\n81-year-old and 75-year-old have recovered. Due to confidentiality and\nprivacy concerns, the names of those who became ill will not be\nreleased. The results from 2 other Dallas County listeria cases are\npending. DCHHS [Dallas County Human Health and Services] won't know\nuntil then if the pending cases are linked to the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Frank Heinz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With 9 outbreak cases reported from Texas and 2 of these from Dallas\nCounty, the other 2 county cases may well be outbreak-related as well.\n- Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] FDA: broader distribution of cantaloupes\nDate: Thu 22 Sep 2011\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Coordinated Outbreak\nResponse and Evaluation (CORE) Network [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Food/FoodSafety/CORENetwork/ucm272372.htm\n\n\nMultistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to Jensen Farms' whole\ncantaloupes\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe FDA is conducting a root-cause investigation and environmental\nassessment at Jensen Farms. This includes the on-site expertise of FDA\nand state of Colorado microbiologists, environmental health\nspecialists, veterinarians, and investigative officers working\ndirectly with Jensen Farms to find how the recalled cantaloupes became\ncontaminated with _Listeria_.\n\nThe experts are assessing the fields, the growing conditions, and the\nenvironment. They are also taking samples and will determine the most\nlikely cause of contamination and identify potential controls to help\nprevent future outbreaks.\n\nJensen Farms recalled its whole cantaloupes on 14 Sep 2011 in response\nto the multi-state outbreak of listeriosis. Cantaloupes from other\nfarms have not been linked to this outbreak. The recalled cantaloupes\nwere shipped from 29 Jul 2011 through 10 Sep 2011. As FDA conducted\naudit checks with Jensen Farms' customers, the Agency found that the\nrecalled cantaloupes were also shipped to Arkansas, California, Idaho,\nOhio, and Oklahoma, in addition to the previously mentioned 17 states:\nArizona, Colorado, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska,\nNew Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Oklahoma,\nPennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, and Wyoming.\n\nBecause a shelf life of a cantaloupe can last about 2 weeks, it is\nalso possible that some of the recalled product could still be in\ncommerce or in home refrigerators. Consumers are advised to check with\ntheir retailer to find out where the cantaloupe they purchased\noriginated. It is the retailers' responsibility to know the source of\ntheir products. If consumers do have the recalled product in their\nhome, discard immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that, as the number of states where distribution of the\nvehicle occurred increases, the number of cases and deaths will\ncontinue to rise as well. The incubation period of listeriosis can be\nseveral weeks, which further skews the outbreak curve to the right as\nwell. We await more information regarding the source of the initial\ncontamination. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "As FDA conducted\naudit checks with Jensen Farms' customers, the Agency found that the\nrecalled cantaloupes were also shipped to Arkansas, California, Idaho,\nOhio, and Oklahoma, in addition to the previously mentioned 17 states:\nArizona, Colorado, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska,\nNew Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Oklahoma,\n LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (06): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This includes the on-site expertise of FDA\nand state of Colorado microbiologists, environmental health\nspecialists, veterinarians, and investigative officers working\ndirectly with Jensen Farms to find how the recalled cantaloupes became\ncontaminated with _Listeria_. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that, as the number of states where distribution of the\nvehicle occurred increases, the number of cases and deaths will\ncontinue to rise as well. The incubation period of listeriosis can be\nseveral weeks, which further skews the outbreak curve to the right as\nwell. In this posting:\n[1] Kansas cases\n Source: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Coordinated Outbreak\nResponse and Evaluation (CORE) Network [edited]\n They are also taking samples and will determine the most\nlikely cause of contamination and identify potential controls to help\nprevent future outbreaks.
