Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nJensen Farms recalled its whole cantaloupes on 14 Sep 2011 in response\nto the multi-state outbreak of listeriosis. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These 5 cases with a death were not included in the 21 Sep 2011 CDC\nupdate on the outbreak.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2011-09-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallas County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sedgwick County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "892475", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=892475", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the 'Rocky Ford' variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, 'Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford' or 'Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.'\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold 'food which was defective and not reasonably safe.'\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n'If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,' Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. 'But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.'\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. 'To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.'\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. \n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. \n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. \n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. With the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania. \n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people. \n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. ' \n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. \n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. The 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. The FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. \n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. \n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. \n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons. The CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food. The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople. \n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. John N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700. Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2011-09-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2011-09-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Artesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "742987", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=742987", "date": "2011-06-05 18:01:29", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA: (COLORADO)\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jun 2011\nSource: 9news.com [edited]\nhttp://www.9news.com/news/article/201433/188/2-dead-in-Colorado-from-outbreak-of-Listeria\n\n\nThe Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment [CDPHE] says\n2 people have died because of an outbreak of listeriosis. The CDPHE\nsays it is working with Denver Public Health and Denver Environmental\nHealth after 3 cases of listeriosis were reported since 20 May 2011.\nAll 3 cases involved people of Hispanic or Latino heritage, according\nto the CDPHE. The 2 people who died were a man in his 30s and a woman\nin her 60s.\n\n'These cases are very concerning to us because we have seen 3 in over\na little more than a week, and usually we see only 10 cases a year. So\nthis is very concerning to us,' Alicia Cronquist, an epidemiologist,\nsaid. The CDPHE says Colorado averages 10 cases of listeriosis a year.\nThe source of the outbreak is still unknown.\n\nPeople who are at high risk for _Listeria_ infection include people\nwith weakened immune systems from transplants or certain chronic\ndiseases, immunosuppressive therapies or medications; pregnant women;\nand people age 60 and older. Healthy people rarely contract\nlisteriosis, according to the CDPHE.\n\nSymptoms can include fever and muscle aches and also can include\ndiarrhea, headache, stiff neck, confusion and convulsions. Listeriosis\nalso can cause miscarriages and stillbirths. Antibiotics can cure it\nand prevent the fetus from being infected.\n\nRecommendations for those at high risk:\n--------------------------------------\nCheeses\n-------\n- Do not eat soft cheese such as feta, queso blanco, queso fresco,\nbrie, Camembert, blue-veined, or panela (queso panela) unless it is\nlabeled as made with pasteurized milk. Make sure the label says, 'Made\nwith pasteurized milk.'\n\nMeats\n-----\n- Do not eat hot dogs, luncheon meats, cold cuts, other deli meats\n(e.g., bologna), or fermented or dry sausages unless they are heated\nto an internal temperature of 165 F or until steaming hot just before\nserving.\n- Avoid getting fluid from hot dog and lunchmeat packages on other\nfoods, utensils and food preparation surfaces. Wash hands after\nhandling hot dogs, luncheon meats and deli meats.\n- Do not eat refrigerated pate or meat spreads from a deli or meat\ncounter or from the refrigerated section of a store. Foods that do not\nneed refrigeration, such as canned or shelf-stable pate and meat\nspreads, are safe to eat. Refrigerate after opening.\n\nSeafood\n-------\n- Do not eat refrigerated smoked seafood unless it is contained in a\ncooked dish, such as a casserole, or unless it is a canned or\nshelf-stable product. Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon,\ntrout, whitefish, cod, tuna and mackerel is most often labeled as\n'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked' or 'jerky.' These fish\ntypically are found in the refrigerator section or deli counters of\ngrocery stores and delicatessens. Canned and shelf-stable tuna, salmon\nand other fish products are safe to eat.'\n\nGeneral recommendations\n-----------------------\n>From the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:\n\n- Thoroughly cook raw food from animal sources, such as beef, pork or\npoultry, to a safe internal temperature. For a list of recommended\ntemperatures for meat and poultry, visit\nhttp://www.fsis.usda.gov/PDF/IsItDoneYet_Magnet.pdf.\n- Rinse raw vegetables thoroughly under running tap water before\neating.\n- Keep uncooked meats and poultry separate from vegetables and from\ncooked foods and ready-to-eat foods.\n- Do not drink raw (unpasteurized) milk, and do not eat foods that\nhave unpasteurized milk in them.\n- Wash hands, knives, countertops and cutting boards after handling\nand preparing uncooked foods.\n\nFor more information, visit the CDC website:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/nczved/divisions/dfbmd/diseases/listeriosis/.\n\n[Byline: Jeffrey Wolf]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org\n\n[The following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in a prior\nProMED-mail post Listeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk\n[but see *** below], soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the\nintestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans,\nand in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Most human\ninfections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur\nfrom mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an\ninfected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in\nveterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or\n[contamination can occur] following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing.\n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it\nis not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with\ningestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have\nbeen held at refrigeration temperatures. Listeria can also survive in\nfrozen food. Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (e.g.,\nbrie, camembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli\nmeats, and hotdogs has been sources of human listeriosis. The sources\nof human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques\nmatching _Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source with a species\nrecovered from a patient.'\n\n***In reference to the statement in the first paragraph of these\ncomments, above: reports have suggested that _L. monocytogenes_ is\nrelatively resistant to heat, which has raised concern about the\neffectiveness of pasteurization for eliminating this organism from\nmilk (Bryan FL. Listeria monocytogenes. In: Riemann H, Bryan FL, eds.\nFood-borne infections and intoxications. 2nd ed. New York: Academic\nPress, 1979:266-8; Bearns RE, Girard KF. The effect of pasteurization\non _Listeria monocytogenes_. Can J Microbiol 1958;4:55-61). In an\noutbreak of listeriosis that occurred in Massachusetts in 1983,\npasteurized whole or 2 percent milk was implicated as the source of\ninfection (Fleming DW, Cochi SL, MacDonald KL, et al. Pasteurized milk\nas a vehicle of infection in an outbreak of listeriosis. N Engl J Med\n1985;312:404-7). An inspection of the milk-producing plant detected no\napparent breach in the pasteurization process. In addition, 2 percent\nof pasteurized milk samples from more than 700 U.S. milk-producing\nplants were culture-positive for _Listeria_ species, primarily _L.\nmonocytogenes_, in a survey conducted during 1987 and 1988 as part of\nthe Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) Dairy Product Safety\nInitiatives (Food and Drug Administration. FDA's dairy product safety\ninitiatives: 2nd year status report to the states. Washington, DC: US\nDepartment of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service,\n1988).\n\nHowever, the U.S. CDC has noted that several studies have shown that\n_L. monocytogenes_ is inactivated by standard milk pasteurization\npractices and that contamination of pasteurized milk in the reports\ncited above were most likely due to improper methods of pasteurization\nor post-pasteurization contamination (see\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00001316.htm).\n\nThe state of Colorado and Denver, its capital, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0C6P. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "However, the U.S. CDC has noted that several studies have shown that\n_L. monocytogenes_ is inactivated by standard milk pasteurization\npractices and that contamination of pasteurized milk in the reports\ncited above were most likely due to improper methods of pasteurization\nor post-pasteurization contamination (see\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00001316.htm). Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon,\ntrout, whitefish, cod, tuna and mackerel is most often labeled as\n'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked' or 'jerky.' [but see *** below], soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the\nintestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans,\nand in crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1988-03-26 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:30", "2011-05-20 00:00:00", "1983-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cochi SL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seafood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York :", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "864475", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=864475", "date": "2011-09-09 12:34:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Sep 2011\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_18843100\n\n\nA new case of listeriosis was reported today, in addition to the 3\ncases over the holiday [Labor Day] weekend [3-5 Sep 2011], bringing\nthe total to 13 since 1 Aug 2011.\n\nCases have been reported in Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Denver, Douglas,\nEl Paso, Jefferson, Larimer, and Weld counties. 2 people died from\nlisteriosis in August 2011 and the 11 others were hospitalized. In an\nearlier outbreak, in June 2011, 2 people diagnosed with the infection\ndied.\n\nThe cause of the most recent outbreak is still under investigation and\nthere is no clear link between the cases, said Mark Salley, spokesman\nfor the Colorado Department of Public Health and Safety. Colorado\naverages about 10 cases of listeriosis per year.\n\nState health officials are concerned about the sudden outbreak and\nhave reissued warnings about eating undercooked hot dogs, meat\nspreads, soft cheeses, and smoked fish.\n\nSymptoms of listeriosis include fever and muscle aches, diarrhea,\nheadache, stiff neck, confusion, convulsions, and it can cause\ncomplications with pregnant women. Listeriosis can be treated with\nantibiotics, but even with treatment some cases result in death. Those\nwith weakened immune systems are at a higher risk and listeriosis\nrarely affects healthy people. Most of those sickened by the illness\nduring this outbreak are between 38 and 90 years old, and the majority\nare older females.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the June 2011 outbreak of listeriosis in Colorado, which was\nreported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO)\n20110605.1719), 2 of 3 patients died. That all 3 were said to be of\nHispanic or Latino heritage would suggest the source could possibly be\nsoft Mexican-style cheeses contaminated with _Listeria_ contamination.\nHowever, the sources for both the June and the current outbreaks\nremain unknown. The news release above says that there is no clear\nlink among the cases in the current outbreak; however, it is not\nspecifically stated if genotyping of patient isolates has been done. A\nsimilar genotype for some or all of the cases would imply a common\nsource for these cases.\n\nThe following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk\n[***], soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in crustaceans,\nfish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Most human infections are\nfoodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to\nfetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth\ncanal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and\nfarmers by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, in raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or\n[contamination can occur] following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing.\n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is\nnot surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion\nof contaminated milk, meat, or vegetable products that have been held\nat refrigeration temperatures. Listeria can also survive in frozen\nfood. Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (such as, brie,\ncamembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli meats, and\nhotdogs has been sources of human listeriosis. The sources of human\ninfection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques matching\n_Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source with a species\nrecovered from a patient.'\n\n*** In reference to the statement in the 1st paragraph of these\ncomments, above: reports have suggested that _L. monocytogenes_ is\nrelatively resistant to heat, which has raised concern about the\neffectiveness of pasteurization for eliminating this organism from\nmilk (Bryan FL: _Listeria monocytogenes_. In: Riemann H, Bryan FL,\neds. Food-borne infections and intoxications. 2nd ed. New York:\nAcademic Press, 1979: 266-8; Bearns RE, Girard KF: The effect of\npasteurization on _Listeria monocytogenes_. Can J Microbiol 1958;\n4(1): 55-61; abstract available at\nhttp://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/abs/10.1139/m58-007). In an\noutbreak of listeriosis that occurred in Massachusetts in 1983,\npasteurized whole or 2 percent milk was implicated as the source of\ninfection (Fleming DW, Cochi SL, MacDonald KL, et al: Pasteurized milk\nas a vehicle of infection in an outbreak of listeriosis. N Engl J Med\n1985; 312(7): 404-7; available at\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198502143120704). An\ninspection of the milk-producing plant detected no apparent breach in\nthe pasteurization process. In addition, 2 percent of pasteurized milk\nsamples from more than 700 US milk-producing plants were\nculture-positive for _Listeria_ species, primarily _L. monocytogenes_,\nin a survey conducted during 1987 and 1988 as part of the Food and\nDrug Administration's (FDA's) Dairy Product Safety Initiatives (Food\nand Drug Administration. FDA's dairy product safety initiatives: 2nd\nyear status report to the states. Washington, DC: US Department of\nHealth and Human Services, Public Health Service, 1988).\n\nHowever, the US CDC has noted that several studies have shown that _L.\nmonocytogenes_ is inactivated by standard milk pasteurization\npractices and that contamination of pasteurized milk in the reports\ncited above were most likely due to improper methods of pasteurization\nor post-pasteurization contamination (see\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00001316.htm).\n\nThe state of Colorado and Denver, its capital, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1e1B. A Colorado county map can be seen at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. -\nMod.ML]", "summary": "However, the US CDC has noted that several studies have shown that _L.\nmonocytogenes_ is inactivated by standard milk pasteurization\npractices and that contamination of pasteurized milk in the reports\ncited above were most likely due to improper methods of pasteurization\nor post-pasteurization contamination (see\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00001316.htm). LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In an\noutbreak of listeriosis that occurred in Massachusetts in 1983,\npasteurized whole or 2 percent milk was implicated as the source of\ninfection (Fleming DW, Cochi SL, MacDonald KL, et al: Pasteurized milk\nas a vehicle of infection in an outbreak of listeriosis. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the June 2011 outbreak of listeriosis in Colorado, which was\nreported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO)\n In addition, 2 percent of pasteurized milk\nsamples from more than 700 US milk-producing plants were\nculture-positive for _Listeria_ species, primarily _L. monocytogenes_,\nin a survey conducted during 1987 and 1988 as part of the Food and\nDrug Administration's (FDA's) In reference to the statement in the 1st paragraph of these\ncomments, above: reports have suggested that _L. monocytogenes_ is\nrelatively resistant to heat, which has raised concern about the\neffectiveness of pasteurization for eliminating this organism from\nmilk (Bryan FL: _Listeria monocytogenes_. Most human infections are\nfoodborne, although vertical transmission can occur from mother to\nfetus transplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth\ncanal, and localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and\nfarmers by direct contact with infected animals. \n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it is\nnot surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with ingestion\nof contaminated milk, meat, or vegetable products that have been held\nat refrigeration temperatures. \n\nThe state of Colorado and Denver, its capital, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1e1B. A Colorado county map can be seen at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/colorado.shtml. The sources of human\ninfection can be pinpointed by DNA identification techniques matching\n_Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source with a species\nrecovered from a patient.' Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (such as, brie,\ncamembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli meats, and\nhotdogs has been sources of human listeriosis. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, in raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or\n ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. \n\nState health officials are concerned about the sudden outbreak and\nhave reissued warnings about eating undercooked hot dogs, meat\nspreads, soft cheeses, and smoked fish. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized milk\n \n\nSymptoms of listeriosis include fever and muscle aches, diarrhea,\nheadache, stiff neck, confusion, convulsions, and it can cause\ncomplications with pregnant women.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-06-26 00:00:00", "1988-03-26 00:00:00", "1979-03-26 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-06-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "1983-03-26 00:00:00", "1958-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-08-01 00:00:00", "2011-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Adams", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cochi SL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "870651", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=870651", "date": "2011-09-14 11:12:42", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (03)\n*****************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2011\nSource: KOB.com [edited]\nhttp://senewmexico.kob.com/news/news/93292-nm-health-officials-investigate-infectious-outbreak\n\n\nA listeriosis outbreak has New Mexico health officials on alert. 3\npeople in the state have already died, 2 men from Bernalillo County\nand a woman from Curry County. 6 others have been hospitalized. There\nare 11 similar cases in Colorado and officials there believe the\nculprit is contaminated cantaloupe.\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health says they're working to determine\nthe source of the bacteria, but right now they can't say with 100\npercent certainty what caused the outbreak.\n\nExperts in Colorado, however, are blaming cantaloupe likely from the\nRocky Ford growing region 60 miles [97 km] east of Pueblo, Colorado.\nHealth officials in New Mexico are expediting samples from across the\nstate to the Center for Disease Control. Jim Winchester with the\nEnvironment Department said they are hoping to have results in the\nnext 48 hours. That will tell them if the cases are connected.\n\nHealth experts said listeriosis is relatively uncommon but dangerous.\n'It's a severe illness...most people, when they get sick, they already\nhave a blood stream infection so they need to get medical attention\nand it can be successfully treated with antibiotics,' said Dr Michael\nLanden, an epidemiologist with the New Mexico Department of Health.\nSymptoms include fever and muscle aches and can also include diarrhea,\nheadache, stiff neck, and convulsions.\n\nDr. Landen said there are 4 high-risk groups that need to stay away\nfrom cantaloupe right now: adults over the age of 60, pregnant women,\ninfants, and those with weakened immune systems. He explained after\nexposure, it can take between a couple days and up to a month to show\nsymptoms.\n\nAs of right now there are no recalls to report. Health officials in\nColorado are advising consumers to wash and dry the outside of melons\nbefore cutting.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 13 Sep 2011\nSource: Forbes.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/09/13/general-specialized-consumer-services-us-listeria-cantaloupe_8677175.html\n\n\nHealth officials have issued a warning for cantaloupes from a revered\nmelon-producing area of Colorado amid a bacterial outbreak blamed for\n4 deaths in the state and New Mexico, troubling farmers who depend on\nsales of the fruit.\n\nThe warning from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]\ncame after 16 cases of a strain of listeriosis were reported in 5\nstates, including 11 from Colorado, 2 from Texas, and one each from\nIndiana, Nebraska, and Oklahoma.\n\nThe agency said it was the 1st listeriosis outbreak linked to\ncantaloupe in the United States. The US Food & Drug Administration\nsaid it had not recalled the melons while it worked to locate the\nsource.\n\nRocky Ford cantaloupes, named for a region along the old Santa Fe\nTrail about 130 miles [209 km] southeast of Denver, are prized for\ntheir above-average sugar content. WC Fields reportedly said bald guys\nhave 'a head shaped like a Rocky Ford cantaloupe,' and Lucile Ball had\nthe melons delivered to her dressing room. 'This is really silly. You\ncan get listeriosis any place. I eat those melons every day,' said\nKent Lusk, a 5th-generation cantaloupe farmer from Rocky Ford.\n\nColorado Agriculture Commissioner John Salazar said it might not be\nthe cantaloupes, but a contaminated truck or other source. He said no\nrecalls have been issued, but several Colorado grocery chains pulled\ntheir supplies as a precaution.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection usually caused by eating food\ncontaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease\nprimarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and adults\nwith weakened immune systems. Colorado health director Chris Urbina\nsaid people who are at high risk included people 60 and older, those\nwith weakened immune systems from transplants, and people with chronic\ndiseases. Symptoms can include fever, muscle aches, diarrhea,\nheadache, stiff neck, confusion, and convulsions. Listeriosis can\ncause miscarriages and stillbirths.\n\nThe CDC warning advised people with cantaloupes at home to see if they\ncame from the Rocky Ford region, and if so, not to eat the melons if\nthey're in a vulnerable group. Health authorities asked people\nthrowing out Rocky Ford cantaloupes to put them in a sealed plastic\nbag before putting them in the trash. Several grocery stores in the\nRocky Mountain region, including King Soopers, Safeway, and Whole\nFoods, voluntarily pulled Rocky Ford cantaloupes. 'We decided out of\nan abundance of caution' to remove Rocky Ford melons in 142 Colorado\nstores, King Soopers spokeswoman Kelli McGannon said.\n\nSchool cafeterias in at least 2 Denver-area school districts threw out\ntheir Rocky Ford melons. Denver Public Schools (DPS) cafeterias had\nplanned to highlight them Wednesday [14 Sep 2011] in a local foods\npromotion. Other Colorado products, including grass-fed beef and green\nchili sauce, also were on the menu, DPS spokeswoman Kristy Armstrong\nsaid.\n\nUrbina said the Colorado health department was expecting more test\nresults this week that might help identify the specific source of the\ncantaloupe sickening people.\n\nLusk said this year's [2011] growing season was almost over and that\nhe doesn't believe the outbreak will have a lasting impact. 'I think\nthere were just a few bad ones,' said Adela Licano, a Chamber of\nCommerce board member who added that about a dozen roadside stands\nwere still open. 'This is a major industry. We hope there is no\npermanent impact. We're going to get to the bottom of this,' Salazar\nsaid.\n\nIn New Mexico, the fatal cases included a 93-year-old man from\nBernalillo County, a 61-year-old woman from Curry County, and a\n63-year-old man from Bernalillo County. State Environmental Health\nBureau inspectors were collecting cantaloupe samples from grocery\nstores and distributors across New Mexico for laboratory analysis.\nMark Salley, spokesman for the Colorado Department of Public Health\nand Environment, said the person who died in Colorado was not being\nidentified.\n\n'We extend our sympathy to the families and friends of those who have\ndied from this infection,' said Colorado Health Secretary Dr Catherine\nTorres. 'At this time, based on the preliminary findings in Colorado,\nwe are cautioning people who are at high risk for listeriosis to avoid\neating cantaloupe.'\n\n[Byline: Steven K Paulson, Susan Montoya Bryan, Kristen Wyatt]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In June 2011 an outbreak of listeriosis occurred in Colorado (see\nProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719), in\nwhich 2 of 3 patients died. That all 3 patients were said to be of\nHispanic or Latino heritage would suggest the source could possibly be\nsoft Mexican-style cheeses contaminated with _Listeria_\ncontamination.\n\nThe current listeriosis outbreak that started in August 2011 was\ninitially reported to involve a total of 13 cases, including 2 deaths,\nand was limited to the state of Colorado (see ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746). According to the 2\nnews releases above, this outbreak has expanded to 25 cases, including\n4 deaths, in multiple states. The states involved are Colorado (11\ncases), New Mexico (9 cases), Texas (2 cases), Indiana (1 case),\nNebraska (1 case), and Oklahoma (1 case).\n\nHopefully, genotyping of patient-isolates is being done. A similar\ngenotype for some or all of the patient-isolates would imply a common\nsource. The sources of human infection can be pinpointed by matching\ngenotypes of _Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source with that\nof patient-isolates.\n\nCantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of Colorado is the suspected\nvehicle, but we are not informed about how this fruit/vegetable came\nunder suspicion. Cantaloupe has been incriminated previously as the\nvehicle for enteric pathogens, specifically _Salmonella_ species, in 3\noutbreaks in North America, in 1991\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00014966.htm), in 2002\n(ProMED-mail post Salmonella poona, cantaloupes - USA, Canada (02)\n20021123.5884), and in 2011 (ProMED-mail post Salmonellosis, serotype\nPanama - USA: ex Guatemala, cantaloupe 20110325.0948).\n\nCantaloupe grows on a vine on the ground and its rind can become\ncontaminated with enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated soil,\nfertilizer, or water used for irrigation or washing. Contamination\ncould also occur later during the distribution process. Cutting\nthrough the outer skin can then contaminate the pulp of cantaloupe, if\nwashing of the outside is inadequate. It is therefore important to\nwash the melon thoroughly before cutting into it, since bacteria can\ngrow on the rind. However, because _Listeria_ multiple at refrigerator\ntemperatures, inoculation of the pulp by even low numbers of the\norganism can result in high-grade contamination of refrigerated\nproduct.\n\nThe Rocky Ford region of Colorado can be found on a map at\nhttp://maps.google.com/maps?q=rocky+ford+colorado&ll=38.052552,-103.720207&spn=0.08908,0.103683&client=safari&oe=UTF-8&gl=us&t=m&z=13&vpsrc=6.\nThe states of the USA involved in this outbreak can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1eJi. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (03)\n*****************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The current listeriosis outbreak that started in August 2011 was\ninitially reported to involve a total of 13 cases, including 2 deaths,\nand was limited to the state of Colorado (see ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746). \n\nThe warning from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC]\ncame after 16 cases of a strain of listeriosis were reported in 5\nstates, including 11 from Colorado, 2 from Texas, and one each from\nIndiana, Nebraska, and Oklahoma.
