That all 3 patients were said to be of\nHispanic or Latino heritage would suggest the source could possibly be\nsoft Mexican-style cheeses contaminated with _Listeria_\ncontamination. most people, when they get sick, they already\nhave a blood stream infection so they need to get medical attention\nand it can be successfully treated with antibiotics,' said Dr Michael\n Cantaloupe has been incriminated previously as the\nvehicle for enteric pathogens, specifically _Salmonella_ species, in 3\noutbreaks in North America, in 1991\n However, because _Listeria_ multiple at refrigerator\ntemperatures, inoculation of the pulp by even low numbers of the\norganism can result in high-grade contamination of refrigerated\nproduct. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In June 2011 an outbreak of listeriosis occurred in Colorado (see\nProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719), in\nwhich 2 of 3 patients died. \n\nDr. Landen said there are 4 high-risk groups that need to stay away\nfrom cantaloupe right now: adults over the age of 60, pregnant women,\ninfants, and those with weakened immune systems. \n\nUrbina said the Colorado health department was expecting more test\nresults this week that might help identify the specific source of the\ncantaloupe sickening people. \n\nThe CDC warning advised people with cantaloupes at home to see if they\ncame from the Rocky Ford region, and if so, not to eat the melons if\nthey're in a vulnerable group. \n\nCantaloupe grows on a vine on the ground and its rind can become\ncontaminated with enteric pathogens by contact with contaminated soil,\nfertilizer, or water used for irrigation or washing. The states involved are Colorado (11\ncases), New Mexico (9 cases), Texas (2 cases), Indiana (1 case),\nNebraska (1 case), and Oklahoma (1 case). \n\n'We extend our sympathy to the families and friends of those who have\ndied from this infection,' said Colorado Health Secretary Dr Catherine\nTorres. ' \n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health says they're working to determine\nthe source of the bacteria, but right now they can't say with 100\npercent certainty what caused the outbreak. According to the 2\nnews releases above, this outbreak has expanded to 25 cases, including\n4 deaths, in multiple states. In New Mexico, the fatal cases included a 93-year-old man from\nBernalillo County, a 61-year-old woman from Curry County, and a\n63-year-old man from Bernalillo County. At this time, based on the preliminary findings in Colorado,\nwe are cautioning people who are at high risk for listeriosis to avoid\neating cantaloupe.' There\nare 11 similar cases in Colorado and officials there believe the\nculprit is contaminated cantaloupe. The US Food & Drug Administration\nsaid it had not recalled the melons while it worked to locate the\nsource. WC Fields reportedly said bald guys\nhave 'a head shaped like a Rocky Ford cantaloupe,' and Lucile Ball had\n We decided out of\nan abundance of caution' to remove Rocky Ford melons in 142 Colorado\nstores, King Soopers spokeswoman Kelli McGannon said. Other Colorado products, including grass-fed beef and green\nchili sauce, also were on the menu, DPS spokeswoman Kristy Armstrong\nsaid. 3\npeople in the state have already died, 2 men from Bernalillo County\nand a woman from Curry County. He said no\nrecalls have been issued, but several Colorado grocery chains pulled\ntheir supplies as a precaution. State Environmental Health\nBureau inspectors were collecting cantaloupe samples from grocery\nstores and distributors across New Mexico for laboratory analysis. Mark Salley, spokesman for the Colorado Department of Public Health\nand Environment, said the person who died in Colorado was not being\nidentified. there were just a few bad ones,' said Adela Licano, a Chamber of\nCommerce board member who added that about a dozen roadside stands\nwere still open. ' Cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of Colorado is the suspected\nvehicle, but we are not informed about how this fruit/vegetable came\nunder suspicion. The states of the USA involved in this outbreak can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1eJi.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-08-26 00:00:00", "2011-06-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1991-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Trail", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Urbina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Curry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guatemala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "557127", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=557127", "date": "2010-10-21 21:00:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (02): (TEXAS), RECALL\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 20 Oct 2010\nSource: Foodpoisonjournal.com [edited]\n<http://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/2010/10/articles/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/texas-bexar-travis-and-hidalgo-counties-hit-with-listeria-from-sanger-produce/>\n\n\nOn 20 Oct 2010, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS)\nannounced that it had determined chopped celery was the source of a\n_Listeria_ food poisoning outbreak among Texas residents. Texas DSHS\nhad been investigating the source of 10 cases of listeriosis -- the\nillness caused by the ingestion of _Listeria [monocytogenes]_\nbacteria, 5 of which resulted in death -- for 8 months when\ninvestigators determined that the source of the outbreak was chopped\ncelery sold by Sangar Fresh Cut Produce in San Antonio. Six of the 10\ncases have been conclusively linked to consumption of the chopped\ncelery.\n\nAccording to a health department press release, all cases of\n_Listeria_ food poisoning occurred in Bexar, Travis and Hidalgo\ncounties. All of the reported cases were in people with serious\nunderlying health problems.\n\nSeveral segments of the population are at increased risk for\ncontracting listeriosis. Individuals at increased risk include:\nPregnant women, who are about 20 times more likely than other healthy\nadults to get listeriosis (about 1/3rd of listeriosis cases happen\nduring pregnancy); Newborns, who, rather than the pregnant women\nthemselves, suffer the serious effects of infection in pregnancy;\nPersons with weakened immune systems, [such as] persons with cancer,\ndiabetes, kidney disease, or AIDS (who are almost 300 times more\nlikely to get listeriosis than people with normal immune systems);\nPersons who take glucocorticosteroid medications (such as cortisone);\nand the elderly.\n\nTexas DSHS ordered the celery manufacturer, Sangar Fresh Cut Produce\nin San Antonio, to stop processing food and recall all products\nshipped from the plant since January 2010 after lab testing of\nchopped celery from the plant indicated the presence of _Listeria_.\nAccording to a press release issued by Texas DSHS, conditions in the\nfood processing plant posed 'an immediate and serious threat to human\nlife or health.'\n\nSangar Fresh Cut Produce recalled products include primarily cut\nfresh produce in sealed packages, which were distributed to\nrestaurants and institutional facilities such as hospitals and\nschools. The chopped celery and other products are not believed to\nhave been sold in grocery stores.\n\nTexas DSHS inspectors reported that they found sanitation issues at\nthe plant during the _Listeria_ outbreak investigation and believe\nthe _Listeria_ bacteria found in the chopped celery may have\ncontaminated other food manufactured in the facility. The agency\nstated in a press release that a condensation leak had been found\nabove the food product area during an inspection. Inspectors also\nfound soil on a food preparation table and identified handwashing\nissues. All of these factors could have contributed to the spread of\n_Listeria_ throughout the food manufacturing plant where celery was\nchopped and packaged.\n\nTexas DSHS food safety personnel are continuing their investigation\ninto the possible points within the facility where the celery became\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ and is contacting distributors,\nrestaurants and institutions believed to have received the recalled\nproducts to ensure the celery and other products sold by Sangar Fresh\nCut Produce does not reach consumers.\n\nThe order issued by Texas DSHS prohibits the plant from reopening\nwithout DSHS approval.\n\nThe incubation period (time between ingestion and the onset of\nsymptoms) for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days and averages 21\ndays.\n\nA person with listeriosis may develop fever, muscle aches, and\nsometimes, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. If\ninfection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache,\nstiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. In\nimmune-deficient individuals, _Listeria_ can invade the central\nnervous system, causing meningitis and/or encephalitis (brain\ninfection). Infected pregnant women ordinarily experience only a\nmild, flu-like illness; however, infection during pregnancy can lead\nto miscarriage, infection of the newborn or even stillbirth.\n\nNewborns may present clinically with early-onset (less than 7 days)\nor late-onset forms of infection (7 or more days). Those with the\nearly-onset form are often diagnosed in the 1st 24 hours of life with\nsepsis (infection in the blood). Early-onset listeriosis is most\noften acquired from the mother through transplacental transmission.\nLate-onset neonatal listeriosis is less common than the early-onset\nform. Clinical symptoms may be subtle and include irritability, fever\nand poor feeding. The mode of acquisition of late-onset listeriosis\nis poorly understood.\n\n[Byline: Bill Marler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSara Volk, PhD\nAssistant Professor, Dept of Biology and Kinesiology\nOur Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX\n<sara.m.volk@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Oct 2010\nSource: MySanAntonio.com [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/health_official_says_celery_was_tainted_105446578.html>\n\n\nState health officials discounted claims by the president of Sangar\nProduce & Processing Co. that the company's celery -- linked to the\ndeaths of 5 people from foodborne illness -- is 'absolutely safe.'\n\n'When we test produce, we do a rapid screen initially,' said Texas\nDepartment of State Health Services spokeswoman Carrie Williams. 'But\nthen we follow up with a very extensive, week long test where we grow\nthe organism to be sure of what we have. The celery was tested\nindependently of other ingredients, and our scientists concluded that\nthe illnesses were linked to the celery processed at the Sangar\nplant.'\n\nState health officials ordered the closing of the produce plant and\nthe recall of all products shipped from there since January 2010\nfollowing the deaths of 5 people in Bexar, Travis and Hidalgo\ncounties from listeriosis. Five other people have become ill after\neating chopped celery processed by the plant at 1500 S. Zarzamora.\nOfficials say there's no indication celery was shipped outside Texas.\n\nIn a statement, company president Kenneth Sanquist Jr. said\nindependent testing done on the produce found it to be safe, adding,\n'we are aggressively fighting the state's erroneous findings.' A call\nto the company headquarters Thursday [21 Oct 2010] morning was\nreferred to the Uresti Law Firm, where an employee said a statement\nwould be released later in the day.\n\nHealth services spokeswoman Williams said Sangar products are sold\nprimarily to restaurants, hospitals and elementary schools, although\nshe would not release the names of any facilities were the celery\nmight have been consumed. Also unknown is the volume of produce\nSangar sold in the 10 months covered by the recall. 'Celery is often\nfrozen and, while you wouldn't want to eat it raw after it was\ndefrosted, it's still often used as an ingredient in other dishes,'\nexplained Williams.\n\nWilliams would not estimate when the Sangar plant would resume\noperations. 'Right now, we're working with the company to collect\ndistribution information and to get the produce back to protect the\nhealth of consumers,' she said. 'After that, we'll work with them to\nmake sure the facility is clean and safe and ready to re-open.'\n\nTracking the outbreak was difficult for several reasons. Only a small\nnumber of cases have been reported, and many of the victims were\nelderly, with poor memories, or had already died. Also, _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, the bacteria that causes listeriosis, has an\nincubation period of up to 70 days.\n\n[Byline: Richard A. Marini]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since _Listeria monocytogenes_ in raw food would be killed during\ncooking, the risk of listeriosis is usually greatest from\nready-to-eat products; that is, food that will not be further cooked\nbefore eating. DNA fingerprinting of the isolates would help in\nestablishing epidemiologic linkage. It is not stated in the news\nrelease above whether DNA fingerprinting was done, and if so, whether\nthere was a common DNA fingerprint among the strains of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ isolated from patients in the Texas outbreak, which\nwould indicate a common source, and whether the DNA fingerprint of\nclinical isolates matched that of the strains isolated from the\ncelery processed at the Sangar plant. A detailed discussion of\nlisteriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post 20071230.4186.\n\nAll cases of the Texas listeriosis outbreak occurred in Bexar, Travis\nand Hidalgo counties. Travis County is part of the city of Austin\nmetropolitan area. Austin is the capital of the U.S. state of Texas\nand is located in Central Texas. San Antonio, the county seat of\nBexar County, is located 80 miles to the southwest of Austin. Hidalgo\nCounty is located on the Rio Grande River at the border with Mexico.\n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Hidalgo%20County,%20Texas,%20United%20States&g=4707196&v=30.7,-98.667,5>.\nHidalgo County can be located on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_Texas_highlighting_Hidalgo_County.sv>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "It is not stated in the news\nrelease above whether DNA fingerprinting was done, and if so, whether\nthere was a common DNA fingerprint among the strains of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ isolated from patients in the Texas outbreak, which\nwould indicate a common source, and whether the DNA fingerprint of\nclinical isolates matched that of the strains isolated from the\ncelery processed at the Sangar plant. \n\nTexas DSHS food safety personnel are continuing their investigation\ninto the possible points within the facility where the celery became\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ and is contacting distributors,\nrestaurants and institutions believed to have received the recalled\nproducts to ensure the celery and other products sold by Sangar Fresh\nCut Produce does not reach consumers. Texas DSHS\nhad been investigating the source of 10 cases of listeriosis -- the\nillness caused by the ingestion of _Listeria [monocytogenes]_\nbacteria, 5 of which resulted in death -- for 8 months when\ninvestigators determined that the source of the outbreak was chopped\ncelery sold by Sangar Fresh Cut Produce in San Antonio. Individuals at increased risk include:\nPregnant women, who are about 20 times more likely than other healthy\nadults to get listeriosis (about 1/3rd of listeriosis cases happen\nduring pregnancy); Newborns, who, rather than the pregnant women\nthemselves, suffer the serious effects of infection in pregnancy;\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nTexas DSHS ordered the celery manufacturer, Sangar Fresh Cut Produce\nin San Antonio, to stop processing food and recall all products\nshipped from the plant since January 2010 after lab testing of\nchopped celery from the plant indicated the presence of _Listeria_.\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since _Listeria monocytogenes_ in raw food would be killed during\ncooking, the risk of listeriosis is usually greatest from\nready-to-eat products; that is, food that will not be further cooked\nbefore eating. Persons with weakened immune systems, [such as] persons with cancer,\ndiabetes, kidney disease, or AIDS (who are almost 300 times more\nlikely to get listeriosis than people with normal immune systems);\nPersons who take glucocorticosteroid medications (such as cortisone);\nand the elderly. \n\nTexas DSHS inspectors reported that they found sanitation issues at\nthe plant during the _Listeria_ outbreak investigation and believe\nthe _Listeria_ bacteria found in the chopped celery may have\ncontaminated other food manufactured in the facility. \n\nState health officials ordered the closing of the produce plant and\nthe recall of all products shipped from there since January 2010\nfollowing the deaths of 5 people in Bexar, Travis and Hidalgo\ncounties from listeriosis. \n\nHealth services spokeswoman Williams said Sangar products are sold\nprimarily to restaurants, hospitals and elementary schools, although\nshe would not release the names of any facilities were the celery\nmight have been consumed. Source: MySanAntonio.com [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/health_official_says_celery_was_tainted_105446578.html>\n\n\nState health officials discounted claims by the president of Sangar\nProduce & Processing Co. that the company's celery -- linked to the\ndeaths of 5 people from foodborne illness -- is 'absolutely safe.' \n\nSangar Fresh Cut Produce recalled products include primarily cut\nfresh produce in sealed packages, which were distributed to\nrestaurants and institutional facilities such as hospitals and\nschools. The celery was tested\nindependently of other ingredients, and our scientists concluded that\nthe illnesses were linked to the celery processed at the Sangar\nplant.' A call\nto the company headquarters Thursday [21 Oct 2010] morning was\nreferred to the Uresti Law Firm, where an employee said a statement\nwould be released later in the day. Celery is often\nfrozen and, while you wouldn't want to eat it raw after it was\ndefrosted, it's still often used as an ingredient in other dishes,'\nexplained Williams. In\nimmune-deficient individuals, _Listeria_ can invade the central\nnervous system, causing meningitis and/or encephalitis (brain\ninfection). Communicated by:\nSara Volk, PhD\nAssistant Professor, Dept of Biology and Kinesiology\n On 20 Oct 2010, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS)\nannounced that it had determined chopped celery was the source of a\n_Listeria_ food poisoning outbreak among Texas residents. Six of the 10\ncases have been conclusively linked to consumption of the chopped\ncelery.\n\n All of these factors could have contributed to the spread of\n_Listeria_ throughout the food manufacturing plant where celery was\nchopped and packaged. The incubation period (time between ingestion and the onset of\nsymptoms) for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days and averages 21\ndays. According to a press release issued by Texas DSHS, conditions in the\nfood processing plant posed 'an immediate and serious threat to human\nlife or health.' \n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Hidalgo%20County,%20Texas,%20United%20States&g=4707196&v=30.7,-98.667,5>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "571305", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=571305", "date": "2010-11-05 13:00:06", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (03): (TEXAS), RECALL\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Nov 2010\nSource: My SA News, San Antonio Express-News report [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/fda_confirms_listeria_contamination_at_sa_plant_106644453.html>\n\n\nAfter conducting their own investigation into a deadly outbreak of\nlisteriosis, federal health officials confirmed Wednesday [3 Oct\n2010] that the source was a San Antonio produce company temporarily\nshut down by the state.\n\nSangar Produce & Processing Co. had disputed earlier test results\nfrom the Texas Department of State Health Services that found\n_Listeria_ on cut celery, arguing that independent tests by a private\nlab on the same batches failed to find any contamination. But the\nFood and Drug Administration (FDA) said in a statement it found\n_Listeria_ bacteria -- not only on celery but also in several places\nin the building, including work surfaces, after a visit 14 and 15 Oct 2010.\n\nThe strain of _Listeria_ was genetically matched to people sickened\nin the outbreak, the FDA statement said.\n\n'These results come as no surprise to us,' said Carrie Williams, a\nspokeswoman for the state health department. 'This adds to the body\nof evidence, and it further confirms the fact there were serious\n_Listeria_ issues inside the plant. If there was any doubt out there,\nthis erases it.'\n\nThe company's lawyer remained skeptical. 'The FDA and the state have\nnot turned over to us the documentation supporting their findings,'\nattorney Jason Galvan said in an e-mail. 'We cannot comment on these\nmost recent findings until the documentation is provided for\nindependent evaluation by our experts.' Still, he added, 'We are\nworking closely with the FDA and the state in the hopes of reopening soon.'\n\nThe FDA also released its own inspection report that found a number\nof sanitary problems at the plant, including improperly refrigerated\nfoods, inadequate hand-washing facilities, and a number of examples\nwhere vegetables and equipment might have come in contact with water\non the plant's floor.\n\nOver several months, 10 people in Bexar, Travis, and Hidalgo counties\nwere infected with the same strain of _Listeria_ -- 5 of them\nfatally. Of the deaths, 3 were from Bexar County and a 4th -- a\nGuadalupe County resident -- died [in San Antonio]. Laboratory tests\nby DSHS now have conclusively linked 7 of the 10 infections to the\ncompany's celery, one more than when the plant was shut down, Williams said.\n\nCiting the possibility of cross-contamination, the state ordered a\nrecall of all products -- not just celery -- shipped from the plant\nsince January [2010]. The recall involved thousands of pounds of\nproduce distributed to more than 300 customers, including\nrestaurants, hospitals, school districts, military facilities, and\nlarge wholesalers.\n\nSangar officials unsuccessfully sought to reopen the plant last week\n[week of 25 Oct 2010]. An administrative hearing has been scheduled\nfor 17 Nov 2010. Williams said it would require 'a series of negative\ntest results on food and environmental samples before the company can reopen.'\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, a bacterium commonly found in soil, can\neasily contaminate meat and vegetables. When eaten, it rarely causes\nserious illness in healthy people but can be deadly in those with\nweakened immune systems such as the elderly, the very young, and\npregnant women.\n\nOf the 10 Texas cases, all were frail and elderly with underlying\nhealth problems. Many were hospitalized before or during their infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As previously reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis, fatal - USA\n(02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813), the Texas Department of State\nHealth Services (TDSHS) has determined that the source for\nlisteriosis in 7 of 10 cases was chopped celery sold by Sangar Fresh\nCut Produce in San Antonio. All of the reported cases were in people\nwith serious underlying health problems; 5 of the 10 died. _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, the bacterium that causes listeriosis, which had been\nfound in the chopped celery, may have also contaminated other food\nproducts manufactured in the facility. As a result, Sangar Fresh Cut\nProduce plant was closed and all products shipped from there since\nJanuary 2010 were recalled; these products were distributed to\nrestaurants and institutional facilities such as hospitals and schools.\n\nThe news release above now states that the Food and Drug\nAdministration also found _Listeria_, not only on celery but on\nseveral environmental surfaces in the plant, as did the TDSHS, and\nthat the DNA fingerprint of strains of _Listeria_ isolated at the\nSangar plant matched that of clinical isolates from people sickened\nin the outbreak. The matching DNA fingerprints confirms the link\nbetween the Sangar celery and the cases of listeriosis.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post\n20071230.4186.\n\nAll cases of the Texas listeriosis outbreak occurred in Bexar,\nTravis, and Hidalgo counties. Travis County is part of the city of\nAustin metropolitan area. Austin is the capital of the state and is\nlocated in Central Texas. San Antonio, the county seat of Bexar\nCounty, is located 80 miles [129 km] to the southwest of Austin.\nHidalgo County is located on the Rio Grande River at the border with Mexico.\n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/r/00WR> and a map showing\nthe counties can be seen at\n<http://geology.com/county-map/texas.shtml>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThe news release above now states that the Food and Drug\nAdministration also found _Listeria_, not only on celery but on\nseveral environmental surfaces in the plant, as did the TDSHS, and\nthat the DNA fingerprint of strains of _Listeria_ isolated at the\nSangar plant matched that of clinical isolates from people sickened\nin the outbreak. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Nov 2010\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As previously reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis, fatal - USA\n(02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813), the Texas Department of State\nHealth Services (TDSHS) has determined that the source for\nlisteriosis in 7 of 10 cases was chopped celery sold by Sangar Fresh\nCut Produce in San Antonio. \n\nThe FDA also released its own inspection report that found a number\nof sanitary problems at the plant, including improperly refrigerated\nfoods, inadequate hand-washing facilities, and a number of examples\nwhere vegetables and equipment might have come in contact with water\non the plant's floor. \n\nSangar Produce & Processing Co. had disputed earlier test results\nfrom the Texas Department of State Health Services that found\n_Listeria_ on cut celery, arguing that independent tests by a private\nlab on the same batches failed to find any contamination. But the\nFood and Drug Administration (FDA) said in a statement it found\n_Listeria_ bacteria -- not only on celery but also in several places\nin the building, including work surfaces, after a visit 14 and 15 Oct 2010. As a result, Sangar Fresh Cut\nProduce plant was closed and all products shipped from there since\nJanuary 2010 were recalled; these products were distributed to\nrestaurants and institutional facilities such as hospitals and schools. _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, the bacterium that causes listeriosis, which had been\nfound in the chopped celery, may have also contaminated other food\nproducts manufactured in the facility. ' [3 Oct\n2010] that the source was a San Antonio produce company temporarily\nshut down by the state.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-11-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-01-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guadalupe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Antonio Express", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Travis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "395682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=395682", "date": "2010-03-14 21:00:03", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA: (ONTARIO)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Mar 2010\nSource: Ifpress.com [edited]\n<http://www.lfpress.com/news/canada/2010/03/12/13205366.html>\n\n\nThere has been an increase in listeriosis cases in Ontario this year\n[2010], and 2 people have died, the provincial health ministry\nannounced Friday [12 Mar 2010].\n\nOn average, Ontario expects to see an average of 40 reported cases of\nlisteriosis per year, and about 8 by March. Between 1 Jan and 11 Mar\nthis year [2010], there have been 14 reported cases, said Dr. Arlene\nKing, Ontario's chief medical officer. 'There is a strong network of\nfederal and provincial agencies that are working diligently to\nminimize the risk of any more incidents of this food-borne illness.\nWe will keep the public informed of any new developments in our\ninvestigation,' said King.\n\nSo far, only 10 of the 14 reported cases have been investigated.\nAside from the 2 deaths, 7 people were hospitalized. At least 2 of\nthe non-fatal cases have been linked to recently recalled ham and\nsalami products from Toronto-based company Siena Foods. Both of those\npatients are from Toronto. They were both hospitalized but are now\nrecovering.\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning consumers that\nSiena-brand Prosciutto Cotto Cooked Ham products may have been\ncontaminated with the bacteria _Listeria monocytogenes_. These\nproducts would have been sold to consumers after 11 Jan [2010] in\ndelicatessens, and grocery and specialty food stores in Ontario,\nQuebec and Alberta. King is also warning people not to consume\nSiena-brand mild Cacciatore Salami, which was recalled in December\n2009 and may be linked to the recent rash of illnesses. Siena Foods\nis voluntarily recalling the affected food while the CFIA\ninvestigates the outbreak. Siena hasn't halted all production at its\nplant. However, only products that test negative for _Listeria_ will\nbe delivered to the public.\n\nConsumers who fear they may have consumed the tainted food are urged\nto contact their local retailers. The ham would have been sold in\nlarge wholesale packages, with best before dates of 8 Mar and 22 Mar\n2010. The salami would have a best before date of 4 May 2010.\n\nFood contaminated with _Listeria_ may not appear spoiled in any way.\nSymptoms include high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness and\nnausea. 'Listeriosis is, in most cases, a mild and self-limiting\ndisease,' said King. However, pregnant women, the elderly, or people\nwith weak immune systems are at a greater risk of death because the\ninfection can lead to blood poisoning or meningitis, King said.\nPregnant women who consume contaminated foods may experience\npremature delivery, spontaneous abortion, or stillbirth. As well, the\ninfection can be passed along to the newborn. King went so far as to\nrecommend people in the high-risk category avoid all deli meats and\nunpasteurized dairy products -- not just those being recalled -- at\nall times. 'There is an inherent risk of bacteria in all of those\nkinds of products,' King said.\n\n22 people in Canada died of listeriosis in 2009. The 2009 outbreak\nprompted Prime Minister Stephen Harper to assign Sheila Weatherill,\nformer head of Edmonton's health system, to issue an independent\nreport about the situation and make recommendations on how to avoid\nsimilar outbreaks in the future. Robert Charlebois, executive\ndirector of food safety and consumer protection with the CIFA, was\nunable to say how many of Weatherhill's 57 recommendations have been\nimplemented. 'Certainly, we have learned from the previous\nlisteriosis cases and the recommendations. We have implemented quite\na bit of the recommendations, and we have accepted all the\nrecommendations,' he said. 'We are implementing as we speak.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the news release above whether listeria was\nisolated at the processing plant or from the Siena-brand deli meats\n(ham and salami), or whether DNA fingerprinting of any strains of\nlisteria that were isolated from the patients or deli meats was done\nand whether the DNA fingerprints proved to be identical. The news\nrelease above also does not pinpoint how the contamination occurred\nduring the production process.\n\nIn 2008, ProMED reported a Canadian deli-meat associated outbreak of\nlisteriosis that involved 20 deaths (Listeriosis, fatal, meat product\n- Canada (04) 20081005.3147). The _Listeria_ bacterium was found deep\ninside slicing equipment, according to company officials at Maple\nLeaf Foods plant, Canada's biggest food company.\n\nThe following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nMost human infections are food-borne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.' Since\nlisteria in raw food would be killed during cooking, the risk of\nlisteriosis is usually greatest from ready-to-eat products, that is,\nfood that will not be further cooked before eating. Listeriosis is\nmore severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or\nolder, and those with compromised immune defenses. A detailed\ndiscussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post\n20071230.4186.'\n\nA map of Canada can be located at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Mar 2010\n \n\nMost human infections are food-borne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. The 2009 outbreak\nprompted Prime Minister Stephen Harper to assign Sheila Weatherill,\nformer head of Edmonton's health system, to issue an independent\nreport about the situation and make recommendations on how to avoid\nsimilar outbreaks in the future. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. Since\nlisteria in raw food would be killed during cooking, the risk of\nlisteriosis is usually greatest from ready-to-eat products, that is,\nfood that will not be further cooked before eating. King went so far as to\nrecommend people in the high-risk category avoid all deli meats and\nunpasteurized dairy products -- not just those being recalled -- at\nall times. ' Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.' These\nproducts would have been sold to consumers after 11 Jan [2010] in\ndelicatessens, and grocery and specialty food stores in Ontario,\nQuebec and Alberta. Robert Charlebois, executive\ndirector of food safety and consumer protection with the CIFA, was\nunable to say how many of Weatherhill's 57 recommendations have been\nimplemented. ' ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. \n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning consumers that\nSiena-brand Prosciutto Cotto Cooked Ham products may have been\ncontaminated with the bacteria _Listeria monocytogenes_. In 2008, ProMED reported a Canadian deli-meat associated outbreak of\nlisteriosis that involved 20 deaths (Listeriosis, fatal, meat product\n- Canada (04) 20081005.3147). At least 2 of\nthe non-fatal cases have been linked to recently recalled ham and\nsalami products from Toronto-based company Siena Foods. However, pregnant women, the elderly, or people\nwith weak immune systems are at a greater risk of death because the\ninfection can lead to blood poisoning or meningitis, King said. Between 1 Jan and 11 Mar\nthis year [2010], there have been 14 reported cases, said Dr. Arlene\nKing, Ontario's chief medical officer. ' The _Listeria_ bacterium was found deep\ninside slicing equipment, according to company officials at Maple\nLeaf Foods plant, Canada's biggest food company. Listeriosis is\nmore severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or\nolder, and those with compromised immune defenses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-05-04 00:00:00", "2021-01-11 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "428158", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=428158", "date": "2010-05-15 17:00:03", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: (TEXAS)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 13 May 2010\nSource: mysanews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/seven_sickened_two_killed_by_food-borne_infection_93633679.html?c=y&page=1#storytop>\n\n\nState and local health officials are investigating a cluster of\nfood-borne infections that sickened 7 people in 3 Texas counties this\nyear, killing 2 of them.\n\nThe patients -- 5 from Bexar County and one each from Travis and\nHidalgo counties -- developed listeriosis, a bacterial infection.\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria are found widely in the\nenvironment, including vegetables and animals. Outbreaks are\nsometimes linked to foods such as soft cheeses and deli meats\ncontaminated after processing.\n\nGenetic analysis found the identical strain of bacteria in all the\npatients, suggesting they were infected by the same food item, said\nRoger Sanchez, senior epidemiologist with the Metropolitan Health\nDistrict. But because of the small numbers and the dispersal of cases\n-- 2 of the patients lived 300 miles apart -- it might be difficult\nto pinpoint the cause, he added.\n\n'This is not a large outbreak. What made it bad is that it has\ninfected people who are fragile, elderly people,' Sanchez said.\n\nMost healthy people aren't in danger from listeriosis though they\nsometimes experience flu-like symptoms. But in the elderly, pregnant\nwomen and people whose immune systems are weakened by illness, the\nfatality rate from the infection can reach 20 percent. The Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimate that 2500 become\nseriously ill each year with listeriosis, and 500 of them die.\n\nSanchez said the infected patients ranged from ages 66 to 93. Most\nhad serious underlying health problems, and all but one were\nhospitalized either before or during their infection. The 1st case\nwas reported in January 2010, the most recent 6 May 2010.\n\nOn Monday [10 May 2010], the U.S. Department of Agriculture issued a\npublic health alert for deli meats imported from Canada and produced\nby Ontario-based Zadi Foods. The products were prosciutto sold under\nthe brands Casa Italia and Emma. A 2008 outbreak in Canada linked to\nanother deli meat producer killed 22 people out of 57 who became ill.\nA number of Texas cases in recent years have been traced to\nunpasteurized soft, white cheese from Mexico.\n\n'Deli meats are implicated a lot because the bacteria can multiply in\nrefrigerator temperatures,' unlike most other forms of bacteria, Sanchez said.\n\nSymptoms of listeriosis can include fever, muscle aches, nausea and\ndiarrhea. If the infection spreads to the nervous system, it can\ncause headaches, confusion, vertigo and convulsions.\n\nTo reduce the risk of listeriosis, people are advised to thoroughly\ncook raw meat and wash raw vegetables before eating, keep raw meats\nseparate from vegetables and other cooked or ready-to-eat foods, and\nwash hands, knives and cutting boards afterward.\n\nFor those at highest risk of serious illness, such as the elderly or\npregnant women, experts recommend avoiding hot dogs or luncheon meats\nunless reheated until steaming hot, avoiding soft cheeses unless the\nlabel states they're made from pasteurized milk, and avoiding\nrefrigerated meat spreads and cold smoked seafood unless it is an\ningredient in a cooked dish.\n\n[Byline: Don Finley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[In 2008, ProMED reported a Canadian deli-meat associated outbreak of\nlisteriosis that involved 20 deaths (Listeriosis, fatal, meat product\n- Canada (04) 20081005.3147). The _Listeria_ bacterium was found deep\ninside slicing equipment, according to company officials at Maple\nLeaf Foods plant, Canada's biggest food company.\n\nOn 16 Mar 2010, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and\nInspection Service (FSIS) issued a public health alert for various\nimported ready-to-eat deli meat products (prosciutto), produced by\nSiena Foods LTD (located in Ontario) because of _Listeria_\ncontamination (see ProMED post Listeriosis, fatal, meat product -\nCanada: (ON) 20100314.0829 and\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/News/NR_031610_01/index.asp>).\n\nOn 10 May 2010, the FSIS issued another alert for various imported\nready-to-eat prosciutto products, produced this time by Zadi Foods\nLtd (also located in Ontario), because they may be contaminated with\n_Listeria monocytogenes _\n(<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/News_&_Events/NR_051010_02/index.asp>).\n\nPreviously on 1 May 2010, FSIS recalled fully cooked crumbled pork\nsausage products, produced by Custom Corned Beef, Inc., (located\nDenver, CO) that may have been contaminated with _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_\n(<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/News_&_Events/Recall_027_2010_Release/index.asp>).\nIt is not stated in the news release above whether the DNA\nfingerprint of the strain of _Listeria moncytogenes_ isolated from\nthe patients in Texas matched any of the strains isolated from these\nvarious culture-positive food products.\n\nMost human _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections are food-borne,\nalthough vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus\ntransplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal,\nand localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers\nby direct contact with infected animals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.\n\nSince listeria in raw food would be killed during cooking, the risk\nof listeriosis is usually greatest from ready-to-eat products; that\nis, food that will not be further cooked before eating. Listeriosis\nis more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or\nolder, and those with compromised immune defenses. A detailed\ndiscussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post 20071230.4186.\n\nTravis County is part of the city of Austin metropolitan area. Austin\nis the capital of the U.S. state of Texas and is located in Central\nTexas. San Antonio, the county seat of Bexar County, is located 80\nmiles to the southwest of Austin. Hidalgo County is located on the\nRio Grande River at the border with Mexico.\n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Hidalgo%20County,%20Texas,%20United%20States&g=4707196&v=30.7,-98.667,5>.\nHidalgo county can be located on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_Texas_highlighting_Hidalgo_County.svg>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "For those at highest risk of serious illness, such as the elderly or\npregnant women, experts recommend avoiding hot dogs or luncheon meats\nunless reheated until steaming hot, avoiding soft cheeses unless the\nlabel states they're made from pasteurized milk, and avoiding\nrefrigerated meat spreads and cold smoked seafood unless it is an\ningredient in a cooked dish. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 13 May 2010\n On 10 May 2010, the FSIS issued another alert for various imported\nready-to-eat prosciutto products, produced this time by Zadi Foods\nLtd (also located in Ontario), because they may be contaminated with\n_Listeria monocytogenes _\n(<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/News_&_Events/NR_051010_02/index.asp>). Most human _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections are food-borne,\nalthough vertical transmission can occur from mother to fetus\ntransplacentally or during delivery through an infected birth canal,\nand localized skin infections can occur in veterinarians and farmers\nby direct contact with infected animals. To reduce the risk of listeriosis, people are advised to thoroughly\ncook raw meat and wash raw vegetables before eating, keep raw meats\nseparate from vegetables and other cooked or ready-to-eat foods, and\nwash hands, knives and cutting boards afterward. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. On 16 Mar 2010, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and\nInspection Service (FSIS) issued a public health alert for various\nimported ready-to-eat deli meat products (prosciutto), produced by\n \n\nGenetic analysis found the identical strain of bacteria in all the\npatients, suggesting they were infected by the same food item, said\nRoger Sanchez, senior epidemiologist with the Metropolitan Health\nDistrict. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures. Source: mysanews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/seven_sickened_two_killed_by_food-borne_infection_93633679.html?c=y&page=1#storytop>\n\n\nState and local health officials are investigating a cluster of\nfood-borne infections that sickened 7 people in 3 Texas counties this\nyear, killing 2 of them. It is not stated in the news release above whether the DNA\nfingerprint of the strain of _Listeria moncytogenes_ isolated from\nthe patients in Texas matched any of the strains isolated from these\nvarious culture-positive food products. \n\nSince listeria in raw food would be killed during cooking, the risk\nof listeriosis is usually greatest from ready-to-eat products; that\nis, food that will not be further cooked before eating. \n\nPreviously on 1 May 2010, FSIS recalled fully cooked crumbled pork\nsausage products, produced by Custom Corned Beef, Inc., (located\n [In 2008, ProMED reported a Canadian deli-meat associated outbreak of\nlisteriosis that involved 20 deaths (Listeriosis, fatal, meat product\n- Canada (04) 20081005.3147). On Monday [10 May 2010], the U.S. Department of Agriculture issued a\npublic health alert for deli meats imported from Canada and produced\nby Ontario-based Zadi Foods. The Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimate that 2500 become\nseriously ill each year with listeriosis, and 500 of them die.\n\n \n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Hidalgo%20County,%20Texas,%20United%20States&g=4707196&v=30.7,-98.667,5>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-05-10 00:00:00", "2010-05-13 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-01-26 00:00:00", "2010-05-01 00:00:00", "2010-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Travis County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hidalgo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bexar County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "272652", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=272652", "date": "2009-08-20 09:00:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): AIRLINE FOOD, CHICKEN WRAP SUSPECTED\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 19 Aug 2009\nSource: Illawarra Mercury [edited]\n<http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/news/local/news/general/wollongong-source-of-virgin-listeria-outbreak/1600649.aspx>\n\n\nA food processing plant in Wollongong has been identified as the\nsource of a listeria food poisoning outbreak on Virgin Blue flights\nlast month [July 2009].\n\nFood Authority of Queensland [Australia] tests revealed the listeria\nbacteria [ _Listeria monocytogenes_] came from cooked, diced chicken\nsupplied by GMI Food Wholesalers Pty Ltd, which trades as Australian\nPoultry and Food Wholesalers, Primary Industries Minister Ian\nMacdonald said today [19 Aug 2009]. The company operates a food\nprocessing plant on Auburn Street in Wollongong.\n\nIn May and June [2009], 7 people contracted listeriosis after eating\nchicken wraps served on Virgin Blue flights out of Brisbane. 2 of\nthose passengers were pregnant women who gave birth prematurely.\n\nMr Macdonald said a prohibition order was placed on the company on [4\nAug 2009]. 'Laboratory analysis finalised this week confirms the link\nthat listeria bacteria consumed by passengers on the Virgin Blue\nflights originated in the chicken processed at the Wollongong-based\nplant,' Mr Macdonald said. 'The prohibition order means the company\nis forbidden from producing or selling the implicated chicken product\nand any other ready-to-eat meats manufactured at the premises. This\norder will remain in place until further notice. Consumers can be\nassured that the contaminated product that was sent to Queensland has\nbeen isolated and removed from the marketplace.'\n\n[Byline: Megan Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news release above is a follow-up of a prior ProMED-mail post\n(Listeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793), which reported on an outbreak of listeriosis among\nairline passengers that was attributed to contaminated chicken meat\nmade into wraps and supplied by airline caterers in May and June\n2009. The airline withdrew the implicated food at the end of June.\n\nContaminated cooked, diced chicken produced at a food processing\nplant in Wollongong is now implicated. However, it is not stated\nwhether listeria was isolated at the plant, or whether a DNA\nfingerprint of any strains of listeria that were isolated from the\nprocessing plant, the patients, or chicken was done and whether the\nDNA fingerprints proved to be identical. The news release above, also\ndoes not pinpoint how the contamination occurred during the\nproduction process. Since listeria in raw food would be killed during\ncooking and the risk of listeriosis is usually greatest from\nready-to-eat products, that is, food that will not be further cooked\nbefore eating, it is understandable that contamination occurred after\ncooking at the food processing plant.\n\nWollongong is a seaside city located in New South Wales, Australia.\nIt is the 3rd largest city in New South Wales, Sydney being the\nlargest (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wollongong,_New_South_Wales>).\nWollongong can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap of Australia at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00I4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 19 Aug 2009\n Since listeria in raw food would be killed during\ncooking and the risk of listeriosis is usually greatest from\nready-to-eat products, that is, food that will not be further cooked\nbefore eating, it is understandable that contamination occurred after\ncooking at the food processing plant. (Listeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793), which reported on an outbreak of listeriosis among\nairline passengers that was attributed to contaminated chicken meat\nmade into wraps and supplied by airline caterers in May and June\n2009. However, it is not stated\nwhether listeria was isolated at the plant, or whether a DNA\nfingerprint of any strains of listeria that were isolated from the\nprocessing plant, the patients, or chicken was done and whether the\nDNA fingerprints proved to be identical. \n\nFood Authority of Queensland [Australia] tests revealed the listeria\nbacteria [ _Listeria monocytogenes_] came from cooked, diced chicken\nsupplied by GMI Food Wholesalers Pty Ltd, which trades as Australian\nPoultry and Food Wholesalers, Laboratory analysis finalised this week confirms the link\nthat listeria bacteria consumed by passengers on the Virgin Blue\nflights originated in the chicken processed at the Wollongong-based\nplant,' Mr Macdonald said. LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): AIRLINE FOOD, CHICKEN WRAP SUSPECTED\n******************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-07-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brisbane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wollongong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "173546", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=173546", "date": "2009-04-11 15:00:59", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO) MEAT SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 8 Apr 2009\nSource: El Mercurio Online [edited]\n<http://www.emol.com/noticias/ingles/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=352829>\n\n\nThe Undersecretary of Health, Jeannette Vega, has confirmed that the\nsource of a new strain of listeriosis is currently being investigated\nat a specific meat company located in the northern sector of Santiago\nafter the bacteria was determined to have caused the death of 1\nperson, as well as 2 miscarriages.\n\n'We are probing a specific industry in the northern area involved in\nthe meat packing business. Just like last year [2008] with Chevrita [a\nChilean brand of goat cheese], this year [2009] we have already\nidentified a possible source for the outbreak based on its\ncharacteristics and as soon as we have results, we will release them,'\nthe ministry told Radio Cooperativa.\n\nVega warned that as long as the origin of contamination remains\nunknown, people should continue to follow a series of recommendations\nfrom the Ministry of Health that include, 'washing your hands,\npreventing cross-contamination by keeping foods separate, consuming\nonly pasteurized products, washing fruits and vegetables even if they\nhave been packaged, as well as consuming only meat and fish that have\nbeen cooked.'\n\nThe undersecretary stated that, so far this year [2009], there have\nbeen a total of 13 reported cases of listeriosis, 8 of which 'are\nrelated to strain 001, which began to appear in October of last year\n[2008].'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 2008 outbreak of listeriosis in Chile, mentioned in the news\nreport above, in which the source was 'Chevrita,' perhaps refers to\nthe 91 cases of listeriosis that occurred mainly in a wealthy section\nof Santiago and that led to withdrawal of a brand of brie, a soft\ncheese often implicated as a source of listeriosis, in which\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected (see ProMED post Listeriosis,\nfatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. RFI 20081128.3754). The news\nreport above also states that the strain of _L. monocytogenes_\nisolated in 8 of the 13 cases in the current outbreak, now attributed\nto consumption of 'meat,' is 'related,' perhaps on the basis of\ngenotyping, 'to strain 001, which began to appear in October of last\nyear [2008].' Assuming strain 001 was the cause of the 2008\n'Chevrita' outbreak, the details of how these 2 outbreaks are linked\nis obviously yet to be determined. Also, the type of meat involved in\nthe current outbreak is not given.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.\n\nListeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60\nyears of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses. A\ndetailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post\n20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/009g>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 2008 outbreak of listeriosis in Chile, mentioned in the news\nreport above, in which the source was 'Chevrita,' perhaps refers to\nthe 91 cases of listeriosis that occurred mainly in a wealthy section\nof Santiago and that led to withdrawal of a brand of brie, a soft\ncheese often implicated as a source of listeriosis, in which\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected (see ProMED post Listeriosis,\nfatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. Vega warned that as long as the origin of contamination remains\nunknown, people should continue to follow a series of recommendations\nfrom the Ministry of Health that include, 'washing your hands,\npreventing cross-contamination by keeping foods separate, consuming\nonly pasteurized products, washing fruits and vegetables even if they\nhave been packaged, as well as consuming only meat and fish that have\nbeen cooked.' The news\nreport above also states that the strain of _L. monocytogenes_\nisolated in 8 of the 13 cases in the current outbreak, now attributed\nto consumption of 'meat,' is 'related,' perhaps on the basis of\ngenotyping, 'to strain 001, which began to appear in October of last\nyear [2008].' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 8 Apr 2009\n The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. The Undersecretary of Health, Jeannette Vega, has confirmed that the\nsource of a new strain of listeriosis is currently being investigated\nat a specific meat company located in the northern sector of Santiago\nafter the bacteria was determined to have caused the death of 1\nperson, as well as 2 miscarriages. \n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals.
