RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=131216", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness. \n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease. LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\n \n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly. The Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5. \n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.) \n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago. Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons. In addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago]. According to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "163273", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=163273", "date": "2009-03-07 23:58:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA: UNCONFIRMED\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Mar 2009\nSource: CBCNews.ca [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2009/03/05/quebec-listeriosis-death.html>\n\n\nHealth officials in Quebec now say they cannot confirm that the\nlisteriosis death of a man in January 2009 was linked to the 2008\noutbreak tied to tainted meat from Maple Leaf Foods.\n\nThe Monteregie public health agency had told the CBC's\nFrench-language network, Radio-Canada, that the 75-year-old Quebec\nman's death was the 21st in Canada tied to the listeriosis outbreak\nthat originated at Maple Leaf. The health officials later said while\nthe man's death was from a strain of the bacterium _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ that was also found in some Maple Leaf foods, they\ncould no longer definitively say the death was linked to the company.\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency has yet to confirm the cause of\nthe man's death.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last ProMED-mail posting in October 2008 on the Canadian\nlisteriosis outbreak reported 20 deaths linked to a strain of\nlisteria that was identified at a Toronto plant run by Maple Leaf\nFoods Inc. (see Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04)\n20081005.3147). The incriminated Maple Leaf Foods products were\nrecalled in late August 2008. With an incubation period for\nlisteriosis of up to 70 days, more cases related to the outbreak\ncould be expected to have occurred up to November 2008, but people\nmay continue to have been exposed to product inadvertently retained\non shelves or refrigerators with best-before dates that extended to\n21 Jan 2009 (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal, meat product -\nCanada: alert, recall 20080821.2605).\n\nIt is difficult to tell how they decided that death of a man in\nJanuary 2009 was not linked to the 2008 outbreak tied to tainted meat\nfrom Maple Leaf Foods. Although not specifically stated in the above\nnews report, perhaps genotyping of the patient's isolate failed to\nestablish linkage of the patient to the outbreak, or perhaps the\npatient died of a cause unrelated to listeriosis.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\narchive 20071230.4186.\n\nA map of Canada can be located at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "With an incubation period for\nlisteriosis of up to 70 days, more cases related to the outbreak\ncould be expected to have occurred up to November 2008, but people\nmay continue to have been exposed to product inadvertently retained\non shelves or refrigerators with best-before dates that extended to\n21 Jan 2009 (see ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal, meat product -\nCanada: alert, recall 20080821.2605). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Mar 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last ProMED-mail posting in October 2008 on the Canadian\nlisteriosis outbreak reported 20 deaths linked to a strain of\nlisteria that was identified at a Toronto plant run by Maple Leaf\nFoods Inc. (see Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04)\n20081005.3147). Source: CBCNews.ca [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2009/03/05/quebec-listeriosis-death.html>\n\n\nHealth officials in Quebec now say they cannot confirm that the\nlisteriosis death of a man in January 2009 was linked to the 2008\noutbreak tied to tainted meat from Maple Leaf Foods. The Monteregie public health agency had told the CBC's\nFrench-language network, Radio-Canada, that the 75-year-old Quebec\nman's death was the 21st in Canada tied to the listeriosis outbreak\nthat originated at Maple Leaf.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-10-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-21 00:00:00", "2008-03-26 00:00:00", "2009-01-26 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "262227", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=262227", "date": "2009-08-07 11:17:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: AIRLINE FOOD, CHICKEN WRAP SUSPECTED\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Aug 2009\nSource: The Australian [edited]\n<http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25894643-23289,00.html>\n\n\nTwo pregnant women gave birth prematurely after eating contaminated\nchicken wraps that were sold in their thousands on Virgin Blue\nflights from Brisbane and the Gold Coast, triggering a national\npublic health alert. The airline confirmed yesterday [6 Aug 2009]\nthat up to 5000 flights in May and June [2009] could have carried the\nsnacks laced with potentially deadly listeria [_Listeria\nmonocytogenes_] bacteria.\n\nFive Queenslanders are known to have contracted listeriosis food\npoisoning after consuming the wraps, including the 2 women who gave\nbirth prematurely, a known complication of the illness. Both women\nand their babies survived.\n\nVirgin Blue public affairs manager Heather Jeffery said 3 other\ncompanies had received the apparently tainted chicken meat.\nQueensland Health refused to name them last night [6 Aug 2009], but\nsaid that there had been no other reports of listeria poisoning.\n\n'There was an ingredient in a batch ... of chicken meat which was\nsupplied to our caterers, which was then supplied to us,' Ms Jeffery\nsaid. Virgin Blue said it withdrew the chicken wraps at the end of\nJune [2009], but health authorities say more cases could emerge,\ngiven that the incubation for listeria poisoning is up to 70 days.\nQueensland Health is warning pregnant women who fear they could be\nvictims of the food scare to see their doctor.\n\nQueensland Health says there has been a spike in listeriosis cases\nthis year [2009], with 9 recorded in Queensland and 56 across\nAustralia. Listeriosis symptoms include fever, headache, tiredness,\naches and pains, diarrhoea, nausea, and abdominal cramps. More severe\ncases may lead to meningitis or septicemia.\n\nVirgin Blue said the tainted chicken wraps were offered on services\nalong the east coast of Australia, to New Zealand and Bali, and out\nof Brisbane and the Gold Coast. Potentially, up to 5000 flights were involved.\n\n'It appears the likely source of the contamination was an ingredient\nsupplied to the manufacturers of the wraps and not Virgin Blue or\nother companies who received the affected products,' the airline\nsaid. Queensland Health chief officer Jeannette Young said the\nillness was not transmitted from person to person. 'Listeria\ninfection is uncommon and causes few symptoms, if any, in healthy\npeople,' Dr Young said. 'However, it can be very dangerous for people at risk.'\n\nSeveral people purporting to be Virgin passengers went on talkback\nradio in Brisbane yesterday [6 Aug 2009] saying they had been made\nill by chicken wraps eaten on flights in April and January [2009].\nThe airline and Queensland Health authorities are urging anyone who\nfears they were at risk to see doctor.\n\n[Byline: Jamie Walker]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news release above states that a contaminated ingredient in a\nbatch of chicken meat made into wraps and supplied by airline\ncaterers in May and June 2009 is the suspected source for the\noutbreak of listeriosis among airline passengers. The airline\nwithdrew the implicated food at the end of June. What the ingredient\nwas, or how the contamination was determined is not indicated. The\nnews release also says that several airline passengers complained of\nbeing made 'ill' by chicken wraps eaten on flights in April and\nJanuary (2009), before the listeria-contaminated chicken was served.\nThe news release states, in addition, that 3 other companies,\npresumably airlines, had also received the tainted chicken meat, but\ngives no further data, except that there were 'no other reports of\nlisteria poisoning.'\n\nThe following is extracted from Mod.ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.\n\nListeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60\nyears of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses. A\ndetailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post\n20071230.4186.'\n\nAustralia can be located in the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008N>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Aug 2009\n The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news release above states that a contaminated ingredient in a\nbatch of chicken meat made into wraps and supplied by airline\ncaterers in May and June 2009 is the suspected source for the\noutbreak of listeriosis among airline passengers. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature, such as, raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from infected cows; or\ncontamination may occur following subsequent cooking or other\nprocessing. \n\n'It appears the likely source of the contamination was an ingredient\nsupplied to the manufacturers of the wraps and not Virgin Blue or\nother companies who received the affected products,' the airline\nsaid. The airline confirmed yesterday [6 Aug 2009]\nthat up to 5000 flights in May and June [2009] could have carried the\nsnacks laced with potentially deadly listeria [_Listeria\nmonocytogenes_] bacteria. \n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. Two pregnant women gave birth prematurely after eating contaminated\nchicken wraps that were sold in their thousands on Virgin Blue\nflights from Brisbane and the Gold Coast, triggering a national\npublic health alert. The news release states, in addition, that 3 other companies,\npresumably airlines, had also received the tainted chicken meat, but\ngives no further data, except that there were 'no other reports of\nlisteria poisoning.' Because the organisms can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is usually\nassociated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable\nproducts that have been held at refrigeration temperatures. \n\nSeveral people purporting to be Virgin passengers went on talkback\nradio in Brisbane yesterday [6 Aug 2009] saying they had been made\nill by chicken wraps eaten on flights in April and January [2009]. \n\nFive Queenslanders are known to have contracted listeriosis food\npoisoning after consuming the wraps, including the 2 women who gave\nbirth prematurely, a known complication of the illness. Virgin Blue said it withdrew the chicken wraps at the end of\nJune [2009], but health authorities say more cases could emerge,\ngiven that the incubation for listeria poisoning is up to 70 days. ML's comments in ProMED-mail post\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391:\n\n'_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-04-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brisbane", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "116881", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=116881", "date": "2008-10-05 23:00:46", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA (04)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Oct 2008\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/02/content_10140470.htm>\n\n\nThe number of deaths from a listeriosis outbreak that have been linked\nto contaminated meat products has reached 20, Canadian health\nofficials said Wednesday [1 Oct 2008]. The latest death occurred in\nOntario, where 15 of the deaths have been reported, the Public Health\nAgency of Canada said in a news release. 2 deaths occurred in the\nwestern province of British Columbia, with one each in Alberta, Quebec\nand New Brunswick. The health agency said 6 other deaths under\ninvestigation may also have resulted from the outbreak.\n\nThe disease originated from the Toronto deli-meat processing branch\nof Maple Leaf Foods plant, Canada's biggest food company. The\n_Listeria_ bacterium was found deep inside slicing equipment,\naccording to company officials. The plant reopened 4 weeks after\nbeing closed on 20 Aug 2008.\n\nSeveral class-action suits are being planned as a result of the\noutbreak, which has led to one of the most serious food crises in\nrecent Canadian history.\n\n[Byline: Jiang Yuxia]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news release reports 20 deaths but does not state the\ntotal number of confirmed and suspected cases linked to the strain\ndiscovered at the Maple Leaf Foods plant. A news release on 2 Sep 2008\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=aHQGyjTAgrKA&refer=canada>\nreported that there were 12 deaths among 38 confirmed cases of\nlisteriosis across Canada, with another 21 under investigation. When\nlast posted by ProMED (Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (03)\n20080828.2701), there were 12 fatalities among 26 cases of the\ndisease from the same strain of listeria that was identified at a\nToronto plant run by Maple Leaf Foods Inc., with an additional 29\ncases under investigation.\n\nThe incriminated Maple Leaf Foods products were recalled in late\nAugust 2008. With an incubation period for listeriosis of up to 70\ndays, more cases related to the outbreak can be expected. A detailed\ndiscussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail posting no.\n20071230.4186.\n\nA map of Canada can be located at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>.\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Oct 2008\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above news release reports 20 deaths but does not state the\ntotal number of confirmed and suspected cases linked to the strain\ndiscovered at the Maple Leaf Foods plant. A news release on 2 Sep 2008\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=aHQGyjTAgrKA&refer=canada>\nreported that there were 12 deaths among 38 confirmed cases of\nlisteriosis across Canada, with another 21 under investigation. 20080828.2701), there were 12 fatalities among 26 cases of the\ndisease from the same strain of listeria that was identified at a\nToronto plant run by Maple Leaf Foods Inc., with an additional 29\ncases under investigation. The number of deaths from a listeriosis outbreak that have been linked\nto contaminated meat products has reached 20, Canadian health\nofficials said Wednesday [1 Oct 2008]. The latest death occurred in\nOntario, where 15 of the deaths have been reported, the Public Health\nAgency of Canada said in a news release. \n\nSeveral class-action suits are being planned as a result of the\noutbreak, which has led to one of the most serious food crises in\nrecent Canadian history. 2 deaths occurred in the\nwestern province of British Columbia, with one each in Alberta, Quebec\nand New Brunswick.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-08-20 00:00:00", "2008-08-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2008-09-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "106803", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=106803", "date": "2008-08-28 18:00:30", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA (03)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 25 Aug 2008\nSource: Bloomberg [edited]\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=aTpurHcA3LQ8&refer=canada>\n\n\nCanadian public health officials said as many as 12 deaths may be linked to\nan outbreak of food poisoning, an increase from 4 yesterday [24 Aug 2008],\nand the number of cases may rise. Eleven of the fatalities from listeriosis\noccurred in Ontario and one was in British Columbia, Mark Raizenne,\ndirector-general for the Public Health Agency of Canada, said today [25 Aug\n2008] at a news conference in Ottawa. The fatalities are among 26 cases of\nthe disease from the same strain of listeria that was identified at a\nToronto plant run by Maple Leaf Foods Inc.\n\nThe company, Canada's largest food processor, expanded a food recall\nyesterday [24 Aug 2008] to include all meat products made at the Toronto\nplant, which is scheduled to reopen tomorrow [26 Aug 2008]. Of the deaths\nin Ontario, listeriosis was listed as the cause or an underlying factor in\n6 fatalities, with the other 5 under investigation to determine the extent\nto which the disease was a factor, Raizenne said. 'We fully expect that the\nnumbers of suspected and confirmed cases will increase as this\ninvestigation continues and samples continue to be tested,' Canadian\nagriculture minister Gerry Ritz said at the news conference.\n\nHealth officials are also investigating an additional 29 suspected cases to\ndetermine whether they are connected to the strain discovered at the Maple\nLeaf plant. Maple Leaf temporarily closed its Bartor Road plant in Toronto\nlast week [week of 18 Aug 2008] after a number of Sure Slice delicatessen\nmeats tested positive for listeria, a type of bacteria that can lead to\nfevers, severe headaches, and nausea. Listeriosis is the disease caused by\nthe bacteria.\n\nA change in practice to include fatalities where listeriosis may not have\nbeen the direct cause contributed to the sharp increase in the death toll,\nhealth officials said.\n\nMaple Leaf fell CAD 1 [USD 0.96], or 10 per cent, to CAD 8.80 [USD 8.42] at\n4:10 pm on the Toronto Stock Exchange, the biggest one-day decline since 22\nFeb 2006. The shares have dropped 18 per cent since 19 Aug 2008, the day\nbefore the Toronto-based company expanded a recall of some of its meat\nproducts.\n\nOntario officials said today [25 Aug 2008] in a statement it asked health\nauthorities to 'check their local hospitals, long term care homes, and\ndaycares to ensure than any products from the Toronto Maple Leaf plant have\nbeen removed and are not been being consumed.' Maple Leaf reiterated today\nthat the recall will cost about CAD 20 million (USD 19.1 million) and said\nits 1st priority is to restore consumers' confidence in its products. 'The\nshort-term financial impact of this action is secondary to our\nresponsibility to safeguard our consumers' health,' chief financial officer\nMichael Vels said today in a conference call. The recall involves more than\n200 meat products that were made as early as January [2008], Vels said. The\nproducts represent a 'small percentage' of the company's annual sales,\nwhich were CAD 5.21 billion [USD 4.99 million] last year [2007]. Vels\ndeclined to speculate on how the recall will affect future Maple Leaf revenue.\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency said today [25 Aug 2008] that\nsandwiches made by Lucerne Foods, a unit of Safeway Inc, are being recalled\nbecause some of them may contain Maple Leaf meats. The Safeway and\nTakeAwayCafe brand sandwiches were distributed in Saskatchewan and Alberta.\n\nMaple Leaf placed advertisements today [25 Aug 2008] in Canadian newspapers\ncommitting to put consumers' interests first. 'This is the toughest\nsituation we've faced in 100 years as a company,' chief executive officer\nMichael McCain said in the ad. 'We know this has shaken your confidence in us.'\n\n[byline: Kevin Bell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSusan Baekeland\nLa Meute du Ruisseau\nLe Ruisseau\n50240 Carnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<grolleyog@tele2.fr>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Susan Baekeland for sending the news release above. A\ndetailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail posting no.\n20071230.4186.\n\nUndoubtedly more cases will be added as additional genetic testing of\nlisteria isolates is done. The incriminated products have been recalled\nlast week, but people may continue to be exposed to product inadvertently\nremaining on selves as they may have best-before dates ranging from 30 Sep\n2008 to 1 Jan 2009. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n\nOntario officials said today [25 Aug 2008] in a statement it asked health\nauthorities to 'check their local hospitals, long term care homes, and\ndaycares to ensure than any products from the Toronto Maple Leaf plant have\nbeen removed and are not been being consumed.' Eleven of the fatalities from listeriosis\noccurred in Ontario and one was in British Columbia, Mark Raizenne,\ndirector-general for the Public Health Agency of Canada, said today [25 Aug\n2008] at a news conference in Ottawa. Maple Leaf temporarily closed its Bartor Road plant in Toronto\nlast week [week of 18 Aug 2008] after a number of Sure Slice delicatessen\nmeats tested positive for listeria, a type of bacteria that can lead to\nfevers, severe headaches, and nausea. The\nshort-term financial impact of this action is secondary to our\nresponsibility to safeguard our consumers' health,' chief financial officer\nMichael Vels said today in a conference call. We fully expect that the\nnumbers of suspected and confirmed cases will increase as this\ninvestigation continues and samples continue to be tested,' Canadian\nagriculture minister Gerry Ritz said at the news conference. The incriminated products have been recalled\nlast week, but people may continue to be exposed to product inadvertently\nremaining on selves as they may have best-before dates ranging from 30 Sep\n2008 to 1 Jan 2009. Of the deaths\nin Ontario, listeriosis was listed as the cause or an underlying factor in\n6 fatalities, with the other 5 under investigation to determine the extent\nto which the disease was a factor, Raizenne said. \n\n[byline: Kevin Bell]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSusan Baekeland\n \n\nA change in practice to include fatalities where listeriosis may not have\nbeen the direct cause contributed to the sharp increase in the death toll,\nhealth officials said. Maple Leaf reiterated today\nthat the recall will cost about CAD 20 million (USD 19.1 million) and said\nits 1st priority is to restore consumers' confidence in its products. ' The Canadian Food Inspection Agency said today [25 Aug 2008] that\nsandwiches made by Lucerne Foods, a unit of Safeway Inc, are being recalled\nbecause some of them may contain Maple Leaf meats.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-08-19 00:00:00", "2006-02-22 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "170308", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=170308", "date": "2009-04-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MEXICAN-STYLE CHEESES - USA: RISK, RECALL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 23 Mar 2009\nSource: FDA (Food and Drug Administration) [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/oc/po/firmrecalls/torres203_09.html>\n\n\nTorres Hillsdale Country Cheese of Reading, Michigan, is expanding\nthe recall of Asadero and Oaxaca soft Mexican-style cheeses due to\npotential _Listeria_ contamination.\n\nConsumption of food contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_ can\ncause Listeriosis, an uncommon but potentially fatal disease.\nListeriosis can cause high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness and\nnausea. It can also cause miscarriages and stillbirths. The very\nyoung, the pregnant, the elderly and persons with compromised immune\nsystems are the most susceptible to infection. People experiencing\nthese problems should seek immediate medical attention.\n\nProducts were distributed to the following states: Illinois, Indiana,\nMichigan, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, North Carolina, South\nCarolina, Ohio, Wisconsin, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Florida, and Alabama.\n\nA routine sample of Asadero cheese, taken by an inspector from the\nMichigan Department of Agriculture's Food and Dairy Division on 23\nFeb 2009 was subsequently tested by the Michigan Department of\nAgriculture Laboratory and discovered to be contaminated with\n_Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nThe recalled Asadero and Oaxaca cheese products were distributed to\nretails stores and delis in 10-pound balls, 16- and 12-ounce plastic\npackages, sold under the name 'Aguas Calientes.' Product was also\nsold in 6-pound blocks shrink-wrapped in clear plastic, under the\nname 'El Jaliciense.' Packaging may also include a label with the\nname 'Torres Hillsdale Country Cheese LLC.' The recall encompasses\nall production dates between 1 Aug 2008 (expiration date 29 Oct\n2008) and 27 Feb 2009 (expiration date 10 May 2009).\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the\nrecalled products. Consumers and retailers are urged to return all\nunused recalled product to the manufacturer.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of listeriosis for people at risk\n(e.g., newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and\nthose with compromised immune defenses), ProMED-mail is posting this\nrecall even though there are no reported human cases associated with\nthe contaminated Asadero and Oaxaca cheese products at this time.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals.\n\nContamination of food can occur in nature; e.g., raw\nvegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from\ninfected cows, or contamination may occur following subsequent\ncooking or other processing. Because the organisms can multiply at\nrefrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is\nusually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or\nvegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures.\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail no.\n20071230.4186.\n\nThe USA can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 23 Mar 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of listeriosis for people at risk\n(e.g., newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and\nthose with compromised immune defenses), ProMED-mail is posting this\nrecall even though there are no reported human cases associated with\nthe contaminated Asadero and Oaxaca cheese products at this time. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. \n\nMost human infections are foodborne, although vertical transmission\ncan occur from mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery\nthrough an infected birth canal, and localized skin infections can\noccur in veterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected\nanimals. \n\nA routine sample of Asadero cheese, taken by an inspector from the\nMichigan Department of Agriculture's Food and Dairy Division on 23\nFeb 2009 was subsequently tested by the Michigan Department of\nAgriculture Laboratory and discovered to be contaminated with\n_Listeria monocytogenes_. \n\nContamination of food can occur in nature; e.g., raw\nvegetables contaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk from\ninfected cows, or contamination may occur following subsequent\ncooking or other processing. Because the organisms can multiply at\nrefrigerator temperatures, it is not surprising that listeriosis is\nusually associated with ingestion of contaminated milk, meat or\nvegetable products that have been held at refrigeration temperatures. The recall encompasses\nall production dates between 1 Aug 2008 (expiration date 29 Oct\n2008) and 27 Feb 2009 (expiration date 10 May 2009). \n\nProducts were distributed to the following states: Illinois, Indiana,\nMichigan, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, North Carolina, South\n Torres Hillsdale Country Cheese of Reading, Michigan, is expanding\nthe recall of Asadero and Oaxaca soft Mexican-style cheeses due to\npotential _Listeria_ contamination. Product was also\nsold in 6-pound blocks shrink-wrapped in clear plastic, under the\nname 'El Jaliciense.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-26 00:00:00", "2008-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-05-26 00:00:00", "2009-02-27 00:00:00", "2009-02-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "50285", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: (MA), update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=50285", "date": "2008-01-18 15:00:14", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: (MASSACHUSETTS), UPDATE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2008\nSource: National Public Radio (NPR), Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=17671727>\n\n\nInvestigators probing the source of a listeria outbreak said Thursday\n[17 Jan 2008] the strain that killed 3 people was found at a dairy\nprocessing plant in central Massachusetts. But officials have not yet\ndetermined exactly where the milk was contaminated.\n\n'We know that there's a problem in that plant and we have connected\nthe patients to the products to the plant, now it would be nice to\nknow exactly how that happened, but that is part of the ongoing\ninvestigation,' said Dr Alfred DeMaria, state director of\ncommunicable disease control.\n\nSince June [2007], 3 elderly men have died after drinking\nbacteria-contaminated milk from the Whittier Farms plant in\nShrewsbury, about 35 miles (56.3 km) west of Boston. The same strain\nof listeria sickened a pregnant woman, who then miscarried. A 2nd\nwoman also was sickened after drinking milk from the plant. No new\ncases have been identified and health officials say the public health\nrisk is low.\n\nThe deadly strain was found in 7 bottles and on the floor near the\nhomogenizer at the Shrewsbury plant. Different listeria strains were\nfound inside 4 other bottles of milk and at 3 different areas inside\nthe plant -- in a drain, in a bottle washer, and in an empty unwashed\nbottle. More than 100 samples were taken.\n\nIt remains unclear how the milk was contaminated, but one theory is\nthat processing equipment may have unintentionally been contaminated\nduring cleaning, state officials said. The processing plant, which\ndistributes milk under various brand names to homes and stores across\ncentral Massachusetts and also operates a 500-acre (202 hectares)\nfarm in the town of Sutton, has been closed since December [2007]. It\nwill remain closed during the investigation and until the bacteria is\neradicated, officials said. A call to Whittier Farms on Thursday [17\nJan 2008] was not immediately returned.\n\nListeriosis is a kind of food poisoning that can be dangerous to the\nelderly, newborns, pregnant women, and people with chronic medical\nconditions. Symptoms include fever, headache, stiffness, nausea,\nabdominal pain, and diarrhea.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDrew Tenenholz\n<drew.tenenholz@isid.org>\n\n[This continues to be an ongoing epidemiologic investigation\npreviously reported in ProMED-mail 20071230.4186. The source of the\ncontamination of milk has still not been defined, although it is\napparent that several strains of listeria have contaminated the plant\nand one of the strains is linked to the patients with listeriosis. In\naddition, there now seems to be an additional patient linked to the\noutbreak since the last posting, a woman whose comorbidities are not\nstated. A surviving pregnant woman, who miscarried, was previously\nreported. All 3 elderly men who were previously reported have now\ndied of listeriosis. We await any further findings.\n\nA more detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\n20071230.4186. - Mod.ML\n\nThe state of Massachusetts in the northeastern United States can be\nlocated on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jan 2008\n Different listeria strains were\nfound inside 4 other bottles of milk and at 3 different areas inside\nthe plant -- in a drain, in a bottle washer, and in an empty unwashed\nbottle. No new\ncases have been identified and health officials say the public health\nrisk is low.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-01-17 00:00:00", "2021-06-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shrewsbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sutton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "33443", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=33443", "date": "2007-10-24 10:00:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, NOSOCOMIAL - NORWAY: (OSLO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 19 Oct 2007\nSource: Aftenposten [edited]\n<http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article2056561.ece>\n\n\nAs if dealing with the possibility of contaminated water wasn't\nenough, officials at Norway's National Hospital in Oslo were also\nbattling an outbreak of infection linked to the listeria bacteria; 2\npatients are already dead. Personnel at both Rikshositalet and\nRadiumhospitalet, which have merged, were scrambling to pinpoint the\nsource of listeria infections.\n\nYet another case of listeria infection was confirmed Friday morning\n[19 Oct 2007] at the National Hospital (Rikshospitalet og\nRadiumhospitalet), which is the country's foremost cancer hospital\nand takes in patients from all over the country. Friday's case\nbring[s] to 12 the number of listeria infections identified since 1\nOct 2007. Of the infected patients, 2 have since died, probably\nbecause their immune systems were already weak because of their illnesses.\n\nHospital officials still haven't confirmed the source of the listeria\nbacteria but suspect it stemmed from contaminated cold food.\nAftenposten.no reported later on Friday afternoon [19 Oct 2007] that\ncheese had emerged as the main suspect.\n\nThe listeria bacteria is an especially dangerous one, leading to the\nserious illness known as listeriosis, which has a mortality rate of\n25 percent. The disease mostly affects pregnant women, newborns, and\nadults with weakened immune systems.\n\nHospital officials have discarded all supplies of refrigerated food\nfrom the kitchen that serves both Radium Hospital and Rikshospital.\nIntense testing was being carried out and officials said they\ncouldn't rule out the possibility of new cases, since the bacteria's\nincubation period can extend up to a month.\n\n[Byline: Nina Berglund]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ that is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm\nanimals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection\nresults in diarrhea and in some patients, invasive disease that\nincludes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses\nin the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine\ninfection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery,\ninfection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare\n(about 2500 cases occur annually in the US), but the disease has an\noverall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women,\npeople 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune\ndefenses (such as, HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to\ninvasive disease.\n\nThe organism can be killed by pasteurization, but heavy contamination\ncan reduce pasteurization's effectiveness. Although cooking can kill\nthe organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can\nrecontaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking\nprior to eating. The organism can then continue to grow in the\nrefrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat product, since _L. monocytogenes_\ngrows at refrigerator temperatures. Its presence in food does not\nalter the taste or smell of the food.\n\nImplicated food has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft\ncheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert,\nice cream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold\ncuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish,\nshellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken. - Mod.ML\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map for Norway can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=60.7,8.7,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 19 Oct 2007\n \n\nImplicated food has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft\ncheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert,\nice cream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, cold\ncuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish,\nshellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken. Infection\nresults in diarrhea and in some patients, invasive disease that\nincludes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses\nin the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine\ninfection. As if dealing with the possibility of contaminated water wasn't\nenough, officials at Norway's National Hospital in Oslo were also\nbattling an outbreak of infection linked to the listeria bacteria; 2\npatients are already dead. Although cooking can kill\nthe organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can\nrecontaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking\nprior to eating. Newborns, pregnant women,\npeople 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune\ndefenses (such as, HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to\ninvasive disease. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis, caused by _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ that is transmitted from the intestinal tract of farm\nanimals to humans by ingestion of contaminated food. \n\nThe listeria bacteria is an especially dangerous one, leading to the\nserious illness known as listeriosis, which has a mortality rate of\n25 percent. Invasive listeriosis is rare\n(about 2500 cases occur annually in the US), but the disease has an\noverall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. [19 Oct 2007] at the National Hospital (Rikshospitalet og\nRadiumhospitalet), which is the country's foremost cancer hospital\nand takes in patients from all over the country. Intense testing was being carried out and officials said they\ncouldn't rule out the possibility of new cases, since the bacteria's\nincubation period can extend up to a month.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9247", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9247", "date": "2007-03-26 21:00:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SANDWICHES - UNITED KINGDOM (ENGLAND): ALERT, RECALL\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 26 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/6496305.stm>\n\nA patient with listeriosis probably caught it by eating a sandwich\nfrom a contaminated batch that was recalled from hospitals, officials\nsaid. The sandwiches, made by Kent-based Anchor Catering, had been\ndistributed across Kent, Sussex, Surrey, Essex, Middlesex, and Greater London.\nOn Mon 26 Mar 2007, the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said the\nhospital patient had the same strain of listeria as the Anchor\nproducts. The HPA said the strain was uncommon and the cases were\nlikely to be linked.\n'An individual with a weakened immune system, who reported eating a\nlikely-to-be-Anchor sandwich in a hospital supplied by Anchor, has\ntested positive for the same strain of _Listeria_ as the one found at\nAnchor Catering,' an HPA statement said. The HPA has not said which\nhospital the patient was in, or released details about his/her condition.\nThe Food Standards Agency (FSA) recalled the sandwiches on 16 Mar\n2007. At that time, no cases of listeriosis had been reported, but\nthe FSA said symptoms could take up to 90 days to appear. The\nsandwiches, with use-by dates from 21 Feb to 14 Mar 2007 and labeled\neither Anchor or Pomegranate, had also been supplied to schools and\nbusinesses across the South East. Warnings came from the FSA that\n'large numbers' might have been eaten before the problem came to\nlight during routine tests on samples by Ashford Borough Council.\nAfter the alert, Anchor voluntarily suspended production at its\nsandwich factory, and recalled the products.\nThe FSA, which is investigating how the contamination happened, said\nmost illness caused by _Listeria_ can usually be treated with\nantimicrobial agents. Those most at risk from the infection are\npregnant women, the elderly, young babies, and people with weakened\nimmune systems. Initial symptoms include fever, a flu-like illness,\nor diarrhea.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has been following this story since the announcement of\nthe recall. Except for botulism or unusual circumstances, ProMED-mail\ndoes not report recalls unless clinical cases occur. Given the\noccurrence of a clinical case, this report and the original alert\nfrom HPA are now posted.\nBecause of the risk of listeriosis from sandwich cold meats, one\nmight think that their distribution as part of a menu in locations\nwhere particularly at-risk individuals such as health care settings\nis not a good idea. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 16 Mar 2007 [10 days ago]\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Protection Agency press statement [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpa/news/articles/press_releases/2007/070316_listeria.htm>\n\nThe Food Standards Agency (FSA) and Health Protection Agency (HPA)\nare alerting consumers about certain sandwiches that may have been\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ and supplied to establishments in London\nand the South East of England by Kent-based Anchor Catering. The HPA\nis not currently aware of any reported cases of listeria infection as\na result of eating these sandwiches.\nThe sandwiches, which had use by dates from 21 Feb to 14 Mar 2007,\nwere supplied to a range of establishments in Kent, Sussex, Essex,\nMiddlesex, Surrey, and Greater London including schools, hospitals,\nand local authorities before the problem became known. The majority\nof the sandwiches were labelled as Anchor products and some others\nwere labelled as Pomegranate.\nAshford local authority identified the problem after a very small\nnumber of samples tested positive for _Listeria_ during routine\nsampling. The risk of listeriosis from eating these sandwiches is\nvery low but as a precautionary measure, the FSA and HPA are alerting\nconsumers about the possible contamination. Vulnerable groups such as\npregnant women, the elderly, and those with lowered immunity are more at risk.\nDr Graham Bickler, Regional Director of the HPA South East said,\n'Most people will not suffer any ill effects but some groups of\npeople are more at risk and will need prompt treatment if they\ndevelop the infection. This group includes pregnant women, the\nelderly, young babies, and people whose immune systems are\ncompromised -- for example people with HIV or those undergoing chemotherapy.\n'We are not aware of any infection at present but want people in\nthose vulnerable groups to be aware that if they have eaten\nsandwiches from this company during the period in question and become\nill within 2-3 months they must seek medical advice. We also want\ndoctors and healthcare workers to be aware of the signs and symptoms\nof listeria infection so the correct treatment can be offered promptly.'\nAndrew Wadge, Chief Scientist at the FSA said, 'Listeria doesn't pose\na threat to the vast majority of the population but it can be serious\nfor some vulnerable groups such as pregnant women. We are working\nclosely with the company and the local authority to discover how this\nhappened. Although the company took prompt action to notify customers\nand withdraw the product, large numbers of sandwiches may have been\nconsumed before the problem was detected.'\nOn discovery of contamination, Anchor Catering voluntarily suspended\nproduction and has informed HPA that it contacted the establishments\nsupplied with the sandwiches to withdraw them from sale. The FSA and\nlocal authority are working with Anchor Catering to identify the\nsource of the contamination and production at the factory remains suspended.\nAlthough there are many other causes of these symptoms, anyone in one\nof the vulnerable groups who may be worried that they have been\nexposed and develops these symptoms, should take advice from their\nphysician or hospital consultant. The illness can usually be\neffectively treated with antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Health Protection Agency press statement [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/hpa/news/articles/press_releases/2007/070316_listeria.htm>\n\nThe Food Standards Agency (FSA) and Health Protection Agency (HPA)\nare alerting consumers about certain sandwiches that may have been\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ and supplied to establishments in London\nand the South East of England by Kent-based Anchor Catering. We are not aware of any infection at present but want people in\nthose vulnerable groups to be aware that if they have eaten\nsandwiches from this company during the period in question and become\nill within 2-3 months they must seek medical advice. An individual with a weakened immune system, who reported eating a\nlikely-to-be-Anchor sandwich in a hospital supplied by Anchor, has\ntested positive for the same strain of _Listeria_ as the one found at\nAnchor Catering,' an HPA statement said. The sandwiches, which had use by dates from 21 Feb to 14 Mar 2007,\nwere supplied to a range of establishments in Kent, Sussex, Essex,\nMiddlesex, Surrey, and Greater London including schools, hospitals,\nand local authorities before the problem became known. Source: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/6496305.stm>\n\nA patient with listeriosis probably caught it by eating a sandwich\nfrom a contaminated batch that was recalled from hospitals, officials\nsaid. The\nsandwiches, with use-by dates from 21 Feb to 14 Mar 2007 and labeled\neither Anchor or Pomegranate, had also been supplied to schools and\nbusinesses across the South East. Because of the risk of listeriosis from sandwich cold meats, one\nmight think that their distribution as part of a menu in locations\nwhere particularly at-risk individuals such as health care settings\nis not a good idea. Although there are many other causes of these symptoms, anyone in one\nof the vulnerable groups who may be worried that they have been\nexposed and develops these symptoms, should take advice from their\nphysician or hospital consultant. The majority\nof the sandwiches were labelled as Anchor products and some others\nwere labelled as Pomegranate.\n This group includes pregnant women, the\nelderly, young babies, and people whose immune systems are\ncompromised -- for example people with HIV or those undergoing chemotherapy. Those most at risk from the infection are\npregnant women, the elderly, young babies, and people with weakened\nimmune systems. The risk of listeriosis from eating these sandwiches is\nvery low but as a precautionary measure, the FSA and HPA are alerting\nconsumers about the possible contamination. On discovery of contamination, Anchor Catering voluntarily suspended\nproduction and has informed HPA that it contacted the establishments\nsupplied with the sandwiches to withdraw them from sale. The HPA\nis not currently aware of any reported cases of listeria infection as\na result of eating these sandwiches. On Mon 26 Mar 2007, the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said the\nhospital patient had the same strain of listeria as the Anchor\nproducts. Andrew Wadge, Chief Scientist at the FSA said, 'Listeria doesn't pose\na threat to the vast majority of the population but it can be serious\nfor some vulnerable groups such as pregnant women. Although the company took prompt action to notify customers\nand withdraw the product, large numbers of sandwiches may have been\nconsumed before the problem was detected.' The FSA, which is investigating how the contamination happened, said\nmost illness caused by _Listeria_ can usually be treated with\nantimicrobial agents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9941", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9941", "date": "2007-04-25 17:00:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, UNPASTEURIZED CHEESE - USA (INDIANA)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2007\nSource: The Indy Channel [edited]\n<http://www.theindychannel.com/news/13091454/detail.html>\n\nSerious health concerns are emerging from recent door-to-door sales\nin Indianapolis, from which at least one person has become seriously\nill. Someone is selling unpasteurized cheese on the city's west side.\nThe Marion County Health Department said it was made aware of the\nbad, white cheese on Tue 24 Apr 2007. Officials are worried that\nothers might buy the product.\nThe cheese was contaminated with a bacteria called _Listeria_.\nExperts said that it takes at least 3 weeks before someone who eats\nsomething contaminated with _Listeria_ to notice symptoms.\n'If something tastes bad, if it's spoiled, we tend not to eat it. We\navoid it,' said Dr. Crystal Jones, medical director of acute diseases\nfor the Marion County Health Department. '_Listeria_ can be in\nsomething that tastes perfectly good. We just don't know it, and if\nwe're in one of those at-risk populations, it can become a very\nserious thing.'\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Another posting from the litany of diseases associated with\nunpasteurized dairy products...\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw\nmilk, supposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly\nsoft-ripened varieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented\nraw-meat sausages, cold cuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all\ntypes), and raw and smoked fish. Its ability to grow at temperatures\nas low as 3 C permits multiplication in refrigerated foods. It is\nparticularly associated with intrauterine infection of pregnant women\nand meningitis in individuals with depression of cellular immunity.\nIndianapolis is located in Marion County in central Indiana and can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis,_Indiana>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "[Another posting from the litany of diseases associated with\nunpasteurized dairy products...\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw\nmilk, supposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly\nsoft-ripened varieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented\nraw-meat sausages, cold cuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all\ntypes), and raw and smoked fish. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Indy Channel [edited]\n<http://www.theindychannel.com/news/13091454/detail.html>\n\nSerious health concerns are emerging from recent door-to-door sales\nin Indianapolis, from which at least one person has become seriously\nill. It is\nparticularly associated with intrauterine infection of pregnant women\nand meningitis in individuals with depression of cellular immunity. We\navoid it,' said Dr. Crystal Jones, medical director of acute diseases\nfor the Marion County Health Department. '_ LISTERIOSIS, UNPASTEURIZED CHEESE - USA (INDIANA)\n*************************************************\n We just don't know it, and if\nwe're in one of those at-risk populations, it can become a very\nserious thing.' Indianapolis is located in Marion County in central Indiana and can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis,_Indiana>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marion County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indianapolis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "104286", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=104286", "date": "2008-08-21 11:00:30", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA: ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 20 Aug 2008\nSource: The Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5igoLk2tBEsp-UFfCW-9HROkxAj8g>\n\n\nAt least one person is dead and 16 others ill across Canada from a\nbacterial infection that can be fatal to the infirm, the elderly, and\nunborn children -- and could be linked to a massive, nationwide\nrecall of ready-to-eat meat products made by food giant Maple Leaf Foods.\n\nHealth authorities in Ontario are dealing with 12 confirmed cases of\nlisteriosis, a disease caused by the bacterium _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ -- often found in soil, vegetation, animal feed, and\nfeces, and recently in certain processed meats produced by a Maple\nLeaf plant in Toronto.\n\nListeriosis was the 'underlying cause of death' in the case of the\none known fatality, said Dr David Williams, Ontario's acting chief\nmedical officer of health. Williams provided no specifics except to\nsay the victim was from southern Ontario. The number of confirmed\ncases, which seem to consist primarily of nursing home residents,\ncould grow as health units across the province continue to submit\nreports on the disease, he added. 'The pattern was people in certain\nlong-term care facilities' across southern Ontario, Williams said.\n'The median age in the males is 76 and in the females is 80.'\n\nNursing homes, deli counters, and restaurants, including McDonald's\nand Mr Sub, are among the establishments where the meat products --\nwhich include turkey, ham, corned beef, and roast beef -- were\ndistributed. Maple Leaf (TSX:MFI) spokeswoman Linda Smith said the\ncompany is taking all the necessary precautions, including shutting\ndown the plant, providing additional food safety training for\nemployees, and ensuring the public is aware of the situation.\n\n'This is a company that has a culture of food safety,' Smith said.\n'We're taking appropriate, broad, comprehensive, and definitive\naction as it relates to this facility. This involves people -- we\nwant people to understand there's a recall, we want people to have\nthat information.' The recall is costing the company approximately\n[CAD] 2 million [USD 1.9 million], Smith added.\n\nWilliams said there are an additional 16 probable or suspected cases\nin the province [Ontario]. 'I strongly advise the public, especially\nthose at high risk for listeriosis ... to make sure they avoid\nconsuming these products,' he said in a statement. 'I have also asked\nall public health units to advise emergency rooms in their\njurisdictions to be on alert for cases. All suspect and confirmed\ncases of listeriosis must be reported immediately to local public\nhealth units and in turn to the ministry within one business day of\nnotification of report.'\n\nConsumption of food tainted with listeria can lead to high fever,\nsevere headache, neck stiffness, and nausea. The illness is a\nparticular danger to pregnant women and their unborn children, the\nelderly, and people with weakened immune systems, cancer, diabetes,\nkidney disease, or AIDS.\n\nSymptoms usually appear within 2 to 30 days, and up to 90 days after\nconsuming contaminated food, according to the Canadian Food\nInspection Agency. The average incubation period is about 3 weeks,\nsays the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care.\n\nThe remaining 4 confirmed cases include 2 in BC [British Columbia],\none in Saskatchewan, and one in Quebec. Health inspectors in all 4\nprovinces were working with Health Canada and the Canadian Food\nInspection Agency [CFIA] to confirm the source of the outbreak.\n\nMargaret Ringland, of the Ontario Association of Non-Profit Homes and\nServices for Seniors, which represents 180 non-profit homes in the\nprovince, said she's had no reports of suspicious deaths at the\nassociation's facilities. 'They would simply not use the meat; they\nwould move into other foods, it's as simple as that,' Ringland said.\n'People aren't going to take a chance. The products they're talking\nabout aren't ones that are a heavy part of menus in most of the\nhomes. I haven't heard from anybody who has an issue over this.'\n\nCFIA spokesman Garfield Balsom said he couldn't say how long it would\ntake to establish any possible links between Maple Leaf products and\nthe bacteria. 'To predict when you're going to complete an\ninvestigation is practically impossible,' he said. 'With the tomato\nissue in the United States, it went on for 3 or 4 months.'\n\nMaple Leaf is recalling all products prepared at the plant since [2\nJun 2008] and shutting down the plant through the weekend [23-24 Aug\n2008] for a comprehensive sanitization, Smith said. Employees are\nalso to receive additional food safety training, and the 2 production\nlines in question are to be dismantled, she added. On Sunday [17 Aug\n2008], the meat packer said it had discovered listeria in Sure Slice\nroast beef and corned beef produced at the Toronto facility and\nissued a recall on those products.\n\nBrand names for some of the recalled products include Schneiders,\nSure Slice, Deli Gourmet, and Burns Bites. A complete list of\naffected products is available on both the Maple Leaf Foods website\n(<http://www.mapleleaf.com>) and that of the CFIA\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca>). The 23 products involved in the\nexpanded recall carry an establishment number of 97B and have\nbest-before dates ranging from [30 Sep 2008 to 1 Jan 2009].\n\nBalsom said the CFIA first became aware of possible problems when it\nwas notified of a listeriosis outbreak on [6 Aug 2008] by a\nparticular health unit; subsequent investigation led them to Maple\nLeaf's Toronto facility, he said.\n\nMcDonald's Canada said Wednesday [20 Aug 2008] it is temporarily\nremoving its turkey BLT [bacon/lettuce/tomato] sandwich from its menu\nas a 'precautionary measure' -- the only item on the restaurant\nchain's menu that is affected. 'We apologize for any inconvenience\nthis may cause, but food safety and quality at McDonald's will not be\ncompromised,' the company said in a release. 'We are closely\nmonitoring the situation and are taking guidance from the Canadian\nFood Inspection Agency.'\n\nThe complete list of affected products, including individual product\ncodes and best-before dates, is as follows:\n\n26365, Sliced Cooked Turkey Breast, 470 grams, Sept. 30;\n02106, Schneiders Bavarian Smokies, 1 kilogram, Oct. 28;\n02126, Schneiders Cheddar Smokies, 1 kilogram, Oct. 28;\n21333, Sure Slice Roast Beef, 1 kilogram, Sept. 30;\n21388, Sure Slice Combo Pack, 1 kilogram, Sept. 30;\n60243, Deli Gourmet Roast Beef slices, 1 kilogram, Sept. 30;\n02356, Seasoned Cooked Roast Beef, 500 grams, Oct. 7;\n42706, Roast Beef, Seasoned and Cooked, 500 grams, Oct. 7;\n21334, Sure Slice Turkey Breast Roast, 1 kilogram, Oct. 14;\n21444, Sure Slice Corned Beef, 1 kilogram, Oct. 14;\n44938, Montreal Style Corned Beef, 500 grams, Oct. 14;\n21440, Sure Slice Black Forest Style Ham, 1 kilogram, Oct. 21;\n21447, Sure Slice Salami, 1 kilogram, Oct. 21;\n21331, Sure Slice Smoked Ham, 1 kilogram, Oct. 21;\n48019, Schneiders Deli Shaved Corned Beef, 200 grams, Oct. 21;\n48020, Schneiders Deli Shaved Smoked Meat, 200 grams, Oct. 21;\n48016, Schneiders Deli Shaved Smoked Ham, 200 grams, Oct. 21;\n48018, Schneiders Deli Shaved Smoked Turkey Breast, 150 grams, Oct. 21;\n48017, Schneiders Deli Shaved Fully Cooked Smoked Honey Ham, 200 grams,\nOct. 21;\n21360, Burns Bites Pepperoni, 500 grams, Jan. 21, 2009;\n99158, Turkey Breast Roast, 1 kilogram, Sept. 30;\n71330, Roast Beef Cooked, Seasoned, 2.5 kilograms, Sept. 30;\n71331 Corned Beef, Smoked Meat, 2.5 kilograms, Sept. 30.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail no.\n20071230.4186. Though unclear in the news release above, 17 cases of\nlisteriosis have apparently been confirmed: 13 in Ontario, 2 in\nBritish Columbia, and one each in Saskatchewan and Quebec\n(<http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080820/mlf_recall_080820/20080820?hub=CTVNewsAt11>).\n\n\nThe company has recalled 23 packaged meat products, including sliced\ncooked turkey breast, roast beef, and salami. _Listeria_ has not been\nfound in all of the 23 products now on recall, but the company is\nrecalling items that share a common production line with the tainted\nmeats\n(<http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080820/mlf_recall_080820/20080820?hub=CTVNewsAt11>).\nThe cause of the outbreak at present remains unknown; linkage between\nthe affected products and human illness likely will await genotyping\nthe isolated strains.\n\nA map of Canada can be located at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=55.4,-101.9,4>. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "The were\ndistributed. On Sunday [17 Aug\n2008], the meat packer said it had discovered listeria in Sure Slice\nroast beef and corned beef produced at the Toronto facility and\nissued a recall on those products. \n\nMcDonald's Canada said Wednesday [20 Aug 2008] it is temporarily\nremoving its turkey BLT [bacon/lettuce/tomato] sandwich from its menu\nas a 'precautionary measure' -- the only item on the restaurant\nchain's menu that is affected. ' Maple Leaf (TSX:MFI) spokeswoman Linda Smith said the\ncompany is taking all the necessary precautions, including shutting\ndown the plant, providing additional food safety training for\nemployees, and ensuring the public is aware of the situation.
