' The number of confirmed\ncases, which seem to consist primarily of nursing home residents,\ncould grow as health units across the province continue to submit\nreports on the disease, he added. ' All suspect and confirmed\ncases of listeriosis must be reported immediately to local public\nhealth units and in turn to the ministry within one business day of\nnotification of report.' Though unclear in the news release above, 17 cases of\nlisteriosis have apparently been confirmed: 13 in Ontario, 2 in\nBritish Columbia, and one each in Saskatchewan and Quebec\n A complete list of\naffected products is available on both the Maple Leaf Foods website\n(<http://www.mapleleaf.com>) and that of the CFIA\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca>). The illness is a\nparticular danger to pregnant women and their unborn children, the\nelderly, and people with weakened immune systems, cancer, diabetes,\nkidney disease, or AIDS. \n\nMaple Leaf is recalling all products prepared at the plant since [2\nJun 2008] and shutting down the plant through the weekend [23-24 Aug\n2008] for a comprehensive sanitization, Smith said. \n\nHealth authorities in Ontario are dealing with 12 confirmed cases of\nlisteriosis, a disease caused by the bacterium _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ -- often found in soil, vegetation, animal feed, and The 23 products involved in the\nexpanded recall carry an establishment number of 97B and have\nbest-before dates ranging from [30 Sep 2008 to 1 Jan 2009].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-21 00:00:00", "1980-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2356-03-26 00:00:00", "1976-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-10-28 00:00:00", "2106-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-10-07 00:00:00", "2021-10-14 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00", "2009-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2126-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "105479", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=105479", "date": "2008-08-25 17:00:30", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL, MEAT PRODUCT - CANADA (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Aug 2008\nSource: Canwest News Service [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/story.html?id=85232d03-4eb4-4211-a1e2-8c0a3c3e6680>\n\n\nHealth officials said Friday [22 Aug 2008] that 5 deaths have now\nbeen linked to a food-borne bacterial outbreak, including the 1st\nconfirmed death outside of Ontario. In the latest death linked to the\noutbreak of listeriosis, a BC [British Columbia] man died after\neating tainted meat he was served in hospital. The case raised the\nfrightening spectre that tainted meat may have been consumed in\nhospitals and care homes across the country.\n\nThe man, a 64-year-old Vancouver Island resident, died at Cowichan\nDistrict Hospital from the illness, which has been linked to the\nconsumption of tainted luncheon meat that was the subject of a\nnationwide recall.\n\n'We just got confirmation today [22 Aug 2008] from the Public Health\nAgency of Canada that it's the outbreak strain,' said Dr Lorna Medd,\nmedical health officer with the Vancouver Island Health Authority.\n\nThe man died on 29 Jul 2008 at the hospital in Duncan, about 60\nkilometres (37 mi) north of Victoria, but it took time to confirm the\ncause of death, the health authority said. 'This incident occurred\nprior to the Canada-wide recall of certain Maple Leaf products,' the\nBC Centre for Disease Control said in a statement late Friday [22 Aug\n2008].\n\nThe tainted meat was possibly served on Vancouver Island at Cowichan\nDistrict Hospital as well as Victoria General Hospital, Royal Jubilee\nHospital, Saanich Peninsula Hospital, Queen Alexandra Hospital,\nAberdeen, Glengarry, Mount Tolmie, the Priory, Gorge Road Hospital,\nCairnsmore Place, and Cowichan Lodge in Duncan and Tofino Hospital.\nThe product has now been removed from these sites and all other local\nhealth authority sites.\n\nTo date, 4 other deaths have been linked to listeriosis by health\nauthorities in Ontario and they are investigating whether 3 more\ndeaths were related to the disease. Dr Richard Schabas, medical\nofficer of health for Hastings and Prince Edward counties, said the\nmost recently confirmed death was an elderly man. 'We had a death\nfrom Hastings-Prince Edward counties, someone who we've now\nidentified as part of the _Listeria monocytogenes_ outbreak. The\ndeath occurred in the middle of July [2008],' Schabas said. He said\nthe number of deaths linked to listeriosis is likely to climb.\n\nEarlier Friday [22 Aug 2008], a Niagara public health official said\ntests confirmed the death of an elderly woman who lived in St\nCatharines, ON [Ontario], was related to the listeriosis outbreak.\nThe health authority in Waterloo, ON, confirmed a 2nd death, while\nthe Hamilton health authority announced the 1st related death\nThursday [21 Aug 2008].\n\nNiagara Public Health spokeswoman Carrie Beatty said a 2nd death of a\nresident from Niagara Falls, ON, was also under investigation, but\nresults are expected to be available until next week. 'We are saying\nit's probably because of contributing factors, like the time frame\nand the fact the person resided in a retirement home,' said Beatty of\nthe 2nd Niagara case.\n\nThere are at least 30 probable cases of the outbreak in Ontario and\nmore are expected, according to Dr David Williams, Ontario's acting\nchief medical officer of health.\n\nWhile the investigation continues, Maple Leaf Foods, Canada's biggest\nfood processor, has temporarily closed its north Toronto meat\nprocessing plant and has initiated special sanitation procedures\nthere. Maple Leaf said none of the suspect meat had crossed the\nborder into the USA.\n\n[Byline: Jorge Barrera, Becky Rynor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 24 Aug 2008\nSource: Globe and Mail and Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080824.wtaintedstaff24/BNStory/Front>\n\n\nThe tainted deli-meat crisis at Maple Leaf Foods will cost the\ncompany at least [CAD] 20 million [USD 19.12 million], it said Sunday\n[24 Aug 2008], 10 times more than originally expected as it pulls\nmore than 220 products off shelves across the country.\n\nIts Toronto processing facility was confirmed over the weekend [23-24\nAug 2008] as the source of a listeria outbreak tied to 4 deaths and\ndozens of illnesses. Maple Leaf has recalled more than 570 000\nkilograms (1.26 million lb) of meat produced at the plant, although\nproduction continues at its other 22 facilities across the country.\n\nChief executive officer Michael McCain updated the company's costs at\na Sunday [24 Aug 2008] press conference, saying the money would be\nspent reimbursing customers for returned products and sanitizing its\nfactory. He warned the figure was liable to change, if the company\nincreases its advertising budget amid lower sales.\n\nMost recently, the Public Health Agency of Canada has confirmed that\nthere are 21 cases of the listeriosis outbreak confirmed in 4\nprovinces. The agency said 16 of the cases were found in Ontario, 3\nin British Columbia, and one each in Saskatchewan and in Quebec.\n\nThe public health agency also said it suspects 30 more cases may be\nlinked to the listeria outbreak. Of those, 14 are in Ontario, 8 are\nin Quebec, 4 are in Alberta, and 2 each are in British Columbia and\nSaskatchewan.\n\nThe Maple Leaf recall, which began with a couple of brands a week\nago, now extends to everything from the company's Bartor Road plant\nin Toronto, more than 200 products.\n\nBrands include Artisan Collection, Best Value, Bittners,\nBittners/Schneiders, Boston Pizza, Burns, Campfire, Compliments,\nCoorsh, Country Morning, Equality, Fleetwood, Foodservice, Generic,\nHarmonie, Hickory Farms, Hygrade, Kirkland Signature, Main Street\nDeli, Maple Leaf, Mayfair/Marque, McDonalds, Mitchell's, Mr. Sub, No\nName, Northern Best Value, Olympic, Our Compliments, Overlander,\nParma, Safeway, Schneiders, and Shopsys.\n\nA full list of recalled products is available at\n<http://files.newswire.ca/464/RecallList.pdf>.\n\nMcCain said consumers could return any Maple Leaf product with 97B on\nthe label, code for the Bartor Road plant, to their retailer for a\nrefund.\n\n[Byline: Steve LaDurantaye]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDavid Fisman, MD MPH FRCPC\nHospital for Sick Children\nToronto\nCanada\n<david.fisman@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Kate Kelley for sending in a similar report.\nThis ongoing outbreak illustrates that almost all cases of\nlisteriosis are foodborne and appropriate genetic testing of isolates\non a large-scale basis will show relatedness of geographically\nseparated infections. Additionally, since listeriosis primarily\noccurs in the elderly and in cellularly immunoincompetent people as\nwell as in pregnant women, the serving of high risk foods in\nhospitals and homes for the elderly should be eliminated. As an\nexample, there is no reason to feed deli cold cuts as a lunch to a\nhospitalized patient under treatment for lymphoma. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nDavid Fisman, MD MPH FRCPC\nHospital for Sick Children\nToronto\nCanada\n<david.fisman@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Kate Kelley for sending in a similar report. Brands include Artisan Collection, Best Value, Bittners,\nBittners/Schneiders, Boston Pizza, Burns, Campfire, Compliments,\nCoorsh, Country Morning, Equality, Fleetwood, Foodservice, Generic,\nHarmonie, Hickory Farms, Hygrade, Kirkland Signature, Main Street\n \n\nWhile the investigation continues, Maple Leaf Foods, Canada's biggest\nfood processor, has temporarily closed its north Toronto meat\nprocessing plant and has initiated special sanitation procedures\nthere. \n\nThe tainted meat was possibly served on Vancouver Island at Cowichan\nDistrict Hospital as well as Victoria General Hospital, Royal Jubilee\nHospital, Saanich Peninsula Hospital, Queen Alexandra Hospital,\n This incident occurred\nprior to the Canada-wide recall of certain Maple Leaf products,' the\nBC Centre for Disease Control said in a statement late Friday [22 Aug\n2008]. The man, a 64-year-old Vancouver Island resident, died at Cowichan\nDistrict Hospital from the illness, which has been linked to the\nconsumption of tainted luncheon meat that was the subject of a\nnationwide recall. This ongoing outbreak illustrates that almost all cases of\nlisteriosis are foodborne and appropriate genetic testing of isolates\non a large-scale basis will show relatedness of geographically\nseparated infections. Additionally, since listeriosis primarily\noccurs in the elderly and in cellularly immunoincompetent people as\nwell as in pregnant women, the serving of high risk foods in\nhospitals and homes for the elderly should be eliminated. \n\n'We just got confirmation today [22 Aug 2008] from the Public Health\nAgency of Canada that it's the outbreak strain,' said Dr Lorna Medd,\nmedical health officer with the Vancouver Island Health Authority. Health officials said Friday [22 Aug 2008] that 5 deaths have now\nbeen linked to a food-borne bacterial outbreak, including the 1st\nconfirmed death outside of Ontario. [22 Aug 2008], a Niagara public health official said\ntests confirmed the death of an elderly woman who lived in St\nCatharines, ON [Ontario], was related to the listeriosis outbreak. \n\nMost recently, the Public Health Agency of Canada has confirmed that\nthere are 21 cases of the listeriosis outbreak confirmed in 4\nprovinces. \n\nNiagara Public Health spokeswoman Carrie Beatty said a 2nd death of a\nresident from Niagara Falls, ON, was also under investigation, but\nresults are expected to be available until next week. ' The man died on 29 Jul 2008 at the hospital in Duncan, about 60\nkilometres (37 mi) north of Victoria, but it took time to confirm the\ncause of death, the health authority said. ' \n\nThere are at least 30 probable cases of the outbreak in Ontario and\nmore are expected, according to Dr David Williams, Ontario's acting\nchief medical officer of health. The health authority in Waterloo, ON, confirmed a 2nd death, while\nthe Hamilton health authority announced the 1st related death\nThursday Dr Richard Schabas, medical\nofficer of health for Hastings and Prince Edward counties, said the\nmost recently confirmed death was an elderly man. ' In the latest death linked to the\noutbreak of listeriosis, a BC [British Columbia] man died after\neating tainted meat he was served in hospital. Its Toronto processing facility was confirmed over the weekend [23-24\nAug 2008] as the source of a listeria outbreak tied to 4 deaths and\ndozens of illnesses. \n\nThe Maple Leaf recall, which began with a couple of brands a week\nago, now extends to everything from the company's Bartor Road plant\nin Toronto, more than 200 products.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Waterloo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Niagara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hygrade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vancouver Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prince Edward", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8314", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, smoked fish - Australia (VIC, NSW): alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8314", "date": "2007-02-23 12:00:07", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SMOKED FISH - AUSTRALIA (VICTORIA, NEW SOUTH WALES): ALERT, RECALL\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 23 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Sydney Morning Herald [edited]\n<http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Listeria-scare-causes-food-recall/2007/02/23/1171734012842.html>\n\nA listeria contamination scare has forced a Victorian foodmaker to\nrecall its smoked trout mousse products after an elderly Melbourne\nman became ill.\nThe 89-year-old fell ill after eating the Yumi brand of smoked trout\nmousse. Subsequent tests proved positive for listeria, Victorian\nchief health officer Dr. Robert Hall said.\nThe health scare has prompted 200 gm. packs of Yumi-branded smoked\ntrout mousse or dip with use-by dates of 10-16 Mar 2007, to be\nrecalled from supermarkets across Victoria and New South Wales.\n'People should not eat this product and should return it to the point\nof purchase,' Dr. Hall said. 'The company is cooperating with the\nrecall and has assisted us in the investigation.'\nDepartment of Human Services spokesman Bram Alexander said the\n89-year-old man taken ill fully recovered after treatment [with antibiotics].\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Complete information about listeriosis is available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Sydney Morning Herald [edited]\n<http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Listeria-scare-causes-food-recall/2007/02/23/1171734012842.html>\n\nA listeria contamination scare has forced a Victorian foodmaker to\nrecall its smoked trout mousse products after an elderly Melbourne\nman became ill. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n packs of Yumi-branded smoked\ntrout mousse or dip with use-by dates of 10-16 Mar 2007, to be\nrecalled from supermarkets across Victoria and New South Wales. LISTERIOSIS, SMOKED FISH - AUSTRALIA (VICTORIA, NEW SOUTH WALES): ALERT, RECALL\n**********************************************************************\n The 89-year-old fell ill after eating the Yumi brand of smoked trout\nmousse.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Melbourne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8988", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Yersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8988", "date": "2007-03-19 19:00:02", "main_text": "YERSINIOSIS, LISTERIOSIS - CANADA (ONTARIO): UNPASTEURIZED MILK/CHEESE\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 19 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Globe and Mail [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070317.TORBRIEFS17-3/TPStory/TPNational/Ontario/>\n\nTwo recent cases of infection in children in Grey Bruce have been\nlinked to raw milk products, public health officials said yesterday,\n18 Mar 2007.\nA 2-year-old was taken to hospital with yersiniosis, a\ngastrointestinal infection, after drinking raw milk on her family\nfarm, according to a statement from Hazel Lynn, the local medical\nhealth officer.\nAnother infant was confirmed to have listeriosis, an infection that\ncauses flu-like symptoms, which seems to have come from raw milk\ncheese consumed by the baby's mother, Dr. Lynn said, adding that the\ninfant seems to be recovering.\nWomen with newborns should not consume raw milk or non-pasteurized\ndairy products in order to avoid infecting their babies, Dr. Lynn said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The association of listeriosis with unpasteurized cheese is well\nknown. The infection has also been reported to cause infection from\npasteurized milk. A well-reported example of this is an outbreak of\n45 cases of listeriosis from contaminated pasteurized chocolate milk\n(1). The report highlights, even with pasteurized milk, that\n- dairies should monitor final products for spoilage and for\npathogens, including _Listeria monocytogenes_;\n- expiration dates should be based on these tests;\n- high standards of plant sanitation must be maintained; and\n- consumers should always store their milk at 4 deg C (39.2 deg F) or\nless and should consume the products before their expiration dates.\nIndeed, since _L. monocytogenes_ may well contaminate milk\nexogenously, other studies have underscored (for example, reference\n2) the importance of good quality silage [fermented, high-moisture\nforage to be fed to cattle and sheep. - CopyEd.MJ], good milking\ntechniques, and barn hygiene in diminishing the risks of\ncontamination of raw milk with _L. monocytogenes_.\nThe other pathogen, probably _Yersinia enterocolitica_ (the species\nis not mentioned), parallels _L. monocytogenes_ in its ability to\nexogenously contaminate raw milk. Both, in addition, are able to\nreplicate at refrigerator temperatures and have contaminated\nnon-pasteurized as well as pasteurized milk (3, 4). An earlier\noutbreak of yersiniosis was associated with contaminated chocolate\nmilk similar to the listeriosis outbreak already cited. (5).\nContamination of raw milk clearly also occurs including these 2\npathogens (6) and pasteurization should substantially decrease the\nrisk of transmission. It is important to note that pasteurized milk\nis not sterile and can possibly contain these and/or other pathogens,\nand that post-pasteurization contamination can occur. Consumers\nshould follow the guidelines about storage at 4 deg C (39.2 deg F) or\nless and use prior to expiration date.\nReferences:\n1. Dalton CB, Austin CC, Sobel J, et al: An outbreak of\ngastroenteritis and fever due to _Listeria monocytogenes_ in milk. N\nEngl J Med 1997; 336: 100-5.\n2. Sanaa M, Poutrel B, Menard JL, Serieys F: Risk factors associated\nwith contamination of raw milk by _Listeria monocytogenes_ in dairy\nfarms. J Dairy Sci. 1993; 76: 2891-8.\n3. Greenwood MH, Hooper WL: Excretion of _Yersinia spp._ associated\nwith consumption of pasteurized milk. Epidemiol Infect. 1990; 104: 345-50.\n4. Ackers ML, Schoenfeld S, Markman J, et al: An outbreak of\n_Yersinia enterocolitica_ O:8 infections associated with pasteurized\nmilk. J Infect Dis. 2000; 181: 1834-7.\n5. Black RE, Jackson RJ, Tsai T, et al: Epidemic _Yersinia\nenterocolitica_ infection due to contaminated chocolate milk. N Engl\nJ Med 1978; 298: 76-9.\n6. Jayarao BM, Henning DR: Prevalence of foodborne pathogens in bulk\ntank milk. J Dairy Sci. 2001; 84: 2157-62.\nThe Gray Bruce region is on the Bruce Peninsula in southern Ontario,\nincluding the city of Owen Sound. For a map, see\n<http://www.visitontario.com/images/Area_Map.jpg> - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The report highlights, even with pasteurized milk, that\n- dairies should monitor final products for spoilage and for\npathogens, including _Listeria monocytogenes_;\n- expiration dates should be based on these tests;\n- high standards of plant sanitation must be maintained; and\n- consumers should always store their milk at 4 deg C (39.2 deg F) or\nless and should consume the products before their expiration dates.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Globe and Mail [edited]\n<http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070317.TORBRIEFS17-3/TPStory/TPNational/Ontario/>\n\nTwo recent cases of infection in children in Grey Bruce have been\nlinked to raw milk products, public health officials said yesterday,\n18 Mar 2007. Another infant was confirmed to have listeriosis, an infection that\ncauses flu-like symptoms, which seems to have come from raw milk\ncheese consumed by the baby's mother, Dr. Lynn said, adding that the\ninfant seems to be recovering. A 2-year-old was taken to hospital with yersiniosis, a\ngastrointestinal infection, after drinking raw milk on her family\nfarm, according to a statement from Hazel Lynn, the local medical\nhealth officer. Indeed, since _L. monocytogenes_ may well contaminate milk\nexogenously, other studies have underscored (for example, reference\n2) the importance of good quality silage [fermented, high-moisture\nforage to be fed to cattle and sheep. - CopyEd. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Both, in addition, are able to\nreplicate at refrigerator temperatures and have contaminated\nnon-pasteurized as well as pasteurized milk (3, 4). A well-reported example of this is an outbreak of\n45 cases of listeriosis from contaminated pasteurized chocolate milk\n(1). Contamination of raw milk clearly also occurs including these 2\npathogens (6) and pasteurization should substantially decrease the\nrisk of transmission. An earlier\noutbreak of yersiniosis was associated with contaminated chocolate\nmilk similar to the listeriosis outbreak already cited. The other pathogen, probably _Yersinia enterocolitica_ (the species\nis not mentioned), parallels _L. monocytogenes_ in its ability to\nexogenously contaminate raw milk. YERSINIOSIS, LISTERIOSIS - CANADA (ONTARIO): UNPASTEURIZED MILK/CHEESE\n**********************************************************************\n Consumers\nshould follow the guidelines about storage at 4 deg C (39.2 deg F) or\nless and use prior to expiration date. Women with newborns should not consume raw milk or non-pasteurized\ndairy products in order to avoid infecting their babies, Dr. Lynn said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "1834-07-26 00:00:00", "2891-08-26 00:00:00", "1990-03-26 00:00:00", "1978-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "1993-03-26 00:00:00", "2000-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dalton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grey Bruce", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7922", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - Czech Republic (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7922", "date": "2007-02-14 12:00:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CZECH REPUBLIC (02)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 13 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: United Press International [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Science/20070213-113200-7345r/>\n\nCzech public health officials say _Listeria_ bacteria has spread to\nmore food products, killing 14 people across the country.\nA recent outbreak of listeriosis originated in a Czech dairy plant,\nwhose production was stopped immediately, but the latest contaminated\nfood was bacon sold in the Litomerice region, Prague Radio reported\nTue 13 Feb 2007.\nIn January 2007, health officials said 13 people had died of\nlisteriosis in the Czech Republic. More than 90 people have fallen\nill with listeria infection during the past several months.\nThe strain of bacteria had been [identified] in soft cheese, salads,\nand fish before it was recently found in bacon.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not clear from this posting how many cases are new diagnoses\nfrom 2007, since the last posting that reported on cases from 2006.\nIn that posting from Eurosurveillance, 75 cases were noted (now the\nnumber is 90) with 12 deaths (now 14 are reported). It is also not\nclear if the contaminated bacon has been shown to be\nmicrobiologically linked to clinical cases.\nLitomerice is in the north part of Czech Republic in the Usti nad\nLabem Region and is approximately 72 km (45 miles) northwest of\nPrague.\nIts location can be found on a map of the country at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Litom%C4%9B%C5%99ice>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A recent outbreak of listeriosis originated in a Czech dairy plant,\nwhose production was stopped immediately, but the latest contaminated\nfood was bacon sold in the Litomerice region, Prague Radio reported\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Source: United Press International [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Science/20070213-113200-7345r/>\n\nCzech public health officials say _Listeria_ bacteria has spread to\nmore food products, killing 14 people across the country. It is also not\nclear if the contaminated bacon has been shown to be\nmicrobiologically linked to clinical cases. Litomerice is in the north part of Czech Republic in the Usti nad\nLabem Region and is approximately 72 km (45 miles) northwest of\nPrague. [It is not clear from this posting how many cases are new diagnoses\nfrom 2007, since the last posting that reported on cases from 2006. In that posting from Eurosurveillance, 75 cases were noted (now the\nnumber is 90) with 12 deaths (now 14 are reported). In January 2007, health officials said 13 people had died of\nlisteriosis in the Czech Republic. The strain of bacteria had been [identified] in soft cheese, salads,\nand fish before it was recently found in bacon. More than 90 people have fallen\nill with listeria infection during the past several months. Date: Tue 13 Feb 2007\n Its location can be found on a map of the country at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Litom%C4%9B%C5%99ice>. LISTERIOSIS - CZECH REPUBLIC (02)\n **\n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-02-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-01-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "45864", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=45864", "date": "2007-12-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA, MASSACHUSETTS): ALERT\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 18 Dec 2007\nSource: WNCT.com [edited]\n<http://www.wnct.com/midatlantic/nct/features.apx.-content-articles-NCT-2007-12-18-0027.html>\n\n\nOfficials with the North Carolina Division of Public Health are\ncautioning pregnant women against consumption of soft cheeses, hot\ndogs and deli-style meats and prepared salads. The warning comes\nafter 3 cases of listeriosis were identified in Moore, Durham and\nMecklenburg counties and a probable case was identified in Buncombe\nCounty.\n\nThe 3 confirmed cases all involved Latinas; 2 (Durham and Mecklenburg\ncounties) of them were pregnant women whose pregnancies resulted in\nmiscarriages as result of the infection. The 3rd case (Moore County)\ninvolved a pregnant woman as well. As a result of the disease, she\ndelivered early, but she and the baby are doing well. The probable\ncase (Buncombe County) involves another pregnant Latina who also lost\nher baby. All 4 had consumed soft cheeses from a variety of sources.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated\nwith the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. Listeriosis outbreaks\nhave been associated with consumption of unpasteurized (raw) milk and\ncontaminated soft cheeses, vegetables and ready-to-eat meats. The\ndisease affects primarily pregnant women, newborns, and people with\nweakened immune systems.\n\n'This is a tragedy, which could have been avoided,' said State\nEpidemiologist Dr. Jeff Engel. 'Listeriosis can be prevented by\navoiding unpasteurized milk and other potentially contaminated food,\nespecially among vulnerable people.'\n\nAlthough the cases occurred close together in time, data from\nmolecular testing conducted at the State Laboratory of Public Health\nshowed that different strains were involved, and therefore a single\nproduct does not seem to be the source of these cases, prompting\npublic health officials to issue a general listeria warning.\n\nA person with listeriosis has fever, muscle aches, and sometimes\ngastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. If infection\nspreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache, stiff neck,\nconfusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. Pregnant women\nand people with depressed immune systems are most likely to become\nseriously ill as a result of the disease.\n\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ is found in soil and water. Vegetables can\nbecome contaminated from the soil or from manure used as fertilizer.\nAnimals can carry the bacterium without appearing ill and can\ncontaminate foods of animal origin such as meats and dairy products.\nThe bacterium has been found in a variety of raw foods, such as\nuncooked meats and vegetables, as well as in processed foods that\nbecome contaminated after processing, such as soft cheeses and cold\ncuts at the deli counter. Unpasteurized (raw) milk or foods made from\nunpasteurized milk are at increased risk to contain the bacterium.\n\nGeneral recommendations to avoid listeriosis include: Avoid\nunpasteurized (raw) milk or foods made from unpasteurized milk;\nthoroughly cook raw food from animal sources; wash raw vegetables\nbefore eating; wash hands, knives, and cutting board after handling\nuncooked foods; consume perishable and ready-to-eat foods as soon as\npossible.\n\nRecommendations for people at high risk, such as pregnant women and\npersons with weakened immune systems, in addition to the\nrecommendations listed above include: Do not eat hot dogs, luncheon\nmeats, or deli meats unless they are reheated until steaming hot;\navoid getting fluid from hot dog packages on other foods, utensils,\nand food preparation surfaces, and wash hands after handling hot\ndogs, luncheon meats, and deli meats; do not eat soft cheeses such as\nfeta, brie, and camembert, blue-veined cheeses, or Mexican-style\ncheeses such as queso blanco, queso fresco, and panela, unless they\nhave labels that clearly state they are made from pasteurized milk;\ndo not eat refrigerated pates or meat spreads (canned or shelf-stable\npates and meat spreads may be eaten); do not eat refrigerated smoked\nseafood unless it is contained in a cooked dish such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,'\n'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n\nMore information about listeriosis and other communicable diseases\ncan be found on the web at\n<http://www.epi.state.nc.us/epi/gcdc.html>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 28 Dec 2007 [edited]\nSource: Boston.com [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/12/28/2_die_from_listeriosis_in_massachusetts/?rss_id=Boston.com+--+National+news>\n\n\nState health officials warned consumers not to drink milk produced by\na Massachusetts dairy, saying it was the likely source of a bacterial\nillness that killed 2 men and sickened 2 others.\n\nWhittier Farms suspended operations and distribution, said Dr. Alfred\nDeMaria, the state director of communicable disease control. Most of\nits customers live in Worcester County. The Department of Public\nHealth issued the warning Thursday [27 Dec 2007] after identifying 4\ncases of listeriosis. Two of the victims, a 78-year-old man and a\n75-year-old man, died in June and October 2007.\n\nInvestigators have not identified the exact source of the\ncontamination in the production process, DeMaria said. But milk\nsamples gathered last week at one of the dairy's 2 retail stores\ntested positive for listeria. Testing showed that the bacteria\ncausing the infections in the 4 victims likely came from the same\nsource.\n\nOfficials at Whittier Farms did not immediately return calls Thursday\n[27 Dec 2007] seeking comment. The dairy has a processing plant in\nShrewsbury and operates 2 retail stores. A message left on an\nanswering machine at the Sutton store said it was closed and that\ninformation to date was ''inconclusive.'' The message said the owners\nwould be addressing the issue as soon as possible.\n\nWhittier Farms' milk products are sold under several brand names,\nincluding Whittier, Schultz, Balance Rock, Spring Brook, and Maple,\nstate health officials said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMark A. Jensen, Ph.D.\nAsst. Professor\nDept. of Epidemiology & Biostatistics\nCollege of Public Health, and Dept. of Genetics\nFranklin College of Arts & Sciences\nUniversity of Georgia\nAthens, GA 30602\n<maj@uga.edu>\n\n****\n[3]\nDate: Thu 27 Dec 2007\nSource: The Milford Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.milforddailynews.com/homepage/x2133873242>\n\n\nThe Department of Public Health (DPH) has issued a warning to\nconsumers not to drink any milk products from Whittier Farms\n[<http://www.whittierfarms.com/index.html>]\nin Shrewsbury because of listeria bacteria contamination, which has\ncontributed to the deaths of 2 people. Four cases of listeriosis\ninfection have been identified by DPH, according to a statement\nreleased by the state department late this afternoon [27 Dec 2007].\nThe cases occurred in June, October and 2 in November 2007. The 4\ncases involved 3 elderly residents and a pregnant woman from\nWorcester county. Two of the people have died. They have not been\nidentified.\n\nDNA fingerprinting conducted by the State Laboratory Institute showed\nthat the bacteria causing these infections came from a common source.\nSamples collected showed product contamination. Listeriosis is a\nserious foodborne disease that can be life-threatening to certain\nindividuals. While most cases of listeriosis occur in adults with\nweakened immune systems, the elderly, pregnant women and newborns,\ninfections can occasionally occur in healthy individuals. 'Although\nevidence suggests that contamination is likely to be at a low level\nand the risk of infection low, even in those at high risk, it is\nrecommended that consumers do not consume these products and discard\nany of these products they have,' said DPH Director of Communicable\nDisease Control Dr. Al DeMaria.\n\nSymptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches and sometimes\ngastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. The illness may\nbe mild, and symptoms are sometimes described as flu-like.\n\nAbout 2500 cases of listeriosis occur each year in the United States.\n22 cases occurred in Massachusetts in 2006. For more information\nabout listeria, call (617) 983-6800 or visit\n<http://www.mass.gov/dph>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Sat 29 Dec 2007\nSource: The Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/12/29/state_is_seeking_cause_of_bad_milk/>\n\n\nA series of routine state inspections this fall 2007 found no health\nviolations at a central Massachusetts dairy farm linked this week to\na bacterial illness that killed 2 elderly men and made 2 other people\nill, according to documents obtained by the [Boston] Globe. But those\nreviews did not look specifically for evidence of listeria [_Listeria\nmoncytogenes_], the bacterium that sickened the 3 men and one woman.\nInstead, following guidelines established by federal health\nregulators, the laboratory at the state Department of Public Health\ntested milk from Whittier Farms for its overall bacteria count,\nfinding only one sample with a marginally elevated level of germs. A\ndairy is cited only if there is a 2nd elevated test on the same\nproduct.\n\nWhittier agreed to halt production on Thursday [27 Dec 2007], and a\nspokesman for the public health agency, Tom Lyons, said last night\nthat when Whittier resumes operations, the state will test milk from\nthe mom-and-pop dairy specifically for listeria. But there are no\nimmediate plans to begin testing for the germ statewide, he said.\nMilk is sampled monthly at all dairies in the state, with more\nexacting reviews carried out 4 times a year. 'We'll certainly take a\nlook at [broader testing for listeria], but no state in the country\ndoes this type of testing,' Lyons said. 'That's because this type of\nbacteria is not usually found to occur in pasteurized milk products.'\n\nThe inspection reports, including an exhaustive quarterly review\ncompleted just 3 weeks ago, only served to deepen the mystery around\nthe dairy and the listeriosis cases, an illness heralded by flu-like\nsymptoms that can progress into life-threatening neurological\nconditions. The state's top disease tracker said he knew of only 2\nother situations in the United States in the past 2 decades when\npasteurized milk was identified as the source of a cluster of\nlisteriosis cases. 'We always ask about hot dogs and soft cheese and\ncold cuts; those are the most implicated foods,' said Dr. Alfred\nDeMaria, the state's director of communicable disease control.\n\nMilk is suspected as the cause in this case because a bottle of\nlisteria-contaminated, coffee-flavored milk was found in the\nrefrigerator of one victim, and the genetic fingerprint of that\nstrain matched the bacteria found in all 4 victims. Also, listeria\nwas found in a milk sample taken last week at one of Whittier's\nstores.\n\nFamily-owned Whittier continued to decline requests for interviews\nyesterday [28 Dec 2007], issuing a statement that it promised to\ncooperate with state investigators and adding that 'we strive to\nproduce the best product, and, therefore, we are extremely concerned\nabout the situation.' As word spread across Worcester County that\nWhittier had halted production, milk drinkers flooded a state hot\nline, corner stores discarded gallons of the drink, and delivery men\nlamented losing customers.\n\nThe state disease hot line received 50 to 100 calls from consumers\nand their physicians expressing concerns about potential exposure to\nlisteria. Patients were told to see their doctors if they were ill,\nand physicians were told to send blood samples for testing at the\nstate laboratory.\n\nAt the Bagel Time deli in Worcester, general manager Tracy Adams had\na worker begin removing Whittier Farms products from the shelves\nbefore sunrise. The shop has been a loyal customer, offering milk\nflavored with coffee, strawberry, and chocolate. Bagel Time is a\ntypical Whittier buyer: a small, neighborhood business, not a major\nchain. Shaw's Supermarkets, for instance, does not sell Whittier\nproducts, which are marketed under brand names that include Whittier,\nSchultz, Balance Rock, Spring Brook, Maple, and Model. Whittier also\nruns its own shops in West Sutton and Shrewsbury. 'It's unfortunate\nbecause their product was top quality,' Adams said. 'They more than\nlikely will not survive this, so we're at a loss.'\n\nFor Brian Gay, the news was especially devastating. Gay delivers\ndirectly to the doorsteps of hundreds of customers. His company is\ncalled Maple Farm Dairy, but his milk actually comes from Whittier\nFarms. Yesterday [28 Dec 2007], his voicemail box overflowed with\ncustomers. Some complained of headaches that they wanted to blame on\nthe milk. Others said that their child's diarrhea surely must be a\nresult of contaminated milk. So he made the necessary decision to\nbegin delivering another company's product, even as some of his\ncustomers told him they were finished with home delivery.\n\n[Byline: Stephen Smith and Megan Woolhouse]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[ _Listeria monocytogenes_, the cause of listeriosis, is widely\ndistributed in nature. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. Most human\ninfections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur\nfrom mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an\ninfected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in\nveterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals.\nContamination of food can occur in nature, e.g., raw vegetables\ncontaminated by soil and manure, and raw milk by infected cows, or\nfollowing subsequent cooking or other processing.\n\nBecause the organisms can multiply at refrigerator temperatures, it\nis not surprising that listeriosis is usually associated with\ningestion of contaminated milk, meat or vegetable products that have\nbeen held at refrigeration temperatures. Listeria can also survive in\nfrozen food. Consumption of raw milk, raw-milk soft cheeses (e.g.,\nbrie, camembert, and Mexican soft cheeses), coleslaw, pate, deli\nmeats, and hotdogs have been sources of human listeriosis. The\nsources of human infection can be pinpointed by DNA identification\ntechniques matching _Listeria_ spp isolated from a possible source\nwith a species recovered from a patient.\n\nThe following is from the previous ProMED-mail post 'Listeriosis,\nnosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452:' Listeriosis is a\nworld-wide zoonosis caused by _Listeria moncytogenes_, which is\ntransmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by\ningestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and in\nsome patients invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an\nevident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord,\nendocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy\ncan lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or\nstillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur\nannually in the US), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of\n20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or\nolder, and those with compromised immune defenses (e.g., HIV-infected\npatients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nThe organism can be killed by pasteurization, but heavy contamination\ncan reduce pasteurization's effectiveness. Although cooking can kill\nthe organism, contaminated surfaces in food preparation areas can\ncontaminate previously cooked food that requires no further cooking\nprior to eating. The organism can then continue grow in the\nrefrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat product, since _L. monocytogenes_\ngrows at refrigerator temperatures. Its presence in food does not\nalter the taste or smell of the food.\n\nImplicated food has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft\ncheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie and camembert, ice\ncream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as cole slaw, cold\ncuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish,\nshellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nThe last 2 articles provide further detail of the outbreak of\nlisteriosis in Massachusetts. Article 3 documents that 3 patients\nwere elderly and one was pregnant. Newborns, pregnant women, people\n60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses\n(e.g., HIV-infected patients) are more susceptible to severe forms of\nlisteriosis. The articles also document that the linkage was found by\nDNA fingerprint between an isolate from chocolate-flavored milk found\nin the refrigerator of one of the 4 patients and the isolates from\nall 4 victims. Also, listeria was cultured from a milk sample taken\nlast week at one of Whittier's stores, but it is not stated whether\nDNA fingerprinting was done on this isolate. Whittier's raw milk\ncould be contaminated with listeria, which then survived perhaps\nfaulty pasteurization and further proliferated in milk stored in the\nrefrigerator (because this organism can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures), or the milk could have been contaminated after\npasteurization, e.g., in the process of adding the chocolate-flavor.\nThe article does not state whether the listeria-positive milk sample\nin one of Whittier's stores was plain or the chocolate-flavored\nvariety, or whether all the patients gave a history of drinking the\nchocolate-flavored variety - Mod.ML]", "summary": "\n\nRecommendations for people at high risk, such as pregnant women and\npersons with weakened immune systems, in addition to the\nrecommendations listed above include: Do not eat hot dogs, luncheon\nmeats, or deli meats unless they are reheated until steaming hot;\navoid getting fluid from hot dog packages on other foods, utensils,\nand food preparation surfaces, and wash hands after handling hot\ndogs, luncheon meats, and deli meats; do not eat soft cheeses such as\nfeta, brie, and camembert, blue-veined cheeses, or Mexican-style\ncheeses such as queso blanco, queso fresco, and panela, unless they\nhave labels that clearly state they are made from pasteurized milk;\ndo not eat refrigerated pates or meat spreads (canned or shelf-stable\npates and meat spreads may be eaten); do not eat refrigerated smoked\nseafood unless it is contained in a cooked dish such as a casserole. \n\nGeneral recommendations to avoid listeriosis include: Avoid\nunpasteurized (raw) milk or foods made from unpasteurized milk;\nthoroughly cook raw food from animal sources; wash raw vegetables\nbefore eating; wash hands, knives, and cutting board after handling\nuncooked foods; consume perishable and ready-to-eat foods as soon as\npossible. Whittier's raw milk\ncould be contaminated with listeria, which then survived perhaps\nfaulty pasteurization and further proliferated in milk stored in the\nrefrigerator (because this organism can multiply at refrigerator\ntemperatures), or the milk could have been contaminated after\npasteurization, e.g., in the process of adding the chocolate-flavor. Although\nevidence suggests that contamination is likely to be at a low level\nand the risk of infection low, even in those at high risk, it is\nrecommended that consumers do not consume these products and discard\nany of these products they have,' said DPH Director of Communicable\nDisease Control Dr. Al DeMaria. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nImplicated food has included raw milk and pasteurized milk, soft\ncheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie and camembert, ice\ncream, raw vegetables, delicatessen salads such as cole slaw, cold\ncuts, turkey franks and other hot dogs, raw and smoked fish,\nshellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken. The organism can be found in soil, water,\nsilage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw and pasteurized\nmilk, soft cheeses, kitchen premises, and in the intestinal tract of\nmany animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and in\ncrustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects. \n\nAlthough the cases occurred close together in time, data from\nmolecular testing conducted at the State Laboratory of Public Health\nshowed that different strains were involved, and therefore a single\nproduct does not seem to be the source of these cases, prompting\npublic health officials to issue a general listeria warning. \n\nThe following is from the previous ProMED-mail post 'Listeriosis,\nnosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452:' Listeriosis is a\nworld-wide zoonosis caused by _Listeria moncytogenes_, which is\ntransmitted from the intestinal tract of farm animals to humans by\ningestion of contaminated food. \n\nThe inspection reports, including an exhaustive quarterly review\ncompleted just 3 weeks ago, only served to deepen the mystery around\nthe dairy and the listeriosis cases, an illness heralded by flu-like\nsymptoms that can progress into life-threatening neurological\nconditions. Most human\ninfections are foodborne, although vertical transmission can occur\nfrom mother to fetus transplacentally or during delivery through an\ninfected birth canal, and localized skin infections can occur in\nveterinarians and farmers by direct contact with infected animals. Four cases of listeriosis\ninfection have been identified by DPH, according to a statement\nreleased by the state department late this afternoon", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-10-26 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-06-26 00:00:00", "2007-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Balance Rock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Whittier", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Sutton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worcester County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MASSACHUSETTS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shrewsbury", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buncombe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buncombe \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moore County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spring Brook", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209040", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209040", "date": "2005-12-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, NOSOCOMIAL - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) (02)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease Gateway Alert\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/anbs3>\nDate: Tue, 13 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ABC News Online [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200512/s1530254.htm>\n\nNew tests have confirmed that food products from an Adelaide company were\ncontaminated with the same strain of listeria that contributed to the death\nof a man at the Royal Adelaide Hospital. Another person died in hospital in\nGawler, while 2 women are recovering from the illness.\nYesterday, 12 Dec 2005, products from Conroy's Smallgoods Bowden factory\nwere recalled. Today the Health Minister John Hill confirmed that 2\nproducts from the company, ham steak and corned beef, tested positive for\nlisteria.\n'That's the same listeria that was found on equipment in Conroy's plant.\nIt's also the same material that's been found in the Royal Adelaide\nHospital,' he said. [It is not stated specifically if the matching hospital\nisolates were from the kitchen or were clinical isolates. - Mod.LL] It is\nstill not known if it has the same molecular make-up as the bacteria found\nin those who died.\nThe CSIRO's Food Science Australia has been appointed to carry out an audit\nof the way the Health Department handled the outbreak and the way the Royal\nAdelaide Hospital supplies food to its patients.\nConroy's Smallgoods has now removed all its products, except bacon, from sale.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200512/s1530254.htm>\n\nNew tests have confirmed that food products from an Adelaide company were\ncontaminated with the same strain of listeria that contributed to the death\nof a man at the Royal Adelaide Hospital. The CSIRO's Food Science Australia has been appointed to carry out an audit\nof the way the Health Department handled the outbreak and the way the Royal\n It is\nstill not known if it has the same molecular make-up as the bacteria found\nin those who died. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease Gateway Alert\n< [It is not stated specifically if the matching hospital\nisolates were from the kitchen or were clinical isolates. LISTERIOSIS, NOSOCOMIAL - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA) (02)\n http://thelancet.url123.com/anbs3>\n **\n >\nSource: ABC News Online \n \n' \n \n \n \n That's the same listeria that was found on equipment in Conroy's plant. Conroy's Smallgoods has now removed all its products, except bacon, from sale. Adelaide Hospital supplies food to its patients.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-12-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Conroy", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7490", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - Czech Republic: 2006", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7490", "date": "2007-02-08 17:00:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CZECH REPUBLIC: 2006\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 8 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070208.asp#1>\n\nFor more than 30 years up to 2006, the incidence of human listeriosis\nin the Czech Republic has been low, ranging between 0.1 and 0.2 cases\nper 100 000 population per year. In 2006, however, the incidence of\nhuman listeriosis was about 0.7. Altogether, 75 cases of listeriosis\nwere reported to have occurred in 2006 [Figure 1. For figures, see\noriginal URL. - Mod.LL], and a few more are still under\ninvestigation. 43 cases were registered during the last quarter of\nthe year (Figure 2). For comparison, in 2005, the overall number of\ncases was 15.\nThe majority of patients with listeriosis were elderly people; 52\npercent of patients were aged 60 and above [Table. For table, see\noriginal URL. - Mod.LL]. In general, men were affected more often\nthan women (42 versus 33 cases), but in the age group 20-39 years,\nwomen (especially pregnant women, 11 cases) constituted the majority\nof patients. A diagnosis of neonatal listeriosis was made in 14\ncases. Miscarriage as a consequence of infection was reported in 2\nwomen. 12 of the 75 patients died. 10 of the deaths were in adults\nbetween 51 and 80 years of age (mean age 71) and 2 in newborn babies.\nThe breakdown of cases by age identified the 3 main population groups\nat risk: newborns, pregnant women and immunocompromised elderly people.\nGeographically, almost half of the country was affected, with 38 out\nof the 76 districts reporting human cases of listeriosis (Figure 3).\nAlthough cases occurred in both Bohemia (western region of the\ncountry) and Moravia (eastern), the latter registered higher\nincidence (0.5 per 100 000 in Bohemia versus 0.99 per 100 000 in Moravia).\nNotification of cases:\nIn the Czech Republic, listeriosis is one of the mandatory notifiable\ndiseases reported within the EPIDAT system. The standard\ndemographical, clinical, laboratory and epidemiological data\ncollected do not include detailed clinical information. All reported\nlisteriosis cases are always laboratory confirmed.\nThe patients affected in the 2006 outbreak (all who recovered) were\ninterviewed by qualified senior epidemiologists to establish what\nfood they had consumed and what their dietary habits were, however,\nno standard questionnaire was used. Most patients reported having\neaten mature cheeses and mixed salads.\nLaboratory findings:\nStrains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolated both from patients and\nfood samples (altogether 36 isolates) were forwarded to the Czech\nnational reference laboratory for listeria for detailed serotyping,\npulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE), and antibiotic susceptibility testing.\nFood consumed by the patients was not available for laboratory\nanalysis. However, food samples collected during inspections of food\nproduction sites and sale outlets were analyzed for listeria.\nLaboratory analysis showed that all strains detected belonged to\nserotype 1/2b and none was found to be resistant against ampicillin,\npenicillin, tetracycline and cotrimoxazole. 30 human isolates were\nanalyzed by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis; 26 belonged to the same\npulse type (type A), and only 4 were types B, C, E1 and X. The pulse\ntype A was also confirmed in 2 isolates gained from a sample of\nmature cheese collected in different food store chains. Several\npatients confirmed consumption of this particular cheese. Another\npulse type was detected in a different sort of mature cheese produced\nby another manufacturer. Furthermore, the pulse type of an isolate of\none patient corresponded with the type found in a mixed salad\ncontaining salami, cheese, vegetable and dressing. The analysis of\nisolated strains identified in food samples continues; so far only 2\nstrains have been analyzed.\nControl measures:\nAs part of the control measures undertaken by the Czech authorities\nin response to the outbreak, 404 inspections were carried out by\npublic health authorities, and _L. monocytogenes_ was detected in 11\nsamples. As a result of inspections, the contaminated products were\nidentified, and their production at several food production sites was\nsuspended.\nThe public health services cooperate closely with the Czech trade\ninspection and Veterinary administration services in control of food\nquality and safety. In addition, the National Institute of Public\nHealth prepared a new standard questionnaire on food habits for use\nin the surveillance of listeriosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is a more detailed report of the outbreak previously posted on\nProMED. As can be seen on the map from the original URL, cases were\nspread throughout the country. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In general, men were affected more often\nthan women (42 versus 33 cases), but in the age group 20-39 years,\nwomen (especially pregnant women, 11 cases) constituted the majority\nof patients. Strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ isolated both from patients and\nfood samples (altogether 36 isolates) were forwarded to the Czech\nnational reference laboratory for listeria for detailed serotyping,\npulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE), and antibiotic susceptibility testing. Source: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070208.asp#1>\n\nFor more than 30 years up to 2006, the incidence of human listeriosis\nin the Czech Republic has been low, ranging between 0.1 and 0.2 cases\nper 100 000 population per year. The patients affected in the 2006 outbreak (all who recovered) were\ninterviewed by qualified senior epidemiologists to establish what\nfood they had consumed and what their dietary habits were, however,\nno standard questionnaire was used. In addition, the National Institute of Public\nHealth prepared a new standard questionnaire on food habits for use\nin the surveillance of listeriosis.\n As part of the control measures undertaken by the Czech authorities\nin response to the outbreak, 404 inspections were carried out by\npublic health authorities, and _L. monocytogenes_ was detected in 11\nsamples. \nLaboratory analysis showed that all strains detected belonged to\nserotype 1/2b and none was found to be resistant against ampicillin,\npenicillin, tetracycline and cotrimoxazole. The pulse\ntype A was also confirmed in 2 isolates gained from a sample of\nmature cheese collected in different food store chains. Although cases occurred in both Bohemia (western region of the\ncountry) and Moravia (eastern), the latter registered higher\nincidence (0.5 per 100 000 in Bohemia versus 0.99 per 100 000 in Moravia). 30 human isolates were\nanalyzed by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis; 26 belonged to the same\npulse type (type A), and only 4 were types B, C, E1 and X. The breakdown of cases by age identified the 3 main population groups\nat risk: newborns, pregnant women and immunocompromised elderly people.\n The analysis of\nisolated strains identified in food samples continues; so far only 2\nstrains have been analyzed. Furthermore, the pulse type of an isolate of\none patient corresponded with the type found in a mixed salad\ncontaining salami, cheese, vegetable and dressing. As a result of inspections, the contaminated products were\nidentified, and their production at several food production sites was\nsuspended. The public health services cooperate closely with the Czech trade\ninspection and Veterinary administration services in control of food\nquality and safety. Another\npulse type was detected in a different sort of mature cheese produced\nby another manufacturer. The standard\ndemographical, clinical, laboratory and epidemiological data\ncollected do not include detailed clinical information.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2060-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Moravia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6409", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic (Moravia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6409", "date": "2007-01-08 00:00:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, PERINATAL - CZECH REPUBLIC (MORAVIA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Prague Daily Monitor [edited]\n<http://www.praguemonitor.com/ctk/?story_id=w49339i20070108;story=Two-women-miscarry-in-Brno-over-listeriosis---press>\n\nTwo women miscarried due to the bacteria causing listeriosis in Brno\nin the past 2 weeks, and the disease was transmitted to the newly\nborn baby in another case, but the child survived, Mlada fronta Dnes\n(MfD) writes today, 6 Jan 2007. Both women miscarried in the 20th\nweek of pregnancy, MfD writes.\nIt says that though it is not yet clear how the women got infected,\nall 3 said they like maturing cheeses, in which the bacteria was\npreviously found at some places in the country.\nIn the 3rd case, doctors were alerted by turbid amniotic fluid and\nimmediately administered antibiotics to the baby and saved it without\nany more serious consequences, LN writes.\nEight people, including a newborn baby died of listeriosis in the\nCzech Republic in 2006. A total of 62 people were diagnosed with\nlisteriosis. This is 4 times more than in 2005, LN writes. The\nincreased incidence was caused by maturing cheeses and some kinds of salads.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The following is an excellent primer from the USA FDA that overviews\nthe relationship of pregnancy and infection with _Listeria monocytogenes_\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~pregnant/whillist.html>:\n'What is _Listeria monocytogenes_?\nIt's a harmful bacterium that can be found in refrigerated,\nready-to-eat foods (meat, poultry, seafood, and dairy (unpasteurized\nmilk and milk products or foods made with unpasteurized milk)) and in\nsoil. Animals can carry this bacterium without appearing ill, and\nthus, it can be found in foods made from animals. _L. monocytogenes_\nis unusual because it can grow at refrigerator temperatures where\nmost other foodborne bacteria do not. When eaten, it may cause\nlisteriosis, an illness to which pregnant women and their unborn\nchildren are very susceptible.\n'How could I get listeriosis?'\nBy eating ready-to-eat meats, poultry, seafood, and dairy products\nthat are contaminated with _L. monocytogenes_. You can also get\nlisteriosis by eating contaminated foods processed or packaged in\nunsanitary conditions or by eating vegetables that are contaminated\nfrom the soil or from manure used as fertilizer.\n'How could listeriosis affect me?'\nThe symptoms can take a few days or even weeks to appear and may\ninclude fever, chills, muscle aches, diarrhea or upset stomach,\nheadache, stiff neck, confusion, and loss of balance. In more serious\ncases, listeriosis could also lead to the mother's death.\nMost of the time, pregnant women who are infected with listeriosis\ndon't feel sick. However, they can pass the infection to their unborn\nbabies without even knowing it. That's why prevention of listeriosis\nis very important. In any case, if you experience any of the above\nsymptoms, see your doctor or health-care provider immediately.\nPregnant women are about 20 times more likely to get listeriosis than\nother healthy adults, and an estimated 1/3rd of all listeria cases\noccur in pregnant women.\n'How could listeriosis affect my baby?'\nDuring the 1st trimester of pregnancy, listeriosis may cause\nmiscarriage. As the pregnancy progresses to the 3rd trimester, the\nmother is more at risk. Listeriosis can also lead to premature labor,\nthe delivery of a low-birth-weight infant, or infant death. Fetuses\nwho suffer a late infection may develop a wide range of health\nproblems, including mental retardation, paralysis, seizures,\nblindness, or impairments of the brain, heart, or kidney. In\nnewborns, _L. monocytogenes_ can cause blood infections and meningitis.\n'Listeriosis and Pregnant Hispanic Women'\nStudies show that pregnant Hispanic women may have a higher incidence\nof listeriosis than pregnant non-Hispanic women. This is most likely\nbecause they might make and eat homemade soft cheese and other\ntraditional foods made from unpasteurized milk. 'Queso fresco'-- a\ntraditional homemade cheese, prepared from unpasteurized milk and\nwidely consumed by Hispanics -- has led to miscarriages, death of\nnewborns, and premature delivery caused by _L. monocytogenes_.\nTo prevent the risk of listeriosis, Hispanic pregnant women should\nnot eat homemade soft cheeses and other traditional foods made from\nunpasteurized milk. Like all other pregnant women, they should follow\nthe food safety precautions outlined below.\n'How can I prevent listeriosis?'\nThe good news is that listeriosis can be prevented! Here's how:\n- Your refrigerator should register at 40 F (4 C) or below and the\nfreezer at 0 F (-18 C). Place a refrigerator thermometer in the\nrefrigerator, and check the temperature periodically. During the\nautomatic defrost cycle, the temperature may register slightly higher\nthan 40 F. This is okay.\n- Refrigerate or freeze perishables, prepared food, and leftovers\nwithin 2 hours of eating or preparation. Follow the 2-Hour Rule:\nDiscard food that has been left out at room temperature for longer\nthan 2 hours. When temperatures are above 90 F (32 C), discard food\nafter one hour.\n- Use ready-to-eat, perishable foods, such as dairy, meat, poultry,\nseafood, and produce, as soon as possible.\nDon't eat:\n- Hot dogs and luncheon meats unless they're reheated until steaming hot.\n- Soft cheeses like Feta, Brie, and Camembert, 'blue-veined cheeses,'\nor 'queso blanco,' 'queso fresco,' or Panela unless they're made with\npasteurized milk; Make sure the label says, 'made with pasteurized milk'\n- refrigerated pates or meat spreads\n- refrigerated smoked seafood - unless it's in a cooked dish, such as\na casserole (Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout,\nwhitefish, cod, tuna, or mackerel is most often labeled as\n'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' These types of\nfish are found in the refrigerator section or sold at deli counters\nof grocery stores and delicatessens.)\n- Raw (unpasteurized) milk or foods that contain unpasteurized milk\nIt's okay to eat:\n- Canned or shelf-stable (able to be stored unrefrigerated on the\nshelf) pates and meat spreads.\n- Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood.\n- Pasteurized milk or foods that contain pasteurized milk.'\nBrno is in southern Moravia in the southeastern Czech Republic and\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://ei.cs.vt.edu/~janlee/Czech/MAP-CZE.GIF>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n- Soft cheeses like Feta, Brie, and Camembert, 'blue-veined cheeses,'\nor 'queso blanco,' 'queso fresco,' or Panela unless they're made with\npasteurized milk; Make sure the label says, 'made with pasteurized milk'\n- refrigerated pates or meat spreads\n- refrigerated smoked seafood - unless it's in a cooked dish, such as\na casserole (Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout,\nwhitefish, cod, tuna, or mackerel is most often labeled as\n'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Prague Daily Monitor [edited]\n<http://www.praguemonitor.com/ctk/?story_id=w49339i20070108;story=Two-women-miscarry-in-Brno-over-listeriosis---press>\n\nTwo women miscarried due to the bacteria causing listeriosis in Brno\nin the past 2 weeks, and the disease was transmitted to the newly\nborn baby in another case, but the child survived, Mlada fronta Dnes\n(MfD) writes today, 6 Jan 2007. a\ntraditional homemade cheese, prepared from unpasteurized milk and\nwidely consumed by Hispanics -- has led to miscarriages, death of\nnewborns, and premature delivery caused by _L. monocytogenes_.\n It's a harmful bacterium that can be found in refrigerated,\nready-to-eat foods (meat, poultry, seafood, and dairy (unpasteurized\nmilk and milk products or foods made with unpasteurized milk)) and in\nsoil. You can also get\nlisteriosis by eating contaminated foods processed or packaged in\nunsanitary conditions or by eating vegetables that are contaminated\nfrom the soil or from manure used as fertilizer. Fetuses\nwho suffer a late infection may develop a wide range of health\nproblems, including mental retardation, paralysis, seizures,\nblindness, or impairments of the brain, heart, or kidney. [The following is an excellent primer from the USA FDA that overviews\nthe relationship of pregnancy and infection with _Listeria monocytogenes_\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~pregnant/whillist.html>:\n' \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Listeriosis and Pregnant Hispanic Women'\nStudies show that pregnant Hispanic women may have a higher incidence\nof listeriosis than pregnant non-Hispanic women. Health minister John\nHill yesterday, 12 Dec 2005, released a list of pre-cooked meat products\nmade by Conroy's Smallgoods -- including ham, mettwurst, and salami --\nafter testing found listeria on cutting equipment at the company's suburban\nAdelaide plant.\nConroy's is a 50 year old South Australian producer of about 120 meat\nproducts. It is a family owned and operated company that employs more than\n100 people and sells more than AUD 10 million [around USD 7.5 million] in\nproducts each year. Mr. Hill said testing at Conroy's had found listeria\nbacteria on the plant's saw, conveyor, slicer block, floor drains and\ncryovac machine, and in the slicer room.\nListeriosis is a serious infection caught from food contaminated with\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, a bacterium widely found in nature and sometimes\nin raw foods.\nMr Hill said recalled products included ready-to-eat champagne ham,\nmettwurst, pastrami, and sandwich ham. The ban did not extend to products\nthat needed to be cooked, such as bacon, bacon bones, and ham steaks. The\nproducts were regularly supplied to the Royal Adelaide Hospital, where one\nof the victims died, and were available from retail outlets and\nwholesalers. He said there was no direct link yet made between Conroy's\nmeats and the outbreak, which may be established by the results of further\ntesting this week [3rd week December 2005].\nConroy's managing director Pat Conroy confirmed the company's meat products\nwere supplied to hospitals, including Royal Adelaide, but said his company\nwas not a direct supplier. He said the recall of its meat products was a\n'serious matter' and the company would cooperate with Health Department\nofficials as testing continued this week [3rd week December 2005].\nThe 2 patients who died were already sick in hospital with low immune\nsystems, but listeria was later detected in the kitchens at the hospitals\nwhere they had been treated, the Royal Adelaide Hospital and Gawler\nHospital, north of Adelaide. 2 other patients who had listeriosis were\nprescribed antibiotics and are recovering.\nThe Health Department yesterday [12 Dec 2005] reissued a warning to those\nat a high risk of listeriosis, including pregnant women and those with low\nimmune systems. They should not consume ready to eat cold meats, cold\ncooked chicken, pate, or raw and chilled ready to eat seafoods.\n[byline: Jeremy Roberts]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Nosocomial listeriosis has been described before in similar circumstances,\nrelated to food service in health care facilities, but is quite uncommon. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Health minister John\nHill yesterday, 12 Dec 2005, released a list of pre-cooked meat products\nmade by Conroy's Smallgoods -- including ham, mettwurst, and salami --\nafter testing found listeria on cutting equipment at the company's suburban\n The 2 patients who died were already sick in hospital with low immune\nsystems, but listeria was later detected in the kitchens at the hospitals\nwhere they had been treated, the Royal Adelaide Hospital and Gawler\n The\nproducts were regularly supplied to the Royal Adelaide Hospital, where one\nof the victims died, and were available from retail outlets and\nwholesalers. [byline: Jeremy Roberts]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Conroy's managing director Pat Conroy confirmed the company's meat products\nwere supplied to hospitals, including Royal Adelaide, but said his company\nwas not a direct supplier. He said the recall of its meat products was a\n'serious matter' and the company would cooperate with Health Department\nofficials as testing continued this week Mr. Hill said testing at Conroy's had found listeria\nbacteria on the plant's saw, conveyor, slicer block, floor drains and\ncryovac machine, and in the slicer room.
