The Health Department yesterday [12 Dec 2005] reissued a warning to those\nat a high risk of listeriosis, including pregnant women and those with low\nimmune systems.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-12-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Conroy", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209210", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, seafood - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209210", "date": "2006-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SEAFOOD - USA\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/news/2006/NEW01303.html>\n\nFDA seeks injunction against Pacific Shellfish, Inc.\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe USA FDA is seeking a permanent injunction against Pacific\nShellfish, Inc. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,'\n'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated. \n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. According to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n The CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole. Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked. Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,'\n'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2006-01-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-12-08 00:00:00", "2006-01-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina Sea Grant", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7336", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic: dairy source", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7336", "date": "2007-02-04 21:00:05", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, PERINATAL - CZECH REPUBLIC: DAIRY SOURCE\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu 1 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: United Press International [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Science/20070201-015150-7112r/>\n\nA recent outbreak of illness caused by dangerous listeria bacteria\noriginated in a Czech dairy plant that has stopped production, Prague\nRadio reported.\nMichael Vit, the Czech Republic's chief public health officer, said\nThu 1 Feb 2007 that the food contaminated with listeria was traced to\nonly one plant, whose name and location he did not disclose.\nIn 2006, 80 people were diagnosed with listeriosis, and 13 died, the\nradio said, 5 times more infected people than in 2005. Listeria\nbacteria may be found in un-pasteurized milk, soft cheeses, and raw\nand processed meats.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 9 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Radio Prague [edited]\n<http://www.radio.cz/en/article/87059>\n\nRecently, the papers here have been full of alarming reports\nconcerning listeria infection in the Czech Republic. So far in 2007,\nthere have been a number of highly publicized cases of poisoning with\nlisteria bacteria, which are often found in certain types of ready\nmade salads and ripe cheeses.\nUsually, there are only one or 2 deaths every year from listeria\npoisoning in the Czech Republic. In 2006, however, 10 people have\ndied from being infected with the bacteria. A significant number of\npregnant women have also had miscarriages as a result of being\ninfected, and, in the last week alone, 3 women have lost their babies\nbecause of listeria.\nThere was a recent news report on how a woman suffering from\nlisteriosis lost her baby after she became infected with the listeria\nbacteria. It's ordinarily a rare occurrence in this country, but in\n2006 the number of serious incidences of listeria infection has risen\nsignificantly, and the mortality rate has increased almost 10-fold.\nDr. Michael Vit, the Chief Public Health Officer for the Czech\nRepublic, says that there are a number of reasons for the rise in\nserious cases of listerioisis:\n'One of the reasons could be that there has been some slackness when\nit comes to proper procedures in the factories where they produce\nsoft and mature cheeses as well as various delicatessen salads.\nAnother reason could be the warm weather we have had over the past 3\nmonths. It may also be that some of the groups at risk of listeria\npoisoning have forgotten that it is not ideal for them to eat these\nkinds of foods.'\nBesides pregnant women, the groups at risk whom Dr. Vit mentions\ninclude people whose immunity systems may be deficient, such as old\npeople, young children and people with diseases such as cancer and\nsevere diabetes.\nDespite the high levels of press coverage for recent cases of\nlisteria poisoning, Dr. Vit says that no comparative data is\navailable for 2006; the incidence of listeria in the Czech Republic\nis generally comparable to many other European countries, and there\nis no need for the public to be alarmed.\n'We are not an exception in the Czech Republic. Our rates of\ninfection according to most recent figures puts us around the same\nlevel as Holland, Germany and France. Every food producer has to\nfollow a series of strict controls. If these are observed, then it\nmeans the level of contamination should be limited.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that at least 3 cases of perinatal listeriosis occurred\nrecently in the Czech Republic. The risk factors related to the other\n10 deaths and other 77 cases is not stated. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Despite the high levels of press coverage for recent cases of\nlisteria poisoning, Dr. Vit says that no comparative data is\navailable for 2006; the incidence of listeria in the Czech Republic\nis generally comparable to many other European countries, and there\nis no need for the public to be alarmed. They include 3 pregnant women, 2 newborns\nand an elderly woman. On average, Houston only has about 8 cases in a year,\nso 6 in a month is especially troubling to health officials.\nThe victims are not all from one area of Houston, so epidemiologists are\ntrying to figure out the source and whether there is a connection.\n'We do know in the past there had been some cases here in Houston and also\nin South Texas where people ate imported Mexican cheese that did not have\nlabels. It was not pasteurized, so there is a danger there,' said Porfirio\nVillarreal, HDHHS. 'We want to make sure that that is not happening.\nBecause we do know of certain flea markets that do sell, illegally, those\nfoods.'\nEating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_, found\nin soil and water, causes the illness. Bacteria can contaminate foods of\nanimal origin, such as meats and dairy products. Those at high risk of\nbecoming infected are pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened\nimmune systems because of AIDS, cancer, diabetes and kidney disease.\nHDHHS warns against eating un-pasteurized or raw dairy products, such as\nsoft cheeses, and recommends people cook left over foods or\nready-to-eat-foods, such as hot dogs, until steaming hot.\nOther recommendations include:\n- Thoroughly cook raw food from animal sources, such as beef, pork or poultry.\n- Wash raw vegetables thoroughly before eating.\n- Keep uncooked meats separate from vegetables and from cooked foods and\nready-to-eat-foods.\n- Wash hands, knives and cutting boards after handling uncooked foods.\nIn 2004, the CDC reported 2500 cases across the country and 500 deaths.\n[Byline: Carolyn Campbell]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of listeriosis in this\ncluster. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Houston Department of Health and Human Services has detected a rise in\nAugust 2005 in the number of cases of listeriosis, a serious illness that\ncan result in miscarriages, stillbirths, premature delivery and babies born\nwith the life-threatening infection. [Byline: Carolyn Campbell]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Microbial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n HDHHS warns against eating un-pasteurized or raw dairy products, such as\nsoft cheeses, and recommends people cook left over foods or\nready-to-eat-foods, such as hot dogs, until steaming hot. \n- Keep uncooked meats separate from vegetables and from cooked foods and\nready-to-eat-foods. The Onondaga County Health Department\nsays the adult patient died yesterday [19 Jul 2005] due to complications of\nthe rare foodborne bacterial disease.\nAuthorities established that 3 of the cases that surfaced this month [July\n2005] were caused by the same strain of _Listeria_ and that they probably\ngot sick from a single source of contaminated food. The 4th patient\nsurfaced a week later. Investigators are trying to determine whether that\ncase is from the same strain.\nListeriosis can be fatal, but severe symptoms are unusual in healthy adults\nand children. The disease most often affects pregnant women, newborn\nbabies, or people with weakened immune systems. In 1998, 16 people died in\na multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to contaminated hot dogs and\ndeli meats.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatal listeriosis, predominantly meningitis, generally occurs in\nindividuals with defects in cellular immune function. This includes\npatients with organ transplantation or malignancies on therapy. Disease may\noccur in apparently normal hosts, however, usually in the elderly. Most\nsporadic cases of listeriosis are thought to be part of a foodborne cluster\nwhich may not be recognized. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In 1998, 16 people died in\na multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to contaminated hot dogs and\ndeli meats.\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nHealth Information for International Travel 2005-2006\n<http://tinyurl.com/c228c>\n Authorities established that 3 of the cases that surfaced this month [July\n2005] were caused by the same strain of _Listeria_ and that they probably\ngot sick from a single source of contaminated food. WNYT\nin Albany reports the 2nd and 3rd cases were confirmed in Montgomery and\nRensselaer counties. The 1st case was confirmed in Schenectady County on 28\nJul 2005. That followed 3 cases in Syracuse in early Jul 2005. 1 of those\npatients died.\nState health officials say the Syracuse and Schenectady cases have all been\nlinked to the same strain of the bacterium. The State Health Department\nhaven't yet linked the Montgomery and Rensselaer County cases.\nSymptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches and sometimes nausea\nand diarrhea. If untreated, it can attack the nervous system and cause\nmeningitis [see below - Mod.LL]. The listeria bacteria are found in soil\nand water, so vegetables can be contaminated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Infection with _Listeria monocytogenes_ often shows no symptoms before the\ndevelopment of bacterial meningitis, which tends to occur primarily in\nindividuals with defects in cellular immunity, such as organ transplant\nrecipients and those on cancer chemotherapy or corticosteroids. No\ninformation is given on the comorbidities of the patients who acquired\nlisteriosis and the manifestations of the illnesses.\nAlthough the genus name monocytogenes suggests that a monocytosis or\nlymphocytosis may occur, this is not usually the case in humans. The\ncerebrospinal fluid cellular pleocytosis in meningitis caused by\n_Listeria_, however, may include other types of cells beside neutrophils.\nThe food source of these cases remains unknown. Schenectady County health officials confirmed the\nsingle case on Fri 12 Aug 2005.\n'It looks like it's coming from the same source,' said Kathy Sen,\nsupervising community health nurse at the Schenectady County Health\nDepartment. Sen said the unidentified patient is thought to have been\nhospitalized with the illness in July 2005 before recovering. Health\nofficials would not provide details about the patient, citing federal\nconfidentiality rules.\nState health officials say the cases in Onondaga and Schenectady counties\nare the only ones they know of. They are looking for a food item,\nrestaurant or other common denominator among the 4 victims.\nListeriosis can be fatal, but severe symptoms are unusual in healthy adults\nand children. The disease most often affects pregnant women, newborns or\npeople with weakened immune systems.\nIn 1998, 16 people died in a multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to\ncontaminated hot dogs and deli meats, including a 75-year-old Liverpool woman.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Elsevier on-line reference:\nMethods for the isolation and identification of Listeria spp. and Listeria\nmonocytogenes: a review. The Syracuse area residents have\nbeen diagnosed with listeriosis, which is a potentially fatal bacterial\ndisease caused by eating contaminated food. Onondaga County health\nofficials say the 3 women, ages 48, 70, and 77, were hospitalized.\nThe USA Food and Drug Administration announced on 28 Jun 2005 a recall of\nGolden Taste Tuna Deluxe, Scallion Tuna Deluxe, and White Fish Salad\nbecause they may contain an organism that can cause listeriosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This FDA recall is one of many for _Listeria_ contamination. ProMED does\nnot post them unless they are linked to human cases, are related to an\nunusual situation, or involve botulism. --\nProMED-mail\n< The International Journal of Infectious Diseases\n<http://tinyurl.com/bj3md>\n Onondaga County health\nofficials say the 3 women, ages 48, 70, and 77, were hospitalized. The\nincreased reports on _Listeria_ isolates in Neuenberg were brought to the\nattention of the BAG on 25 May 2005 by the National Reference Center for\nListeria (CNRL, Lausanne). Since the middle of Apr 2005, there have been 10\nreported cases of listeriosis in Neuenberg, with 7 detected between 18 May\nand 4 Jun 2005. 8 cases were severely ill hospitalized patients, 3 of whom\nhave died. 2 pregnant patients suffered miscarriages because of listeria\ninfections. All 10 of the CNRL investigated isolates had identical 1/2a\nserotypes.\nPatient questioning implicated a local soft cheese product made of\npasteurized milk. Through the advice of the canton chemist, the production\nof this cheese was stopped and distributed product was recovered and\ndestroyed. On 8 Jun 2005, several of the cheese samples tested positive for\n_L. monocytogenes_. CNRL also verified serotype 1/2a in these samples. In\nthe meantime, other listeria-contaminated milk products by the same\nmanufacturer were identified. The manufacturer may resume production when\nthe breaches in the production line are identified and rectified, so the\ncheese can be safely brought to market.\nTo more clearly identify the source of contamination, a molecular\nbiological analysis is currently under way on the clinical and cheese\nsamples. The results of this more complete analysis will be released within\na week.\nListeria is a bacterium widely distributed throughout the environment, and\ntherefore the agricultural world. It can multiply in food that is stored\nfor a long time, even at refrigerated temperatures. People may be infected\nthrough dairy or meat products. This outbreak has shown that the use of\npasteurized milk does not provide certain safety, because contamination can\noccur afterwards.\n--\nThomas Roesel, MD, PhD\n<Thomas.Roesel@na.amedd.army.mil>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nincreased reports on _Listeria_ isolates in Neuenberg were brought to the\nattention of the BAG on 25 May 2005 by the National Reference Center for\nListeria (CNRL, Lausanne). Officials have yet to determine\nthe source of the infection.\nListeria is found in soil and water. Unpasteurized milk and cheeses have\nbeen associated with outbreaks in the past. The disease is not contagious\nand can be treated with antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_L. monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw milk,\nsupposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly soft-ripened\nvarieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented raw-meat sausages, cold\ncuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all types), and raw and smoked\nfish. Its ability to grow at temperatures as low as 3 degrees C permits\nmultiplication in refrigerated foods.\nRecalls related to contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occur\nfrequently. Whether this cluster of cases in upstate New York is related\nto food from a previous recall -- where some of the contaminated food was\nnot recalled from a consumer or from a soon-to-be-discovered food -- is yet\nto be determined. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[_L. monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw milk,\nsupposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly soft-ripened\nvarieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented raw-meat sausages, cold\ncuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all types), and raw and smoked\nfish. Health department officials say it's unusual to have a\ncluster of 5 cases in this short period of time.\nListeriosis is caused by the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. Unwashed\nproduce, raw meat, soft cheese, and cold cuts can carry the germs. It can\ncause mild symptoms that include nausea or diarrhea, but, if it enters the\nbloodstream, or nervous system, it can cause a severe illness such as\nmeningitis. People with compromised immune systems [particularly those with\ndefects in cellular immunity, and pregnant women - Mod. LL] are\nparticularly vulnerable to the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Typing of the organisms can tell if they are identical. If so, a food\nsource, such as cold cuts, needs to be sought to minimize additional cases\nthat could be spread over a larger area. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n It can\ncause mild symptoms that include nausea or diarrhea, but, if it enters the\nbloodstream, or nervous system, it can cause a severe illness such as\nmeningitis. If so, a food\nsource, such as cold cuts, needs to be sought to minimize additional cases\nthat could be spread over a larger area. Source: WHSV.com [edited]\n<http://www.whsv.com/news/headlines/882512.html>\n\nHealth officials investigate listeriosis cases\n --\nProMED-mail\n< LL] are\nparticularly vulnerable to the disease.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Richmond", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VIRGINIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208022", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208022", "date": "2005-06-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - SWITZERLAND (NEUENBURG): ALERT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 7 Jun 2005\nFrom: Thomas R. Roesel <Thomas.Roesel@na.amedd.army.mil>\nSource: Tages-Anzeiger.ch (translated by submitter) [edited]\n<http://www.tages-anzeiger.ch/dyn/news/schweiz/506308.html>\n\nDeadly cheese in Neuenburg\n--------------------------\n2 elderly people died from _Listeria_ infection in the canton of Neuenburg.\nIn addition, 2 women suffered miscarriages, and 6 others were brought to the\nhospital. All had eaten Tomme cheese (a raw milk white cheese) produced in\nthe canton.\nThe Neuenburg canton physician Daphne Berner confirmed the deaths through a\nreport on the local RTN radio. Both elderly people had died during the past 2\nweeks. The bacterial infection contributed to their deaths.\nBeforehand the public health officials reported on a cluster of _Listeria_\ncases occurring in May 2005, but without any mention of deaths. At present,\n10 patients have entered hospitals with listeriosis. Within the past week, 5\ncases have become known.\nCanton Neuenburg's Tomme soft cheese has been implicated as the cause. The\ninvestigators state in their report that those affected had eaten cheese of\nthis type produced by the firm. The canton chemist is conducting further\ninvestigations to identify the origin of the disease-causing bacteria.\n***Because of the severity of the incident, the Health Department declared\nthat the public should not consume Neuenberg Tomme cheese already purchased\nfrom the stores within the canton or at marketplaces. Suspect cheese should\nbe destroyed. At the same time the officials called on pregnant women to\nconsult their doctor should they have consumed Neuenburg Tomme over the past 3\nweeks and have a fever. Listeriosis can also be dangerous to those with a\nweakened immune system. The illness manifests itself with flu-like symptoms\nand can lead to an infection and even to meningitis.***\nThis occurrence harks back to the unpleasant memories of the _Listeria_\nepidemic in 1987 that occurred in French-speaking Switzerland. At that time\n31 people in Switzerland died after consuming contaminated Vacherin Mont d'Or\ncheese. At least half of the deaths were fetuses and newborns. As a\nconsequence, officials [banned] a dozen different cheese types, and a ton of\ncheese had to be destroyed. The market within Switzerland as well as outside\ndeclined rapidly, and brought many cheese producers in the western part of\nSwitzerland to financial ruin. France experienced a _Listeria_ epidemic in\n1992 that cost 60 people their lives.\n--\nThomas Roesel, MD, PhD\n<Thomas.Roesel@na.amedd.army.mil>\n[Unpasteurized cheese is a common vehicle for _L. monocytogenes_. As noted in\nthe report, serious infection with this Gram-positive bacillus is most common\nin the elderly, the immunosuppressed, and pregnant women and their fetuses. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\nThomas Roesel, MD, PhD\n<Thomas.Roesel@na.amedd.army.mil>\n As a\nconsequence, officials [banned] a dozen different cheese types, and a ton of\ncheese had to be destroyed. *Because of the severity of the incident, the Health Department declared\nthat the public should not consume Neuenberg Tomme cheese already purchased\nfrom the stores within the canton or at marketplaces. The\ninvestigators state in their report that those affected had eaten cheese of\nthis type produced by the firm. At that time\n31 people in Switzerland died after consuming contaminated Vacherin Mont d'Or\ncheese. As noted in\nthe report, serious infection with this Gram-positive bacillus is most common\nin the elderly, the immunosuppressed, and pregnant women and their fetuses. The market within Switzerland as well as outside\ndeclined rapidly, and brought many cheese producers in the western part of\nSwitzerland to financial ruin. At the same time the officials called on pregnant women to\nconsult their doctor should they have consumed Neuenburg Tomme over the past 3\nweeks and have a fever. Source: Tages-Anzeiger.ch (translated by submitter) [edited]\n<http://www.tages-anzeiger.ch/dyn/news/schweiz/506308.html>\n\nDeadly cheese in Neuenburg\n The canton chemist is conducting further\ninvestigations to identify the origin of the disease-causing bacteria.\n France experienced a _Listeria_ epidemic in\n1992 that cost 60 people their lives.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-05-26 00:00:00", "1992-03-26 00:00:00", "1987-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canton", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205365", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, neonatal - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205365", "date": "2004-03-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, NEONATAL - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 6 Mar 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Marin Independent Journal [edited]\n<http://www.marinij.com/Stories/0,1413,234%257E24407%257E2000616,00.html>\n\nWarning follows illness of 2 Marin infants\n---------------------------------------------\nMarin County health officials are warning the pregnant and infirm to\navoid certain food choices, after 2 infants were sickened during\nFebruary 2004 with the bacterium _Listeria_. The babies, born on 14\nand 16 Feb 2004, became ill with listeriosis shortly after birth,\ntriggering an investigation into potential sources for the bacteria,\nsaid Deputy Public Health Officer Dr. Nathalie Bera. Both babies have\nmade a full recovery, she said.\nCounty health officials and the state Department of Food and\nAgriculture recently investigated an unidentified local market after\nthe mothers reported eating cheese, but a batch of soft cheese sent\nto a state lab came back negative for _Listeria_. A vendor peddling\ncheese from a cart in San Rafael's Canal neighborhood also fell under\nsuspicion, but without a sample of the cheese or access to the\nvendor, a conclusive connection is difficult, health officials said.\n'Where we're at right now is the state is interested in looking into\nthe vendor angle,' said Dave Smail of the county's Environmental\nHealth Services division. 'It's not uncommon for the state to\ninvestigate allegations of street vending of cheese. The state is\nintending to do that.'\nListeria grows in soil and water and is often carried by animals.\nCommon food-borne culprits include meat, unpasteurized products such\nas soft cheeses, and raw vegetables. The bacteria is killed when food\nis cooked, but not when it is refrigerated, county health officials\nsaid. The bacteria can cause gastrointestinal problems, fever and\nflu-like symptoms, and is most dangerous for pregnant women, people\nwho have compromised immune systems, and small children.\nCounty health officials have asked San Rafael police to keep a\nvigilant eye on food carts, which have been the source of such\ninfections in the state in the past. 'We're looking for any peddlers,\nin particular in the Canal neighborhood,' said San Rafael police Sgt.\nJonathan Bean. 'Aside from a public health threat, it's a violation\nfor the vendors to operate without a city business license, a police\nvendor permit, and the county environmental health service permit.'\nCity spokeswoman Lydia Romero said officers will strictly enforce the\ncity's vendor ordinance. Only 6 or 7 such business licenses to\noperate have been issued to date, she said. On average, 0 to 2 cases\nper year of illness from Listeria are reported in Marin, county\nhealth officials said.\nCounty health authorities have alerted health care providers in the\ncounty, urging them to advise pregnant women and people with\ncompromised immune systems to avoid foods that could spread the\nbacteria. If they do eat such foods, common-sense food practices,\nsuch as washing raw vegetables carefully and fully cooking meats, are\nadvised.\n[Byline: Jennifer Upshaw]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The temporal association between the 2 neonatal infections suggests\na common source, although comparison of the 2 isolates is required.\nSoft cheeses and meat cold cuts, 2 of the more common vehicles for\n_L. monocytogenes_, should be avoided in high-risk groups, including\npregnant women, whether or not there are known cases. Many of the\npregnancy-related cases result in miscarriages. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n County health officials and the state Department of Food and\nAgriculture recently investigated an unidentified local market after\nthe mothers reported eating cheese, but a batch of soft cheese sent\nto a state lab came back negative for _Listeria_. County health authorities have alerted health care providers in the\ncounty, urging them to advise pregnant women and people with\ncompromised immune systems to avoid foods that could spread the\nbacteria. A vendor peddling\ncheese from a cart in San Rafael's Canal neighborhood also fell under\nsuspicion, but without a sample of the cheese or access to the\nvendor, a conclusive connection is difficult, health officials said. \nMarin County health officials are warning the pregnant and infirm to\navoid certain food choices, after 2 infants were sickened during\nFebruary 2004 with the bacterium _Listeria_. \n'Where we're at right now is the state is interested in looking into\nthe vendor angle,' said Dave Smail of the county's Environmental\nHealth Services division. The babies, born on 14\nand 16 Feb 2004, became ill with listeriosis shortly after birth,\ntriggering an investigation into potential sources for the bacteria,\nsaid Deputy Public Health Officer Dr. Nathalie Bera. If they do eat such foods, common-sense food practices,\nsuch as washing raw vegetables carefully and fully cooking meats, are\nadvised.\n [Byline: Jennifer Upshaw]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Aside from a public health threat, it's a violation\nfor the vendors to operate without a city business license, a police\nvendor permit, and the county environmental health service permit.' On average, 0 to 2 cases\nper year of illness from Listeria are reported in Marin, county\nhealth officials said. County health officials have asked San Rafael police to keep a\nvigilant eye on food carts, which have been the source of such\ninfections in the state in the past. ' The bacteria is killed when food\nis cooked, but not when it is refrigerated, county health officials\nsaid.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-02-26 00:00:00", "2004-02-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Marin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Rafael", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203926", "headline": "PRO> Listeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203926", "date": "2003-06-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, NEW PREVENTION REGULATIONS - USA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 5 Jun 2003 08:04:09 +0100\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@virgin.net>\nSource The State.com (South Carolina, USA) Thu, 5 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thestate.com/mld/thestate/news/world/6016937.htm>\n\nUSDA: Companies Must Share Listeria Plans\n------------------------------------------\nMonths after a deadly outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_, the USA\nAgriculture Department says it will require 2500 companies that make\nhot dogs and deli meats to come up with plans for preventing the\nharmful bacteria from contaminating their products.\nCompanies also must test areas such as walls, equipment, and\ncountertops and share the results with inspectors, said Elsa Murano,\nhead of the department's food safety division.\n'The rule is tough, it's fair, it's based on science,' she said Wed,\n4 Jun 2003. Plants that don't comply could be shut down by\ninspectors, Murano said.\nUnder the regulations, companies will have flexibility in their\nprevention efforts. They are allowed to add germ-killing ingredients\nsuch as sodium lactate to the meat or to use a hot wash. Those that\ndo both can tout it on their product label. Those that do only one\nprocedure will face greater testing by government officials. Federal\ninspectors will continue to randomly test plants for _L.\nmonocytogenes_.\nThe bacterium is difficult to control because it may persist in\nready-to-eat meats after they are precooked at the plant. Consumers\ncan prevent sickness by cooking the meat.\nCompanies aren't allowed to use irradiation to kill germs on such\nmeats because the Food and Drug Administration has not approved it\nfor those products. The technology, which involves using gamma rays\nor electricity to sanitize meat, is allowed on ground beef.\nThe Agriculture Department has been working on the listeria rule\nsince 2001, when it first was proposed by the Clinton administration.\nConsumer groups have criticized the department for taking so long to\ncome up with the regulation, arguing that it could have sped up\nrecalls of products linked to a listeriosis outbreak last fall. The\noutbreak sickened 53 people, killed 8, and caused 3 miscarriages.\n[Deaths generally occur in immunocompromised hosts and fetuses. -\nMod.LL]\nMurano said it took months to finish the rule because the agency was\ncompleting studies that would determine the best way to prevent\nlisteria. Advocates complained that the new regulations don't\nspecify how often companies should test surfaces and products. They\nalso said the rule should require companies to warn pregnant women\nand people with weak immune systems to reheat products before eating\nthem.\n'We hope that this regulatory approach, coupled with the scientific\nstrategies employed by meat and poultry companies, will help us\nachieve our mutual goal: producing ready-to-eat meat and poultry\nproducts that consumers can enjoy with confidence,' said J. Patrick\nBoyle, president of the American Meat Institute.\nBecause it's an interim rule, the industry and public can comment on\nthe rule and the government can make changes over the next 18 months.\nHowever, it is slated to go into effect in September 2003.\n[Byline: Emily Gersema, Associated Press]\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As reflected by a number of significant outbreaks of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ in recent years and posted on ProMED-mail, listeriosis\nis clearly a major food-borne problem. The infection is most\nsignificant among pregnant women; miscarriages often occur due to\ninfection of the placenta and fetus. In the immune-deficient host,\nmeningitis and bacteremia occur.\nTreatment of precooked meats can diminish the risk of the\ntransmission of this Gram-positive bacillus. A variety of organic\nacids can be used as additives to inhibit the bacterium, as\ndemonstrated by the following 2 abstracts:\nMbandi E, Shelef LA: Enhanced antimicrobial effects of combination of\nlactate and diacetate on _Listeria monocytogenes_ and _Salmonella\nspp._ in beef bologna. Int J Food Microbiol 2002;76:191-8.\n'The antimicrobial activities of salts of organic acids such as\nlactate and acetate are well documented, but there is limited\ninformation on their effect when used in combination. We previously\nreported enhanced inhibition of _Listeria monocytogenes_ and\n_Salmonella enterica_ serovar Enteritidis in sterile comminuted beef\nat 5 and 10 degrees C by combinations of sodium lactate (SL) (2.5\npercent) and sodium diacetate (SDA) (0.2 percent). The present study\nwas undertaken to evaluate the inhibitory effect of these salts,\nalone and in combination, in ready-to-eat (RTE) meat. Single strains\nand 6-strain mixtures of each of the pathogens ( approximately 3 log\nCFU/g) were tested in beef bologna during aerobic storage at 5 and 10\ndegrees C for up to 60 days. The growth rate of the 6-strain mixture\nof _Listeria_ was faster than that of the single strain (Scott A) in\nthe lactate/diacetate-free product.\nWhile each of the salts delayed growth of the listeriae at 5 degrees\nC, the effect of their combination was listericidal for the single\nstrain and listeriostatic for the 6-strain mixture. Enhanced\ninhibition by the salt combination was also observed at 10 degrees C.\n_Salmonella_ numbers declined to undetectable levels in the untreated\nmeat product and in each of the treatments after 20-30 days. However,\nthe decline was more rapid in meat with the combination of the salts\nduring storage at both 5 and 10 degrees C. Each of the salts further\ndelayed the growth of the background microflora during storage at 5\ndegrees C, with their combinations showing the most effect.'\nPorto AC, Franco BD, Sant'anna ES, et al: Viability of a 5-strain\nmixture of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in vacuum-sealed packages of\nfrankfurters, commercially prepared with and without 2.0 or 3.0\npercent added potassium lactate, during extended storage at 4 and 100\ndegrees C. J Food Prot 2002;65:308-15\n'The viability of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was monitored on\nfrankfurters containing added potassium lactate that were obtained\ndirectly from a commercial manufacturer. 8 links (ca. 56 g each) were\ntransferred aseptically from the original vacuum-sealed bulk packages\ninto nylon-polyethylene bags. Each bag then received a 4-ml portion\nof a 5-strain mixture of the pathogen. Frankfurters containing 2.0 or\n3.0 percent potassium lactate were evaluated using 20 CFU per\npackage, and frankfurters containing 3.0 percent potassium lactate\nwere evaluated using 500 CFU per package.\nThe packages were vacuum-sealed and stored at 4 or 10 degrees C for\nup to 90 or 60 days, respectively. During storage at 4 degrees C,\npathogen numbers remained at about 1.6 log10 CFU per package over 90\ndays in packages containing frankfurters with 2.0 percent potassium\nlactate that were inoculated with about 20 CFU. In packages\ncontaining frankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate that were\ninoculated with about 20 CFU and stored at 4 degrees C, pathogen\nnumbers remained at about 1.4 log10 CFU per package over 90 days. In\npackages containing frankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate\nthat were inoculated with about 500 CFU and stored at 4 degrees C,\npathogen numbers remained at about 2.4 log10 CFU per package over 90\ndays.\nHowever, in the absence of any added potassium lactate, pathogen\nnumbers increased to 4.6 and 5.0 log10 CFU per package after 90 days\nof storage at 4 degrees C for starting levels of 20 and 500 CFU per\npackage, respectively. During storage at 10 degrees C, pathogen\nnumbers remained at about 1.4 log10 CFU per package over 60 days in\npackages containing frankfurters with 2.0 percent potassium lactate\nthat were inoculated with about 20 CFU. In packages containing\nfrankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate that were inoculated\nwith about 20 CFU and stored at 10 degrees C, pathogen numbers\nremained at about 1.1 log10 CFU per package over 60 days of storage.\nIn the absence of any added potassium lactate, pathogen numbers\nincreased to 6.5 log10 CFU per package after 28 days and then\ndeclined to 5.0 log10 CFU per package after 60 days of storage at 10\ndegrees C. In packages containing frankfurters with 3.0 percent\npotassium lactate that were inoculated with about 500 CFU per\npackage, pathogen numbers remained at about 2.4 log10 CFU per package\nover 60 days of storage at 10 degrees C, whereas in the absence of\nany added potassium lactate, pathogen numbers increased to about 6.6\nlog10 CFU per package within 40 days and then declined to about 5.5\nlog10 CFU per package after 60 days of storage. The viability of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ in frankfurter packages stored at 4 and 10 degrees C\nwas influenced by the pH and the presence or levels of lactate but\nnot by the presence or levels of indigenous lactic acid bacteria or\nby the proximate composition of the product.\nThese data establish that the addition of 2.0 percent (P < 0.0004) or\n3.0 percent (P < 0.0001) potassium lactate as an ingredient in\nfrankfurters can appreciably enhance safety by inhibiting or delaying\nthe growth of _L. monocytogenes_ during storage at refrigeration and\nabuse temperatures.'\nThis last abstract supports the synergistic use of heat and lactate:\nMcMahon CM, Doherty AM, Sheridan JJ, et al: Synergistic effect of\nheat and sodium lactate on the thermal resistance of _Yersinia\nenterocolitica_ and _Listeria monocytogenes_ in minced beef. Lett\nAppl Microbiol 1999;28:340-4\n'The effect of sodium lactate (NaL) (0, 2.4 or 4.8 percent), in\nheating and recovery media, on _Yersinia enterocolitica_ and\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ numbers recovered from minced beef heated at\n55 degrees C, was examined. Survivors were enumerated on selective\nmedia at pH 5.7/7.4 (_Y. enterocolitica_) or pH 5.7/7.2 (_L.\nmonocytogenes_). Recovery of the organisms depended on the pH and NaL\nlevels in the recovery medium. The heat resistance of _Y.\nenterocolitica_ (P < 0.001) and _L. monocytogenes_ (P < 0.01)\ndecreased as the concentration of NaL in the minced beef increased\nfrom 0 to 2.4 percent or 4.8 percent. The thermal destruction of\npathogens in foods processed using mild temperatures may be enhanced\nby the addition of 2.4 percent NaL.'\nOnly time and experimentation will show whether irradiation will\nfurther improve the clearance of _L. monocytogenes_ in precooked\nmeat. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Porto AC, Franco BD, Sant'anna ES, et al: Viability of a 5-strain\nmixture of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in vacuum-sealed packages of\nfrankfurters, commercially prepared with and without 2.0 or 3.0\npercent added potassium lactate, during extended storage at 4 and 100\ndegrees C. J Food Prot 2002;65:308-15\n'The viability of _Listeria monocytogenes_ was monitored on\nfrankfurters containing added potassium lactate that were obtained\ndirectly from a commercial manufacturer. In packages containing frankfurters with 3.0 percent\npotassium lactate that were inoculated with about 500 CFU per\npackage, pathogen numbers remained at about 2.4 log10 CFU per package\nover 60 days of storage at 10 degrees C, whereas in the absence of\nany added potassium lactate, pathogen numbers increased to about 6.6\n In\npackages containing frankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate\nthat were inoculated with about 500 CFU and stored at 4 degrees C,\npathogen numbers remained at about 2.4 log10 CFU per package over 90\ndays.\n Lett\nAppl Microbiol 1999;28:340-4\n'The effect of sodium lactate (NaL) (0, 2.4 or 4.8 percent), in\nheating and recovery media, on _Yersinia enterocolitica_ and\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ numbers recovered from minced beef heated at\n55 degrees C, was examined. A variety of organic\nacids can be used as additives to inhibit the bacterium, as\ndemonstrated by the following 2 abstracts:\nMbandi E, Shelef LA: Enhanced antimicrobial effects of combination of\nlactate and diacetate on _Listeria monocytogenes_ and _Salmonella\nspp._ in beef bologna. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n These data establish that the addition of 2.0 percent (P < 0.0004) or\n3.0 percent (P < 0.0001) potassium lactate as an ingredient in\nfrankfurters can appreciably enhance safety by inhibiting or delaying\nthe growth of _L. monocytogenes_ during storage at refrigeration and\nabuse temperatures.' The viability of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ in frankfurter packages stored at 4 and 10 degrees C\nwas influenced by the pH and the presence or levels of lactate but\nnot by the presence or levels of indigenous lactic acid bacteria or\nby the proximate composition of the product. We hope that this regulatory approach, coupled with the scientific\nstrategies employed by meat and poultry companies, will help us\nachieve our mutual goal: producing ready-to-eat meat and poultry\nproducts that consumers can enjoy with confidence,' said J. Patrick\nBoyle, president of the American Meat Institute. \nMonths after a deadly outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_, the USA\nAgriculture Department says it will require 2500 companies that make\nhot dogs and deli meats to come up with plans for preventing the\nharmful bacteria from contaminating their products. In packages containing\nfrankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate that were inoculated\nwith about 20 CFU and stored at 10 degrees C, pathogen numbers\nremained at about 1.1 log10 CFU per package over 60 days of storage. During storage at 10 degrees C, pathogen\nnumbers remained at about 1.4 log10 CFU per package over 60 days in\npackages containing frankfurters with 2.0 percent potassium lactate\nthat were inoculated with about 20 CFU. During storage at 4 degrees C,\npathogen numbers remained at about 1.6 log10 CFU per package over 90\ndays in packages containing frankfurters with 2.0 percent potassium\nlactate that were inoculated with about 20 CFU. Frankfurters containing 2.0 or\n3.0 percent potassium lactate were evaluated using 20 CFU per\npackage, and frankfurters containing 3.0 percent potassium lactate\nwere evaluated using 500 CFU per package. In packages\ncontaining frankfurters with 3.0 percent potassium lactate that were\ninoculated with about 20 CFU and stored at 4 degrees C, pathogen\nnumbers remained at about 1.4 log10 CFU per package over 90 days. In the absence of any added potassium lactate, pathogen numbers\nincreased to 6.5 log10 CFU per package after 28 days and then\ndeclined to 5.0 log10 CFU per package after 60 days of storage at 10\ndegrees C. However, in the absence of any added potassium lactate, pathogen\nnumbers increased to 4.6 and 5.0 log10 CFU per package after 90 days\nof storage at 4 degrees C for starting levels of 20 and 500 CFU per\npackage, respectively. This last abstract supports the synergistic use of heat and lactate:\nMcMahon CM, Doherty AM, Sheridan JJ, et al: Synergistic effect of\nheat and sodium lactate on the thermal resistance of _Yersinia\nenterocolitica_ and _Listeria monocytogenes_ in minced beef. Single strains\nand 6-strain mixtures of each of the pathogens ( approximately 3 log\nCFU/g) were tested in beef bologna during aerobic storage at 5 and 10\ndegrees C for up to 60 days. The heat resistance of _Y.\nenterocolitica_ (P < 0.001) and _L. monocytogenes_ (P < 0.01)\ndecreased as the concentration of NaL in the minced beef increased\nfrom 0 to 2.4 percent or 4.8 percent. They\nalso said the rule should require companies to warn pregnant women\nand people with weak immune systems to reheat products before eating\nthem. The thermal destruction of\npathogens in foods processed using mild temperatures may be enhanced\nby the addition of 2.4 percent NaL.'\n LL]\nMurano said it took months to finish the rule because the agency was\ncompleting studies that would determine the best way to prevent\nlisteria. [Byline: Emily Gersema, Associated Press]\n---\nProMED-mail\n< _Salmonella enterica_ serovar Enteritidis in sterile comminuted beef\nat 5 and 10 degrees C by combinations of sodium lactate (SL) (2.5\npercent) and sodium diacetate (SDA) (0.2 percent). While each of the salts delayed growth of the listeriae at 5 degrees\nC, the effect of their combination was listericidal for the single\nstrain and listeriostatic for the 6-strain mixture. However,\nthe decline was more rapid in meat with the combination of the salts\nduring storage at both 5 and 10 degrees C. Each of the salts further\ndelayed the growth of the background microflora during storage at 5\ndegrees C, with their combinations showing the most effect.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2003-03-26 00:00:00", "2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franco BD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206193", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206193", "date": "2004-07-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, CLUSTER - USA (VIRGINIA)(02): BACKGROUND\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 23 Jul 2004\nFrom: Steve Berger <Tel@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: Gideon Online [edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com>\n\nA chronology of food-borne listeriosis outbreaks in the USA\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nDairy products:\n1983 - An outbreak in Massachusetts (49 cases, 40 confirmed, 4 fatal, 7\nperinatal) - milk was implicated but not proven.\n1985 - An outbreak in California (142 cases, 48 fatal, 93 perinatal) was\ntraced to soft cheese.\n1994 - An outbreak in Illinois (45 cases, 11 confirmed) was ascribed to\nchocolate milk.\n2000 to 2001 - An outbreak in North Carolina (12 cases) was ascribed to\nhomemade Mexican-style cheese.\nMeat and poultry:\n1998 to 1999 - An 11-state outbreak (62 cases, 10 fatal) was caused by\ncontaminated hot dogs and other meat products. A recall of 15 million\npounds of meat was projected as a result.\n2000 - A multistate outbreak of infection from deli turkey meat (8\nperinatal and 21 non-perinatal cases; 4 fatal) involved New York, Georgia,\nConnecticut, Ohio, Michigan, California, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Utah, and\nWisconsin. The outbreak resulted in recall of 16.7 million pounds of\nready-to-eat poultry products from one company.\n2001 - 189 000 pounds of luncheon meat sold in 10 states were recalled\nbecause of contamination by Listeria.\n2001 - 16 people attending a catered party in Los Angeles, California were\ninfected by contaminated delicatessen meat.\n2002 - A multistate outbreak in Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania, New York,\nDelaware, Connecticut, Maryland, Michigan and Ohio involved 46 cases (7\nfatal, 3 stillbirths and miscarriages) and was ascribed to turkey meat.\n2002 - One company recalled 27.4 million pounds of cooked sandwich meat,\nand another recalled 4.2 million pounds of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken\nbecause of possible Listeria contamination.\nSeafood:\n1989 - An outbreak in Connecticut involving 10 cases (1 fatal) was ascribed\nto shrimp.\nOther and unknown:\n1986 to 1987 - An outbreak (36 cases, 16 fatal, 4 perinatal) was reported\nin Philadelphia.\n1997 - An outbreak was ascribed to contaminated hommus (chickpea paste).\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<Tel@post.tau.ac.il>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nDairy products:\n1983 - An outbreak in Massachusetts (49 cases, 40 confirmed, 4 fatal, 7\nperinatal) - milk was implicated but not proven. \n2000 - A multistate outbreak of infection from deli turkey meat (8\nperinatal and 21 non-perinatal cases; 4 fatal) 2002 - A multistate outbreak in Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania, New York,\nDelaware, Connecticut, Maryland, Michigan and Ohio involved 46 cases (7\nfatal, 3 stillbirths and miscarriages) and was ascribed to turkey meat. 2002 - One company recalled 27.4 million pounds of cooked sandwich meat,\nand another recalled 4.2 million pounds of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken\nbecause of possible Listeria contamination. USA (VIRGINIA)(02): BACKGROUND\n****************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "1989-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00", "1985-03-26 00:00:00", "1983-03-26 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "1994-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "virginia)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202907", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, poultry - USA: recall (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202907", "date": "2002-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Chronicle / Reuters 21 Nov 2002 (edited)\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/business/1671780>\n\nPoultry recall for Listeria outbreak widens\n-----------------------------\nWASHINGTON - A New Jersey poultry company linked to a _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ outbreak that sickened 50 people in the Northeast expanded\nits recall of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken to 4.2 million pounds, the US\nAgriculture Department said today, 21 Nov 2002.\nPrivately held Jack Lambersky, which does business as J.L. Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n'The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,' the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. The product bears establishment code 'P-4340' inside the USDA\nseal of inspection.\nSpokesman Lynn Kettleson said officials 'assume a goodly portion of the\nproduct was consumed.'\nOn 2 Nov 2002, the company recalled 200 000 pounds of poultry, after its\nproducts were linked to an outbreak in the Northeast that has killed 7\npeople. USDA said the strain found in both incidents were\n'indistinguishable.' Despite the government's findings, the company said\n'to our knowledge, no one has become ill as a result of consuming these\nproducts.'\nPilgrim's Pride, the No. 3 poultry producer based in Pittsburg, Texas, was\nalso linked to the listeriosis outbreak. It recalled 27.4 million pounds of\nits Wampler brand turkey and chicken, a record recall. Despite USDA\ntest results finding the listeria outbreak strain at its plant, Pilgrim's\nPride also has said its products were not to blame for the illnesses.\nJack Lambersky's plant in Camden, N.J., was voluntarily closed after the\ninitial recall of 200 000 pounds. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. 'The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,' said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. 'The complete plant was\ncleaned up.'\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. 'We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,' the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive\nthe firm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nProduction Dates/Identifying Codes:\nProduced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. Each product label bears the\nestablishment number 'P-4340' inside the USDA mark of inspection. [The long\nlist of the products under recall can be found at the above web site. -\nMod. LL]\nProblem/Reason for Recall:\nThe products may be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nHow/When Discovered:\nOn 3 Oct 2002, FSIS collected samples from retail as part of an ongoing\nfood safety investigation of illnesses in the Northeastern United States.\nAn intact sample was reported positive for _L. monocytogenes_ by the FSIS\nOutbreaks Laboratory. The positive results strongly suggest that the\nrecalled products may be linked to the source of the widespread illnesses\nin the Northeastern US. Based on this information firm has voluntarily\ninitiated the recall and suspended its operations.\nIn response to an on-going food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _L. monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive the\nfirm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nEstablishment: 4340 P\nJack Lambersky Poultry Inc.\nQuantity Recalled: Approximately 4.2 million pounds (This includes the\n200 000 pounds from 2 Nov 2002 recall)\nConsumer Inquiries: 1-800-535-4555\nWeb Site: <http://www.fsis.usda.gov/oa/recalls/rec_intr.htm>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n WASHINGTON - A New Jersey poultry company linked to a _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ outbreak that sickened 50 people in the Northeast expanded\nits recall of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken to 4.2 million pounds, the US\nAgriculture Department said today, 21 Nov 2002. Privately held Jack Lambersky, which does business as J.L. Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.
