On 3 Oct 2002, FSIS collected samples from retail as part of an ongoing\nfood safety investigation of illnesses in the Northeastern United States.\n The positive results strongly suggest that the\nrecalled products may be linked to the source of the widespread illnesses\nin the Northeastern US.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-05-29 00:00:00", "2002-10-03 00:00:00", "2002-11-14 00:00:00", "2002-08-30 00:00:00", "2002-11-06 00:00:00", "2021-11-18 00:00:00", "2002-11-20 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-11-21 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-12-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pittsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Northeastern United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "N.J.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camden", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202710", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - Australia: background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202710", "date": "2002-10-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA: BACKGROUND\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 07:52:55 +0200\nFrom: <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nBackground on listeriosis in Australia:\nYear Cases\n1991 44 (26 in Victoria)\n1992 38\n1993 53\n1994 34\n1995 65\n1996 70\n1997 73\n1998 58 (30 in New South Wales)\n1999 63\n2000 67\n2001 61\nDisease rates during this period were 0.3/100 000 to 0.4/100 000.\nBetween 1980 and 1995, 2 foodborne outbreaks involving 13 patients (0\nfatal) were reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Year Cases\n1991 44 (26 in Victoria)\n1992 38\n1993 53\n1994 34\n1995 65\n1996 70\n1997 73\n1998 58 (30 in New South Wales)\n1999 63\n2000 67\n2001 61\nDisease rates during this period were 0.3/100 000 to 0.4/100 000. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 07:52:55 +0200\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-14 00:00:00", "1992-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202814", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, poultry - USA: recall (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202814", "date": "2002-11-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA : RECALL (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ABC 7 Eyewitness News / AP [edited]\n<http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/news/WABC_110302_usda.html>\n\nUSDA Issues Another Recall in Connection with Listeria Outbreak\n------------------------\nA NJ company is recalling 200 000 pounds of ready-to-eat chicken and turkey\nsold nationwide and possibly linked to a listeria outbreak that sickened 50\npeople and killed 7.\nJack Lambersky Poultry Company Inc., of Camden, NJ, is pulling precooked\nturkey and chicken products made between 27 Jun 2002 and 3 Jul 2002. It\nalso has halted operations. Tests showed some of the meat contained a\nlisteria strain matching the one that infected people in 8 northeastern\nstates, according to the Agriculture Department. The meat was distributed\nto retail stores and other institutions across the country. The company\ndoes business as J.L. Foods Company Inc.\n'Consumers should check their refrigerators and freezers for products\ninvolved in this recall and return them to the point of purchase,' Dr.\nGarry L. McKee, administrator of USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service,\nsaid in a statement.\nOfficials at Jack Lambersky Poultry Company are continuing to compile\ninformation about the recalled meat, said Kenneth Martin, the general\nmanager for the family-owned company.\nUSDA inspectors have been working with the CDC to find the cause of the\nlisteria outbreak that began in mid-July 2002. The investigation prompted\nanother meat plant, Wampler Foods in Franconia, PA, to recall 27 million\npounds of ready-to-eat poultry meat on 12 Oct 2002 -- the largest recall.\nAfterward, Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman directed inspection officials\nto strengthen the listeria testing program. Watchdog groups and members of\nCongress have been urging her to toughen food safety rules in light of the\nlarge recall.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[At this point, with the finding of another potential source of the recent\nlisteriosis outbreak in the northeast USA, it has yet to be understood what\nrelationship there is between the 2 sources. Which came first, the turkey\nor the Listeria? - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Nov 2002\n The investigation prompted\nanother meat plant, Wampler Foods in Franconia, PA, to recall 27 million\npounds of ready-to-eat poultry meat on 12 Oct 2002 -- the largest recall.\n \nA NJ company is recalling 200 000 pounds of ready-to-eat chicken and turkey\nsold nationwide and possibly linked to a listeria outbreak that sickened 50\npeople and killed 7. Watchdog groups and members of\nCongress have been urging her to toughen food safety rules in light of the\nlarge recall.\n Officials at Jack Lambersky Poultry Company are continuing to compile\ninformation about the recalled meat, said Kenneth Martin, the general\nmanager for the family-owned company. Tests showed some of the meat contained a\nlisteria strain matching the one that infected people in 8 northeastern\nstates, according to the Agriculture Department. Source: ABC 7 Eyewitness News / AP [edited]\n<http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/news/WABC_110302_usda.html>\n\nUSDA Issues Another Recall in Connection with Listeria Outbreak\n [At this point, with the finding of another potential source of the recent\nlisteriosis outbreak in the northeast USA, it has yet to be understood what\nrelationship there is between the 2 sources.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-07-03 00:00:00", "2002-10-12 00:00:00", "2002-06-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Franconia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camden", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203027", "headline": "PRO> Listeriosis, poultry - USA: Recall (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203027", "date": "2002-12-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 11 Dec 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/11/national/11MEAT.html>\n\nPlant's Sanitation May Have Link to Deadly Bacteria\n--------------------------------------------------\nA Federal meat inspector said a Pennsylvania poultry plant, 1 of 2\noperations under investigation as a likely source of a listeria\noutbreak that has killed 8 people since July 2002, had persistent\nsanitation problems that could have fostered the bacteria. But the\ninspector, Vincent Erthal, said inspection officials had failed to\ncrack down on some of the problems in part because of what he and\nother critics see as confusion and indecision in a new federal system\nfor regulating the nation's food companies.\nMr. Erthal said in interviews that the chief government inspector at\nthe Wampler Foods plant in Franconia, PA, USA, disagreed about the\nextent of the dangers and opposed his efforts to force a cleanup in\nthe fall of 2001, about 8 months before the outbreak, which also\nsickened 54 people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut,\nPennsylvania, and 5 other states. Mr. Erthal also said that as health\nauthorities issued the first alerts about the outbreak in late August\n2002, he and a supervisor recommended that top regional inspection\nofficials consider forcing the Wampler plant to close for repairs.\nBut, he said, little was done until 6 weeks later.\nSeveral Agriculture Department officials said sanitation problems,\nincluding mold and algae on the walls and condensation dripping from\nductwork over the processing tables, were chronic enough to justify\nclosing the plant. The department ordered the plant closed\ntemporarily on 13 Oct 2002 after the strain of _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ that caused the deaths was found in the plant's\ndrains. Wampler, a part of Pilgrim's Pride, the nation's\nsecond-largest poultry company, also recalled 27 million pounds of\nmeat, one of the largest amounts in American history, and later\nreopened on 13 Nov 2002.\nThe Agriculture Department's Inspector General and Democrats in\nCongress are investigating why nothing more was done before listeria\nwas found in the drains. Both the government and Wampler officials\nsaid none of the meat returned under the recall had tested positive\nfor the same rare strain of _L. monocytogenes_ that caused the\noutbreak. They also said there was no proof that anyone had been\nsickened by Wampler's turkey deli meats and other ready-to-eat\nproducts.\nIdentical bacteria have been found in turkey processed by an\nunrelated company, J. L. Foods Co. Inc., in Camden, NJ, and health\nofficials say it remains unclear how most of the victims became ill.\nStill, food-safety experts say Mr. Erthal's complaints raise new\nquestions about the Agriculture Department's inspection and\nbacteria-testing program, which has come under scrutiny as a result\nof huge recalls of contaminated beef and poultry at some of the\nnation's largest processing companies since mid-July 2002. To safety\nadvocates, government auditors and some meat inspectors, the biggest\nfailures have come in how the department's Food Safety and Inspection\nService has implemented changes that grew out of a 1993 outbreak of\n_E. coli_ O157:H7 at the Jack-in-the-Box hamburger chain.\nBilled as revolutionary, the new approach was meant to be more\nscientific than the 'poke and sniff' methods that inspectors had used\nsince the turn-of-the-century days of Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle.'\nBecause the worst hazards come from microscopic toxins, the idea was\nto place more responsibility on the companies for proper\nrefrigeration and handling and to require them to create plans to\nkill any germs. The program was phased in over several years, and\nsupporters credit it with helping to reduce the frequency of serious\nfood-borne illnesses from _E. coli_, _Salmonella_ and _L.\nmonocytogenes_, which caused the recent outbreak.\nBut surveys by the Agriculture Department's Inspector General and the\nGeneral Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, show\nthat many plants have been allowed to get by with inadequate safety\nplans.\nMr. Erthal, 40, who has been a meat inspector for 18 years, said the\nnew rules have 'a lot of gray areas.' He said inspectors were still\ntaught to step in quickly at any sign of direct contamination. But\nwhen it comes to broader sanitation problems, he and others said,\nmany inspectors are waiting longer to intervene out of a sense that\nit is now the company's role to deal with those issues unless there\nare repeated failures. Rodney Leonard, a former administrator of the\ninspection service, said the result is 'a clear `don't ask, don't\ntell' mandate' that is causing inspectors to miss 'red flags all over\nthe place.'\nRepresentative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California and the\nranking minority member on the House Committee on Government Reform,\nsaid, 'I think what we're seeing is a picture of a department that\nhas abdicated its responsibility to protect the public in the area of\nfood safety.' Dr. Elsa Murano, the Agriculture Department's under\nsecretary for food safety, disputed the criticism, saying she\nexpected her inspectors to be as aggressive as ever.\nDepartment officials -- and Wampler executives -- said that if Mr.\nErthal, who was the night-shift inspector at Wampler from May 2000\nuntil last September 2002, when he received a requested transfer to a\ndaytime assignment at another plant, was so worried about the\nconditions, he should have taken harsher actions against the plant\nhimself or pushed harder to blow the whistle before the outbreak\noccurred.\nDr. Murano said the recall at Wampler was a prime motivation for a\nnew listeria testing directive that went into effect on Mon, 9 Dec\n2002. Under the plan, if companies that make ready-to-eat products\nlike hot dogs and deli meats do not voluntarily provide the\ngovernment with test results for even the most general, and least\nharmful, types of bacteria in their plants, then the department will\nexpand its own testing. The agency is also working on a new rule to\nrequire companies to test their processing areas for listeria, Dr.\nMurano said, so 'you can find it before it gets into the product.'\nFelicia Nestor, an official at the Government Accountability Project,\nan advocacy group that has been helping Mr. Erthal and other\nwhistle-blowers, said, 'The regulations focused on direct product\ncontamination, and it's only now that USDA is adding a focus on\nenvironmental testing, which is an acknowledgment that they have left\nconsumers without adequate protection up till now.' Dr. Murano said\nthat if the agency had known before the outbreak that Wampler's own\ntests had detected the more general types of listeria in the plant,\n'we would have acted.'\nRon Morris, the senior vice president for turkey operations at\nPilgrim's Pride, said the company had shared its listeria testing\nresults, both positive and negative, with the government by placing\nthem in a file drawer with other records available to the inspectors.\nBut department officials said the inspector in charge, Debra Martin,\nwho declined to comment, has denied knowing anything about the\ncompany's test results, and Mr. Erthal said he never saw the logs in\nthe drawer.\nStill, Mr. Erthal said that over time company employees told him\ninformally that the tests were finding general types of listeria in\nthe plant. Experts say that many listeria [species] can be harmless,\nbut their presence can also signal that conditions are ripe for _L.\nmonocytogenes_, the deadly type.\nMr. Erthal said that when Ms. Martin walked around with him in his\nfirst days at the plant, he pointed to the algae on the walls,\nflaking paint, and condensation on air-conditioning ducts. But, he\nsaid, Ms. Martin told him that under the new regulatory system, such\nhazards were not a high priority unless they threatened to\ncontaminate meat directly. Then, in the fall of 2001, Mr. Erthal\nsaid, Ms. Martin disagreed with his suggestion that the violations\nwarranted broader enforcement action. She told him the plant was\nmaking improvements, Mr. Erthal said, and he ultimately backed off.\nMr. Erthal agreed that the plant had made progress, replacing old\nwalls in one area and increasing the use of floor sanitizers. But he\nalso was concerned about how often floor drains got clogged and\nbacked up into puddles in the processing rooms.\nThen, on 28 Aug 2002, he said, he went through a number of the\ndeficiency notices with his circuit supervisor, Muhammad A. Choudry.\nOfficials said Mr. Choudry sent an e-mail message to managers in the\nPhiladelphia district office suggesting that the Wampler plant was a\ngood candidate for an enforcement notice, which gives a company 3\ndays to create a plan to fix safety problems or face being\ntemporarily shut down.\nJan T. Behney, the district manager in Philadelphia, and John Sworen,\nthen the district's top enforcement officer, said that their aides\nreviewed the material within several working days and agreed that the\nviolations were documented well enough to support a notice.\nBut Steven Cohen, a spokesman for the inspection service in\nWashington, said health officials initially focused on a different\ncompany's plant as the most likely source of the outbreak, and the\ndistrict inspection office did not turn its attention to Wampler\nuntil 27 Sep 2002.\nMr. Cohen said the department took 2 samples from the Wampler plant's\ndrains on 3 or 4 Oct 2002 that matched the strain of listeria in the\noutbreak. He added that 25 of the 57 samples tested positive for\nother strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nMr. Morris, the Pilgrim's Pride senior vice president, said the\ncompany 'diligently worked' to fix the problems with mold and\ncondensation over the past year. Mr. Morris said Wampler recently\nstrengthened safety programs.\n[Byline: Christopher Drew and Elizabeth Becker]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report from the New York Times illustrates the many levels of\nissues involved in food safety. We appear to be making some progress\nalong these fronts, but there is likely to be a long and winding\nyellow brick road littered along the way with the lions and tigers\nand bears -- and wicked witches -- of outbreaks of food-borne\norganisms, until the Emerald City of Uniformly Safe Food is reached\n-- if ever. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Department officials -- and Wampler executives -- said that if Mr.\nErthal, who was the night-shift inspector at Wampler from May 2000\nuntil last September 2002, when he received a requested transfer to a\ndaytime assignment at another plant, was so worried about the\nconditions, he should have taken harsher actions against the plant\nhimself or pushed harder to blow the whistle before the outbreak\noccurred. \nFelicia Nestor, an official at the Government Accountability Project,\nan advocacy group that has been helping Mr. Erthal and other\nwhistle-blowers, said, 'The regulations focused on direct product\ncontamination, and it's only now that USDA is adding a focus on\nenvironmental testing, which is an acknowledgment that they have left\nconsumers without adequate protection up till now.' Officials said Mr. Choudry sent an e-mail message to managers in the\nPhiladelphia district office suggesting that the Wampler plant was a\ngood candidate for an enforcement notice, which gives a company 3\ndays to create a plan to fix safety problems or face being\ntemporarily shut down.\n Mr. Erthal said in interviews that the chief government inspector at\nthe Wampler Foods plant in Franconia, PA, USA, disagreed about the\nextent of the dangers and opposed his efforts to force a cleanup in\nthe fall of 2001, about 8 months before the outbreak, which also\nsickened 54 people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut,\nPennsylvania, and 5 other states. We appear to be making some progress\nalong these fronts, but there is likely to be a long and winding\nyellow brick road littered along the way with the lions and tigers\nand bears -- and wicked witches -- of outbreaks of food-borne\norganisms, until the Emerald City of Uniformly Safe Food is reached\n-- if ever. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n But Steven Cohen, a spokesman for the inspection service in\nWashington, said health officials initially focused on a different\ncompany's plant as the most likely source of the outbreak, and the\ndistrict inspection office did not turn its attention to Wampler\nuntil 27 Sep 2002. \nRon Morris, the senior vice president for turkey operations at\nPilgrim's Pride, said the company had shared its listeria testing\nresults, both positive and negative, with the government by placing\nthem in a file drawer with other records available to the inspectors. But department officials said the inspector in charge, Debra Martin,\nwho declined to comment, has denied knowing anything about the\ncompany's test results, and Mr. Erthal said he never saw the logs in\nthe drawer. Mr. Erthal also said that as health\nauthorities issued the first alerts about the outbreak in late August\n2002, he and a supervisor recommended that top regional inspection\nofficials consider forcing the Wampler plant to close for repairs. Several Agriculture Department officials said sanitation problems,\nincluding mold and algae on the walls and condensation dripping from\nductwork over the processing tables, were chronic enough to justify\nclosing the plant. The department ordered the plant closed\ntemporarily on 13 Oct 2002 after the strain of _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ that caused the deaths was found in the plant's\ndrains. Rodney Leonard, a former administrator of the\ninspection service, said the result is 'a clear `don't ask, don't\ntell' mandate' that is causing inspectors to miss 'red flags all over\nthe place.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-11-13 00:00:00", "2040-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-09-27 00:00:00", "2002-08-28 00:00:00", "2002-12-26 00:00:00", "1993-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-07-26 00:00:00", "2000-05-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Emerald City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franconia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202664", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (06): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202664", "date": "2002-10-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (06): CORRECTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 7 Oct 2002 07:30:17 -0600 (CST)\nFrom: James Perdue <jperdue@DisCon.TDH.state.tx.us>\n\nRe previous post: >Forty people...have become sick, and 40 have died...from\nlisteria...<\n100 percent mortality from listeriosis...???... seems high...even for\nlisteriosis..\n--\nJames N. Perdue\nPublic Health Technician\nInfectious Disease Epidemiology\nand Surveillance (IDEAS) Division\nTexas Department of Health\n<jperdue@DisCon.TDH.state.tx.us>\n[I apologize for the error in moderating the posting. The first 2 paragraphs\nof the Reuters story are below:\n<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=3Dstory&u=3D/nm/20021004/sc_nm/food_l\nisteria_dc_1>\nAs shown, there are 40 cases and 7 deaths linked to the turkey meat but 120\ncases and 20 deaths all told.\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - Turkey deli meat was one likely source of a listeria\noutbreak blamed for 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in 8 states, US government\nofficials said on Friday, 4 Oct 2002.\nThe Centers for Diseases Control and Prevention, along with the US\nAgriculture Department, has linked at least 7 deaths and 40 illnesses to the\nsame listeria strain. The illnesses were reported in early September 2002. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The first 2 paragraphs\nof the Reuters story are below:\n<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=3Dstory&u=3D/nm/20021004/sc_nm/food_l\nisteria_dc_1>\n From: James Perdue <jperdue@DisCon.TDH.state.tx.us>\n\nRe previous post: >Forty people...have become sick, and 40 have died...from\nlisteria...<\n100 percent mortality from listeriosis...??? Turkey deli meat was one likely source of a listeria\noutbreak blamed for 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in 8 states, US government\nofficials said on Friday, 4 Oct 2002. The Centers for Diseases Control and Prevention, along with the US\nAgriculture Department, has linked at least 7 deaths and 40 illnesses to the\nsame listeria strain. ... seems high...even for\nlisteriosis..\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2002-10-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202706", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, poultry - USA:RECALL", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202706", "date": "2002-10-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 13 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times.com / AP 14 Oct 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/business/AP-Meat-Recall.html>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Joe Parrish, Pablo Nart and Maria Jacobs\nfor submitting articles on this recall as well. - Mod.MPP]\n\nBacteria Fears Prompt Largest Ever U.S. Meat Recall\n-------------------------------------------------------\nPoultry processor Pilgrim's Pride is recalling 27.4 million pounds of\ncooked sandwich meat after warnings of possible contamination from\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the largest meat recall in US history. The\ncompany pulled 295 000 pounds of turkey and chicken products Wednesday 9\nOct 2002, but expanded the recall over the weekend after tests came back\npositive for a strain of the potentially fatal bacteria, the company said\nSunday, 13 Oct 2002.\nThe nationwide recall covers meat processed at the company's plant in\nsuburban Franconia from 1 May through 11 Oct 2002. The recall covers deli\nmeat primarily sold under the company's Wampler Foods brand, though it is\nalso sold under brands including Block & Barrel, Bonos, Golden Acre,\nReliance, and a variety of private labels. The products include turkey and\npoultry sold freshly sliced or made into sandwiches at deli counters and in\nindividually sold packages of sliced deli meats.\nBecause consumers might not have access to the meat's original packaging,\nthe best way to know whether a product falls under the recall is to ask if\nit comes from a package that bears the plant number P-1351 inside the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture mark of inspection, said company spokesman Ray\nAtkinson. Production dates also can be found on that part of the\nlabel. The deli products were sold in retail groceries, in delicatessens\nand by food service distributors.\nConsumers were urged by the company to return any affected meat to the\nstore or deli where it was purchased for a full refund. The discovery\nfollowed an investigation of a listeria outbreak in 8 northeast states\nsince early summer that caused at least 120 illnesses and 20 deaths, the\nUSDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service said. ``We want consumers to be\naware of the recall because of the potential for foodborne illness,'' said\nDr. Garry L. McKee, the inspection service's administrator.\nNo products have been linked to that outbreak, said David Van Hoose,\nWampler's chief executive officer. The genetic strain that caused the\noutbreak is different from the strain found at the plant, officials\nsaid. 'We don't have any scientific evidence at this point that there is a\nconnection, but our analysis of sampling in that plant is not complete,''\nsaid the USDA's Steven Cohen. He said the recall was the largest in U.S.\nhistory.\nCompany officials said the recall didn't include fresh turkeys, and that it\nshould have no effect on the holiday season.\nListeria can cause high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness and nausea,\naccording to the USDA. It can be fatal in young children, the elderly and\npeople with weak immune systems and can cause miscarriages and\nstillbirths. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Web site for\nlisteriosis recommends that left-over or ready-to-eat foods should be\ncooked until steaming hot before eating.\nThe company said it halted all production Saturday at the plant about 25\nmiles north of Philadelphia so that it could be thoroughly cleaned. The\nmeat being recalled makes up roughly 6 percent of the company's total\npoultry production, Van Hoose said. The company didn't say how much revenue\nit would lose as a result of the shutdown.\nThe largest previous meat recall in US history was in 1997, when Hudson\nFoods recalled 25 million pounds of ground beef after 15 people in Colorado\nfell ill from _E. coli_ after eating hamburger from its plant in Columbus,\nNeb. The Wampler recall comes less than 3 months after ConAgra Beef\nrecalled nearly 19 million pounds of ground beef because of _E. coli_\ncontamination at its plant in Greeley, Colo.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although this contamination was discovered in the search for the origin of\nthe multistate outbreak of listeriosis in the northeastern USA, genetic\ntesting has found that the recall and outbreak strains are not the\nsame. Deli meats are always a significant concern in the spread of\nlisteriosis since they are ready to eat. The size of this recall\nreemphasizes the potential for food-spread illnesses in today's world. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 13 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n The\ncompany pulled 295 000 pounds of turkey and chicken products Wednesday 9\nOct 2002, but expanded the recall over the weekend after tests came back\npositive for a strain of the potentially fatal bacteria, the company said\nSunday, 13 Oct 2002. The largest previous meat recall in US history was in 1997, when Hudson\nFoods recalled 25 million pounds of ground beef after 15 people in Colorado\nfell ill from _E. coli_ after eating hamburger from its plant in Columbus,\nNeb. The recall covers deli\nmeat primarily sold under the company's Wampler Foods brand, though it is\nalso sold under brands including Block & Barrel, Bonos, Golden Acre,\nReliance, and a variety of private labels. The Wampler recall comes less than 3 months after ConAgra Beef\nrecalled nearly 19 million pounds of ground beef because of _E. coli_\ncontamination at its plant in Greeley, Colo.\n-- [Although this contamination was discovered in the search for the origin of\nthe multistate outbreak of listeriosis in the northeastern USA, genetic\ntesting has found that the recall and outbreak strains are not the\nsame. The discovery\nfollowed an investigation of a listeria outbreak in 8 northeast states\nsince early summer that caused at least 120 illnesses and 20 deaths, the\nUSDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service said. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Poultry processor Pilgrim's Pride is recalling 27.4 million pounds of\ncooked sandwich meat after warnings of possible contamination from\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, the largest meat recall in US history. The products include turkey and\npoultry sold freshly sliced or made into sandwiches at deli counters and in\nindividually sold packages of sliced deli meats. The\nmeat being recalled makes up roughly 6 percent of the company's total\npoultry production, Van Hoose said. ``We want consumers to be\naware of the recall because of the potential for foodborne illness,'' said\nDr. Garry L. McKee, the inspection service's administrator. The genetic strain that caused the\noutbreak is different from the strain found at the plant, officials\nsaid. it comes from a package that bears the plant number P-1351 inside the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture mark of inspection, said company spokesman Ray\nAtkinson.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "1997-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greeley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neb.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colo.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York Times.com", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franconia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202711", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202711", "date": "2002-10-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (08)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 15 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Press Release 15 Oct 2002\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r021015.htm>\n\nUpdate: Listeriosis Outbreak Investigation\n------------------------\nCDC, state and local health departments, and the United States Department\nof Agriculture (USDA) Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) have been\ninvestigating an outbreak of listeriosis, primarily affecting persons in\nthe northeastern United States. Thus far, 46 ill persons infected with the\noutbreak strain of Listeria have been detected since mid-July; most were\nhospitalized, 7 have died, and 3 pregnant women have had miscarriages or\nstillbirths. Epidemiologic data indicate that precooked, sliceable turkey\ndeli meat is the cause of this outbreak.\nAs part of the outbreak investigation, the United Stated Department of\nAgriculture's (USDA) Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) obtained\nfood and environmental samples from Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, located in\nFranconia, Pennsylvania. One food product and 25 environmental samples\ntested positive for Listeria. USDA-FSIS laboratories performed DNA\nfingerprinting on these bacteria. Comparison of different strains was\nconducted through PulseNet, which is a network of public health and\nregulatory laboratories that perform DNA fingerprinting of bacteria and\nelectronically share results. The food product had a strain of Listeria\ndifferent from the outbreak strain. Of the 25 environmental Listeria\nstrains fingerprinted, 1 matched that of the food product and 3 matched\nthat of patients in the current outbreak. On 13 October 2002, the plant\nvoluntarily shut down operations and issued a recall of approximately 27\nmillion pounds of fresh and frozen ready-to-eat turkey and chicken products\nproduced since May 1, 2002. Turkey meat products included in the recall\nshould not be eaten. Information on specific products and brands covered by\nthe recall is available at:\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/prelease/pr090-2002.htm>.\nListeriosis is a serious foodborne disease that can be life-threatening to\ncertain individuals, including the elderly or those with weakened immune\nsystems. It can also cause miscarriages and stillbirths in pregnant women.\nThe affected patients live in 8 states: Pennsylvania (14 cases), New York\n(11 cases in New York City, 7 in other locations), New Jersey (5 cases),\nDelaware (4 cases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1 case), Michigan (1\ncase), and Massachusetts (1 case). Twenty-eight patients were male and 18\nwere female. Fifteen patients were age 65 or above, 14 patients were age 1\nto 64 years and had an immunocompromising medical condition, 7 others were\npregnant, and 3 were neonates; 6 patients were age 1 to 64 years and were\nnot pregnant or known to have an immunocompromising condition. Of the 7\npatients who died, 6 had immunocompromising conditions (3 of these patients\nwere also age 65 or older), and one was a neonate. The most recent patient\nbecame ill on September 30.\nIn addition to the patients whose illnesses have been confirmed as part of\nthe outbreak, CDC and state and local health departments have learned about\nother cases of Listeria infection in the same region during the outbreak\ntime period. DNA fingerprinting has shown that strains from 64 patients in\nthese same states are different from the outbreak strain and 18 of these\npatients have died; these illnesses are part of the 'background' of\nsporadic Listeria infections and are likely due to a variety of different\nfoods. In addition, testing of strains from several additional persons is\nongoing, some of these may be identified as the outbreak strain. Because\npregnant women, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are\nat higher risk for listeriosis, we recommend the following measures for\nthose persons:\nDo not eat hot dogs and luncheon meats, unless they are reheated until\nsteaming hot.\nAvoid cross-contaminating other foods, utensils, and food preparation\nsurfaces with fluid from hot dog packages, and wash hands after handling\nhot dogs.\nDo not eat soft cheeses such as Feta, Brie and Camembert cheeses,\nblue-veined cheeses, and Mexican-style cheeses such as 'queso blanco\nfresco.' Cheeses that may be eaten include hard cheeses; semi-soft cheeses\nsuch as mozzarella; pasteurized processed cheeses such as slices and\nspreads; cream cheese; and cottage cheese.\nDo not eat refrigerated p\u00e2t\u00e9s or meat spreads. Canned or shelf-stable p\u00e2t\u00e9s\nand meat spreads may be eaten.\nDo not eat refrigerated smoked seafood, unless it is contained in a cooked\ndish, such as a casserole. Refrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon,\ntrout, whitefish, cod, tuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as\n'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' The fish is found in\nthe refrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\nDo not drink raw (unpasteurized) milk or eat foods that contain\nunpasteurized milk.\nAbout 2500 cases of listeriosis occur each year in the United States. The\ninitial symptoms are often fever, muscle aches, and sometimes\ngastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. The illness may be\nmild and ill persons sometimes describe their illness as flu-like. If\ninfection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache, stiff\nneck, confusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. Most cases of\nlisteriosis and most deaths occur in adults with weakened immune systems,\nthe elderly, pregnant women, and newborns. However, infections can occur\noccasionally in otherwise healthy persons. Infections during pregnancy can\nlead to miscarriages, stillbirths, and infection of newborn infants.\nPrevious outbreaks of listeriosis have been linked to a variety of foods\nespecially processed meats (such as hot dogs, deli meats, and pat\u00e9) and\ndairy products made from unpasteurized milk.\nThe risk of an individual person developing Listeria infection after\nconsumption of a contaminated product is very small. If you have eaten a\ncontaminated product and do not have any symptoms, we do not recommend that\nyou have any tests or treatment, even if you are in a high risk group.\nHowever, if you are in a high risk group, have eaten the contaminated\nproduct, and within a month become ill with fever or signs of serious\nillness, you should contact your health care provider and inform him or her\nabout this exposure.\nUnited States Department of Health and Human Services\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention\nOffice of Communication\nDivision of Media Relations\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is an excellent example of using environmental sampling to identify\npotential sources of contamination. In this case, sampling of precooked\nturkey deli meat from the implicated producer did not yield isolates of the\n'outbreak' strain of listeria (see ProMED-mail posting Listeriosis, poultry\n- USA: recall 20021014.5550); yet environmental sampling from the factory\nproducing the epidemiologically implicated precooked turkey deli meats did\nyield one isolate that was identified by DNA fingerprinting to be identical\nto the outbreak strain. It's fascinating to see the 'marriage' of\nlaboratory, environment and epidemiology as a unified approach to\ninvestigate outbreaks. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "In this case, sampling of precooked\nturkey deli meat from the implicated producer did not yield isolates of the\n'outbreak' strain of listeria (see ProMED-mail posting Listeriosis, poultry\n- USA: recall 20021014.5550); yet environmental sampling from the factory\nproducing the epidemiologically implicated precooked turkey deli meats did\nyield one isolate that was identified by DNA fingerprinting to be identical\nto the outbreak strain. United States Department of Health and Human Services\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention\nOffice of Communication\nDivision of Media Relations\n--\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 15 Oct 2002\n DNA fingerprinting has shown that strains from 64 patients in\nthese same states are different from the outbreak strain and 18 of these\npatients have died; these illnesses are part of the 'background' of\nsporadic Listeria infections and are likely due to a variety of different\nfoods. \nCDC, state and local health departments, and the United States Department\nof Agriculture (USDA) Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) have been\ninvestigating an outbreak of listeriosis, primarily affecting persons in\nthe northeastern United States. Because\npregnant women, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are\nat higher risk for listeriosis, we recommend the following measures for\nthose persons:\n Fifteen patients were age 65 or above, 14 patients were age 1\nto 64 years and had an immunocompromising medical condition, 7 others were\npregnant, and 3 were neonates; 6 patients were age 1 to 64 years and were\nnot pregnant or known to have an immunocompromising condition. The affected patients live in 8 states: Pennsylvania (14 cases), New York\n(11 cases in New York City, 7 in other locations), New Jersey (5 cases),\nDelaware (4 cases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1 case), Michigan (1\ncase), and Massachusetts (1 case). In addition to the patients whose illnesses have been confirmed as part of\nthe outbreak, CDC and state and local health departments have learned about\nother cases of Listeria infection in the same region during the outbreak\ntime period. Thus far, 46 ill persons infected with the\noutbreak strain of Listeria have been detected since mid-July; most were\nhospitalized, 7 have died, and 3 pregnant women have had miscarriages or\nstillbirths. On 13 October 2002, the plant\nvoluntarily shut down operations and issued a recall of approximately 27\nmillion pounds of fresh and frozen ready-to-eat turkey and chicken products\nproduced since May 1, 2002. However, if you are in a high risk group, have eaten the contaminated\nproduct, and within a month become ill with fever or signs of serious\nillness, you should contact your health care provider and inform him or her\nabout this exposure. As part of the outbreak investigation, the United Stated Department of\nAgriculture's (USDA) Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) obtained\nfood and environmental samples from Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, located in\nFranconia, Pennsylvania. Comparison of different strains was\nconducted through PulseNet, which is a network of public health and\nregulatory laboratories that perform DNA fingerprinting of bacteria and\nelectronically share results. Of the 25 environmental Listeria\nstrains fingerprinted, 1 matched that of the food product and 3 matched\nthat of patients in the current outbreak. Cheeses that may be eaten include hard cheeses; semi-soft cheeses\nsuch as mozzarella; pasteurized processed cheeses such as slices and\nspreads; cream cheese; and cottage cheese. Previous outbreaks of listeriosis have been linked to a variety of foods\nespecially processed meats (such as hot dogs, deli meats, and pat\u00e9) and\ndairy products made from unpasteurized milk. Of the 7\npatients who died, 6 had immunocompromising conditions (3 of these patients\nwere also age 65 or older), and one was a neonate. Do not eat soft cheeses such as Feta, Brie and Camembert cheeses,\nblue-veined cheeses, and Mexican-style cheeses such as 'queso blanco\nfresco.' Most cases of\nlisteriosis and most deaths occur in adults with weakened immune systems,\nthe elderly, pregnant women, and newborns. Avoid cross-contaminating other foods, utensils, and food preparation\nsurfaces with fluid from hot dog packages, and wash hands after handling\nhot dogs. If you have eaten a\ncontaminated product and do not have any symptoms, we do not recommend that\nyou have any tests or treatment, even if you are in a high risk group.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-13 00:00:00", "2021-09-30 00:00:00", "2002-05-01 00:00:00", "2002-10-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Listeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Franconia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202673", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202673", "date": "2002-10-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (07)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 8 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Press Release [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r021008.htm>\n\nUpdate: Listeriosis Outbreak Investigation\n-------------------------------------------\nCDC and several state health departments are investigating an outbreak of\nlisteriosis, primarily affecting persons in the northeastern U.S. Thus far,\n43 ill persons with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have\nbeen detected; all were hospitalized, 7 died, and 3 pregnant women had\nmiscarriages or stillbirths. These patients live in 7 states: Pennsylvania\n(14 cases), New York (11 cases in New York City, 6 in other locations), New\nJersey (4 cases), Delaware (4 cases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1\ncase), and Michigan (1 case).\nAnalysis of data collected to date indicate that the leading suspect food in\nthis outbreak is sliced turkey deli[catessen] meat. Federal, state, and\nlocal health and officials are continuing to investigate to determine the\nbrand(s) and origin of the product involved.\nListeriosis is a very serious foodborne disease that can be life-threatening\nto certain individuals, including the elderly or those with weakened immune\nsystems. It can also cause miscarriages and stillbirths in pregnant women,\nso we need to continue to remind persons at high risk to thoroughly heat\ndeli meats before eating them. Persons in these risk groups who reside in\nthe affected states may reduce their risk of infection by not eating sliced\nturkey deli meats or by thoroughly heating them. This is consistent with\nstandard recommendations for persons at high risk:\n* Avoid foods from deli counters or thoroughly heat deli meat products\nbefore eating.\n* Heat hot dogs until steaming before eating.\n* Avoid cross-contaminating other foods, utensils, and food preparation\nsurfaces with fluid from hot dog packages, and wash hands after handling hot\ndogs.\n* Avoid soft cheeses such as feta, Brie, Camembert, blue-veined, and\nMexican-style cheese. (Hard cheeses, processed cheeses, cream cheese,\ncottage cheese, and yogurt need not be avoided).\nThe following additional food safety measures, which should be routine for\nall persons, can also reduce the risk of listeriosis:\n* Thoroughly cook raw food from animal sources, such as beef, pork, or\npoultry.\n* Wash raw vegetables thoroughly before eating.\n* Keep uncooked meats separate from vegetables and from cooked foods.\n* Avoid raw (unpasteurized) milk or foods made from raw milk.\n* Wash hands, knives, and cutting boards after handling uncooked foods.\nIn addition to the 40 patients whose illnesses have been confirmed as part\nof the outbreak, CDC and State Health Departments have learned about other\ncases of Listeria infection in the same region. DNA subtyping has shown that\nstrains from over 30 patients in these same states are different from the\noutbreak strain; these illnesses are part of the 'background' of sporadic\nListeria infections and are likely due to a variety of different foods.\nAbout 2500 cases of listeriosis occur each year in the United States. The\ninitial symptoms are often fever, muscle aches, and sometimes\ngastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. The illness may be\nmild, and ill persons sometimes describe their illness as flu-like. If\ninfection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache, stiff\nneck, confusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. Most cases of\nlisteriosis and most deaths occur in adults with weakened immune systems,\nthe elderly, pregnant women, and newborns. However, infections can occur\noccasionally in otherwise healthy persons. Infections during pregnancy can\nlead to miscarriages, stillbirths, and infection of newborn infants.\nPrevious outbreaks of listeriosis have been linked to a variety of foods,\nespecially processed meats (such as hot dogs, deli meats, and pate) and\ndairy products (such as soft cheeses and milk). Pasteurization eliminates\nListeria bacteria; dairy products cause illness only when pasteurization is\nnot done, is inadequate, or when food is contaminated after pasteurization.\nIf you have questions about Listeria, you can call your local or state\nhealth department, or your physician, or visit the CDC web site at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "\nCDC and several state health departments are investigating an outbreak of\nlisteriosis, primarily affecting persons in the northeastern U.S. Thus far,\n43 ill persons with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have\nbeen detected; all were hospitalized, 7 died, and 3 pregnant women had\nmiscarriages or stillbirths. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The following additional food safety measures, which should be routine for\nall persons, can also reduce the risk of listeriosis:\n* Thoroughly cook raw food from animal sources, such as beef, pork, or\npoultry.\n These patients live in 7 states: Pennsylvania\n(14 cases), New York (11 cases in New York City, 6 in other locations), New\nJersey (4 cases), Delaware (4 cases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1\ncase), and Michigan (1 case). DNA subtyping has shown that\nstrains from over 30 patients in these same states are different from the\noutbreak strain; these illnesses are part of the 'background' of sporadic\n If you have questions about Listeria, you can call your local or state\nhealth department, or your physician, or visit the CDC web site at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>\n Previous outbreaks of listeriosis have been linked to a variety of foods,\nespecially processed meats (such as hot dogs, deli meats, and pate) and\ndairy products (such as soft cheeses and milk). Persons in these risk groups who reside in\nthe affected states may reduce their risk of infection by not eating sliced\nturkey deli meats or by thoroughly heating them. It can also cause miscarriages and stillbirths in pregnant women,\nso we need to continue to remind persons at high risk to thoroughly heat\n * Avoid cross-contaminating other foods, utensils, and food preparation\nsurfaces with fluid from hot dog packages, and wash hands after handling hot\ndogs. In addition to the 40 patients whose illnesses have been confirmed as part\nof the outbreak, CDC and State Health Departments have learned about other\ncases of Listeria infection in the same region. Most cases of\nlisteriosis and most deaths occur in adults with weakened immune systems,\nthe elderly, pregnant women, and newborns. Pasteurization eliminates\nListeria bacteria; dairy products cause illness only when pasteurization is\nnot done, is inadequate, or when food is contaminated after pasteurization. If\ninfection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache, stiff\nneck, confusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. Listeriosis is a very serious foodborne disease that can be life-threatening\nto certain individuals, including the elderly or those with weakened immune\nsystems. This is consistent with\nstandard recommendations for persons at high risk:\n*", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202657", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202657", "date": "2002-10-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (06)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 5 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health 4 Oct 2002 5:25 PM EST (edited)\n<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story2&cid=571&ncid=751&e=1&u=/nm\n/20021004/hl_nm/bacteria_meat_dc>\n\nDeli meat suspected source of killer bacteria: CDC\n--------------------------------------------------\nNEW YORK (Reuters Health): Forty people in the north eastern United States\nhave become sick, and 40 have died from infection with the foodborne\nlisteria bacteria, according to officials at the US Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta, Georgia.\n'Analysis of data collected to date indicate that the leading suspect food\nin this outbreak is sliced turkey deli meat,' say CDC experts. They say\nhealth officials are working hard to track down the exact brand of meat\nresponsible for the outbreak.\nSo far, 7 states have been affected: Pennsylvania (14 cases), New York (11\ncases in New York City, 3 elsewhere), New Jersey (4 cases), Delaware (4\ncases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1 case), and Michigan (1 case).\nEach year, about 2500 Americans come down with listeriosis after eating\nfoods -- most often meats, raw vegetables, and soft cheeses -- contaminated\nwith the bacterium.\nFor further information on listeria, visit the CDC website\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nNEW YORK (Reuters Health): Forty people in the north eastern United States\nhave become sick, and 40 have died from infection with the foodborne\nlisteria bacteria, according to officials at the US Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta, Georgia. Each year, about 2500 Americans come down with listeriosis after eating\nfoods -- most often meats, raw vegetables, and soft cheeses -- contaminated\nwith the bacterium.\n So far, 7 states have been affected: Pennsylvania (14 cases), New York (11\ncases in New York City, 3 elsewhere), New Jersey (4 cases), Delaware (4\ncases), Maryland (2 cases), Connecticut (1 case), and Michigan (1 case). They say\nhealth officials are working hard to track down the exact brand of meat\nresponsible for the outbreak.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-04 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202647", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202647", "date": "2002-10-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (05)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 13:14:35 GMT-3\nFrom: Luz Alba Fornells <luzalba@bioqmed.ufrj.br>\nSource: Reuters.com [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.com/news_article.jhtml?type=search&StoryID=1531036>\n\nUS investigates food outbreaks linked to 20 deaths\n--------------------------------------------------\nUS health and food officials said on Thursday, 3 Oct 2002, that they are\ninvestigating the source of a foodborne listeria outbreak blamed for at\nleast 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in north eastern states.\nIn this outbreak, the United States Department of Agriculture said its Food\nSafety and Inspection Service began 'vigorous sampling' of lunch meats and\ndeli products after illnesses were reported in early September 2002. Most\nillnesses were in New York, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, but Michigan,\nMaryland, Ohio, Connecticut, and Delaware also were affected. Federal\nofficials have not yet been able to pinpoint whether the listeria\ncontaminated ready-to-eat meats or other foods such as seafood, soft\ncheeses, and unpasteurized milk.\n'Working with state health officials, Food Safety and Inspection Service\n(FSIS) investigators have been probing every possible lead in an attempt to\nnarrow the list of possible sources of contamination,' FSIS administrator\nGarry McKee said in a statement. 'Multiple samples have been collected and\nanalyzed, but as of yet, all have tested negative.'\nOf the 120 listeria illnesses reported to health officials, 36 were linked\nthrough laboratory tests, said FSIS spokesman Steve Cohen. The 36 illnesses\nresulted in 6 deaths. Officials said they have not yet determined the\nstrain of listeria that caused the other 14 deaths.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --------------------------------------------------\nUS health and food officials said on Thursday, 3 Oct 2002, that they are\ninvestigating the source of a foodborne listeria outbreak blamed for at\nleast 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in north eastern states. Working with state health officials, Food Safety and Inspection Service\n(FSIS) investigators have been probing every possible lead in an attempt to\nnarrow the list of possible sources of contamination,' FSIS administrator\n Federal\nofficials have not yet been able to pinpoint whether the listeria\ncontaminated ready-to-eat meats or other foods such as seafood, soft\ncheeses, and unpasteurized milk. In this outbreak, the United States Department of Agriculture said its Food\nSafety and Inspection Service began 'vigorous sampling' of lunch meats and\ndeli products after illnesses were reported in early September 2002. Officials said they have not yet determined the\nstrain of listeria that caused the other 14 deaths.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-01 00:00:00", "2002-10-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States Department of Agriculture", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202547", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (Multistate) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202547", "date": "2002-09-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (02)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/17/nyregion/17ILLN.html>\n\nThis summer 6 people in the New York City metropolitan area have died\nof the food-related illness listeriosis, according to city health\nofficials, who have issued warnings to the elderly, pregnant women,\nand those with weakened immune systems, advising them to avoid soft\ncheeses and deli meats.\nWhile 4 of the deaths were in New Jersey, 2 were in New York City. In\nall, as many as 44 people in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania\nhave been among the dozens infected by the outbreak in the Northeast\nand Midwest, with 8 of those cases in New York City.\nListeriosis is caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, a species of\nbacteria sometimes found in raw foods, including uncooked meat and\nunpasteurized milk.\n'This particular bacteria, unlike others, grows in cold\ntemperatures,' said Richard McGarvey, a spokesman for the\nPennsylvania Department of Health. 'So naturally what you tell people\nis if they're going to eat meats, heat it up first.'\nThe people who died had weakened immune systems, officials said,\nwhich placed them at high risk. New York City Health Department\nofficials said 20 percent of those who have compromised immune\nsystems typically die if they contract listeriosis.\nWhile the source of the illness is unknown, this summer's outbreak\nwas first identified in Pennsylvania [see ProMED posting\n20020901.5205 -Mod.LL], where 4 elderly people have died from the\ndisease. It has also been found in Connecticut, Maryland, and\nMichigan. DNA testing has shown that the bacteria in the cases in\nNew York City was the same strain as that in the Pennsylvania cases.\nNew Jersey health officials have reported 4 listeria-related deaths\namong elderly people [see ProMED posting 20020915.5323 -Mod.LL], but\nlaboratory tests have not determined whether those deaths are tied to\nthe Pennsylvania cases.\nEating listeria-contaminated food results in flulike symptoms, which\nmay not show up for 10 weeks, including fever, muscle aches, and\ndiarrhea in otherwise healthy people. Pregnant women are at\nparticular risk; they are 20 times more likely to contract\nlisteriosis.\nTo prevent outbreaks of the disease, health officials advised washing\nand cooking food thoroughly and keeping uncooked meats apart from\nvegetables and other foods. They urged those at high risk for\ncontracting listeriosis, including pregnant women and the elderly, to\navoid hot dogs and luncheon meats or to reheat such meat until it is\n'steaming hot.' They also advised avoiding soft cheeses, including\nfeta and Brie, which are made with unpasteurized milk and can contain\nthe listeria bacteria.\nAlthough the bacteria should be killed during processing by food\nmanufacturers, it has been found to survive in some ready-to-eat\nmeats. In New York City, recent outbreaks have been linked to hot\ndogs, turkey meat, and refrigerated pate. In May 2002, a Bronx meat\npacking firm recalled 77 000 pounds of hot dogs and bologna that\nmight have been contaminated with the organism.\n[Byline: Daisy Hernandez]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The FDA issued this release on 13 Sep 2002 regarding this multistate outbreak:\n'The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Food Safety\nInspection Service (FSIS) are advising the public of a recent\nincrease in cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in Pennsylvania and\nmonitoring for possible increases in adjacent states. Contaminated\nfood products can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant\nwomen, serious and sometimes fatal infections in newborns, frail or\nelderly people, and others with weakened immune systems. Healthy\nindividuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever,\nsevere headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhea.\nThe specific food associated with the increased incidence of illness\nhas not been identified. For this reason, FDA and FSIS are issuing\nthis advisory as it continues to work closely with CDC and the states\nto identify the source of contamination. However, because of the\nnumber of cases and serious illness caused by _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, FDA and FSIS are providing the following information\nand advice to consumers:\nPeople at risk for listeriosis and their family members or\nindividuals preparing food for them should take the following\nprecautions:\nDo not eat hot dogs and luncheon meats, unless they are reheated\nuntil steaming hot.\nDo not eat soft cheeses such as Feta, Brie and Camembert cheeses,\nblue-veined cheeses, and Mexican-style cheeses such as 'queso blanco\nfresco.'\nDo not eat refrigerated pates or meat spreads. Canned or shelf-stable\npates and meat spreads may be eaten.\nDo not eat refrigerated smoked seafood, unless it is contained in a\ncooked dish, such as a casserole. Refrigerated smoked seafood, such\nas salmon, trout, whitefish, cod, tuna or mackerel, is most often\nlabeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' The\nfish is found in the refrigerator section or sold at deli counters of\ngrocery stores and delicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked\nseafood may be eaten.\nDo not drink raw (unpasteurized) milk or eat foods that contain\nunpasteurized milk.\nConsumers experiencing the symptoms described above or concerned with\nexposure should contact their physician immediately.'\n- Mod. LL]", "summary": "Source: NY Times Online [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/17/nyregion/17ILLN.html>\n\nThis summer 6 people in the New York City metropolitan area have died\nof the food-related illness listeriosis, according to city health\nofficials, who have issued warnings to the elderly, pregnant women,\nand those with weakened immune systems, advising them to avoid soft\ncheeses and deli meats. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [The FDA issued this release on 13 Sep 2002 regarding this multistate outbreak:\n'The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Food Safety\nInspection Service (FSIS) are advising the public of a recent\nincrease in cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ in Pennsylvania and\nmonitoring for possible increases in adjacent states. However, because of the\nnumber of cases and serious illness caused by _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, FDA and FSIS are providing the following information\nand advice to consumers:\n They urged those at high risk for\ncontracting listeriosis, including pregnant women and the elderly, to\navoid hot dogs and luncheon meats or to reheat such meat until it is\n'steaming hot.' Contaminated\nfood products can cause miscarriages and stillbirths among pregnant\nwomen, serious and sometimes fatal infections in newborns, frail or\nelderly people, and others with weakened immune systems. They also advised avoiding soft cheeses, including\nfeta and Brie, which are made with unpasteurized milk and can contain\nthe listeria bacteria.\n People at risk for listeriosis and their family members or\nindividuals preparing food for them should take the following\nprecautions:\n In May 2002, a Bronx meat\npacking firm recalled 77 000 pounds of hot dogs and bologna that\nmight have been contaminated with the organism.\n In\nall, as many as 44 people in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania\nhave been among the dozens infected by the outbreak in the Northeast\nand Midwest, with 8 of those cases in New York City. Do not eat soft cheeses such as Feta, Brie and Camembert cheeses,\nblue-veined cheeses, and Mexican-style cheeses such as 'queso blanco\nfresco.' To prevent outbreaks of the disease, health officials advised washing\nand cooking food thoroughly and keeping uncooked meats apart from\nvegetables and other foods. Eating listeria-contaminated food results in flulike symptoms, which\nmay not show up for 10 weeks, including fever, muscle aches, and\ndiarrhea in otherwise healthy people. Although the bacteria should be killed during processing by food\nmanufacturers, it has been found to survive in some ready-to-eat\nmeats. New York City Health Department\nofficials said 20 percent of those who have compromised immune\nsystems typically die if they contract listeriosis. Refrigerated smoked seafood, such\nas salmon, trout, whitefish, cod, tuna or mackerel, is most often\nlabeled as 'nova-style,' 'lox,' 'kippered,' 'smoked,' or 'jerky.' Healthy\nindividuals may suffer only short-term symptoms such as high fever,\nsevere headache, stiffness, nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhea. New Jersey health officials have reported 4 listeria-related deaths\namong elderly people [see ProMED posting 20020915.5323 -Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-09-17 00:00:00", "2002-05-26 00:00:00", "2002-09-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City Health Department", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202622", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202622", "date": "2002-09-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (04)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 20:30:50 +0100\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@virgin.net>\nSource: NJ.com [edited]\n<http://www.nj.com/news/ledger/jersey/index.ssf?/base/news-2/1033118135130310..xml>\n\nListeria outbreak now at 20 cases: source remains unknown\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThe number of cases of a foodborne illness that has killed 5 state\nresidents has risen to 20, New Jersey health authorities said.\nInvestigators remained unable to pinpoint the source of the sickness that\nhas also struck people in 7 other states. Besides New Jersey, cases have\nbeen reported in Pennsylvania, New York, Delaware, Connecticut, Maryland,\nMichigan, and Ohio. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\nhave isolated and matched the strain of bacteria in 31 patients from 5 of\nthe 7 other states, suggesting that these patients acquired the illness\nfrom eating the same food.\nFive of New Jersey's 20 cases have been conclusively linked to the strain\nof listeria identified from the outbreak, said Eddy Bresnitz,\nepidemiologist with the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior\nServices. Some 20 to 30 cases are usually reported in New Jersey every\nyear. Throughout the United States, there are an estimated 2500 cases of\nlisteriosis a year, with about 500 reported deaths.\nBresnitz said patients have been filling out detailed questionnaires about\ntheir eating habits going back at least 4 weeks before they fell ill. 'This\nis like detective work on a national level, finding out what the affected\npeople ate, when they ate it, what brand, and then looking for the\ncommonality and then testing the food and people,' said Thomas Montville,\nprofessor of food science at Rutgers' Cook College in New Brunswick.\nIn New Jersey, the illness has claimed the life of a person in Burlington\nCounty, 1 in Gloucester, another in Mercer, and 2 people in Bergen County,\nstate health department officials said. Of the 20 cases detected so far in\nNew Jersey, the youngest person has been 56 and the oldest 82. The latest\nperson to take ill reported symptoms that started on 18 Sep 2002, Bresnitz\nsaid. None of the victims has been identified. So far 5 other people also\nhave died, in New York City, Pennsylvania, and Michigan.\nThose at higher risk of getting listeriosis include the elderly, pregnant\nwomen, newborns, and adults with weakened immune systems, such as those\nwith terminal cancer or AIDS. Bresnitz said 4 of the New Jersey cases were\npregnant women, none of whom died. Many of the other cases were people with\nunderlying medical problems, he said.\nLinda Doughtery, vice president of the New Jersey Food Council, said her\nagency is among those looking to 'raise the bar' on food handling in the\nindustry. 'We are on the front line of offering training for food handlers\nin New Jersey to upgrade their skills,' she said. 'It is a priority not\njust for the industry, but for the consumer.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n This\nis like detective work on a national level, finding out what the affected\npeople ate, when they ate it, what brand, and then looking for the\ncommonality and then testing the food and people,' said Thomas Montville,\nprofessor of food science at Rutgers' Cook College in New Brunswick.
