' Investigators remained unable to pinpoint the source of the sickness that\nhas also struck people in 7 other states.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-09-18 00:00:00", "2002-09-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucester", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burlington \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bergen County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mercer", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202540", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (multistate)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202540", "date": "2002-09-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 14 Sep 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Star Ledger, Sat 14 Sep 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.nj.com/news/ledger/index.ssf?/base/news-2/103199462959344.xml>\n\nNew Jersey has joined a federal investigation into the source of a\nfood-borne illness that may be linked to the recent deaths of 4 elderly\npeople in the state, Health and Senior Services Commissioner Clifton R.\nLacy announced.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta reports a\nspecific strain of listeria -- a type of bacteria found in uncooked or\ntainted foods that causes the disease listeriosis -- has sickened 16 people\nin Pennsylvania, New York, Maryland, Michigan, and Connecticut, Lacy said.\n[ProMED-mail posted cases in Pennsylvania earlier this month -\n20020901.5205 - Mod.LL]\nThere have been 11 cases of listeriosis reported in New Jersey since June\n2002, including the 4 deaths, but it is unclear whether those cases are\nlinked to the ones in the other states. 'Further laboratory analysis is\nbeing conducted to determine if the cases were caused by the same strain of\nlisteria,' Lacy said.\nThe illness claimed the lives of 2 elderly people in Burlington County, 1\nin Gloucester, and another in Mercer since June 2002, according to the\nhealth department.\nThose at the highest risk of contracting the disease include the elderly,\npregnant women, newborns, and people with weakened immune systems. Symptoms\ninclude fever, muscle aches, and sometimes nausea and diarrhea.\nSome 20 to 30 cases are reported in New Jersey every year. In the USA, an\nestimated 2500 persons become seriously ill with listeriosis each year. Of\nthese, 500 die, according to the CDC Web site.\nThe bacterium has been found in a variety of raw foods, such as uncooked\nmeats and vegetables, as well as in processed foods that become\ncontaminated after processing, such as soft cheeses and cold cuts at the\ndeli counter, according to the CDC Web site.\nPeople can avoid the illness by thoroughly cooking ready-to eat meats, like\nhot dogs, and avoiding soft cheeses like Brie and feta and unpasteurized\nmilk, state epidemiologist Eddy Bresnitz said. The disease is not contagious.\nAdditional information can be obtained at the CDC's Web site:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>\n[Byline: Susan K. Livio]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta reports a\nspecific strain of listeria -- a type of bacteria found in uncooked or\ntainted foods that causes the disease listeriosis -- has sickened 16 people\nin Pennsylvania, New York, Maryland, Michigan, and Connecticut, Lacy said. Further laboratory analysis is\nbeing conducted to determine if the cases were caused by the same strain of\nlisteria,' Lacy said. Additional information can be obtained at the CDC's Web site:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-26 00:00:00", "2002-09-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Burlington County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mercer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2199144", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199144", "date": "2000-12-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FOODBORNE, TURKEY PRODUCTS - USA (02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2199110", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199110", "date": "2000-12-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FOODBORNE, TURKEY PRODUCTS - USA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nProMED-mail, a program of ISID\n<http://www.promedmail.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2202459", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202459", "date": "2002-09-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (PENNSYLVANIA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 30 Aug 2002 21:13:43 -0400\nFrom: Jerry Zuckerman <zuckermj@einstein.edu>\nSource: Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Health Department Press Release\n\n\nFOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:\nHEALTH DEPARTMENT ANNOUNCES INVESTIGATION OF LISTERIA INFECTIONS\n\nState Health Secretary Robert S. Zimmerman Jr. today announced that his\ndepartment and the Philadelphia Department of Health are conducting an\ninvestigation into cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that have occurred in\nJuly and August 2002 in the western and southeastern parts of the\nCommonwealth. The infection occurs when people eat contaminated food\nproducts.\n\nTo date, a total of 20 cases have been reported throughout Pennsylvania (7\nin Philadelphia residents); 2 of the 20 people have died.\n\n'While Listeria can be dangerous for some, most people who are exposed will\nexperience minor, if any, symptoms,' Secretary Zimmerman said. 'Taking\nsimple, common-sense approaches to food handling and preparation can prevent\nthe spread of the bacteria. These include washing and cooking food\nthoroughly; keeping uncooked food separate from cooked foods; and washing\nhands, knives, and other food preparation items.'\n\nAn epidemiological and laboratory investigation into these cases is ongoing.\nAt this time, no specific food product has been identified as a cause for\nthe infections. Laboratory specimens from cases are being collected and\nforwarded to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for further\ntesting.\n\nListeria is an infrequent cause of illness and death in the very young and\nthe very old. It is most frequently contracted through eating contaminated\nfood products. Pregnant women in particular can become infected and spread\nthe infection to their newborns, who then experience severe symptoms such as\nmeningitis.\n\nListeria bacteria are found in soil and water. Vegetables can become\ncontaminated from the soil or from manure used as fertilizer. Listeria has\nbeen found in a variety of raw foods, such as uncooked meats and vegetables,\nas well as in processed foods that become contaminated after processing,\nsuch as soft cheeses and cold cuts at the deli counter. Unpasteurized (raw)\nmilk or foods made from unpasteurized milk also may contain the bacterium.\n\nNationally, an estimated 2500 people become seriously ill with Listeria each\nyear. In Pennsylvania, fewer than 2 dozen cases are reported in most years.\nHowever, Listeria infection only became a reportable disease statewide this\nyear [2002]. Now that reporting is mandatory, those numbers may increase in\nfuture years.\n\nInvestigation of Listeria infection can be difficult because symptoms can\nsurface anywhere from a few days to more than 2 months after a person eats\ncontaminated food. Fortunately, most people who eat foods containing\nListeria bacteria do not become ill.\n\nPeople who develop Listeria infection may experience a range of symptoms\nincluding fever, muscle aches and gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea\nor diarrhea. If infection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as\nheadache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance or convulsions can occur.\n\nPregnant women are at increased risk for Listeria infection compared to\nother healthy adults. About one-third of Listeria cases happen during\npregnancy. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like\nillness; however, infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery,\ninfection of the newborn, or even stillbirth. There is no routine screening\ntest for susceptibility to [infection with?] Listeria during pregnancy.\n\n--\nJerry Zuckerman, MD\nHospital Epidemiologist\nAlbert Einstein Medical Center\nPhiladelphia, PA\n<zuckermj@einstein.edu>\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Sat, 31 Aug 2002 12:30:31 +0100\nFrom: 'Pablo Nart' <p.nart@virgin.net>\nSource: KYW news radio 1060, 31st August 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.kyw1060.com/news_story_detail.cfm?newsitemid=23558>\n\n\nPhiladelphia health officials are warning about an outbreak in Pennsylvania\nof a food-borne illness that has already claimed two lives.\n\nOfficials say in the past 2 months 22 cases of the bacterium Listeria have\noccurred throughout the state, including 7 in Philadelphia; 2 of the 22\ndied, though neither fatality was in the city. The ages of those struck by\nListeria range from newborn to 98 years. None of the cases appears related.\n\n--\nPablo Nart\n<p.nart@virgin.net>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n State Health Secretary Robert S. Zimmerman Jr. today announced that his\ndepartment and the Philadelphia Department of Health are conducting an\ninvestigation into cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ that have occurred in\nJuly and August 2002 in the western and southeastern parts of the\nCommonwealth. Listeria has\nbeen found in a variety of raw foods, such as uncooked meats and vegetables,\nas well as in processed foods that become contaminated after processing,\nsuch as soft cheeses and cold cuts at the deli counter. Albert Einstein Medical Center\nPhiladelphia, PA\n<zuckermj@einstein.edu>\n\n*****\n \nJerry Zuckerman, MD\nHospital Epidemiologist\n \n\nInvestigation of Listeria infection can be difficult because symptoms can\nsurface anywhere from a few days to more than 2 months after a person eats\ncontaminated food. \n\nPeople who develop Listeria infection may experience a range of symptoms\nincluding fever, muscle aches and gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea\nor diarrhea. These include washing and cooking food\nthoroughly; keeping uncooked food separate from cooked foods; and washing\nhands, knives, and other food preparation items.' Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like\nillness; however, infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery,\ninfection of the newborn, or even stillbirth. Officials say in the past 2 months 22 cases of the bacterium Listeria have\noccurred throughout the state, including 7 in Philadelphia; 2 of the 22\ndied, though neither fatality was in the city. Source: KYW news radio 1060, 31st August 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.kyw1060.com/news_story_detail.cfm?newsitemid=23558>\n\n\nPhiladelphia health officials are warning about an outbreak in Pennsylvania\nof a food-borne illness that has already claimed two lives. Pregnant women in particular can become infected and spread\nthe infection to their newborns, who then experience severe symptoms such as\nmeningitis. Taking\nsimple, common-sense approaches to food handling and preparation can prevent\nthe spread of the bacteria. \n\n--\nPablo Nart\n<p.nart@virgin.net> Laboratory specimens from cases are being collected and\nforwarded to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for further\ntesting. LISTERIOSIS - USA (PENNSYLVANIA)\n********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-07-26 00:00:00", "2002-03-26 00:00:00", "1060-03-26 00:00:00", "2002-08-31 00:00:00", "2002-08-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202559", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (Multistate) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202559", "date": "2002-09-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (03)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 01:59:55 EDT\nFrom: John L. Hyde <Jlhdvm@aol.com>\n\nIn ProMED Digest Tue 17 Sep 2002 Volume 2002: Number 257,\nListeriosis - USA (Multistate) (02) (posting 20020917.5334),the\nfollowing statement appears as one of the recommendations [from the\nFDA news release - Mod.LL] under 'People at risk for listeriosis and\ntheir family members or individuals preparing food for them should\ntake the following precautions:\n'Do not drink raw (unpasteurized) milk or eat foods that contain\nunpasteurized milk.'\nThis implies that pasteurization inactivates _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nWhile it is true that many organisms are killed during regular\npasteurization, not all are. Pasteurization inactivates tubercle\nbacilli and was [originally - Mod.LL] the major reason for using it\nto process milk. It does not result in sterile milk. An unopened\ncontainer of regular pasteurized milk placed in the refrigerator for\nabout 5-7 days will show this.\nPerhaps some are mistaking regular pasteurization with 'Ultra high\ntemperature (UHT) Processing Method' which, when properly done,\nresults in sterile milk which can be kept at room temperatures for\nweeks and even months.\nWith the increased numbers of individuals with compromised immune\nsystems, it would seem prudent that all liquid milk for human\nconsumption be required by Public Heath Law to be 'Ultra High\nTemperature (UHT) Processed'.\nBergey's Manual addresses strains of Listeria that survive regular\npasteurization or high temperature-short time (HTST) processing.\n--\nJohn L. Hyde, DVM, MS\nUSDA/ ARS/ 'Retired'\nIthaca NY\n<Jlhdvm@aol.com>\n[ProMED-mail agrees with Dr. Hyde that pasteurization is not\nequivalent to sterilization. Certainly, raw or inadequately\npasteurized milk can be a vehicle for a variety of pathogens\nincluding species of salmonella, listeria, brucella, and yersinia as\nwell as _E. coli_ (1). It is also the case that _L. monocytogenes_\nis considered to be more heat-resistant than many other bacterial\npathogens. However, it appears that the pasteurization process is\nadequate to kill _L. monocytogenes_ (2). This reference from the CDC\nsummarizes the information is this regard and is reprinted below.\nHowever, even if a large inoculum were present and some organisms\nsurvived the process, pasteurized milk and cream products are\nrefrigerated and have a short shelf life, so that any\ncold-temperature replication (which can occur with this pathogen) is\nnot likely to produce an adequate inoculum.\nBe that as it may, Fleming, et al. (citation 6 in the CDC reference)\ndid report an outbreak of listeriosis in Massachusetts in 1983 for\nwhich, despite no evidence of improper pasteurization in the plant,\npasteurized milk was implicated epidemiologically (no pasteurized\nmilk cultures were positive) as the source, albeit a 'distinctly\nuncommon one.' Despite the rarity of cases of human listeriosis\nlinked to pasteurized milk, researchers in Spain (3) and Turkey (4)\nhave reported pasteurized milk samples from which Listeria was\nisolated.\nOne cannot argue with Dr. Hyde's suggestion that all milk for human\nconsumption should be ultrapasteurized. It may be even more prudent\nfor the recommendation to be made that for individuals at substantial\nrisk for morbidity and mortality from this infection, such as the\ncellularly immunocompromised person (i.e., organ transplant\nrecipients, those receiving chemotherapy or corticosteroids) or the\npregnant woman consume only ultrapasteurized milk products.\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Salmonellosis from\ninadequately pasteurized milk -Kentucky. MMWR 1984; 33: 505-506.\n2. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Epidemiologic notes\nand reports update - Listeriosis and pasteurized milk. MMWR 1988;\n37:764-766.\n3. Fernandez Garayzabal JF, Dominguez Rodriguez L, Vazquez Boland JA,\net al: Listeria monocytogenes in pasteurized milk. Can J Microbiol\n1986; 32: 149-150.\n4. Ahrabi SS, Erguven S, Gunalp A: Detection of Listeria in raw and\npasteurized milk. Cent Eur J Public Health 1998; 6: 254-255\nEpidemiologic Notes and Reports Update -- Listeriosis and Pasteurized Milk\n(MMWR 1988; 37: 764-766)\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ can be cultured from approximately 5 percent\nof raw (unpasteurized) milk samples, and case reports have shown that\ndisease in humans can be caused by consumption of unpasteurized\ncontaminated milk (1-4). Other reports suggesting that _L.\nmonocytogenes_ is relatively resistant to heat have raised concern\nabout the effectiveness of pasteurization for eliminating this\norganism from milk (1, 5).\nIn an outbreak of listeriosis that occurred in Massachusetts in 1983,\npasteurized whole or 2 percent milk was implicated as the source of\ninfection (6). An inspection of the milk-producing plant detected no\napparent breach in the pasteurization process, thereby prompting\nfurther interest in the effectiveness of pasteurization. Since then,\nseveral studies have shown that _L. monocytogenes_ is inactivated by\nstandard pasteurization practices (4, 7-10). This report summarizes\ninformation regarding the effectiveness of pasteurization in\neliminating _L. monocytogenes_ from milk.\nCurrent state and local regulations throughout the United States\nspecify time and temperature conditions for pasteurization. These\nregulations call for milk to be heated to at least 71.7 C for 15\nseconds (i.e., high-temperature short-time (HTST) process) or to 62.8\nC for 30 minutes (11). In one study using milk artificially\ninoculated with _L. monocytogenes_, investigators found that 0.9\nseconds at 71.7 C is needed for each one log10 reduction in the\nnumber of _L. monocytogenes_ organisms (7). Other studies of\nartificially inoculated milk have concluded that at the same\ntemperature, a period of 2.75 to 3.1 seconds is needed for each log10\nreduction (4). Since the concentration of _L. monocytogenes_ likely\nto be present in contaminated raw milk is estimated to be\napproximately 10 organisms per mL, these data suggest that there is a\nsubstantial margin of safety in the HTST pasteurization process (4).\nAnother study found that at 62 C, each log10 reduction in the number\nof surviving _L. monocytogenes_ organisms could be achieved in 6 to\n20 seconds, well within the 30 minutes required for pasteurization at\nthis temperature (8). Other investigators also have concluded that\n_L. monocytogenes_ will not survive the normal milk pasteurization\nprocess (9) and have questioned previously reported methods that\nsuggested _L. monocytogenes_ could survive pasteurization (8,9).\nIn a pasteurization study designed to simulate the natural situation\nmore closely, milk from cows that had been purposefully infected with\n_L. monocytogenes_ was used, along with several different _L.\nmonocytogenes_ isolation procedures (12). Viable _L. monocytogenes_\ncould be recovered after minimum HTST treatment (71.7 C for 15\nseconds), although not after treatment at 76.4 C-77.8 C for 15\nseconds. This survival was attributed in part to protection of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ within leukocytes in milk (intracellular _L.\nmonocytogenes_ organisms are found in milk from infected cows but not\nin artificially inoculated milk). Because this milk had L.\nmonocytogenes concentrations of 103 to 104 per mL, higher\nconcentrations than are usually found when _L. monocytogenes_ is\npresent in raw milk, these findings may not be applicable to usual\nproduction conditions. In another study in which investigators\nidentified cows that had been naturally infected with _L.\nmonocytogenes_ (10), proper pasteurization was found to inactivate\n_L. monocytogenes_ in milk contaminated through natural infection as\nwell as in artificially inoculated milk.\nAfter reviewing these studies, a World Health Organization Working\nGroup on foodborne listeriosis recently concluded that\n'pasteurization is a safe process which reduces the number of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ occurring in raw milk to levels that do not pose an\nappreciable risk to human health' (4).\nReported by: Milk Safety Br, Div of Cooperative Programs, Center for\nFood Safety and Applied Nutrition, Food and Drug Administration.\nMeningitis and Special Pathogens Br, Div of Bacterial Diseases,\nCenter for Infectious Diseases, CDC.\nEditorial Note: Improperly performed pasteurization and the\noccurrence of contamination after pasteurization are the most likely\nexplanations for the presence of _L. monocytogenes_ in pasteurized\nmilk. In a survey conducted during 1987 and 1988 as part of the Food\nand Drug Administration's (FDA's) Dairy Product Safety Initiatives, 2\npercent of pasteurized milk samples from more than 700 U.S.\nmilk-producing plants were culture-positive for Listeria species,\nprimarily _L. monocytogenes_, (13). Even when pasteurized milk is\nproven to be contaminated by bacteria, the exact source and mode of\ncontamination may be difficult to identify. For example, in a recent\nlarge epidemic of salmonellosis in Illinois, the epidemic strain of\n_Salmonella typhimurium_ was isolated from patients and the\nimplicated pasteurized milk products they had drunk (14). However, an\ninspection of the plant by a task force of FDA officials and other\nexperts could not prove how the milk was contaminated. Efforts to\nensure that milk is safe from _L. monocytogenes_ contamination should\nfocus on promoting proper methods of pasteurization and on\nidentifying and eliminating sources of postpasteurization\ncontamination.\n1. Bryan FL. Listeria monocytogenes. In: Riemann H, Bryan FL, eds.\nFood-borne infections and intoxications. 2nd ed. New York: Academic\nPress, 1979:266-8.\n2. Lovett J, Francis DW, Hunt JM. Listeria monocytogenes in raw milk:\ndetection, incidence, and pathogenicity. J Food Protection\n1987;50:188-92.\n3. Hayes PS, Feeley JC, Graves LM, Ajello GW, Fleming DW. Isolation\nof Listeria monocytogenes from raw milk. Appl Environ Microbiol\n1986;51:438-40.\n4. WHO Working Group. Foodborne listeriosis. Bull WHO 1988;66:421-8.\n5. Bearns RE, Girard KF. The effect of pasteurization on Listeria\nmonocytogenes. Can J Microbiol 1958;4:55-61.\n6. Fleming DW, Cochi SL, MacDonald KL, et al. Pasteurized milk as a\nvehicle of infection in an outbreak of listeriosis. N Engl J Med\n1985;312:404-7.\n7. Bradshaw JG, Peeler JT, Corwin JJ, et al. Thermal resistance of\nListeria monocytogenes in milk. J Food Protection 1985;48:743-5.\n8. Donnelly CW, Briggs EH, Donnelly LS. Comparison of heat resistance\nof Listeria monocytogenes in milk as determined by two methods. J\nFood Protection 1987;50:14-7.\n9. Beckers HJ, Soentoro PSS, Delfgou-van Asch EHM. The occurrence of\nListeria monocytogenes in soft cheeses and raw milk and its\nresistance to heat. Intl J Food Microbiol 1987;4:249-56.\n10. Farber JM, Sanders GW, Emmons DB, McKellar RC. Heat resistance of\nListeria monocytogenes in artificially-inoculated and\nnaturally-contaminated raw milk (Abstract). J Food Protection\n1987;50:893.\n11. Food and Drug Administration. Grade A pasteurized milk ordinance.\nWashington, DC: US Department of Health and Human Services, Public\nHealth Service, 1985; FDA publication no. 229.\n12. Doyle MP, Glass KA, Beery JT, Garcia GA, Pollard DJ, Schultz RD.\nSurvival of Listeria monocytogenes in milk during high-temperature,\nshort-timepasteurization. Appl Environ Microbiol 1987;53:1433-8.\n13. Food and Drug Administration. FDA's dairy product safety\ninitiatives: 2nd year status report to the states. Washington, DC: US\nDepartment of Health and Human Services, Public Health Service, 1988.\n14. Ryan CA, Nickels MK, Hargrett-Bean NT, et al. Massive outbreak of\nantimicrobial-resistant salmonellosis traced to pasteurized milk.\nJAMA 1987;258:3269-74.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "Cent Eur J Public Health 1998; 6: 254-255\nEpidemiologic Notes and Reports Update -- Listeriosis and Pasteurized Milk\n(MMWR 1988; 37: 764-766)\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ can be cultured from approximately 5 percent\nof raw (unpasteurized) milk samples, and case reports have shown that\ndisease in humans can be caused by consumption of unpasteurized\ncontaminated milk (1-4). (citation 6 in the CDC reference)\ndid report an outbreak of listeriosis in Massachusetts in 1983 for\nwhich, despite no evidence of improper pasteurization in the plant,\npasteurized milk was implicated epidemiologically (no pasteurized\nmilk cultures were positive) as the source, albeit a 'distinctly\nuncommon one.' However, even if a large inoculum were present and some organisms\nsurvived the process, pasteurized milk and cream products are\nrefrigerated and have a short shelf life, so that any\ncold-temperature replication (which can occur with this pathogen) is\nnot likely to produce an adequate inoculum.\n It may be even more prudent\nfor the recommendation to be made that for individuals at substantial\nrisk for morbidity and mortality from this infection, such as the\ncellularly immunocompromised person (i.e., organ transplant\nrecipients, those receiving chemotherapy or corticosteroids) or the\npregnant woman consume only ultrapasteurized milk products. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n After reviewing these studies, a World Health Organization Working\nGroup on foodborne listeriosis recently concluded that\n'pasteurization is a safe process which reduces the number of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ occurring in raw milk to levels that do not pose an\nappreciable risk to human health' (4). \nEditorial Note: Improperly performed pasteurization and the\noccurrence of contamination after pasteurization are the most likely\nexplanations for the presence of _L. monocytogenes_ in pasteurized\nmilk. Other reports suggesting that _L.\nmonocytogenes_ is relatively resistant to heat have raised concern\nabout the effectiveness of pasteurization for eliminating this\norganism from milk (1, 5). Another study found that at 62 C, each log10 reduction in the number\nof surviving _L. monocytogenes_ organisms could be achieved in 6 to\n20 seconds, well within the 30 minutes required for pasteurization at\nthis temperature (8). These\nregulations call for milk to be heated to at least 71.7 C for 15\nseconds (i.e., high-temperature short-time (HTST) process) or to 62.8\nC for 30 minutes (11). Perhaps some are mistaking regular pasteurization with 'Ultra high\ntemperature (UHT) Processing Method' which, when properly done,\nresults in sterile milk which can be kept at room temperatures for\nweeks and even months. Tue 17 Sep 2002 Volume 2002: Number 257,\nListeriosis - USA (Multistate) (02) (posting 20020917.5334),the\nfollowing statement appears as one of the recommendations [from the\nFDA news release - Mod. --\nJohn L. Hyde, DVM, MS\nUSDA/ ARS/ 'Retired'\n Heat resistance of\nListeria monocytogenes in artificially-inoculated and\nnaturally-contaminated raw milk (Abstract). This report summarizes\ninformation regarding the effectiveness of pasteurization in\neliminating _L. monocytogenes_ from milk. An inspection of the milk-producing plant detected no\napparent breach in the pasteurization process, thereby prompting\nfurther interest in the effectiveness of pasteurization. An unopened\ncontainer of regular pasteurized milk placed in the refrigerator for\nabout 5-7 days will show this. Since then,\nseveral studies have shown that _L. monocytogenes_ is inactivated by\nstandard pasteurization practices (4, 7-10). Survival of Listeria monocytogenes in milk during high-temperature,\nshort-timepasteurization. Listeria monocytogenes in raw milk:\ndetection, incidence, and pathogenicity. USA (Arkansas & Ohio)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194996", "date": "1999-01-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MEAT RECALLS - USA (ARKANSAS & OHIO)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/ahead>\nDate: Sat, 23 Jan 1999 09:25:25 -0800\nFrom: James Chin, CDPC-mail <jchin@cwix.com>\nSource: Nando Net, 23 Jan 1999\n\nTwo more companies voluntarily recalled meat Friday after deadly _Listeria_\nbacteria, which recently killed 11 people, were reportedly found in their\nproducts. The action raises to four the number of companies recalling their\nmeat out of concern for _Listeria_ over the past month. In one case\ninvolving meat produced by Bil Mar Foods, a division of Sara Lee Corp, at\nleast 11 people died and three women had miscarriages, according to the\nCentres for Disease Control. Agriculture Department officials said there\nwas no evidence to link the cases. No illnesses have been reported in\nconnection with the new recalls, officials said.\nOn Friday, Thorn Apple Valley Inc. recalled hot dogs and luncheon kits\nproduced over six months at its Forrest City, Ark., plant after government\ntests discovered _Listeria_ bacteria in meat produced by the Southfield,\nMich.-based company. Recalled products include 'EST 13529' and 'EST\nP-13529' on the packaging. Thorn Apple Valley is recalling products\nproduced from July 6 through Dec. 30 that were sold nationwide by a variety\nof companies and packaged under different names, including Kroger and\nSafeway grocery stores. The products were also sold to companies in South\nKorea and in Russia, the department said. Agriculture Department and\ncompany officials said they did not know the quantity of meat that was\nbeing recalled in the case, but some said that due to the broad range of\nproduction dates, the amount was sure to be big.\n>From July to December, the Agriculture Department said tests found\n_Listeria_ in five out of 20 ready-to-eat product samples it collected.\n'Based on these repetitive findings, as well as conditions found in the\nplant, the agency concluded that there may be a significant public health\nrisk associated with the product being recalled,' the department said in a\nstatement. The Agriculture Department withdrew its meat inspectors from the\nForrest City plant on Dec. 31, effectively shutting it down after the\ncompany did not comply with 'sanitation requirements,' the USDA said. The\nplant remains closed.\nIn the second case announced Friday, Bosell Foods, Inc., of Cleveland\nrecalled 350 pounds -- a tiny amount by meat production standards -- of\nsliced ham. The meat was only distributed in the Cleveland area, the USDA\nsaid. Involved in the recall are half-pound packages of the 'Dinner Bell'\nVirginia Brand Cooked Ham, Water Added, with sell-by code 2-18-1999.\nPackages are marked with EST 2587 in the USDA seal.\nA week ago, Oscar Mayer Foods, a unit of Philip Morris Cos. , voluntarily\nrecalled two types of luncheon meat after an elderly man in Kansas City,\nMo., became sick after eating the company's deli meat. Agriculture\nDepartment tests discovered _Listeria_ bacteria in samples of the meat. Bil\nMar's voluntary nationwide recall began a month ago and company officials\nsaid they expected to retrieve approximately 15 million pounds of meat. The\ncompany Wednesday took out full-page advertisements in 60 U.S. newspapers\nto apologize to customers...\nConsumers with questions can call the Agriculture Department's Meat and\nPoultry hotline, 800-535-4555, Thorn Apple Valley, 800-316-2855, or Bosell\nFoods, Inc., 216-911-7600.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Canada: background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194663", "date": "1998-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - CANADA: BACKGROUND\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192869", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, risk assessment using mouse model (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192869", "date": "1998-03-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, RISK ASSESSMENT USING MOUSE MODEL (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192549", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192549", "date": "1998-01-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, CONTAMINATED FISH - SWEDEN: 1994/95 (02)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192889", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, risk assessment using mouse model (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192889", "date": "1998-03-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, RISK ASSESSMENT USING MOUSE MODEL (03)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2192862", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, risk assessment using mouse model", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192862", "date": "1998-03-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, RISK ASSESSMENT USING MOUSE MODEL\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Fri, 6 Mar 1998 12:33:03 -0400 (AST)\nFrom: Dr. Michael Meredith <meredith@farmline.com>\nSource: epivet-l@upei.ca\n\nSTUDIES ON THE RISK ASSESSMENT OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES\nJournal Of Food Protection 61: 244-248, Feb. 1998\nS. NOTERMANS, J. DUFRENNE, P. TEUNIS,2 AND T. CHACKRABORTY\nABSTRACT\nHumans are frequently exposed to _Listeria monocytogenes_, and high numbers\nmay be ingested during consumption of certain types of food. However,\nepidemiological investigations show that listeriosis is a rare disease.\nRisk assessment studies using an animal mouse model indicate that almost all\n_L. monocytogenes_ serovars present in food have clear virulent properties.\nThe intravenous dose causing infection in 50% (IV ID50) of mice not\npreviously exposed to _L. monocytogenes_ (non protected mice) was 1.8 log10\nunits. For mice previously exposed to _L. monocytogenes_ (immunologically\nprotected mice), the IV ID50 was 5.6 log10 units. The ID50 of orally exposed\nnon protected mice amounted to 6.5 log10 units. And no significant effects of\ntype of food (water/milk) and storage time at 5C (milk) were observed. The\noral ID50 of immunologically protected mice was >9.0 log10 units.\nFurthermore, there was approximately 1-2 log10 difference between the ID50\nand the lethal dose causing death in 50% (LD50).\nThe results show that both the intestinal barrier and the specific immune\ndefense mechanism are highly effective in preventing infection of mice\norally exposed to _L. monocytogenes_. Delaying the immune defense had no\neffect on the protective activity of the intestinal barrier, indicating that\nthese protective mechanisms operate independently. The risk assessment\nresults obtained in the mouse model support the epidemiological finding that\nlisteriosis is a rare disease in humans, despite frequent exposure to the\norganism.\n--\nDr. Michael Meredith, M.A., B.Sc., B.Vet.Med., Ph.D., MRCVS\nPig Disease Information Centre Ltd.\nM.D.'s Electronic mail: meredith@farmline.com\ne-mail: pdic@btinternet.com\n[This interesting paper goes part of the way to describe why this disease is\nessentially seen only in children, the elderly, and pregnant women. - Mod.MHJ]\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n The risk assessment\nresults obtained in the mouse model support the epidemiological finding that\nlisteriosis is a rare disease in humans, despite frequent exposure to the\norganism.\n The intravenous dose causing infection in 50% (IV ID50) of mice not\npreviously exposed to _L. monocytogenes_ (non protected mice) was 1.8 log10\nunits. The results show that both the intestinal barrier and the specific immune\ndefense mechanism are highly effective in preventing infection of mice\norally exposed to _L. monocytogenes_. The\noral ID50 of immunologically protected mice was >9.0 log10 units.\n Source: epivet-l@upei.ca\n\nSTUDIES ON THE RISK ASSESSMENT OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES\nJournal Of Food Protection 61: 244-248, Feb. 1998\n Delaying the immune defense had no\neffect on the protective activity of the intestinal barrier, indicating that\nthese protective mechanisms operate independently. A ProMED-mail post\nDate: Fri, 6 Mar 1998 12:33:03 -0400 (AST)\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: For mice previously exposed to _L. monocytogenes_ (immunologically\nprotected mice), the IV ID50 was 5.6 log10 units. The ID50 of orally exposed\nnon protected mice amounted to 6.5 log10 units. Risk assessment studies using an animal mouse model indicate that almost all\n_L. monocytogenes_ serovars present in food have clear virulent properties. Humans are frequently exposed to _Listeria monocytogenes_, and high numbers\nmay be ingested during consumption of certain types of food. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-02-26 00:00:00", "1998-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "M.A.", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192541", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192541", "date": "1998-01-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, CONTAMINATED FISH - SWEDEN: 1994/95\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2194812", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, multifocal - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194812", "date": "1998-12-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MULTIFOCAL - USA\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Fri, 18 Dec 1998 10:05:39 -0800\nFrom: Dr. James Chin, CDPC-mail <jchin@cwix.com>\nSource: Nando net, December 18, 1998\n\nFederal health officials are looking at an outbreak of food poisoning from\n_Listeria_ that has sickened more than 35 people in nine states and killed\nfour. The prime suspects are hot dogs and cold cuts, the federal Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention confirmed Thursday. Neither the CDC nor\nofficials at the Agriculture Department, in charge of meat safety, would\nconfirm which brands or manufacturer were under suspicion in the continuing\ninvestigation. But the CDC said people at the greatest risk from food\npoisoning -- pregnant women, the elderly and people with weak immune\nsystems -- should take precautions. 'If they want to reduce their risk,\nthey should avoid those foods or thoroughly reheat their cold cuts before\neating them,' CDC spokesman Tom Skinner said.\nBil Mar Foods in Zeeland, Mich., a division of Sara Lee, is cooperating\nwith government investigators, but at this time cannot say if a number of\nbrands of meat products packaged there are the source of the _Listeria_,\nsaid Sara Lee spokesman Jeffrey Smith. 'We would need to know that there is\na connection between the sources of _Listeria_ and this product' before\ndeciding whether to recall any foods, Smith said. 'The safety of our\nconsumers is of the utmost importance to us and ... as more information\nbecomes available, we'll provide it.' Genetic fingerprinting of the\nbacterium helped health officials link the cases, and they suspect hot dogs\nand cold cuts because those are foods the patients have in common.\nThe CDC expects laboratory test results from products within two days that\ncould determine the brands involved, Skinner said. Agriculture officials\nthen would determine if any recalls are required. He said that while the\nlast known patient became ill in late November, 'if there still is\ncontaminated product out there, we might see more cases.' _Listeria_ is a\nbacterium that healthy people often fight off with no more than flu-like\nsymptoms. But it also can kill through meningitis or blood infection. It's\nespecially dangerous during pregnancy, when bacteria passed to the fetus\ncan cause miscarriage or stillbirth even if the mother has no symptoms.\nCases are under investigation in Ohio, New York, Tennessee, Massachusetts,\nMichigan, West Virginia, Connecticut, Oregon and Vermont.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The safety of our\nconsumers is of the utmost importance to us and ... as more information\nbecomes available, we'll provide it.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-26 00:00:00", "1998-12-18 00:00:00", "2021-04-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeeland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mich.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vermont", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Virginia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202097", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, sausage - France (multidepartment)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202097", "date": "2002-07-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SAUSAGE - FRANCE (MULTIDEPARTMENT)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 4 Jul 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6(27): 020704 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020704.html>\n\nCluster of listeriosis cases in France\n--------------------------------------\nA cluster of 8 cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection with the same\nserotype and pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) profile has been\nidentified by the surveillance scheme operated by the Institut de Veille\nSanitaire (National Institute for Health Surveillance) and the National\nListeria Reference Center at the Institut Pasteur, Paris, since 29 May 2002.\nThe first 2 strains were isolated in week 22 (27 May-2 June), 2 more were\nisolated in week 23 (3-9 June), and 4 were isolated in week 24 (10-16\nJune). Seven of these 8 patients presented with infection of the central\nnervous system and 1 with bacteremia; 5 patients had underlying medical\nconditions or were being treated with immunosuppressants, and so were at\nrisk for listeriosis. One of these 5 patients has died. Five of the 8 cases\nwere from 2 departments (Moselle and Bas-Rhin) in eastern France, and the\nothers are in 3 different departments [see map of cases on the\nEurosurveillance Weekly website - Mod.MPP].\nThe coordinating committee for listeria investigations was mobilized to\ncoordinate investigations, which included the obtaining of food histories\nof cases, the analysis of the supply channels of products on sale in shops\nwhere the patients had bought food in order to identify common suppliers,\nsampling of foods from these shops and from the patients' refrigerators,\nand screening for the epidemic clone among strains isolated from food\nproducts in France since January 2002. German health authorities have been\ninformed and asked to identify any cases that could possibly be linked to\nthis outbreak close to the German border.\nThe main vehicle for transmission has been identified as spreadable\nsausage, a ready-to-eat food prepared from raw pork and fat. Among its\ncollection of strains isolated from foods and food plants, the National\nReference Center identified a strain with the same characteristics as the\noutbreak strain. This strain had been isolated from an unopened package of\nspreadable sausage produced by a manufacturer in eastern France. Of the 7\npatients for whom this information was available, 5 reported having eaten\nthis type of product.\nOn 2 Jul 2002, the manufacturer recalled this spreadable sausage product.\nOn 3 Jul 2002, all pork products from this manufacturer were withdrawn from\nthe market. These products include different meat products sold under the\nbrand names Stoeffler, Dulano, and Claude Leger, and specific supermarket\nchain brands. All these products bear the establishment number 67-348-02.\nOn the same day, a notification was sent to all member states of the\nEuropean Union through the Rapid Alert System For Food (RASFF). Analysis of\nexport distribution channels for the products is continuing.\nConsumers have been advised to throw away the affected products, or return\nthem to the point of purchase. Since the risk of developing listeria\ninfection after eating a contaminated product is very low, people who have\neaten the implicated product have been informed that they do not need any\nspecial medical evaluation or treatment, even if they are in high risk\ngroups. Nevertheless, people have been advised that if they develop fever\n(or fever accompanied by headache) within 2 months of eating the product,\nthey should consult a doctor, and inform him or her about this exposure.\nCase surveillance is continuing. Because of the [potentially - Mod.LL] long\nincubation period (between 4 days and as long as 2 months [or more -\nMod.LL]), cases may continue to occur and be reported for several weeks\nafter a thorough product recall.\nThe role of food in transmission of listeriosis in humans was established\nin the 1980s, when around 1000 new cases were seen in France each year.\nSubsequent changes made in agriculture and the food industry have reduced\nthe annual number of cases to under 300.\n[Translated and adapted by Elizabeth Hoile (eurowkly@phls.org.uk),\nEurosurveillance editorial office]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This cluster of listeriosis demonstrates, once again, that (1) sporadic\ncases of the disease can be linked to others by aggressive epidemiological\ninvestigations; and (2) the widespread marketing of a prepared food product\nis an excellent method of spreading enteric pathogens. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The coordinating committee for listeria investigations was mobilized to\ncoordinate investigations, which included the obtaining of food histories\nof cases, the analysis of the supply channels of products on sale in shops\nwhere the patients had bought food in order to identify common suppliers,\nsampling of foods from these shops and from the patients' refrigerators,\nand screening for the epidemic clone among strains isolated from food\nproducts in France since January 2002. \nA cluster of 8 cases of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infection with the same\nserotype and pulsed field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) profile has been\nidentified by the surveillance scheme operated by the Institut de Veille\nSanitaire (National Institute for Health Surveillance) and the National\nListeria Reference Center at the Institut Pasteur, Paris, since 29 May 2002. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Translated and adapted by Elizabeth Hoile (eurowkly@phls.org.uk),\nEurosurveillance editorial office]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Since the risk of developing listeria\ninfection after eating a contaminated product is very low, people who have\neaten the implicated product have been informed that they do not need any\nspecial medical evaluation or treatment, even if they are in high risk\ngroups. [This cluster of listeriosis demonstrates, once again, that (1) sporadic\ncases of the disease can be linked to others by aggressive epidemiological\ninvestigations; and (2) the widespread marketing of a prepared food product\nis an excellent method of spreading enteric pathogens. Five of the 8 cases\nwere from 2 departments (Moselle and Bas-Rhin) in eastern France, and the\nothers are in 3 different departments [see map of cases on the\nEurosurveillance Weekly website - Mod. Seven of these 8 patients presented with infection of the central\nnervous system and 1 with bacteremia; 5 patients had underlying medical\nconditions or were being treated with immunosuppressants, and so were at\nrisk for listeriosis. Among its\ncollection of strains isolated from foods and food plants, the National\nReference Center identified a strain with the same characteristics as the\noutbreak strain. The first 2 strains were isolated in week 22 (27 May-2 June), 2 more were\nisolated in week 23 (3-9 June), and 4 were isolated in week 24 (10-16\nJune). Nevertheless, people have been advised that if they develop fever\n(or fever accompanied by headache) within 2 months of eating the product,\nthey should consult a doctor, and inform him or her about this exposure. Source: Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6(27): 020704 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020704.html>\n\nCluster of listeriosis cases in France\n These products include different meat products sold under the\nbrand names Stoeffler, Dulano, and Claude Leger, and specific supermarket\nchain brands. Subsequent changes made in agriculture and the food industry have reduced\nthe annual number of cases to under 300.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-01-26 00:00:00", "2003-06-09 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2002-07-03 00:00:00", "2002-05-29 00:00:00", "2002-07-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}]}]}], "listeriosis_num_of_articles": "238"}
